title: THEODORE STEMMLER
description: Theodore W. Stemmler, a retired New York investment banker and consulting engineer, died Saturday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 88 years old and lived also at 730 park Avenue.

title: Our Uncle Is Now Dorian Sam
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The odd thing is not that we are in the business of overthrowing other peoples' governments, but that we can still be surprised when somebody reminds us of it. In Asia, Latin America, Africa, the Mediterranean and the Middle East we have been propping up and knocking down governments more or less openly for the last 25 years.

title: The Proceedings the U.N. Today Oct, 1, 1974
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. to hear Grenada, Czechoslovakia, Syria, Tanzania, Cyprus, Liberia, Egypt, Southern Yemen, Mauritania, Luxembourg (tentative) and Colombia.

title: 7 Die in Suspicious Fire In Chicago Rooming House
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (UPI)Seven persons were killed last. night when a flash fire ripped through a rooming house above a South Side tavern. Two persons were injured.

title: RAIL PENSIONS BILL GOES TO PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Congress finished work today on a $7,1billion railroad retirement financial reorganization bill and sent it to President Ford.

title: Doc Medich and Pennant Trauma
description: About two weeks ago George (Doc) Medich of the New York Yankees phoned Mrs. Trudy Barris, the assistant to the associate dean for student affairs at the University of Pittsburgh Medical School.

title: Walton Arrives With Huckleberry Look
description: Looking like a 6foot11inch Huckleberry Finn, Bill Walton gave the world of pro basketball a glimpse into his lifestyle yesterday.

title: STUDY IN COLLEGE REPORTED LONGER
description: A survey of students throughout the country who entered college in 1961 and 1966 shows that it apparently is far more common than was previously believed for students to take longer than four years to earn a degree.

title: $1Million Lottery Numbers
description: The five qualifying numbers were picked yesterday for New York State's $1million lottery drawing on Oct, 14. The numbers are: 403773, 512766, 251602, 228528, 935570. Holders of those numbers have until Oct, 12 to register at any lottery office in the state for the $1million drawing. They are guaranteed $10,000, no matter how they fare in that drawing.

title: Kidnapping Charges Dropped Against Suspect in Ohio
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 30 (UPI)  Kidnapping charges against Frank J. Wiechman, held for six days in connection with the abduction of the 4yearold daughter of Charles S. Mechem Jr., Taft broadcasting company board chairman, were dropped today and Mr. Wiechman was released.

title: Tentative Accord Reached In American Motors Strike
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 30 (AP)  The American Motors Corporation, the fourth largest automobile in the United States, and the United Automobile Workers announced a tentative agreement tonight on new contract, ending a twoweek strike.

title: Laurel Considers 6 U.S. Horses
description: LAUREL, Md., Sept. 30 (UPI)Elmendorf Farm's Big Spruce, the winner of the Marlboro Cup in New York two weeks ago, and Harry T. Mangurian's Desert Vixen, a leading filly, head a list of six American thoroughbreds which the Laurel race track president, John D. Schapiro is considering for invitations to the Washington D. C. International to be run here Nov. 9.

title: Strike Ends at C.M. Delco Unit; Ford and Chrysler Layoffs Set
description: DETROIT, Sept. 30 (UPI)A major strike that jeopardized production of the General Motors Corporation ended today, but another strike forced the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation to lay off 24,550 assembly line workers. Chrysler said it would close another plant next Monday and idle an additional 9,300 workers.

title: SENATE, 57 TO 20, VOTES TO CUT OFF U.S. AID TO TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Senate voted tonight to cut off military aid to Turkey.

title: ICED GETS VOICE IN CUSTODY SUITS
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30A legislative measure that would guarantee the right of a child to express a choice between living with a father or a mother in a legal matrimonial proceeding received final legislative approval here this evening in the Assembly by a vote of 65 to 1.

title: Mrs. Carner Wins By 3 in Portland
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 29 (AP)Joanne Carner, aided by an eagle on the seventh hole, won her sixth tournament this year with a threestroke victory today over Donna Caponi Young in the $35,000 Portland Golf Classic. Mrs. Carner finished eight under par with a 71211.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1974

title: Wilson, Taking Offensive, Calls Senator Krupsak Soft on Crime
description: In his most slashing attack of the campaign so far, Governor Wilson charged yesterday that State Senator Mary Anne Krupsak, the Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, was soft on crime and had voted for dirty books and dirty pictures.

title: Case of Missing Goal Posts Could Cause Rules Change
description: Eastern college football teams will be requested to provide an extra set of goal posts at all future home games after an incident that resulted in the 66 tie between Princeton and Rutgers last Saturday. Princeton was unable to attempt a kick for the extra point in the closing seconds of the bizarre game at Princeton because fans had scored the tying touchgoal posts before the Tigers had scored the tying touchdown.

title: ABC Evening News With Captions for Deaf on PBS
description: In the profitoriented world of commercial television, it is unusual for one network to donate a program to, another.

title: Advertising
description: Over in the Seagram Building on Park Avenue, there's a young man who is betting heavily that the economic crunch isn't going to hurt sales of the country's top. selling premium Scotch and that a good increase in its advertsing budget will push the sales to new heights.

title: Socialist Workers Say Democrats Try To Block Petitions
description: ALBANY, Sept. 30The Socialist Workers party candidate for United States Senator contended today that the leadership of the state Democratic party was behind an attempt to remove, her party's candidates from the ballot in the Nov. 5 election.

title: Film Festival: 'Lancelot':A Bresson 'Spectacle' Inspired by Malory
description: It's said that at one time or another every film director yearns to make a spectacle, one of those multimillion-dollar epics with lots of horses, costumes and extras, the sort of film that has to be directed from a raised platform with an electronic voice-magnifying system. To the extent that "Lancelot of the Lake" has horses, costumes and extras (a few), and to the extent that it's inspired by some of the tales in Malory's "Morte D'arthur," it may be called Robert Bresson's spectacle, but it's unlike any conventional film spectacle, you've ever seen.The film, which was shown last night at Alice Tully Hall in the New York Film Festival, will be repeated Thursday evening."Lancelot of The Lake" is about the last days of King Arthur's Round Table when, after the bloody, fruitless quest for the Holy Grail, the knights return to a fading Camelot and fall out among one another.The age of chivalry is over but no one knows why. Arthur suspects that God has been provoked. He urges his knights to forget their enmities and to better themselves.Lancelot, who once was allowed a vision of the Grail, thinks God is punishing them all for his being Guinevere's lover. When he asks her to release him from his vows to her and to surrender to God, she refuses. "If I surrender," she says, "it will be to you not God."Although Mr. Bresson ("Diary of a Country Priest," "Au Hazard, Balthazar," "La Femme Douce," etc.) is not especially interested in visual spectacle, he has made a stunning-looking movie that often pares down spectacle to what seems to be an irreducible minimum. Virtually an entire tournament is photographed with the camera's eye focused between the horse's hoofs and midsection.Mr. Bresson once said that the true calling of cinema "is first to be exact, and then to be interior  rather than exterior or decorative.""Lancelot" could never be called decorative, but it is sometimes breathtaking in its exterior details, which is not the same as being realistic. The concluding sequence of the film, after chivalry's final upheaval, is one of the most beautiful and strange the director has ever done:A riderless horse charges aimlessly through a twilight forest as the world's last knight, wounded and dying, staggers slowly toward the bodies of other armor-clad knights. It looks simultaneously mysterious, like the remains of the civilization on another planet, and banal, like a pile of damaged gasoline pumps.What's missing from the film is any urgent interior meaning, and this it may be because of the distractions of the exterior details. It may also be because the conflicts that rage within Lancelot  between duty and desire, courtly love and physical love  simply aren't complex enough to bring out the best in Mr. Bresson. There are times, too, when the armor seems to get in the way of ideas or any sense of passion. There's something essentially comic about the sight of a knight impetuously trying to tear off his gear for a quick roll in the loft.As usual in a Bresson film, the actors are unknowns or nonprofessionals, chosen by the director for their faces and their willingness to be drilled into that state of somnambulance by which he is best able to create his interior visions.Laura Duke Condominas is a lovely, young, girlish Guinevere, who is both passionate and demanding. Luc Simon also looks right as a Lancelot who is no longer young, and whose trials have given a firm set to ascetic features that, in youth, would have seemed soft.In "Lancelot of the Lake," which the director first announced in 1957, the style is intact but the content is missing.

title: A Career Man and a Racing Buff
description: A former accountant and bookkeeper who made good at General Motors, the company's new chairman has spent almost 37 of his 58 years on G.M.'s financial staff and became the frontrunner to succeed the retiring Richard C. Gerstenberg when he was named vice chairman in December, 1971 ... Known as a straighttothepoint executive with a reserved disposition ... Yet he has what close associates call a quick Irish wit ... Joined G.M. at 22, late in comparison with top officials ... Spent his early youth in Buffalo and later went to the St. Leo High School, Chicago, and then to the University of Illinois ... Became treasurer of G.M. in 1968, 31 years after joining company, rising two years later to vice president and truckandcar group executive ... The parents of three children, he and his wife, the former Catherine Maguire, have a home in Bloomfield Hills, near Detroit, and an apartment here on Sutton Place.

title: WATERGATE TRIAL WILL BEGIN TODAY FOR 5 DEFENDANTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Judge John J. Sirica cleared the way today for the start of the Watergate coverup trial tomorrow at 9:30 A.M. in Federal District Court by severing the case of a defendant whose prosecution had become involved in a legal tangle.

title: Aid Endangered
description: The Ford Administration has chosen to risk two of most urgent foreign economic programs rather than tolerate a modestand probably ineffectiveCongressional effort to limit Presidential discretion in the disbursal of foreign aid funds.

title: Amnesty Plan Accepted By Only 70 Deserters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)  The Defense Department said today that only 70 deserters had volunteered so far to take part in President Ford's amnesty program.

title: Dr. Edward Frey, Led Unit On Lutheran Architecture
description: The Rev. Dr. Edward S. Frey, who retired in April as head of the Commission on Church Architecture of the Lutheran Church in America, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home at 120 Adams Avenue, River Edge, N. J.

title: Eastland for Action To Curb Marijuana
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)  Chairman James O. Eastland of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee said today that if the current rate of marijuana use continued, Americans might find themselves saddled with a large population of semizombies.

title: Redskins Trounce Broncos
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Washington Redskins 30, Denver Broncos 3.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Delmarva Power and Light Company has joined the growing ranks of utilities that are cutitng back their expansion plans. The company said yesterday at its Wilmington, Del., headquarters that it planned to reduce electric construction outlays by $7.5million and those for gas by $2million for the balance of this year. Next year it will cut electric outlays by $37million and from 1976 through 1978 an additional $72.5million will either be eliminated or postponed.

title: BOGUS POLICE GET $195,000 IN JEWELS
description: A Jewelry salesman was robbed yesterday of jewels valued at $195,000 by two armed men, one of whom was wearing a police uniform, the police said.

title: AMERICAN BRANDS SETS ACQUISITION
description: American Brands, Inc., a conglomerate engaged in production and sales of tobacco, food, spirits, office equipment, and other products, announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Marvel Lighting Corporation for $17.5million in cash plus an additional undisclosed amount to be based on earnings over the next five years.

title: Pincay, in Hot Seat, Wins 5 at Belmont
description: Laffit Pincay keeps winning at Belmont Park and, apparently, the fans don't believe it. The Panamanian rider, who is hopeful of reaching the $4million mark in earnings this year, came through with five winners on yesterday's card, and four of his prices were hardly insignificant.

title: A Federal Law to Curb Dogfighting Is Urged at a Congressional Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Humane groups and law enforcement officials asked Congress today for legislation to curb the growing problem of dogfighting and attendant gambling and other illegalities.

title: Carved Toys That Have a Touch of Humor
description: At the age of 10, Antonio Vitali became interested in woodcarving. Now 55 years later, the Italianhorn Swiss designer is still putting this talent to use, creating wooden toys for children.

title: Sports Center Plan For 57th St. to Go Before City Board
description: A sports and recreation center proposed some months ago for Seventh Avenue and 57th Street will be considered by the City Planning Commission on Oct. 16.

title: WATERGATE TRIAL WILL BEGIN TODAY FOR 5 DEFENDAND
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Judge John J. Sirica cleared the way today for the start of the Watergate coverup trial tomorrow at 9:30 A.M. in Federal District Court by severing the case of a defendant whose prosecution had become involved in a legal tangle.

title: Ethiopia Drops 2 Generals From New Command Posts
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethopia, Sept. 30 (Reuters)Ethiopia's military rulers tonight rescinded the appointment of two generals to top posts, causing speculation that there was a power struggle in the military council running the country.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Asians and Africans living on the periphery of the Indian Ocean are indeed very grateful to U.S. Senator Charles H. Percy, who, while on a recent twoweek visit to the subcontinent, suggested that President Ford put off for at least one year the recent announcement to expand the U.S. military bases on the island of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean. The intention of going ahead with this project was affirmed at the first news conference held by President Ford.

title: New Chief in Lisbon
description: LISBON, Sept. 30  Gen. Francisco da Costa Gomes has become President of Portugal almost by default. void had to be filled after the suddent resignation of Gen. Antnio de Spnola today and, in a country dominated by the military, that void was naturally filled by the highest military man of all.

title: Chamberlain, 38, Rehires; Basketball's Top Scorer
description: Wilt Chamberlain, the most controversial and prolific scorer in pro basketball history, will announce his retirement this week.

title: Judge's Aide Slain
description: Burr C. Hollister, 32, law secretary to a State Supreme Court justice, was found murdered in a court building in Mineola, L. I. Page 45.

title: United Parcel Strike Here Lifts U.S. ParcelPost Activity 25%
description: The United States Postal Service estimated yesterday that it had been handling 25 per cent more parcel post in its Northeastern region during the United Parcel Service strike, which started last Aug. 28.

title: Eabor Again Talks of Democrats Gaining More Than 40 Seats in House Elections
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Organized labor has muted its trumpets on the theme of a vetoproof Congress  a springtime slogan that Republicans, led by thenVice President Ford, turned into a threat of legislative dictatorship.

title: Major Accused of Taking Bribes To Help 400, Avoid Army Duty
description: A 45yearold Army major assigned to the Selective Serv ice headquarters in Manhatta?? was accuse'd yesierday in a Fed eral indictment of having ac cepted $50,000 In bribes in a?? alleged scheme to help 400 me?? evade the draft or get out ?? service between 1968 and 1972The major,. William Sangemi?? no, who lives at Fort Hamilto?? in Brooklyn, was charged with conspiracy to defraud the United States, bribery and perjury If convicted, he faces a maximum prison sentence of 25 years as well as fines.

title: TV: Torpid View of American Dream
description: The point of National Town Meetings, a new series carried Sundays at 4:30 P.M. on the Public Broadcasting Service, is to rekindle the spirit of participatory democracy in the United States. The first installment, considering the question Whatever Happened to the American Dream? persistently stayed beside the point.

title: Raymond Schmittein, 70, Dies; Won Soviet Aid for Free French
description: PARIS Sept. 30 (AP)Raymond Schmittlein, who negotiated the recognition of the Free French forces by the Soviet Union, died yesterday in a Colmar hospital. He was 10 years old.

title: 19 Food Places Get Notices of Violations Of City Health Code
description: The Health Department has released the names of 19 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

title: SPINOLA RESIGNS AND LEFTISTS GAIN CONTROL IN LISBON
description: LISBON, Sept. 30President Antnio de Spnola who assumed the leadership of Portugal's democratic revolution five months ago, resigned unexpectedly today with a warning that the country was heading toward chaos and new forms of slavery.

title: Carey Would End Crangle's State Job
description: ALBANY, Sept. 30Guiding his running mates from one jubilant crowd of Democrats to another, Representative Hugh L. Carey promised today to remove his party's state chairman from the state government payroll if the public elected a Democratic ticket.

title: Carey Rejects FrontRunner Role; Strengthens Campaign Organization
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey often finds himself these days gazing at questioners with honest eyes of Irish blue and explaining why he should not be regarded as the favorite in the race for the governorship.

title: 47 Key Districts On List of Labor
description: Following are the 47 Congressional districts where the A.F.L.C.I.O.'s Committee on Political Education has targeted Republican incumbents for highpriority challenge in the November election. Democratic challengers are listed first and the Republican incumbents are second.

title: Senate Watergate Panel Officially Ends Existence
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) The Senate Watergate committee, its mission over and its files closed, officially went out of business today, 19 months after it was created by the Senate.

title: BRIDGET D. CONNORTON
description: Bridget Della Connorton, widow of Patrick Connorton and mother of Dr. John V. Connorton, a former Deputy Mayor, died Sunday in the Mary Manning Walsh Home. She was 83 years old.

title: Pincay, in Hot Seat, Wins 5 at Belmont
description: Laffit Pincay keeps winning at Belmont Park and, apparently, the fans don't believe it. The Panamanian rider, who is hopeful of reaching the $4million mark in earnings this year, came through with five winners on yesterday's card, and four of his prices were hardly insignificant.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: South Africa Is Arresting Black Militants
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Afrim, Sept. 30Government Security curity officials have initiated what appears to be a crackdown on militant black political activity in this whiteruled country.

title: CHARGE ANNOUNCED BY RESORTS CONCERN
description: Resorts International, Inc., announced yesterday that it had made a charge of about $25.2million against earnings for the nine months ended Sept. 30, which will also affect accumulated retained earnings. This results from a reduction in Value of its investment in Pan American World Airways, Inc.

title: AFFECTION CITED AS KIDNAP MOTIVE
description: RUTHERFORD, Sept. 30The father of George Kaloyerakis, the 7yearold victim of a kidnapping on Sept. 22, said today that he believed his son had been abducted by Thomas V. Burns, 23, of Rutherford, because he was afraid he would not be permitted to see the boy. any more.

title: Cynthia Gregory to Dance in Cuba
description: Cynthia Gregory, one of the country's leading young ballerinas and a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater, plans to dance in Cuba near month. She will be the first major American artist to perform there since Washington and Havana broke off diplomatic relations in 1961.

title: Berlin Success Story
description: BERLINThe one piece of encouraging news that can be reported from a Europe heading into a winter of discontentmarked by inflation, social tension and political instabilityis that West Berlin is alive and well and still prospering a hundred miles inside Communist East Germany.

title: Chou, After Illness, Reappears at Peking Fete
description: PEKING, Sept. 30 (Reuters) Premier Chou Enlai made his first major public appearance in two months tonight at a reception marking the 25th anniversary tomorrow of Commoist rule in China.

title: A.&P. HAS PROFIT, AGAINST 73 LOSS
Half a Million Army Ants Are the Stars Of Exhibit at Natural History Museum
description: When Howard R. Topoff flew to Panama recently, he took along a 50pound generator hooked to a household vacuum cleaner. After 10 days of sweeping, Mr. Topoff and his assistant, Raymond Mendez, returned last week from the tropics with their mission accomplished: The half million army ants they vacuumed up are now on view at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Thermal and Natomas Sued Over Merger
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30Smoldering controversy over the proposed merger of the Thermal Power Company and the Natomas Company, both bf San Francisco, flared into legal action today when one of a number of disgruntled brokers and stockholders filed a class action suit in Superior Court here.

title: State Senate Votes Bill Curbing Migrant Leaders
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30A bill imposing stringent regulations on crew leaders hired by farmers to oversee the state's 20,000 migrant workers received final passage in the Senate today by a vote of 31 to 0.

title: Army Files Appeal Asking That Calley Be Kept in Prison
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 30 (AP)The Army asked a Federal Appeals Court today to order that William L. Calley Jr. be kept in prison pending an appeal of a judge's order that he be freed.

title: WILLIAM C. TRAPNELL
description: William C. Trapnell, who retired in 1971 as senior vice president, secretary and treasurer of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia, died yesterday in a hospital in Portland, Me. He was 68 years old and lived at High Knob, Front Royal, Va.

title: SENATOR'S REPORT HELD MISLEADING
description: Supreme Court Justice Harold Baer, speaking for the court, yesterday described as misleading a report issued by State Senator Ralph J. Marino that cited 67 illegal discharges of narcotics defendants following a change in the law in 1969.

title: Queens Road Wafts Slated
description: The Manhattan bound lanes of the QueensMidtown Expressway, which leads into the QueensMidtown Tunnel, will be closed today, tomorrow and Thursday night for resurfacing, the Transportation Administration announced yesterday. The repaving involves a milelong stretch of the roadway. One Manhattanbound lane will be closed at 7 P.M. and the two others at 11 P.M. All three lanes will be reopened at 5 A.M.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Control StorageTank Construction
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30 (AP)The State Senate passed and sent to the Assembly today a bill to establish state regulation over the construction of storage tanks for volatile and flammable materials.

title: Standard Time Voted
description: The Senate passed and sent to President Ford a bill to return the nation to standard time for four months, from Sunday, Oct. 27, to Sunday, Feb. 23, 1975. Page 81.

title: The Revival of a FashionAnd Lingerie Land Is Puzzled
description: Women's lib isn't going to like it at all. No sooner has pantyhose freed women from contrivances to hold up their stockings, than some people have started a return to garter belts.

title: JAIL TERM RISKED BY DRAFT EVADER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30William Meis; a 29yearold draft evader who says he lived for seven years in Montreal, said today that he would surrender to a United States Attorney this week and risk a prison sentence in protest against President Ford's conditional amnesty program.

title: Oil Price Dip in Kuwait May End Up as Increase
description: Uncertainty over world crude oil prices continues, with Kuwait announcing yesterday a price decrease that many experts think may actually turn out to be an increase for the consumer.

title: A Dream Miscarries
description: The Federal Government's brave experiment in guaranteeing a basic minimum income for the needy aged, blind and disabled is bringing increased hardship and despairinstead of the promised dignityto hundreds of thousands in New York and other states.

title: ThirdDown Weakness Hurts Jets
description: They just were more physical than us, Coach Charley Winner observed yesterday, after viewing films of the Jets' 1612 loss to the Bills on Sunday in Buffalo.

title: RAISE IN MEDICAID BACKED BY ALBANY
description: The state's Budget Director yesterday approved a $100million increase in Medicaid payments to healthcare facilities through the state for fiscal year 1975 retroactive to Sept. 1. The package increase is expected to result in a $45million bonus for the city's financially ailing Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1974

title: Concert
description: Jens Nygaard is, a pianista superior onewho in the last few seasons has been the impresario of what might be called the Floating Chamber Music Society. This season, for instance, Music with Jens Nygaard will be giving a series at Carnegie Recital Hall, at the Lincoln Center Library, at CAMI Hall, in Westchester and in Washington Heights, a total of 25 concerts. That alone would make Mr. Nygaard's work worth paying atterttion to.

title: Busing Foes and Backers Stage Protests in Boston
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) Opponents and supporters of busing staged demonstrations today and attendance at two racially troubled high schools increased substantially as Boston entered its third full week of courtordered school integration.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: The high school football season had not yet begun last week when Coach John Chironna of Morristown was shortening his practices, a tactic usually employed later in the season when teams require less time to maintain precision.

title: Democrats to Meet in Effort To End a Rift Over Minorities
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Democratic party factions that have been warring most of the summer about minority participation in party affairs will meet here Oct. 10, hoping to resolve their differences before the Democratic charter conference in Kansas City in December.

title: 123 HOTEL CLOSING DENIED BY OWNER
description: Seymour B. Durst, owner of the 123 Hotel, at 123 West 44th Street, said yesterday that they hotel would remain open despite an announcement earlier by the operator that he planned to abandon it today.

title: JOSEPH SHURE
description: Joseph Shure, a senior vice president and director of Bache & Co., stockbrokers, and resident manager of its New Haven office, died yesterday of a. heart attack in Woodbridge, Conn., where he lived. He was 68 years old.

title: Hrs. Ford Facing Tests To Determine Treatment
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 30.Betty Ford's physicians reported today that they had found cancer cells in two of the 30 lymph nodes removed with her right breast last Saturday.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Colt Owner Plays Executioner's Role
description: It was Robert (Tiger) Irsay, the redhaired owner, who dismissed Howard Schnellenberger, coach of the Baltimore Colts, on Sunday and not Joe Thomas, the team's general manager, who had become accustomed to terminating the employment of Colt players and coaches. In fact Irsay shocked Thomas, who is 53 years old and had open heart surgery three years ago, by immediately naming him as interim coach of a team which has little chance to achieve a winning record this season.

title: SENATE, 57 TO 20, VOTES TO CUT OFF US, AID TO TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Senate Voted tonight to cut off militarifid to Turkey.

title: 5 on Gas Tank Begin Vigil For Prisoners in Vietnam
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 30 (UPI)  Five protesters, affiliated with a group headed by Philip F. Berrigan, the former priest and antiwar leader, scaled a 254foot natural gas storage tank today and unfurled banners proclaiming an international week of concern for political prisoners in South Vietnam.

title: A NEW CANDIDATE SET IN CAROLINA
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 30Representative William Jennings Bryan Dorn was chosen today to replace Clfarles D. Ravenel as the Democratic nominee for Governor of South Carolina.

title: $300Million RoadRail Bonds Approved by Jersey Legislature
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30A $30million bond issue for highway construction and railroads cleared the Legislature this evening by 59 to 15.

title: Javits and Pell Find Castro Friendly
description: HAVANA, Sept. 30Senators Jacob K. Javits and Claiborne Pell flew back to Washington today to report on a total of 10 hours of talks with Premier Fidel Castro and other Cuban leaders about improving relations between the United States and Cuba.

title: Connecticut to Bar Funds If Antiabortion Bill Passes
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 30 (AP)If Congress votes to prohibit the use of Federal funds for nontherapeutic abortions, the Connecticut Welfare Department will do the same, Commissioner Nicholas Norton said today.

title: Ottawa Outlines Budget Program to Control Inflation
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 30  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Irudeau's new Government, bolstered by a strong parliamentary majority won in the July elections, outlined today a legislative program concentrating on control of inflation through restraints on spending and the expansion of production.

title: WILSON CRITICIZES SENATOR KRUPSAK
description: In his most slashing attack of the campaign so far, Governor Wilson charged yesterday that State Senator Mary Anne Krupsak, the Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, was soft on crime and had voted for dirty books and dirty pictures.

title: FARM PRICES DROP BY 2% IN A MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Prices of raw farm products dropped 2 per cent from Aug. 15 to Sept. 15, marking the first decline since last spring, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Ford to Explain Pardon in Person to House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30President Ford said tonight that he would appear personally before a House subcommittee within the next 10 days to answer a series of questions about his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Villemure Suspended By Rangers
description: Gilles Villemure, the Rangers' No. 2 goalie, may not be aware of it yet, but he was suspended last night by Emile Francis, the team's nononsense coach and general manager, for failing to appear at the Rangers' game with the Detroit Red Wings in Madison Square Garden.

title: Bill Sets Bilingual Trials
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill providing for simultaneous translation of Federal court proceedings involving citizens who do not speak English.

title: Police Officer Is Injured By a Crowd in Queens
description: A 26yearold police officer suffered a broken arm yesterday afternoon when he was reportedly first surrounded by a crowd of about 50 people and then pushed to the sidewalk while he was arresting a man later charged with breaking windows in the Jamaica section of Queens.

title: People and Business
description: George Meany, the crusty president of the American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organizations, has more than once indicated his dissatisfaction with Washington's economic policies. But last week he really broke loose.

title: LEONARDO'S NOTES EXCITE SCHOLA??
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The discovery of two Leonard?? da Vinci notebooks, some 5?? pages of which go on exhibition here tomorrow, has provided a gold mine of new information on the history of mechanics, according to a leading d?? Vinci scholar.

title: Huarte Doubtful Starter
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 30 (AP)John Huarte has not fully recovered from a leg injury and the Memphis quarterback probably will miss the Southmen's World Football League game against the Jacksonville Sharks Wednesday night, Coach John McVay said.

title: Two Women Die in Fire
description: FITCHBURG, Mass., Sept. 30 (AP)Two women were killed and a man was injured today in an apartment house fire. The dead women, both residents of the building, were Ethel Lyle, 39 years old, and her sister, Harriet Graves, 50. Harvey Aker, 54, was reported in fair condition, hospitalized for smoke inhalation.

title: Villemure Suspended By Rangers
description: Gilles Villemure, the Rangers' No. 2 goalie, may not be aware of it yet, but he was suspended last night by Emile Francis, the team's nononsense coach and general manager, for failing to appear at the Rangers' game with the Detroit Red Wings in Madison Square Garden.

title: Hurricane Watch Ends
description: MIAMI, Sept. 30 (UPI)A hurricane watch was dropped today for the Windward Islands after Hurricane Gertrude lost force over the western Atlantic Ocean and was downgraded to a tropical storm.

title: Welfare Youth Get Health Tests Texas Says 36% Need More Aid
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 30 Paramedical workers for the Texas State Health Department are finding that more than one of three welfare children they examine have signs of medical problems, with a surprising number with indications of lead poisoning.

title: SPINOLA RESIGNS AND LEFTISTS GAIN CONTROL IN LISBON
description: LISBON, Sept. 30President Antonio de Spinola who assumed the leadership of Portugal's democratic revolution five months ago, resigned unexpectedly today with a warning that the country was heading toward chaos and new forms of slavery.

title: Simmons Clout With 2 on Tops Expos, 51
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 30 The St. Louis Cardinals left the country today but still kept pace with the Pittsburgh Pirates by defeating the Montreal Expos, 5.1. With the Pirates also winning, the two teams remained deadlocked for first place in the National League East, with each having two games left.

title: BREZHNEV PUSHING WORLD RED TALKS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30Leonid I. Brezhnev and the Hungarian Communist leader, Janos Radar, ended six days of talks today with a pledge to take practical steps toward holding regional party meetings leading up to a world Communist conference.

title: FARM PRICES DROP BY 20 IN A MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Prices of raw farm products dropped 2 per cent from Aug. 15 to Sept. 15, marking the first decline since last spring, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: China 25 Years After: Pride and Anxiety,
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 30The statistics come in a torrent, too rapidly to be absorbed: industrial production in Shanghai since 1949 has undergone a 17fold increase, including a 12fold increase in the production of bicycles; output of iron ore and petroleum are both 150 times greater; production of food grains, more than doubled; tap water in the city of Swatow, up 12 times; secondary school students, 24 times as many, and the income of the families of 24 former ricksha pullers in Peking, 840 per centall in the quarter of a century since Liberation.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The executive committee of the National Book Committee, which oversees the National Book Awards, is to engage energetically in fundraising attempts during the next month, John C. Frantz reported yesterday.

title: $10,000 Taken in Holdup
description: BROOKLINE. Mass., Sept. 30 (AP)  Two armed men took $10,000 and escaped by car today from the Blue Hill Credit Union here. Myer Finkel, manager of the credit union, said that 10 customers and 10 employes had heen there at the time of the robbery, but that no one was hurt.

title: LEGAL AID STAFF ENDS STRIKE TODAY
description: Legal Aid Society lawyers, citing hardships to their clients and economic losses to themelves, decided last night to end their 20day strike and return to work today.

title: People in Sports Braves Grant King TwoYear Contract
description: Clyde King's contract as manager of the Atlanta Braves has been extended through the 1976 season. The softspoken King had been named interim pilot of the National League club on July 24, relieving Eddie Mathews. He has guided. the Braves to a 3624 wonlost record since taking over and the club clinched third place in. the Western Division, its best finish since 1969. We hope we can strengthen our, team in a couple of spots, said King. We feel we don't need too many new faces to make is a contender. Our main need is for a righthanded power hitter and one or two more lefthanded pitchers. . . . The Houston Astros rehired Preston Gomez as manager for the 1975 season. Gomez is one of the hardestworking managers I've ever been associated with, said H. B. Richardson, general manager of the National League club. It's not his. fault, or his coaching staff, the Astros didn't do better in 1974.

title: INFLATION FEARS DEPRESS BONDS
description: Corporate bonds fell in price yesterday under the pressure of a heavy offering calendar and renewed fears over inflation.

title: Senate Votes Return to Standard Time For Four Months and Sends Bill to Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Senate agreed today by voice vote to end yearround daylight saving time and put the nation back on standard time for four months.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SMILE OF RECOGNITION To readers of The New Yorker, few cartoon styles are as familiar as that of Whitney Darrow Jr., who has been producing drawings for that magazine for four decades. The amazing thing about Mr. Darrow's cartoons is that his humor and whimsey have never changed. even though the fads he makes fun of have gone. through changes that might have left other cultural observers confused and sourtempered.

title: LEGAL AID STAFF ENDS STRIKE TODAY
description: Legal Aid Society lawyers, citing hardships to their clients and economic losses to themselves, decided last night to end their 20day strike and return to work today.

title: New York Lottery Winners
description: The five qualifying numbers were picked yesterday for New York State's $1million lottery drawing on Oct. 4. The numbers are: 403773, 512766, 251602, 228528, 935570. Holders of those numbers have until Oct. 12 to register at any lottery office in the state for the $1million drawing. They are guaranteed $10,000, no matter how they fare in that drawing.

title: Soviet Dissident Is Asking Swiss for Political Asylum
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 130 (AP)  A Soviet religious writer, Anatoly Levitin, who left on a visa to emigrate to Israel, has asked for political asylum in Switzerland, the police reported today.

title: Books of The Times
description: SOMETHING HAPPENED. By Joseph Heller. 569 pages. Knopf. $10.

title: GLOOM DOMINATES MEETING OF I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The heads of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund presented today worried views of the world economic situation for both rich and poor nations as the two institutions opened their annual meeting.

title: Friends of Haldeman Seek Funds From Wealthy Persons and Politicians for His Defense
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 Friends and associates of H. R. Haldeman here have been quietly soliciting persons Mans and some national political figures, most unknown personally to the former White House chief of staff, in an attempt to raise legal defense funds for Mr. Haldeman's forthcoming trial.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION RISES 0.5% IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Sept. 28 edged ahead by 0.5 per cent to 2,774,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This raised the weekly production index to 113.7 from the 113.1 level of a week ago when a total of 2,759,000 tons of steel was poured.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS GET U.N. REBUFF
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30The General Assembly today rejected the credentials of the South African delegation and called on the Security Council to review the relationship between the United Nations and South Africa.

title: U.S.State Program To Widen Medicaid For Newark Gains
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Nearly half the population of Newark would be eligible for Government medical assistance under the terms of a bill adopted today by the State Senate, according to one reliable estimate.

title: VERGARI IS SCORED ON GRAFT INQUIRY
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 30Joel Arnou, a White Plains lawyer, charged today that his Republican opponent, District Attorney Carl A. Vergari, had manipulated vital investigative information to enhance his own political future.

title: Envoy Turned Back In Attempt to Aid Dominican Captives
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 30The American Ambassador attempted to take mattresses Into the Venezuelan Consulate here for the seven hostages who have been held there since Friday. But he was turned away by the guerrillas who have seized the building.

title: President Described as Cool to Higher Gasoline Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30President Ford does not favor an increase in the Federal sales tax on gasoline but is not, unalterably opposed to such an increase, White House officials said today.

title: Danbury Paper Going to 20c
description: DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 50 (UPI)The newsstand price of the Danbury New Times will go from 15 cents to 20 cents a copy on Oct. 20, while the weekly home delivery rate will rise from $1.05 to $1.30. The New York Times, with a circulation of 36,000 daily and 35,400 on Sundays, is the first newspaper in the state to rains its newstand price to 20 cents.

title: Cowens Sidelined
description: BUZZARDS BAY, Mass., Sept. 30 (AP)  The Boston Celtics center, Dave Cowens, will not be able to play in the exhibition season because of a right leg injury, the Celtics said today.

title: Civil Rights Chief Named
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)Vernon N. Potter was sworn in today as New Jersey's third civil rights chief. Mr. Potter, 55 years old, of Orange, had been acting director of the Division on Civil Rights since the resignation of Gilbert H. Francis last June.

title: The American Vision
description: With the approaching Bicentennial, there is a lot of talk about American art. Almost every proposal includes an American art show, and the rummaging and ransacking of museum cellars and attics have already begun. For too long, Americans have thought of their native work as a poor second to European sources. But the best American work reveals a fresh vision, gentle insights, incisive reporting and surprising beauties. American art is due for a stunning reevaluation with Bicentennial attention.

title: ARNOLD S. RINALDI
description: Arnold S. Rinaldi, an architect with offices in Hempstead, L.I., died Sunday in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L.I., after a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 49 years old and lived at 53 North Long Beach Avenue in Freeport, L.I.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE.
description: ACROSS 1 River of Rotterdam

title: Beame to See Ford Today on Transit
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he would ask President Ford today to support an emergency plan allowing the city to divert half of its $240million in Federal grants for transit construction to meet operating deficits.

title: Fighting Yanks Wait Tensely
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 30The New York Yankees tried to patch up their family fight today while waiting tensely for the Baltimore Orioles to play their extra game as the final lap began in the race for the American League's Eastern championship.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, TUESDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1974
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30Twenty years ago a great exodus of modern Asian history dislocated Vietnam. A torrent of political and religious refugees928, 152, by one countfled from the North to the South.

title: Fellini: The Picture Will Direct Me
description: Amarcord, Federico Fellini's latest film, apparently. his biggest success since La Dolce Vita, is, says the director, about a tiny little village with people suffocating in it, with one year representing a whole life span. In the vernacular of Romagna, the area of Italy that Mr. Fellini comes from, Amarcord means I remember, and this is Mr. Fellini's look back at his adolescence in the nineteenthirties.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: Manila  Dan De Guzman, Philippines, knocked out Sornravy Yorntrakit, Thailand, 3 rounds, welterweights.

title: Malle: Lucien Could Be Any of Us, if ...
description: Louis Malle spins riddles. As in his enigmatic film, Lacombe, Lucien, dealing with citizen collaboration in Vichycontrolled France which he says can be validly interpreted with any set of prejudices and on any level the viewer brings to itMr. Malle in conversation asserts, then backs away; alternately pleads innocence and cynicism; speaks straightforwardly, then professes contradictory innocence.

title: Jews Demonstrate at U.N. Against Syrian Exit Curb
description: United Nations, N. Y., Sept. 30Members of Jewish organizations erected a symbolic prison wall opposite the United Nations headquarters today to dramatize a campaign seeking emigration of Jews from Syria.

title: NURSES ALLOWED TO WIDEN DUTIES
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30Governor Byrne signed legislation today to allow New Jersey's 30,000 registered nurses to diagnose minor ailments and perform other duties once limited to doctors, but he vetoed measures that would have exempted students from jury duty and changed the date of Veterans Day in the state.

title: Gulf Oil Increases Price of Gasoline, While Sohio Cuts It
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday it was raising the wholesale price on all grades of gasoline by 1.5 cents a gallon, effective immediately. At the same time, however, the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced a price cut of 1 cent a gallon, effective today, for companyoperated and dealer stations.

title: Offshore Oil Not Expected To Ease Shortages Quickly
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 29The huge oil deposits off the nation's coasts are unlikely to be the quick and easy palliative for the energy pinch that many people expect, Congressional hearings indicated here over the weekend.

title: U.S. STILL HOLDING CHILEAN RETAILER
description: Three days after a Federal judge ordered him freed, a Chilean who says he was kidnapped remained in the hands of United States narcotics agents yesterday at a West Side motel room.

title: Chess: Karpov and Korchnoi Adjourn In a Level EndGame SetUp
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30VikKorchnoi and Anatoly Karpov adjourned the seventh, game of their final Candidates Match for the right to play for the world championship in a level position after 44 moves tonight in the House of Unions. Karpov, who leads the match with two victories to Korchnoi's none, can afford draws, but Korchnoi must even up before 24 games are played or lose the contest.

title: Bridge: PostMortem Can Be Used As Place to Blow Off Steam
description: Keeping one's temper in the face of disaster is, of course, most desirable at the bridgetable, not only as a matter of manners but also because a lack of selfcontrol will damage partnership morale and engender further misfortunes. But there are occasions when a player can be forgiven for raising his voice a few decibels in the postmortem.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The superior court's Appellate Division refused to overturn a Board of Public Utility Commissioners ruling rejecting a 34 per cent rate increase for the Monmouth Consolidated Water Company. The company claimed that the Board miscalculated its financial position in granting only a 9 per cent increase on Oct. 15, 1973, to raise an additional $599,773 in revenues.

title: Texaco's New Neighbors Protest
description: Forty smartly dressed pickets from Purchase, an affluent Westchester community, demonstrated yesterday in front of the Chrysler Building to protest a plan by Texaco to erect an office building on 100 acres amidst their $150,000 to $500,000 homes.

title: Pratt Galleries Will Ban Frontal Nudity
description: Richardson Pratt Jr., president of the Pratt Institue in Brooklyn, has banned art works showing frontal nudity from three of the institute's public galleries for fear of offending visitorsparticularly the parents of students.

title: Stock Prices Decline Sharply; Margin Calls Termed a Factor
description: The stock market, beset by increasing investor concern over inflation and mounting margin calls, took another battering yesterday in heavy trading.

title: DOMINICANS UPSET BY A SECOND SIEGE
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 30While guerrllas continued their siege at the Venezuelan Consulate here today, the Dominican police were holding two journalists, and some Dominicans look upon their detention as the more disturbing development.

title: Ford to Explain Pardon In Person to House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30President Ford said tonight that he would appear personally before a House subcommittee within the next 10 days to answer a series of questions about his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: FORD NAMES PANELS ON JOBS AND HEALTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)  President Ford today appointed 10 persons to a National Commission for Manpower Policy and five others to an interagency committee on emergency medical services.

title: Wallace Backers to Poll Voters on ThirdParty Bid
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 30 (AP)Supporters of Gov. George C. Wallace plan to mail thousands of letters this week in an effort to determine how many voters might back the Alabama Governor in a new thirdparty bid for the Presidency.

title: PAYOFF IS DENIED BY PODELL AGAIN
description: Representative Bertram L. Podell testified at his bribery trial yesterday that he never accepted any money to assist Florida Atlantic Airlines with Federal agencies.

title: 3 Die as Building Collapses
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 30 (UPI)  A twostory building under construction collapsed and killed three workers today, the authorities said. The Baton Rouge coroner, Hypolite Landry, said he had been told that there had been an explosion and all the steel beams just collapsed.

title: Nassau and Suffolk Still Found to Rely On City for Work
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 30 No matter how selfsufficient Nassau and Suffolk Counties become economically, their residents will continue to rely heavily on New York City for jobs, according to a study released here today by the NassauSuffolk Regional Planning Board.

title: British Brokerage Concern To Cease Business Nov. 8
description: LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP)One of Britain's biggest provincial stock brokerage concerns announced today it would close down Nov. 8 because of lack of business in the depressed stock exchange and national economy.

title: Standard Time Voted
description: The Senate passed and sent to President Ford a bill to return the nation to standard time for four months, from Sunday, Oct. 27, to Sunday, Feb. 23, 1975. Page 81.

title: Graft Jury Hears Investigator's Tape
description: A jury of nine men and three women heard Detective Robert Leuci in person and on tape yesterday on the sixth day of the Brooklyn bribery conspiracy trial of three former police detectives.

title: Hindsight On Attica Won't Wash
description: Congress ought to explore thoroughly the qualifications and attitudes of any man who is to stand a heartbeat from the Presidency. But last week before the Senate Judiciary Committee, the response of Nelson Rockefeller to a question about the Attica prison rebellion raised serious questions about his memory, his veracity or both; the committee only let the matter drop.

title: Pincay Wins 5 Races
description: Laffit Pincay, the Panamaman jockey, rode five winhers at Belmont Park yesterday. Story on Page 51.

title: The Theater Marlowe's Edward II
description: The C.S.C. Repertory Company opened its eighth New York season at the Abbey Theater last night. This has always been an unusually wellendowed Off Broadway house, but the company has now remodeled it so that it provides an outstanding stage for the classic theater. The trust platform stage and the semicircle of seats provides an attractive ambiance and a most practical stage area.

title: NIXON IS CHARGED IN WIRETAP SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Former President Richard M. Nixon was named today as a defendant in a civil lawsuit brought by a former National Security Council official whose home telephone was tapped by the Government between 1969 and 1971.

title: New Cabinet for Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 30 (Reuters)President Suleiman Franjieh has accepted the resignation of Premier Takieddin Solh's Government and will begin consultations with parliamentary leaders tomorrow on the formation of a new one, it was announced here tonight.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Argentina Annuls Contracts
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30 (AP)  Partially completed) contracts totaling $225million involving the International Telephone and Telegraph Corpo??tion, Siemens, A.G., and Entel, the stateowned telephone company, since 1969 were formally annulled today by Argentina. I.T.T. and Siemens denied any wrongdoing. The pacts were to provide updated equipment and maintenance for Entel over a fiveyear term.

title: State Democrats Announce Task Force on the Economy
description: Joseph F. Crangle, the state Democratic chairman, and Stanley Steingut, minority leader of the State Assembly, yesterday announced the formation of an economic task force that would hold hearings around the state to find ways to relieve our worsening economic situation.

title: Longer Trading Hours To Take Effect Today
description: A 30minute extension in trading hours goes into effect, today on the New York and American Stock Exchanges and in the NASDAQ system of the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: Police Aide Supports Sergeant Who Fatally Shot Boy in Bronx
description: Deputy Inspector Walter F. Priestly, in charge of the Alexander Avenue station in the Bronx, said yesterday that there was absolutely no reason at this time to believe that a police sergeant involved in the fatal shooting Saturday night of a 17yearold youth had acted improperly.

title: Giants' Joy Is Tempered As Key Men Are Injured
description: With celebration still fresh in their minds, the New York Giants learned yesterday that two injured regulars on offense, Ron Johnson and Tom Mullen, probably would not play against the Atlanta Falcons Sunday at Yale Bowl.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Chrysler Offering Improved Warranty
description: DETROIT, Sept. 30  The Chrysler Corporation announced today a oneyear unlimited mileage guarantee for its 1975model cars. The company also said that a car would be lent without charge to an owner if his new model had to be kept overnight at a dealer for warranty work.

title: Man Found Slain in Brooklyn
description: An unidentified man in his 30's was found dead with two bullet wounds in the back of his neck on the grounds of a New York State institution for the retarded in the East New York Section of Brooklyn, the police reported. Detectives investigating the ganglandstyle slaying said the body was first discovered by employes of the Kings County State School at Vandalia Avenue, about half a mile west of Fountain Avenue, slumped the wheel of a car.

title: Slaying Suspect a Familiar Figure in West 80th St.
description: As a fifthfloor resident of a oneroom apartment at 165 80th Street, Julio Vasquez blended unobtrusively into the heterogeneous life of the block between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: An Effort to Save Wyoming
description: MOOSE, Wyo.  The bald eagle, symbol of our national pride and vigor since 1783, but offered no protection from man's guns, snares, works, traps and poisons until 1940, might well be the emblem of John F. Turner, a young Wyoming state representative, rancher and ecologist who believes his state will be ravaged by a mineralhungry world unless immediate controls are enacted.

title: Contract Awards
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Western Electric Company unit said it had awarded a $190million cable contract to Phelps Dodge Industries, Inc., and the United Aircraft Corporation's Essex International division. The contract calls for delivery of about 68 billion conductor feet of plastic insulated exchange cable Over a sevenyear period.

title: Dispute on Alleged Alioto Conflict Rises
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 Controversy continued to build last week over whethe Mayor Joseph L. Alioto's participation in the purchase of a shipline constituted a conflict; of interest.

title: Boeing and lis Mechanics Reach Tentative Accord
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 30 (AP) The Boeing Company and negotiators for 27,000 of its aerospace mechanics reached tentative agreement today on threeyear contract less than two days before the present contract expires.

title: Occupational Safety Order
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) President Ford announced today that he had signed an Executive order directing the Secretary of Labor to, issue detailed guidelines for occupational safety and health programs in all federal departments and agencies.

title: Kison's 3Hitter, Triple by Zisk Beat Cubs, 21
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30Bruce Kison of Pittsburgh overcame a shaky first inning and pitched a threehitter for his first complete game of the season. Richie Zisk came off the bench and drove in his 100th run of the season with a tiebreaking triple.

title: Beame Proposes Improvement of Subway Entrances
description: Mayor Beame proposed underground zoning yesterday to provide spacious, weather  protected subway station entrances in landscaped plazas or under the overhang of new buildings along the route of the new Second Avenue line.

title: A.C.L.U. to Challenge Amnesty Program; Offers Free Legal Aid to Exiles
description: Calling President Ford's conditional amnesty plan worse than no amnesty at all, the American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday it would legally challenge what it termed constitutional inequities and defects of, the clemency offer and show Vietnamera exiles that there are better options for repatriation open to them.

title: ECEVIT FAILS IN BID FOR TURKISH CABINET
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 30Premier Bulent Ecevit, whose coalition Cabinet collapsed two Weeks ago in a dispute over Turkey's Cyprus policy, abandoned today an attempt to form a new Government.

title: Mets Win on Garrett Clout
description: Jerry Koosman concluded his finest season in five years last night when he pitched the Mets to a 52 victory last night over Philadelphia that prevented the Phillies from taking sole possession of third place in the National League's Eastern Division.

title: Investors, Stung by Stocks, Choose Delft Over Dow
description: Like hundreds of thousands of other investors in these days of plummeting prices on Wall Street, Don Smith, a 43yearold Seattle trumpet player and music store proprietor, has pulled most of his money out of stocks and bought into something he considered more attractivein his case, United States Treasury bills.

title: Kissinger Reports Progress on Cyprus
description: Secretary of State Kissinger reported some progress yesterday in discussions with Greek and Turkish officials on ways to resolve the Cyprus crisis.

title: LEWIS BERTRAND, 78, TRANSLATOR, IS DEAD
description: Lewis Bertrand, a literary and commercial translator and interpreter here for more than 50 years, died Sunday in Paris, where he had been working recently. He was 78 year old and lived at 120 West 58th Street.

title: After Breast Cancer Operations, A Difficult Emotional Adjustment
description: It's been called the operation that women fear most, and last Saturday, it was performed on the wife of the President of the United States, Betty Ford.

title: Most Futures Rise, Led by Soybeans, Silver and Copper
description: Most commodity futures rose yesterday, and a metals analyst said that gold, grains and Japan sum up in three words the reason for the increase.

title: Doctor Says a Trip by Nixon to Testify at Trial Must Be Put Off One to Three Months
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 30Former President Richard M. Nixon will not be medically fit to travel to Washington for one to three months to testify a in the Watergate coverup trial, Mr. Nixon's doctor said here today. Mr. Nixon is expected to be discharged from Memorial Hospital Medical Center next weekend.

title: An ExConvict Is Accused In Killing of Policeman
description: A 31yearold former convict was arrested yesterday morning and accused of the murder of Officer Patrick J. Kelly, whose dismembered body was found early Saturday on West 79th Street.

title: C.M. Elects Murphy Chief Executive
description: The General Motors Corpo ration, the world's largest in dustrial company, yesterday named a new and expanded management team to lead the automobile giant. It also an nounced a shift in domestic, in ternational and nonautomotive responsibilities.

title: Defender Asking New Trial for Carter and Artis
description: The New Jersey Public Defender's Office will file court papers today demanding a new trial for Rubin (Hurricane) Catter; the former boxer, and a codefendant who are serving life prison terms for a triple murder.

title: RAISE IN MEDICAID BACKED BY ALBANY
description: The state's Budget Director yesterday approved a $100million increase in Medicaid payments to healthcare facilities through the state for fiscal year 1975 retroactive to Sept. 1. The increase is expected to result in a $45million bonus for the city's financially ailing Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Montana and North Dakota Demand Coal Output Role
description: BILLINGS, Mont., Sept. 30The Governors of Montana and North Dakota warned the Federal Government in strongly worded speeches today that their states were demanding a voice in the newly urgent planning in Washington to meet the energy crisis by the crash development of coal resources here.

title: Carey Rejects FrontRunner Role; Strengthens Campaign Organization
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey often finds himself these days gazing at questioners with honest eyes of Irish blue and explaining why he should not be regarded as the favorite in the race for the governorship.

title: Former Chilean General Killed By Bomb Mast in Buenos Aires
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30 (Reuters)  Gen. Carlos Prats Gonzlez, former commander of the Chilean army, and his wife were killed in a bomb blast today as they drove toward their home in Buenos Aires.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beame ordered a 30day delay in plans to curtail drastically the city's program of emergency repairs in rundown buildings, which is now limited to correcting conditions that threaten the lives and safety of tenants.

title: Jury Starts Deliberating In ArsonMurder Case
description: PATERSON, Sept. 30A jury in the trial of a Passaic landlord accused of murdering a woman and three children in a fire at three buildings he owned deliberated for three hours today in Superior Court here this afternoon before recessing for the clay.

title: Bill on Fiscal Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)A bill requiring all highlevel Federal officials to make a public disclosure of their financial worth was introduced today by Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC DECLINE
description: With optimistic news still lacking, investors sent prices down again yesterday on the Americn Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: Mrs. Ford Facing Tests To Determine Treatment
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 30.Betty Ford's physicians reported today that they had found cancer cells in two of the ??0 lymph nodes removed with her right breast last Saturday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: N'SELE, Zaire, Sept. 30 (AP)  The world heavyweight boxing champion, George Foreman resumed gym work today after a twoweek layoff with a cut over his right eye which forced postponment of his title defense against Muhammad Ali. The fight, originally planned for Sept. 24, has been rescheduled for Oct. 30 in Kinshasa, Zaire (Oct. 29 New York time). Foreman, who appeared to have kept his weight down to near fighting trim, shadow boxed and hit the speed bag for five rounds. It feels good to be back in the ring again, he said. I've been doing my roadwork for the past five days and when Dick Sadler says it's O.K., we'll be sparring again.

title: PUBLIC LABOR BILL MEETS OBSTACLE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30The ex. pected final legislative passage of a controversial bill giving teachers and other public em. ployes sgnificant new collective bargaining rights failed today when its principal supporters objected to an amendment narrowly voted in the State Assembly.

title: The Diplomats Protest
description: The tradition of American professional diplomats is accept without public complaint the appointment of noncareer ambassadorsand to make the best of it. Many a Foreign Service officer has worked overtime to make up for the incompetence of an ambassador who had obtained his job by cash contributions or service to his political party.

title: Court Rules for Rail Reorganizations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30A special appeals court established under the Regional Rail Reorganization Act of 1973 ruled today that four bankrupt railroads, of which the Penn, Cem?? Transportation Company is the largest, could be reorganized unaer the Government's reorganization program.

title: An ExConvict Is Accused In Killing of Policeman
description: A 31yearold former convict was arrested yesterday morning and accused of the murder of Officer Patrick J. Kelly, whose dismembered body was found early Saturday on West 79th Street.

title: MERGER PLANNED BY WHITE, WELD
description: Wall Street, which has already seen 122 brokerage houses disappear in the last two years, lost another oldline company yesterday.

title: Securities Unit Urges Rise in Big Board's Minimum Rate Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Securities Industry Association disclosed today that it had asked the New York Stock Exchange to revise substantially upward its proposal to increase minimum fixed commission rates by an average of 18 per cent on orders between $5,000 and $300,000.

title: Stolid I.M.F. Faces Rapid World Change
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The labyrinthan corridors of the Sheraton Park Hotel were filled with sober men in sober clothes today, the world's finance ministers and central bank chiefs among them.

title: KUWAITI, AT U. N., DEFENDS OIL PRICE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30The Foreign Minister of Kuwait, in an address tonight to the General Assembly, rejected any link between the energy and food crises and defended the oilproducing countries against the charge that their prices had caused worldwide inflation.

title: DELAY IS ORDERED IN REPAIR MEAD
description: Mayor Beame yesterday or dered a 30day delay in plans curtail drastically the city program of emergency repair in rundown buildings, which now limited to correcting con ditions that threaten the live and safety of tenants.

title: God in Every Pot
description: PITTSBURGH  Patriotism, Samuel Johnson said, is the last refuge of a scoundrel. Religion, in the rhetoric of American politics, is surely the first refuge of selfrighteous patriotism.

title: Women's Lob Strikes It Rich
description: Women's Lob has scored another point.

title: Chamberlain, 38, Rehires; Basketball's Top Scorer
description: Wilt Chamberlain, the most controversial and prolific scorer in pro basketball history, will announce his retirement this week.

title: Oil Groups Reported To Refuse Invitations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (Reuters)The two major groupings of oilexporting nations refused invitations to attend the joint annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, informed sources have disclosed.

title: 3 AIDES OF MILLS QUERIED BY JURY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) A Watergate grand jury has questioned three current and former aides of Representative Wilbur D. Mills about dairyinterest funds used in the Arkansas Democrat's brief 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: List of 14 Questions Ford Faces on Nixon Pardon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Following are the questions about the pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon that President Ford agreed today to answer personally before a House Subcommittee:

title: The Nixon Trial
description: The Watergate trial, which begins today in the United States District Court in Washington, is both the continuation and the culmination of the long, circuitous pursuit of the truth in what former Attorney General John Mitchell, one of the defendants, so fittingly called the White House horrors.

title: Carey Would End Crangle's State job
description: ALBANY, Sept. 30Guiding his running mates from one jubilant crowd of Democrats to remove his party's state chairman from the state government payroll if the public elected a Democratic ticket.

title: PLANS FOR HOUSE STIR DEMOCRATS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The House of Representatives began a gingerly debate today on how to reorganize itself, with some of its more influential senior Democrats attacking a restructuring of committees proposed last March by a bipartisan house panel.

title: Justice's Law Secretary Found Slain in His Office
description: MINEOLA, LI., Sept. 30The 32yearold law secretary to State Supreme Court justice was found shot to death in his office in the State Supreme Court Building here this morning.

title: EXCITY AIDE HEED IN SLAYING OF SON
description: A former technical consultant in the city's Housing and Development Administration was charged last night with having murdered his teenaged son, after he admitted the slaying to Queens detectives, and then helped them to recover the youth's body from a pond in the Adirondack Mountains where he had dropped it from a boat.

title: Man Dies in Attack on Home
description: AXTON, Va., Sept. 30 (AP)One person was killed and seven, including five children, were injured today in a fire and gunshot attack on a house trailer in this Henry County community, There was no indication of a motive.

title: Investors, Stung by Stocks, Choose Delft Over Dow
description: Like hundreds of thousands of other investors in these days of plummeting prices on Wall Street, Don Smith, a 43yearold Seattle trumpet player and music store proprietor, has pulled most of his money out of stocks and bought into something he considered more attractivein his case, United States Treasury bills.

title: 2 Bids to Holders Planned by MGM
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30Directors of MetroGoldwynMayer, Inc., authorized today a cash tender offer in midOctober for all of its outstanding 5 per cent convertible debentures due in 1993 and a proposed offer early next year to exchange outstanding common stock for a callable new issue.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A $300million bond issue for highway construction and railroads cleared the New Jersey Legislature yesterday. At the same time, the State Senate gave initial approval to a $900million bond issue for low and moderately priced housing and sent it to the Assembly, where Democratic leaders there scheduled a final vote for next Monday.

title: HISTORY UNIT WEIGHS SUIT ON NIXON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)  The head of a historical association said today that his group and at least two others were considering court action to insure that former President Richard M. Nixon's tapes and documents were not destroyed.

title: Market Place
description: If there is any doubt as to the seriousness of the sickness that grips this marketthe Dow Jones industrials threatened to drop below the 600 level yesterdayall one needs to do is to look at the cumulative preferred shares of the Avco Corporation.

title: Roberto Devereux Completes Cycle at City Opera
description: Roberto Devereux entered and departed the New York{is City Opera's repertory Sunday night, completing the company's first Donizetti Queen cycle within a single season.

title: OldTime Jazz Violinist Plays Smoothly
description: When the Quintet of the Hot Club of France caught the attention of the jazz world almost 40 years ago, it was primarily because of the playing of Django Reinhardt, the Belgian gypsy guitarist, the first nonAmerican jazz musician to be an influence on American jazzmen. Stephane Grappelli, the violinist in the Quintet (which also included two other guitarists and a string bass), gained some recognition, but was always overshadowed by Mr. Reinhardt's presence.

title: Villemure Quitting Rangers for Trots
description: Gilles Villemure, unable to get the National Hockey League's New York Rangers to renegotiate his contract, is retiring, his attorney said yesterday.

title: Helms, the C.I.A. and Public Trust
description: WASHINGTONThe judgments that, led to covert United States intervention In Chilean politics deserve to be criticized, but at least there the Central Intelligence Agency was within its legal authority under its charter. That was not the case with C.I.A. complicity in Watergate extraagency activities and the subsequent coverup.

title: Leftists in Prison Condemn Dominican Kidnapping
21 DISTRICTS LACK TEACHER PACTS
description: NEWARK, Oct, 1With the school year almost a month old, teachers, in 21 school districts across New Jersey arc still working without contracts, which a spokesman for the New Jersey Education Association today called. very, very unusual.

title: CORRUPT REGIME DENIED BY THIEU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1President Nguyen Van Thieu tonight denied allegations of corruption recently made against him but rhetorically offered to resign from office if, as he put it, the entire people and army no longer have confidence in me.

title: VAN NESS SCORES NATURALGAS PLAN
description: TRENTON, Oct. 1  The state's Public Advocate, Stanley C. Van Ness, filed a petition with the Federal Power Commission today to block construction of a proposed liquefied naturalgas storage facility in Woodbridge.

title: Boston Council Votes Raise
description: BOSTON, Oct. I (AP)The Boston City Council voted itself a $7,500 pay rise last night, raising salaries to $20,000 year, effective Jan, 1.

title: Wilson, in Sharp Letter, Assails City's Efforts on CleanAir Plan
description: Governor Wilson has sent a sharply worded letter to Mayor Beame saying the state has received no significant cooperation from the city in developing a workable plan to meet Federal cleanair standards for New York City.

title: C. A. B. APPROVES 25% AIRFARE CUT
description: Air travelers were granted a measure of relief yesterday from relentlessly rising fares when the Civil Aeronautics Board approved a 25 per cent winter discount for many domestic flights.

title: As New Fashion Season Begins, Part of the Show Is the Audience
description: Boots area sure sign. So are sweaters, especially those by Sonia Rykiel. Cape's count, and the chemise is making its appearance.

title: TREASURY BILLS ADVANCE IN YIELD
Woman, 81, and 3 Grandchildren Spared Eviction as City Pays Rent
description: An 81yearold woman and her three grandchildren, caught between the bureaucracies of the city's public housing and public assistance agencies, escaped eviction when the Department of Social Services turned over $716 yesterday to the New York City Housing Authority.

title: Federal Employes Get 5.52% Salary In crease
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. (UPI)  President Ford reluctantly ordered today an immediate 5.52 per cent pay rise for 3.5 million Federal Government workers and military personnel.

title: Mrs. Ford, Regaining Strength, Has Good Day, Doctors Report
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)Betty Ford's doctors reported today that she was regaining her strength and had a very favorable day.

title: Hershey Is Reducing Weight of Chocolate Bar
description: HERSHEY, Pa., Oct. 1 (Reuters)  The Hershey Foods Corporation is reducing the weight of its 15cent chocolate bar to 1.2 ounces from 1.4 ounces, a company official said today.

title: Sharp Increase in Income Forecast by Merrill Lynch
description: A sharp rise in net income for the third quarter is expected by Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., Donald T. Regan, chairman, said yesterday.

title: Safety Rules Issued for Vinyl Chloride
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Department of Labor announced today final industrial health rules designed to reduce worker exposure to vinyl chloride, a cancercausing chemical widely used as a basic. material in the manufacture of plastics.

title: State Helps Fleeced Clients
description: TRENTON, Oct. 1 (AP)The acting administrative director of New Jersey's courts reported today that $327,000 had been paid out of a special fund to clients fleeced by their lawyers. Arthur J.
