Simpson Jr., the courts' administrator, said the fiveyearold fund, which is basically financed by $15 annual payments by all practicing lawvers in the state, has returned money to 78 claimants. He said the claims involved the actions of 14 lawyers.

title: Fred J. Rosenau Is Dead at 87; Maker of Cinderella Dress Line
description: Fred J. Rosenau, retired board chairman of the countrys largest manufacturer of childrens dresses, died Monday at his home near Philadelphia. He was 87 years old and lived in Rydal, Pa.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (Reuters)  Total United States reserve assets rose $548million in August to a total of $15.46billion with a surge in convertible foreign currency holdings, the Treasury Department reported today. Reserve assets at the end of July were $14.91billion.

title: AMEX PRICES SLIP AS VOLUME GAINS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to slide yesterday in slightly stepped up trading as bullish news on the economy remained scarce. Prices on the overthecounter market closed mixed.

title: U.S. Forgoes Bid to Extradite Hughes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Justice Department has decided not to seek the extradition from the Bahamas of Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire industrialist, to stand trial in a stockfraud case.

title: 3 States Ask Court to Halt Dumping in Lake Superior
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin asked the Supreme Court today to order an immediate end to the Reserve Mining Company's dumping of iron ore waste into Lake Superior, on the ground that thousands of people were being daily exposed to cancercausing contaminants in drinking water.

title: Hirshhorn Museum Unveiled in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1With the pomp befitting high occasion, the capital's newest cultural treasure, the Joseph H. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, was formally unveiled this evening.

title: S. E. C. SUSPENDS TRADING OF AVIS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday suspended trading in the stock of Avis, Inc., amid rumors that UAL, Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, was negotiating to buy the major carrental company from the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Production of 2 Pesticides Is Banned in Safety Move
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, ordered today an immediate ban on the production of two widely used pesticides, Ialdrin and dieldrin, to avoid unreasonable human health risks.

title: Notes on People
description: As expected, routinely and by voice vote, the Senate yesterday confirmed the nomination of Richard L. Roudebush, former United States Representative from Indiana, to be the Veterans Administrator. The former lawmaker, a Republican, replaces Donald E. Johnson as head of the vast bureaucracy that is the Veterans Administration.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne endorsed proposed legislation for Federal public service employment to offset rising unemployment, which he said was as bad or worse in New Jersey than anywhere in the country. Our latest figures show that the unemployment rate in New Jersey has reached 8.3 per cent, Mr. Byrne told the House Select Subcommittee on Labor in Washington. He said the rate was twice as highin urban areas and four times higher among the young and minorities.

title: SCUFFLE BROKEN UP AT SCHOOL IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP)School officials broke up brief scuffle between white and black students in the South Boston High library today. There were no injuries.

title: Clark Criticizes Javits on Contributions And Scores Failure on Moral Leadership
description: Former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark charged yesterday that Senator Jacob K. Javits had accepted large campaign contributions from representatives of the most powerful special interest lobbies.

title: Vinyl Chloride Rules
description: The Department of Labor is imposing permanent rules to protect plastics workers against cancer by restricting the amount of vinyl chloride to which they may be exposed. Page 26.

title: Hirshhorn Museum Unveiledin Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1With the pomp befitting high occasion, the capital's newest cultural treasure, the Joseph H. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, was formally unveiled tonight.

title: Robinson May Be Named Tomorrow
description: Frank Robinson will be named playing manager of the Cleveland Indians tomorrow, thereby becoming the first black manager in major league baseball history, United Press International reported yesterday. Robinson's salary will remain at its present $173,000 level, automatically making him the highestpaid manager in the history baseball.

title: BLOUSTEIN URGES MASSIVE LOBBYING
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 1Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, Rutgers University president, called today for a massive lobbying of the Legislature to try to stave off a budget crisis at the university.

title: UNEASY PORTUGAL ON VIGIL FOR COUP
description: LISBON, Oct. I  Portugal's armed forces have been placed on full alert as a precaution against a coup, following the resignation yesterday of President Antnio de Spnola.

title: SCIENTISTS ATTAIN FUSIONLEVEL HEAT
description: Scientists at the University of Texas in Austin announced yesterday that by using a new device that heats gas by means of intense turbulence they had achieved temperatures about 10 times higher than those within the sun. This is a necessary requirement for the development of nuclear fusion power.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: EAST ORANGE, Oct. 1  The Fitzgerald family East Orange, which has already contributed one member the United States Olympic track and field team, has two more at home with similar ambitions.

title: FREIGHTRATE RISE FOR RAILS SOUGHT
description: The railroad industry's campaign for a new round of freight rate increases acceler ated yesterday as representatives of three major railway associations said that petitions would be filed in the near future with the Intersate Commerce Commission seeking a 7 per cent acrosstheboard rate increase by Jan. 1, 1975.

title: People in Sports
description: Chris Evert and Jimmy Connors, tennis's most famlove birds, have decided to postpone their wedding although they are still very much in love, according to Miss Evert's father. The tennis stars were scheduled to be married in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Nov. 8.

title: U. S. DROPS CASE AGAINST 8 POLICE
description: A Federal indictment against aight policemen resulting from the Knapp Commission investigation into police corruptionan indictment that depended on the testimony of a suspended patrolman, William R. Phillips has been withdrawn by the Government, primarily because Mr. Phillips's credibility has been brought into question.

title: F. D. R.'s Trees Periled
description: SEWARD, Neb.  Many of F. D.R.'s trees still shade the Great Plains.

title: Ford Decision Tied to View Of Limits on Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1President Ford's surprise decision to appear before a Congressional subcommittee to answer questions about the pardon of Richard M. Nixon was described by close associates today as reflecting his view that executive privilege is not the absolute right many of his predecesors believed it to be.

title: $2Billion Gas Line Is Proposed in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 1A Canadian company has apprised the National Energy Board of plans for a $2billion domestic pipeline to natural gas fields in the Canadian Arctic. It is offered as an alternative to the program of a CanadianAmerican private consortium for a 2,625 mile line, costing $6billion, to carry both Canadian and Alaskan gas to consumers in both countries.

title: Fordham Station Makes a Bid to Inherit WNCN's Concert Albums
description: As dozens of musicians, city officials, artists and cultural leaders marched yesterday morning in a demonstration to head off the impending demise of classicalmusic programing at WNCNFM, a noncommercial FM station, WFUV, operated by Fordham University, made a bid to inherit the station's library of some 16,000 concert music albums.

title: Soviet Presses Attack on Peking, On the Chinese National Holiday
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1The Soviet Union today used the 25th Anniversary of Communist rule in China to continue polemics against the Chinese leadership and to emphasize its own past aid to Peking during friendlier years.

title: Dream Ended on BasesFull Hit by Scott
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 1The New York Yankees finally shouted their last hurrah tonight when they were defeated by the Milwaukee Brewers in 10 innings, 32, and fell out of the race for their first pennant in 10 years.

title: Calley's Plea for Freedom Is Taken to Appeals Court
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 1 (AP) Lawyers for William L. Calley Jr. reaffirmed today their request that Mr. Calley be freed immediately and argued that it was sheer nonsense for the Army to seek authority to courtmartial him a second time on My Lai murder charges.

title: YOUTHS IN RAMPAGE ON BROOKLYN TRAIN
description: A large group of youths armed with chains, sticks, knives, pipes, a dagger and a zipgun rampaged on a southbound IND F train in the Borough Park section of BrookIlyn yesterday morning, threatening passengers before being ejected by transit policemen at the Avenue I station.

title: Meany Tells Senate Detente Is Phony
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1George Meany testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, today criticized the United States policy of seeking dtente with the Soviet Union as onesided appeasement. He called for a tough, realistic relationship in which Moscow would make reciprocal concessions.

title: More Virulent Strain Of Influenza Expected
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 1 (UPI)A new and more virulent influenza strain is expected to hit the United States this winter, according to the Center for Disease Control.

title: Chain Stores Gain
description: Leading chainstore and catalogue companies showed a gain of 11 per cent in sales in August, compared with the corresponding month a year ago. Details on Page 67.

title: Orioles Win Title
description: Baltimore nosed out the Yankees for the American League's Eastern Division title yesterday. The Orioles defeated Detroit, 76, and clinched the crown when the Yanks lost to Milwaukee, 32, in 10 innings. Details, Page 33.

title: Greek Archeologist Killed at Excavation
description: ATHENS, Oct. 1 (AP)Spyros Marinatos, one of Greece's most distinguished archeologists, was killed in an accident today while overseeing excavations on the island of Santorini, the police reported.

title: Production of 2 Pesticides Is Banned in Safety Move
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, ordered today an immediate ban on the production of two widely used pesticides, aidrin and dieldrin, to avoid unreasonable human health risks.

title: Lockheed and Greece Plan Repair Plant Near Athens
description: ATHENS, Oct. 1 (AP)The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the Greek Government have agreed to set up a $120million airplane maintenance and repair plant in Greece, the Government announced today.

title: Merrill Lynch Approves Family Life Merger Plan
description: The board of Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., the holding company for the nation's largest stock brokerage firm, approved yesterday a formal plan and agreement to acquire the Family Life Insurance Company of Seattle. The tentative merger plan, first announced on June 13, proposed an exchange of stock on the basis of 1.58 shares of Merrill Lynch common for each share of Family Life common stock.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: 3 R's Get Upgrading in 2 Schools
description: You find yourself wanting to do more than is expected of you, said Jill Cohen, a 16yearold senior who attends the Learning In a Free Environment program at Lawrence High School in Cedarhurst, L. I. I was a constant cutter in the regular school program but I never cut here.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Trenton Is Pat on List Of High Unemployment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Trenton was added today to the Labor Department's list of major labor areas with substantial unemployment.

title: Conteh Outpoints Ahumada
description: WEMBLEY, England, Oct. 1 John Conteh lost three titles tonight but picked up the one he said he was going after since he was 11 years old.

title: House Votes to Raise Funds For Education $198Million
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) The House voted today to add another $198million to Federal spending for education programs despite a rebuke from President Ford for exceeding Administration requests for education by nearly a halfbillion dollars in another bill.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: A Collection That Puts Museum in the Select Class
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1No less than artists or works of art, collections, too, acquire their aura of legend, mystery and scandal. This was certainly the case with the collection of Joseph H. Hirshhorn. Long before it was offered as a gift to the nation, this vast repository of modern painting and sculpture was talked about, joked about, attacked, defended and otherwise dilated both in and out of the parochial purlieus of the art world.

title: 16.9Billion Rise Projected In Cost of Major Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Defense Department reported today that in the second quarter of this year the projected cost of 42 major weapons programs increased by $16.9billion, largely because of inflation.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (In pounds sterling per metric ton)

title: On the Runway, It's the Furriers' Turn
description: Suppose you already have a perfectly adequate mink coat hanging in your closet. Or supposejust for the sake of argument, of coursethat you really don't want one.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Trial of Equity Funding ExChief Opens
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1  A jury of seven women and five men was selected today in the first day of the Federal criminal trial of Stanley Goldbaum, former president and chairman of the Equity Funding Corporation of America, the onetime highflying mutual fundinsurance company that was rocked by scandal last year and is now in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Three escapees from a psychiatric ward at Grasslands Hospital in Valhalla, N.Y., were captured here early yesterday. Acting on confidential information, 30 officers from the city police department, the Westchester County District Attorney's office and the Westchester parkway police captured James Brown, 34 years old of Manhattan: Tyrone Freeman, 18, of White Plains, and Thomas Wilkerson, 22, of Hawthorne, N.Y.

title: EGYPTIAN DEFENDS ARAB OIL POLICIES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1Egypt took a militant position today in defending Arab oil policies and also pushed for United Nations recognition of the Palestinians.

title: Parties at White House Still On Despite Surgery
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) The White House is going ahead with three social events that were on the schedule before Betty Ford became ill. Mrs. Ford's daughter Susan, 17 years old, will help as hostess.

title: N.H.L. Divisions Get NameTags
description: East is East and West is Westexcept in the National Hockey League.

title: G.O.P. IS COURTED ON HOUSE REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  A scaled  down reorganization plan for House committees drawn by a panel of Democrats was made a bit more palatable to Republicans today.

title: Responsive President
description: By volunteering to appear before a committee of the House of Representatives to answer questions about the pardon he granted to Richard Nixon, President Ford has set an admirable example of open and responsive government. Such readiness to be accountable to Congress gains in significance by its contrast to the Nixon Administration's defiant custom of hiding behind the stone wall of executive privilege.

title: Connecticut Gets $6Million For PublicServioe Job Aid
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 1 (AP)Connecticut is receiving more than $6million for publicservice jobs for unemployed persons, according to figures obtained today by United States Representative Ronald A. Sarasin.

title: PRESIDENT BACKS TRANSIT MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1President Ford gave unqualified support today to a longterm, $11billion masstransit bill and won the support of 22 Mayors and eight business and labor leaders in helping to press for legislation during this session of Congress.

title: CHILEAN'S JAILING ANGERS U.S. JUDGE
description: A Federal judge told a Government prosecutor yesterday that he was completely outraged at the treatment of Chilean jailed here by mistake and then kept in isolation by narcotics agents despite a release order.

title: TV: Sara's Summer Is ABC's Gift to Children
description: Not without calculated reason, ABCTV has been Crowing about its performance in children's programing these days. One executive has gone so far as to invite both parents and children to monitor an Open House Week for Children's Television beginning Oct. 19. Beyond that publicity ploy, however, ABC has been considerably more imaginative in the area than either of its network competitors over the last couple of years.

title: Fun on the West Side and Other Amusements
Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Daylight Time

title: JUDGE DISMISSES LEE MYLES CASE
description: A State Supreme Court judge dismissed charges in Queens yesterday against five persons indicted last June in connection with the alleged use of stolen engines by the Lee Myles Transmissions Company.

title: State's Fornication Law Of 1796 Upheld by Judge
description: NEWWARK, Oct. 1The constitutionality of a 1796 fornication statute, which prohibits sexual intercourse outside marriage, was upheld by an Essex County Superior Court judge today.

title: STATE IS ASSAILED ON BELLEVUE UNIT
description: The State Department of Mental Hygiene was assailed yesterday by city officials, state legislators and mentalhealth experts for having blocked construction of a psychiatric center in the new 21story Bellevue Hospital Center.

title: Chess: An Inevitable Draw (the 5th) Is Korchnoi's Lot Once More
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1Viktor Korchnoi is having so much trouble getting anything out of his openings against Anatoly Karpov in their final candidates match here in the House of Unions that he is reduced to playing out end games of any kind, favorable or not. Korchnoi came in this afternoon, played four moves of the seventh game, then offered a draw. There was nothing to be accomplished in such a sterile position as the two players reached after 44 moves of play yesterday, but Korchnoi stubbornly sealed 45 PQ5, hoping against hope that his 23year old opponent would somehow botch the rookandminorpiece ending.

title: McDonald Chosen For Key Mets' Post
description: The New York Mets unveiled their fifth general manager yesterday, the lowkeyed Joseph Anthony McDonald, a loyal and original Met.

title: Kidnapped Woman Found Dead in Car; Husband Unharmed
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 1 (AP) The body of Mrs. E. B. Reville, kidnapped yesterday by three gunmen, was found in the trunk of her car on a dirt road west of here late today, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: BOND DEALER TIED TO P.O.W. SWINDLE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Securities and Exchange Commission accused a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., municipalbond dealer today of swindling hundreds of former Vietnam prisoners of war out of thousands of dollars of back pay and asked a Federal court to force restitution of the money.

title: ALBERT F. PATTERSON
description: Albert F. Patterson, former paperindustry executive, died Saturday in Christiansted, St. Croix, where he had been living for the last two years. He was 56 years old.

title: Orioles Get Yank Result By Phone, Whoop It Up
description: DETROIT, Oct. 1  Andy Etchebarren got the winning run across for the Orioles in both games today.

title: Hearst Will Be Honored By Veteran Newsmen Here
description: Willian Randolph Hearst Jr., editor In chief of the Hearst newspapers, will receive on Oct. 21 the Society of the Silurians' Quarter Century News Achievement Gold Quill, Charles Hagedorn, the group's president, announced yesterday.

title: Yankees Eliminated
description: Baltimore nosed out the Yankees for the American League's Eastern Division title yesterday. The Orioles defeated Detroit, 76, and clinched the crown when the Yanks lost to Milwaukee, 32, in 10 innings. Details, Page 33.

title: Murderer, Father and Lawyer Indicted In Alleged Plot to Kill 3 Trial Witnesses
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct, 1A convicted murderer, his wealthy father and a lawyer were indicted today on charges that they conspired to kill three persons who had been witnesses, in the trial that resulted in the murder conviction and a life sentence.

title: WARNING IS ISSUED ON OIL PRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Federal Energy Administration, John C. Sawhill, warned oil refiners today not to raise prices to recover any costs they may have entered on their books under a socalled doubledip provision of the crude oil allocation regulations.

title: Bill to Curb Wiretaps Splits Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1A proposal to strip the President of power to order wiretaps in foreign intelligence investigations without advance Federal Court approval is causing sharp divisions in Congress.

title: Vinyl Chloride Rules
description: The Department of Labor is imposing permanent rules to protect plastics workers against cancer by restricting the amount of vinyl chloride to which they may be expected. Page 30.

title: CITY TO CUT 4,700 FROM ITS PAYROLL
description: The city will reduce its payroll by more than 4,700 employes during the current fiscal year to help meet an estimated budget deficit of $190million, Budget Director Melvin Lechner said yesterday.

title: Courtroom a Witness to Boredom
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Trials almost always begin slowly; jury selection, the necessary first step, seldom provides the good theater that lawyerly combat does. But few judicial set pieces can have opened on as flat a note as today's Watergate trial.

title: U.S. Drops Charges Against 8 Policemen In Knapp Hearings
description: A Federal indictment against eight policemen resulting from the Knapp Commission investigation into police corruptionan indictment that depended on the testimony of a suspended patrolman, William R. Phillips has been withdrawn by the Government, primarily because Mr. Phillips's credibility has been brought into question.

title: Music: Flashy Pianism
description: Jonathan Miles Freeman is a spectacularly flashy pianist whose technical facility at this point (he is 23 years old) outruns his musical sophistication. A young man primarily in love with playing the piano rather than playing the music composed for it, Mr. Freeman can throw off Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue with a kind of oldfashioned virtuosity that is absolutely astonishing. He did just that at his recital on Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Hubert W. Chanler Dies; Retired Admiral Was 74
description: Rear Adm. Hubert W. Chanler, U.S.N. retired, died yesterday at Highland Hospital, Rochester. He was 74 years old and lived at Sweet Briar Farm, Geneseo, N.Y.

title: Wyszinski, at Synod in Rome, Calls East Bloc Fertile for Evangelization
description: ROME, Oct. 1Stefan Cardinal Wyszinski, the Archbishop of Warsaw, told the Synod of Bishops of the Roman CatholicChurch today that the Communist bloc was still a fertile field for evangelization despite official efforts there to discourage it.

title: SKELLY AND CLARK TO CUT GAS PRICES
description: The Skelly Oil Company of Tulsa, Okla., and a major midwest independent, Clark Oil and Refining Corporation announced yesterday a reduction of gasoline prices, following price cuts made on Monday by the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) and the Mobil Oil Corporation late last month.

title: Wilson Is Attempting to Make Inflation His Issue
description: HORSEHEADS, N.Y., Oct. 1Trying to use the inflation issue to his advantage, Governor Wilson is keying his campaign to attacks on the spending policies of Washington and the Democratic Congress and, less overtly, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's administration, which preceded the Wilson administration.

title: Dermot Morrah, Royalty Expert, Herald Extraordinary, 78, Dead
description: LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP)Dermot Morrah, an expert on British royalty and ceremony who held the title of Arundel Herald Extraordinary, died yesterday. He was 78 years old.

title: Drug Dealer Sentenced To 15 Years in Prison
description: A man identified as a major supplier of heroin and cocaine in the metropolitan area was sentenced yesterday to a maximum of 15 years in prison for scheming to import 300 pounds of narcotics in 1970 and 1971.

title: FORD'S TESTIMONY IS SET NEXT VIEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Representative William L. Hungate said today that President Ford would testify before a House subcommittee next week, no later than Thursday, about his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: PRESIDENT BACKS TRANSIT MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1President Ford gave unqualified support today to a longterm, $11billion masstransit bill and won the support of 22 Mayors and eight business and labor leaders in helping to press for legislation during this session of Congress.

title: The Economist's Editor Stoops to Conquer London's Fleet Street
description: LONDON, Sept. 28There is not literally such a thing as an ivory tower, but if there were it would be the editorial offices of The Economist. The offices occupy the 13th floor of a gleaming building in St. Sames's, one of London's ivoried neighborhoods, and its windows frame hazy views of green parks, the spires of Parliament and the cupolas of Whitehall.

title: World Football League
description: Eastern Division

title: Pratt Ban on Nude Art Protested by Faculty
description: The faculty union of Pratt Institute has filed a complaint under its contract grievance clause against the recent decision of the school's President to ban from certain of the institute's public galleries works of art that depict frontal nudity.

title: STOCKS DECLINE; INDEX DROPS 3.05
description: After three sharp declines, the stock market managed to post only a modest loss in accelerated trading yesterday.

title: Chief Judge Denies Court Backs Meskill Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The chief judge of the Second United States Circuit Court of Appeals, has denied that most of its members support the nomination of Connecticut's Gov. Thomas J. Meskill to the court.

title: Soviet Six Turns Back Canada, 32
description: MOSCOW, Oct 1The Soviet national hockey team seined an early lead and then outskated and outclassed a sputtering Team Canada tonight for a 32 victory and the upper hand in their transPacific series.

title: Police, in a Routine Car Check, Uncover $103,740 in lts Trunk
description: After six policemen spent more than seven hours counting, the Police Department's Property Clerk Division entered on its books yesterday the sum of $103,740the proceeds of a routine car check by the Auto Crime Unit. According to Lieut. Frank J.

title: Mao, 80, and Chou, 76, Absent From Celebration of 1949 Victory
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 1Chairman Mao Tsetung was absent today from celebrations in Peking marking 25 years of Communist rule, but China's aging leaders used the anniversery to put on a determined display of unity.

title: Conferees End Deadlock On Election Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Senate and House conferees worked out today a compromise to end a deadlock that had threatened to scuttle paign spending reform tion.

title: Nixon's Doctor Reports Lung Healing
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 1 The area of former President Richard M. Nixon's right lung that was damaged by a blood clot that broke off from a vein in his phlebitisdamaged left leg has partly healed and no new blood clots have lodged in either lung in the past week, Mr. Nixon's doctor said here today.

title: Podell Enters Guilty Plea, Ending Conspiracy Trial
description: Representative Bertram L. Podell suddenly ended his trial yesterday with a dramatic plea of guilty to conspiracy and conflict of interest involving $41,350 that he received for helping a small Florida airline.

title: MRS. GANDHI ASKS STRICT AUSTERITY
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 1Prime Minister Indira Gandhi urged the nation tonight to undertake strict austerity measures to cope with India's economic crisis.

description: The ideological and personality divergences inside Portugal's military leadership have finally broken the new Government apart, removing the thin facade pragmatic unity which gave the Portuguese people their best hope for achieving a stable democratic system.

title: JAMES W. GUNTER
description: James W. Gunter, a reporter and editor with Stars and Stripes, the Army newspaper, died, apparently of a heart at tack, Monday evening at his home in Odenwald, near Darmstadt, West Germany. He was 53 years old.

title: Satellite Launching Delayed
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 1 (AP)The launching of Westar II, the second domestic satellite to be operated by Western Union, has been postponed one day to Oct. 9. Space agency officials said they wanted retest a hydraulic pump motor believed to have been the cause of a weather satellite failure a year ago. The launching has been delayed several months because of problems in its Delta rocket.

title: 62Vote Loser Drops Bid for a New Election
description: Arthur J. Paone, who lost the Democratic nomination in the 15th Congressional District by 62 votes to Leo C. Zeferetti, has decided not to press for a new election.

title: Landlord in Jersey Is Guilty of Murder In 4 Arson Deaths
description: PATERSON, Oct. 1Joseph Satkin, a 49yearold Passaic landlord, was found guilty today of arson, conspiracy, and the murder of a woman and three children who died in fire set last year in three buildings he owned.

title: Chain Sales Advanced 11% in August
Dance: Polish Group
description: The Poles are back in New York, opening last night at the City Center 55th Street Theater, which, by the way, has been nicely refurbished in black and white, and given a rather peculiar new curtain. Slask is one of Poland's two major folkdance ensembles, the other being the perhaps slightly better known Mazowsze.

title: Dodgers Clinch Title
description: The Los. Angeles Dodgers. clinched the National League West Division title last night when the Atlanta Braves eliminated the Cincinnati Reds from contention with a 71 victory: Details, on Page 36.

title: Revised Rent Rule
description: Despite the complaint of some tenant groups that their members will need a seeingeye dog to steer them through the formula's complexities, the revised rules for rent increases in 400,000 formerly decontrolled apartments are much fairer than those originally promulgated by the city's Rent Guidelines Board.

title: Report Intensifies a BreastCancer Dispute
description: A preliminary report on a new study of breast cancer surgery has intensified a decadeslong international controversy over how much surgery a breast cancer patient must undergo to have the best chance for a cure.

title: Redskin Victory Revives '72 Memories
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1At last a shaft of light seemed to shine on George Allen here last night as the harassed coach's team, the Redskins, defeated the Denver Broncos, 303, and played hack to the form of their marvelous Super Bowl year of 1972.

title: A Collection That Puts Museum in the Select Class
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1No less than artists or works of art, collections, too, acquire their aura of legend, mystery and scandal. This was certainly the case with the collection of Joseph H. Hirshhorn. Long before it was offered as a gift to the nation, this vast repository of modern painting and sculpture was talked about joked about, attacked, defended and otherwise dilated both in and out of the parochial purlieus of the art world.

title: 10% OIL TARIFF PLAN REPORTED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 1 (Reuters)The Senate Finance Committee is considering a plan to impose a 10 per cent tariff on the price of imported oil, informed Senate sources said today, A copy of the proposal was made available to Reuters.

title: HUNTING WORLD WINS ABERCROMBIE SUIT
description: Judge Sylvestor J. Ryan of the United States Court for the Southern District ruled on Monday in favor of The Hunting World in connection with a fiveyearold suit filed against that New York store by Aber. crombie & Fitch. Abercrombie had charged that the Hunting World infringed on the Safari trademark owned by Abercrombie.

title: FORD'S TESTIMONY IS SET NEXT WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Act. 1Representative William L. Hungate said today that President Ford would testify before a House subcommittee next week, no later than Thursday, about his pardon of former President Richard M, Nixon.

title: Prices Decline for Soybean Futures
description: The s??eady upward trend in soybean prices ended late in the session yesterday, when speculators sold futures contracts in enough volume to lower price below Monday's level on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: VENEZUELA RAISES OIL TAXES SHARPLY
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 1 The Venezuelan Government today increased the taxes it charges United States and other foreign oil companies operating here, and said the increase would be retroactive to Jan. 1.

title: People in Sports
description: Chris Evert and Jimmy Connors, tennis's most famlove birds, have decided to postpone their wedding although they are still very much in love, according to Miss Evert's father. The tennis stars were scheduled to be married in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Nov. 8.

title: FIRST STEP TAKEN ONCARTERRETRIAL
description: PATERSON, N. J. Oct. 1Affidavits from two prosecution witnesses who admitted they lied at the 1967 triplemurder trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, a former boxing star, and another man were filed in Superior Court here today as defense lawyers took the first legal step to win a new trial.

title: ' The Night Porter,' Portrait of Abuse, Stars Bogarde
description: If you don't love pain, you won't find "The Night Porter" eroticand by now, even painbuffs may be satiated with Nazi decadence. The movie, which opened yesterday at the Baronet, reunites a former SS officer (Dirk Bogarde) and a young woman (Charlotte Rampling) who was raped by him during her adolescence in a concentration camp. In Vienna, in 1957, they enthusiastically resume their old sadomasochistic relationship, which includes a taste for broken glass.Since the director, Liliana Cavani, made a four-hour documentary on the Third Reich for Italian television, she has a robust background in fascism. Yet her new movie is romantic about abuse. The anguish of the prisoners in the camps is exploited simply for the sake of sensationalismgiven the serial motifs of the film, their suffering is almost made to seem chic. And when Mr. Bogarde and Miss Rampling relive their common past in flashbacks, the titillating build-up to the rape scene is accompanied by "The Magic Flute," which both characters are hearing: Pamina and Tamino sing pledges of undying love while the cruelties grow more intricate. If the friends of Mozart decide to picket on his behalf, I'll be among them.Is this slab of opulent claptrap worth any serious consideration? Yes, because of the talents involvedmainly Mr. Bogarde's. Sensuality and austerity meet and mingle in the face of this impeccable authoritarian, and his silken moments alternate with harsh ones. He's best when he's reservedhis outbursts aren't always successfuland there are a few too many sly, slow smiles. But he's skilled at hiding his feelings from the characters around him while revealing all of his emotions to the audience. When it occurs to him to murder someone, his rigid poise lapses, and he becomes socially awkward  slightly embarrassed and ingratiating at the same time. Occasionally, you recall his performance in "The Servant," but his range is much wider here.Miss Rampling's elegant sternness and low, bitter voice are suitable for her role, but she's a one-dimensional actress who can't convey much beyond tension. Toward the end, she produces one sulky scowl that makes you grateful for a new facial expression. Also, she has the world's most unconvincing laugh  especially when making love. Credibility is a problem throughout the' picturepartly because of Miss Rampling's styles of response. In a scene where she's literally fettered, someone tries to break into her lover's apartment, and she rattles her chains like an apprehensive hostess  just as a nervous partygiver may fidget with her jewelry before the guests arrive."The Night Porter" is handsomely filmed in dark, rich tones. But the movie's visual virtues are negated by infinite absurditiesparticularly by the sentimentality with which the director views this luckless couple. Near the finish, we even catch a whiff of an old Hollywood formula, which asks us to regard these lovers as poignant  because the world won't allow them to enjoy each other in peace.All in all, the image that recurs is that of sucking a wound. Meanwhile, if you're in the market for masochism, see Luis Buuel's "Belle de Jour" again, or revisit Bernardo Bertolucci's "The Conformist" for fascist decay. Granted that both are classics. But that's why "The Night Porter" shouldn't be allowed to ride on their reputation.

title: Caesar,' a Foolish Film, Seen at Fete
description: "Rome Wants Another Caesar," which was shown at the New York Film Festival last night and will be repeated this evening, comes quite close to being a hysterically funny bad film, a movie of such ridiculous pretentions that it restores a lofty reputation to philistinism.It is an Italian production directed by Miklos Janeso, the Hungarian who once made two good films, "The Roundup" and "The Red and The White," which seemed to be pioneering a new kind of epic film making. What impressed many of us about those two early films was the director's extraordinary ability to turn complex historical events into personal political dramas of intense lyricism. In his recent films, Mr. Janeso has pursued his spectacular camera-techniques to a point of no return. The only memorable thing about "Winter Wind," shown here in 1970, was that the entire film consisted of 12 takes (compared to a couple of hundred in an ordinary film). "Red Psalm," shown at the 1972 New York Film Festival, was done in 26 takes. The style added nothing to the movie. it was the movie."Rome Wants Another Caesar" looks not quite so inhibited, but it may be Mr. Janeso's most sincerely witless work. It's about some Roman revolutionaries in Numidia in North Africa during the last days of the Roman republic, plotting to assassinate the Roman proconsul and arguing among themselves.That is what it is about, but what we see is a kind of junior high school pageant with a dozen European actors on location in Tunisia, wearing funny looking costumes and carrying swords as if they were eels. That is, awkwardly. Holding hands and dancing around statues of Caesar, they get off such mind-benders as "The wise man knows that without enemies it's impossible to create friends."Mr. Janeso isn't really much interested in ancient Rome. He keeps making lugubrious parallels between revolutionaries then and now. Instead of illuminating his subject, he buries it in sand. What the movie is doing in the New York Film Festival, I can't imagine. It is to serious film making what knitting is to a benched football player.It's fooling around.

title: REAGAN DISCLOSES LARGE INVESTMENTS
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 1 (UPI)For the first time, Goy. Ronald Reagan has disclosed that he has large real estate, manufacturing and oil company investments.

title: Recantations to Face a 3Part Test
description: In 1960, three men were convicted of killing a patron of New Jersey tavern. Shortly after the jury verdict, two of the men recanted their prior statements implicating the third man and said that the third man had been an unwilling participant in the murder. But in 1962, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that the two had little to lose by recanting and it denied the third man a new trial.

title: Maw's Music Introduced by Ormandy
Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: About New York
description: It's all the regulars and reformers getting together, Robert F. Wagner was saying. They're all getting together now, and then they'll all fight when we leave. The former Mayor was smiling and standing next to Hugh L. Carey, who was smiling and standing next to Frank Rossetti.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GERMANS AND SHEPHERDS. In this still new fall art season, with museums and galleries in Soho and uptown blooming with upcoming artists, it can he altogether exhilarating to rediscover an array of fondly remembered perennials. This particular crop is in the thirdfloor Paul J. Sachs Gallery at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: AutoUse Tax Is Taken For a Ride by Battista
description: Assemblyman Vito P. Battista, Brooklyn RepublicanConservative, took to a horse and buggy on Broadway opposite City Hall to dramatize his demand for the repeal of the city's $15 auto use tax, which went into effect yesterday.

title: Turnpike Police to Ticket Noisy Vehicles
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Oct. 1 State troopers patrolled the New Jersey. Turnpike today ready to hand out summonses to enforce the antinoise code recently adopted by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

title: St. Louis Loses to 2Run Clout
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 1  A tworun homer by Mike Jorgensen of the Montreal Expos in the eighth inning sank the St. Louis Cardinals, 32, tonight and dimmed their chances for a National League East Division championship. With the Pittsburgh Pirates overcoming the Chicago Cubs, 65, the Cardinals were one game behind the Pirates with only one game left for each club.

title: Price of Gold Increases by $5 For 2Day Rise of $10 an Ounce
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 1 (UPI) The price of gold rose another $5 today, for a twoday gain of more than $10. The dollar declined on international money markets.

title: Rights Leader Surrenders
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 1 (UPI)The Rev. Hosea L. Williams, contending that the Federal Government wants to silence him, surrendered today to the Federal authorities on a charge of trying to take a pistol aboard an airplane. He was released without bond pending arraignment Friday. Mr. Williams, head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, here said that he disarmed a wino at the organization's free soup kitchen March 8 and forgot the man's .38caliber Colt Commando was still in his attach case the next morning when he went to board a flight to Pittsburgh.

title: UNIONIST TRAINING MOVES TO CAMPUS
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., Oct The A.F.L.C.I.O. will open a $6.5million Labor Studies Center here Sunday to provide unionists with practical training for the increasingly complex responsibilities they face in labor relations.

title: Trial in Oakland Slaying Delayed Until NextMonth
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. (UPI) The murder trial of two alleged members of the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army who are charged with Slyoting Oakland's school superintendent last year was delayed today until next month.Superior Court Judge Harold B. Hove said The was awaiting a State Supreme. Court ruling on whether the trial should be moved bedause of the publicity over the kidnapping of Patricia Hearst.

title: West Orange in Agreement Over Fire Fighter Cutback
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 1 (UPI)West Orange firemen met with Mayor William Cuozzi today to resolve differences caused by the Mayor's plan to economize by cutting the size of the Fire Department.

title: A Canadian Family's Battle With Inflation
description: POINTECLAIRE, Quebec,  Karl Benne, a 35yearold social worker, is stuffing $40 worth of extra insulation into the attic of his fall in an attempt to bring down the soaring cost of heating.

title: ROBLEMS CITED AT WILLOWBROOK
description: The president of the American Association on Mental Deficiencies testified in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday that conditions at the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded were in some ways worse last summer than they were two years ago when conditions at the Staten Island institution first gained widespread public notice.

title: A National Debate On Cuba Ties Asked Senator Buckley
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, called today for a national debate before the United States improves relations with Cuba.

title: FORD IS SET BACK BY SENATE AGAIN; CHILE AID CUT OFF
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Senate handed the Ford Administration a series of setbacks today by voting to cut off military aid to Chile, stop fertilizer shipments to South Vietnam and affirm its military aid cutoff to Turkey, despite the threat of a Presidential veto.

title: People and Business
description: The computer industry has long been described as a young man's business. Apparently the board of Honeywell, Inc., took that into consideration yesterday when it shook up top management.

title: U.S. Atom Aid in Mideast Tied to Facility Inspection
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The United States has proposed that Egypt and Israel agree to place all future nuclear facilities and materials under international inspection as a condition for receiving American atomic power plants.

title: Conferees End Deadlock On Election Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Senate and House conferees worked out today a compromise to end a deadlock that had threatened to scuttle campaign spending reform legislation.

title: Inflation, the Foe
description: Following are excerpts from a letter that Lord Rothschild, a former biologist at Cambridge University, sent to Prime Minister Wilson of Britain in connection with his retirement as director of the Government's Central Policy Review Staff, or think tank. Lord Rothschild's retirement was announced earlier this year.

title: A Fortress of a Building That Works as Museum
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1No visitors to the Joseph H. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden will have to be given one of those floor plans that are the only key to the labyrinthine corridors of traditional museums like the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Here the plan, a circle, is simple and instantly comprehensible, and that is one of the new museum's assets. It is very hard to get lost in the Hirshhorn.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A convicted murderer, his wealthy father and a lawyer were indicted by a Nassau County grand jury on charges that they conspired to kill three persons who had been witnesses in the trial that resulted in the murder conviction and a life sentence.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1974

title: S.E.C. Accuses 3 Philips Men of Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed fraud charges yesterday against three executives of the North American Philips Corporation, alleging that they had bought Magnavox shares on the basis of inside information shortly before Philips announced an offer for all the shares of Magnavox.

title: A Fortress of a Building That Works as Museum
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1No visitors to the Joseph H. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden will have to be given one of those floor plans that are the only key to the labyrinthine corridors of traditional museums like the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Here the plan, a circle, is simple and instantly comprehensible, and that is one of the new museum's assets. It is very hard to get lost in the Hirshhorn.

title: Views of Brokers Mixed on 4 P.M. Close for Trading
description: Wall Street's experiment to extend trading by 30 minutes a day in an effort to produce more revenue for hardpressed stockbrokers got under way here yesterday, but the reaction among brokersdespite a strong increase in Big Board trading was mixed.

title: Grateful Man Wills Library $368,000
description: When the New York Public Library received $368,000 last year from the estate of a man named Martin Radtke, officials wondered who he was.

title: U.S. Ideas For Action Offered at Weekend Oil Parley
description: The United States has reportedly put forth specific ideas to the major oil importers to deal with the problems caused by the high costs of oil and help prepare the way for an eventual meeting of consuming and producing countries.

title: 12 TigerCage Protesters Seized Outside U.S. Mission
description: Twelve persons, including five women, were arrested yesterday on charges of disorderly conduct after they had placed a socalled tiger cage on the sidewalk outside the United States Mission to the United Nations at 44th Street and First Avenue.

title: Hospitals Bar All 33 Demands, Internes and Residents Assert
description: The Committee on Internes and Residents, which represents staff doctors in 35 New York City public and private hospitals, said yesterday that Management had rejected each of its 33 labor demands, and the committee's leaders threatened to intervene in hospital accreditation. The old contract expired at midnight Monday.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Clio and the Doctors: PsychoHistory, QuantoHistory and History, by Jacques Barzun (University of Chicago Press, $7.95). An Inquiry into the spirit of history.

title: NO OIL PRICE RISE SET BY INDONESIA
description: The Indonesian state oil company, Pertamina, said yesterday, that it had decided not to raise petroleum prices this quarter, marking the first quarter since the oil crisis began in October that the company has not announced price increases.

title: Books of The Times
description: LION BY THE TAIL: The Story of the ItalianEthiopian War. By Thomas M. Coffey. 360 pages. New York: The Viking Press. $12.50.

title: Drug Found in Trotter Traced to Caffeine in Soda Pop
description: A 25cent can of soda his turned into an $875 headache for the handlers of a trottez who finished second in a rade at Batavia Downs last Sept. 5.

title: Baltimore Run in 9th Beats Tigers, 76
description: DETROIT, Oct. 1  Seven hours after winning an eventful day game, 76, from the Detroit Tigers, the Baltimore Orioles emerged tonight as champions of American League East when the New York Yankees lost their night game in Milwaukee.

title: Big Nations Divide On Coping With Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Despite a clear and widespread wish to cooperate, important differences emerged today among the world's leading industrial nations on how to cope with the massive problem caused by higher oil prices and other financial strains in the world's economy. The occasion was the second day of the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Speeches by delegates from major nations, and later elaboration by high officials, revealed gaps in philosophy on how to deal with the problem.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Atlantic City (Steel Pier), deduct 26 min, from Sandy Hook time.

title: ESCAPED MURDERER ACQUITTED IN KILLING
description: A State Supreme Court jury has acquitted the man it knows as Louis Velazquez of a murder charge while convicting him of robbery and possession of a weapon.

title: GRAND UNION CO. RAISES EARNINGS
description: The Grand Union Company reported yesterday increased sales and operating earnings for the quarter and halfyear periods ended Aug. 31. The final, income however, was only moderately higher in the quarter but lower in the six months compared with last year betause of special charges.

title: Burial for Reform?
description: The House power barons are at it again. Just as the report of the bipartisan select committee on reorganization of the House of Representatives finally got to the floor for debate, superbaron Wilbur Mills tried to yank it back behind the closed doors of the Democratic Caucus to give it an indecent private burial. Having failed in that, opponents of reform are now trying to talk it to death.

title: Dodgers Win Title; Reds Out
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Steve Garvey keyed two rallies, one with his 200th hit of the season, to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to an 85 victory over the Houston Astros tonight as Los Angels won the National League West title.

title: State Department Criticizes Seoul's Policies on Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)The State Department said today that we do not approve of South Korea's policies on human rights.

title: Knicks Beaten; Walton: 6
description: Bill Walton, with his red hair, ponytail, knee pads and milliondollar reputation came to Madison Square Garden for the first time last night. All he forgot was his shooting eye, but he made up for it in many ways as he helped the Portland Trail Blazers to a 10093 victory over the Knicks.

title: Connecticut Electric Companies Overcharged, Mrs. Grasso Says
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 1Connecticut's three major electric power companies overcharged customers in the last year by $11million, United States Representative Ella T. Grasso said today.

title: Debate on B1 Bomber Expected to Intensify
description: Controversy over the Air Force's intercontinental B1 nuclear uclear bomber is expected to intensify with new Pentagon estimates that each aircraft will cost $76million, an increase of $14.5milion over the previous estimate.

title: MENTAL TEST DUE IN POLICE SLAYING
description: Julio Vasquez, the suspect arested in the dismemberment murder of Police Officer Patrick V. Kelly, was sent to the Bellevue Hospital Center for a psychiatric examination after his arraignment yesterday.

title: Makarios, at U.N., Rejects A Federation for Cyprus
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1Archbishop Makarios, the exiled President of Cyprus, in an address to the United Nations General Assembly today, sternly denounced Turkey as an aggressor, and rejected geographical federation as a means for bringing peace to the island.

title: Visit of President To Congress Panel To Be 2d in History
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1President Ford's scheduled testimony before a house subcommittee would mark only the second time that an incumbent President had appeared in person before a panel of Congress, according to research done last year by the Library of Congress.

title: Havana Caper
description: The restoration of normal relations with Cuba is something this newspaper has long advocated; but we don't think Senator Javits' and Senator Pell's weekend Havana was a very good way of furthering that goal.

title: Notes on People
description: As expected, routinely and by voice vote, the Senate yesterday confirmed the nomination of Richard L. Roudehush, former United States Representative from Indiana, to be the Veterans Administrator. The former lawmaker, a Republican, replaces Donald E. Johnson as head of the vast bureaucracy that is the Veterans Administration.

title: Advertising
description: General Cigar's Tiparillo, the nation's best  selling tipped cigar, is introducing new packaging in a way its marketing people consider novel for the industry. It'll be: Buy an oldstyle five pack and get a new one free.

title: Drug Arrests Reach 151
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 1 (UPI) The number of arrests in series of drug raids scattered among 23 North Carolina counties reached 151 today, the State Bureau of Investigation reported.

title: A GRUMMAN LOAN BY 11 BANKS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (Reuters)The financially ailing Grumman Corporation, a major aerospace company, has obtained nearly $200million in bank credit, sources disclosed today.

title: Nations Report a Drop In Tourism This Year
description: PARIS, Oct. 1 (Reuters)  Tourism fell substantially this year in most of the world's developed countries because of the oil crisis and the worsening international economic situation, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has reported.

title: U.S. Atom Aid in Mideast Tied to Facility Inspection
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The United States has proposed that Egypt and Israel agree to place all future nuclear facilities and materials under international inspection as a condition for reiceiving American atomic power II plants.

title: An Explosive Mixture
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Damon Runyon, the great sports writer once said that where the human race is concerned, the odds are 9 to 5 against. An observer at the current annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund would see no reason to quarrel with that conclusion.

title: Nigeria Drops Pledge of Civil Rule by '76
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 1 (Agence FrancePresse)Nige ria announced today that she would not adhere to a promise to return to civilian government in 1976.

title: Red Smith
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1In the last 47 years, the Pittsburgh Pirates have had either 17 or 20. managers, depending on how you count Daniel Edward Murtaugh, who has taken the job four times and given it back thrice, Over that span they have won two world championships, both under Murtaugh's direction; two National League pennants, both under Murtaugh; and three halfpennants, two under Murtaugh. When Manager Murtaugh completed this moist and chilly night's work, the Pirates had a onegame lead in the East with one more game to play. He manages funny, too, a visitor had observed to Bob Skinner, the coach. This was in midafternoon when only three or four Pittsburgh players and none of the Chicago Cubs had arrived in Three Rivers Stadium. Skinner and the visitor were in the doorway of the manager's empty office. He waits till Sept. 30 to let Bruce Kison pitch nine innings, and Kison throws a fourhitter. He sets Richie Zisk down because he's in a slump, then calls him off the bench and Zisk triples for the winning run. He ... migiwd, this is Dapper Dan?

title: Janet Roth, 61, a Founder Of B'nai B'rith Women's Unit
description: Janet Falk Roth, wife of Chester M. Roth, the board, chairman of the KayserRoth Corporation, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 61 years old and lived in Purchase, N. Y., and in the Pierre Hotel.

title: Podell Enters Guilty Plea, Ending Conspiracy Trial
description: Representative Bertram L. Podell suddenly ended his trial yesterday with a dramatic plea of guilty to conspiracy and conflict of interest involving $41,350 that he received for helping a small Florida airline.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Whatever one may feel about the character of Richard Nixon, he certainly achieved two most important goals for this country. The first was extricating us from the Vietnam war and the second was the dtente he achieved with Russia and China.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS FELL 7.3% IN MONTH
description: DETROIT, Oct. 1American auto production, at 667,944 units last month, fell 7.3 per cent from 720,822 in September, 1973.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Frank Robinson will be named playing manager of the Cleveland Indians tomorrow, thereby becoming the first black manager in major league baseball history, United Press International reported yesterday. Robinson's salary will remain at its present $173,000 level, automatically making him the highestpaid manager in the history of baseball.

title: Magazine on Breeding and Matching of Pit Dogs Under Inquiry
description: STARKE, Fla.,  As magazines go, Pit Dogs, which is published periodically and regularly in this little town a few miles from Gainesville, seems rather skimpy.

title: Robertson Belt Assures Tie
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1Bob Robertson of the Pirates. swung at a pitch, hit a tworun homer and called it fate. Some might look at Manager Danny Murtaugh and call it Irish luck or just plain genius.

title: FORD IS SET BACK BY SENATE AGAIN; CHILE AID CUT OFF
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Senate handed the Ford Administration a series of setbacks today by voting to cut off military aid to Chile, stop fertilizer shipments to South Vietnam and affirm its military aid cutoff to Turkey, despite the threat of a Presidential veto.

title: Market Place Lender of Last Resort
description: Since the nation's businesses are clamoring for money to build needed plants and the capital markets and the banks seems to provide less and less, perhaps it is time to find an alternative method of providing the necessary money.

title: Kent State Trial Reset
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 (UPI)Chief Justice Frank 3, Battisti of the United States District Court here has moved the trial of eight former Ohio National Guardsmen, charged with violating the civil rights of Kent State University students in May, 1970, back to Oct. 21, from Oct. 15.

title: Bridge: CueBid an Ambiguous Term With At Least 3 Variations
description: The most ambitious of all technical terms in the bridge lexicon is the cuebid. It is regrettable that bridge writers have never managed to achieve a terminological separation of the two main varieties: The lowlevel cuebid in the opponents' suit that simply indicates a desire to be in game without making any promises about the suit bid; and the highlevel cuebid, at the gamelevel or above in a suit that cannot be trumps, to show some control and slam interest.

title: Extradition Proceedings Begun On Coast for Suspect in 5 Rapes
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 1  Hudson County Prosecutor James O'Holleran said today his office had begun extradition proceedings against Arthur W. Smith, the California truck driver suspected of raping five Hudson and Union County women last month while he allegedly was in New Jersey on longdistance truck deliveries.

title: Amax Plans to Use Output Of Coal Minesfor Repayment
description: Amax, Inc., said yesterday that it planned to use the output of 12 of its coal mines to repay a $200million companywide expansion program that would go toward financing expansion of its various enterprises. The program will take the form of coal production payment of which the initial installment will be $25million, which Amax can draw down as needed.

title: Grateful Man Wills Library $368,000
description: When the New York Public Library received $368,000 last year from the estate of a man named Martin Radtke, officials wondered who he was.

title: A.M.P.I IN ACCORD ON ANTITRUST CASE
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct, 1Associated Milk Producers, Inc., agreed today to a judgment awarding the state of Texas $230,000 in civil penalties under state antitrust laws. A.M.P.I. also agreed to a pernrnent injunction restraining the dairy farm cooperative, which is based in San Antonio, Tex., from discriminating against haulers, farmers and processers in any fashion

title: Pakistan Warns Guerrillas In Baluchistan to Yield
description: RAWALPINDI,Pakistan, Oct. 1 (AP)The Pakistani Government said today that if guerrillas in Baluchistan province did not respond to an Oct. 15 deadline to come down from the hills, then we will }ave to hit with whatever we have got.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: 2 Call for Little Rabbit, Then Slay 2 on East Side
description: Two men were shot to death early yesterday in an East Side nightclub after two gunmen burst in and reportedly called out, Little Rabbit, where are you?

title: Landlord in Jersey Is Guilty of Murder In 4 Arson Deaths
description: PATERSON, Oct. 1Joseph Satkin, a 49yearold Passaid landlord, was found guilty to day of arson, conspiracy and the murder of a woman and three children who died in a fire set last year in three buildings he owned.

title: EXREP. C. G. M'INTIRE OF MAINE DIES AT 66
description: BANGOR, Me., Oct. 1Former United States Representative Clifford G. McIntire died here today in the Eastern Maine Medical Center. He was 66 years old.

title: LEONARD LARSON, '61 HEAD OF A.M.A.
description: Dr. Leodard W. Larson, president of the American Medical Association in 1961 and an advocate of a sound system of voluntary prepayment for medical services,, died Monday at Bismarck, N.D. He was 76 years old.

title: Cunningham Scores 6 As 76er
description: BINGHAMTON, Oct. 1, N.Y. (AP)Julius Erving poured in 25 points tonight to lead the New York Nets to a 10698 victory over Philadelphia in exhibition game that saw Billy Cunningham return to the 76ers.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1974

title: POTENTIAL JURORS QUERIED AS TRIAL IN COVERUP OPEN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  The trial of the Watergate coverup case began today, bringing to a court of law the events that caused a twoyear national trauma and then, on Aug. 9, forced Richard M. Nixon from the Presidency.

title: Waiting For Jerry
description: In the normal switch from one American President to another; the new man has about ten weeks between election and inauguration to figure out where he's going and who's going with him; but Gerald Ford was an instant President who had to put, the ball in the air before anybody knew the signals.

title: ExFlorida Official Holds Lead In Democratic Race for Senate
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 1 Richard Stone, a Miami and Tallahassee businessman, appeered late tonight to have won the Democratic nomination for the Senate in Florida.

title: POTENTIAL JURORS QUERIED AS TRIAL IN COYERUP OPENS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  The trial of the Watergate coverup case began today, bringing to a court of law the events that caused a twoyear national trauma and then, on Aug. 9, forced Richard M. Nixon from the Presidency.

title: Gracie Mansion Feast For Restaurant City
description: Mary Beame walked up to a hot dog vendor who was grilling Nathan's Famous in a tent on her lawn at Gracie Mansion and asked: You got a hot one for me?

title: SENATE SHELVES FOREIGN AID BILL IN FORD VICTORY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Senate upheld the Ford Administration tonight by voting to shelveat least until after the November electionsthis year's controversial $2.5billion foreign aid bill. The vote was 41 to 39.

title: Saving on Oil
description: The top financial officials of the world's industrial nations have been grappling all week with the problem of how to gain control of a worsening global economic situation but have not yet found a common approach.

title: Bonn Sees West Closer to Unity on oil
description: BONN, Oct. 2While German Foreign Ministry officials have been keeping closemouthed about what happened at last weekend's fivepower energy conference in Washington, the Germans are known to believe that the Western world is closer than before to a unified approach to the oilprice problem.

title: Bridge: Choosers of an Opening Lead Are Divided Into 3 Groups
description: In choosing an opening lead from three small cards, bridge players are divided, like Gaul, into three parts. The majority group, including almost all rubber bridge players and the largest segment of tournament players, leads high. We can call them traditionalists.

title: Buckley Offers a Bill to End Curbs on the Price of NewFound Natural Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Senator James L. Buckley has introduced legislation to deregulate the price of newly discovered natural gas.

title: ShowTrial by Proxy
description: WASHINGTONThe publicity extravaganza that opened in Federal Courthouse here this week is the most inherently unfair trial in many a year: The accused faced the wrong charge in the wrong place before the wrong judge.

title: World Football League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: FOE ASSAILS CAHN ON ACQUITTAL RATE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 2 Denis Dillon, the Democratic candidate for Nassau County District Attorney, said today that comparison of the District Attorney's offices in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties showed that Nassau had the highest percentage of acquittals and cases dismissed by the court before trial and the lowest percentage of convictions.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Nelson and Diane Sloane, a 72yearold Lakehurst man and his 24yearold wife, were accused of trying to rob Toms River drug store at gunpoint. The police said that Mrs. Sloan had entered the store armed with a handgun and demanded the cash in the register while her husband waited outside in their car with the motor running. Mrs. Sloan apparently panicked when a bystander knocked the' gun from her hand, the police said, and she ran from the store. Her husband crashed the car into a median.

title: Ailing Freedom National Bank Gets a New Chief
description: A vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank was named yesterday as president and chief executive of the ailing Freedom National Bank in Harlem, and he immediately pledged to change the whole posture of that institution.

title: EXAIDE OF PENNSY HAZY ON '70 FACTS
description: David C. Devan, former financial chief for the Penn Central Transportation Company, took the witness stand under subpoena here yesterday but failed to shed much new light to help a jury decide whether Goldman, Sachs & Co., the pestigious investment banking house, should be made to reimburse three investors who lost money on Penn Central commercial paper when the railroad went bankrupt.

title: Of Oil and the West
description: To the Editor: Consuming less oil will not bring down world oil prices. The cartel cuts. production, as it has done this summer. And the longer the cartel goyernments are permitted to accumulate revenues, the easier for them to manage future cutbacks or embargoes.

title: OPPOSITION SCORNS DEFENSE BY THIEU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2Opposition politicians reacted today with disappointment, anger and scorn to a policy speech delivered last night by President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: Artificial Sea Usec To Fight Oil Spills
description: LEONARDO, N.J., Oct. 2  A 2.6million gallon test tank, longer than two football fields and described the largest and among the most advanced of its kind, was dedicated here today by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency in an effort to find better ways of handling what the agency called the nation's intolerable number of oil spills.

title: STATE TO MONITOR MENTAL PATIENTS
description: Governor Wilson yesterday announced a new state mentalhealth program that he said would provide for careful followup and treatment of all patients released from state mental institutions into community facilities for rehabilitation.

title: Pelham One Two Three, Starring Matthau, Catches the City's Mood
description: THE TAKING OF PELHAM ONE TWO THREE; directed by Joseph Sargent; screenplay, Peter Stone, based on the novel by John Godey; director of photography, Owen Holzman; editors, Gerald Greenberg and Robert Q. Lovett; music, David Shire; producers, Edgar J. Scherick and Gabriel Katzka; released by United Artists; a Palomar Pictures and Palladium Productions presentation. At the Criterion Theater, Broadway at 45th Street, and the 86th Street East z Theater at Third Avenue. Running time: 102 minutes. This film is classified R.

title: Mrs. Peron Calls Parley of Leaders As Violence Rises
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2 (UPI) President Isabel Martinez de Pern decided today to call meeting of Argentine leaders from all walks of life to try to do something about. a rising wave of political murders,

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Ed Reinecke was given a suspendled 18month sentence today, only minutes after aides submitted his formal resignation as Lieutenant Governor of California.

title: STATE TO MONITOR MENTAL PATIENTS
description: Governor Wilson yesterday announced a new state mentalhealth program that he said would provide for careful followup and treatment, of all patients released from state mental institutions into community facilities for rehabilitation.

description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 2 (AP)Tom Van Arsdile and Fred Boyd combined for 35 points tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers surged from a halftime tie to beat the New York Nets, champions of the American Basketball Association, 10989.

description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 2Richard Stone, a Tallahassee and Miami businessman, has emerged as the surprise winner in the runoff yesterday for the Democratic Senate nomination and is now favored to win election to the Senate next month.

title: Coronado Dancers, In 7 Solos, Display Desire for Repose
description: The dancers of Jose Coronado's company spent an inordinate amount of time lying on the floor of the Cubiculo during Mr. Coronado's dance concert on Tuesday evening. Creative use of stillness is one thing, but this looked like an attack of sleeping sickness.

title: TV: New Sports Series
description: Television needs another sports show about as urgently as radio needs another rockmusic station, but logic has rarely been triumphant over opportunism in the broadcasting industry. So now, on the Public Broadcasting Service, of all places, there is a 13week series of halfhours called The Way It Was.

title: BANK FAILURE HITS TRACER OF NAZIS
description: VIENNA, Oct. 2The Jewis?? Documentation Center, which Simon Wiesenthal runs here for tracing Nazi criminals, lost the equivalent of nine months operating expenses through the collapse last month of ?? Austrian bank.

title: Koch Urges 2Cent Tax On Cigarettes for Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) Cigarette smokers would help finance the fight against cancer under a proposal that would put an additional 2cent tax on each pack of cigarettes.

description: TRENTON, Oct. 2Governor Byrne signed into law today the socalled right to conscience abortion bill permitting physicians, nurses and hospitals to refuse to perform elective abortions, but he acknowledged that the controversial measure may go too far.

title: India, Badly Needing Aid, Hails Visiting Shah of Iran
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 2The Shah of Iran arrived here today on the last leg of a 17day tour of five Asian and Pacific nations.

title: 2 Die in Riot in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2 (Reuters)Two persons were kiled and more than 200 arrested after a daylong riot in southeastern Mexico, the police said today. The riot began yesterday morning in Oaxaca as a protest against the rising cost of living.
