description: Prof. Spyridon Marinatos, former inspector general of Greece's Archeological Services, has died in a fall on the Aegean island of Thera. He was 73 years old.

title: Boy, 5, Left Alone In Apartment Here, Is Killled in a Fire
description: A 5yearold boy, left first by his mother in care of his sister and then by his sister in care of friends who then allegedly left him alone, died yesterday of smoke inhalation after fire broke out in the Manhattan apartment he shared with all of them, the police said.

title: Villemure Decides to Unretire
description: Gilles Villemure, the tough little Ranger goalie who announced his retirement on Tuesday, said last night, I'm going hack to work tomorrow.

title: Mondale Tells of a Surge In Support for 1976 Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)  Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that financial commitments to his unannounced Presidential campaign surged in the week following the withdrawal announcement from the race of Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: CHINA, IN U.N., HAILS ARABS' OIL WEAPON
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2  China today praised the Arab countries' use of oil as a political weapon.

title: Meat Prices Fall, but City Sees Bad Omen, Not Welcome Trend
description: The prices for most meats dropped sharply last week, lowering the overall cost of feeding a family here, but consumer agencies interpreted the price decline as a portent of bad things rather than a sign of a trend to lower prices.

title: A Venetian Festival at Kennedy Center
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1It is only three years since the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts opened its doors with the premiere of Leonard Bernstein's Mass. That event turned out to be more symbolic than it seemed at the time. It had something of everything in it, old and new, traditional and experimental, music, dance, theater. This became the content of the center's presentations in its three main auditoriums, and the place has flourished as a good many people did not expect it might in a city of moderate pretensions where the performing arts were concerned.

title: Rockefeller, Substituting for Ford, Speaks in Utah and California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2Nelson A. Rockefeller made his first public appearance in a VicePresidentiallike role today, substituting for President Ford at a university in Utah and a convention here despite what the former New York Governor described as his suspended status.

title: Buffalo Show of Max Bill Introduces Artist to U.S.
description: BUFFALO  Among the European artists of his generationhe was born in 1908 Max Bill has always had a place of his own. It is not, however, a place that has been well defined. Nor is it one that has been universally recognized. Only now, with a show that has just opened at the Albright  Knox Art Gallery here and will travel later to Los Angeles and San Francisco.

title: Britain and Spain Spar At U.N. Over Gibraltar
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2  Spain and Britain clashed over Gibraltar today at the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Kissinger Ends Consultations on Mideast
description: Secretary of State Kissinger wound up his consultations with officials from the Middle East yesterday in advance of his fiveday trip to the area next week to spur further negotiations between Israel and her Arab neighbors.

title: Boy Dies, 6 Burned
description: CRANSTON, R. I., Oct. 2 (UPI)One boy was killed and at least six others were severely burned at the Rhode Island Training School tonight when they were trapped in a windowless day room that they had set fire, school officials said. Officials said two boys, placed on punishment detail for setting fire to a mattress earlier in the day, barricaded the dayroom with pool tables. Five other boys were in the room.

title: Champlin Plans Expansion
description: ENID, Okla., Oct. 2 (UPI)The Champlin Petroleum Corporation announced today a $28million expansion for its Enid refinery and said the project, with engineering already under way, would be completed within two years.

title: Most Women Want Status Improved, Poll Finds
description: A majority of American women now favor efforts to improve their status in society, according to a nationwide poll released yesterday.

title: 2 Trades Helped Dodgers
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers got a chance, in 1974, to replay their disappointing season of 1973, and this time they made it come out right.

title: Film Festival: Kluge's 'Part-Time Work of a Domestic Slave' and Chabrol's 'Bench of Desolation'
description: She drops the plates, he glowers, the children wail, he says the house is a pigsty. He even reproaches her for the kind of bread she buys. He's furious when she leaves the house for work, and the children tend to build dangerous little fires in her absence. There's no apparent friendliness in this marriagethe man and woman seem to share only a nose-wrinkling disgust. As a chemist who prefers research to wageearning, he lets her support him by performing abortionswhich he deplores.From the content, you might think that Alexander Kluge's "Part-Time Work of a Domestic Slave"which played Tuesday and last night at the New York Film Festivalis sympathetic to women's issues. And I suspect that the director may fancy himself a male feminist. However, "Slave" manages to be reactionary in several wayspartly because you can't possibly like either of these one-note characters: the wife (Alexandra Kluge, the director's sister) is presented as a dreary clod, and the husband (Franz Bronski) is just a grouch. The shallowness of the characterization, combined with the pretentious bleakness that runs throughout, results in a paralyzing pessimism that makes the lives depicted seem contemptible.There's an exceptionally grim abortion that should please the Friends of the Foetus  especially since this foetus quivers after it's removed. (Program notes state that the operation was simulated.) The patient appears to be dressed for a festive occasion (indeed, who would wear an off-the-shoulder blouse to her abortion?). It's hard to know what this scene is supposed to proveunless it's a device to establish the director's toughness.The husband reluctantly takes a job, and the wife becomes a political activist. Most of the time, she's hopelessly inefficient, naive, and ineffective. Her social concerns are made to appear faddish, until she manages to rally the workers at her husband's firm against the management. Hence her husbandwho doesn't like her politicsis fired. The conclusion implies that the effort for change is useless. All in all, the movie would be depressing if it weren't so dull.Also on the program is a marvelous adaptation of Henry James's "The Bench of Desolation," directed by Claude Chabrol for television. A fastidious man is faced with a breach of promise suit by a woman who eventually makes him pay a sum that plummets him into a lifetime of debt and destroys his marriage.Years later, the woman reappears and offers to repay himwith interest. Her love and her revenge took the same form: of making money for him (and out of him), and of creating his need for her. She has blighted his life so that she may later have the chance to comfort himthat is, if he no longer loathes her.The James tale respects the pain of both charactersthe rejected woman and the crippled manwhile stressing her appalling ruthlessness and condemning the aptitude for suffering plus the dread of vulgarity that made him unable to defy her. (She's also the kind of controlling, semi-maternal figure that frightened James himself.)The movie is faithful to the original, and it's admirably performed. Catherine Samie achieves an extraordinary shift of character: early on, she's formidable, threatening in her upright posture; later, she's extremely touching, also acrid and sensitive by turns. Meanwhile, the contrast between Michel Duchaussoy's cautious glares and his moments of raw suffering fully express his sense of a wasted life. These people even have the pallor that James described, and the film is merely a small triumph for Mr. Chabrol.

title: T.V.A. Weighs Cutback
description: MURFREESBORO, Tenn., Oct. 2 (AP)The Tennessee Valley Authority will decide in midNovember whether it will curtail its output of electric power to industrial customers, a T.V.A. official said last night.

title: State Investigates American Indian Museum
description: The Museum of the American Indian, the repository for the most comprehensive collection in its field, is the object of a broadbased state investigation into its deaccession, investment and financial policies.

title: Case Joins Opponents Of Casino Gambling
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) Senator Clifford P. Case said today he was opposed to the proposed casino gambling in New Jersey because it would invite loansharking, prostitution and corruption of public officials.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 45

title: Committee Rules Judge Wrong In Calling Colleagues Thieves
description: A committee on judges' conduct found yesterday that a Supreme Court justice who had called some of his colleagues outright thieves, fakers and lazy had failed to prove his charges.

title: Federal Aide Resigns Amid Controversy Over Alleged Abuse of Civil Service
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) A top official of the General Services Administration, identified by Administration officfals as one of eight accused of political use of the Civil Service System, has resigned from the Government.

title: EXXON ANNOUNCES WRITEOFF ON TAX
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that Tuesday's 3.5 per cent increase in taxes by Venezuela, which was made retroactive to Jan. 1, would reduce the company's net income for the first half of 1974 by $75million, or 34 cents share.

title: DR. CARL WOODWARD OFU.OF RHODEISLAND
description: Dr. Carl R. Woodward, president emeritus of the University of Rhode Island, died yesterday at South County Hospital, Wakefield, R.I. He was 84 and lived in Kingston.

title: Jesuit and 5 Others to Leave White House Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Despite what is described as President Ford's reluctance to force out White House holdovers, the exodus of Nixon appointees accelerated today with announcements of six resignations, including that of the Rev. Dr. John McLaughlin, the controversial Jesuit priest.

title: Saudi Ties OilPrice Cut To Mideast Settlement
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Arabian oil minister, said tonight that a settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict would reduce the price of Arab oil.

title: Francis R. Clines Jr. Dies; St. John's Development Aide
description: Francis R. Clines Jr., director of development of St. John's University, Jamaica, Queens, died Tuesday evening of a heart arrest while undergoing surgery in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 52 years old and lived in Hempstead, I L.I.

title: Contract Awards
description: Iran has offered to purchase 36 McDonnell Douglas Phantom jets similar to the latest version of the United States Air Force F4E model of the twin engine, twoman, allweather weapons system, the company said. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed but industry sources estimated the sale price to be in excess of $150million.

title: KILLING OF CALVES IN PROTEST PUT OFF
description: STEPHENVILLE, Tex., Oct. 2 (AP)About 400 ranchers and dairymen herded hundreds of calves before a bulldozed trench today and then scrapped plans for a mass slaughter after an 11thhour appeal from the White House.

title: Rumania Revalues Currency
description: BUCHAREST, Oct. 2 (UPI)Rumania has revalued her national currency for noncommercial operations and from today on visitors will get 12 leis for $1 instead of 14.38 leis, the official press agency, Agerpres, said today.

title: Orioles: Miracle Of 1974
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2 After one of the most remarkable stretch drives in the 74year history of the American League, the Baltimore Orioles were champions of the Eastern Division today, for the fifth time in six years.

title: Fire Kills 29,000 Hens
description: PITTSFIELD, Me., Oct. 2 (AP) Fire swept through a chicken house here last night, killing some 29,000 laying hens and damaging property valued at more than $50,000. Fire Chief Paul Nichols said the fire might have been caused by an exhaust fan, but that a thorough investigation would he conducted.

title: Unindicted CoConspirator Is Added in CoverUp Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 A White House lawyer who worked as special counsel to former President Richard M. Nixon has been added by the prosecution to its list of coconspirators in the Watergate coverup trial, sources familiar with the case said today.

title: After the Drought, a Shaken Niger Faces Long Uphill Struggle
description: NIAMEY, NigerAn extensive international relief effort has substantially ended the famine in Niger, one of the countries most tragically afflicted by last year's catastrophic drought that spanned the African continent immediately below the Sahara.

title: Sleepers, Wake: II
description: The first clear warning of the impact that the new oil prices could have on world economics and politics was sounded last January by Walter J. Levy, the oil economist. He laid out the figures on what oil would cost the consuming countries, and pay the producers, and concluded that urgent steps were necessary to avoid international economic disorder.

title: Reynolds May Abandon Its Guyana Bauxite Plant
description: The Reynolds Metals Company is reportedly abandoning its $20million bauxite facility in Guyana on the Northeast Coast of South America.

title: Wilson, Who Long Stood on Fringe of Power, Now Revels in It
description: For 15 years, Malcolm Wilson was often the unheeded voice of dissent in the generally liberal inner circle of Nelson A. Rockefeller when he was Governor, but now that. Mr. Wilson has power as Governor he is making up for lost time in his race for a full term.

title: Mets Finish With Defeat In 10th, 32
description: Bill Robinson's 10thinning sacrifice fly gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 32 victory over the Mets last night at Shea Stadium in the final game of the season.

title: CITY SEEKS TO BUY ANOFFICE BUILDING
description: A city proposal to purchase 250 Broadway, a privately owned 29story office building across from City Hall that is largely tenanted by municipal agencies, came to light yesterday at hearings on the capital budget for the 197576 fiscal year.

title: HOUSE CUTS FUNDS FOR NIXON BY 75% TO $200,000 TOTAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The House of Representatives voted tonight to cut by more than threequarters the amount of money sought by former President Richard M. Nixon to pay for his pension and official expenses as a private citizen.

title: Byrne Approves Bill Linking Conscience To Elective Abortion
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2Governor Byrne signed into law today the socalled right to conscience abortion bill permitting physicians, nurses and hospitals to refuse to perform elective abortions, but he acknowledged that the controversial measure may go too far.

title: RULING DELAY ASKED ON A SHELTER PLAN
description: Community Planning Board 4 voted last night to ask a bankruptcy referee to give it more time to consider a proposal by the French and Polyclinic Health School and Medical Center to use its New Yorker Hotel property as a temporary shelter for families made homeless by fires and other disasters.

title: Areas With High Unemployment to Get $350Million for Public Service Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 States and localities with substantial unemployment will receive $350million to create an estimated 73,000 public service jobs, Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan said today.

title: JORDAN STRESSES PALESTINIAN TIES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2Jordan's chief delegate emphasized in an address to the General Assembly today that his country had a special relationship with the Palestinian people.

title: State Investigates American Indian Museum
description: The Museum of the American Indian, the repository for the most comprehensive collection in its field, is the object of a broadbased state investigation into its deaccession, investment and financial policies.

title: 3 Tied in Golf
description: CHEPSTOW, Wales, Oct. 2, (Reuters)South Africa's Gary Player and Neil Coles and Eddie Polland of Britain shot twounderpar 69's today to share the firstround lead in the $46,000 Dunlop Masters golf tournament. Grier Jones of the United States and Brian Barnes, Roddy Carr and David Chillas, all of Britain, trailed by a stroke.

title: Senate Cafeteria Prices Deplored by Humphrey
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey complained today about price increases that have pushed the cost of hamburger to 75 cents in the Senate cafeterias.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Highest Utility Rates Paid by New Yorkers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (AP)The California Public Utilities Commission has released figures showing that San Francisco has the lowest combined electricity, gas and telephone rate among the nation's 25 biggest cities while New York had the top bill$49.51 a monthfor the same services.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1974

title: VOTER REGISTRATION WILL START TODAY
description: Led by Mayor Beame and City Council President Paul O'Dwyer, a group of candidates for national and state offices gathered on the steps of City Hall yesterday to urge voters to register for the November election.

title: Florio Aims His Drive for Camden Congress Seat, 102 Years in G.O.P. Grip
description: CAMDENNo Democrat has been elected to the House of Representatives from New Jensey's First Congressional Distrist for 102 years, but Assemblyman James J. Florio of Camden is campaigning on a breakfasttomidnight schedule in an effort to change that.

title: Simon Tells Inquiry That Oil Executive Played No Policy Role in Work for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Secretary of the Treasury William Simon insisted in testimony before a House subcommittee today that Robert C. Bowen, an oil executive on loan to the Government, didn't participate in policy decisions.

title: Business Briefs
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 2 (AP)  The West German central bank said today that West Germany had a basic balanceofpayments deficit in August of $420million, in contrast to a revised surplus of $189.9million in July. The deficit was the first this year.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Thursday, October 3, 1974

title: Jeanne M. Loeb Wed To F. S. Knox in South
description: Jeanne Mendelson Loeb of New York and Sarasota, Fla., widow of George A. Loeb, a stock analyst, was married yesterday evening in. Sarasota to F. Samuel Knox of Cincinnati and Sarasota. The ceremony was performed in the nondenominational Logboat Key Chapel by the minister, the Rev. James Marsh.

title: Israel Releases a Syrian But Fails to Get 3 Druse
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 2 (Reuters)Israel returned to Syria today a soldier who strayed into Israeliheld territory last month. But the Syrians did not free three Druse civilians in exchange, as had been expected.

title: Prof. Aleksandr Letov Dies; Soviet Mathematician, 62
description: VIENNA, Oct. 2Prof. Aleksandr Letov, a Soviet mathematician who was an expert on control systems, died Sunday. He was 62 years old.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: U.S. on Day of Tax Trial, Drops Case Against ExMackell Aides
description: The Federal Government yesterday dropped its tax charges against two members of the staff of former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell. The men had been accused of having failed to report income of approximately $168,000 they had gained from an illegal getrichquick scheme.

title: CONDITIONAL PACT SIGNED ON HERSTATT
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Oct. 2 (AP)  A conditional agreement was signed today under which Hans Gerling agreed to sell half his insurance group to a West German banking consortium in order to fund compensation to creditors of the bankrupt Bankhaus, I.D. Herstatt.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Ed Reinecke was given a suspend: ed 18month sentence today, only minutes after aides submitted his formal resignation as Lieutenant Governor of California.

title: Kotar Warms to Heavier Load As FillIn for Giants' Johnson
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 2With Ron Johnson a doubtful starter because of an ankle he sprained in last Sunday's game, Doug Kotar figures to he seeing more action at running back against Atlanta this Sunday in the Yale Bowl, and he welcomes the extra work.

title: Pirates Win Eastern Division Crown With 54 Triumph Over Cubs in 10th
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 Amid an atmosphere reminiscent of the Shea Stadium outburst in last season's National League playoffs, the Pittsburgh Pirates edged Chicago, 54, in 10 innings tonight, and wrapped up their fourth Eastern Division title in the last five years.

title: Kissinger's View of Oil Problem: A Deep Foreboding
description: Secretary of State Kissinger returns to Washington today burdened not only with the usual problemsa rebellious Congress, unresolved foreign policy issues, and a hectic travel schedule for the rest of the month but also with a deep personal foreboding about the future. His concern about the ability of the Western world to cope with the economic crisis spawned by the rising costs of oil has pervaded his thinking. It has also led to a number of questions, not the least of which is whether his longrange gloomy view is fully shared by President Ford; the Secretary of the Treasury, William E. Simon, and others involved in policymaking.

title: New Track to Specialize in Drugged Horses
description: New York's next race track will be a halfmile oval where all the races are fixed and most of the horses drugged.

title: 17 Indicted on CommodityOptions Deals
description: Stale Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced indictments yesterday charging that investors were bilked of $2,099,065 in commoditiesoptions deals with the bankrupt Collins & Day Group, Inc. He asserted members of organized crime had tried to take over the firm and got preferential treatment.

title: Interest on Support Loans For Commodities Raised
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI), The Agriculture Department has announced an increase in interest rates charged on pricesupport commodity loans and loans for storage facilities and drying equipment made by the Commodity Credit Corporation.

title: Tim Taylor, 54, Newsman, Wrote Book of Presidents
description: Tim Taylor, a New York newspaperman who wrote The Book of Presidents, a reference work, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 54 Riverside Drive. He was 54 years old.

title: L.I. MAN IS INDICTED IN LOAN EXTORTION
description: A Federal grand jury here has filed a fourcount extortion indictment against a reputed underworld figure who had been acquitted two years ago of charges he murdered a key prosecution witness in another extortion investigation.

title: Newark Council Votes Plump Raises For Itself, Mayor and Other Officials
description: NEWARK, Oct. 2The City Council today approved substantial raises for themselves, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and several top administration officials.

title: Soybeans Continue Strong Rise; Corn Prices Also Show Advance
description: Traders in commodity futures could feel The chill in the air yesterday in the Midwest and the Northeast, and they did not need precise weather news to tell them that frost was damaging more crops. The result was a resumption in the strong price rise in soybeans.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: All in the Family may be a dominant theme for major New Jersey schoolboy football teams that are seeking state. supremacy this season.

title: Stockton, Tanner Score; Connors Out With Virus

This 80minute revue opened Tuesday night at Jimmy's Restaurant (Upstairs).

Nixon who was regarded almost from the beginning as having been clean. Except for a 1972 allegation that he had ben involved in the settlement of an antitrust action against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, he lacked the taint of Watergate when he submitted his resignation from the Administration last summer.

Suffolk is a microcosm of America, he proudly told the visitor, who seemed impressed by the rows of suburban houses and acres of shopping centers. What we have here is the fastestgrowing county in the country.

Congress, the nation's oldest institution, is getting younger. As a result, it could be entering a period of reform.

His trainer is the Danishborn Kay Jensen; his owner is Dr. Tracks Archie Donaldson of the Bahamas. The rider was Jean Cruguet, a true Parisian making his annual visit to this country.

title: BILLIE PIERCE, 67, JAZZ PIANIST, DIES
description: Billie Goodson Pierce, who with her husband, De De Pierce, led the Preservation Hall Jazz Band in the nineteensixties, died Tuesday in New Orleans. She was 67 years old.

title: Don Nelson Is Making It As Promoter
description: Don Nelson, the Boston Celtic who looks like a football player and shoots free throws like a shotputter, will he in Toronto tomorrow night playing a preseason basketball game against the Buffalo Braves, but his money will be in Dayton, Ohio.

description: Detective Robert Leuci, the prosecution's major witness in a bribery trial of three suspended detectives, yesterday told the jury that he had rejected the idea of reporting what he knew about police corruption to his superiors in the department.

description: The United States is spending too much money for defense and military purposes, according to 44 per cent of the people interviewed in the latest Gallup Poll.

description: FOOTBALL

description: Collins & Day Group, Inc., the insolvent commodity firm involved in charges that investors were bilked of $2million, specialized in commodity options.

title: Syrian Counsels Consumers
description: WASHINGTON, Oc. 2 (AP)The Economics Minister of Syria, Dr. Mohammed Ali Imadi, today advised oilconsuming nations to stop complaining about prices and instead help those most affected. The financially strong nations in the consumer group should help the weak, he said.

title: Stock Prices Are Mixed In a Technical Recovery
description: A technical recovery enabled the stock market yesterday to finish mixed in much lighter trading following four losing sessions in a row.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
Notes on People
description: The archivists who played a major role in exposing the backdating of a deed for Richard M. Nixon's donation of his Vice Presidential papers to the National Archives has been transferred from her job in the Archives Office of Presidential Libraries. Mrs. Mary Walton Livingston, a supervisory archivist, refused to discuss her tranfer, but there were reports that the shift was made because her old office would soon begin working with Mr. Nixon in arranging his papers, for a proposed Nixon library. James B. Rhoads, Archivist of the United States, denied reports that Mrs. Livingston might have been pressured to leave her job; the change, he said, was voluntary.

title: BYRNE'S CHAUFFEUR LIABLE FOR SPEEDING
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) Governor Byrne said today that if a state trooper stopped his limousine for speeding he would expect the officer to give his driver a ticket. Mr. Byrne made the remark at his weekly news conference when questioned about an incident last week in which the Governor's limousine, carrying Acting Gov. S. Howard Woodson Jr., was observed exceeding the 55mileanhour speed limit.

title: Screen: Professor Bucks Odds in 'The Gambler':Caan, in the Title Role, Fights Compulsion
description: Axel Freed (James Caan), the young New York English professor, the hero of Karel Reisz's "The Gambler," has a ravenous monkey on his back. Axel loves to gamble. He'll bet on anything for staggering stakes. More than winning he likes the uncertaintly, the threat of disaster that, ultimately, is death or its reasonable facsimile.At the beginning of the film, Axel has just lost $44,000, which he doesn't have, and by the time the film ends he's even worse off, though he may be happy because, momentarily, anyway, he's achieved the terrible humiliation he's apparently been seeking all along."The Gambler," which opened yesterday at Loews Tower East Theater, was written by James Toback who, in his first film, becomes the author of some of the most disabling dialogue to be imposed on any serious movie in years. But more about that later.Compulsive gamblers are very special cases. Mr. Reisz, the director of several notable English films ("This Sporting Life." "Morgan," "Isadora"), and Mr. Toback have no special interest in treating Axel as a psychoanalytic case, though they provide some basic information if anyone else wants to go into that.Axel's father is nowhere on the family scene. His mother, Naomi (Jacqueline Brooks), is a successful medical doctor, a self-sufficient, liberated sort of woman who might have had man-to-man talks with her son when he was 12 years old.Observing the family from a walled-in compound in Riverdale is Axel's grandfather, A. R. Lowenthal (Morris Carnovsky), a self-made millionaire (a chain of furniture stores) who is probably a good deal less kindly than the movie would want us to believe.The movie prefers to consider Axel almost romantically, as a kind of artist whose misspent life is his work-in-progress. Axel himself brushes aside all efforts of friends and family to make him see himself as sick."My, god, Axel," his mother says at one point, in a line that Woody Allen might have written for laughs, "have I been such a failure as a mother that I've raised a son with the morals of a snake?" Says Axel's girlfriend (Lauren Hutton), "I don't understand any of it." Replies Axel: "It's just something I like to do."The movie follows Axel's downward path with such care that you keep thinking there must be some illuminating purpose, but there isn't. "The Gambler" is a very small movie, sometimes with embarrassing delusions of grandeur as when Axel quotes E. E. Cummings ("Buffalo Bill's defunct") or lectures his class on William Carlos Williams and Dostoyevsky. Mr. Toback writes as if he were a literature groupie, snatching at bits and pieces of other men's ideas for the loose-leaf album that eventually became his screenplay.His original inspirations tend to a particular awfulness. Early in the film there's a scene in which Axel accompanies his mother to the bank where she wants to withdraw money to pay Axel's debts. The bank man insists on two pieces of identification, though Naomi has only her driver's license. At this point Axel grabs the bank man and shouts: "Look, I came out of her womb and telling you she's Naomi Freed!"Each one of us, I suppose, is someone else's I.D. card, but that's not what "The Gambler" is all about.Mr. Reisz and Mr. Toback reportedly worked a couple of years putting the screenplay into this shape, which is lifeless The physical production, shot mostly in New York, looks good and Mr. Caan is generally convincing, except in those classroom scenes, but all of the other actors, with the exception of James Sorvino who plays a sympathetic bookie, seem defeated by the quality of the material.

title: Suspect in Officer's Killing Did Not Work as Butcher
description: A spokesman for the State Department of Correctional Services reported yesterday that Julio Vasquez, the suspect arrested in the murder and dismemberment of Police Officer Patrick V. Kelly, had never worked as a butcher's assistant while serving a prison term at Attica.

title: 3.4% Rise Shown In Factory Orders
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 2 (UPI) Factory orders, inventories and shipments rose in August, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Lisbon Said to Accuse Rightists Of a Plot to Assassinate Spinola
description: LISBON, Oct. 2  Foreign Minister Mario Soares has reportedly told foreign diplomats that rightists had plotted to kill President Antonio de Spfnola over the weekend as part of a move to bring down Portugal's provisional Government.

title: Hayes Football Team Is Workin' on the Railroad
description: Smoke billows from a garbage fire in the Penn Central Railroad yards and covers the adjacent practice field at Cardinal Hayes High School.

title: AMEX STOCKS DIP AS COUNTER GAINS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower again yesterday but those in the overthecounter market rose on profit taking. Overall, there was no news that could be construed as encouraging investment.

title: Stage: Medea and Jason
description: Quite possibly, the Greeks would have had a word for it, but I certainly do not. The play is Medea and Jason, or rather The Eugenie Leontovich production of Medea and Jason freely adapted from the Medea of Euripides by Robinson Jeffers. It opened last night at the Little Theater on West 44th Street. It was not interesting.

description: ATHENS, Oct. 2 (Reuters)  Parliamentary elections will be held in Greece Nov. 17, the Government announced tonight.

title: OldTime CarWash Business Is Threatened
description: ELIZABETH, Oct. 2Miron Kaciupsky admits he probably has no legal ground on which to fight the redevelopment agency that wants him out of his unmechanized, onecaratatime, bucketandhose car wash here.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court refused today to reinstate an order blocking construction of a highway in the lower Copper River Valley in Alaska. The request had been made by the Alaska Conservation Society.

title: Chessie System Net Up
Supervisors Are Scored In M.T.A. Report on Fire
description: A board of inquiry reported yesterday that Transit Authority supervisors were sluggish confused and errorprone in reacting to a fire in an East River tunnel Aug. 20, compounding problems for hundreds trapped in three stalled trains.

description: Representative Edward I. Koch formally asked Congress and the Federal Government yesterday for both administrative and criminal investigations Into the Dairylea Cooperative's admitted adulteration of milk between 1967 and 1973.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A substantial cutback in oil consumption by the main importing countries has been suggested by the United States as the first step in a strategy to force down world prices. Some European officials said Secretary of State Kissinger had mentioned a 15 per cent cutback at meetings in Washington with British, West German, French and Japanese ministers last weekend. [1:8.]

title: Trial Raises Questions On Rape Victims' Rights
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 1 Inez Garcia was a bride at the age of 14. By age 20 she had a 3yearold son and had formulated the belief that, as she later said, a good wife is a silent wife. She should cause her husband no problem.

title: CHINA, IN U.N., HAILS ARABS' OIL WEAPON
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2  China today praised the Arab countries' use of oil as a political weapon.

description: The crowd outside Ca??egie Hall on Tuesday evening pushed and shoved, there was excited talk, and clearly it was a Big Event. Was it a Horowitz recital? Karajan and the Berlin Philharmonic? No, it was Virgil Fox, who was giving the dedicatory concert of the new Rodgers electronic organ.

title: PHILLIPS RETRIAL IN SLAYINGS OPENS
description: The retrial of William R. Phillips in the Christmas Eve murder of a pimp and prostitute in 1968 was marked yesterday by an opening statement by his attorney, Henry Rothblatt, that the suspended policeman was being framed to avenge the death of another detective.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The District of Columbia Court of Appeals today ordered the former White House counsel, John W. Dean 3d, barred from practicing law here.

description: The city yesterday paid the highest interest rate ever, 7.79 per cent, in the sale of $420.4million in oneyear bond anticipation notes.

description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2Anatoly Karpov adjourned the eighth me of his final candidates watch for the world chamwonship a pawn ahead in a minorpiece ending with Viktor Korchnoi after 41 moveshere in the House of Unions tonight.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI)President Ford said that his wife, Betty, was feeling much, much better tonight after a 90minute hospital visit during which the Fords telephoned their sons in Massachusetts and Utah.

description: Looking back a week and a half and sticking to his longstanding belief that Eastern colleges should do all they can to strengthem and improve their football programs and image, Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State said, Yes, it was good for the East when Navy beat us.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2President Ford today named a woman born in England to the second highest post in the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration.

title: Surgery Is Postponed
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 2 (UPI)Surgery scheduled for today on Jack Concannon, Green Bay Packers quarterback, was postponed and Dr. E.S. Brusky said it might not be necessary. Concannon suffered a fractured cheekbone yesterday morning in an auto accident. Brusky said additional Xrays taken late last night indicate there was not so much displacement of the bone as had been thought.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Long Island Lighting Company announced that it had asked the State Public Service Commission to approve a $19.9million increase in its gas rates. The company, which has 836,000 customers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and on the Rockaway peninsula of Queens, said that if its application were approved, a customer who now pays $9.97 monthly for gas for cooking and heating water, would pay $12.15. A customer who now pays $34.49 monthly to heat his home with gas would pay $41.23.

title: 5 Die in Spanish Crash
description: LA CORUNA, Spain, Oct. 2 (AP)Five persons were killed and 15 were injured today in a collision of a bus and a truck, the pike reported.

title: Dandle Dinmont a Dandy in Show Ring
description: The Dandie Dinmont terrier is a breed made famous by Sir Walter Scott. In his novel, Guy Mannering, one of the characters, a farmer, Dandie Dinmont, kept six of these dogs. Historically, King Louis Philippe of France owned a pair in 1845.

title: High U.S. Aide Sees Thieu, Says Hanoi Ignores Truce

description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa Oct. 2An appeals court has upheld South African centors in banning a controversial Afrikaanslanguage novel that focused attention on this country's censorship methods, which are equally controversial.

title: Europeans Seeking $20Million Missing From Israeli Company
description: PARIS, Oct. 2A new financlal mystery has arisen in Europe involving a Hungarian Resistance hero, a Baron Rothschild, the State of Israel, Swiss bankers, West German politics and $20million.

title: COALITION COLLAPSE IS EXPECTED IN ITALY
description: ROME, Oct. 2, (Reuters)The collapse of the Italian Governmentprobably next week was seen as virtually inevitable in political circles tonight.

title: Illinois Aide Gives House Panel Some Grim Details on Dogfights
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)A House panel considering a Federal ban on dogfighting for sport was told today of an Illinois fight in which pigeon blood was poured over one of the dogs to illustrate its desire for blood.

title: Serum Containing Strain of Hepatitis Leaked at Airport
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)Blood serum containing hepatitis, albeit a harmless strain, was spilled in an air shipment to Washington's National Airport last January, the Federal Aviation Administration disclosed today.

title: Pittsburgh Fans Throw Bottles
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 The Cubbies, a player on the Chicago Cubs' bus muttered to himself riding back to the hotel last night after the Pirates had won the nexttolast game of their season. One game, and the Cubbies, 40 games out of it, decide it all.

title: SLAIN CHILEAN SAW PLOT AGAINST HIM
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2The former Chilean army commander who was assassinated in Buenos Aires Monday said in a recent letter that Chile's military rulers had been trying to soil his professional image because of his service to the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: CHRYSLER WORKERS REJECT 4DAY WEEK
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2The United Auto Workers union and the Chrysler Corporation have dropped a fourday workweek experiment at a parts depot in Tappan, N.Y. Both sides said the employes decided after two months they didn't like the program.

title: Col. Hans Handler, Headed Vienna's Lipizzaner School
description: VIENNA, Oct. 2 (AP)Col. Hans Handler, director of the Spanish Ridinng School here, died this evening during a performance of the school's renowned Lipizzaner white stallions, the police reported. He was 61 years old.

title: Congress Getting Younger; Reform Period Is Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The election next month will quicken an evolution on Capitol Hill that, in the view of many members of Congress and others, could have revolutionary consequences. Congress, the nation's oldest institution, is getting younger. As a result, it could be entering a period of reform.

title: U.S. ISSUES RULES ON CLEAN WATER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency announced today regulations designed to limit the discharge of water pollutants from steam  driven power plants. Over industry objections, the agency is requiring installation of cooling towers on most plants to reduce discharges of heated water into streams and lakes. Only small, old plants would be exempt from the regulation.

title: Chase Manhattan Reports $34Million Overvaluation
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, in an announcement that sent a tremor of concern throughout the financial community, disclosed yesterday that it had discovered that securities in its bondtrading account had been overvalued by $34million in its financial records.

title: Nixon Doctor Says Tests Have Found No Sign of Cancer
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 2 Preliminary results of the first of a series of exhaustive tests to determine the cause of former President Richard M. Nixon's phlebitis condition have not detected a hidden cancer, Mr. Nixon's doctor said here today.

title: WILLIAM LIPKIND, ANTHROPOLOGIST
description: Dr. William Lipkind, anthropologist and an author of children's books, died yesterday at his home. He was 69 years old and lived at 15 West 11th Street.

title: The Nixon Records
description: Clearing away the debris of the Nixon Administration is proving more difficult than cleaning up the Santa Barbara oil spill. A variety of questions relating to the former President's transgressions, records and upkeep are now making their tortured way through the Congress. A vote on the most important of thesethe preservation of the Nixon recordsis to come on the floor of the Senate today.

title: Aaron Hits Horner With Final Swing
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 2 (AP)Henry Aaron, whose first swing this season resulted in the home run that tied Babe Ruth's career mark of 714, lined a solo shot over the leftfield fence in his final swing of the season tonight for home run No. 733.

title: Artificial Sea Used To Fight Oil Spills
description: LEONARDO, N.J., Oct. 2  A 2.6million gallon test tank, longer than two football fields and described the largest and among the most advanced of its kind, was dedicated here today by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency in an effort to find better ways of handling what the agency called the nation's intolerabie number of oil spills.

title: Dave Anderson
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 2In the pitcher's previous game, the manager had stayed with him too long and their team had lost. Now, although the pitcher, Juan Pizarro, was working on a 20 shutout in the eighth inning, the manager removed him. Annoyed, the pitcher stalked off the mound even before, a coach arrived there to officiate at his departure. In the dugout the pitcher strode angrily and silently past the toward the clubhouse.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: North: Cloudy, cool today; clear and very cool tonight. Temp. range 4052. South: Mostly sunny, cooler today; clear, cold tonight. Temp, range 3753. Details on Page 85.

title: Halfway to Reform
description: Two years after Watergate, rivers of cash, like the Mississippi, just keep rolling through the nation's political life.

title: Mobil Cuts Gasoline Prices 2c a Gallon
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday it was reducing its gasoline price by cents a gallon effective today. The action reflects lower crudeoil costs in September, the company said, noting that prices could be expected to fluctuate monthly, depending on crude costs in the preceeding month. Mobil also reduced prices on residual fuel by 8 cents a gallon and on jet fuel by 1 cents a gallon.

title: Dominican Leader Steps Up Pressure To Halt Terrorists
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 2President Joaquin Balaguer of the Dominican Republic has decided to exert additional pressure on the leftist terrorists who are holding seven hostages In the Venezuelan Consulate here.

title: Personal Finance
description: If I only had known before I signed the papers what I know now, I would have acted differently, said a woman who was divorced recently. It's not only the emotional anguishit's also the financial details that you don't always think of at the time.

title: BISHOP DENOUNCES RHODESIAN POLICY
description: ROME, Oct. 2The whiteminority Government of Rhodesia was denounced before the Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops today as a political absurdity.

title: Advertising
description: Many a small ad agency starts out handling only local advertisers and never goes any further. Not so Van Leeuwen Advertising of New Haven, founded in 1968, which graduated to regional and then national accounts.

title: Networks to Broadcast Ford's House Testimony
description: The three major networks said yesterday that they will carry live television and radio coverage of President Ford's scheduled Oct. 10 appearance before a House Judiciary subcommittee, where he will be questioned about his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: City Warns of Rabies in Handling Bats
description: Citing a recent increase in the number of grounded and floundering bats reported in the city, the Department of Health has warned people not to handle the flying mammals, as they may well be rabid. Any good, healthy bat would not let you near him, said Dr. Alan Beck, the head of the department's new bureau of animal affairs. Just yesterday, he said bureau employes picked up three bats in Brooklyn which they are testing for rabies. And three weeks ago, a bat was found in Brooklyn that turned out to be rabid, setting off a successful search for a 7yearold girl who had been seen playing with it.

title: People and Business
description: Sidney L. Jones, Deputy Assistant to the President, said yesterday that I do not think our system will really function with doubledigit inflationat least the market system we know today.

title: JAVITS DEFENDS CAMPAIGN FUNDS
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits challenged Ramsey Clark, the Democratic candidate for his seat, yesterday to come up with proof of his charge about Javits campaign financing before he has it rammed down his throat.

title: Public Radio Says Its Growth Is Impeded by School Stations
description: The proliferation in recent years of 10watt radio stations operated by high schools and colleges has impeded the growth of a national public radio system offering a wide range of general programing, according to Matthew Coffey, president of the Association Public Radio Stations, a Washingtonbased organization representing the interests of noncommercial stations.

title: CORPORATE BONDS HAVE GAINS PARED
description: Selling pressure in intermediateterm bonds and some price slippage in Treasury securities were among features of the credit markets yesterday.

title: CURB ON WIRETAPS OPPOSED BY SAXBE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Attorney General William B. Saxbe urged Congress today not to overreact to the Watergate scandal by requiring Federal court approval of wiretaps that are designed to provide foreign intelligence or national security information for the President.

title: HOUSE TO RETAIN SECURITY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The House of Representatives, battling for the third day over how to streamline its committee structure, voted by a wide margin today to retain the controversial House Internal Security Committee..

title: JERSEY JURY GETS RAPE CASE TODAY
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 2A Hudson County grand jury will hear evidence tomorrow allegedly linking a California man to the rapes of three New Jersey women last month.

title: Eagleton Says to Make Flanigan Envoy Would Disgrace U.S
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Senator Thomas P. Eagleton told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that a vote to confirm Peter M. Flanigan as Ambassador to Spain will disgrace the United States.

title: Banished Children
description: Banishment has always been regarded as a harsh punishment, Generally, it has been imposed on adult criminals and, political or religious dissidents. Today, in this country, it is increasingly being practiced against disabled children nobody wants.

title: SENATE SHELVES FOREIGN AID BILL IN FORD VICTORY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Senate upheld the Ford Administration tonight by voting to shelveat least until after the November electionsthis year's controversial $2.5billion foreign aid bill. The vote was 41 to 39.

title: U.S. Believes Israel Gains In Arms Over 2 Arab Foes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Israel is in a stronger military position now in relation to Egypt and Syria than before the outbreak of the war a year ago, according to American experts.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Tokyo  Shoji Oguma, 112 pounds, Japan, outpointed Betulio Gonzalez, 109, Venezuela, 15 rounds; Oguma won World Boxing Council flyweight championship.

title: CONGRESS TO DELAY TAX REFORM ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) Congress has put off consideration of tax revision and trade hills until after the monthlong election recess that begins Oct. 11.

title: DR. C. R. STRAATSIM PLASTIC SURGEON, 78
description: Dr. Clarence R. Straatsma, a plastic surgeon, died yesterday at the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 78 years old, lived at 17 Eck Place, New Rochelle, N.Y., and maintained, an office here at 5 East 83d Street.

title: Nurul Amin, 80, of Pakistan; Vice President Until 1973
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 2 (Reuters)Nurul Amin, former Vice President of Pakistan, died here today after suffering a heart attack. He was 80 years old.

title: Chase Manhattan Reports $34Million Overvaluation
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, in an announcement that sent a tremor of concern throughout the financial community, disclosed yesterday that it had discovered that securities in its bondtrading account had been overvalued by $34million in its financial records.

title: HORMONES LINKED TO A BIRTH RISK
description: A study by the New York State Health Department india, rates that women exposed earIy in pregnancy to oral synthetic hormones, such as those in birth control pills or certain pregnancy tests, may face an increased risk of bearing infants with birth defects.

title: The Modern Sheriff: A New Breed
description: STOCKTON, Calif.He sits behind his desk in a tan business suit, talking of computers, multi  million  dollar budgets, inservice training, personnel requirements and management objectives.

title: HOUSE CUTS FUNDS FOR NIXON BY 75% TO $200,000 TOTAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The House of Representatives voted tonight to cut by more than threequarters the amount of money sought by former President Richard M. Nixon to pay for his pension and official expenses as a private citizen.

title: JAMES DRIVER Sr.
description: James Driver Sr., who had been a member of the stereotype department of The New York Times since 1945, died Monday evening in Lydia E. Hall Hospital, Freeport, L. I. He was 67 years old and lived at 304 Martin Place, Bellmore, L. I.

title: Plan for Assisting Pan Am Detailed
description: The Department of Transportation estimated yesterday that its sevenpoint Action Plan to aid this country's ailing overseas airlines could mean a $149million Increase in revenues for Pan American World Airways by the end of 1975.

title: Parents' Boycott Over Teachers Closes Two Schools,
description: Two Harlem schools were closed because of teacher staffing disputes yesterday.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The report includes the following:

title: Villemure Decides to Unretire
description: Gilles Villemure, the tough little Ranger goalie who announced his retirement on Tuesday, said last night, I'm going hack to work tomorrow.

title: Prosecutor to Fight Dismissal Of Indictment on Myles Motors
description: District Attorney Nicholas Ferraro of Queens said yesterday that his office intended to reargue the dismissal by a State Supreme Court justice of charges against five persons indicted last June in connction with the alleged use of stolen engines by the Lee Myles Transmissions Company or go to appeal immediately.

title: New Jersey Justice
description: In this time of intense sophistication about pardons and other aspects of the criminal justice system, there can he little doubt that the cases of Rubin Carter and John Artis should he reconsidered by the courts of New Jersey or, failing that, by Governor Brendan T. Byrne himself. The only witnesses who placed the two nien at the scene of the triple murder for which they were convicted and for which they have each now served seven years in prison have recanted. The witnesses now say that they saw neither man at the scene and they perjured themselves when they said they did.

title: Lingering Doubts and Irony Mark Yanks' Fall in Dramatic Finish
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 2  It would probably be an oversimplification to say that a brawl in a hotel lobby had cost the New York Yankees their last chance for a division title. But that suspicion lingered today as the Yankees ended their dramatic season in second place and put their dream in mothballs for the winter.

title: NEWS INDEX
Books of The Times
description: BABE. The Legend Comes to Life. By Robert W. Creamer. 443 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster, $9.95.

title: EUROPEANS AVERT CLASH ON FARMING
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 2The European Economic Community tonight ended a potentially destructive conflict touched off by a veto by West Germany last week of price Increases for the community's 10 million inflationsqueezed farmers.

title: Starvation in Living Color
description: LONDONSix years ago, the distinguished scientist and novelist C. P. Snow warned us in a speech at Fulton, Mo., that we were approaching the time when many millions of people in the poor countries are going to starve to death before our eyes and that we will see them doing so on our television sets.

title: French Report U.S. Is Considering Idea Of Secret Oil Talks
description: PARIS, Oct. 3Secretary of State Kissinger was reported today by French officials to be considering a round of secret talks with oilproducing states to discuss the price of oil and the world economy.

title: Ambro and Roncallo Both See Victory
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct.3Jerome A. Ambro, the Huntington Town Supervisor, commissioned a poll a few days ago, and it showed him leading Representative Angelo D. Roncallo by nearly 7 per cent in the race for Mr. Roncallo's Congressional seat.

title: About Real Estate
description: MT. KISCO, N.Y.  The brochures for The Village in Mt. Kisco don't show Jack Modlin.

title: Iran and U.S. Banks Lend Grumman $200Million
description: A $200million financialaid package from a group of American banks and a stateowned Iranian bank yesterday resolved the deep financial troubles that have been threatening the Grumman Corporation's production of F14A fighter planes.

title: Nixon Called Security Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (Reuters)  Representative John E. Moss. Democrat of California, (urged President Ford today to (halt intelligence briefings for former President Richard M. Nixon, alleging that Mr. Nixon was a security risk. Mr. Moss said Mr. Nixon should be denied access to classified Government information because he had committed illegal acts during his term as President.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Dictaphone Bid Is Dropped
description: The Northern Electric Company, Ltd., of Montreal yesterday withdrew its tender offer to acquire the common shares of the Dictaphone Corporation of Rye, N. Y., at $12 a share. A spokesman for the company said the decision to withdraw the offer was made at a meeting of the Northern Electric board in Winnepeg.

title: A Reporter's Notebook Cuba Still Finding Her Way
description: HAVANA, Oct. 3Cuba is the kindergarten or maybe the first grade of socialism, an East German correspondent remarks with an amiable smile to an American colleague who is visiting Cuba for the first time. We have to indulge their excesses as parents do their favorite children.

title: Mother Cited in Son's Death,
description: A 24yearold Brooklyn day for allegedly killing her 4yearold son, apparently by drowning, while she was punishing him. The police said the woman, Wendy Rodriquez of 567 Hendrix Street in the East New York section, was charged with the homicide of her son, Joseph Tolima.

title: Dance Uptown Series Begins Breezily
description: Two choreographers sent out two messages Wednesday night as the Gymnasium Events programs of the Dance Uptown series at Barnard College got off to a lively start.

title: 20 Finance Chiefs Meet
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  A deadline of Jan. 15 was established today by the world's leading finance ministers for proposals from the International Monetary Fund to deal with the problem of future recycling of the vast flows of money going to oilexporting countries.

title: Grace Increases Dividend
description: W. R. Grace & Co. announced yesterday that it was raising its quarterly common stock dividend to 40 cents a share from 37, cents. The dividend is payable Dec. 10 to shareholders of record Nov. 18.

title: Salomon's Profit Soars From Loss a Year Ago
description: Salomon Brothers, one of the nation's leading investment banking houses, reported yesterday that profits for the year ended Sept. 30 soared to $22milliona strong turnaround from the previous year, when the giant securities firm lost $6.6million.

title: Boy, 5, Fatally Stabbed On Lower East Side
description: A 5yearold boy was found stabbed to death last night in an East Village apartment and the police said that they were seeking the boy's father to question him about the crime.

title: LESLIE F. WOODCOCK
description: Leslie F. Woodcock, former chairman of the Nationwide Life Insurance Company and for many years a representative of the International Cooperative Alliance at the United Nations, died yesterday in Columbus, Ohio, where Nationwide has its headquarters. He was 81 years old and lived in New Paltz, N.Y.

title: NIXON UNDERGOES PANCREAS TESTS
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 3 Former President Richard M. Nixon underwent special studies today to determine the status of his pancreas, a digestive gland deep in the abdomen, Mr. Nixon's doctors said here today.

title: Market Place
description: The word that the Chase Manhattan Bank had discovered that securities in its bond trading account had been overvalued by $34million might have been jarring in yesterday's sliding marketbut it wasn't.

title: Anarchy in Aid
description: The performance of the United States Senate and the Ford Administration in a week of agitation over the foreign aid program stands as a glaring example of how not to run a government. Secretary of State Kissinger has been given his first serious taste of resentful mischief from disenchanted legislators, but neither he nor his Capitol Hill adversaries seem to have bothered to calculate the real costs of their feud to American foreign policy and to poor peoples around the world.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Two publishing executives, speaking at a news conference yesterday, accused the Soviet Union of literary piracy in publishing unauthorized excerpts from books by Kutt Vonnegut Jr. and Norman Mailer.

title: TEACHERS STRIKE 7 NASSAU HORS
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 3Teachers in the BellmoreMerrick central high school district went on strike today after a breakdown in contract negotiations; annd 10,800 pupils were sent home from seven schools this morning.

title: ...And the Reviews
description: Classical Japanese cuisine, more than any other in the world, depends on standards of preparation and conventions of presentation that are becoming impossible even in Japan. It is a directfromcheftodiner cuisine that rules out preparation in large quantities, and a meal when properly served takes on such a ritual quality that you begin to think of your kimonoed attendant as a priestess.

title: BOLLING FORESEES STALLING ON PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3An embattled plan to reorganize committees of the House of Representatives for the first time since 1946 finished its first week on the House floor today, snagged at times by stalling tactics and its fate still in doubt.

title: Willowbrook Employe Forced Inmates to Try Sex, Judge Told
description: Mrs. Brand's testimony came in the third day of a hearing before. Judge Orrin G. Judd on a suit seeking to have Willowbrook closed and its patients transferred to smaller residences or to their own or foster homes.

title: NADJARI FOCUSES ON FIVE PRECINCTS
description: Agents for the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, are investigating charges of graft in five precincts in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, law enforcement sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Mrs. Ford Cheered by Her Mail; Her Rapid Recovery Continues
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)Betty Ford, ahead of schedule in her recovery from surgery, began to read her mail today and was reported thrilled by the expressions of concern for her.

title: The Pop Life
description: Some kinds of progressive rock are moving farther and farther away from nineteenfifties primitivism. But many of the progressives aren't too eager to renounce their roots entirelyin part, perhaps for fear of alienating their youthful audiences.

title: CARL M. SAUNDERS, NEWSMAN, IS DEAD
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 3 (AP)Carl M. Saunders, retired editor of The Jackson (Mich.) Citizen Patriot who won the Pulitzer Prize in 1949, died here Wednesday. He was 83 years old.

title: Pepsico Net Up 10% to Record; Sales Rose 21% in 3d Quarter
description: Pepsico, inc., reported yesterday record results for the 12 and 36 weeks ended Sept. 7, reflecting increases in all areas of its operations, which include soft drinks, syrups, snack foods, transportation, leasing and sporting goods.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 2%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.05billion, up 8 per cent from the yearearlier $966million. Total retail store sales were about $10.38billion up 2 per cent from last year's $10.17billion.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: The Dow Index Pierces 600 As Stocks Near 12Year Low
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday in continued listless trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing below the 600 barrier for the first time in almost 12 years.

title: Nadjari Focuses On Five Precincts
description: Agents for the special New York State prosecutor. Maurice H. Nadjari, are investigating charges of graft in five precincts in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, law enforcement sources disclosed.

title: Fringe Party, in Big Step, Buys TV Time
description: The Free Libertarians, a fledgling political party that has been only nibbling at the edges of voters' notice, sought more attention yesterday by putting a commercial on television.

title: INQUIRY DEFENDED IN ENERGY DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Petersen and Representative John D. Dingell clashed heatedly today over the competence of an inquiry by the Justice Department into a conflictofinterest case.

title: Jackson Praises Israel For Her Ability to Build
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson strongly praised Israel last night for her ability, in the midst of turmoil, to continue to biuld, and he promised continued support of efforts to win freedom for Soviet Jews.

title: Keep an Eye on Rummy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The man to watch in the Ford Administration overthe next few months is Donald Rummy Rumsfeld, the 42yearold former U.S. Ambassador to NATO, who has just taken over as the President's top staff coordinator at the White House.

title: Ford Held Unlikely to Ask Quick Action to Save Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Administration sources said today that there was little chance that President Ford's economic policy message next week would include measures capable of causing an early, significant reduction in energy consumption and oil imports.

title: Cleo Laine Pleases Enthusiastic Fans With Vocal Variety
description: Cleo Laine has clearly captured a certain segment of the New York audience completely. Wednesday night's Carnegie Hall appearance was yet another triumph for the British popjazz singer, who made her New York debut two years ago, and who was once again appearing with a small combo led by her husband, John Danknorth. The house was sold out and the audience was rapturously enthusiastic, hurling flowers onto the stage.

title: Soviet Six Wins In Rough Game
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3  The Soviet national hockey team overpowered Team Canada tonight, 52, in a rough game that erupted into a brawl among all but a couple of players on both sides as it ended.

title: V.F.W. Aide Is Charged
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Oct. 3 (AP)Gerald B. Kelsey, the Oklahoma commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, has resigned after surrendering to, authorities on a $13,023 embezzlement charge.

title: Notes on People
description: The Pentagon announced yesterday that Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster Jr., who will be replaced Nov. 1 as NATO commander by Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., is retiring from the Army after 35 years. James R. Schlesinger, the Secretary of Defense, said that President Ford had nominated the 59yearold former deputy commander of United States forces in Vietnam for retirement in the grade of general. General Goodpaster, who has been Supreme Allied Commander in Europe since mid1969, as well as commapder of all North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces, was a protege of the late Dwight D. Eisenhower, whom he helped in organizing the postwar military structure of the NATO alliance. He later served more than six years as a militry adviser to President Eisenhower, and he was involved in the 1955 Geneva summit conference, the 1956 Suez invasion crisis and the U2 spy plane affair. General Haig, his successor, recently eided a tour of duty as White House chief of staff and formerly served as an aide to Henry A. Kissinger.

title: 158th Farmers' Almanac Wheezes In
description: The 1975 edition of the Farmers' Almanac  a 48page compendium of helpful advice (for ecology's sake, recycle newspapers), timely articles (the metric system is on its way), useful information (sunrise is 7:27 A.M. on Jan. 27), inspirational messagges (Take time to workit's the price of success, offbeat recipes (peanut soup), climatic Prognostications (beware of storms on Sept. 16), handy instructions (how to make bricks from manure) and bad jokes (Heard about the pussy Oat who ate a ball of wool and had mittens?)is off the presses.

title: PERCY W. HALL
description: Percy William Hall, a retired textile broker, died yesterday Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 223 Foxwood Road, Stamford.

title: Jets Keep Neal Shifting His Feet
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 3After five years In the National Football League, four of them with the New Orleans Saints, Richard Neal, knows what it feels like to be in the rookie class again.

title: Tax Break for Wealthy Dropped by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee unexpectedly dropped a major tax break for ilia wealthy from its tax revisionbill today, then agreed to hold off final action on the bill until it gets President Ford's tax propasals.

title: EXPERT TESTIFIES ON PHILLIPS'S GUNS
description: A police ballistics expert yesterday repeated testimony he gave two years ago that neither of two revolvers owned by Police Officer William R. Phillips could have been used in the killing of a procurer and an 18yearold prostitute.

title: CHARLES J. ELY
description: Charles Jarvis Ely, a general partner of Kuhn, Loeb & Co., Wall Street house, from Jan. 1, 1956, to Dec. 31, 1967, and limited partner since then, died Wednesday, apparently of heart attack, in Hackensack, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived at the Arcola Country Club in Franklin Lakes, N.J., and in Stuart, Fla.

title: About New York
description: This is a city of small mysteries, and the other night, alone in an apartment on Riverside Drive, a woman called Judy Neale heard a thump outside the window. Looking up, Miss Neale saw flash of white. It was, she thought, a mugger on the fire escape.

title: Reynolds Challenges Legality of a Levy On Guyana Bauxite
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday it could not pay a bauxite levy imposed by the Government of Guyana and filed suit there challenging the legality of the tax. The company estimated the levy, which was made retroactive to Jan. 1, would cost it more than $8.5million this year.

title: Giants Favored on Sunday; Jets Are Underdogs Monday
description: About Pro Football

title: FOREIGN BORROWING SAID TO WORRY BONN
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 3 (Reuters)  The West German central bank plans to open talks with the Finance Ministry in Bonn seeking to end current Government borrowings abroad through private banks, informed sources close to the Bundesbank said today.

title: So. Africa Leads, 10, in Davis Cup
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 3 (UPI)South Africa won an opening singles match from Italy and was one game away from a victory in another as the Davis Cup semifinals opened today.

title: Terrorists Holding 7 in Santo Domingo Reduce Demands
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 3The terrorists holding seven hostages in the Venezuelan Consulate lowered their ransom demands today, apparently in response to what one official called the turning of the screw by the Dominican Government,

title: Crime and Tension Are Always With a Policeman in the 103
description: The call Man With a Gun crackled over the police radio.

title: 2 Swedish Writers Win the Nobel Prize
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 3Eyvind Johnson and Harry Edmund Martinson, Swedish writers regarded as literary giants in their own country but virtually unknown abroad, were named by the Swedish Academy today as cowinners of the 1974 Nobel Prize in Literature,

title: Register to Vote
description: Voter apathy is a threat to representative government at all levels. In this city the ratio of citizens registered to vote remains shockingly low. For those not yet registered, only two days remain to qualify for the November electionstomorrow from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. and next Thursday, Oct. 10, from 5:30 P.M. to 10:30 P.M.at each voter's regular local polling place. Anyone in doubt about the location may get the information by calling the Board of Elections at 2262600.

title: Mexico Decrees Price Controls to Stem Her Inflation
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 3Despite strong objections from private business and industry, the Mexican Government today decreed a broad system of price controls aimed at reducing the current high rate of inflation.

title: Both Contenders in Connecticut Assail PowerBilling Practices
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 3both candidates for Governor in Connecticut asked today for special session of the General Assembly to deal with a growing controversy over the way the state's three major electric power companies were billing their customers.

title: Byrne Offers a Plan On Hiring Minorities
description: TRENTON, Oct. 3Governor Byrne announced today plan for the hiring of women and minoritygroup members by the state government. But the plan was promptly and bitterly denounced by several black leaders as toothless and ineffectual.

title: Witness Who Recanted Shifted To Jail Where He Fears for Life
description: A key witness who has recanted his testimony in the Rubin Carter murder trial was quietly transferred yesterday to the Passaic County Jail in Paterson, N. J., a jail where he has said his life would be endangered.

title: 158th Farmers' Almanac Wheezes In
description: The 1975 edition of the Farmers' Almanac  a 48page compendium of helpful advice (for ecology's sake, recycle newspapers), timely articles (the metric system is on its way), useful information (sunrise is 7:27 A.M. on Jan. 27), inspirational messagges (Take time to workit's the price of success, offbeat recipes (peanut soup), climatic prognostications (beware of storms on Sept. 16), handy instructions (how to make bricks from manure) and bad jokes (Heard about the pussy cat who ate a ball of wool and had mittens?)is off the presses.

title: YUGOSLAVIA CITES PLEDGES ON PLOT
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 3The Government announced today that it had received assurances from some Communist countries that they would not allow Yugoslav emigres within their borders to interfere in the internal affairs of Yugoslavia.

title: FORD WILL STRESS INFLATION ON TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3While prepared for the loss of Republican seats in Congress and some state houses this fall, President Ford will plunge into the campaign next week, with visits to as many as 18 states before the election Nov. 5.

title: Hint of Detente With Cuba Stirs Up Wrath of Exiles
description: WEST NEW YORK, Oct. 3The recent visit to Havana by two members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the possibility of a thaw in United StatesCuban relations have brought an outpouring of antiCommunist sentiment in Cuban communities along the Hudson River.

title: Brrr! Upstate Gets Snow And City a Surprise Chill
description: A wave of unseasonably cold weather, spreading across the northcentral and eastern United States yesterday, brought record low temperatures and early snowfalls, killing crops in the Middle West, knocking out power lines near Syracuse and bringing out fur coats onto New York City streets.

title: ACTION BY REPORTER ENDS PERJURY CASE
description: LOS ANGELES Oct. 3, (UPI) The refusal of a reporter, William Farr, to testify about the sources of an article he wrote during the murder trial of Charles M. Manson brought dismissal today of perjury charges against a former deputy district attorney, Vincent Bugliosi.

title: Impasse on U.S. Aid for States Ends With Accord on Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3After a twoyear impasse, Federal and state officials reached agreement with key members of Congress today on the terms of a new social services bill that would provide up to $3.3billion next year to the elderly, the needy and the handicapped.

title: Screen: The Abdication
description: Someone should give a crash course on how distinguished actors and actresses choose their scripts, since it's one of the queasier mysteries of the movie business. What, for example, persuaded two such particularly intelligent performers as Liv Ullmann and Peter Finch to appear in Anthony Harvey's The Abdication? Was it the legend of Greta Garbo in Queen Christina in 1933? But that was one of Garbo's creakiest vehicles, which fully justified Graham Greene's complaint that she was often badly served ... by writers and producers ... in compensation they treat her with deathly reverence: she is like a Tudor mansion set up again brick by numbered brick near Philadelphia.

title: Beame Made Few Promises and Some Remain Just That
description: A cagey campaigner  his innate caution reinforced by the certainty that he was going to be elected MayorAbraham D. Beanie doled out promises cautiously last year.

title: RECORD BOND SALE PLANNED BY CITY
description: New York City, underscoring its continuing need for new money, announced plans yesterday to sell $475.58million ink serial bonds on Oct. 16.

title: People in Sports
description: Needing backup help behind John Gianelli at center, the Knicks decided yesterday to give one more chance to Tom Riker. They signed the free agent, who had been their top draft pick in 1972 after starring for three years at the University of South Carolina. The 6foot10inch center was a disappointment as a pro, however.

title: The Reasons...
description: With a gusto once reserved for chow mein and egg foo yong, New Yorkers are now dipping their chopsticks into another Oriental taste treatJapanese cuisine. And while sushi and tempura aren't exactly household words, they're familiar menu items with an increasing number New Yorkers who are flocking to Japanese restaurants search of the exotic. Ten years ago there were about dozen Japanese restaurants in the metropolitan area. Today that figure has climbed.

title: Ford Held Unlikely to Ask Quick Action to Save Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Administration sources said today that there was little chance that President Ford's economic policy message next week would include measures capable of causing an early, significant reduction in energy consumption and oil imports.

title: BLUE CROSS SEEKS A LIMIT ON COSTS
description: The Blue Cross Association has formulated a sevenpoint plan that it hopes will hold down hospital costs.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 3Madison Square Garden Corporation chose a race track as the setting today for its annual stockholders' meeting. About 150 stockholders showed up at Roosevelt Raceway, one of the Garden properties.

title: Meeting in District 1 Ends As TV Sets Are Smashed
description: Angry supporters of suspended District 1 School Superintendent Luis Fuentes charge onto the stage of a Lower East Side school last night and smashed two closed circuit television receivers that had been set up in the auditorium to carry the proceedings of the embattled community school board, meeting in a highsecurity area in a remote part of the building.

title: Impasse on U.S. Aid for States Ends With Accord on Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3After a twoyear impasse, Federal and state officials,, reached agreement with key members of Congress today on the terms of a new social services bill that,would provide up to $3.3billion next year to the elderly, the needy and the handicapped.

title: Chess:
