description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3  Although Anatoly Karpov retained his onepawn advantage to the end of the eighth game of his final candidates match for the world championship, Viktor Korchnoi's active bishop proved teo strong an obstacle to overcome and the players agreed to a draw in 51 moves.

title: Yanks' Loss Is Indians' Gain
description: The Yankees, who passed up a chance to make baseball history a year ago, unwittingly helped create it yesterday by a move they didn't make last June.

title: F. D.I. C. REJECTS FRANKLIN'S PLAN
description: The Franklin National Bank's plan to remain an independent hank on Long Island received setback yesterday as the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation rejected the proposal.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: TAX RATE PRESERVED ON UNEARNED INCOME
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (Reuters)The House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to keep the 70 per cent maxi. mum tax rate on interest, dividends and other unearned income, after moving earlier to drop the maximum rate to 50 per cent.

title: Security ReRun
description: The objections by Attorney General Saxbe to legislation prohibiting use of wiretaps without Federal court approval merely rehearse arguments made familiar but not believable by his predecessors, most recently by John N. Mitchell. These rely on the claim that such unauthorized surveillance is essential to root out foreign espionage and to protect national security. Once again the definition of what constitutes the national interest is left conveniently vague.

title: Nov. 1 Deadline Is Stressed On Pulitzer Prize Entries
description: Book publishers were reminded yesterday by Columbia University of the Nov. 1 deadline for submitting nominations for the 1975 Pulitzer Prizes in letters.

title: Vasily Shukshin, 45, Dead; Film Director and Writer
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (Reuters)Vasily Shukshin, a leading film director, died of a heart attack today at the Moscow film studios, film sources said. He was 45 years old.

title: ORDAINED WOMEN TO AT AS PRIESTS
description: Three New York women who were ordained to the Episcopal priesthood in Philadelphia last July served notice yesterday that they would start functioning as priests very soon, whether or not their bishop, the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr., gave his assent.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS Oct. 3. 1974
description: New York316818

title: Frank Robinson Is First Black Manager
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 3With the poise that has characterized his career as a slugger of 574 home runs and as a clubhouse leader, Frank Robinson was named today by the Cleveland Indians as major league baseball's first black manager. He received a oneyear contract.

title: Senate Vote Near On Public. Access To Nixon's Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)The Senate pushed toward a final vote today on a bill to assure the public and courts full access to Richard M. Nixon's White House tapes, and papers. By voice vote, Senators adopted a resolution urging President Ford to do what he could to make public all the facts about the Watergate scandal, including any relevant documents from Mr. Nixon's 5 years in office.

title: FORREST H. FARMER JR.
description: Forrest H. Farmer Jr., former president of Standard Electrica, S.A., a Brazilian subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died of a heart attack in Rio de Janeiro on Saturday. He was 61 years old.

title: YearOld Housing Court Wins Some Approval and Disapproval
description: A year after the city's Housing Court began operating, the court is getting high marks from its administrators and those who spearheaded its tion and varying degrees of approval and disapproval from landlords and tenants.

title: Health of Mrs. Ford Linked to Race in '76
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  President Ford will not run for a second term in 1976 if his wife's health is questionable then, J. F. terHorst, former White House press secretary, said today.

title: Jerry West's High Standards Force Him to Quit as Active Laker
description: Jerry West, who came out of Cabin Creek in the West Virginia mountains to become one of pro basketball's greats with the Los Angeles Lakers, retired yesterday. After 14 seasons the 36yearold West, the only player in National Basketball Association history to be named to play in the allstar game every season in the league, joined the growing list of standouts who came up together in the early 1960's to retire.

title: L.I. Man Is Accused Of Plotting Murder Of Father inLaw
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Oct. 3A 31yearold man was arrested this morning and charged with conspiring to murder his fatherinlaw, a wealthy automobile muffler dealer, by retaining a hit manwho turned out to be an undercover agent.

title: A Deserter, Back Home, Has Awkward Moments
description: GILROY, Calif.Home. For nearly six years of exile in Canada as an American military deserter, Gary Della Bitta had thought of little else.

title: No New Oil Embargo Expected by U.S. Aide
description: James E. Akins, the United States Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, said yesterday that there was little likelihood of a resumption of the Arab oil embargo unless hostilities broke out again in the Middle East.

title: Sterling National Bank Set To Finance Peck & Peck
description: The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company of New York said yesterday that it would make available up to $2million in financing for Peck & Peck, a chain of 58 women's specialty shops currently operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Shah Offers Oil but Bars U.S. Dictation of Terms
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 3  The Shah of Iran said tonight in discussing oil prices that he hoped to share resources with the United States but not on dictation terms.

title: CONFEREES VOTE $1118BILLION BILL ON MASS TRANSIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  A HouseSenate conference on mass transit today approved a sixyear, $11.8billion bill that the White House later indicated it would accept.

title: Rival Carriers Fail to Fix Fees On TransAtlantic Air Charter
description: A twomonth effort by rival groups of scheduled and nonscheduled airlines to agree for the first time on standard prices for transAtlantic charter flights collapsed yesterday, and threw future international airline pricing into a state of turmoil.

title: Of Oil and Food, of Goose and Gander
description: Apparently the Arabs and other oil producers are expected to behave in a way that America has hardly ever behaved.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Conventional wisdom suggests that growth is the answer to our current economic troubles. However heretical it may sound, what we need is a policy of degrowthing society.

title: MINORITIES GIVEN WORK ON PIPELINE
description: Forty minorityrun businesses around the country have been granted contracts totaling $44million for construction on the Alaska oil pipeline, according to the head of the Commerce Department's office of minority business enterprise.

title: Deserter Is Released on Bond In Protest Over Ford Program
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 3William Meis, a 29yearold draft evader who fled to Canada seven years ago, turned himself over to the United States Attorney today and was then arrested and released on bond as he began a protest against President Ford's conditional amnesty program.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Byrne Orders State Plan To Spur Minority Hiring
description: TRENTON, Oct. 3A new plan for the state government to hire minority workers was announced today by Governor Byrne at the annual conference of the New Jersey Human and Civil Rights Association was promptly and bitterly denounced by several black leaders as toothless and ineffectual.

title: Deserters Face CourtMartial By Refusing Alternate Service
description: CAMP ATFERBURY, Ind., Oct. 3 (AP)Deserters taking part in President Ford's conditional amnesty program can be courtmartialed for not fulfilling their alternative service, a Defense Department spokesman said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: With a mixture of selfcongratulations and admonitions that more needs to be done, city and state, political and judicial figures commemorated the first anniversary of New York City's Housing Court, designed as a major reform in the battle to stem housing decay and improve landlordtenant relations here.

title: Advertising
description: The New Yorker isn't the exclusive property of New Yorkers. Far from it. Why, you probably don't even realize that one out of three families in Belvedere, Calif.; Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and Highland Park, Ill., subscribe to it.

title: New Jersey Sports St. Peter's Rejoices
description: NEWARK, Oct. 3  They are still celebrating at St. Peter's and will continue to do so for another week before they play another football game. The Peacocks deserve their fun. To prolong their exuberation at winning their first football game of the season, they have taken the week off.

title: Notes on People
description: The Pentagon announced yesterday that Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster Jr., who will be replaced Nov. 1 as NATO commander by Gen. Alexander M, Haig Jr., is retiring from the Army after 35 years. James R. Schlesinger, the Secretary of Defense, said that President Ford had nominated the 59yearold former deputy commander of United States forces in Vietnam for retirement in the grade of general. General Goodpaster, who has been Supreme Allied Commander in Europe since mid1969, as well as commander of all North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces, was a protg of the late Dwight D. Eisenhower, whom he helped in organizing the postwar military structure of the NATO alliance. He later served more than six years as a militry adviser to President Eisenhower, and he was involved in the 1955 Geneva summit conference, the 1956 Suez invasion crisis and the U2 spy plane affair. General Haig, his successor, recently ended a tour of duty as White House chief of staff and formerly served as an aide to Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: LASERIUM All of us by now have heard of laser beams, those exotic strings of light that can cut metal in James Bond films, carry sound transmissions and assist in surgery. But it appears the laser's capabilities are endless, and California is coming here to show us a few wrinkles.

title: PERU EARTHQUAKE KILLS AT LEAST 20
description: A violent earthquake rocked Lima, Peru, and the coastal region mainly to the south yesterday. There was extensive property damage, but first reports indicated a relatively low loss of life.

title: Democrats Favored Again ln 4 Old G.O.P. Bastions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Each of the nation's 435 Congressional districts is holding an election this fall, but four are different from the rest.

title: Two Games In Ivy Loop Tomorrow
description: Coach Bill Campbell of Columbia was thinking mostly of yards yesterday while his counterpart at Brown, John Anderson, was concerned mostly with touchdowns on the eve of the Ivy League football season, which opens tomorrow on two fronts. Campbell is to send his Lions against Princeton at Baker Field in a struggle that the Tigers are expected to dominate. The Bruins will entertain Pennsylvania in a contest in which heaps of scoring is anticipated. Brown's coach is convinced that his squad will have to tally more than a couple of touchdowns to win.

title: SEPT. 2130 SALES OF CARS OFF 40.1%
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3Domestic car sales were off 40.1 per cent in late September despite the introduction of most 1975 models by the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company in the period. Deliveries totaled 255,528 in the Sept. 2130 period compared with 426,705 last year.

title: A's Kubiak Out of Playoff
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 3 (UPI)Ted Kubiak, second baseman of the Oakland A's will miss the American League playoffs because of a leg injury. Manny Trillo has been activated for the playoffs beginning Saturday at the Coliseum against the Baltimore Orioles. But Kubiak said, I'll play in the World Series.

title: Coast Truck Driver Accused in 5 Rapes Indicted in Hudson
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct, 3A Hudson County grand jury today handed up a 19count indictment against Arthur W. Smith, a California truck driver accused of having raped five New Jersey women last month.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, in a move to resolve a longstanding problem of financial reporting, announced yesterday that research and development costs should be charged as expenses as incurred.

title: NIXON BIDS COURT QUASH SUBPOENAS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Former President Richard M. Nixon asked Federal District Judge John J. Sirica today to quash the subpoenas commanding his appearance as a witness at the Watergate coverup trial.

title: I.M.F. Job Marks Bedie's Increasing Status
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The Finance Minister with the most arduous assignment during this week's meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank may be Henri Konan Bettie of the Ivory Coast.

title: Bridge: Flannery Convention Solves Minimum Opening Problems
description: One of the most popular conventions among modern tournament players is Flannery, a device invented in Pittsburgh a decade or so ago. It is designed to solve the special problems presented by minimum opening hands containing five hearts and four spades.

title: Soviet Six Wins In Rough Game
description: MOSCOW, Oct, 3  The Soviet national hockey team overpowered Team Canada tonight, 52, in a rough game that erupted into a brawl among all but a couple of players on both sides as it ended.

title: G.E. Making Gains in MHD Research
description: Scientists at the General Electric Company's Space Sciences Laboratory at Valley Forge, Pa., have scored what they describe as a dramatic breakthrough in the efficiency barrier that has stalled magnetohydrodynamics electric power research for the past 10 years. It involves a blast of hot gas roaring at 3,000 miles an hour through a 60footlong shock tunnel to convert 20 per cent of the heat into 1,800 kilowatts of electricity in hundredthofasecond bursts.

title: Date Set for Eligibles To Sign Up for Lottery
description: Holders of five tickets qualifying for the grand tier drawing for New York State's $1million lottery on Oct. 14 have already registered with the state lottery, officials said yesterday. Others with the qualifying numbers have until Oct. 12 to sign up at any lottery office in the state.

title: 2 Major Business Groups in NearMerger Here
description: Two of the city's leading business organizations  the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Economic Development Council announced yesterday that they were joining in a fully coordinated working relationship that stopped short of full merger.

title: At Film Festival: 'A Bigger Splash':5 Shorts at Whitney
description: "A Bigger Splash," which was shown at the New York Film Festival last night, is a fiction film about David Hockney, one of the more successful and durable of the English pop artists to come out of the nineteen-sixties, in which Mr. Hockney and his friends play themselves in situations that may or may not have happened in life.A note in the festival program draws a parallel between what Jack Hazan, the director-cameraman-producer of this film, is doing in "A Bigger Splash" and what Mr. Hockney's paintings do when the artist takes details from life, strips them to their essential lines and colors, then projects them into larger-than-life reality onto huge canvases.Perhaps because most movie screens, including the one at Alice Tully Hall (where the film will be repeated tonight), are already larger than life, the effect of this fragmented, often self-conscious film is to make the subject seem sort of small and drab, a fact that is immediately denied whenever we are given a chance to look at the paintings themselves.There is a kind of story line to the film, which, we're told, was three years in the making. It's about Mr. Hockney's inability to finish a painting when his lover for the last five years, another artist named Peter Schlesinger, walks out on him. His friends worry about him. They worry about a forthcoming show, and they worry about the dcor of his house. "It looks like a waiting room now," says Celia Birtwell, a beautiful young woman who looks a lot like Andy Warhol's Viva. Another friend says, "When love goes wrong, it's more than two people suffer."In these moments, there's a suggestion of the satire that is almost always evident in Mr. Hockney's paintings, but the film's Hockney-like gags are mostly blunt, as when Henry Geldzahler of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is "discovered" striking the pose in which Mr. Hockney once painted him.The manner of making the filmin London, Geneva, California and New York, whenever the artist's schedule permittedhas as much to do with the non-content of the film as with its style. There are only the slightest traces of the outrageous self-promotion and put-on that once were so much a part of the pop scene. "A Bigger Splash" is unforgivably solemn, something that Andy Warhol and Paul Morrissey would never have allowed.5 Shorts at Whitney"Transformations" is the blanket title covering a well-organized exhibition of five short films exploring motion pictures as the vehicle of expression of pure art. The exhibition opened yesterday for a week's run in the New American Filmmakers Series at the Whitney Museum of American Art.Of the five, which range in length from 6 to 35 minutes, the least imaginative was "Birds of Paradise," by Mike Lovell, in which the soaking of film in bleach produced whitened patterns washing across repetitive shots of caged vultures.More active and successful in working out thematic variations were Steve Osborn with "Polyphemus," a piece of cinematic choreography that makes the camera and a mirror partners in a contredanse; Sheldon Brown's "Clean Gate!!," fugal in the increasing complexity of its patterns; Mr. Brown's "Frame/Rate Declension" in which juxtaposed vertical film strips moving at changing speeds provide a tapestry of images, and David Hykes's "Moving Parts," a combination of eerie sound and colored particles that form a kaleidoscopic universe, at once pastoral and nightmarish.

title: Stocks Below 600
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 13.92 points to 587.61  its first closing below 600 in almost 12 years. Page 53.

title: SCOPETTA TO GET CHEATING CHARGES
description: Allegations by four sanitationmen that there was widespread cheating on a Civil Service promotion test a year ago will be turned over today by Councilman Theodore Silverman, chairman of the Civil Service and Labor Committee, to Nicholas Scoppetta, Investigation Commissioner.

title: Prices of Soybeans Climb Daily Limit
description: Temperatures in the 30's continued to chill midwesterners and crops yesterday, with the result that soybeans, wheat and corn jumped the daily permissible limits in trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: SCOPPETTA TO GET CHEATING CHARGES
description: Allegations by four sanitationmen that there was widespread cheating on a Civil Service promotion test a year ago will be turned over today by Councilman Theodore Silverman, chairman of the Civil Service and Labor Committee, to Nicholas Scoppetta, Investigation Commissioner.

title: Saudi Sheik Links Oil Price Cut to Mideast Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani of Saudi Arabia, whom Americans tend to regard as the good guy among Arab oil officials, was in Washington today talking, in his soft, persuasive voice, about cutting oil prices.

title: Physicians and Hospitals Upset By Shortage of Anticoagulant
description: A nationwide shortage of heparina leading anticoagulant drughas developed within the last several weeks, causing concern among doctors, pharmacists and hospital officials.

title: Stage: Ginzburg's The Advertisement
description: Natalia Ginzburg's play The Advertisement, which opened a limited run at the Provincetown Playhouse last night, has been termed theater of recollection. Perhaps theater of monologue might drove nan apter title.

title: NIXON BIDS COURT QUASH SUBPOENAS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Former President Richard M. Nixon asked Federal District Judge John J. Sirica today to quash the subpoenas commanding his appearance as a witness at the Watergate coverup trial.

title: 2 4,900MILE ICBM'S FIRED BY SOVIET SUB
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) The Russians have testfired two new long range submarinelaunched missiles about 4,900 miles from the Barents Sea into the Pacific, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Heins Cards 66 for Lead In Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Oct. 3 (UPI)  Littleknown Bobby Heins, a rookie who has made the cut just five times in 34 tries this year, shot a fiveunderpar 66 today to take a oneshot lead in the $135,000 Sahara Invitation golf tournament.

title: L.I. Man Is Accused Of Plotting Murder Of FatherinLaw
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Oct. 3A 31yearold man was arrested this morning and charged with conspiring to murder his fatherinlaw, a wealthy automobile  muffler dealer, by retaining a hit manwho turned out to be an undercover agent.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Rockefeller Back in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller returned to Washington for two meetings today after speaking yesterday in Utah and California. He attended a luncheon meeting of Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, of which he has been a member for several years, at the Pentagon, and met later with Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Frank Robinson Is First Black Manager
description: CLEVELAND, Oct, 3With the poise that has characterized his career as a slugger of 574 home runs and as a clubhouse leader, Frank Robinson was named today by the Cleveland Indians as major league baseball's first black manager. He received a oneyear contract.

title: Young Leftists in Bonn's Ruling Party Challenge Schmidt's Policy
description: BONN, Oct. 3After a fourmonth ceasefire, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and the left wing of his own Social Democratic party have taken up arms against each other again.

title: Electronic Checkout Speeds Food Buying
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 3The Pathmark supermarket chain unveiled here today an electronic checkout system that eliminates the manual ringing up of items by a cashier.

title: Books of The Times
description: SURVIVING THE LONG NIGHT. By Sir Geoffrey Jackson, 226 pages. Illustrated. Vanguard Press. $7.95.

title: Tests for Bombing Suspect
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (UPI)  Two psychiatrists were appointed yesterday to determine whether Muharem Kurbegovic, the alleged Alphabet Bomber, is competent to stand trial on charges of killing three persons in an airport bomb blast.

title: Stars Win, 4130, on 33Point First Half
Europeans Agree on Aid
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 3The nine members of the European Economic Community decided today to contribute jointly $150million worth of foreign aid to the 25 countries mose severly hit by the energy crisis. The action was a response to an emergency appeal begun by the United Nations in June.

title: OPTIMISM FADING ON MIDEAST TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Secretary of State Kissinger hopes to convince Israeli and Arab feeders to agree to an early resumption of negotiations during his trip to the Middle East next week, a senior American Official said today.

title: E. BOYD, 71, WRITER ON THE SOUTHWEST
description: Elizabeth Boyd, writer, artist and curator emeritus of Spanish Colonial Arts for the Museum of New Mexico, died Monday in Santa Fe, N. M., where she lived, Her age was 71.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Norman J. Lawrence, who manufactured women's raincoats under the Lawrence of London label for 25 years, has a new interest. He's keeping pretty busy importing fleecelined sheepskin and leather coats from England and selling them from his 11thfloor showroom at 417 Fifth Avenue.

title: For Ulster, the Election Can Only Widen the Rift
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 3  Northern Ireland is taking part in the British general election roughly in the same sense that an apartment dweller who has to get to work in the morning takes part in an allnight party going on overhead.

title: Group to Solicit Funds For Nixon Law Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI)  Former President Richadr M. Nixon has run up more than $100,000 in legal expenses, a former aide says, but a fund has been set up to help him pay the debt.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1974

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Lead Shot Ban
description: This month and next, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service will conduct four hearings across the country on its proposal to ban the use of lead shot for waterfowling in the Atlahtic Flyway in 1976, the Mississippi Flyway in 1977 and in certain areas of the Central and Pacific Flyways in 1978.

title: Jazz Burial in New Orleans For Billie Pierce, Pianist
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 3 (AP) Friends of Billie Pierce, the jazz pianist, who died Tuesday, buried her today with a trumpet blast, a drum roll, and dancing in the streets.

title: 2 Swedish Writers Win the Nobel Prize
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 3Eyvind Johnson and Harry Edmund Martinson, Swedish writers regarded as literary giants in their own country but virtually unknown abroad, were named by the Swedish Academy today as cowinners of the 1974 Nobel Prize in Literature.

title: 11% Drop Is Forecast
description: Thirdquarter earnings of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, according to its preliminary estimates, will be about 11 per cent below the $127.3million, or $1.02 a share, earned in the corresponding quarter last year, the company announced yesterday.

title: Work on Proposed Vault for Nixon's Tapes and Papers Is Held Up as Opposition Mounts
description: LAGUNA NIGUEL, Calif., Oct. 3The construction of $110,000 Government vault here to make former President Richard M. Nixon's tapes and papers readily available to him has been halted because of mounting Congressional opposition.

title: Worldly Letters
description: It may say something about the state of the century since 1901 that the Nobel Prizes in Literature are less controversial and more lasting than those Awarded for Peace. Books and plays live; peacemakers hover under a sword of Damocles. The joint award this year to Eyvind Johnson and Harry Edmund Martinson, both Swedish novelists and poets, will not be disputed by the comparatively small number of readers in the United States who know their work and admire the lyric, mythic nature of Nordic literature.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market declined again yesterday in slow trading.

title: Admiral Moosbrugger, 73; Led Destroyers in Pacific
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 3 (AP)Frederick Moosbrugger, a retired vice admiral who was regarded as one of the Navy's top destroyer commanders in World War II, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 73 years old.

title: AMOCO PARES PRICES ON GAS AND FUEL OIL
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced yesterday that its Amoco Oil Company unit was cutting prices on gasoline and heating oil by 3 cents a gallon effective immediately. The company said the cuts were the first price changes Amoco has made since last May 6.

title: MRS. HARRY MERWIN
description: Julie Newman Merwin, a freelance book editor and researcher, died yesterday. She was 67 years old and lived at 16015 Powells Cove Boulevard, Beechhurst, Queen.

title: Nov. 1 Deadline Is Stressed On Pulitzer Prize Entries
description: Book publishers were reminded yesterday by Columbia University of the Nov. 1 deadline for submitting nominations for the 1975 Pulitzer Prizes in letters.

title: 2 Groups Ask Court to Stay WNCN Format Change
description: Lawyers for the citizens groups protesting the change of format of WNCNFM from classical music to rock went immediately to court yesterday when the Federal Communications Commission declined order the Starr Broadcasting Company to stay its intended converison of format, scheduled to take place at midnight.

title: People and Business
description: In a recent offthecuff remark, Alan Greenspan, chairman of President Ford's Council of Economic Advisers, said that Wall Street stockbrokers had suffered more, proportionately, from inflation than anyone else.

title: $110Million Asked For Paks Repairs
description: New York City's Parks Administrator, Edwin L. Weisl Jr., conceding that the city's parks were in a sorry state, asked $110million in the upcoming capital budget for repairs. The parks got $65million in the current fiscal year.

title: British Parties Battle Nationalists for Scotland's Crucial Votes
description: BATHGATE, Scotland, Oct. 2Some 200 workers in the tractor and truck factory were eating their lunch today in the canteen.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given In Eastern Daylight Time
description: Today, Oct. 4

title: President's Aides Divided Over Inflation and Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Serious differences of opinion have emerged among the top policymakers of the Ford Administration who are trying to work out a program for simultaneously fighting inflation and reducing the nation's consumpdon of energy.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Salam Asked to Resume Premiership in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 3 (AP)  A former Premier of Lebanon, Saeb Salam, was asked today to resume the post in a move to end an eightday Government crisis caused by the resignation of Premier Takieddin Solh.

title: Composite Tape Trial Delayed for 2 Weeks
description: A twoweek delay in the start of a composite tape experiment with 15 stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange, due to have begun today, was announced yesterday by the Consolidated Tape Association.

title: JOHN S. PEAKE
description: John Stephen Peake, a Philadelphia insurance executive, died Monday in Chestnut Hill Hospital, Philadelphia. He was 68 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
New Jersey Briefs
description: The Board of Public Utility Commissioners yesterday approved an 11 per cent interim rate increase for the Hackensack Water Company that will add about $2.6million a year to the concern's revenues. The increase amounts to a little more than half of the $5million rate rise that the company had sought. The P.U.C. said it would schedule further hearings on the balance of the company's request soon.

title: City Seeking Changes in Auction Rules
description: Major changes in the rules governing sales at auction galleries were recommended yesterday by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs to open up to bidders some information now held secret.

title: IRVING LEADERMAN
description: Irving Leaderman, a founder and vice president of Max Epstein Sportswear here, died yesterday in Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 91 Bateman Place, Mount Vernon.

title: Bahrain Is Said to Relent on U.S. Base
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The United States Navy will be permitted to retain its port facilities on the Persian Gulf island of Bahrain as a result of a Shift in the emirate's policy, Pentagon sources said today.

title: Red Smith
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3About 20 minutes after the baseball season ended last night with the Pirates again halfchampions of the National League, two bottles champagne were delivered to the visiting team's clubhouse. Manny Sanguillen, the Pittsburgh catcher, had sent them to Jose Cardenal and Jerry Morales, the Chicago outfielders whose shapely skulls had been targets of a shower glassware from the stands while the Pirates were struggling toward the victory that decided the Eastern Division title. It seemed a friendly gesture but Cardenal and Morales had had enough of bottles for one evening. And anyway, it was only a domestic wine, not well chilled. When the bottle was placed at his feet Cardenal snatched it up and removed it to table in abrupt rejection.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The recent visit to Havana by Senators Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, and Claiborne Pell, Democrat Rhode Island, and the possibility of a thaw in United StatesCuban relations have brought an outpouring of antiCommunist sentiment in Ctiban communities along the Hudson River, where there are the greatest concentrations of Cubans in the United States outside of Dade County, Fla.

title: Investors Funding in Payment Default
description: The Investors Funding Corporation announced yesterday that as a result of defaults on payments to holders of $137million of subordinated debentures it had been informed that the principal amount of these debentures are due and payable immediately.

title: DUPONT MUST END DUMPING IN GULF
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Environmental Protection Agency, in a decision regarded as an environmental landmark, told the du Pont de Nemours & Co. today to stop dumping chemical wastes in the Gulf of Mexico 230 miles off the coast of Florida, even though no ecological harm from the practice had been shown.

title: RUMOR'S CABINET RESIGNS IN ITALY
description: ROME, Oct. 3Italy's 36th postwar government resigned tonight.

title: PANEL IN CONGRESS VOIDS AID CUTOFF FOR TURKEY, CHILE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3A HouseSenate conference committee voted today to remove bans on military aid to Turkey and Chile from a stopgap resolution to continue foreign aid spending.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.1 billion tonmiles, 3.6 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 548,954 cars, 4 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 6 per cent below last year.

title: President's Aides Divided Over Inflation and Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Serious differences of opinion have emerged among the top policymakers of the Ford Administration who are trying to work out a program for simultaneously fighting inflation and reducing the nation's consumption of energy.

title: Stocks Below 600
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 13.92 points to 587.61  its first closing below 600 in almost 12 years. Page 53.

title: Crime and Tension Are Always With a Policeman in the 103
description: The call Man With a Gun crackled over the police radio.

title: Try ItIt May Be Safe
description: On three fronts, Government agencies are moving to reject the strange principle that an industrial process must be proved beyond doubt to cause cancer before any curb or control is warranted. That has been the contention of the Shell Chemical Company, makers of two pesticides suspected as carcinogens; of the Reserve Mining Company, accused of dumping possibly cancerous materials into Lake Superior; and of the Society the Plastics Industry, whose membercompanies have been using vinyl chloride, an industrial gas linked to liver cancer.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Nears Backing of Carey
description: KIAMESHA, N. Y., Oct. 3The selection of Hugh L. Carey as the labor movement's choice for Governor seemed certain tonight when the executive council of the New York State A.F.L.C.I.O. voted in secret session to recommend his endorsement tomorrow to the 1,800 delegates at its annual convention in the Concord Hotel.

title: Barbados Is On Her Way
description: The tired tourist is lured to the Caribbean like Ulysses by the Circe of Madison Ave., and the siren song is sensuous, sensual: sun, bikinis, calypso, ruin and smiling natives.The average tourist will find the reality of Barbados in 1974 perplexing. If Barbadians are neither dreamy figurea from a Gauguin batiknor selfhating and aggressive black revolutionariesmany foreigners are bound to be disappointed.

title: PANEL IN CONGRESS VOIDS AID CUTOFF FOR TURKEY, CHILE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3A HouseSenate conference committee voted today to remove bans on military aid to Turkey and Chile from a stopgap resolution to continue foreign aid spending.

title: Contingency Plans On Possible Strike At Coal Mines Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)The Federal Government is preparing contingency plans to divert some coal supplies from electric utilities and to embargo coal exports in the event of a strike by miners next month.

title: So. Africa Leads, 10, in Davis Cup
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 3 (UPI)South Africa won an opening singles match from Italy and was one game away from a victory in another as the Davis Cup semifinals opened today.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON BANK INSURING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 House and Senate conferees have agreed on compromise legislation that would increase from $20,000 to $40,000 the Federal insurance on savings accounts at Federally insured banks, savings and loans institutions and credit unions.

title: Mobil Signs an Agreement For Libyan Oil Exploration
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 3 (UPI)Libya has signed a new agreement with the Mobil Oil Corporation for land and offshore oil exploration in Libya, the Libyan news agency said today.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
Who Will Be on First in 1976?
description: When Gerald R. Ford became President of the United States by appointment and succession last August, he also became the allbutcertain nominee of the Republican party for 1976 and the automatic favorite for election that year to a Presidential term of his own. Or so it seemed, particularly after Mr. Ford let it be known rather casually that he probably would be a candidate.

title: F. D. I. C. REJECTS FRANKLIN'S PLAN
description: The Franklin National Bank's plan to remain an independent bank on Long Island received setback yesterday as the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation rejected the proposal.

title: Japanese Boxer Retains Title
description: TOKYO, Oct. 3 (AP)Kunalaki Shibata of Japan defended his World Boxing Council Junior lightweight championship with a 15thround technical knockout of Ramiro Bolanos of Ecuador today. Shibata weighed 130 pounds and Bolanos 128. Referee Anselmo Escobedo of, Mexico stopped the fight after Shibata punished Bolanos throughout the bout. Bolanos's left eye was closed by the 13th round, and the fight was stopped at 2:29 of the last round.

title: Polish Chief Sees Ford Tuesday, Seeking Wider Trade With U.S.
description: WARSAW, Oct. 3 (AP) Edward Gierek, the Polish Communist party leader,: said today that he was ready to discuss with President Ford next Tuesday large purchases of capital goods from the United States. He said he hoped that PolishAmerican trade would soon top $1billion a year.

title: LOANS BY BANKS SHOW SHARP GAIN
description: Commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks posted a huge $496million increase in the, week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. It was the eighth increase in nine weeks and the largest since the record of $1.16billion reported July 3. Such loans declined $12million in the preceding week.

title: A Fighting Leader Frank Robinson
description: He stood close to the plate, perilously close, defying pitchers to miss him. His bat was held high and unwavering, like a torch. When Frank Robinson was at bat, he was a presence. His wife, Barbara Ann, couldn't bear to sit behind home plate with the other players' wives when Frank Robinson was up. She had to switch to a different angle because the pitches came so close to his head.

title: Airlines Talking Merger
description: Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines notified their employes today that they were exploring the possibility of a merger. The news had been disclosed previously by both companies and by Government officials in Washington. However, both companies said only exploratory talks had taken place, no actual negotiations.

title: The Glorious Summer
description: Even before the league playoffs and the World Series, it is possible to render a critical judgment on the 1974 baseball season. It was a smash.

title: Conferees Set a Fee Limit For U.S. Aides' Speeches
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  A HouseSenate conference committee agreed today to limit the fees that Federal officials, including members of the Congress, could accept for speeches, articles and public appearances.

title: CAR GUARDING CHIEF OF CYPRUS FIRED ON
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. (UPI)The police surprised carload of gunmen today along the route that President Glafkos Clerides was scheduled to take from his office and chased them off after an exchange of gunfire.

title: '74 CRIME UP 16%, CONTINUING A TREND
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) A sharp upturn in serious

title: Minorities Seeking Work Halt City College Project
description: Demonstrators demanding greater minority participation in the construction of the North Academic Center at City College carried out a previously made threat yesterday and halted the $53million job.

title: MATTHEW LEIBOWITZ
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 (AP) Matthew Leibowitz, a graphic designer, died Tuesday of leukemia. He was 57 years old.

title: CONFEREES VOTE $11.8BILLION BILL ON MASS TRANSIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  A HouseSenate conference on mass transit today approved a sixyear, $11.8billion bill that the White House later indicated it would accept.

title: People in Sports
description: Needing backup help behind John Gianelli at center, the Knicks decided yesterday to give one more chance to Tom Riker. They signed the free agent, who had been their top draft pick in 1972 after starring for three years at the University of South Carolina. The 6foot10inch center was a disappointment as a pro, however.

title: Israeli Minister Sees LongRange Hope in Arab Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 3Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel expressed measured optimism today that negotiations could solve his country's disputes with the Arab states and also satisfy the needs of the Palestinians.

title: RATE PLAN OF A.T.&T. IS REJECTED BY F.C.C.
description: An American Telephone and Telegraph Company rate plan for a new data transmission service was rejected yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission as too low.

title: Japan Reported Willing to Join ln Consumers' OilImport Curbs
description: TOKYO, Oct. 3  Japan is willing to go along with Secretary of State Kissinger's suggestion that major oil consuming nations cut their petroleum imports in an effort to break high Arab prices, Japanese officials said today.

title: WILSON TIES CRIME TO JOB LOSS IN CITY
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 3 Combining the crime and economic issues, Governor Wilson charged yesterday in speeches before labor and industry groups that crime was a principal reason for the huge loss of manufacturing jobs in New York City in recent years.

title: $7.50 a Share Offered
description: UAL, Inc., parent company of United Airlines, yesterday offered the International telephone and Telegraph Corporation $7.50 a share for its 52 per cent interest in Avis, Inc., the nation's second largest auto rental company. I.T.T. rejected the offer as inadequate.

title: Big Board Relaxes Rule
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had relaxed its Rule 394 to make it easier for a member firm to go to the overthecounter market to trade in Big Board stock if it could get a better price away from the exchange. James J. Needham, chairman, termed it a move to eliminate the anticompetitive feature of the rule, and at the same time to give the public the benefit of the better price.

title: A Deserter, Back Home, Has Awkward Moments
description: GILROY, Calif.Home. For nearly six years of exile in Canada as an American military deserter, Gary Della Bitta had thought of little else.

title: CONSUMER CREDIT SOARED IN AUGUST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) Consumer credit outstanding soared $1.76billion in August, the sharpest gain since November's rise of $1.9billion, the Federal Reserve board reported today.

title: Paris Tries To Save Oil But Shivers
description: PARIS, Oct. 3Lunch was hot today at the presidential palace, but the guests were cold.

title: Robinson Follows Robinson: 27 Years, One Hurdle Later
description: It should happen, not for tokenism or black revolution, said Larry Doby of the Cleveland Indians' coaching staff, but because it's a free country. And God gave us all a certain amount of ability.

title: Educator Gets Kick Out of His Son's Punting
HOUSING FOR ALL SOUGHT BY CLARK
description: Ramsey Clark, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, called yesterday for an increasing commitment of Federal funds to provide decent housing for all Americans.

title: Mary W. Cushing, ExCritic Of Dance on Herald Tribune
description: Mary Watkins Cushing, former dance critic of The New York Herald Tribune, died yesterday at her home, 106 East 85th Street. She was in her 80's and formerly lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Conversions for Aged Speeded in SingleRoom Occupancy Sites
description: Some of the city's rundown and crimeridden singleroomoccupancy hotels may be converted into modern housing primarily for the elderly under plans now being actively pursued by community groups in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

title: Opera: Miss Somogi Leads Traviata
description: The fortresses of ignorance seldom collapse at the sound of the first loud trumpet, but of late they do seem to be crumbling in selected areas. On the same day that a black man became the first manager of a majorleague baseball team, another group was breaking through at the New York City Opera. On Thursday, Judith Somogi conducted a splendid performance of La Traviata, thus becoming the first woman to lead the company in an operatic work.

title: KATHRYN T. LINDER
description: Kathryn Taylor Linder, the, widow of Frederick M. Linder, who was president of the Jacob Ruppert Brewery from 1948 until his death in 1958, died Thursday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N. Y. She was 86 years old and lived at 8 Midland Gardens, Bronxville.

title: Alimentary, My Dear Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  Mecklin has sent me his suggestion for fighting inflation. Is it as insane as it seems? Perhaps not. In obedience to President Ford's suggestion that we consumers think up ways to fight inflation and send them to our neighbors, Mecklin writes, I am writing to suggest that you join me in eating our way to lower prices.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Edward H. Tiller, a longtime Union County Freeholder and former Mayor of Garwood, has been indicted by A state grand jury on bidrigging charges, the State Attorney General's office announced yesterday, Mr. Miller, 62 years old, was accused of attempting to rig bid specifications for the county's communications equipment so a friend would be the favored bidder for the contract, according to Matthew P. Boylan, director of the State Division of Criminal Justice.

title: Carey Wins Endorsement Of A.F.L.C.I.O. by 90%
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 4  The twomillionmember New York State A.F.L.C.I.O. endorsed Representative Hugh L. Carey over Governor Wilson, the Republican incumbent, tonight by a margin of about 90 per cent of its 1,800 convention delegates here. A vote of only twothirds was needed for endorsement.

title: Sirica Extends Hours for Court As Questioning of Jurors Lags
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Judge John J. Sirica continued today to try to pick a jury for the Watergate roverup case but apparently encontered more difficulties than he had expected.

title: B. J. MULLERTHYM, BUSINESS COUNSELOR
description: Bernard J. MullerThym, a (management consultant who once taught philosophy at SC Louis University, died Sunday. He was 64 years old and lived at the Hotel Dover, 687 Lexington Avenue.

title: BUCKLEY TO JOIN WILSON ON STUMP
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 4 Senator James L. Buckley will campaign extensively with Governor Wilson in the final weeks of the campaign in an effort to counter the expected appeal of Representative Hugh L. Carey among Roman Catholic and conservative Democratic voters.

title: India Shuns Tennis With South Africa
description: India has refused to play South Africa in the final round of the Davis Cup tennis competition because of South Africa's policy of apartheid. The action has the effect of conceding to South Africa the symbol of world supremacy in tennis.

title: Miss Evert Gains Houston Semifinals
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 4 (AP)Firstseeded Chris Evert and Pam Teeguarden advanced tonight to the semifinals of the $50,000 women's tennis tournament.

title: Bronx Youth Shot In Error From Bus Dies of the Wound
description: A 17yearold Bronx youth died yesterday in Fordham Hospital, apparently the victim of a bullet intended by a youth gang for someone else, according to the police.

title: OIL FROM SHALE RECEIVES SETBACK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Oilshale development, one of the major elements in the nation's effort to reduce reliance on imported oil, received a setback today with the suspension of plans for construction of the nation's first commercial shaleoil plant.

title: The Dance. Greenhouse at the Cubiculc
description: The Greenhouse Dance Ensenble, composed of past and present members of the Erick Hawkins Dance Company, gave its first concert nearly two years ago. Thursday night at the Cubiculo, this troupe of choreographerdancers, offered stunning proof of how much progress an esthetically coherent group can make in a short time.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1974

title: ALEXANDER'S SHOWS PROFIT AFTER LOSS
description: Alexander's, Inc., the retail chain that operates 12 department stores in the New York metropolitan area, operated in the black in the fourth fiscal quarter ended July 27, after showing a deficit in the preceding three months. As a result, the year's earnings were up 8.1 per cent over fiscal 1973, the company reported yesterday.

title: Why the Old Soldier in Lisbon Faded Away
description: LISBON, Oct. 4The resignation Monday of President Antnio de Spinola has dramatized divisions within Portugal that threaten the country's first effort in close to 50 years to establish a democracy.

title: Antique: MotelModern Yields to State Department Treasures
description: WASHINGTON  Thirteen years ago Mary Caroline Herter broke into tears when she saw the motelmodern touches in the esthetically barren interiors of the diplomatic reception rooms in the State Department's new home on C Street.

title: Jobless Rate Up to 5.8%, Highest Since April, 971
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 4Unemployment increased sharply in September to 5.8 per cent of the work force, the Labor Department reported today. The level of unemployment was the highest for any month since April, 1972, when the economy was still emerging from a recession and the rate was also 5.8. The increase of fourtenths of a percentage point from the August unemployment figure was the largest rise for a single month since January.

title: Jersey Seeks to Move Witness On Carter From Jail He Fears
description: The Attorney General of New Jersey intervened yesterday in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case by demanding the immediate transfer of a major defense witness from the Passaic County Jail, in which, he says, his life has been threatened.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz of New York said he had obtained a court order directing New York City to shdw why it should not be forced to build a stadium on Staten Island as part of a 1962 agreement, which included $600,000 paid to finance the project. Mr. Lefkowitz said the city had been ordered to show Oct. 16 why it should not be ordered to build the stadium.

title: Anticrime Plan Calls for Nerve
description: On Thursday of last week, three men walked into the Bobby Dazler Men's Shop on Second Avenue. They did not behave like ordinary customers. They did not browse they moved into position.

title: ELIZABETH HOPSON
description: Elizabeth Hopson, who had taught for many years at the Spence School here, died on Tuesday at the Adams House, a convalescent home in Torrington, Conn. She was 93 years old, lived in Kent, Conn., and was a member of one of Kent's oldest families.

title: Area Yields on Food Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)Beaver County in Oklahoma, the last holdout against starting a food stamp program, has agreed to begin issuing coupons to needy people by Nov. 1, the Agriculture Department said today. But three other counties that initially began or agreed to begin food stamp operations are not cooperating in the program, officials said. Those are Choctaw County, Miss.; Montgomery County, Ind., and Madison County, Mont.

title: Britain's Crisis of Confidence Sends Shares Plunging
description: LONDON, Oct. 4The British investment community is so depressed that employment agencies are experiencing a surge in applications from outofwork stockbrokers seeking clerical positions at salaries a fraction of what they customarily earn.

title: CROSSWORD' PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: COLD WAVE LIFTS SOYBEAN FUTURES
description: The cold wave in Middle West harvest areas continued to send soybean prices higher in early trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade However, the high prices led to some selling of beans in many areas by farmers and the day's gains were below the 30centabushel limit.

title: Alice KriegerIsaac Dies; Was Pianist and Teacher
description: Alice KriegerIsaac, a former concert pianist and teacher, died Thursday at her home, 5658 217th Street, Bayside, Queens. Her age was 79.

title: A Golden Eagle Is Sighted
description: WEST PATERSON, Oct. (UPI)A golden eagle, a pro tected species seldom seen out side remote mountainous reigions or plains, was sighted flying over Rifle Camp Parl yesterday. Philip J, Conroy, ?? naturalist for the Passai?? County Nature Center and Philip J. Del Vecchio, a news paper nature columnist, identified the eagle in independen sightings. It was flying les?? than 60 feet above the ground just above treetops, they said The park is on Garret Mountain, which overlooks Paterson

title: Hunter, Cuellar Are Starters in Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 4For the third time in the last four years, it will be the Baltimore Orioles facing the Oakland Athletics for the American League championship when the threeoffivegame series begins tomorrow (at 4 P.M., New York time) in the Oakland Coliseum.

title: Shops on Upper East Stae Upset by a Rise in Holdups
description: First it was a liquor store, and although the owner handed over the money without a word, they shot him dead. Then it began to happen regularly. A shootout at a big supermarket, shops hit in the daylight hours, an old man beaten up for the contents of his cash register.

title: Whitlam andFord Confer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia held what aides called a lowkeyed and amiable chat, today with President Ford, then flew off to Canada for unofficial talks with Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau. The White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, said there was an exchange of views on global and regional problems.

title: AN AGENT OFFERS NIXON'S MEMOIRS
description: Irving Paul Lazar, the California agent, has been asking $750,000 for United States hardcover publication rights and allied rights to former President Richard M. Nixon's unwritten memoirs, executives of two hardcover publishing houses reported yesterday.

title: Manila and Peking Will Begin Talks On Full Relations
description: MANILA, The Philippines, Oct. 4 (AP)President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that Philippine and Chinese diplomats would begin talks in Peking late this month on establishing full diplomatic relations.

title: HERBERT D. WILLIAMS
description: Herbert D. Williams, a retired investment banker, died yesterday at his home, 242 East 72d Street. He was 96 years old.

title: Brezhnev to Visit France in December
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4  Leonid I. Brezhnev will visit France in early December for talks with President Valry Giscard d'Estaing as part of a campaign to build links with new leaders in the West and to renew Western commitments to dtente.

title: Ford Plans Strong Support in Congress for MassTransit Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4President Ford indicated today that he would give strong support in Congress to a sixyear, $11.8billion mass transit bill, which appeared likely to clear a major parliamentary obstacle in the house.

title: An OldWorld Elan Colors Song Style Of Enrico Macias
description: The Uris Theater on Broadway at 50th Street is apparently now the flagship theater for music on Broadway. It has several music performers from soul singers to middleoftheroaders lined up for the next few months.

title: Music: Study in Sonority
description: Bernd Alois Zimmermann was a German composer who was reaching out for an international career at the time of his death four years ago, at the age of 52. He was an avantgardist whose music stemmed more from such composers as Xenakis and Berio, than from the international serialists. His opera, Die Soldaten, attracted a great deal of interest a few years back.

title: Dr. Bessie Louise Pierce Dies; Author of A History of Chicago
description: IOWA CITY, Oct. 4 (AP)Dr. Bessie Louise Pierce, author of A History of Chicago, died yesterday at a hospital here. She was 86 years old.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: TokyoKuiaki Shibata, 130 pounds, Japan, knocked out Ramiro Bolanos, 128, Equador, 15 rounds; Shibata retained World Boxing Council junior lightweight title.

title: Governor Adds New Force in OldStyle Campaign
description: On the rare days that he can relax at home, a highranking state official likes to dress up in the kind of clothing he would never wear in public and show it off to a few old and trusted friends.

title: Other Games Today
description: Home learns are listed first

title: Rise in Milk Prop Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The Senate adopted today a resolution urging the Secretary of Agriculture to increase the price support level for milk. The resolution asked for a support level of at least $7.10 per hundredweight. A Senate Agriculture Committee report said that in September the price fell to $6.70 while production costs skyrocketed.

title: Justice Department Joins Plea on Dumping in Lake
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Solicitor General Robert H. Bork announced today that the Justice Department would join Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin in asking the United States Supreme Court to stop the Reserve Mining Company's daily dumping of 67,000 tons of iron ore waste into Lake Superior.

title: Mocco Trial Ends With a Hung Jury
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 4 (UPI)The trial on conspiracy and conflictofinterest charges of Mayor Peter M. Mocco of North Bergen ended in a hung jury today.

title: The Loose Ends
description: The legal and ethical concerns Special Prosecutor Jaworski reportedly has about disclosing the full extent of former President Nixon's involvement in Watergate in his final report to Congress would be resolved by a bill Senators Mondale of Minnesota and Brooke of Massachusetts have submitted to the Senate Judiciary Committee. Its passage would pave the way for Mr. Jaworski to write the final chapter in the Watergate saga.

title: P.S. 188 OCCUPIED BY 40 PROTESTERS
description: Supporters of two ousted coprincipals at Public School 188 on the Lower East Side who entered the school Thursday night staged an allday sitin yesterday to protest the removal of the principals by the Community School Board of District 1.

title: NEWARK PRESSED ON REVALUATION
description: NEWARK, Oct. 4A State Superior Court judge today ordered the City Council to authorize the expenditure of.$1.5million for a revaluation of the city's ratable property and to sign a contract with a private revaluation company within 30 days or face charges of contempt of court.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WEST SIDE For the fifth successive year, the American Museum of Natural History will today become a daylong block party with entertainments and programs in and around the 105yearold museum in celebration of West Side Day.

title: FROST COST IS HIGH ON NATIONS CROPS
description: A September cold wave has caused hundreds of millions of dollars in damage to crops across the Midwest and East, Government officials and farm groups reported yesterday.

title: President to Callon Nation For Economic Sacrifices
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4President Ford will present to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday an economic program that will require sacrifices from the American people, the White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, reported today.

title: LES PAUL RETURNS AS JAZZ GUIT ARIST
description: Les Paul is an enigmatic figure in the rock world. Part artist, part engineer, his hit records of the early nineteenfifties were consldered avantgarde in terms of multitracking voice and guitar techniques and other innovations now considered the norm.

title: Body of Child Recovered
description: NELSON LANDING, Nev., Oct. 4 (UPI)Searchers yesterday recovered the body of the 3yearold girl whose father, mother and brother died in a flash flood that destroyed Nelson Landing Sept. 14. The National Park Service said the body of Kelly Modlin was found floating on the surface in the middle of Lake Mohave about 2.5 miles south of Nelson Landing.

title: American, Jailed in Brazil, Is Tortured, Embassy Says
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. ?? (UPI)An American business man living in the northeastern city of Recife has been arrested for alleged subversive activitie?? and tortured by Brazilian mili?? tary authorities, a United State?? Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Lefkowitz Transfers Aide Who Was Assigned to Dairylea Case
description: Six days before Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz planned to present the Dairylea milkadulteration case to an Lefkowitz has placed a new assistant attorney general in charge of the case and has taken issue with the prosecutor who has been handling it.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TEANECK, Oct. 4Last year when Fairleigh Dickinson University formed a club hockey team, the squad members included a 41yearold priest, the Rev. John Pierce, who became the regular center and created considerable publicity for the school.

title: U.S PUSHING PLAN FOR 1975 LEASING OF OFFSHORE OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Department of the Interior is pushing a Nixon Administration plan to begin sales of offshore oil leases in the Atlantic Ocean and off Alaska next year.

title: Notes on People
description: The Senate adopted a resolution yesterday to confer honorary citizenship on Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the exiled Nobel. Prizewinning Soviet writer who now lives in Switzerland. The resolution, approved by routine voice vote, now goes to the House. The measure would instruct President Ford to issue a proclamation declaring Mr. Solzhenitsyn the third honorary citizen in American history. The Marquis de Lafayette was granted honorary citizenship before the establishment of Congress, and in 1963, Congress voted honorary citizenship for Sir Winston Churchill, the British World War II leader whose mother was Americanborn. The resolution on Mr. Solzhenitsyn, whose dissident views led to his being stripped of Soviet citizenship, was introduced last February by Senator Jesse A, Helms, Republican of North Carolina. The Senate Judiciary Committee, in recommending adoption of the resolution, noted that Mr. Solzhenitsyn has performed meritorious service for freedom at great personal risk. . . It is an honor pure and simple. It does not imply that he must accept or reject it. It merely places the United States on record, in a most emphatic way, that this nation honors him for his contributions to the freedom of mankind.

title: President to Call on Nation For Economic Sacrifice
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 President Ford will present to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday an economic program that will require sacrifices from the American people, the White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, reported today.

title: OIL FROM SHALE RECEIVES SET BACK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Oilshale development, one of the major elements in the nation's effort to reduce reliance on imported oil, received a setback today with the suspension of plans for construction of the nation's first commercial shaleoil plant.

title: 3d Week of Boston Busing Ends in Protest March
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4Thousands of whites marched through South Boston today protesting courtordered busing for school integration.

title: PRICE OF GOLD RISES BY $4.50 AN OUNCE
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 4 (UPI)Gold soared in value today, climbing to its highest point in months. The dollar went up in Tokyo and Milan but fell on most other international currency exchanges.

title: Chattanooga Papers Up
description: CHATTANOOGA, Oct. 4 (AP) The Chattanooga Times has announced an increase in subsubscription rates. The morning newspaper will cost $1 a week or $4.35 a month for daily and Sunday delivery, up from 80 cents and $3.50. The newsstand price will go from 10 to 15 cents for daily editions and remain at 30 cents for the Sunday paper.

title: British Oppose Cutback in Oil Imports
description: LONDON, Oct. 4  Denis Healey, Chancellor of the Exchequer, suggested today that Britain would not be willing to make any major cutback in her oil consumption as part of a general effort to force down the world price of petroleum.

title: Shepaug River Under Study
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Senate voted unanimously yesterday to add Connecticut's Shepaug River to the Department of the Interior's national wild and scenic rivers study list. If the 35mile long river is placed on the list, it would be protected by a prohibition against the construction of power dams and other encroachments. An identical bill awaits action in the House.

title: Delayed. Riders on L.I.R.R. Flee A Train in Morning Rush Hour
description: Fortyseven Long Island commuter trains with 40,000 riders bound for New York were delayed up to 50 minutes during the morning rush hour yesterday when an electric train lost power and impatient passengers poured onto the tracks.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: A BROADWAY FLAVOR IN GALLAGHER SONGS
description: Helen Gallagher is not overlooking her theatrical career of more than 25 years in the nightclub act she is doing this week at Reno Sweeney. She opens with Give My Regards to Broadway and manages to stay close to that thoroughfare in her material and in her reminiscencesfor most of the evening.

title: Kennedy Rules Out Support For Wallace on '76 Ticket
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., Oct. 4 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that he would not back any Democratic presidential ticket in 1976 if Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama were on it.

title: All's Fair as Colleges Join in a Carnival Approach to Recruitment
description: The New York Coliseum, a place where eager salesmen usually promote such items as automobiles, yachts and housewares, this weekend is offering a different kind of product: colleges.

title: ARTHUR M. BERGER OF YONAH SCHIMMEL
description: Arthur M. Berger, proprietor of Yonah Schimmel's Knishes Bakery, a landmark of the Lower East Side since 1910, died Thursday at his home here. He was 69 years old and also lived in Long Beach, L.I.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: E.F.T.A. TRADEDEFICIT LAID TO COSTS OF OIL
description: GENEVA, Oct. 4  The European Free Trade Association today attributed the doubling of the overall trade deficit of its, seven member countries in the first half of this year to the higher cost of oil imports.

title: Union Literature Upheld
description: A Federal judge enjoined city officials yesterday from prohibiting the peaceful distribution of union campaign literature during nonworking hours in Sanitation Department locker rooms.

title: ISRAELI RULES OUT WAR OF ATTRITION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel said today that his country, if attacked by an Arab state, would not allow the other side to determine the type of war to be fought but would strike back at once with all its new military might.

title: Shazar in Failing Condition
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 4 (AP)Former President Zalman Shazar of Israel is in failing condition at Hadassah Hospital, his physicians reported. A founding father of the Jewish state, Mr. Shazar will, be 85 years old on Sunday. The doctors said he was suffering from the deterioration of age.

title: People and Business
description: The computer industry has been waiting with high interest the important antitrust suit initiated by the Justice Department against the International Business Machines Corporation. But Federal Judge David N. Edelstein, who is presiding over the case, indicated yesterday that the wait may be considerable.

title: SHELL CUTS PRICE OF GAS 2C A GALLON
description: The Shell Oil Company an nounced yesterday that it was decreasing the wholesale price of gasoline by 2 cents a gallon, effective immediately. The company said the cut was in compliance with the Federal Energy Administration's pricing regulation and in part reflected the lower crude oil costs. The company's action follows a number of other oil producers, which have announced price reductions in recent days. Among them are the Amoco Oil Company, the Mobil Oil Corporation, the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), the Skelly Oil Company and the Clark Oil and Refining Company. The price cuts ranged from 1 cent to 3 cents gallon.

title: Mine Claim by 2 U.S. Men Stirs Furor in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 4Early this year two American geologists staked a claim to rich vein of rubies that they had found in Kenya's Tsavo National Park. Today the mine figured in both a court action and a statement of protest by the Kenyan Foreign Ministry.

title: Frank Robinson's Mover and Shaker
description: Now that Prank Robinson has been promoted, he has to be promoted. The new manager of the Cleveland Indians will be on display today as a guest TV commentator at the American League playoff game in Oakland, then he travels to Miami, where he will visit the TV booth during the Monday night pro football game. He returns to Los Angeles to inspect the National League playoff games there next week, then moves on to New York next weekend for several business conferences before attending the World Series.

title: Revue
description: Shades of the Ritz Brothers, Sid Caesar and Spike Jones! There's en evening of eclectic hilarity these days at the Little Hippodrome, a comfortable din ner  theater place at 227 East 56th Street, programed for you to watch a show on som ething other than an empty sotmach.

title: Saigon Base Is Reported Lost, Opening Key Corridor to Reds
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4South Vietnamese military sources said today that the Government had apparently lost one of its last bases between the Central Highlands city of Kontum and the coast, thereby opening an important logistics corridor to the Communists.

title: So. Africa Defeats Italians
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 4 (AP)South Africa took an unbeatable 30 lead (pier Italy today in the Davis Cup tennis semifinals by completing a singles victory and winning the doubles.

title: Specter of 1923's Superin flation Haunts West Germans
description: BONN, Oct. 4For Germans, inflation means a terrifying, incomprehensible, cruel time between the end of the first World War and November 1923, when money became quite literally worthless.

title: ISRAELI RULES OUT WAR OF ATTRITION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel said today that his country, if attacked by an Arab state, would not allow the other side to determine the type of war to be fought but would strike back at once with all its new military might.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS BLAMED IN DELAYS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has uncovered evidence of sporadic, isolated slowdowns by air traffic controllers around the country that have delayed thousands of air travelers recently.

title: WINE TALK
description: There is nothing more intriguing to a wine fan than a truly extensive wine list. There are some in this country. A couple of the San Francisco and Berkeley restaurants have fine lists of hardtofind California wines. New Orleans, Chicago and St. Louis each has a restaurant or two with a good wine selection. Here in New York, surprisingly, with the exception of a few placesLutece, The Four Seasons, Le Chambertin, Maxwell's Plum, Aperitivo and maybe a half dozen othersthe wine lists are mostly uninspiring.

title: Woody Hayes, OneMan Army
description: It's a great honor to be here in Ohio todaysometimes known as the land of the free and the home of Woody Hayes. President Ford at Ohio State University commencement exercises, Aug. 30.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Recent incidents in which New York City police officers have fired their revolvers resulting in deaths or serious injuries under allegedly unjustifiable conditions is a matter demanding the concern of all.

title: ROCKEFELLER GAVE KISSINGER $50,000,
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) Secretary of State Kissinger received a $50,000 gift from Nelson A. Rockefeller when Mr. Kissinger left Mr. Rockefeller's staff to join the Nixon Administration, a spokesman for the Secretary of State said tonight.

title: Home of Democratic Aide Set Afire in Glen Ridge
description: GLEN RIDGE, Oct. 4The home of a local Democratic official was firebombed early today in an attack that some party officials believe is linked to bitterness between regulars and party reformers.

title: News Summary and Index
Frazier Scores 20, Knicks Win First
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 4 (UPI) Walt Frazier scored 20 points and handed off seven assists tonight to lead the New York Knicks to their first victory in four preseason games, a 10692 decision over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: SENATE BIDS FORD UNDO NIXON PACT AND RETAIN TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Senate voted 56 to 7 today to direct the Ford Administration to retain custody of former President Richard M. Nixon's White House tape recordings and papers.

title: SECURITIES SOLD BY CERTAINTEED
description: The CertainTeed Products Corporation of Valley Forge, Pa., announced yesterday that it had completed the sale of equity securities to Compagnie de Saint GobainPontMousson of France for a total of $23.35million in cash. Stock sold to Saint Gobain, one of the world's largest manufacturers of glass products, includes 1 million shares of a new Series C convertible preferred stock for $20million and 400,000 shares of common stock for about $3.35million.

title: Economy and Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Despite the cool winds of partisanship that ruffled last weekend's summit conference on inflation, President Ford emerged from the meeting with some potentially meaningful politi, cal gains. Mr. Ford was widely praised for having conducted an open, democratic national dialogue on a central issue, in contrast to the style of policy formulation in Richard M. Nixon's White House.

title: Jobless Rate Up to 5.8%, Highest Since April, 1972
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 4Unemployment increased sharply in September to 5.8 per cent of the work force, the Labor Department reported today. The level of unemployment was the highest for any month since April, 1972, when the economy was still emerging from a recession and the rate was also 5.8. The increase of fourtenths of a percentage point from the August unemployment figure was the largest rise for a single month since January.

title: Seoul Foresees an Increase In Provocations by North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. (Reuters)  President Park Chung Hee said today that North Korea was likely to step up provocations against the South, making the next four or five years a critical period in relations between the two countries.

title: At P.S. 139, Parents Prepare for a Different Battlean Annex
description: Public School 139 in Flatbush is, as one parent calls it, a real United Nations of children from every ethnic, economic and racial background. And because it has always had among the best reading scores in the city, the school has been a magnet that has drawn middleincome young families to the handsome neighborhood just south of the Parade Grounds over the last 10 years.

title: The Real Inside Dope on Flaubert and Maupassant
description: So, we learned recently in the press that President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France studies Flaubert and Maupassant and is fascinated by the question whether Maupassant was not only Flaubert's pupil but also his son.

However, yesterday,s ruling by Judge Richard Fuller apparently will not block a countywide referendum

title: Business Briefs
description: The number of help wanted ads fell in August from July's figure, indicating that unemployment is on the rise, the Conference Board reported yesterday. The help wanted advertising index was 115 in August1967 equal's 100four points, below July's, reading and 11 points behind the yearago level, the board said.

description: Longshoremen called off their dock strike in Puerto Rico in its fourth day yesterday with the announcement that agreement on wages and fringe benefits had been worked out in talks here.

description: Of the four painters who are represented in the exhibition called Leonid and His Friends, on view at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Colombus Circle, Leonid himself is probably the least widely known. He is alsoat the age of 78the only one still among us and working. The others  Pavel Tchelitchew, Christian Berard and Leonid's younger brother, Eugene Berman (all deceased)enjoyed a more spectacular or more scandalous celebrity in their lifetimes.

description: The Navy lightweight football team routed Columbia, 540, yesterday at Baker Field. The Midshipmen were paced by Greg Sawyer, who scored three of their eight touchdowns and led all rushers with 195 yards.

title: WILLIAM BRINKERHOFF
description: William D. Brinkerhoff, who had been on the editorial staffs of several New York newspapers, died yesterday in Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 4314 Douglaston Parkway, Douglaston, Queens.

India Shuns Tennis With South Africa
