description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4A group of nonconformist artists have followed up their successful mass outdoor art show last Sunday with a request to the Moscow City Council for permission to put on a considerably longer exhibition indoors in December, a spokesman disclosed today.

title: Plan to Recycle Oil Funds Again Draws U.S Doubts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4While pledging an open mind, the United States reiterated its doubts today concerning the need for a large new recycling mechanism in the International Monetary Fund to return to consuming countries part of the vast flow of money to oilexporting countries.

title: Screen: New Sjoman
description: Vilgot Sjoman, who was effectively serious about sex, politics and sundry other matters in his controversial I Am Curious Yellow and I Am Curious Blue, is impishly curious only about sex in Til Sex Do Us Part, which opened this week at the Cin Malibu and Cinema Village. But if the Swedish director and his cast appear to be having a fine old raunchy time, their farce unfortunately, is as thin as a negligee and as obvious as its good measure of nudity and couplings.

description: RULDOSO, N. M.Anyone who feels inclined to poke fun at Smokey Bear should not do it around the forest ranger station here.

title: How Working Women Can Help Themselves
description: Each year, more women are joining the labor force, and working for longer periods of time. Yet many women are unaware of recent laws designed to protect them against discrimination in the job market, and to give them equal opportunities with men in hiring, pay, advancements and retirement benefits.

description: Gimbel Brothers, Inc., has been restructuring almost all its division managements and merchandising policies since the 132yearold retail chain, one of the country's largest, was acquired last year by the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, according to Richard G. Shapiro, president of Gimbel.

description: The Dictaphone Corporation's victory in rebuffing an attempted takeover by the Northern Electric Company of Canada turned into bad news yesterday for some getrichquick investors in Wall Street.

title: A RECORD LOW OF 28 SET IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: The cold wave that came in from Canada this week made for a chilly morning yesterday in New Jersey, as temperatures dropped to record lows.

description: The explosive growth of the socalled money market funds at a time of record hiqh interest rates has brought with it a proliferation of problems and concerns.

description: Some opening leads stick out like a sore thumb, and are put on the table automatically. Nevertheless, the player who makes them winds up occasionally feeling sore at the fates, which have meanly arranged for him to make the only lead to allow the contract to make.

description: Irving Goldman, the Shubert Theater official who is the city's $1ayear. Cultural Affairs Commissioner, is fighting a subpoena of some of his private business records.

title: Service for Taiwan Envoy
description: A memorial service for Kuoping Yu, who was Taiwan's consul and consulgeneral in New York from 1956 to 1972, will be held at 4 P.M. on Monday at the Presbyterian Church, Market and Henry Streets in Chinatown. Mr. Yu, who was Ambassador to Honduras, was assassinated Sept. 13 at the Taiwanese Embassy there. A suspect, his chauffeur, was arrested by the police last Monday.

title: Market Mixed as Technical Recovery Counters Many Sharp Earlier Losses
description: The stock market finished mixed yesterday after a modest technical recovery managed to erase many of the sharp earlier losses in heavier trading.

title: India and Iran Say Links Are Growing
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 4India and Iran cemented their links today and announced efforts to expand and deepen their economic relationship.

title: Meany U.
description: Union officials have to be experts these days in law, finance, foreign trade, politics and a thousand other fields, but labor has continued to lag far behind industry in programs designed to train people for executive responsibilities. The tradition still holds that the best training for leadership is at the work bench, at the wheel of a truck or in a mine.

title: MOUNTAIN, NOW TRIO, PLAYS INVENTIVELY
description: The power triounadorned lead guitar, bass guitar and drums, amplified to excruciationis a staple of latterday, postCream rock n roll. All too often, the austerity of instrumentation does little more than make an inordinate amount of noise and expose an inordinate paucity of talent. But things were different at the Mountain concert Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall.

title: Discipline Problems Giving 2 Southeast Coaches Fits
description: Thursday night is the night you have to be careful about, said Vince Dooley, football coach at the University of Georgia. You work the players hard in Tuesday and Wednesday practice and give them light work on Thursday. They aren't as tired that night and sometimes sow oats.

title: 17 Old Skeletons Found In Mass Grave in California
description: RED BLUFF, Calif., Oct. 4 (AP)Seventeen human skeletons were uncovered accidentally by workers today in a long trenchlike grave on a ranch 20 miles south of Red Bluff, the Tehama County sheriff's department said.

title: Game Contamination Feared
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 4 (UPI)Game in 450,000 acres of eastern Washington, eastern Oregon and northern Idaho sprayed with DDT to stop the tussock moth infestation last summer may be contaminated, according to the United States Forest Service.

title: Auburn Defeats Miami
description: MIAMI, Oct. 4 (AP)Gregg Gillis kicked a 24yard field goal for Auburn tonight in the third quarter and the Tigers defeated Miami, 30. Gillis's kick followed recovery of a fumble by Woody Thompson of Miami on the Miami 47yard line.

title: Guyana Weighing Actions on Reynolds
description: The continuation of bauxite operations in Guyana by the Reynolds Metals Company appeared yesterday to be entirely in the hands of the government of that South American nation.

title: Mrs. Ford May Leave Hospital by Wednesday
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) President Ford said today that he hoped his wife, Betty, would be out of the hospital and back at the White House by the middle of next week if she continued her strong recovery from surgery for breast cancer six days ago.

title: 5th Fuel Drinker Dies
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 4 (UPI)A fifth man, died today out of a group of at least eight men who drank a mixture of orange drink and methyl alcohol from a jellied campstove fuel in an attempt to become intoxicated. Lee Smith, about 32 years old, of Shelby, died at Charlotte Memorial Hospital.

title: Music: Beethoven Cycle
description: Whenever a string quartet sets out to perform the Beethoven cycle, as the Cleveland String Quartet did Wednesday night, one of many suspenseful questions is how the Grosse Fuge will be handled. This gigantic movement, originally intended by Beethoven as the finale of his Quartet in B flat (Op. 130), is sometimes played as such, but is more often detached and treated as a separate work. tic movement, originally intended by Beethoven as the finale of his Quartet in B flat (Op. 130), is sometimes played as such, but is more often detached and treated as a separate work.

title: Saudi Aide Pledges Not to Cut Oil Flow
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Arabian Minister of Petroleum Affairs, assured the West today that his country would not respond to the energyconservation moves of oilconsuming nations by cutting production, and that conservation would lead lower prices.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4 (AP)Team Canada's fading hopes for a tie with the Soviet Union in their eightgame hockey series received a blow today when it was disclosed that Broce MacGregor would not play in the final two games. MacGregor, a forward, injured ligaments in his knee yesterday in aussia's 52 victory. He said after the game he believed the injury was only a bruise, but the extent of the injury was discovered before practice today.

title: COURT BACKS CONDOR IN ALLOCATION TEST
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 4 (AP)In a Federal court ruling that could gain small oil producers more independence from large refiners, a small producer has won the first round of a challenge to a part of the Federal energy allocation program.

title: VENEZUELA PLANS 10% OIL CUTBACK
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 4 (UPI)  Venezuela, which ships over half its oil to United States markets, will reduce production levels by around 10 per cent in 1975, according to budget figures disclosed today.

title: Wild Lands Designated
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The Senate passed a bill today to designate lands in the Farallon National Wildlife Refuge in California as wilderness, and to add lands to the Point Reyes National Seashore. The House passed similar legislation earlier.

title: 2 NEW SHIPMENTS OF AMERICAN GRAIN TO SOVIET HALTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Administration announced tonight that it had put a hold order on two new contracts for the sale of 125 million bushels of wheat and corn to the Soviet Union.

title: Erving Scores 20 As Nets Win, 9678
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 4  Julius Erving scored 20 points, 14 of them in the opening period, as the New York Nets beat the Chicago Bulls, 9678, in an exhibition game tonight at Nassau Coliseum before 7,264 persons.

title: Brother Urges Suspect To Yield Abducted Boy
description: RUTHERFORD, Oct. 4 (AP)  The brother of Thomas Burns, suspected of having kidnapped George Kaloyerakis, 7 years old, on Sept. 23 from a schoolyard here, has appealed to him to return the boy.

title: U.S. Will Sell Bangladesh $35Million Worth of Grain
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (Reuters)The United States Agency for International Development announced today the sale of 100,000 to??s of wheat and 50,000 ions of rice to Bangladesh to help feed Bengalis whose crops were flooded by heavy monsoon rains in carly August.

title: Triple Returns $68,881
description: BOWIE, Md., Oct. 4 (UFI)The largest triple in United States racing history was recorded at Bowie Race Course today when the ninthrace finish of Nos. 1023 returned $68,881.50 for a $3 ticket.

title: New National Museum
description: The birth of a new museum in the nation's capital is not an unusual event; they appear with elephantine regularity. But in the case of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, the fanfare of this week's multiple openings is justified. This is the overdue inauguration of a national museum of modern art, something the capital has conspicuously lacked.

title: Federal Criticism of Effect Of Marijuana Reported Due
description: Changing its position on the health dangers of smoking marijuana, the Government plans to issue its first serious warning about its potential physical effects next week, according to a report on NBC Uews last night.

title: 2 BIGGEST BANKS CUT PRIME RATES
description: The Bank, of America and the First National City Bank of New York, the nation's first and second largest bank's, lowered their prime lending rates yesterday to 11 per cent from 12 per cent.

title: SENATE BIDS FORD UNDO NIXON PACT AND RETAIN TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Senate voted 56 to 7 today to direct the Ford Administrator to retain custody of former President Richard M. Nixon's White House tape recording: and papers.

title: Intensive Talks Planned in Italy In Quest for a New Government
description: ROME, Oct. 4  President Giovanni Leone announced plans today for broad consultations with political leaders on the crisis created by the resignation of the Government yesterday.

title: How to Catch the Supermarket Robbers
description: The first break came when Detective Kenneth Ford (24 years with the Police Department) and Detective Edward Murnane (20 years on the force) got lost on Rikers Island.

title: British Football Results
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE Third Division

title: Pulsar Find Hints Answer To Basic Science Puzzles
description: NEWPORT, R. 1., Oct. 4Pulsing radio emissions from deep within the constellation Aquila have revealed two objects orbiting one another, each of which weighs as much as the sun but is so dense it is probably only a few miles in diameter.

title: Waymaker Wins Futurity Trot
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 4 (AP)Clarence F. Gaines's Waymaker wore down his opposition today in the first fourheat Kentucky Futurity in 17 years to win the $100,000 third gem in trotting's triple crown.

title: U.S. AFFIRMS PLAN ON AEROSOL SPRAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Oat. 4 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that it would go ahead with a plan to require companies to buy back from consumers perhaps millions of cans of spray paint and other products containing vinyl chloride.

title: 11th Hour on Transit
description: The compromise bill to provide $11.8 billion in Federal masstransit subsidies over a sixyear period would go a long way toward averting the threat of a disastrous rise in this city's bus and subway fare. For the nation, the measure approved by a HouseSenate conference committee would represent the Federal Government's first longterm commitment to support of urban mass transportation.

title: Congress and the Administration Agree on Atom Security Slash
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Ford Administration and the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy have agreed to a major slash in an urgently requested security program designed to lessen the chances of the theft of nuclear materials.

title: Eichelberger And Coody Lead in Golf
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Oct. 4 (UPI)Aarles Coody and Dave Eichelbefger, a pair of softspoken Texans who haven't won on the tour since 1971, Moved into the lead of the $135,000 Sahara invitation today with 36hole totals of 135.

title: New England Phone Layoff
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4 (AP)The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company said today it would lay off about 850 craft employes. It said further reductions were expected before the end of the year.

title: ABBE B. RABINER
description: Abbe B. Rabiner, former owner of the Rabiner Corporation, manufacturer of women's apparel, died Thursday of heart attack at his home, 333 East 69th Street. He was 61 years old.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Liddy Sentence. Ends But Another Begins
description: WASHINGTON, Oct..I (AP) At one minute past noon today, G. Gordon Liddy was no longer in contempt of court but he remained in jail to serve his sentence in the Watergate breakin.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Alyeska Pipeline Service Company has awarded a $130million jointventure contract to the Willamette Western Corporation, Portland Ore., and the Peter Kiewitt Sons Company, Omaha, for the construction of four tanker berths in Valdez, Alaska. Alyeska is the consortium of eight oil companies building the $5billion 789mile transAlaska pipeline.

title: Cancer Fear Cited For a 2d Chemical
description: A widely used chemical raw material similar to vinyl chloride, which was cited earlier this year as the cause of a rare form of liver cancer among., workers, has also come under scrutiny as a result of evidence linking it to cancer in rats.

title: Dogfighting Curb Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) Senator Lowell T. Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, has joined lawmakers seeking to curb promoters who transport dogs across state lines for use in fighting. Mr. Weicker, who owns five dogs, yesterday cosponsored legislation prohibiting the interstate transportation of dogs used for fighting.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: For accepting gifts from art galleries, Samuel Lacher, a former import specialist with the United States Bureau of Customs, began to serve a twomonth term in Federal prison yesterday. The rest of the oneyear sentence, imposed by Judge Robert J. Ward of the United States District Court after Mr. Lacher had pleaded guilty on four counts, will be suspended.

title: Major Users of Power to Pay Bigger Part of Rate Rise
Malone's Bow Brings Crowd
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 4 (UPI) They came to see Big Mo.

title: Democrats in Hawaii Pick 1 of 3 for Governor Today
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 4  What looks in advance to be one of the closest primary campaigns in this state's short history will be decided tomorrow when the Democrats pick one of three men to run for Governor.

title: A Terrorist Leader Warns U.S, Envoy in Santo Domingo
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 4At the first meeting they have had, the leader of the terrorists holding seven hostages in the Venezuelan consulate told the United States Ambassador that the condition of the hostages was deteriorating, that their morale was bad and that something should be done soon.

title: 250,000 Hit by Sudan Flood
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan, Oct. 4 (Reuters)The worst floods in a decade have left 250,000 people homeless in southern Sudan, the Government announced today.

title: Recession Toll...
description: The sharp jump in unemployment last month eliminates any possible question that the economic program President Ford promises to present early next week must deal comprehensively with the reality of recession well as the reality of runaway inflation.

title: People in Sports
description: Willie Davis of the Montreal Expos had a busy day. First he was named the Expos' player of the year by the Montreal chapter of the Baseball Writers of America. Then, later in the day, he announced that he would not return to the Expos next season because the team had failed to guarantee he would not be traded.

title: Regazzoni Takes Battle to the Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 4Jackie Stewart has an accident and everyone blames the suspension. Clay Regazzoni has an accident, everyone blames Clay Regazzoni. They don't even look to see if a wheel came off.

title: Severe Food Scarcities Peril Five Indian States in Drought
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 4  At least five of, India's 22 states are facing serious food scarcities because of drought.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Friday, Oct. 4, 1974

title: Officials in Jersey Upset Over Oil Drilling Reports
description: TRENTON, Oct. 4Governor Byrne and his Commissioner of Environmental Protection, David J. Bardin, expressed concern today over reports that the United, States Department of Interior wanted to selli leases for oil drilling off the New Jersey coast in 1975.

title: U.S. PUSHING PLAN FOR 1975 LEASING OF OFFSHORE OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Department of the Interior is pushing a Nixon Administration plan to begin sales of offshore oil leases in the Atlantic Ocean and off Alaska next year.

title: Auto Local Approves Pact
description: KENOSHA, Wis., Oct. (UPI)Striking members of Local 72 of the United Auto. mobile Workers ratified a two. year national contract with the American Motors Corporation yesterday and returned to work at midnight on production lines that had been stopped since Sept. 16. In Milwaukee, Local 75 reached accord on a local agreement and scheduled ratification votes for the weekend on both the national and local pacts. Ratification by Local 75 would mean full production of 1975 model cars would begin Monday morning.

title: COUPLE SENTENCED IN F.H.A. SCANDAL
description: The head of one of the largest mortgage lending concerns in the East was sentenced yesterday to five years in jail, and his wife to four, after they were convicted of bribery and fraud in a scandal involving Federal housing programs for the poor.

title: Nixon Leaves the Hospital; He Must Restrict Activity
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 4 Former President Richard M. Nixon was discharged today from Memorial Medical Center here with instructions from his doctor to restrict his physical atictivity for a few weeks.

title: Military on Alert As the Portuguese Mark Anniversary
description: LISBON, Oct. 4 (Reuters)Military units in and around Lisbon were back on alert today as leftleaning air force officers met to pick two new men for the ruling military junta and the country prepared for major celebrations tomorrow marking the anniversary of the Portuguese republic.

title: PAYMENT IS SET BY STEINBRENNER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 George M. Steinbrenner 3d, chairman of the American Ship Building Company, consented in Federal district court here today to re;mburse the company for all illegal political contributions he made to the Finance Committee to ReElect the President and all other political donations since 1970.

title: CAREY'S CAMPAIGN GOES TO SUFFOLK
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 4Representative Hugh L. Carey took his gubernatorial campaign into Suffolk tonight, to the home county of Dominic Baranello, the Democratic leader who stood by him in the thinnest of times and who now is being mentioned as a future Democratic state chairman.

title: Governor Adds New Force in OldStyle Campaign
description: On the rare days that he can relax at home, a highranking state official likes to dress up in the kind of clothing he would never wear in public and show off to a few old and trusted friends.

title: Connecticut Candidate Stumps Grand Central
description: A Connecticut politician yesterday carried her battle for reelection into the alien territory of Grand Central Terminal, hoping to turn the heads of commuting voters who sometimes forget they are not, really New Yorkers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Suspect Booked in Fatal Mugging

title: Ford, Aide Hints a Veto Of G.I.'s Education Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4A White House spokesman indicated today that President Ford may veto the new education bill for Vietnam veterans that House and Senate conferees agreed to Wednesday.

title: WNCN Shift Is Temporarily Stayed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The United States Court of Appeals temporarily stayed today the planned conversion from classical music to rock by WNCN, the New York radio station.

title: Detectives Relate Crimes in Leuci Tapes
description: Want to hear a funny one? is the way Chester Dorris, a suspended detective, started relating a tale of cops and robbers wherein the cops became 1 the robbers and then the Robin Hoods with a load of stolen color TV, sets for the entire safe, loft and truck squad of the Police, Department.

title: It Was Malaysian Women Vs. the KingAnd the Women Won
description: KUALA LUMPUR, MalaysiaIf Malaysian women are not downtrodden, neither are, they elevated, for the state religion is Islam, Which among other things allows each man to have four wives and to divorce any one of them whenever he wants simply by saying I divorce thee three times (in Malay, it's Talag, Talag, Talag.

title: FARM LOBBY LINKED TO DELAY ON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)Strong lobbying by farmer cooperatives prompted a House Republican study group on antitrust matters to shelve a confidential staff report urging curbs on cooperatives' power as a means of reducing food prices, several sources said today,

title: State and City Agree on Steps To End Bellevue Center Impasse
description: ALBANY, Oct. 4The heads of the state and city mental health agencies agreed today on steps that they felt would end the long deadlock in the construction of a psychiatric center on the top four, floors of the new 21story, Bellevue Hospital in New York.

title: FRANKLIN NATIONAL QUITS CLEARING UNIT
description: The Franklin National Bank said yesterday that it had withdrawn as a member of the New York Clearing House Association, effective Sept. 30.

title: Vehicle Faults Traced By Builtin RCA Setup
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 The RCA Corporation is patenting features of a builtin test and diagnostic system for vehicles that is expected to prove a great timesaver in both military and commercial applications. Prototype equipment has been produced at the RCA government communications and automated systems division in Burlington, Mass., under contract with the Army's tank automotive command. An RCA spokesman predicted that the system would reduce maintenance checkout time on military vehicles by as much as 90 per cent.

title: City Almost Cites Wilson As PosterLaw Violator
description: A new dirty dozen politicians and companies who have put up posters illegally was made public yesterday by Environmental Protection Administrator Robert A. Low and he stopped just short of making it a baker's dozen by including Governor Wilson, the Republican gubernatorial candidate.

title: Humphrey Bright Spot For Falcons
description: It's depressing enough for Claude Humphrey that the Atlanta Falcons lost their first three games, after having set their sights on a playoff spot in the National Football League this season.

title: Joining Forces Weighed By Lehman and Abraham
description: Lehman Brothers Inc., the big Wall Street investment banking house, disclosed yesterday that it was discussing joining forces with Abrahan & Co., Inc., a highly regarded brokerage, house with a following among wealthy individual investors and a number of financial institutions.

title: Pulsar Find Hints Answer To Basic Science Puzzles
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 4Pulsing radio emissions from deep within the constellation Aquila have revealed two objeers orbiting one another, each of which weighs as much as the sun but is so dense it is probably only a few miles in diameter.

title: Art: George Segal Uses Past in a Jolt to Present
description: Art is made from other art, very largely. The other art in question may or may not be immediately visible, but if we are touched at all deeply by what we see, it is almost certain to be there.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market closed mixed yesterday as a result of profit taking and short covering.

title: Money
Jersey Seeks to Move Witness On Carter From Jail He Fears
description: The Attorney General of New Jersey intervened yesterday in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case by demanding the immediate transfer of a major defense witness from the Passaic County Jail, in which, he says, his life has been threatened.

title: Malpractice Costs Driving Doctors Off
description: The sharply rising cost of medical malpractice insurance in New York State is forcing the retirement of many doctors in lowincome areas and is preventing young physicians from going into practice here, a top official of the State Medical Society said yesterday.

title: 2 NEW SHIPMENT OF AMERICAN GRAIN TO SOVIET HALTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Administration announced tonight that it had put a hold order on two new contracts for the sale of 125 million bushels of wheat and corn to the Soviet Union.

title: JOHN W. EGGERS
description: John W. Eggers, who retired in 1972 as board chairman of Cresmer, Woodward, O'Mara & Ormsbee, Inc., newspaper representatives, died Thursday in Naples, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 63 years old.

title: State Releases $3Million For Improvement of L.I.R.R.
description: The state has released $3million from its $30million rail preservation fund for urgently needed track improvements on the Long Island Rail Road in Suffolk County, according to State Transportation Commissioner Raymond T. Schuler.

title: Mexican Business Leaders To Contest Price Freezes
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct, 4 (UPI)  Mexico's business leaders said today they would go to court to overturn President Luis Echeverria's sweeping decree that freezes prices on 150 items at Sept. 1 levels.

title: Sutton Gets Call Against Reuss in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4Without even pausing for dramatic effect, baseball will hustle tomorrow from the sizzling races of September into the postseason play of October. And in the playoff for the National League pennant here, the Los. Angeles Dodgers will confront the Pittsburgh Pirates with a classic test deep pitching against furious hitting.

title: 9th KarpovKorchnoi Game Adjourned
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4Anatol Karpov and Viktor Korchnoi, the Soviet grandmasters who area competing to pick a challenger or successor to Bobby Fischer as world chess champion, adjourned the ninth game of their match today in an unclear position.

title: C. R. Cleveland Jr. Weds Miss Whiteside
description: Susan Meredith Whiteside, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Burgess Whiteside of Tarrytown, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon in the Holy Trinity Anglican Church in Hamilton Parish, Bermuda, to Chevis Randle Cleveland Jr., a programer with the International Business Machines Corporation in Sterling Forest, N. Y. The Rev. Robert H. Hyslop performed the ceremony.

title: Humphrey Bright Spot For Falcons
description: It's depressing enough for Claude Humphrey that the Atlanta Falcons lost their first three games, after having set their sights on a playoff spot in the National Football League this season.

title: Ruffian Hurt, Out For Year
Official, in Shift, Retains Aide Who Disclosed Computer Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) Arthur F. Sampson, head of the General Services Adnunisitation backed down today from his decision to dismiss a computer expert who leaked information to Congress about a controversial Federal computer network.

title: PAY CUT IS URGED ON PAN AM PILOTS
description: Officers of the Pan American World Airways pilots' union unanimously recommended to its 2,000 members yesterday that they take a 10percent pay cut next year to help the airline cope with a threatened financial crisis.

title: Puetz Sheds 10 Pounds for Dolphins Game
description: Although some guards in the National Football League may feel they need to get up for Manny Fernandez, Miami's tough defensive tackle, Gary Puetz of the New York Jets feels he has to get downin weight, that is.

title: Wolfgang Windgassen: A Leading Heldentenor Remembered
description: Wolfgang Windgassen, who died on Sept. 8 at the age 60, was the leading Wagnerian tenor of the postwar generation. Although he sang infrequently in this country (six performances in the Metropolitan Opera's 1957 Ring cycles and a few Tristans in San Francisco in 1970), Windgassen was long considered an, indispensable participant in important Wagner performances in Europe, particularly at the Bayreuth Festival where he appeared 159 times between 1951 and 1966. The late Wagnerian conductor Hans Knappertsbusch once summed up Windgassen's unique position in the meager ranks of Heldentenors when a critic asked him: What in the name of God would Bayreuth do without Windgassen? Kna merely shrugged and growled back: What else? Go and fetch him at once.

title: W.F.L. Takes Control of The Blazers
description: ORLANDO, Ha., Oct. 5 (AP) The World Football League assumed control of the Florida Blazers late last night, brushing aside a lastminute brushing managing general partner Rommie Loudd to block the action.

title: On the Ganges: a Spy From Another World
description: AN Indian journalist in New Delhi warned me: All you need for Benares is a strong stomach and an open mind. If you drink only tea, your stomach should he fine. I cannot speak for your mind.

title: New Bill on Fund Disclosures
description: TRENTONA bill requiring candidates for office and all appointed or elected officeholders to disclose their sources of income will be introduced in both houses of the Legislature this month.

title: The World
description: In Summary

title: Wilderness Status for Brigantine Refuge Debated
description: OCEANVILLEThe tranquil bays and salt marshes of Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge seem to be safe from the encroaching development that is engulfing much of the state. But environmentalist fear that the refuge might be disturbed someday, perhaps by power lines from a floating nuclear plant or by new asphalt roads.

title: Mary Smith Hall Rewed
description: Mary Smith Hall, widow of Edwin H. Hall, was married yesterday afternoon at her home in Stratford, Conn., to J. Tyler Patterson of Old Lyme, Conn., a retired lawyer and former majority leader and Speaker of the Connecticut House of Representatives. The Rev. Joseph Shaw of the First Congregational Church in Stratford performed the ceremony. Mr. Patterson's first wife died.

title: Bloomfield Victor On Runs by Testa
description: Joe Testa scored 20 points in the second half yesterday and Bloomfield increased its unbeaten streak to 11 games with a 210 victory at Belleville, its second success of the season by that margin.

title: CAREY ON FORAY INTO ROCHESTER
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 5  Representative Hugh L. Carey toured this area today on an occasion of the kind that affords a campaigning politician an easy chance for favorable public exposure.

title: A DIVERSE PROGRAM IS GIVEN BY FISHBEIN
description: Zenon Fishbein, a pianist who has given several recitals here over the last 15 years, returned to Town Hall on Saturday afternoon with an unusual program that began with nine mazurkas by Chopin, continued with Prokofiexes Sonata No. 7 and ended with Bach's Goldberg Variations.

title: Morristown Gains 76 Victory
description: Morristown and Parsippany, both offensive powerhouses staged a defensive battle yesterday, and Morristown came away with a 76 victory in Morristown.

title: News of the Stage
description: Mourning Pictures, a first play by a young poet named Honor Moore, a graduate of Radcliffe College, will make its Broadway debut at the Lyceum Theater on Nov. 6.

title: Parent and Child
description: When it was disclosed earlier this year that administrators in a Bronx junior high school had routinely used paddle and strap to discipline pupils, the reaction at New York's Board of Education was firm and uncompromising. The paddlewielding deans were suspended from their jobs. School Chancellor Irving Anker issued a directive reminding the city's 950 public schools of the city's ban against corporal punishment. Spokesmen for civic groups expressed shock and surprise over the episode and over revelations that the incident may not have been as isolated as had initially been thought.

title: The 93d Was More Than The Impeachment Congress
description: WASHINGTONCongress, as it turns out, was not so much obsessed with Watergate as prodded by it.

title: Democrats Holding Wide Lead In Campaign, Gallup Poll Finds
description: The Democratic party holds wide lead over the Republican party in the Congressional campaign, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: On the Salmon: Like Riding on A Rollercoaster
description: A FEW weeks after I had sent our $200 deposit to Jim Campbell, the Idaho outfitter who takes passengers down the Salmon River in rubber rafts, a wellmeaning friend mailed me a clipping from a Boise newspaper: Four persons had drowned trying to run the river in May.

title: Alabama Rallies to Beat Mississippi Team, 3521
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 5 (UPI)Willie Shelby scored two touchdowns today to rally secondranked Alabama to a 3521 Southeastern Conference victory over Mississippi.

title: Two Council Committees Slate Public Meetings
description: The City Council has scheduled the following committee meetings open to the public this week: THURSDAYFinance Committee will consider, among other legislation, a bill providing for a joint annual audit of city funds and investments by the Controller and Finance Administrator. 10 A.M.

title: Knicks Trounced By 76ers, 13091
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct, 5 (AP)  Doug Collins and Perry Warbington scored 18 points apiece to pace a balanced Philadelphia attack as the 76ers overwhelmed the New. York Knicks. 13091, tonight in a National Basketball Association exhibition. game.

title: S.M.U. Outruns Oregon State
description: DALLAS, Oct, 5 (AP)Rex Garner, Wayne Morris and Risky Wesson rushed for more than 400 yards today as Southern Methodist subdued Oregon, 3730. Garner, a sophomore, scored touchdowns on runs of 5 and 12 yards and gained 103 yards on 15 carries. Morris rolled for 114 yards on 18 carries and scored once.

title: Officer's Son Shot By S.I. Policeman In Alleged Holdup
description: The 15yearold son of 2 veteran policeman was shot late Friday night by a police officer after the youth allegedly pointed a toy pistol at him during a holdup attempt in the Great Kills section of Staten Island.

title: Gymnast, 22, Retires
description: DENVER, Oct. 5 (UPI)Debbie Hill, 22 years old, said today that she would retire from active gymnastics and concentrate on coaching duties at the Denver School of Gymnastics. She had competed internationally for six years.

title: Photography
description: ONE of the most serious shortcomings of art criticism during the past century has been its utter and continuing failure to engage meaningfully with the most diversified and revolutionary imagemaking medium to evolve during that period.

title: European Tour a Boost For U. S. Dressage Squad
description: The United States Equestrian Team's dressage squad gave a good account of itself on the recently completed European tourthe first time the U.S.E.T. has sent an official dressage group across the Atlantic except for the Olympics. The team finished fifth in the world championship in Copenhagen behind West Germany, the Soviet Union, Switzerland and France. Denmark, Austria and the Netherlands finished behind the United States riders.

title: Sluggish Farmingdale Pulls Out 147 Verdict
description: Farmingdale, which lost only to Syosset, the top team in Nassau County last year, was forced to rally yesterday to defeat Oceanside, 147, in its first game in Conference I, which is composed of the schools with the largest enrollments in Nassau County.

title: Island Is Found Still Dependent on City
description: HAUPPAUGE  To those who have maintained that the rapid industrial development of Long Island over the last decade would lead to economic selfsufficiency for Nassau and Suffolk Counties, a 28page document that was released here last week came as a bit of a surprise.

title: South Korea Cautiously Shows Progress in Curbing Growth of Its Population
description: PYONGCHANG, South Korea, Oct. 2A yellow motorcycle with the words Family Planrung inscribed on it has long been a familiar sight in this small village, some 30 miles south of Seoul.

title: 4Run Surge in 5th Routs Hunter as Cuellar Wins
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 5 Neither starting pitcher was in top form today, but Mike Cuellar was closer to it than Jim (Catfish) Hunter as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Oakland A's, 63, in the first game of the American League's threeoffive championship series.

title: Rougher Play, Stiffer Penalties Forecast for N.H.L. Season
description: Jungle law will vie with written law during the National Hockey League season that opens on Wednesday. The extraordinary success last season of history's most penalized team, the Philadelphia Flyers, has led most clubs to figure that's the way to win a Stanley Cup.

title: TRINITY IS LOSING ITS HEADMASTER
description: Richard M. Garten, headmaster of the Trinity School since 1964, is resigning, effective next July 31, to lead what he hopes will be a simpler life as headmaster of the Gulf Stream School, in Gulf Stream, Fla.

title: Noam Chomsky argues, an Israeli and Arab talk
description: Long before he was interested in Vietnam, Noam Chomsky was interested in the Middle East. As a young man, he tells us in his new book, he hovered on the fringes of leftwing Zionist groups. In the days before the establishment of Israel, he opposed Jewish statehood, favored some form of binationalism, thought that the main struggle was not between Arabs and Jews but between socialism and capitalism. Almost 30 years later he holds fast to those views. He still believes that socialist hinationalism is the correct position and now, on the first anniversary of the fourth ArabIsraeli war, he has published a book to defend that position.

title: Oneupmanship
description: ACROSS

title: JEWS WILL MARK A JOYOUS HOLIDAY
description: Simhat Torah, one of the most joyous days in the Hebrew calendar, begins at sundown tomorrow.

title: Greenwich, New Canaan Post Routs
description: Greenwich and New Canaan continued to plunder their opposition yesterday en route to their confrontation in two weeks.

title: First Trial Decision in MeatFraud Cases Involving BriberyConspiracy and Tax Evasion Is Due Tomorrow
description: The first trial decision in a series of major state and Federal prosecutions of meat business figures charged with tax evasion and briberyconspiracy is expected tomorrow in the case of the world's largest beef company and its cochairman.

title: Dismissal of Head Of Texas U. Sparks Call for an Inquiry
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct 5The Austin chapter of the American Association of University Professors voted yesterday to ask its national organization to investigate the dismissal of Dr. Stephen H. Spurr from his post as president of the University of Texas.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Hooked Rug Was the Artistic Apotheosis of the Potato Sack
description: A UNDERFOOT might well have been the appropriate title for the stunning exhibition of 19th and early 20thcentury American rugs now on view at the Museum of American Folk Art. But the prim and proper title under which it is billed, Hooked Rugs in the Folk Art Tradition, does lend a touch of academic classentirely deservedto an art form which, even with, the current rage for patchwork quilts and primitive paintings, has only lately come into prominence. Connoisseurs and collectors of American folk art have treasured hooked rugs for some time, of course. But the present exhibition should definitely raise them to the status of a genuine art for the publicatlarge.

title: An easy road to unsuccess
description: My friend has meant for some years now to write her memoirs, to be entitled Passive Like Me. The catch is, of course, that even though the possibilities are limitless, she's far too loyally passive to get started. Donald Peabody Coffin, the dumb hero of L. J. Davis's fourth novel, is also devoted to passivity, but his devotion is of a nature so doggedly humorless that it requires constant effort to be entertained or enlightened by his author's witty descriptions of his passage.

title: Top Award Is Captured By Terrier
description: WHITEHORSE, Pa., Oct. 5 Joe Tacker, who has been piloting lanes for Hawaiian Air for 25 years, is a man accustomed to making fast decisions. It took him just nine minutes to decide today that a Lakeland terrier, Ch. Tarnbreck Cassius, owned by Countess Ercilia Le Ny of Milford, N.J., was best in a field of 2,279 at the 62d annual show of the Devon Dog Show Association at the Radnor Hunt Club.

title: WILSON APPOINTS STATE STUDY UNIT
description: Governor Wilson yesterday announced the appointment of the members of his Little Hoover Commission to study the economy and efficiency of state government. The appointments came nine months after the Governor had announced the establishment of the commission.

title: $113,870 in Drug Award
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 5 (UPI) The Texas Supreme Court has ruled that Winthrop Laboratories must pay $113,870 to a widow whose husband died of a drug advertised as harmless as aspirin. The court said that Winthrop, a division of Sterling Drug, Inc., was liable for the death of Glenn E. Crocker in 1968 because it said the painkiller Talwin was nonaddictive and advised his physician the drug was as harmless as aspirin.

title: National Guard Pilot Killed
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 5 (AP)The pilot of an A37 Air National Guard plane was killed today when his aircraft crashed during a lowlevel practice bombing run at nearby Camp Drum, officials said. The pilot, who was alone In the twoseat plane, was not immediately identified. It was the fourth fatality on the same practice staffing range since 1963, a National Guard spokesman said.

title: Headliners
description: A Manager

title: Opera: City Troupe Returns With HalfHearted Don Giovanni
description: When the New York City Opera's new production of Don Giovanni was unveiled, two years ago, it was universally condemned as a cheap distortion of Mozart's ideas. Julius Rudel may have thought so too, for last night the same production of Don Giovanni was brought back, but with new staging by Stephen Porter, and with Mr. Rudel himself in the pit. The cast, too, was largely new: Only Robert Hale, in the title role, and Spiro Malas, as Leporello, were holdovers.

title: Hollywood Is Crossing the Last Racial Barrier
description: YEARS AGO, when Hollywood still spun fantasies of a Rinso White World, the sensuous Lena Home desperately wanted to play Julie in MGM's remake of Showboat. She seemed absolutely perfect for the part of an entertainer on the Cotton Blossom who leaves the troupe in shame when word spreads that she has Nigra blood. But she didn't get to play the doomed mulatto. It wasn't a question of black not being beautiful. Black simply wasn't acceptable as sexy. Lilywhite Ma Gardner sailed on the showboat instead of Lena Horne.

title: River Battle: Lumbermen Vs. Ecologists
description: The Salmon River is part of central Idaho's 2.5millionacre wilderness area, the largest remaining in the United States outside Alaska. Martel Morache, of the Idaho Fish and Game Department, has called it perhaps the largest highquality relatively undisturbed major river system left in the continental United States. The waters of its creeks run clear in the spring when other waters run brown. Chinook salmon and steelhead trout migrate 700 miles from the Pacific to spawn in these creeks, fighting a battle for survival against downstream dams and the damage to upstream watersheds. The 190 species of wildlife identified along its banks include cougar, lynx, bobcat, coyote, fox, porcupine, badger, beaver, marten, mink, otter, muskrat, skunk, elk, bighorn sheep and bear.

title: No. Carolina Wins, 4529, From Pitt
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 5 (UPI)Mike Voight scored two touchdowns in an explosive third period to lead North Carolina to a 4529 victory over Pittsburgh today.

title: Susan P. Cooney, Editor, Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bossert Cooney of Old Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Park Cooney, to Carter Scott Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carnot Wagener Evans of Darien, Conn.

title: F.A.O. Is Warning About the Shortage Of Food in India
description: ROME, Oct. 5The Food and Agriculture Organization is preparing to sound an alarm about the Indian food shortage.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The last few years have brought some skillful writing about cops who happen also to be American Indians. One has merely to think of Richard Martin Stern's Johnny Ortiz and Tony Hillerman's Joe Leaphorn. Now Warwick Downing's Joe Reddman (red man, get it?) can be added to the list. He appears in THE PLAYER (Saturday Review Press, $5.95), and he operates as a private eye out of Denver. One thing about Indians such as Ortiz, Leaphorn and Reddman, they are not as other men. They may have the veneer of civilization, but when there is a crisis, layer upon layer peels offand sheer atavism brings them to their opponent. They know Nature; they can track and run endlessly; they are terrible machines when aroused.

title: Puerto Rico Dock Workers Return to Jobs After Strike
description: SAN JUAN, Oct. 5 (AP)Longshoremen began today to unload container ships that had been idle for nearly a week because of a strike.

title: Civil Service Rules Facing 2 Challenges
description: TRENTONFor as many years as Civil Service has protected public employes, there has been a growing concern, both in the Legislature and the courts, that its protection placed public employment in a bureaucratic straitjacket.

title: Colorado Plane Crash Kills 5
description: DENVER, Oct. 5 (AP)family of five on the way Texas for a birthday celebi tion was killed when a ligh plane crashed into a south eastern Colorado farm field, the Baca County sheriff said today The singleengine Cessna 18 was flying to Springfield, Colo

title: D. A. Verdery Fiance of Miss Lunan
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Douglas Lunen of Middlebury, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Jessica Laing Lunen, to Donald Aldrich Verdery, son of the Rev. John D. Verdery, headmaster of the Wooster School, and Mrs. Verdery of Danbury, Conn.

title: Poly Prep Is Victor Over Horace Mann
description: Poly Prep's Ben Preziosi, a senior fullback had a good day against Horace Mann yesterday in leading Poly Prep to a 4714 victory. It was Horace Mann's first defeat in three games while the winners are now 2 and 1.

title: VOTERS TO DECIDE VARIETY OF ISSUES
description: Americans will vote on Nov: 5 for candidates for Governor, Congress and dozens of lower offices.

title: CampaignSpending Bill's Key Provision Doesn't Apply
description: WASHINGTONThere is no subject on which Congressmen have more expertise, none on which they are more conversant, than the subject of how best to get elected.

title: ARAB GUERRILLAS SHRUG OFF SPLIT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 5The breakaway from the Palestine Liberation Organization of an intransigent Marxist faction opposed to any ArabIsraeli political settlement has produced only a surface ruffle in Palestinian ranks.

title: Baseball Diamond: A Girl's Best Friend
description: Whenever I play baseball with my brother and I get a hit, he says it was luck. But if I strike out it's because of my sex. Click!

title: Weak Warrants
description: Last summer in this space we reported that the American Telephone & Telegraph Company had a problemthe prospect that its outstanding issue of warrants might expire next year without being exercised, thus ending up worthless and not helping to raise some $1.6billion for the company.

title: Notre Dame Overcomes Michigan State by 1914
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 5 (AP)Wayne Bullock scored two touchdowns and Dave Reeve kicked two field goals today as seventhranked Notre Dame defeated stubborn Michigan State, 1914.

title: WALLACE L. CLAPP
description: Wallace L. Clapp, a vice president of Insurance Magazine, who retired in 1971 after 50 years with the publication, died on Friday in Mountainside Hospital, Glenu Ridge, N. J. He was 74 years old and lived at 11 Gordonhurst Avenue, Upper Montclair, N. J.

title: 6 Serving Life Terms Got U.S. Tax Refunds.
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 5 (AP)Six men serving life terms in a state prison have been charged with filing Federal tax returns and collecting refunds.

title: Juror Fee Rise Backed
description: WASITINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) Fees paid to Federal court jurors would be increased to $25 from $20 a day under a bill passed Wednesday by the Senate. The measure was sent to the House.

title: Hot Summer of '74 in Miami
description: MIAMI, Oct. 5 (AP)  The summer of 1974 was the hottest on record in Miami, the National Weather Service said Tuesday. Forecasters said that the average temperature at Miami International Airport in September set a record of 84.1 degrees. June, July and August also recorded the hottest temperatures on record, officials said.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Former Ambassador Edwin O. Reischauer (The Korean Connection, Sept. 22) has perceptively described the strategic dilemma of the United States with respect to South Korea: The situation has changed considerably while we are tied to an antiquated policy of unnecessary military aid. However, his analysis of the moral question rests on less firm ground. Two points in particular deserve much closer scrutiny.

title: Letters: Eurailpass Stops at the Border
description: To the Editor: Owners of the Eurailpass should be made aware that when traveling to Berlin it is necessary to pay the East German conductor a supplementary fare, because East Germany, like the rest of the European Communist bloc, does not honor the pass. Although it is stated in fine print on the back of the pass that it is not valid in Communist sectors, one can imagine that many unsuspecting rail travelers have and will continue to assume incorrectly that the journey to West Berlin requires nothing more than the routine presentation of pass and passport.

title: INFLATION PERILS NAVY'S SHIP PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5The Navy, which took a calculated risk in reducing the size of its fleet to obtain funds for modernization, now finds itself running short of money for construction of new warships.

title: NIXON BEGINNING RECOVERY PERIOD
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Oct. 5  Former President Richard M. Nixon began today a new phase of his convalescence from phlebitis in his left leg and a blood clot in his right lung as he spent the first full day at home after nearly a twoweek stay at the Memorial Hospital Medical Center of Long Beach.

title: Catharine A. Christiansen Has Nuptials
description: Catharine Ann Christiansen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot A. Christiansen of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday afternoon in the Reformed Church, to Richard Arthur Hollenberg, son of Mrs. Howard Morrison of Morristown, N.J., and the late Dr. Arthur V. Hollenberg. The Rev. Theodore Fritch performed the ceremony.

title: Pension Plan for Teenagers
description: Keogh for kids?

title: BUDWORM PERILS FORESTS IN MAINE
description: GREENVILLE, Me., Sept. 27 On July 16 at 9:30 P.M., the Weather Service radar at Limestone picked up a slowmoving blip some 20 miles wide and 8,000 feet deep.

title: Something Happened
description: The company that made a movie out of Joseph Heller's first novel, Catch22, had to assemble what became the 11th or 12th largest bomber force on the planet at the time. If somebody wants to make a movie out of his second novel, Something Happened, he can get most of his props at Bloomingdale'sa few beds, a few desks, some tables and chairs.

title: Empty Trucks and Inflation
description: Item: John Heagy, a small trucker in Riverhead, L.I., makes a living hauling produce into New York City. He'd like to haul processed foods or, for that matter, anything else back to the island. But the Federal Government won't let him, so his truck returns empty.

title: London Testing a Pact With Unions
description: LONDON: Oct. 5As they move sluggishly toward the national election on Oct. 10, Britain's three major political parties agree on one fact: inflation is the most serious problem confronting the nation. How to cure the malady, however, is a matter of intense debate.

title: Miss Desch Wed to M. D. Lenihan
description: Barbara Kay Desch and Michael Daniel Lenihan were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg in the Garden City (L. I.) Community Church.

title: Petty Retains Lead In Driver's Race
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. Oct. 5 (AP)Although Richard Petty finished 29th in the field of 30 at last Sun, day's Old Dominion 500 at Martinsville, Va., he still leads the driving championship race of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing.

title: People/Business
description: There was both good news and bad news on the energy front last week.

title: Gardens
description: IF PLANTS and all living things have feelings and respond to human at tention, as recent experiments sug gest, then this year's display of au tumn foliage color, might be viewed in a new light. Perhaps the ordinarily stately welldressed trees are behaving like burlesque strippers. They may be deliberately attracting attention to them selves with an extravagant display of color just before they drop their foliage finery and stand naked for the winter.

title: President Signs Bill Setting Standard Time
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) The nation will go back to standard time for a fourmonth period starting Oct. 27 under a bill signed today by President Ford.

title: Urban Development Unit Curbed on New Projects
description: Governor Wilson has curbed the authority of the. State Urban Development Corporation to undertake new projects and is forming a special task force to recommend changes in the agency's operations and financing methods.

title: Kings Point's Running Downs Fordham, 176
description: Jack Castagna, a tailback for Kings Point, battered Fordham for 105 yards, including a 37yard touchdown jaunt, in the first half yesterday to lead the Mariners to a 176 victory over the Rams in a Metropolitan Conference football opener for both teams.

title: Aerosol Spray Curb Urged
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 5 (AP)The Ann Arbor City Council has advised local residents to stop using aerosol sprays until a National Academy of Sciences panel completes a study of the sprays.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The intriguing question in the Soviet Union now is whether last week's successful and officially sanctioned show of modern and unorthodox art in Moscow will be a onetime event or lead to further cultural liberalism for the Russians.For the time being, everyone seems to be in a waitandsee mood. Soviet authorities have made no move, evidently eager to preserve the goodwill that their gesture generated in the West. The artists sense that they accomplished something extraordinary and are not in a hurry to press their luck. Plans of some iconoclastic poets to hold an outdoor reading so far have not materialized.

title: With budget, telephone and hope through wildest New York
description: The epic trek through the New York wilderness by Maycr Abe Beame and his small loyal band is now in its 10th month andEpic?

title: Racing World's Attention Focused on Watkins Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 5  This is the Monte Carlo of Elmira, the Monza of Binghamton, the Nuerbuergring of the Finger Lakes the site of the United States Grand Prix, virtually the only automobile race in this country that the rest of the world cares about.

title: Mrs. Knauer Chides Hotels On OverBooking Practice
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) Virginia H. Knauer, the President's consumer adviser, has warned the motel and hotel industry to expect Federal intervention if overbookings of as many as 1.4 million travelers a year do not cease.

title: YUGOSLAVIA RAISES TRAFFIC PENALTIES
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 5Yugoslavia, whose roads are regarted by many traffic experts as the most dangerous in the world, has enacted a law to increase penalties for violations tenfold.

title: State Deposit Plan Is Hailed by Leone
description: TRENTONNot long after taking office last January, State Treasurer Richard C. Leone said that he did not want his office to control where the state would be investing its money in time deposits. He still feels that way today, especially in view of the fact that a new deposit plan, which is based on competitive bidding, is working.

title: By HILTON KRAMER
description: WASHINGTON, D. C.

title: '37 Rating at Yale Found Ford Mature and Wise
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 5 (AP) President Ford's store of general information was rated not the best when he applied for admission to Yale Law School, but his judgment was described as good.

title: Northwestern Topples Oregon Team by 1410
description: EVANSTON, III., Oct. 5 (AP)Mitch Anderson's two touchdown passes offset the brilliant running of Don Reynolds today and lifted Northwestern to a 1410 intersectional football victory over Oregon.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The date of the next meeting of the Long Beach school board was incorrectly reported in this section last week. The meeting is to be held Tuesday at the Magnolia School.

title: The World /Continued
description: Whose side are the international oil companies on? Are the Texacos and Exxons of this world working hand glove with the producing nations to squeeze the last dollar out of the oilstarved consumer countries? Or are the companies simply the meek and powerless tools of the rasping Mideast sheiks?

title: Sunday Observer
description: For days we sat at the box, mesmerized by sport. We saw the Mets beat the Nets and the Jets, saw Pancho Segura score a hole in one and watched thunderstruck while Evonne Goolagong came off the bench in the final seconds of play to whip the mighty Nebraska Cornhuskers with a line drive to center field.

title: Hearing Set For Report On Parking In Bayside
description: A detailed report analyzing the controversial parking and traffic problem plaguing residents living near Queensborough Community College in Bayside will be the subject of a community board meeting tomorrow night.

title: WOMAN CONVICTED DESPITE RAPE PLEA
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 5Inez Garcia, 30 years old, was convicted of seconddegree murder here yesterday for shooting and killing a 300pound man who, she says, helped another man rape her.

title: Woman Farmer Unsettles Chester's Mayoralty Race
description: CHESTERIt is early autumn in this semirural borough in the rolling hills and woods of southwestern Morris County. The apple harvest is already here, a few leave. are turning scarlet and the name Janet Abeles is becoming a familiar one.

title: ... and How to Do It
description: In view of President Ford's dismaying reluctance deal with excessive gasoline consumption at the point where it is easiest to controlthat is, at the gas station it is all the more incumbent on his Administration act promptly on all those other fronts where fuel can be saved, to the advantage of this country and the frustration of the international oil pricegougers.

title: C. C. Bradford Weds Nancy Roloff
description: The marriage of Nancy Roloff to Charles Cozad Bradford 3d took place yesterday afternoon in Christ and Trinity Episcopal Church in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Dana Forrest Kennedy performed the ceremony.

title: Nancy Haas Married To Timothy Adriance
description: Nancy Elizabeth Haas and Timothy Michael Adriance were married yesterday morning in the chapel of the Bryn Mawr, Pa. Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Ray J. Dollenmayer.

title: CITY SEEKS MORE FROM BLUE CROSS
description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation is seeking to compel Blue Cross to stop discriminating against pity hospitais and to begin paying or the cost of caring for its subscribers who receive psychiatric treatment in city facilities.

title: Belmont Race Charts
Aerosol Spray Curb Urged
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 5 (AP)The Ann Arbor City Council has advised local residents to stop using aerosol sprays until a National Academy of Sciences panel completes a study of the sprays.

title: ANNE SEXTON DIES; PULITZER POET, 45
description: WESTON, Mass., Oct. 5 (AP) Anne Sexton, the poet who won the 1967 Pulitzer Prize for her volume Live or Die, was found dead yesterday inside an idling car, parked in her garage.

title: Child to the Manheimers
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Manheimer of Beverly Hills, Calif on Sept. 19 at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital in Los Angeles. The child has been named Dani Ruth. Mrs. Manheimer is the former Eliza beth Derfner of New York. Her husband is national publicity manager of MetroGoldwynMayer.

title: Kupecs on Target In North and South
description: MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Oct. 5This was a better than normal day for the Kupec family of Syosset. Matt Kupec's quarterbacking helped Syosset demolish Massapequa, 3214, here while in Chapel Hill, N.C. Chris, Matt's brother, guided the University of North Carolina to a 4529 victory over Pittsburgh.

title: 2 DEALERS CANCEL SOVIET GRAIN SALE AT FORD'S BEHEST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5After meeting with President Ford today, two grain companies agreed to cancel a $500million sale of corn and wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: Islip Artists' Colony Seeks Historic Designation
description: OAKDALE  When Mrs. Mary Ann Morrison tells people, We live in a chicken coop, she isn't complaining about tight quarters. She is speaking literallyand with some pride about the unusual type of dwellings she and more than 150 other residents occupy in the barnyard section of the former William K. Vanderbilt estate, Idle Hour.

title: Accord Is Reached in City U. Building Jobs Dispute
description: Following a meeting with demonstrators who halted construction of the north academic center at City College over minority employment the New York State Dormitory Authority has agreed to promote specific employment and contractor objectives of the protesters:

title: Nader Is Testing the Testers
description: PRINCETON  For about 24 years now, the Educational Testing Service has been administering standard entrance, examinations for colleges and graduate schools. This year, a Ralph Nader study group is testing the service's willingness to undergo examination itself.

title: Thomas Francis Ruhm Marries Michele Wood
description: The marriage of Michele Wood, daughter of Mrs. John Walter Wood of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Mr. Wood, to Thomas Francis Ruhm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman D. Ruhn of Southport, Conn., and Cumberland Center, Me., took place yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church, Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Charles A. Rudnick, president of Rudnick, Kramer & Co., Inc. has purchased a controlling interest in Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., one of the oldest real estate firms in the city. The two companies will be merged to form Rudnick, Brett, Wyckoff, Inc.

title: TEHERAN'S MAYOR DRAWS CRITICISM
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 5The way Mayor Gholam Reza Nikpay describes it, Teheran is a wonderful place with no really serious problems.

title: Cooke Got Malaria On African Visit; Is Resting at Home
description: Cardinal Cooke has been confined to his residence since Friday with a case of malaria contracted on his recent sixday visit to the heart of the drought area in West Africa.

title: Gradual Change Seen in Mozambique Under Rebels
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, MozambiqueMany people feared that the coming of a guerrillacontrolled government to Mozambique would bring sudden and dramptic cha??ges.

title: Candidates in 4th C.D. Mostly Disagree
description: MINEOLA  The Republican and Democratic candidates in the Fourth Congressional District agree on only two things: integrity as a main issue and a limit on the funds they will spend on their campaigns.

title: Small Bakeries Face Difficult Times
description: NORTH ARLINGTON The New Jersey Bakers Board of Trade held its annual convention in Atlantic City last month, but Joe Laspada, who owns Joe's Bake Shop on Ridge Road, was too busy trying to make ends meet to attend:

title: Zalman Shazar Is Dead at 84; President of Israel for 10 Years
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 5Zalman Shazar, Israel's third President, died in Jerusalem this morning, a day before his 85th birthday.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  New Jersey already has scores of different commissions and committees studying everything from interstate sanitation and corporation laws to beach, erosion. All were created by various Legislatures, but none has ever been regarded as much of a political threat to the Governor in office at the time.

title: 5,099,000 of Voting Age
description: WASHINGTONNew Jersey has 5,099,000 votingage residents, according to a new Census Bureau calculation. However, if a downward trend of recent years persists, only about 45 per cent of these people will cast ballots on Nov. 5.

title: CANADA MAY GET HER OWN CHARTER
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 5Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, with the agreement of the parliamentary Opposition, plans to obtain a truly Canadian constitution and thereby end the anomaly under which Canada's charter, the closest document to a constitution that the country has, can be amended only by the British Parliament.

title: Dance: Mika Wakamatsu
description: Pretentiousness and talent marked the American debut of Miki Wakamatsu, a Japanese modern dancer, at the Riverside Church Theater on Friday night.

title: Karen Gottlieb Plans Nuptials
description: Hilda Gottlieb of Silver Spring, Md., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Karen Ruth Gottlieb, to Robert Grant Dressner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard R. Dressner of New York. A December wedding is planned.

title: A.M.A. SAID TO AID HOUSE CAMPAIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP)Organized medicine has contributed more than $400,000 to the campaigns of 42 members of the House of Representatives, most of them supporters of the American Medical Association's healthinsurance proposal, a lobbying organization has disclosed.

title: The Nation
description: House and Senate conferees have agreed upon a relatively broad campaign reform law that would limit spending and contributions in all Federal elections and introduce government subsidies for Presidential candidates. The legislation, which seems assured of passage and Presidential approval, is the most significant result so far of the Watergate scandal.

title: Blue Cross Rate Rise Asked
description: BOSTON, Oct, 5 (AP)Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Massachusetts have filed a rate increase request with the state Insurance Commission. The proposed increase for the companies' 280,000 nongroup family and individual subscribers, as much as $27 per year, is needed to pay for additional benefits mandated by the 1973 Massachusetts Legislature, the Companies said.

title: Choate Rolls to Third Triumph, 3512
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 5  Choate had five touchdowns and conversions before Andover managed to score today and Choate went on to a 3512 victory. Jerry Barken put the finishing touches on touchdowns by Tirn McAuliffe, Brooks McMillen, Marty Smith and Frank Buntin with conversion kicks. Buntin scored twice.

title: Burlington Chorale Holding Auditions
description: PEMBERTONThe Burlington Chorale is holding auditions every Monday evening at Burlington County College.

title: Indiana Ties Loss Mark
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 5  A junior quarterback, Chuck Fiorante, sparked a 21point second quarter today as West Virginia downed Indiana, 240.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks on Soviet Jews' Emigration Periled
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5Negotiations for a compromise that could, allow at least 60,000 Soviet Jews and others to emigrate yearly in return for American trade concessions have run into serious problems that may block an agreement.

title: Carcinogens: Unchecked, They Threaten An Epidemic
description: Cancer invariably arouses fear and anger when it strikes, but society has done very little to control the thousand or more substances in the environment that are thought to cause from 60 to 90 per cent of the nearly 700,000 cases of cancer in the United States each year.

title: Ellen Leeds Is Married
description: The marriage of Ellen Adrienne Leeds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira F. Leeds, to Richard Alan Schehr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Schehr of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday evening at Temple Rodeph Sholem. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony. The bride's father is senior vice president of Glemby International, operators of beauty salons in department and specialty stores. Mr. Schehr's father is president of the Fabric Leather Corporation, a division of Borden, Inc.

title: Fashion Bypasses Stone Carver, 81
description: For 81yearold Silvio Bianchi, a stone carver for 60 years, there is no work any more. The carving of the majestic figures that used to adorn churches, houses and government buildings throughout the country has given way to the functional buildings of modern technology, and the creators, like the creations, are a vanishing breed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article OutofTown Builders Falter in City [Sept. 15], while basically accurate, failed to point out the success of Village Greens as measured by the 500 or so families in residence.

title: Natural Glamour and Prestige Keeps Sports Wedded to Politics in World
description: Sports and politics do mix, Arthur Ashe once remarked.

title: Leftist Gains Lead to Renewed Revolutionary Fervor in Portugal
description: LISBON, Oct. 5The name of Portugal's former dictator, the late Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, was removed today from Europe's longest suspension bridge in one manifestation of the renewed revolutionary fervor now sweeping the country.

title: The Region
description: At 3:30 P.M. on Thursday, a dozen members of Congress walked through the double doors of a Capitol dining room beneath the legend this Government, the offspring of our own choice, uninfluenced and unawed, has a just claim to your confidence and support.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: TWO months ago, in the waning days of the Nixon Administration, the stock market stood battered and bruised in the area of 800 for the DowJones industrial average after a drop of some 250 points from its historic high only 18 months earlier. It was a precipitous drop in a relatively short period and was attributed to adverse trends in the economy, high interest rates and the growing lack of confidence in the nation over the Watergate trauma.

title: U.S.Bred Allez France Choice Today in Tare
description: PARIS, Oct. 5  There more than $4million to be picked up in the Prix de l' Arc de Triomph national lottery, and bettors in France, invesing 60 cents or more, will toss around another couple of million dollars to win the Tierce, France's version of the triple.

title: Ideas &Trends Continued
description: The second stage of an (agri)cultural exchange with Communist China has been completed. The participants are the Nanking Botanical Gardens and the Cary Arboretum, a branch of the New York Botanical Gardens in Millbrook; N. Y.; the reciprocal shipments involved tree seeds, the first such exchange in more than 20 years.

title: Winifred Knott May, Teacher, Bride of Bruce Roger Nyquist
description: Winifred Knott May, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winston Lewis May Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married in New Canaan yesterday afternoon to Bruce Roger Nyquist, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard B. Nyquist of Rockford, Ill. The ceremony was performed in St. Mark's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Grant A. Morill.

title: Krishna Menon Dies
description: V. K. Krishna Menon, former Defense Minister of India and a controversial figure in Indian and international politics for much of his life, died in New Delhi at the age of 77. Obituary, Page 64.

title: Babylon's Alert Play Surprises East Hampton, 348
description: Babylon High, displaying alert defensive play and sparked by the passing of Glen Vickers, turned in an early surprise in Suffolk yesterday, completely dominating East Hampton, 348, in the league A2 opener for both teams.

title: The founding grandfather
description: Fiftysix floors above Manhattan's Rockefeller Center, William Couper's bust of America's first billionaire gazes out stonily on the private offices of his four surviving grandsons. Those who knew him in his later years find the likeness striking, for at the end of his life John Davison Rockefeller (18391937) had a remarkably graven look. He is remembered as a wrinkled, bony nonagenarian who distributed 20,000 dimes to strangershe started with nickels but found them too heavyand spent his last days among the black parishioners of the Union Baptist Church in Ormond Beach, Fla., chanting prayers and reedily affirming in his quavering tenor that when the roll was called up yonder, he'd be there.

title: In the Coop Market, a New Realism Takes Hold
description: What its owners call the greatest coop in New York Cityeight rooms in a tower on Central Park West with a panoramic view of nearly everything worth viewinghas been on the market for two years.

title: Randall Shaw Has Nuptials
description: In the Reformed Church of Bronxville, N. Y., yesterday afternoon, Randall Leath Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Shaw of Bronxville, N. Y., was married to Stephen Lansing Zabriskie, son of Mrs. John Lansing Zabriskie of Aurora, N. Y., and the late Mr. Zabriskie. The ceremony was performed by the senior minister, the Rev. Dr. Charles L. Copenhaver. He was assisted by the Rev. Richard Kuenkler of the Aurora Presbyterian Church.

title: South Jersey Set For Revere Race
description: HADDONFIELD  South Jersey has an unsung Paul Revere, if legends are to be believed. His name is Jonas Cattell, and one morning in 1777 he supposedly ran nine milesfrom Haddonfield to Fort Mercer on the Delaware Riverto warn of approaching Hessians.

title: Scholarships for Women: A Pure and Simple Plan Set
description: The number of college athletic scholarships open to women next year is expected to increase from several hundred to several thousand as schools attempt to meet Federal guidelines toward equalization But coaches won't of sports programs. But coaches won't be flying prospects across the country for camput visits, or taking them out dinner or hounding them in their homes. According to new regulations issued by the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women (A.I.A.W.) governing recruitment and financial aid, the recruiting of studentathletes may not be subsidized by the university.

title: Manasquan Streak Ends, 128
description: Shore Regional surprised Manasquan, 12.8, at West Long Branch to snap New Jersey's longest winning streak at 20 game.

title: FRANCE IS DIVIDING CORSICA INTO 2 AREAS
description: PARIS, Oct. 5 (Reuters)The French Government has divided Corsica into two administrative departments in a move that could help defuse growing independence agitation on the Mediterranean island.

title: A Visiting Orchestra From L. A.
description: THE Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra is completing its first European tour this week and setting up a threeday miniresidency at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. Since its conductor, Zubin Mehta, is such a wellknown quantity, it seemed worthwhile to have a word with the orchestra's executive director, Ernest Fleischmann, a person of some reputation on the musical scene who was naturally willing to expand on the recent progress of his organization.

title: Montgomery Kellogg Weds Sally Gernert
description: Sally Gernert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Breetz Gernert of St. Davids, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Montgomery Alexander Kellogg. He is the son of Mrs. Cornelia F. Keresey of New York and Richard C. Kellogg of Villanova, Pa.

title: Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: I WAS most distressed to read Stephen E. Rubin's article about Schuyler Chapin and the Metropolitan Opera [The Met's Own Ills Sound Like an Opera Plot, Sept. 22].

title: Jeanne Anne Hermann Bride of Paul Stenard
description: Jeanne Anne Hermann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hermann of Plandome Manor, L. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Paul Whitney Stenard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Stenard of Garden City, L. I.

title: Numismatics
description: ALTHOUGH Gerald R. Ford was not ushered into office with the usual trappings, his inauguration will be commemorated in at least one customary waywith an official inaugural medal. Thus will his Presidency continue a numismatic tradition that began with the second term of William McKinley in 1901.

title: Recordings
description: ACOMIC opera by Verdi means just one thing to most opera goersFalstaff, his very last work composed when he was 80.
