description: NEWARK  Thomas Carmichael, this year's winner of the coveted Roscoe Pound award of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency, is an angry man.

title: Daughter of A Revolutionary
description: Natalie HerzenTatawas the eldest of Alexander Herzen's daughters and by far his favorite child: On Tata I had pinned my highest hopes. She was the repository of his ambitions his spiritual heir, the most Russian of her generation of Herzens. She has our tastes, he wrote to Tata's brother, notre gnie. This moral legacy would have been burdensome for any descendant, even for a son. Herzen was a powerful figurea brilliant writer, one of the most politically influential men of his time, which was the middle 19th century. He was a Russian socialist revolutionary of aristocratic originthe name Herzen had been invented for him by his fatherwho went into voluntary exile in 1847. Bakunin would say of him, as a theorist, he is unsurpassed. His two periodicals, The Pole Star, and above all The Bell, smuggled Into Russia, fostered and kept alive the hope of radical change. One of his great political gifts was his intelligent understanding of the Westan intellectual advantage his Russian successors were not to inherit. According to Isaiah Berlin, Herzen was the acknowledged leader of all that was generous, enlightened, civilized, humane in Russia.

title: Stamps
description: FOLLOWING up on the World Population Conference in Bucharest, Romania, in late August, the United Nations is issuing on Oct. 18 four commemoratives in observance of World Population Year, intended by the world organization as an effort to defuse the ticking global population bomb.

title: Javits Warns Housing Recession Could Affect Rest of Economy
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits cautioned yesterday that this country was approaching a recession in the housing market which could foment a general recession affecting all economic sectors.

title: Sylvia Fallow Is Wed in Hartford
description: Sylvia Cabot Fallow and Benjamin, Brewster, seniors at Trinity, College in Hartford, were married in the college's chapel yesterday evening by the bridegroom's brother, the Rev. William Brewster, an Episcopal priest. Thee Rev. Alan C. Tull, chaplain of Trinity, assisted.

title: Halting Nuclear Spread
description: Secretary of State, Kissinger's offer to work urgently with other countries toward a system of effective international safeguards against the diversion of peaceful nuclear materials into explosives contained a belated admission as vital as the offer itself. It represented acknowledgment, after the fact, that the Nixon Administration's commitment to provide large nuclear power reactors to Egypt and Israel was made without adequately considering that such a safeguard system not only did not exist but was difficult to build.

title: Freedom from the press: An essay on the daily addiction of news and why, if the reader were to take the author's argument to heart, this would be...
description: Iseldom read a newspaper, and you shouldn't read one, either; I seldom watch television; seldom pick up a popular magazine, though I read Time magazine almost every week when I lived in Hiroshima in 195758. I listen to FM radio in the car. Last year, a San Francisco professor said to me: But how would you know about Watergate? Come on, Leonard (I replied), a man or a woman of instinct knows about Watergate from history, from literature.

title: Kelly Leads Exeter to 217 Victory
description: EXETER, N. H., Oct. 5Mike Kelly, the quarterback, passed for all three touchdowns as Exeter won its first game in two starts today with a 217 victory over Tabor. It was the visitors first loss in two outings.

title: Lucy Gail Campbell Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Glover Leigh Campbell of Ottawa, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Gail Campbell, to Thomas Tredick Leuchtenburg, son of Dr. and Mrs. William E. Leuchtenburg of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., and Centerbrook, Conn. The wedding is planned for Dec. 28 in Christ Episcopal Church in Ottawa.

title: Katherine McLaughlin Bride of Joseph Morse
description: Katherine Dana McLaughlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Paul McLaughlin of Philadelphia, and Joseph F. Morse, son of Albert Raymond Morse of Manchester, N.H., and the late Mr. Morse, were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents by Judge Ethan Allen Doty of the Court of Common Pleas.

title: Son Born to Mrs. Hose
description: A son was born Sept. 28 to Mr. and Mrs. John R. Hose at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. The child has been named John Daniel Haven. Mrs. Hose, the former Janet Florence Rice, is a club director at Maomillan Book Clubs, Inc. Mr. Hose is an administrator with the central office of the City University of New York and member of the adjunct faculty at Queens College.

title: Top U.S. Golf Pros In Aussie Tourney
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 5 (AP)Fifteen American golfersa record for an Australian tournament will compete in the month's Chrysler Classic Nov. 7 through 10 at the Royal Melbourne Club.

title: Black Domestics Act to Upgrade Status
description: PRINCETON  Several black women who clean, cook and babysit for families in this affluent community have created an organization to upgrade the status of their occupation.

title: It Isn't Required, But It Is Welcomed
description: During the Watergate years, a number of Americans have looked longingly at the Parliamentary system of government. They liked the vision of a Prime Minister immediately accountable to Parliamenthaving to go down into the pit and answer members' questions, always subject to legislative rebuke and removal.

title: Mahwah Wants to Detour Route 287
description: MAHWAHThe farms that once dominated this northwestern Bergen County township are gone, and in their place have come industry and express highways. For most of the 12,000 residents of Mahwah the changes that have taken place in the last decade have been satisfactory, except for what has happened to their community as a result of roads cutting through so that motorists can link up with the New York State Thruway in nearby Suffern.

title: Go First Class, Fly With Rockefeller
description: A halfdozen long black limousines rolled through the streets of Manhattan before dawn, picking up their sleepy passengers and heading for the airport. Nelson A. Rockefeller was on the move.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5In what the cynics considered a crucial test of weakness, Princeton blasted Columbia by a score of 4013 today at Palmer Stadium.

title: School for Meditation Opens
description: FAIRFIELD, Iowa, Oct. 5About 650 students from the United States, Canada and Europe started classes this week at Maharishi International University at Fairfield in buildings, once occupied by Parsons College. The university, which moved to Fairfield from a temporary campus at Santa Barbara, Calif., after purchasing the buildings from Parsons, which closed in 1973 in bankruptcy.

title: L.I. Art Display Is Short of Mark
description: SOUTHAMPTON  Everyone knows that art festivals or competitions of any kind generally turn out to be duds and mostbut definitely not all  of the work on view in the current exhibition of Long Island artists at the Parrish Museum fits this dreary pattern.

title: How to Beat Inflation
description: FIERY RUN, Va., Oct. 5The cool winds are now blowing across the Blue Ridge and seeping through the logs and mortar of our cabin. The crops and bills are coming in and it is finally possible for the proprietor to give an account of our family's war on inflation.

title: Goldwater Urges a Cut In the Defense Budget
description: CAREFREE, Ariz., Oct. 5 (AP)Senator Barry Goldwater, one of the stanchest Congressional supporters of the military, said today that $5billion could be trimmed from the defense budget in an effort to stabilize the economy.

title: Future Social Events
description: $500 a Plate in Memory of Dr. Chaim Weizmann Oct. 10The 100th anniversary of the birth of the scientist  statesman who became the first president of Israel will be celebrated at a Chaim Weizmann centenary dinner at the New York York Hilton. Abba Eban, former Foreign Minister of Israel, and Dr. Gerald M. Edelman of Rockefeller University will be the principal speakers. Proceeds of the dinner, which is given by the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot, Israel, will go the institute. Tickets from the American Committee.

title: Bridge
description: Stupid players, obviously, do not try to be stupid, although they often are. Clever players, less obviously, do not try to be clever, although they occasionally are. Experts find that the road to success is paved with solidity and accuracy. Those who regularly try to be brilliant provoke raised eyebrows and mocking laughter far more often than loud applause.

title: General Motors' New Generals
description: In the kingdom of corporations, none attracts so much attention as General Motors does when it rearranges its executive suite because, among other things, G. M. has the very largest kingdom of them all.

description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: World News Briefs
description: BERLIN, Oct. 5The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, arrived in East Berlin today where he will attend celebrations marking the 25th anniversary of East Germany.

title: How It Happened
description: Q: How did it happen?

title: MEDICARE RAISING COST TO PATIENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) The nation's 23.5 million Medicare beneficiaries will have to pay $8 more of their hospital bills beginning Jan. 1 because of rising health care costs, according to Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Striped Bass Is Adaptable to Various Waters and Palates
description: The roaring autumn surf brings the stripers as they make their annual migration southward. They are coaxed from the sea on sturdy lines, harvested in the nets of the haul seiners or piled alongside the weary fishermen on boats returning to Sheepshead Bay, Montauk or ports between.

title: The Personal Level: 10 Ways to Economize at Home
description: From the looks of last weekend's great Washington conference on the economy, one thing is clear: If you wait around for the experts to solve the inflation problem, you're likely to be squeezed a lot further before anything happens.

title: TRANSIT AGENCY ON SAFETY URGED
description: Asserting that it is not proper for administrative agencies to investigate themselves, a Federal safety administrator has suggested creation of a new state investigative agency to oversee the safety of masstransit systems, highways and other transportation modes in New York.

title: The Willowbrook Trial: Still a Sore Issue
description: A lawyer met a reporter in a corridor at the Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn last week. What are you here for? the lawyer asked.

title: Colombia Landslide Buries Part of a Town, Killing 30
description: MEDELLIN, Colombia, Oct. G (AP)At lease 30 persons were killed and several dozen injured today when a landslide buried parts of Betulia, a small town 100 miles north of here, the police reported.

title: MAYO A. SHATTUCK
description: Mayo A. Shattuck, vice president of the State Street Investment Corporation and a former deputy treasurer of Harvard University, died Saturday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 48 years old and a resident of Hingham, Mass.

title: Mary Stuhidreher, Writer Was Widow of Quarterback
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6Mary A. Stuhldreher, a writer and former college dean, who was the widow of Harry A. Stuhldreher, one of Notre Dame's football Four Horsemen, died Friday at her home here. She was 69 years old,

description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: HOSPITAL PHYSICIANS TO SPUR BARGAINING
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 6 (UPI)  A national organization of young hospital doctors said today that it would seek to expand collective bargaining between doctors and hospitals for better patient care and working conditions.

title: Care of Aged Poor A Growing Scandal
description: Since Medicaid opened the Treasury spigot in 1967, growing numbers of Americans have placed their aged parents in nursing homes. The result has been a national scandal.

title: A Blues Current Flows Under Rock Of Fleetwood Mac
description: Fleetwood Mac is a British rock band that dates to 1967. It started as a blues group, splitting off from John Mayall, and over the years it shifted in personnel and gradually evolved into a purveyor of a blend of rock styles. It wasn't the most striking band, maybe, but it was respected, did well commercially and gave pleasure.

title: A's Win, Even Playoff Dodgers Take 20 Lead
description: The Oakland A's defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 5 to 0, in Oakland yesterday and evened the American League championship playoff at one game for each team.

title: PRICES DEFENDED BY VENEZUELAN
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct 6Venezuela has launched national crusade to defend the high price of oil and other raw materials.

title: Ford to Speak in Vermont
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. (AP)President Ford will address a dinner here tomorrow night in honor of Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, who is reting this year after 34 years in the Senate.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: TULANE U. WIDENS HEALTH SERVICES
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 6A protest at Tulane University and Newcomb College over what the students said was inadequate service in offering them gynecological examinations and prescribing birth control pills has ended after the adminstration agree to increase student gynecological services.

title: A New, Pugnacious Gov. Wilson
description: Who wound him up? was the widespread reaction among politicians to Governor Wilson's surprisingly strong attack on the Democratic state ticket and particularly State Senator Mary Anne Krupsak, the only woman statewide candidate on the major party tickets.

title: Minish and His G.O.P. Rival Both Predict a Victory
description: MONTCLAIRWith less that four weeks before Election Day the Democratic and Republican candidates in the 11th Congressional District are enthusiastically predicting victory, while a third candidate, representing the Socialist Labor party, already concedes defeat.

title: Ebe Stignani Dies in Italy; MezzoSoprano Was 67
description: IMOLA, Italy, Oct. 6 (AP)Ebe Stignani, considered a classic mezzospprano, died yester. day. She was 67 years old.

title: ARTHUR KOPPEL, 83, REAL ESTATE BROKER
description: Arthur D. Koppel, who retired last year as head of the Arthur D. Koppel Company, real estate mortgage brokers, died Saturday at his home, Scarswold Apartments, Garth Road, Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Some 2,500 textile dyers in New Jersey are set to go on strike today over wages. A spokesman for the Textile Dyers Union of America said the members of the locals in Passaic, Lodi, Union City and Paterson had voted walk out after their contract expired Friday. The dyers were seeking an 11 per cent pay raise in the first year the threeyear contract and a 10 per cent increase in each of the next two years.

title: Hepatitis Outbreak on Coast
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. (UPI)Eight recruits at the naval training center here were hospitalized over the weekend with infectious hepatitis. All Were reported in good condiion, officials said today.

title: H. RANDALL WICKES
description: SAGINAW, Mich. Oct. 6 (AP) H. Randall Wickes, former chairman of the Wickes Corporation, a leading retailer of lumber and building supplies, died here today at the age of 85. Mr. Wickes was president of the concern from 1947 to 1964 and chairman from 1964 to 1969, when he was named honorary chairman.

title: Bridge: ProAm Tourney Provides Some Sociable Competition
description: When New York's topranked stars meet in Manhattan they are almost always out for blood. Once a year, however, they meet on a social occasion, and the results are less important though not unimportant.

title: Joan Blair Married To Donald Schuler
description: The marriage of Joan Blair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Blair of Winter Park, Fla., to Donald Schuler, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Schuler of Larchmont, N.Y., took place yesterday afternoon.

title: Falcons Defeat Giants
Controlling Secret Operations
description: MIDDLEBURG, Va.The dramatic and divisive issue of secret operations abroad has again been raised by the recent exposures of the United States role id Chile. These operations have been challenged as an illegal and immoral form of diplomacy impermissible in an open society. They have been derided as antiquated holdovers from the cold war, and have been denounced as acts of the executive not open to Congressional or popular judgment.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: A Deadly Shade of Gold by John D. MacDonald (Lippincott, $7.50). A Travis McGee thriller.

title: State Audit Scores Efficiency Of City's Kings County Hospital
description: Kings County Hosptial spent nearly a million dollars more than necessary last year to care for patients who should not have been retained in the hospital, according to an audit of the city's largest hospital complex by State Controller Arthur Levitt.

title: MRS. ROBERT J. DONOVAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Martha Fisher Donovan, wife of Robert J. Donovan, an associate editor of The Los Angeles Times, died today of cancer at the Washington Hospital Center. She was 62 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Orioles Beaten by 2 Errors, Holtzman
LS. SEEKS CHANGE IN ATEST TREATY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Officials have disclosed that the Ford Administration, faced with what it considers almost certain Senate rejection of the treaty former President Nixon signed in Moscow last July to limit the underground testing of nuclear weapons, is seeking to broaden the agreement to include peaceful nuclear tests.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE SIEGE OF KRISHNAPUR. By J. G. Farrell. 344 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $7.95.

title: Opera: A Rare Cimarosa
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5The Venetian Festival currently in progress at the Kennedy Center is giving audiences a chance to sample some music not normally encountered in this country. This evening something really rare was presented at the Opera HouseDomenico Cimarosa's Il Mercato di Malmantile, also known as La Vanita Delusa. The Rome Piccolo Opera and the Virtuosi di Roma conducted by Renato Fasano did the honors.

title: Walker, a Black, Named '76 Olympic Track Coach
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP)Dr. Leroy Walker, track coach at North Carolina Central College in Durham, was named today as head coach for the United States men's 1976 Olympic track and field team. He is the first black to hold the position.

title: Hawaiian Democrats Pick Japanese
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 6George R. Ariyoshi, the son of a sumo wrestler who was born over a soybean curd shop in the Japanese section of Honolulu, was nominated by the Democratic party yesterday for Governor of Hawaii.

title: Britain's Election: Apathy Runs Deep But Anger May Help Get Out the Vote
description: LONDON, Oct. 6Barney Bookman is a 72yearold farmer in the lovely Yorkshire Dales with a son who doesn't want to be a farmer, 50 beef and dairy cattle, 120 acres he's worked all his life, and a problem. For him, the British election this Thursday is all about the fall in the price of livestock.

title: ALLON DENOUNCED ON PALESTINE VIEW
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 6A statement by Foreign Minister Yigal Alton in New York that Israel might agree to a federation between a future Palestinian state and Jordan has drawn fire from the rightwing opposition.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
FISCHER DEFENDS DEMAND ON RULES
description: Bobby Fischer, the first American in modern history to win the world chess championship and the first player ever to resign it, has gone public in his own defense, angrily attacking critics of his demand for change in the rules for a title match.

title: A's Win, Even Playoff Dodgers Take 20 Lead
description: The Oakland A's defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 5 to 0, in Oakland yesterday and evened the American League championship playoff at one game for each team.

title: Julie Osier Is Bride of an Editor
description: Julie Ann Osier, daughter of Mrs. Henry Sonenblick and the late David Saul Osler, was married here yesterday afternoon to Jonathan Dolger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Dolger. The ceremony was performed in Temple Israel by Rabbi Martin Zion.

title: 3 Events Show City's. Ethnic Diversity
description: The city's, ethnic character usually gets its best display on Sundays, and yesterday was the kind of Sunday that had at least three of New York's major ethnic groupsPoles, Italians and Jews of East European originbelieving that the bright sun shone for them alone.

title: Stove Fumes Kill Two In Back of Parked Vail
description: ASSATEAGUE, Md., Oct. (AP)A young man and young woman from New Jersey who fell asleep in their van, with a charcoal stove still burning, were found dead here yesterday.

title: Russians, Too, Find Costs Rising
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 6Officially, there is no inflation in the Soviet Union. Inflation is an economic cancer that supposedly grows only in an unhealthy capitalist environment. The Soviet press has lately been driving home that point in lurid detail, and one high official asserted that the Soviet retail price index had actually gone down 0.3 per cent since 1970.

title: Kate Wins Yacht Race At Stamford
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 6 Robert W. Hubner's Kate a Palmer Johnson48 out of Noroton, won Division 1 honors today as the StamfordDenmark Friendship Race was sailed as a feature of the annual, StamfordDenmark Frendship Week.

title: Albanian Archeologists Find Ancient Illyrian pity
description: ROME (Reuters)  An ancient Illyrian city, said by Albanian archeologists to have been burned and destroyed by the Romans in 167 B.C., has been uncovered in Albania, the Italian News Agency reported from Tirana.

title: A Law for Creativity
description: The first major revision of the United States copyright law since 1909 has finally been approved by the Senate. The measure would help to bring creativity into line with technology. It would go a long way toward insuring the survival of individual composers, dramatists and authors, and raise the standard of protection to that already existing in most nations of the Western world. In a large sense, it would encourage freedom for selfcreated works a freedom sadly lacking in countries that look over the shoulders of writers, artists, and performers.

title: 3Run Rally in 8th Defeats Pirates
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6Los Angeles pitching continued to master Pittsburgh power today as the Dodgers stopped the Pirates again, 52, and moved within one game of the National League pennant.

title: Iran's Flood of Oil Money Aggravates Her Inflation
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 6While Western statesmen assert that high oil prices are threatening the stability of oilconsumer nations, Iran is finding her own economic order severly strained by the sudden and immense infusion of petroleumbased wealth.

title: Labor Throws Its Weight
description: There never was anything edifying in the process by which former Governor Rockefeller used massive statesponsored construction projects and state money generally to purchase the political fealty of the leadership of the state A.F.L.C.I.O. Now, with the heads of the mammoth unions representing state and city public employes in the vanguard, the Federation seems bent on establishing a political lien on the man it clearly expects to be occupying the Governor's chair in the next four years  Representative Hugh L. Carey, the Democratic nominee.

title: STUDY QUESTIONS REVENUE SHARING
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 6A ma study of Federal revenue sharing has concluded that statistics on which revenuesharing funds are based are inaccurate and inadequate, according to a draft report.

title: Spanish Police Accuse 47 Of Plot to Spread Strikes
description: MADRID, Oct. 6 (UPI)Fortyseven alleged underground labor leaders arrested in Barcelona have been plotting to extend a wave of illegal strikes to Spain's biggest industrial factory, the police said today.

title: P. B. A. CRITICIZES GARFIELD OFFICER
description: GARFIELD, Oct. 6Members of Local 46 of the Garfield Patrolmen's Benevolent Association expressed broad dissatisfaction today with the decision to return Patrolman Gabriel Valos to duty without giving him a psychological test. The patrolman was acquitted in a jury trial last week of illegal possession of heroin, a gun and a switchblade knife.

title: BREZHNEV ASKING NEW MOVE TO CURB ATOMARMS RACE
description: BERLIN, Oct. 6Leonid I. Brezhnev, head of the Soviet Communist party, told an East German rally today that the Soviet Union was prepared to take additional steps with the United States to curb the arms race.

title: Peru Mourns Quake Deaths
description: LIMA Peru, Oct. 6 (UPI)Peru observed a day of national mourning today to commemorate the victims of an earthquake that shook the capital and smaller coastal towns Thursday. The civil defense command said at latest count 83 persons had been killed and 2,500 injured.

title: Driver Is Killed as Fittipaldi Wins Title at Watkins Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 6Carlos Reutemann won the United States Grand Prix, Emerson Fittipaldi won the world drivers' championship and Helmuth Koinigg lost his life today.

title: EDITH M. KEYSHORE
description: Edith Margolis Keyshore, a literary agent for 30 years with the Lenniger Agency here, died Wednesday in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 651 Vanderbilt Street, Brooklyn.

title: Dr. Robert Moore, 91, Dies; U. of Texas Mathematician
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 6 (UPI)Dr. Robert L. Moore, emeritus professor of mathematics at the University of Texas, died Friday. He was 91 years old.

title: Russians, Too, Find Costs Rising
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 6Officially, there is no inflation in the Soviet Union. Inflation is an economic cancer that supposedly grows only in an unhealthy capitalist environment. The Soviet press has lately been driving home that point in lurid detail, and one high official asserted that the Soviet retail price index had actually gone down 0.3 per cent since 1970.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Petrodollar Agency Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)A Federal agency should be established to keep track of how the oilexporting nations are spending their massive new wealth, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today. The Minnesota Democrat released a letter he had written to President Ford, urging him to create such a monitoring agency by executive order. Senator Humphrey said he was planning a bill to make the agency an arm of the Treasury Department.

title: 150 Charged in Smuggling Of $35Million in Cocaine
description: An unusual galaxy of local and Federal prosecutors joined yesterday to announce that 150 persons have been charged for importing and distributing 300 pounds of cocaine with an estimated street value of $35million.

title: PENTAGON DENIES AMNESTY CHANGE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The Defense Department appears to have changed its policy on whether deserters will be courtmartialed for refusing alternative service after signing up for the President's earned reentry program.

title: Ford Finds Wife Better
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) President Ford said tonight that his wife was getting better every day in her recovery from breast surgery last weekend. During his visit at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., Mr. and Mrs. Ford watched a film put together by David Kennerly, the White House photographer.

title: U.S. SEEKS CHANGE IN ATEST TREATY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Officials have disclosed that the Ford Administration, faced with what it considers almost certain Senate rejection of the treaty former President Nixon signed in Moscow last July to limit the underground testing of nuclear weapons, is seeking to broaden the agreement to include peaceful nuclear tests.

While the fire burned, an unsigned leaflet was delivered to the Milan office of the Italian news agency ANSA, saying that the fire was revenge for I.T.T.'s role in Chile.

Then return with us today or anytime until Nov. 2 and wallow in jungle nostalgia at the Puck Gallery, 23 East 67th Street, where a Tarzan retrospective entitled Tarzan Swings is on exhibit.

Hunter defeated P.C.B. 2336, with Victor Lopez second in 26 minutes 13 seconds on the 4.6mile course.

title: Atlanta's Confident Hope Is Faltering

Ninetyfive per cent of those present were black.

Holy Family, winning for the second time, stopped St. Dominic's and its star quarterback, Tony Capozzoli, 287. Dorney ran for two touchdowns, passed for another and completed four tosses for 64yards. His heralded counterpart, Capozzoli, had five passes picked off and hit on only 14 of 30 for 104 yards. Rich Heimerle led the winners' defense with two interceptions.

Y., Oct. 6The delegates of South Africa were absent last week when the General Assembly adopted committee recomendations that representatives of African liberation movements be brought hereas observers. No casualties were reported. The police said the bomb damaged the women5s restroom in the Sheraton Inn at Los Angeles International Airport.

title: At the Film Festival:'Ali':Fassbinder Explore Racial Prejudice The Cast New Tanner Film Opens Emotions
description: One of the most encouraging things about Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the young German writer-director-actor, is his extraordinary productivity, not that productivity is much help to someone without talent. There's no question that Mr. Fassbinder, whose "Ali" was shown at the New York Film Festival on Saturday and yesterday evenings, has a great deal of talent, so much that he seems driven by it in the healthiest sense.Since 1969 he has made at least 11 films, written several plays for the theater, acted in others and written and directed an eight-part television drama. I mention all this because such a large part of a film director's life these days must be devoted either to deal-making or to rewriting and polishing scripts for the approval of people who have easier access to money than to any artistic sensibility.Mr. Fassbinder obviously works fast. He doesn't fool around getting things perfect. He tries something difficult, and if it works, fine. If not, he'll do it better the next time around. Shakesspeare worked this way. So, I'm sure, did a lot of the people in Hollywood in what are called the good old days. Experience doesn't accumulate like dust. You simply can't sit around waiting for it to settle on you. You have to work to get it.Mr. Fassbinder is neither Shakespeare nor an old-time Hollywood type. In addition to his talent and tremendous energy, he has absolutely no fear that he might be off on the wrong track making a fool of himself. His most recent films seen over here, "The Merchant of Four Seasons" and "The Bitter Tears of Petra Von Kant," have been both praised and ridiculed in the kind of extravagant terms that make one pay attention, even when not agreeing.I particularly liked one of his early works (if one can decently call a film by someone who's not yet 30 an early work). "Recruits in Ingoistadt," which was an effectively stylized screen adaptation of a 1929 Brechtian theater piece, shown at the 1971 New York Film Festival.I like "Ali" even more because it seems to take even greater risks. Its story is the cinematic equivalent of a piece of pop art: Emmi (Brigitte Mira) is a late-fiftyish German charwoman, a widow whose children have grown up and into proper middle-class prigs. Emmi is no femme fatale. She's short and dumpy and has a too-great willingness to please, a quality she shares with many of the world's lonely and insecure.Quite by chance, Emmi meets Ali, a young, virile Moroccan who has come to Germany to earn a living as a garage mechanic. They are both lonely. Emmi's friendliness and her common sense, as well as her apartment, beckon Ali. They get married for their own satisfaction and to the horror of family and friends.The careful detail with which Mr. Fassbinder dramatizes the couple's subsequent ostracism, and the rampant racial prejudice they face, is a deadpan cover for the film's real concerns, which, as I read the film, are the many disguises of love. In one of the several twists that Mr. Fassbinder gives the story, it's Emmi who, once secure in Ali's love, reverts to type, becoming small-minded and in her own way thoroughly heartless.The presence of the director is so dominant in Mr. Fassbinder's films that it's difficult to judge their individual parts. I'm not sure whether Miss Mira and El Hedi Ben Salem, who plays Ali, are especially good actors but they look right. Although they have their idiosyncracies they are primarily types.The entire film, in fact, has a kind of posterlike blandness to it, something that at times is made visual. When Emmi and Ali go outside, other people are seldom seen, unless they are characters in the film. There are no extras in the background to convince you this is photographed reality, which it most certainly is not."Ali" is not an easy movie to warm up to. It's no May-December romance that tugs at the heart. It is, rather, another quite courageous attempt by Mr. Fassbinder to develop a film style free of the kind of realistic conventions that sentimentalize life's mysteries.

title: Mack & Mabel and Silent Film Era
description: First for the good news. With the splashy Mack & Mabel, Which splashed, at times rather damply, into the Majestic Theater last night, wideeyed, diminutive and contralto Bernadette Peters found herself as a major Broadway star. Also Gower Champion's staging of this overly talkative saga of the silent screen is the most elaborate bag of tricks we have been offered since Bob Fosse's Pippin. Then there are Robert Preston and one or two very catchy and one or two lushly attractive songs by Jerry Herman. For that matter it's nice to have the producer David Merrick back where he belongs.

title: Net Final To Evert In 3 Sets
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)Chris Evert defeated Virginia Wade, 63, 57, 61, in the final of the $50,000Virginia Slims tennis tournament today.

description: China appears to have raised agricultural production and evened the distribution of food so successfully that she seems well protected against the food shortages now afflicting the underdeveloped world, according to 10 leading American farm researchers who recently visited China.

title: Abrams Giving Lefkotvitz His Stiffest Election Fight
description: After nearly 18 years in office, four easy election victories and years of being regarded as an unbeatable, institution, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz is faced with his most serious challenge in the Nov. 5 general election.

Germany's 25th anniversary, said he favoreda ban on underground testing of all nuclear weapons and suggested that the two major powers withdraw from the Mediterranean all their nucleararmed ships and submarines. [1:8.]

description: BOSTON, Oct. 6At the Senate hearings on Nelson Rockefeller's nomination for Vice President, there was a solemn discussion of whether his family's money gave it power. Mr. Rockefeller dismissed that notion as a myth. He hoped it would be exposed and dissipated.

description: A 75yearold Bronx woman was raped yesterday in her groundfloor apartment by two teenage youths who after tying her up with cloth belts also may have robbed her, the police reported. The woman was admitted to Morrisania Hospital in satisfactory condition.

description: From the provincial backwater of Orangeburg, S.C., to the glittering financial centers of New York, London, Zurich and Vienna, banks are no longer the rocks of Gibraltar they once were. Hardly a week goes by without some new banking problems surfacing.

title: Malaise in Britain
description: CAMBERLEY, EnglandBehind the high unemployment figures, the disastrous trade balance, tie devastated stock Market, the 20 per cent rate of inflation, and the occasional Irish Republican Army bomb at an army base or a national monument, Britain still has the look of a country enjoying prosperity unparalleled in her history. But as she heads into her second election in eight months, on Thursday, the prosperity has a flavor of Indian summer to it, and there is the faint smell of panic in the air.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WEST PATERSON Oct. 6If Lou Duva has his way, the local professional boxing club, the grass roots of the sport for so many years until television and other reasons killed it, will enjoy a renaissance. And to prove his point, the Totowa resident is putting his money where his feelings are.

title: About New York
description: Autumn is made for New York. It is both the best and the saddest of seasons  a good time to begin a romance, say, but a dreadful time to break one off, and autumn is different here than it is in other places. In other places, autumn is a time to harvest. In New York, it is a time to sow.

title: Concert
description: Has anyone ever heard Rudolf Firkusny give a poor recital, or even a soso one? Perhaps, but in this listener's experience, the Czechborn pianist is not only one of the finest now performing, but also a remarkably consistent one. Mr. Firkusny's playing yesterday afternoon at the Hunter College Assembly Hall, although more subdued and reflective than usual, was a catalogue of musical virtues.

title: HANNAH D. COLT, 91, WESTCHESTER AIDE
description: Hannah Dunlop Colt, who was active in social and educational activities in Westchester County for many years, died on Friday at her home, 20 Oriole Avenue, Bronxville, N. Y. She was 91 years old.

description: PARIS, Oct. 6While the world's monetary leaders talk about new international machinery to recycle the vast wealth flowing to the oil producing nations, the major industrial countries have been quietly dispatching emissaries to them to attract funds directly.

title: AbdulJabbar Out For 7 or 8 Games
description: Kareem AbdulJabbar was fitted for an elbowtoknuckles cast on his right arm yesterday and is expected to miss at least seven or eight games of the regular National Basketball Association season which will open for his Milwaukee Bucks on Oct. 18. The 7foot2inch center suffered a fractured bonethe fourth metacarpalin his right hand Saturday night while the Bucks were defeating the Boston Celtics, 11298, in Buffalo.

description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 6Carlos Reutemann won the United States Grand Prix, Emerson Fittipaldi won the world drivers' championship and Helmuth Koinigg Jost his life today.

title: Decline of the West?
description: The crisis in Italy that has followed the fall of the Rumor Government is a symptom of a wider malaise that is rapidly overtaking the Western democracies in Europe. The impact of a staggering increase in oil prices on top of already soaring inflation and rising deficits in payments abroad has sent governments reeling everywhere. Intensified almost beyond effective management now are problems that otherwise might have yielded in time to the normal muddling through for which Britain is famous and that democratic governments everywhere practice most of the time.

title: Boy With Immune Deficiency Challenges Theories in 3 Years of His Life in Plastic Bubble
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 6A 3yearold child who has spent all but about 30 seconds of his life isolated in a plastic bubble may force psychologists to question longaccepted theories about what is necessary for successful personality development, according to a psychiatrist who has studied the child.

title: FORD SAID TO LEAN TO TAX REVISIONS IN INFLATION PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6President Ford appeared today to be leaning toward proposals to ease tax burdens on the poor while increasing taxes of those in higher income brackets.

description: Susan Elizabeth Norman, who is with Boston University's School of the Arts as coordinator of student activities and alumni affairs was married yesterday afternoon in Hopkinson, Mass. to Marc Aaron Blumenthal, director of the Learning Guild, an educational consulting organization in Boston.

title: Officer Is Shot by Driver On a Downtown Street
description: A police officer was shot in the left hand and knee last night by a driver moving suspiciously along a lower Manhattan street, the police reported.

title: Red Smith
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6Standing in the coach's box at third base regarding his navel, Bob Skinner lifted his eyes at 3:05 P.M. today and recognized the lean, cleanshaven features of Paul Popovich, a parttime infielder and pinchbatter with the Pittsburgh Pirates. Well, said Skinner, gregarious soul, it's nice to see you. The playoff for the National League pennant was in its 16th inning and Popovich was the first Pittsburgh baserunner to reach Skinner's sector since last Wednesday. Moments later Popovich scored, to be followed on the next play by Gene Clines. Skinner may not have that much company again before April. The champions of the National League East surprised and pleased themselves and 49,247 witnesses by making two runs against the Los Angeles Dodgers in the seventh inning today and thus achieving a tie that endured for several minutes. In the eighth the first five Dodger batters hit safely, three got home, and Los Angeles won yawning, 52.

title: ExSoninLaw Held in Couple's Slaying
description: The former soninlaw of an elderly couple stabbed to death in their Waterbury, Conn., home 10 days ago was arrested at his home in Forest Hills, Queens, last night and charged with two counts of homicide.

title: A Program for the Retarded, Where the School Age Begins at 5 Weeks Old
description: PHILADELPHIASee you at the next parents' matting, Fawnda Patterson said, and pushed her grocery cart off in the direction of granulated sugar.

title: City Hall Listens to Whites But the Results Seem Mixed
description: New York's Italians, Irish, Poles and a smattering of other groupsthe white ethnic people who were probably the most alienated in the city under the Lindsay administrationare fashioning a more pleasant, but still uncertain, relationship with the Beame administration in City Hall.

title: Jackson Pays a Visit to New Hampshire and Considers Trying a Primary Race There in 1976
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 61 Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington now says it was a mistake for him to bypass the New Hampshire primary: in his 1972 campaign for the Democratic nomination for President. He is scouting the: territory again and promising an early announcement of the state's place in his primary strategy for 1976.

title: Experts Say Israel, Despite Arms Lead, Is Losing Strategic Balance to Arabs
description: On the first anniversary of the October war, the consensus of American, British and Soviet experts is that the longterm strategic balance in the Middle East is weighted against Israel.

title: Robber Is Shot Dead When Man Walks In On Brooklyn Holdup
description: A thin young man entered a Brooklyn grocery store that was being held up Saturday night, shot and killed the gunwielding holdup man and then fled into the street.

title: Personal Finance: Electricity Cost
description: A recent survey showed that residents of New York City paid the highest utility bills of any major city in the United States. It makes sense, therefore, for every New Yorker to take whatever action he can to cut his expenses in any way possible.

title: Hamstringing E.P.A.
description: Environmentalists were dismayed when Representative George Mahon of Texas, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, had the bad judgment to assign environmental agencies to an agriculture subcommittee headed by Representative Jamie L. Whitten, Mississippi Democrat. Representative Whitten is well known for his opposition to anything that interferes with profitsasusual down on the farm or in business.

title: Abrams Giving Lefkowitz His Stiffest Election Fight
description: After nearly 18 years in office, four easy election victories and years of being regarded as an unbeatable institution, Attorney general Louis J. Lefkowitz is faced with his most serious challenge in the Nov. general election.

title: Care of Aged Poor A Growing Scandal
description: Since Medicaid opened the Treasury spigot in 1967, growing numbers of Americans have placed their aged parents in nursing homes. The result has been a national scandal.

title: $50,000 DAMAGE FOUND IN SCHOOL
description: A new elementary school in the Bronx that was opened just last month was heavily vandalized over the weekend by youths who apparently made repeated forays into the building, doing damage estimated at $50,000 at a minimum, the police said last night.

title: PARDON OF NIXON IS OPPOSED IN POLL
description: New Jersey residents disapprove of President Ford's pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon by a margin of nearly 2 to I, and most believe the books on Watergate should not be closed, according to a statewide poll by the Eagleton Institute of Rutgers University.

title: Rebuilt Village Church Holds Services
description: One of Greenwich Village's most respected landmarks, St. John's Episcopal Church, at the corner of Waverly Place and West 11th Street, came to life again yesterday when parishioners gathered in their modern, new edifice three and a half years after their old building was destroyed by fire.

title: Chinese Farm Gains Impress Visitors
description: China appears to have raised agricultural production and evened the distribution of food so successfully that she seems well protected against the food shortages now afflicting the underdeveloped world, according to 10 leading American farm researchers who recently visited China.

title: Geiberger Takes Sahara by 3 Strokes
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct 6 (AP)Al Geiberger ended an eightyear drought today by Shooting a final twounderpar 69 to win the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament by three shots.

title: Jets Seeking to Upset Dolphins
description: MIAMI, Oct. 6The Jets, who have not beaten the Dolphins since 1971, take on the National Football League Champions tomorrow night at the Orange Bowl with the kickoff at 9 P.M. Channel 7 will televise the game in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: An Angry Employe Sends Dempsey's Out With a Crash of Glass
description: Hours before Jack Dempsey's Restaurant closed its doors to the public last night for the last time, a disgruntled employe smashed five of its windows with a wrench.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, head of the Soviet Communist party, says the Soviet Union prepared to take additional steps with the United States to curb the arms race. Mr. Brezhnev, the guest of honor in East Ber lin at a rally marking East Germany's 25th anniversary, said he favored a ban on underground testing of all nuclear weapons and suggested that the two major powers withdraw from the Mediterranean all their nucleararmed ships and submarines. [1:8.]

title: Clash With Police Stirs Boston Protest
description: BOSTON, Oct. 6In an offshoot of this city's school integration problems, South Boston, the city's Irish stronghold, rose up in protest today against the Boston Police Department's elite corps, the Tactical Patrol Force.

title: Weinberger Says Congress Bars Cuts in H.E.W. Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that he could trim the department's budget by $3billion to $4billion if Congress allowed him to eliminate some programs he thnught had outlived their usefulness.

title: MRS. WILLIAM PRAGER
description: Kay Scott Prager, the wife of William A. Prager, a vice president of Daniel J. Edelman, Inc., a public relations concern, died Saturday of cancer. She was 59 years old and lived at 420 East 23d Street.

title: HERBERT D. WILLIAMS
description: Herbert D. Williams, a retired investment banker, died Friday at his home, 242 East 72d Street. He was 96 years old.

title: Charles W. Gleason, 80, Led Green Point Savings
description: Charles W. Gleason, who retired in 1973 as chairman of the Green Point Savings Bank of Brooklyn and was former president of the Savings. Bank Association of New York State, died Saturday at the Creek Club in Locust Valley, L.I., where he lived. His age was 80.

title: PORTUGAL HOLDS A CLEANUP DAY
description: LISBON, Oct. 6Millions of Portuguese abandoned their traditional day of rest today and worked in their factories, offices and shops while schoolchildren and older students hosed, scraped, scrubbed and washed away five months of political graffiti and posters from buildings and monuments.

title: Nixon Recovering at Home; Testimony Ruling Up in Air
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Oct. 6 (UPI)Former President Richard M. Nixon recuperated from his bout with phlebitis and blood clots at his home today, with the decision on his subpoenaed testimony in the Watergate coverup trial still up in the air.

title: Back to the Sewing Circle
description: A debate on committee reorganization the other day demonstrated much of what is wrong with the House of Representatives. As part of a plan offered by Representative Julia Hansen, Washington Democrat, the Speaker would have been given the power to bypass the Rules Committee and bring bills from legislative committees directly to the floor.

title: Advertising
description: There used to be a saying about corporate advertising (slightly revised here for genteel readers) that it was like dropping coffee on a dark blue suitmakes you feel nice and warm, but nobody notices it.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: ASSEMBLY TO ACT ON CAMPAIGN AID
description: TRENTON, Oct. 6 (AP)A bill to extend the concept of public financing of election campaigns to gubernatorial primaries is scheduled for a vote tomorrow in the Assembly.

title: 68% of Purchasing Men Worried About Economy
description: The National Association of Purchasing Management reported over the weekend that in a survey 68 per cent of purchasing agents said they were concerned or worried about the economy in the next 12 months. The remaining 32 per cent said they were either optimistic or satisfied about business activity.

title: TV Review
description: Wimsey's back and, with a little help from Mobil Oil, the Public Broadcasting Service's got him. This time the vehicle for Dorothy L. Sayers's detective is an adaptation of Murder Must Advertise, in which the breezily arch hero confronts bright young sophisticates, the drug scene and the advertising profession, among other blotches on the social fabric.

title: MAURICE W. SALOMON
description: Maurice W. Salomon, who retired in 1968 as vice president and circulation director of Pocket Books, Inc., died Sunday in Silver Spring, Md., where he lived. His age was 6S.

title: GREECE'S PREMIER TO RESIGN TODAY
description: ATHENS, Oct. 7The Government of Premier Constantine Caramanlis will resign tomorrow and open the way for a caretaker regime to conduct Greece's first parliamentary elections in more than 10 years, a Government spokesman said today.

title: West Europe Is Reacting With Caution To Tougher U.S. Policy on Oil Lands
description: LONDON, Oct. 7Western Europe has adopted an extremely cautious stance in reaction to a new and harder line on oil policy expressed in recent speeches by President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Saks, Bergdorf and Bonwit Accused as PriceFixers
description: Three leading Fifth Avenue specialty stores and two of their top executives were accused yesterday by a Federal grand jury of engaging in a conspiracy to fix prices of women's clothing.

title: Festival: Two Films From Rivette
description: Unheard melodies may be sweet, but unsolved mysteries are about as satisfying as a windowful of succulent food that you can't afford. Jacques Rivette's Out One/ Spectrewhich played Saturday and Sunday at the New York Film Festivalis frustrating for two reasons: first, because 4 hours of hidden motivations is hard on the soul; second, because some of the characterizations and performances are tantalizingly good  hence you really want to understand these people and what drives them. (The movie has been edited down from a 13hour version that was and then wasn't intended for television.)

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX HD 0TC
description: In expectation of some encouraging news from President Ford today about proposals to curb inflation, traders on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market sent prices up yesterday for the first time since midJuly.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was;

title: HARVEST HELD KEY TO GRAIN EXPORTS
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 7President Ford's new policy of controlling large grain export sales had the expected effect today of checking a sharply rising corn and soybean market.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Man Killed in West Side Hotel

title: No Firewornen, Vizzini Asserts
description: The head of the city firemen's union, Richard J. Vizzini, said yesterday that firefighting was no job for a woman.

title: CONFEREES SEEK END TO AUTO INTERLOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) A SenateHouse conference voted today to put an end to the interlock system that prevents a car from being started until seatbelts are fastened.

title: FRIDA S. BUCKY
description: Frida Sarsen Bucky, widow of Dr. Gustav Bucky, the radiologist and inventor long associated with Albert Einstein, died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 91 years old.

title: CAREY CRITICIZES FISCAL PRACTICES
description: PLATTSBURG, N.Y. Oct. 7Appealing to the fiscal conservatism of upstate Republicans, Representative Hugh L. Carey charged today that the RockefellerWilson state administrations were responsible for a 16yearlong spending spree.

title: Nassau Hearing Is Due On Dual Price Labels
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 7A public hearing will be held Oct. 21 by the Nassau County Board of Supervisors on a bill that would prohibit supermarkets from marking up prices on items that have already been marked.

title: Transportation Chief Counts On Voter Support on Bond Issue
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Oct. 7Enlightened selfinterest on the part of New Jersey voters is what the Commissioner of the State Department of Transportation is counting on to carry the controversial $200million bond issue for highway construction this November.

title: Ford Rejects Bid to Raise Federal Salaries by 7.22%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)  President Ford has formally rejected a recommendation by a White House advisory panel that an Oct. 1 pay rise for Federal employes of 5.52 per cent be increased to 7.22 per cent.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: In expectation of some encouraging news from President Ford today about proposals to curb inflation, traders on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market sent prices up yesterday for the first time since midJuly.

title: Canoeist's Body Found
description: MADISON, N.H., Oct. 7 (AP) The body of a Massachusetts man was recovered Saturday by divers after the canoe he was riding in capsized Friday on Conway Lake, the police said. The victim was identified as Steven Lewis, 27, of Somerville, Mass.

title: People and Business
description: William G. Kuhns, president of the General Public Utilities Corporation since 1967, was elected yesterday to the new position of chairman and chief executive officer of the New Yorkbased public utility holding company. At the same time, Herman M. Dieckamp, who joined the company a year and a half ago as vice president, was elected president and chief operating officer.

title: 1973 OIL SHORTAGE FOUND AVOIDABLE
description: A special New York State grand jury investigating the petroleum industry said yesterday that the country's major oil companies had access to each other's inventories and knew in advance that fuel shortages would exist last year, yet did not produce sufficient products for consumers even though the industry at that time possessed the overall capability to do so.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Team Canada Policy Under Fire

title: Hospital Rate Inquiry
description: BOSTON, Oct. 7 (AP)A Federalstate investigation will be conducted into rate increases announced this month by 13 Bostonarea teaching hospitals, officials said today. The hospitals increased their room rates by an average of 15 per cent.

title: Lanier, Pistons Defeat Nets, 11294
description: DETROIT, Oct. 7 (AP)Bob Lanier scored 23 points and grabbed 21 rebounds and Willy Norwood added 20 points to lead the Detroit Pistons to 11294 preseason victory over the New York Nets tonight.

title: G.E. PROFITS UP 2% ON 16% SALES RISE
TV: Welby Tackles Child Molestation
description: While organizations representing homosexuals are angry with ABC about tonight's episode of Marcus Welby, M.D., they may be at least partially assuaged by WABC, the network's New York station, and a halfhour documentary presented last Saturday at 7 P.M.

title: PRESEASON HOCKEY
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Pioneer Olympic Coach Dr. Leroy Tashreau Walker
description: It took five ballots, an intense, allday meeting and considerable political wheeling and dealing to select the head coach for the 1972 United States Olympic men's track and field team. On Sunday in Chicago, after only one ballot that lasted 2 minutes, Dr. Leroy T. Walker overwhelmingly was named head coach for the 1976 Games in Montreal.

title: Legislative Outlook
description: Action in the remaining three months of this Congress pivots on the economic program that President Ford is expected to submit today, Although Senate Majority Leader Mansfield offered at the economic summit conference a sound and comprehensive ninepoint program one that could well serve as the agenda for this Democraticcontrolled Congressno one seriously expects results to flow from his lonely initiative. Power is so diffused among rival committee chairmen and between the two houses that, for better or worse, President Ford has to be the moving force if there is to be one.

title: U. N. Is Given 2 Chinese Works of Art
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7The United Nations today acquired a spectacular tapestry and an ivory carving as gifts from the Chinese Government.

title: Secrecy in Albany Target of Campaign
description: Describing the New York State government as one of the most secretive, unresponsive, and oligarchical in the nation, Common Cause the national organization that calls itself a citizen' lobby, yesterday named New York its No. 1 target for 1975.

title: Books of The Times
description: John Irving's title suggests that marriage is a middleweight attempt to solve heavyweight problems, a shaky structure for controlling the uncontrollable, a strategy for lulling the ego into habits and security in the hope that it will forget its Faustian hunger. The 158Pound Marriage depicts that institution as a precarious balancing, and immobilizing, of the urge for novelty that, according to Freud, is an inherent instability in our makeup. Our children, one of the book's characters says, are the adventurous, explorative element in our married lives. Through them, we can still live dangerously. Wives or husbands, he adds, are almost rational choices.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The walking stick, long associated with country squires and silverhaired grande dames, was given the fashion kiss of status some months ago by Bianca Jagger. At that time, the wife of the pop singer, Mick Jagger, was seen sporting one around London. Now the fad has filtered down to the department store level. The Attitude boutique on the third floor of Gimbels East, for instance, carries a small stock of canes ranging in price from $20 to $35. A slender wooden cane with an ivory bulbtop handle is tagged at $20, while thicker one in wood and snakeskin goes for $30. The imitation ebony and silver ones are the store's bestselling canes (prices begin at $20).

title: RIGHT TO KNOW BILL IS SENT TO PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) Congress completed action tonight on a compromise bill designed to improve the antisecrecy force of the nation's basic right to know law and sent it to President Ford.

title: F. T. C. Chief Calls Role Of Agencies Inflationary
description: DETROIT, Oct. 7In an unusual speech for a Federal official, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Lewis A. Engman, attacked Federal regulatory agencies todayspecifically including the Civil Aeronautics Board and the Interstate Commerce Commission. He charged them with protecting the industries they regulate in an unhealthy relationship that raises costs to the consumer unnecessarily and thus contributes to inflation.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The outflow of savings from savings and loan associations abated in, September from the nearrecord August level but remained large, the United States League of Savings Associations estimated today.

title: Investors Expecting Inflation EightDow Rises 23
description: The stock market advanced substantially in active trading yesterday on expectations that President Ford's economic message today would contain strong measures to combat inflation.

title: Ray's Lawyers Upheld
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 7 (UP1)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit upheld today the right of attorneys for James Earl Ray to examine much of the evidence collected by the state in connection with the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968. The ruling, which upheld an earlier order from Federal District Judge Robert McRae Jr., dismissed assertions by attorneys for the state of Tennessee that the materials to be examined were not relevant to a hearing for Mr. Ray before Judge McRae on Oct. 22.

title: Senate Votes to Conclude 4 National Emergencies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  The Senate voted today end four national emergencies dating from the Depression and to curb the authority of the President to govern by emergency proclamation.

title: Campisi Mistrial Move Denied As Judge's Words Stir Furor
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Oct. 7 Judge W. Thomas McGann of the Burlington County Superior Court today denied a motion for a mistrial in a murder and racketeering trial here after defense lawyers, heatedly accused the judge of creating a courtroom atmosphere prejudicial to their clients.

title: U. N. Is Given 2 Chinese Works of Art
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7The United Nations today acquired a spectacular tapestry and an ivory carving as gifts from the Chinese Government.

title: 60% in Louis Harris Poll Call Nixon Pardon Wrong
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (Reuters)Most Americans are convinced, an opinion poll published today says, that the full pardoning of Richard M. Nixon was wrong.

title: COMMUNITY BOASTS HUGE BALL OF TWINE
description: CAWKER CITY, Kan. (AP)he pride and joy of this small farming community is what residents claim is the world's largest ball of twine. It's 29 feet around, weights 4, tons, and if unravelled from Cawker City, the twine would pass through Kansas City and end at Carroll. ton, Mo., 310 miles down U. S.24

title: No Firewomen, Vizzini Asserts
description: The head of the city firemen's union, Richard J. Vizzini, said yesterday that firefighting was no job for a woman.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Festival: Two Films From Rivette
description: Unheard melodies may be sweet, but unsolved mysteries are about as satisfying as a windowful of succulent food that you can't afford. Jacques Rivette's Out One/ Spectrewhich played Saturday and Sunday at the New Y,ork Film Festivalis frustrating for two reasons: first, because 4 hours of hidden motivations is hard on the soul; second, because some of the characterizations and performances are tantalizingly good  hence you really want to understand these people and what drives them. (The movie has been edited down from a 13hour version that was and then wasn't intended for television.

title: U.S. SETS CONTROL OVER LARGE SALES OF EXPORT GRAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Ford Administration announced today a limited system of controls over large sales of grain for export.

title: Moderate Quake on Coast
description: CAMARILLO, Calif., Oct. 7 (UPI)A moderate earthquake, measuring 4.0 on the Richter Scale, jolted coastal areas of Ventura and Los Angeles Counties tonight. The Caltech seismograph station at Pasadena said the tremor was centered between Point Mugu and Point. Dume alongthe Pacific Shore. It registered at 5:56 P.M.

title: Waitress Is Slain As Holdup Hostage In Restaurant Here
description: A 22yearold counter girl in a Burger King restaurant on West 125th Street in Harlem was shot to death Sunday night by holdup Men who held her hostage and carried out their threat to kill her unless the manager opened a safe.

title: Advertising
description: Is it a luxury item? Is it an impulsepurchase item? Or is it part of everybody's menu? Now that the prices are soaring we'll find out which, said Edward H. Meyer, president of Grey Advertising.

title: NASA Parley Is Told Agency Has a Future Role but There Are Some Disturbing Trends
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 5A diverse group of specialistsa pioneer in modern communications, a Nobel laureate in economics, astronauts, modelers of the future, directors of international agencies and others met here last week to speculate on how a space program might fit into the final years of this century.

title: Stockbroker, 41, Held in Queens In Murder of Former InLaws
description: A 41yearold stockbroker charged with the murder of his former fatherinlaw and motherinlaw in their Waterbury, Conn., home last month was ordered held without bail in Queens Criminal Court yesterday, pending extradition by Connecticut authorities.

title: TOP PHOTO AWARDS WON BY 2 TIMES MEN
description: ALBANY, Oct. 7 (AP)Don Hogan Charles, a photographer with The New York Times, won the bestinshow award today in the annual photo competition of the New York State Associated Press Association.

title: Former Police Aide Guilty of Manslaughter
description: ELIZABETH, Oct. 7 (UPI) A former New Jersey civilian police dispatcher waived his right to trial today and pleaded guilty to manslaughter in connection with the death of a young Westfield secretary found strangled in her apartment. Jacobs B. Ehrlich, 34 years old, charged with the murder of Linda Sisko, 25, entered the plea before Judge Edward W. McGrath in Union County Court.

title: ROSE K. BRISKMAN
description: Rose Kimmel Briskman, a member of the international executive board of B'nai B'rith Women, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L. I. She was 61 years old and lived at 11 Stratford North, Roslyn Heights, L. I.

title: Future Steel Price Rises Held Linked to Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation indicated today that the steel industry can get by without further big price increases only if costs are held down in other sectors of the economy.

title: British Soccer
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: MARTIN F. HASSETT
description: Martin F. Hassett, a heating, ventilating and airconditioning contractor of Huntington, L.I., died yesterday in Meadowbrook (L. I.) Hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: Stock Market Rises
description: Stocks rallied strongly yesterday after a twomonth bear market. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 23 points to 607.56. The surge was attributed to hopes that President Ford's economic message today would contain strong antiinflationary measures. Page 57.

title: People in Sports
description: They called him The Big Bear and when Denis Hulme was in a grizzly mood he was one of the more determined racing drivers around. But he is 38 years old and the mood wasn't coming over him oftenjust one victory (in the opening world championship race, the Argentine Grand Prix, last January) and Huh me has decided to retire, probably to go home to some property he recently bought in New Zealand.

title: CARTER WITNESS MOVED FROM JAIL
description: A principal witness in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter triplemurder case was moved from the Passaic County Jail in Paterson, N.J., yesterdsy after having complained that he feared for his safety there.

title: Rodriguez Beats Weston on Points
description: With a furious finish, Fausto Rodriguez of the Dominican Republican scored a majority decision over Harold Weston Jr. of Greenwich Village last night in a 10round welterweight bout before crowd of 2,402 at the Felt Forum.

title: GEORGE P. STRATIGOS
description: George P. Stratigos, founder and owner of George's Bakery in Rockville Centre, L. I., died Friday in Mercy Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 99 Woodland Avenue in Rockville Centre.

title: Call to Action?
description: The adequacy of the economic proposals which President Ford will submit to Congress today represents crucial test of his own adequacy to fulfill the exacting responsibilities of the Presidency.

title: Threat to Children
description: Twenty years ago, discovery of the Salk vaccine against polio was greeted with an instant rush Of millions of parents to have their children immunized. In the intervening years, the crippling and killing disease has been virtually eliminated; 1969 was the first year in which no death from polio was reported in the United States. Since then, immunization has also greatly reduced the danger from a variety of diseases which used to claim a heavy toll, particularly of children.

title: Notes on People
description: President Ford and President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France will hold their first meeting in midDecember on the French island of Martinique, it was announced yesterday in Washington and Paris.

title: 3dQuarter Gain is 35%
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, the holding company that owns the Chemical Bank, the nation's sixth biggest bank, reported yesterday that earnings before securities transactions increased by 35.2 per cent in the third quarter. Chemical is the first of the country's major banks to report earnings for the period.

title: Ford, in Vermont, Makes Appeal for 2Party Rule
description: BURLINGTON, Vt. Oct. 7President Ford, making his first purely political trip since taking office, unveiled tonight what might turn out to be a major Republican theme of the 1974 election: Vote Republican to save the twoparty system.

title: Seeking the Possible
description: Secretary of State Kissinger need accomplish no miracles to make this latest journey to the Middle East worthwhile; it will be quite enough for one trip if he succeeds in extracting a common answer from both Arabs and Israelis to the question he has been posing all summer: What do you want to try for next?

title: Kissinger Seeks to Save Soviet Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Secretary of State Kissinger plans to meet with three key Senators tomorrow to see if they can salvage a compromise allaving trade benefits to the Soviet Union in return for a liberalization in Moscow's emigration policies.

title: Willowbrook Negligence Cited By a Nurse in Court Testimony
description: On June 8, a young teenage boy, a patient at the Willobrook Developmental Center, for the mentally retarded, was admitted to the United States Public Health Service Hospital, also on Staten Island, with ?? broken leg.

title: Rockefeller Envelopes Carry Wilson Labels
description: In the interest of economy, Governor Wilson's press staff has been pasting yellow labels with the Governor's name and office address over the printed return address of his predecessor.

title: Mrs. Grasso Bids State Borrow $2Biuion for Power Companies
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 7  Suggesting there might be room for a useful new partnership between government and industry, United States Representative Ella T. Grasso, the Democratic nominee for Governor, proposed today that Connecticut borrow up to $2billion over an 11year period to finance new construction for the three big power companies in the state.

title: WITNESS LOSES PART OF HER JOBLESS PAY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)State officials said today that a woman subpoenaed to testify, against a robbery defendant could not collect $68 in unemployment benefits because of the four days she spent in court.

title: Bridge:
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7Two United States partnerships shared top honors in the first PanAmerican Invitation Pair Championships here yesterday, but only after a fierce struggle with players from Mexico, Bermuda and Jamaica.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday war:
description: ?? matching the number win $10,000. Tickets with the five numbers in reverse win $1,000. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25 Losing tickets are eligible for a special prize drawn on Thursdays.

title: Boy Killed, His Companion Hurt In Subway Mishap at, 135th St.
description: A 12yearold boy was fatally injured last night and his 8yearold playmate was critically hurt when they were crushed between a subway train and the platform of the 135th Street and Eighh Avenue station as they tried to dart across The tracks in front of the incoming train.

title: VENEZUELA OFFICIAL DENIES OIL CUTBACK
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct 7 (AP)Venzuela has no immediate plan to reduce her oil production, now approximately 3 million barrels a day, by 10 per cent next year, a top Mines and Hydrocarbons Ministry official said today.

title: Historical Society Reports the Theft Of a 1500 Painting
description: A 16thcentury painting en titled The Crucifixion, value at an estimated $30,000, was reported stolen from the New York Historical Society at 17?? Central Park West some time last weekend, the police said last night.

title: 1973 OIL SHORTAGE FOUND AVOIDABLE
description: A special New York State grand jury investigating the petroleum industry said yesterday that the country's major oil companies had access to each other's inventories and knew in advance that fuel shortages would exist last year, yet did not produce sufficient products for consumers even though the industry at that time possessed the overall capability to do so.

title: U.S. IS CONDEMNED BY CUBAN AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 7Foreign. Minister Ral Roa Garcia of Cuba said today that negotiations with the United States could not begin until what he described as a criminal, arbitrary, anachronistic and contradictory blockade of Cuba was lifted.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Tuesday, Oct. 8, 1974

title: Beneficiaries of Rockefeller Gifts Will Vote on His Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 7When the VicePresidential nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller comes to a vote in the Senate and House, the voters will include several Republican members of Congress who have been the beneficiaries of campaign contributions from Mr. Rockefeller and his family.

title: A Dotty Logic Marks Celine and Julie Go Boating
description: The riddles and delusions of Jacques Rivette's Cline and Julie Go Boating are much more accessible than the enigmas of his Out One/ Spectre. Cline, the later movie, has the dotty logic of dreams, and the characters rational solemnity while talking nonsense does succeed in evoking Lewis Carroll. The movie played last night at the New York Film Festival and will be repeated do Friday.

title: Ford to Alter Format Of News Conferences
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)  President Ford plans to make a significant change in the format of his next mews conference, a spokesman said today.

title: Democrat' Dilemma
description: Representatives of the more liberal elements in the Democratic party made a shim of strength last week in Washington, just as the party goes into a period of crunch as to what its new charter ought to say about affirmative action arid proportional representation in delegate selection.

title: Sketches of 3 Leading American Grain Dealers
description: Recognized as one of the largest privately owned companies in the world, with more than $3billion in revenues annually . . . Based in the Wall Street district at 2 Broadway. . . Established in Arlon, Belgium, 161 years ago . . . Shares with Cargill, Inc., of Minneapolis, the reputation of being the two top grain companies . . . Absence of legal requirements for public disclosure preclude definite estimates of the worth of either company . . . Headed since 1944 by Michel Fribourg, great great grandson of the company's founder . . . Employs more than 14,000 people worldwide, maintains offices in more than 44 countries . . Diversified holdings extend into bakeries, foreign flour mills in the Caribbean, Zaire and South America.

title: Canoeist's Body Found
description: MADISON, N.H., Oct. 7 (AP) The body of a Massachusetts man was recovered Saturday by divers after the canoe he was riding in capsized Friday on Conway Lake, the police said. The victim was identified as Steven Lewis, 27, of Somerville, Mass.

title: Focus on Rising Crime Shifts to the Suburbs Around New York
description: In one brief period late last month, residents of the suburbs surrounding New York, many of whom had moved there escape the city's crime, were shocked by the following major crimes:

title: Jury Selection May Delay Ford's House Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7President Ford's testimony to Congress about his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon will be postponed if necessary to avoid prejudicing potential jurors in the Watergate coverup case, members of Congress And others familiar with the matter indicated today.

title: Saks, Bergdorf and Bonwit Accused as PriceFixers
description: Three leading Fifth Avenue specialty stores and two of their, top executives were accused yesterday by a Federal grand jury of engaging in a conspiracy to fix prices of women's clothing.

title: Bridge: 2 U.S. Teams Share Honors For PanAm Championship
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7Two United States partnerships shared top honors in the first PanAmerican Invitation Pair Championships here yesterday, but only after a fierce struggle with players from Mexico, Bermuda and Jamaica.

title: FERTILIZER PRICES SEEN STAYING HIGH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (Reuters)The Department of Agriculture is forecasting a continued, tight market for world fertilizer supplies in 1975 and 1976. In a summary of the world fertilizer situation to be published Oct. 17, the department's outlook and situation board said potash supplies would tighten and there would be some upward price pressure, but not at the intensity of the last nine months.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Xerox Is Introducing a Speedier Electric Typewriter
