description: The Xerox Corporation took a major step in a new direction yesterday by introducing an electric typewriting system said to be capable of operating at speeds up to 350 words a minute.

title: Team Canada Policy Under Fire
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7 (AP)Alan Eagleson, executive director of the National Hockey League Players Association, made a proposal today to Russian hockey officials for another team CanadaSoviet Union series, with some games Played perhaps as early as December. But Eagleson said the next Team Canada should include the best professionals, not just players from one league. He said the team that had been defeated by the Russians (four games to one with three ties) was an inferior product and it was doubtful whether five team members could make an allstar team chosen from North American pros.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: Newark Police Told A Third of Recruits Must Be Minorities
description: NEWARK, Oct. 7A Federal district court judge issued a temporary order today that requires the Police Department here to revise its hiring procedures so that onethird of all new recruits are black or Hispanic.

title: Army Officer Shot By Terrorist Group Near Buenos Aires
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 7An army major was shot and killed today by unidentified terrorists who lost two of their gunmen when the officer's son fired back.

title: 18 Arrested in West Virginia As Textbook Protest Goes On
description: CHARLESTON W. Va., Oct. 7 (UPI)Angry parents stepped up a crusade against new school textbooks today by blockading bus garages and keeping hundreds of children out of classrooms. Eighteen persons were arrested.

title: EDITH M. KEYSHORE
description: Edith Margolis Keyshore, a literary agent for 30 years with the Lenniger Agency here, died Wednesday in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 651 Vanderbilt Street, Brooklyn.

title: School Day: SitIn, Boycotts, Rampage
description: The first school day of the week was marred in several schools in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx by boycotts, student protests and the aftermath of severe vandalism.

title: Bronx Man Is Held in Rape Of a Nun, 63, in Her Convent
description: A 22yearold Bronx man was indicted for rape yesterday for allegedly assaulting a 63yearold Roman Catholic nun in the corridor of her convent.

title: CARTER WITNESS MOVED FROM JAIL
description: A principal witness in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter triplemurder case was moved from the Passaic County Jail in Paterson, N.J., yesterdsy after having complained that he feared for his safety there.

title: To Mack Writers, Custard Man Is the Icing on Cake
description: To be memoralized in a doctoral thesis or even in a bestselling book is an estimable honor, but it's been bestowed on so many people that biography sections in libraries overflow the shelves. But to become the central figure in a big Broadway musicalwell, that's distinction.

title: Inflation Troubles Australian Labor Party
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 7 A top official of the Australian Labor Party said last week that some Cabinet members were doubtful about winning the next election and expressed his own belief that the party would lose if it went to the polls now.

title: I.R.S. Triples Rothkos' Value, Asks Tax
description: While seven sets of lawyers have been arguing over the value of 800 paintings left by Mark Rothko, one of the leading abstractexpressionists of the 20th century, the Internal Revenue Service has entered the fray. The tax agency has come to the conclusion that the paintings are worth $16.5million, or more than three times the estimate of the executors.

title: House to Limit Debate on 2 Reorganization Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Backers of the first reorganization of committees of the House of Representatives in 28 years won a key procedural victory tonight as the House voted to limit a weeklong debate on two rival reorganization plans.

title: South Boston Crowd Attacks Black as Tensions Rise
description: BOSTON, Oct. 7The crowd was milling around the intersection at South Boston's Old Colony housing project this afternoon, glaring and jeering at the police, when someone saw a black man, his car stuck in the traffic jam on Dorchester Street.

title: Soviet Union Leading In World's Oil Output
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 7The Soviet Union is the world's largest oil producer, according to figures compiled, by the Venezuelan Mines Ministry for the first six months of 1974.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Landlords, Not the City, to Give Rent Rises for 500,000 Tenants
description: The tenants of some 500,000 rentcontrolled apartments will be told by their landlords, rather than the city, what their rent increases will be, the Beame administration announced yesterday.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Oct. 7, 1974 Petition tiled by;

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS A PACKAGE TODAY TO CURB INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7President Ford will present a package program for controlling inflation by July 4, 1976, when he addresses a joint session of Congress tomorrow, the White House said today.

title: Garden Matchup: Reserve Centers
description: By afoul ??

title: HOUSE AGAIN ACTS TO BAN DELIVERIES OF ARMS TO TURKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7For the second time in less than two week, the House of Representatives voted tonight to cut off military aid to Turkey after having overwhelmingly rejected a milder restriction sought by the Administration.

title: Economic Solutions Without War
description: War is mankind's historic pseudocure for economic and social ills.

title: John McPherrin, Publisher Of American Magazine, 77
description: John W. McPherrin, a former editor of The American Druggist and publisher of the American Magazine, died Wednesday in Tucson, Ariz., where he moved in 1970. He was 77 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Energy: A Case for Forced Thrift

title: Frank, OverPainted Flowers Opens
description: FLOWERS, devised, designed and directed by Lindsay Kemp. Lighting by Mr. Kemp and John Spradbery; sound by Andrew Wilson; setting supervised by Leo B, Meyer; lighting supervised by John Gleason; production stage manager, John Spradbery. Presented by Herman and Diana Shumlin and Merrold Suhl in association with Larry Parues. At the Biltmore Theater, West 47th Street.

title: Senate Votes to Conclude 4 National Ernergencies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  The Senate voted today to end four national emergencies dating from, the Depression and to curb the authority of the President to govern by emergency proclamation.

title: South Koreans Open Trial of Man Held For Attempt on Park
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 7  The gunman who shot at President Park Chung Hee of South Korea on Aug. 15 went on trial today with the prosecution striving to prove that the attempted assassination had been ordered by North Korea.

title: Great Western United Sued By L. F. Rothschild & Co.
description: Two Wall Street firms, L. F. Rothschild & Co. and Bache & Co., Inc., brought suit yesterday in the Chancery Court in Delaware seeking to force the Great Western United Corporation to pay dividend arrears and sinking funds on its $1.88 preferred stock.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Pap 43

title: Monoxide Leak Kills Man
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (AP) Carbon monoxide fumes leaking through an apartment killed a 60yearold man and sickened a woman and her two children, over the weekend, the police said. The police said John Wilson was pronounced dead at the hospital and Ernestine Young, with her two sons. Darryl and Tracey, were revived.

title: Senate Votes Cargo Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) The Senate voted today to restrict hazardous materials on passenger planes. The restriction on cargo was contained in a bill designed to improve the safety, of all forms of transportation, It was passed 69 to 0 and sent to conference with the House, One section of the bill, opposed by the Ford Administration, would make the National Transportation Safety Board completely independent of the Department of Transportation.

title: HOUSE CHIEFS EXPECT TRANSIT BILL TO PASS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 House Democratic and Republican leaders today predicted passage of a sixyear, $11.8billion masstransit bill during this session of Congress.

title: 2 Women Boxers Ask Licenses
description: Two fighters, one whose nickname is Tyger and the other who is a former wrestler and sometime entertainer, became the first women to apply yesterday for New York State boxing licenses.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: If you asked a seacoast New Englander if he enjoyed eating rockfish, you would probably get a blank stare, but if you asked him the same question about striped bass, you would get an answer.

title: Rangers Lose, 74, To Bruins
description: BOSTON, Oct. 7  The shooters are ahead of the hitters.

title: Teams Drill in RainKison Is Pirate Choice
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7A strange portent, the true significance of which no one could determine, marked the practice sessions of the Los Angeles Dodgers and Pittsburgh Pirates today. The teams resume their playoff for the National League championship tomorrow with the Dodgers needing one victory to close out the threeoffive series in three straight games.

title: Giants Let Up After Scoring First
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 7Are the New York Giants letting up after scoring the first points in a game, and thus losing the killer instinct that was synonymous with their championship era?

title: A Deserter's Long Exile Ends, His Amnesty Fears Unjustified
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 7From a distance they looked like new recruits, stepping off the Trailways bus in civilian clothes and shivering in the cold night air, waiting to be told what to do.

title: SEOUL POLITICIAN SCORES PRESIDENT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 7 The new leader of South Korea's major opposition party, Kim Young Sam, threatened today to lead his party into struggle on the streets unless Pres ident Park Chung Hee revised the nation's constitution.

title: MRS. WILLIAM PRAGER
description: Kay Scott Prager, the wife of William A. Prager, a vice president of Daniel J. Edelman, Inc., a public relations concern, died Saturday of cancer, She was 59 years old and lived at 420 East 23d Street.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Ford Administration has announced a limited system of controls over large grainexport sales to prevent sudden, excessive drains on diminished supplies and to avert a recurrence of last weekend's very embarrassing cancellation of two large deals with the Soviet Union. The plan calls for advance approval of sales above 50,000 tons of wheat, corn, sorghum, soybean's and soybean meal. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

title: COUNTERSUIT FILED BY MULTIAMP CORP.
description: The MultiAmp Corporation of Dallas filed a $2.3million countersuit yesterday against a group of investors who, it charged, were planning a takeover of the company.

title: Near Jersey Sports
description: The singlewing offense seems to have been missing from the football scenario for more than just several years, but it is alive and succeeding in the Monmouth County community of Matawan.

title: 30,000 BACK AT G.M., FORD AND CHRYSLER
description: DETROIT, Oct. 7 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation recalled more than 30,000 assembly line workers today after a oneweek layoff caused by strikes at key parts plants.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY OCTOBER 8, 1974
description: International

title: A DANCE COMPANY TAKES A STUMBLE
description: Total disaster struck the Louis Falco Dance Company when it made a joint appearance Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall with Weather Report, a jazz group that was clearly the main draw.

title: FUNDS REQUESTED FOR TUNNEL FANS
description: The subway tunnel under the East River, in which a smoky fire in 1973 led to the death of one passenger and to a panicky evacuation for hundreds of others, would get uptodate exhaust fans under a capital budget request made public yesterday by the Transit Authority.

title: GASOLINE PRICES REDUCED BY ARCO
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday that it had reduced wholesale prices on all grades of gasoline by 2 cents a gallon. The move by Arco follows price cuts by number of other major oil companies, as gasoline continues to be in oversupply in both the United States and Europe.

title: In Egypt Year After War: New Spirit of Political Debate
description: CAIRO, Oct. 7A year after President Anwar elSadat ordered Egypt's armed forces to cross the Suez Canal, igniting the fourth ArabIsraeli war, Cairo is a bustling, struggling metropolis whose mood could not be further from one of war.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Hospital Opposes Housing Prisoners

title: Fine on Tape Pirates Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) The House voted today to increase the penalties for unauthorized duplication of recordings. Aimed at socalled record and tape pirates, the bill would set $25,000 fine for a first offense and $50,000 for subsequent offenses. The penalties now are $100 and $1,000.

title: TV SPOTS SHIFT ETHNIC PATTERN
description: With the aim of easing the tensions, fostered by the desegregation of schools, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has financed a campaign of public service television spots that abandon the melting pot and brotherhood themes of previous race relations campaigns and, instead, concentrate on the problems and value of an ethnically mixed society.

title: Wilson Assails Careyism And Blames It for Inflation
description: ALBANY, Oct. 7Governor Wilson intensified his new attack strategy today by repeatedly alleging before upstate audiences that elderly citizens and other voters were being destroyed by Carey inflation.

title: Baseball Playoffs
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Landlords, Not City, To Spell Out Rises To 500,000 Renters
description: The tenants of as many as 500,000 rentcontrolled apartments will be told by their landlords rather than the city, what their rent increases will be, the Beame administration announced yesterday.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Contract Awards
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has received a contract for the construction of a 632megawatt nuclear., power plant and related facilities in Yugoslavia at a total cost of $518million.

title: Julian Bond to Enter Presidential Primaries in '76
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 7  Julian Bond, the black civil rights advocate, plans to enter a number of Democratic Presidential primaries in 1976.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: If you asked a seacoast New Englander if he enjoyed eating rockfish, you would probably get a blank stare, but if you asked him the same question about striped bass, you would get an answer.

title: Franklyn B. Boutelle Dies; ExGovernor of Amex, 65
description: Franklyn B. Boutelle, a director and senior vice president of Merkin & Co., Inc., stockbrokers, and a former governor of the American Stock Exchange, died Sunday in St. James, L.I., where he had a summer home. He was 65 years old and lived at 70 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

title: Thai King Decrees and Objects to New Constitution
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 7  King Phumiphol Aduldet promulgated Thailand's ninth Constitution today but objected to one of its provisions, which he asserted would drag him into the political fray.

title: U.S. SETS CONTROL OVER LARGE SALES OF EXPORT GRAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Ford Administration announced today a limited system of controls over large sales of grain for export.

title: StripMine Showdown
description: Unless a HouseSenate conference committee comes up with a compromise today, there is little chance that a strong measure to control strip mining will emerge from this session of Congress. Such an outcome would be as potentially disastrous as it is unnecessary.

title: Labor Urges Public Sector Job Help
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 Leaders of public employe unions are pressing for legislation providing for Federal regulation of labor relations in the public sector at the state and local level.

title: F.T.C. Chief Calls Role Of Agencies Inflationary
description: DETROIT, Opt. 7In an unusual speech for a Federal official, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Lewis A. Engman, attacked Federal regulatory agencies todayspecifically including the Civil Aeronautics Board and the Interstate Commerce Commission. He charged them with protecting the industries they regulate in an unhealthy relationship that raises costs to the consumer unnecessarily and thus contributes to inflation.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DUFFYLAND Duffy Square that triangular island in the middle of Broadway at 47th Street, that haven for pigeons presided over by the sternvisaged marble statue of Father Duffy, becomes an outdoor dance hall this morning at 10.

title: Fittipaldi Steering Toward Indy Race
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 7Emerson Fittipaldi, the only world champion racing driver named for an essayist, left today to conquer new worlds.

title: Music: For Schoenberg
description: Arnold Schoenberg, the centennial of whose birth the music world is celebrating, was like a man who gives up a profitable life as a banker to go exploring at the South Pole. At the crest of a career as a composer of lush, postWagnerian music, he moved beyond that idiom and ventured out into the uncharted wastes of atonal, and then 12tone, composition. It required a great man's courage, just as adventuring to Antarctica must have for later explorers.

title: U.S. ATOMIC ARMS AGAIN STIR TOKYO
description: TOKYO, Oct. 7A new nuclear controversy broke out here today in the wake of reports from Washington quoting a retired American admiral as having told Congress that United States Navy ships carrying nuclear weapons had ene tered Japanese ports.

title: Nursing Homes Use a Variety of Fiscal Ruses to Lift Profits Above the 10% Allowed by Law
description: For more than 20 years, local, state and Federal authorities have sought to limit the profits of nursing homes and to keep them in the hands of small and presumably dedicated owners. Government agencies have had no more success in this than in eliminating the perennial scandals of neglect and fraud that the authorities say have stained the industry.

title: Army Is Off Penn State's Slate
description: Army, which has been a breather on Penn State's football schedule at times, asked to be relieved of its commitment to play the Nittany Lions after the 1976 season. Penn State agreed and came up yesterday with Ohio State, another breather, to replace Army in 1978.

title: The Dance
description: Awed admiration is about the only appropriate reaction to the irrepressible energy of the generation of dancers and choreographers that founded modern dance in the nineteentwenties and thirties. Each in his or her separate way continues to work and create. Martha Graham, at 80, is leading her company halfway around the world on a tour, and Charles Weldman, in his 70's, has just created Highlight, a dance memorial to the Denishawn company, from which they both sprang. It was shown Sunday evening for the first time at the Expression of Two Arts Theater.

title: Stock Market Rises
description: Stocks rallied strongly yesterday after a twomonth bear market. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 23 points to 607.56. The surge was attributed to hopes that President Ford's economic message today would contain strong antiinflationary measures. Page 57.

title: HOUSE AGAIN ACTS TO BAN DELIVERIES OF ARMS TO TURKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7For the second time in less than two week, the House of Representatives voted tonight to cut off military aid to Turkey after having overwhelmingly rejected a milder restriction sought by the Administration.

title: PHILLIPS IS NAMED AT TRIAL AS KILLER
description: William R. Phillips, the suspended police officer and former Knapp Commission witness who is being retried for murder, was identified again yesterday as the gunman who killed a prostitute and her procurer and left her customer for dead on Christmas Eve, 1968.

title: SECURITY IS RAISED FOR MENTALLY ILL
description: Plans to provide secure facilities for mental patients who are potentially dangerous to others or to themselves were announced yesterday by Governor Wilson and State Senator Ralph J. Marino, chairman of the Senate Committee on Crime and Correction.

title: The Ebony Fashion Fair It's Still a Lively social Institution
description: Carefully groomed and excitingly dressed, they poured into the New York Hilton Hotel. They were in leather or velvet parts suits, long knitted dresses or skirts, simple pastel jersey outfits. Many were in platform shoes but none in miniskirts as more than 3,000 women, sonic accompanied by children, husbands or men friends, showed up Sunday afternoon at the Ebony Fashion Fair, a social institution now in its 17th year. They paused in the anteroom long enough to greet friends and look over each other's clothes, then surrendered the tickets, for which they paid from $8 to $15, and took their seats around the long, high runway that jutted into the center of the vast ballroom.

title: Assembly Votes New Power for Unions
description: TRENTON, Oct. 7Organized labor and the major publicemploye unions won a major legislative victory today when the lower, house gave final legislative approval to a measure embracing sweeping changes in the state public emplove relations law.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A longtime elderly resident of Brooklyn's Parkside section was strangled in his secondfloor apartment at 100 East 18th Street in what was believed to be a $37 robbery. The police arrested two boys, 14 and 15 years old, who allegedly followed him into the building and killed him, the police said. Harold Solomon, the dead man, was a widower and a retired furniture salesman who was 90 years old, according to his lawyer, and 73 according to the police.

title: A KORCHNOI ILLNESS POSTPONES MATCH
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7  Viktor Korchnoi took an illness postponement of the 10th game of his final candidates match for the world chess championship with Anatoly Karpov, which had been scheduled for this evening in Tchaikowsky Hall.

title: Jury Selection May Delay Ford's House Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7President Ford's testimony to Congress about his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon will be postponed if necessary to avoid prejudicing potential jurors in the Watergate coverup case, members of Congress and others familiar with the matter indicated today.

title: Schmidt Unitto Halt Brewing
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (AP) Brewery operations at the Schmidts Beer plant in Norristown, Pa., will be halted by the end of the year, affecting some 259 workers a company spokesman announced today.

title: GASOLINE PRICES REDUCED BY ARCO
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday that it had reduced wholesale prices on all grades of gasoline by 2 cents a gallon. The move by Arco follows price cuts by number of other major oil compates, as gasoline continues to be in oversupply in both the United States and Europe.

title: CLARK ASKS END TO HIGHWAY FUND
description: Ramsey Clark, the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate, yesterday called for the dismantling of the Highway Trust Fund and an immediate study of the feasibility of free subways and buses for the city.

title: SEVERAL ETHIOPIANS DIE IN ARMY STRIFE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct 7 (AP)Factional strife in the ruling armed forces led to shooting today in which several persons died, reliable sources reported.

title: Financial Help Offered
description: Citicorp, the holding company that owns First National City Bank, announced yesterday that it opened 15 offices in four outofstate citiesDenver, New Orleans, Phoenix and Salt Lake Citythat will offer a number of services offered by bank branches.

title: Dolphins Repel Jet Rally, 2117
description: MIAMI, Oct. 7The Jets extended the Miami Dolphins right to the end of their game here tonight but lost, 2117. It was close. On the New York team's nexttolast offensive play, Tim Foley, the Miami cornerback, knocked the ball out of Jerome Barkum's hands as Barkum went for a pass from Joe Namath at the Dolphin 2yard line.

title: A DANCE COMPANY TAKES A STUMBLE
description: Total disaster struck the Louis Falco Dance Company when it made a joint appearance Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall with Weather Report, a jazz group that was clearly the main draw.

title: U.S. and Cuba: A Visit That May Forge Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7There are times in international affairs when a relatively minor event can set in motion a chain of developments leading to a substantial change. That is what seems to be happening in the wake of the visit to Cuba of Senators Jacob K. Javits and Claiborne Pell, accompanied by 30 American newsmen.

title: 2 Boys Charged With Strangling An Elderly Man in $37 Robbery
description: An elderly Brooklyn man was robbed of $37 and strangled yesterday, allegedly by two boys who followed him from a bakery to his apartment building.

title: Wheels, Sharks May Fold in W.F.L.
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Oct. 7 (AP)The World Football League announced today that the games of the Detroit Wheels and Jacksonville Sharks this week were postponed.

title: State Candidates of 10 Parties Win Places on Election Ballot
description: ALBANY, Oct. 7The State Board of Elections has certified candidates of 10 political parties for statewide offices that will be contested in the Nov. 5 election.

title: Volkswagen Denies Its Ads Exploited Energy Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) Volkswagen of America, Inc., denied today that its advertising had exploited the energy crisis. It said gasoline mileage claims for three of its imports were actually conservative.

title: NEWS INDEX
19 Seized in Florida At Illegal Dogfight; 100 Get Summonses
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 7 (AP)Nineteen persons were arrested and another 100 given summonses in a weekend raid on an illegal dogfight, the police said.

title: New Cancer Survey to Cover 20 Million Persons
description: BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 7The National Cancer Institute has organized a new continuing survey of cancer data believed I to be by far the largest and most detailed program of its kind ever undertaken in the United States.

title: Saudi Arabia Sets Up Fund To Aid Developing Countries
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. (Reuters)Saudi Arabia has set up a development fund with a capital of 10billion Saudi riyals (83.55billion) to extend loans to developing countries, the Middle East Economic Survey said here today.

title: The Year of the Paupered Pol
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  Poverty has never been so richly displayed as it is this fall among campaigning politicians. This is why I didn't recognize Senator Survine on Pennsylvania Avenue the other day.

title: SUPREME COURT OPENS NEW TERM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Supreme Court formally opened its 197475 term today with a fourminute ceremony and then retired into closed session to tackle a heavy accumulation of pending requests for review.

title: Five Sisters Die in Fire
description: QUEEN CREEK, Ariz., Oct. 7 (UPI)Five sisters died today in a fire that destroyed their mobile home five miles east of here. The victims were Regina Kroeger, 14 years old; Chrissie, Donna, 7; Joanie, 5, and Karen Lynn, 10 months. Their brother, Lester, 12, escaped with face burns. The parents were at work.

title: Return of Cooper Union Forums Marks Reopening of Renovated 115YearOld Building
description: The massive renovation of Cooper Union's landmark Foundation Building on Coop. er Squarestarted nearly two years agois virtually complete and the 115yearold building reopened officially yesterday with the return of the Cooper Union Forum, the oldest free public lecture series in the country.

title: Costa Rican Chief Questions U.S. Sincerity in Its Efforts to Extradite Vesco
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The recently elected President of Costa Rica has accused the Nixon Administration of having been less than sincere in its offorts last year to return Robert L. Vesco to this country to stand trial in the Watergate case.

title: Grain and Soybean Prices Off Sharply
description: Corn, wheat and soybean prices dropped sharply in futures trading on the Chicago Board of Trade and all other leading markets yesterday in reaction to the cancellation, at President Ford's request, by exporters of contracts to sell large amounts of corn and wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: A Dotty Logic Marks Celine and Julie Go Boating
description: The riddles and delusions of Jacques Rivette's Cline and Julie Go Boating are much more accessible than the enigmas of his Out One/ Spectre. Cline, the later movie, has the dotty logic of dreams, and the characters' rational solemnity while talking nonsense does succeed in evoking Lewis Carroll. The movie played last night at the New York Film Festival and will be repeated on Friday.

title: C. J. Latta, 80, Who Headed British Film Company, Dies
description: C. J. Latta, former managing director of the Associated British Picture Corporation, London, producers and owners of theaters and television stations, died Sunday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Stamford, Conn. He was 80 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla., and formerly in Stamford.

title: Tanner Beaten In Final
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 7 (AP)John Newcombe defeated Roscoe Tanner yesterday, 76, 76, to win the $50,000 Island Holidays tennis tournament, a new event.

title: Harry Herbert Dies at 74; Jewish Welfare Board Aide
description: Harry Herbert, director of the support and development services of the National Jewish Welfare Board from 1951 to his retirement in 1966, died Sunday in La Guardia Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 9840 64th Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: '76 DEFENSE FUNDS DIVIDE FORD AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The White House's Office of Man agment and Budget has proposed that defense spending in the next fiscal year be set at $92billion, an $8billion increase over the present year.

title: BRANDS OF AEROSOL WILL BE PUBLICIZED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that it had decided to make public the brand names of aerosol products under its jurisdiction that contain vinyl chloride, the chemical gas suspected of causing cancer.

title: Court Overrules F.P.C. On Price of Natural Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia set aside today a record 73 per cent increase for new natural gas approved by the Federal Power Commission.

title: 3 Senators Query Memo On Offshore Oil Leases
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 Three Democratic Senators from coastal states pressed the Department of the Interior today to make certain that no plans were laid to lease vast tracts of offshore oil land without careful environmental studies.

title: For the French, Day Care Centers Have Become a Necessity
description: PARIS A few minutes walk from Pigalle there is a building, dating to the time of Louis XIV, the since 1889 has sheltered very young children. Toward the eastern end of the city, in a middleclass section where there has been much demolition and construction, is another crche, or day care center, that opened in 1971 in a bright new building in the Rue des Pyrenes.

title: Justice in Intensive Care
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 7 (AP)Charlie (Choo Choo) Justice, an allAmerica football player at the University of North Carolina in 194849, was in satisfactory condition today after suffering a mild heart attack Saturday during the PittsburghNorth Carolina game. A spokesman at North Carolina Memorial Hospital said Justice was in the intensive care unit but was in good spirits.

title: MRS. HART E. VAN RIPER
description: MaryVirginia Smith Van Riper, the wife of Dr. Hart E. Van Riper, former medical director of the National Foundation, died Sunday in Hartford Hospital. She was 63 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: Newark Police Told A Third of Recruits Must Be Minorities
description: NEWARK, Oct. 7A Federal district court judge issued a temporary order today that requires the Police Department here to revise its hiring procedures so that onethird of all new recruits are black or Hispanic.

title: Treasury Bills Mixed At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Yields were mixed on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: A.M.A. Open to Compromise on a Plan For Health Insurance, Its Leader Says
description: Dr, Malcolm C. Todd, the president of the American Medical Association, says that his organization is willing to compromise on a crucial aspect of national health insurance legislation that would bring the association's Medicredit plan into line with the other major health insurance proposals being considered in Congress.

title: Angolan Aide Foresees Early SelfRule
description: LUANDA, Angola, Oct. 7An official of the colonial Government ruling Angola predicted today that a coalition of African guerrilla movements, and political parties, black and white, would be formed; before the end of the year to take control of this Portuguese colony.

title: BALAGUER OFFERS A SAFE CONDUCT
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 7President Joaquin Balaguer tonight offered a group of terrorists safe passage out of the country in return for the seven hostages they have been holding in the Venezuelan Consulate for 10 days.

title: U.S. Agents Wiretapped Colombo Aide 4 Yonths
description: Federal agents placed electronic surveillance equipment in the car of a leading figure in the underworld for four months earlier this year, providing prosecuting authorities with information on the daily concerns and workings of all the Mafia families in the metropolitan area, officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Despite Token Opposition, 5 Senators Raise Big Campaign Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Senators without serious challenges to their reelection this year have raised hundreds of thousands of dollars in paign contributions.

title: 2 Companies to Develop Fighter Plane for Nary
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 7 (AP)The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the Northrop Corporation have entered into an agreement to develop jointly an air combat fighter for the Navy, officials for both companies announced today.

title: EEL DROPS PUN FOR OIL TRAINING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Federal Energy Administrator, John C. Sawhill, has abruptly canceled plans for six officials of his agency to attend a training course operated by the American Petroleum Institute, the principal trade association and lobbying arm of the oil industry.

title: 3 PLEAD NOT GUILTY IN PENNSY FRAUD CASE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (UPI) Three more defendants pleaded not guilty today in Philadelphia to charges involving the alleged misuse of $4.2million in assets of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad.

title: 13 MigrantLabor Leaders Accused of U.S. Violations
description: NEWARK, Oct. 7The United States Attorney's Office filed criminal charges and civil complaints against 13 migrantcrew leaders today in a move Federal officials said was aimed at ending the exploitation of migrant. workers anywhere in the country.

title: U.S. Confirms Sale Of 34 Jets to Chile For $72Million
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (Reuters)The United States has agreed to sell Chile 18 Northrup F5E fighters and 16 Cessna A37 attack planes, United States officials said today.

title: Crowds Drop as New Leaders Arise in Early N.F.L. Action
description: MIAMI, Oct. 7The year of change continues in the National Football League. With four games, or roughly onethird of the season, completed, the pecking order of the 26 teams has About altered somewhat and attendance is Pro down. The continued presence of the New England Patriots and St. Louis Cardinals atop their divisions with unbeaten status in the greatest shakeup to the established order although it is far too early for their supporters to budget for playoff tickets or plan Super Bowl trips to New Orleans. The Patriots, for example, have the league's most difficult schedule facing them although next Sunday's game against the Jets in New York would be an exception.

title: Iowa Beef Convicted Of Bribery Charges
description: Supreme Coart Justice Burton B. Roberts yesterday found the world's largest beef processor and its chairman guilty of conspiring to bribe meat.union officials and supermarket executives, but then encouraged them to seek reversal of his verdict on appeal.

title: Ars Longa, Vita Brevis
description: The motionpicture business is not a business like selling soap, making plastic toys or aluminum airplane parts. Nobody knows before he sets out to make a picture whether it's going to be good or bad, successful or unsuccessful. It's like craps: You can't predict whether the dice will come up sevens or snake eyes. I've had both. Fortunately, you're not remembered for the bad ones, but only for the good ones.

title: RESERVE MINING CURB RYHIGH COURT URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to order a Minnesota mining company to halt its discharge of allegedly hazardous pollutants into Lake Superior and the air.

title: South Boston Crowd Attacks Black as Tensions Rise
description: BOSTON, Oct. 7The crowd was milling around the intersection at South Boston's Old Colony housing project this afternoon, glaring and jeering at the police, when someone saw a black man, his car stuck in the traffic jam on Dorchester Street.

title: Valiant Brothers Beaten
description: Brunno Sammartino and Indian Jay Stranghow defeated Jimmy and Johnny Valiant in their tagteam wrestling match last night, before 22,093 fans in Madison Square Garden.

title: Dave Anderson
description: To some people Chuck Fairbanks, the sudden genius of the New England Patriots, appears preoccupied.

title: Duryea Running Hard for Assembly Seat In Eastern L.I., Base of His Political Power
description: MONTAUK, L.T.  Perry B. Duryea, Speaker of the Assembly, is running for reelection to his legislative seat as if it were the governorship.

title: Chessie Sets TwoforOne Split; Dividend on Common Is Raised
description: Directors of the Chessie Systern, Inc., parent of several big coalcarrying railroads, includling the Chesapeake & Ohio and the Baltimore & Ohio, voted yesterday to recommend a twoforone split of the common stock. The board also voted yesterday to increase the quarterly dividend onthe presently outstanding shares from 90 cents to $1.05 a share.

title: A.M.C. Raises Prices on '75 Models 9.9%
description: DETROIT, Oct. 7The American Motors Corporation announced today that it was raising its 1975 model prices by an average of $384, or 9.9 per cent.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The House Subcommittee on Education heard testimony today on legislation to divorce the American Film Institute from the National Endowment for the Arts and establish it as an independent agency. The legislation calls for twothirds Federal funding of the institute and for a reconstruction of its board to include members of Congress, of the executive branch and private citizens.

title: Limits for F.B.I. Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (Reuters)The Senate voted today to limit the term of the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to one 10year period.

title: 50 BROKERS RULED UNDER TRUST LAW
description: A Federal District Court judge in Chicago has ruled that some 50 brokerage housesincluding some of the largest in the country and three major stock exchanges are subject to antitrust law even though they are regulated by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Orioles and A's Enter Game 3 Tied, 11
description: The Baltimore Orioles and Oakland A's will resume their grappling for the American League pennant today with Jim Palmer pitching against Vida Blue as the baseball playoffs switch geography to Baltimore and Los Angeles.

title: A KORCHNOI ILLNESS POSTPONES MATCH
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7  Viktor Korchnoi took an illness postponement of the 10th game of his final candidates match for the world chess championship with Anatoly Karpov, which had been scheduled for this evening in Tchaikowsky Hall.

title: Government and Corporate Issues Show Gains
description: Government issues and corporate bonds rose in price yesterday, continuing the rebound that began last Friday. A number of corporate issues showed gains of a point each, equivalent to $10 for a $1,000 bond. These developments took place against a background of worsening economic newssuch as the big jump in the unemployment rate reported last Fridayand declining interest rates.

title: CITY HEALTH UNIT INSPECTS SCHOOLS
description: The city's Health Department has begun an inspection of every New York City public school, the first time such an examination has ever been undertaken, according to the city's Health Commissioner, Dr. Lowell E. Bellin.

title: Simhat Torah Fete Beginning for Jews At Sundown Today
description: Simhat Torah, one of the happiest events in the Hebrew calendar, begins at sundown today and continues through sundown tomorrow. The city's alternatesideofthestreet parking rules will be suspended on both days.

title: Assembly Backs $90Million for Housing
description: TRENTON, Oct. 7  The Assembly passed tonight a $90million bond issue for low and moderateprice housing. The issue will be placed on the ballot in November, joining three others already approved for public referendum.

title: Rev. Walter Offutt Jr., 63, Dies; Human Rights Aide for State
description: The Rev. Walter P. Offutt Jr., special assistant to the Commissioner for Religious Affairs of the State Division of Human Rights, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 2110 33d Road, Long Island City, Queens.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The outflow of savings from savings and loan associations abated in September from the nearrecord August level but remained large, the United States League of Savings Associations estimated today.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, TUESDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1974
description: BERLIN, Oct. 7East Germany, celebrating its 25th anniversary today, is also celebrating its acceptance by the West after nearly a quartercentury of frigid isolation.

title: Tired Birds Given a Lift Over Alps
description: GENEVA, Oct. 7Too cold and hungry to fly south over the Alps in their annual migration from northern Europe to the warmer Mediterranean, thousands of swallows are making the trip by rail and Commercial airliner.

title: Iowa Beef Convicted Of Bribery Charges
description: Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts yesterday found the world's largest beef processor and its chairman guilty of conspiring to bribe meat union officials and supermarket executives, but then encouraged them to seek reversal of his verdict on appeal.

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS A PACKAGE TODAY TO CURB INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7President Ford will present a package program for controlling inflation by July 4, 1976, when he Addresses a joint session of Congress tomorrow, the White House said today.Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary, said that Mr. Ford's proposals must be looked at and carried out as a package, not as a shopping list for picking and choosing.

title: People and Business
description: Dale W. Hardin, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, reacted sharply yesterday to the charge on Monday of Lewis A. Engman, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, that Federal regulatory agencies, specifically the I.C.C. and the Civil Aeronautics Board, contributed to inflation.

title: The Power of Rockefeller Money
description: Nelson A. Rockefeller's money has been a powerful force in New York for many years, whether it was manfested in a $550,000 gift to a longtime aide, the dispensing of the presidency of Rockefeller Center to another, the financing of the Republican party in the state, or the building of the World Trade Center as part of an effort, led by his banker brother, to give New York City a secend skyline downtown. Rockefeller Power is what many politicians call it. Sometimes, they say, it is altrustica rethey say, it is altruistica reBut many times, they contend, it is completely pragmaticto a Rockefeller goal.

title: Filming in City: Trend Is Down, but Hope Is Up
description: Film cameras, which used to grind in profusion on the sidewalks of New York, are a rare spectacle these days. But a new effort is being made to lure back the movie industry.

title: Malaysia's Election: Opposing Views of How Democracy Fared
description: SINGAPORE, Oct. 8  The final results from Malaysia's national election are now in, with the arrival of returns from remote and jungled Sarawak. The ruling National Front coalition has amassed 135 of the 154 seats in Parliament nearly 90 per cent. Prime Minister Abdul Razak and his supporters say the outcome proves that the people voted for multiracial harmony and national unity.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: In what was described as the opening salvo in a massive fight to force integration of housing in predominantly white Bergen County, a Federal class action suit was filed yesterday, charging a major apartment owner with racial discrimination. Named as defendant in the suit was the owner of the Henpal and Mipal Realty companies that have apartment houses in Englewood, Cliffside Park and Hackensack.

title: Turkish Exchange Student Adjusts Nicely to Busier Pace Here
description: WANTAGH, L.I. Kursat Onder knew he was adjusting when he started to dream in English. It happened fast only three weeks after he got off the plane from his native Turkey.

title: GREEKS TO SWEAR IN NEW CABINET TODAY
description: ATHENS, Oct. 8, (Reuters)The Government of Constantine Carmanlis resigned today and a caretaker Cabinet to supervise the Nov. 17 parliamentary elections will be sworn in tomorrow.

title: 5% Less Driving, ColdWater Laundry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8President Ford called on the American people today to adopt a variety of voluntary energysaving measures, including driving 5 per cent less and washing the laundry in cold water.

title: Woman's Mutilated Body Is Found on East Side
description: The badly mutilated body of a woman was found by the police in an apartment on the Lower East Side last night. The victim was tentatively identified as Carmen Lopez, 42 years old, who lived at 135 Norfolk Street, near Rivington Street.

title: ABUSES OF POWER BY MOSCOW SEEN
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8The dissident Marxist historian Roy Medvedev said today that the Soviet press had suppressed news about Watergate not only because of support for former President Richard M. Nixon but because of the Kremlin's fear of showing how an independent press and judiciary and representative bodies can restrain executive power.

title: Bando's Homer in 4th Off Palmer Puts Oakland Within a Game of Third Straight Pennant
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 8Vida Blue, the unhappy lefthander from Louisiana, pitched the Oakland A's to within one game of their third straight American League pennant today with a stunning twohit, 10 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: GOLDBLUM ENTERS EQUITY GUILT PLEA
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8In an unexpected turn of events, the conspiracy and fraud trial of Stanley Goldblum ended today when he pleaded guilty to five counts of conspiracy and fraud that could bring him a prison sentence of 30 years and fines totaling $36,000.

title: Eisaku Sato
description: In the career of Eisaku Sato, as in the recent history of Japan, triumph as followed on defeat and defeat on triumph.

title: Churches Are Damaged By Quake in Leewards
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 8 (AP)An earthquake rocked the eastern Caribbean today, damaging churches and other buildings on Antigua and St. Kitts in the Leeward Islands. There were no immediate reports of death or serious injury.

title: RockefellerGift Reactions Vary, but All See Potential Implications
description: Political leaders took varying views yesterday of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's gifts to associates, but all expressed concern about the potential implications of conflict of interest in government service.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 8 (AP)  An official of the World Football League reported today that he was talking to three groups of potential purchasers for the Jacksonville Sharks, but warned that the W.F.L. team would die in a few days unless a deal was, completed. At this point there has been no firm offer to purchase the club, said Chuck Rohe, the W.F.L. official who is managing the Sharks for the league. The closest proposal was an option to buy, but other owners in the league have told Gary. Davidson [W.F.L. commissioner] they wouldn't agree to anything but a sale. Rohe said the players haven't been paid for last week's game and their salaries were four weeks behind under the previous owner, Fran Monaco. But he said they would get the back money. Yesterday, the league postponed this week's games of the Sharks and the financially troubled Detroit Wheels.

title: Sports Today
description: Orioles vs. Oakland As, A.L. championship playoff, at Baltimore, and Dodgers vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, N.L. championship playoff, at Los Angeles. (TelevisionChannel 4, 2 P.M. DodgersPirates game will be picked up in progress following A.L. game)

description: FOUR IN ONE The Brooklyn Museum, coincidental with the appointment of its new director, Michael Botwinick, is staging a fourply opening today, an exciting day for the museum after a year of internal troubles, and we've all invitedfree.

description: Fordham University has threatened to seriously consider giving up the rolling turf and Gothic turrets of its Bronx campus and moving to Westchester because of a dispute with the Federal Government.

description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8The surprise Soviet attempt to purchase 3.4 million tons of American corn and wheat represents a breakdown in an agreement between former President Richard M. Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, in June, 1973, for an exchange of agricultural information. At the behest of President Ford the Continental Grain Company and Cook Industries agreed on Saturday to cancel the $500million sale to the Russians.

title: Use of Lead Tops Output
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, Oct. 8 (AP)World consumption of refined lead in the first half of 1974 totaled 2,159,800 metric tons, exceeding production by 104,900 tons and mining output by 486,700 tons, the World Bureau of Metal Statistics reported today.

title: Hospital Right to Bar Abortions Is Upheld
description: TRENTON, Oct. 8 (AP)A Superior Court judge today upheld the right of a hospital to refuse to allow its facilities to be used to perform an abortion.

title: $84.9Million More Asked For Amtrak in '75 by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) President Ford asked Congress today for an additional $84.9million to keep Amtrak passenger trains running beyond February.

title: FED ACTS TO DRAIN BANKING RESERVES
description: The Federal Reserve acted to drain reserves from the banking system on two occasions yesterday, apparently signaling that it did not want to seel Federal funds trading below10 per cent level at this time. These actions suggest that the acceptable target range for the funds rateis perhaps 10 per cent to 10 per cent, down from approximately 11 per cent to 12 per cent at the end of August.

title: Tweed Courthouse Put On National Register
description: The dilapidated 103yearold Tweed courthouse, the city's major monument to municipal corruption, has been placed on the National Register of Historic Places, Paul O'Dwyer, City Council President, said yesterday.

title: Detroit Sees Key to Fuel Saving Goal In Smaller Cars and Rules on Pollution
description: DETROIT, Oct. 8Automobile executives said today that it would take a major relaxation of Government antipollution rules, coupled with a switch to smaller cars, if the industry was to improve fuel economy by 40 per cent within four years.

title: Suspect Surrenders In Attack Last June On Officer in Bronx
description: A 27yearold city sanitation worker wanted in the shooting of a police officer during a Bronx burglary on June 22 surrended to the police here yesterday and was charged with attempted murder.

title: WHEAT IS STEADY, BUT CORN PLUNGES
description: Soybeans and corn plunged the daily permissible limits yesterday in futures trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, just as they did on Monday. Wheat futures, however, held firm at the close in nearby deliveries, indicating some underlying buying strength.

title: People in Sports
description: Bill Virdon, who guided the Yankees to a secondplace finish in the American League East, was named major league manager of the year by The Sporting News yesterday. Virdon was selected in a poll of the big league managers conducted by the sports weekly. Billy Martin of the Texas Rangers was the runnerup.

description: To the Editor:

description: Two of the betterknown series of poetry readings will start the new season this month.

description: YONKERS, Oct. 8A series of four $100,000 races highlights this final week of the 72night Yonkers Raceway meeting. Known as the Sire Stakes, the series offers colts, fillies and geldings bred in New York State.

description: Following is a transcript of President Ford's economic address before a joint session of Congress yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Anne Sexton Ruled Suicide
description: WESTON, Mass., Oct. 8 (AP) Anne Sexton, the poet who won the 1967 Pulitzer Prize, committed suicide, a medical examiner ruled today. Mrs. Sexton, who was 45 years old, was found dead in her car Friday. The car was in the garage with its engine running. Dr. Peter Angelo, the Medical Examiner, said Mrs. Sexton died of carbon monoxide poisoning.

title: A CALL FOR ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 President Ford, urging a new mobilization against inflation, proposed today a broad, basically conservative program ranging from reducing oil imports to a oneyear tax increase for corporations, as well as many private citizens.

title: Braves Rout Knicks, 11983; Cowens Hurt in Celtic Loss
Paul C. Hoffman Is Dead at 83; Led Marshall Plan and U.N. Aid
description: Paul G. Hoffman, the automobile executive who headed the United Nations Development Program and who was the first administrator of the Marshall Plan after World War II, died yesterday in his sleep. sleep.

title: Lanier, Pistons Defeat Nets, 11294
description: DETROIT, Oct. 7 (AP)Bob Lanier scored 23 points and grabbed 21 rebounds and Willy Norwood added 20 points to lead the Detroit Pistons to 11294 preseason victory over the New York Nets tonight.

title: Pipe Maker Laying Off 375
description: ANNISTON, Ala., Oct. 8 (UPI) The Mead Corporation, a pipemanufacturing concern, said tdday that 375 of the 1,100 workers at its three foundries here were being laid off.

title: Transit Bill Blocked
description: The House Rules Committee yesterday blocked the. sixyear, $11.8billion masstransit bill, but the committee chairman and supporters of the legislation predicted that the vote would be reversed today. Page 18.

description: The Franklin National Bank was declared insolvent yesterday in the largest bank failure in American banking history.

description: BOSTON, Oct. 8  Mayor Kevin H. White went into Federal District Court today and requested United States marshals to keep order in this city's strifetorn program for school busing for integration.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Twentyfive women prisoners at the state correctional facility at Bedford Hills, N.Y., were injured and 28 were thrown into segregation after an uprising there last August, it was charged yesterday during a news conference to protest maltreatment of women prisoners state facilities.

title: Minuteman Missile Lofted
description: VANDENBURG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 8 (UPI)Strategic Air Command combat crews launched a Minuteman 2 Intercontinental ballistic missile last night as part of a series of operational test launches.

title: Little Concern Evident in L.I. on Bank TakeOver
description: MINEOLA, L. I, Oct. 8Although the announcement that the Franklin National Bank had been declared insolvent and taken over by the EuropeanAmerican Bonk and Trust Company came as a surprise to both Nassau County officials and Long Islandbased companies, little real concern was apparent today.

title: TONE OF MESSAGE IS WIDELY BACKED
description: While President Ford's economic message evoked general approval from the business community yesterday, a number of executives and economists said they believed that his program was not specific enough. Others warned that Congressional approval of some of his proposals remained in doubt.

title: The Cyprus Test
description: ATHENS  If Henry Kissinger can first obtain at least some concessions from Turkey, Greece is prepared to regard the Secretary of State as a valid mediator in the unhappy Cyprus affair, despite contradictory statements by politicians contesting this country's first free election in years. But something tangible must be secured; also Washington should make public its private acknowledgment that, even if recent policy was not mistaken, it contained omissions.

title: 2 Share Peace Prize
description: The Nobel Peace Prize for 1974 was awarded yesterday. to former Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan and to Sean MacBride of Ireland, the United Nations commissioner for SouthWest Africa. Page 5.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 45

title: Dwight Murray is Dead; ExA.M.A. Head Was 86
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 8 (AP)Dwight H. Murray, who was president of the American Medical Association in 1956, died here yesterday in a hospital. He was 86 years old.

title: Kennedy Statue Is Bombed
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 8 (AP) A bomb destroyed a statue of the late President John F. Kennedy in downtown La Paz today. The statue, a gift from the United States Government, was on the Avenue of the Americas near the central railway station. No injuries were reported.

title: Film Fete: Errant Humor of 'Paloma':Kitsch and Camp Clash in Story of Singer 'Alice in the Cities' Swiss Import Seethes With Revenge
description: When you play with clichs, you have to be very careful that they don't backfire; the little things have a way of maiming almost everything around them.Daniel Schmid's "La Paloma"  which was shown last night and to be repeated tonight at the New York Film Festival  is intentionally crammed with cultural chestnuts, and also makes a heavy pass at the plots of "Camille" and "La Traviata." Kitsch and camp collide in this storm of pity and terror and wonder, which seethes with boundless love, burning glances, and unfathomable revenge. Nestling within this Swiss movie are some humorous intentions gone astray; it's also what they call dreamlike, although the dreams I've been watching lately have been funnier.A glum nightclub singerIngrid Caven, who's tricked out like a caricature of Dietrich  is ailing with some nameless rot. She permits a wealthy young admirer (Peter Kern) to cosset her, cure her, and finally marry her. It's repeated that she doesn't love him, but she cherishes his passion for her. Then she falls for his best friend and wants to decamp with him; her husband selfishly refuses to finance the expedition. Therefore, she dies slowly and even more tidily than Ali McGraw in "Lovy Story."Her deathbed wish forces her husband to exhume and dismember her three years later; the corpse chuckles as he moans while converting it into cutlets. By then, since I was into the swing of the movie, I expected poisonous fumes to rise from the coffin and wipe out the suffering spouseand was rather embarrassed when they didn't.Some obligatory decadence trickles through the nightclub scenesbut mercifully, the movie is set in 1952, so there aren't any Nazis around. The soundtrack endows the actors with theme-tunes; occasionally, they even flower into song, and the incidental music ranges from an opera by Erich Korngold to "Don't Sit Under the Apple Tree." Just after the couple are married, there's a soaring duet on a mountaintop. Suddenly, a transparent apparition floats over their heads: the thing grins jovially while its draperies flap in a breeze that doesn't even ruffle their coiffures.You can't really discuss "La Paloma" in terms of acting; the performers stalk rigidly about, exchanging long, brooding stares or significant smirks, and the result is a failed parody of the grand manner. (It was probably meant to be some sort of pantomime.) They also speak their lines very, very slowly  as though one another's reflexes were impaired.The ultimate astonishment is the appearance of Bulle Ogier as the husband's mother. Looking younger than her offspring, she doesn't seem to be on good terms with her cane. If only Elaine May had directed "La Paloma"  the brisk deadpan delivery that she can draw out of actors might have been marvelous for this material.

title: Sean MacBride
description: Last night, hours after he had learned that he had been named to share the Nobel Peace Prize for 1974, Sean MacBride was not certain why.

title: Nibbling The Bullet
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8President Ford has now defined the economic crisis of the nation and proposed a catalogue of remedies. The question now is whether the solutions he proposed are equal to the crisis he defined, and the fear here is that he didn't bite the bullet but nibbled it.

title: Betty Corcoran Wed in Miami
description: Betty Margaret Corcoran, owner of Corcoran & Greenberg, Inc., an art gallery in Coral Gables, Fla., was married in Miami last evening to Joseph Z. Fleming, a partner in the law firm of Fleming & Neuman there. The civil ceremoney was performed in Mr. Fleming's office by his partner, Aviva D. Neuman, in her capacity' as notary public.

title: Senate Votes 5Year Term on Broadcast Licenses
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) The Senate voted 62 to 10 today to require that broadcast licenses be issued and renewable for a fiveyear period instead of the present three years.

title: Senate Unit Clears a Bill To Help Pan Am Compete
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Senate Commerce Corn cleared legislation today designed to help troubled Pan American World Airways compete more effectively with foreign airlines.

title: Mayor Calls for Marshals To Keep Order in Boston
description: BOSTON, Oct. 8  Mayor Kevin H. White went into Federal District Court today and requested United States marshals to keep order in this city's strifetorn program for school busing for integration.

title: GIRL IN ROCKLAND IS MURDER VICTIM
description: NANUET, N.Y., Oct. 8  The bludgeoned body of a missing 15yearold high school girl was found here today in a wooded area near one of the largest shopping centers in Rockland County, about a block from her home.

title: Stargell's Homer Long Overdue
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8Wilver Dornel Stargell is one of baseball's authentic sluggers, a 33yearold lefthanded batter who has hit 346 National League home runs in a 12year career with the Pittsburgh Pirates. He has been in the running for mostvaluableplayer awards, he can wear a world championship ring earned in 1971, and he has been on allstar teams seven times.

title: Venezuela, Decrying Threats, Calls in U.N. for Oil Dialogue
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8The Foreign Minister of (Venezuela, the western hemisphere's leading oilexporting nation, told the United Nations General Assembly today that the welfare of onethird of the world is being achieved at the expense of the other twothirds.

title: Free and Unafraid
description: Paul G. Hoffman was an exuberant exponent of all that is best in the American tradition. A highly successful salesman and corporate executive, he never lost sight of the reality that free enterprise was viable only to the extent that it genuinely served the interests of human freedom and social responsibility.

title: Jersey Sweepstakes Prep Slated Today
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 8 (AP)  The outcome of tomorrow's Jersey Sweepstakes Prep race will help determine which horses run in the main event Oct. 26, which will combine parimutuel betting and lottery tickets, Twelve Jerseybred horses will run in tomorrow's sevenfurlong race at Atlantic City Rage Track for a $12,000 purse. The event is a preliminary to the $40,000 Jersey Sweepstakes, an invitation onemile, 70yard race for Jerkybred 3yearold and older horses. The sweepstakes will be combined with a special lottery, of $1 tickets to be drawn at Monmouth Park just before the race. For every million sweepstakes lottery tickets sold, there will be 309 cash prizes totaling $490,900. Individual prizes will be as high $100,000.

title: SHERWIN ORDERED TO JAIL BY COURT
description: TRENTON, Oct. 8Former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two codefendants apparently lost their twoyear fight to stay out of prison today when the State Supreme Court denied a hearing on their appeals and instead ordered the defendants to surrender at noon Friday.

title: Quintuplets Born in Baltimore; Boy and 4 Sisters Doing Well
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 8A suburban Baltimore housewife gave birth today to quintuplets, four girls and a boy, at Univercity of Maryland Hospital here.

title: Maine Computer Plant Set
description: WESTBROOK, Me., Oct. 8The Data General Corporation of Southboro, Mass., announced yeterday that it would built a $2million plant here to make subassemblies for the small computers it assembles in Southboro and Hull, Quebec. Edson D. deCastro, Data General's president, said the company hoped to employ 500 its first year, with total employment eventually going to 2,000.

title: The Exuberance of June Is Gone; Egypt Realistic Toward West
description: CAIRO, Oct. 8On landing here tomorrow, Secretary of State Kissinger is not likely to find any of the exuberance that greeted him in June, when he arrived with Richard M. Nixon on what turned out to be Mr. Nixon's final foreign tour as President.

title: Absurd Person Singular, Comedy
description: We have a new fun house in town. It is called Absurd Person Singular, has been constructed by Alan Ayckbourn and was unveiled at the Music Box last night. And it is singularly absurd, although the hilarity is gentle rather than riotous. It is a British play, and it admirably demonstrates the difference between British and American humor. But more of that later.

title: Impact of the Program
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8President Ford's new economic program would make a modest difference to most taxpayers, a potentially significant difference to regular members of the labor force who have lost their jobs and have no unemployment compensation but apparently, according to analysts, rather little difference to the current problems of the national economy, including inflation.

title: MORTGAGE SUPPORTS WOULD BE EXPANDED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The housing portion of President Ford's economic package presented to Congress today involves a $3billion expansion, with one important modification, of an existing $10billion package of mortgage support programs that is now largely exhausted.

title: Notes on People City's Top Honor for Lippmann
description: At Gracie Mansion yesterday, Mayor Beame presented Walter Lippmann with the city's highest honor, the Bronze Medallion. The presentation came two weeks after Mr. Lippmann's 85th birthday celebration on Sept. 25.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: FIGURES IN THE SAND, two oneact plays by Nathan Teitel, staged by Nick Havinga, at the St. Clements Theater, 423 West 46th Street, 7.

title: Plans for an Office of Hispanic Affairs In Newark Appear Mired in Red Tape
description: NEWARK, Oct. 8Plans for the establishment of an Office of Hispanic Affairs, regarded as a major concession made to the city's Spanishspeaking community by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson after last month's racial disturbances here, appear to be languishing in a morass of bureaucratic red tape and opposition.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Urging a new mobilization against inflation, President Ford proposed a broad program that included a call for a reduction of oil imports and a oneyear tax increase for corporations and many individuals. In an address to a joint session of Congress, Mr. Ford called on all Americans to enlist in the fight to whip inflation now. The President's proposals would provide tax incentives for business, help unemployed workers, stimulate home construction, and expand agricultural production. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: PAULINE S. WALTON
description: Pauline Shaw Walton, a member of the National Society of Colonial Dames, died yesterday at her home, 435 East 52d Street. She was 87 years fold.

title: SCHOOL AIDES ASK END TO TAX MIT
description: School district officials and other local government officers pleaded yesterday for relief from limitations on their taxing power imposed by the State Constitution.

title: JOINT STOCK SYSTEM PREPARED BY N.A.S.D.
description: Gordon S. Macklin, president of the National Association of Securities Dealers, declared in Arizona yesterday that if talks with the New York and American stock exchanges, for a joint composite stock quotation plan, broke down, the regulatory body for the overthecounter market was prepared to present its own plan to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Many Ifs Mark Jets' Loss
description: MIAMI, Oct. 8It is the nature of the Jets to live precariously through a National Football League season, That has been the character of the team for years, since the 1969 Super Bowl.

title: Hialeah Faces Closing; Franchise Sale Voted
description: Hialeah Park, an aristocratic showcase of American horse racing for half a century, appears ready to go out of business.

title: Upstate Weekly Bans Reports On ProAbortion Candidates
description: Proclaiming on his editorial page that I and the members of the staff still firmly believe in God, the editor of a small upstate weekly newspaper has refusd either to accept advertising from or to print news articles about any candidates for political office who favor abortion.

title: Minibus to Serve Garment Area
description: Free minibus service to transport outoftown buyers from midtown hotels to the garment district will be opened next Tuesday.

title: FORD THREATENS VETO ON AID ANEW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8President Ford threatened again today to veto pending legislation that would cut off military aid to Turkey, calling the measure that the House of Representatives adopted yesterday misguided and extremely harmful.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1974
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Ford News Conference Today in Rose Garden
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)  President Ford will hold his third news conference at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow in the White House Rose Garden, his chief spokesman announced today.

title: Paulsen Keeps Ring Title
description: OSLO, Norway, Oct. 8(AP)Svein Erik Paulsen of Norway scored a 15round decision tonight over Giovanni Girgenti of Italy and retained his European Junior lightweight boxing title. Paulsen weighed 129 pounds and Girgenti 129.

title: 3 From Weis Told To Assist the Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Three of five defendants convicted of securities law violations leading to the collapse of Weis Securities, Inc., have been sentenced to devote five hours a week for one year to work with and render assistance to underprivileged people.

title: Ford's Surtax Proposal Is Criticized by Wilson
description: SALDWIN, L. I. Oct 8Governor Wilson criticized the proposed imposition of Federal surtax on incomes today as he campaigned for crucial votes in this suburban heartland.

title: Ford Terms Reaction To Proposal Favorable
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) President Ford said today that the reaction to his economic program proposals so far had been favorable.

title: Rangers to Open Season Here Tonight
description: Now that the exciting part of the hockey season is over the exhibitionsthe National Hockey League will begin the yawning part todaythe regular season.

title: Czech Six Beats Team Canada, 31
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 8 (AP)A rejuvenated Czechoslovak hockey team took a 20 lead in the first 10 minutes and went on to hand Team Canada a 31 defeat today in the final game of its European visit.

title: IMPASSE ARISES ON STRIPMINE BILI
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Members of a SenateHouse conference committee that has worked for nearly three months to reach a compromise on diffaring versions of a Federa stripmine control law failed tonight to meet a midnigh ?? deadline that could have meant passage this week of the first Federal environment al controls on surface mining for coal.

title: 1YEAR, 5% SURTAX AT $15,000 AND UP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Congress received from President Ford today a manyfaceted tax program that would give small tax reduction to the working poor, impose a oneyear tax increase on corporations and on most individuals above bare middleincome levels and provide two permanent programs of tax relief for business.

title: CENTRAL PARK ZOO GETS A NEW CHIEF
description: The Central Park Zoo, with its 472 animals and birds has a new director. He is Robert Beach, a 42yearold New Yorker who has been with the Parks Department for 16 years.

title: 2,000 Hispanic Children Boycott Newark Classes
description: NEWARK, Oct. 8More than 2,000 Hispanic children stayed away from nine elementary schools here today in protest against an impending cutback in bilingual classes.

title: Rockefeller Gifts Queried; $550,000 Went to Ronan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Senator Howard W. Cannon, chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, has asked Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller to supply detailed background information about the financial gifts he has made to his aides and associates.

title: Ronan Is Still a Paid Rockefeller Adviser
description: Since last May, when he stepped down as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Dr. William Ronan has served as the ried senior adviser to the Rockefeller family, in addition to salaried memberships on the boards of directors of two sayings banks and an industrial corporation.

title: Ford to Speak Tonight
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (UPI)  President Ford will speak here tomorrow evening at a Republican fundrasing and testimonal dinner for former Gov. William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania. The $200aplate dinner is the first of three that the Republicans will hold in the state this month to raise campaign funds.

title: 12 BIG OIL CONCERNS ARE SUED BY KANSAS
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 8 (UPI) Vern Miller, Attorney General of Kansas, filed suit in Federal court here today against 12 major oil companies, asking that they divest themselves of exploration and production holdings and hinting at a pricing conspiracy.

title: Ford's House Testimony Delayed Until Next Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8President Ford's appearance before Congress to explain his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon was postponed tonight and rescheduled for next week so that a jury could be picked and sequestered for the Water gate coverup trial before Mr. Ford testifies.

title: Sherwin Ordered to Jail By Jersey's High Court
description: TRENTON, Oct, 8Former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two codefendants apparently lost their twoyear fight to stay out of prison today when the State Supreme Court denied a hearing on their appeals and instead ordered the defendants to surrender at noon Friday.

title: 300 Blacks Storm New Utrecht, Forcing High School to Close
description: About 300 black students and lother youths stormed through New Utrecht High School in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday disrupting classes, challenging white students to fight and forcing the closing of the school until tomorrow.

title: 36 Homeless in Fire
description: A threealarm fire quickly spread through the upper two floors of a partially abandoned sixstory tenement in the Morrisania section of the Bronx last night, leaving 36 tenants homeless and injuring seven firemen who were treated for smoke inhalation and heat exhaustion. The fire, at 1668 Vyse Avenue, was declared under control at 11:11 P.M.

title: House Panel Delays Action On Drinking Water Quality
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The House Rules Committee by voice vote deferred indefinitely today disposition of a pending bill providing for mandatory Federal standards of drinking water quality throughout the country.

title: St. Catherine's Park: Community's Dream Leads to Disappointment
description: On any day, almost anywhere in the city, it might be possible to find young mothers sitting over cups of coffee, scribbled papers strewn about a table, eagerly discussing a subject dear to their hearts: getting a new or revitalized neighborhood playground for their children to play in.

title: Franklin Is Biggest, But List of Failures Of Banks Is Growing
description: The insolvency of the Franklin National Bank comes just one year after the failure of ,the United States National Bank in San Diego and against a background of a generally rising incidence of banking collapses in recent years.

title: Wall St. Clerk Shot Dead, Body Found in Parked Car
description: The body of aman tentatively identified as a Wall Street stock clerk was found in a parked car yesterday afternoon in Forest Hills, Queens. The body had two bullets in it.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WALDWICK, Oct. 8Someday Henry Steinsiek is going to make it in pro football, preferably with the New York Giants. But not as a player. Henry isn't big enough, strong enough or tough enough.

title: Du Pont Unit Plans Layoffs
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, Oct. 8 (UPI)Du Pont de Nemours, G.m.b.H., the West German subsidiary of the American chemical giant, plans to put half of its 2,200 employes on parttime shifts, a company spokesman said today.

title: Black Coach at Tennessee
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 8 (AP)Larry Robinson, captain of Tennessee's 197273 basketball team and until recently a Dallas Cowboy back, was hired today as assistant football coach. The 23yearold Robinson is the first black to join the Tennessee coaching staffs.

title: KENNETH LESLIE, POET, DEAD AT 81
description: HALIFAX, Noya Scotia, Oct, 8 (AP)Kenneth Leslie, whose poetry reflected life in the rural areas of this province and won him the 1938 GovernorGeneral's Medal, died yesterday. He was 81 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: VERSIONS OF THE PAST. The Historical Imagination in American Fiction. By Harry B. Henderson 3d. 344 pages. Oxford. $12.50.

title: Shipping/Mails
