description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Help for Boston
description: After simmering for a month, the lid appears about to blow off the Boston school situation. The Boston police, severely tested, stretched and drained by four week of keeping peace are now showing severe signs of strain. South Boston High, standing virtually empty since the opening of school, has become the symbol that is sparking resistance to the courtordered integration plan in other areas of the city where compliance had been relatively peaceful. The black community, having demonstrated remarkable restraint in the face of substantial hostility, is becoming restive. Mobs on the streets of South Boston have produced some of the ugliest scenes in a generation of ugly memories.

title: Infant Girl Dies in Fire
description: Firemen found a 3monthold girl dead in the bedroom of a burning Lower East Side apartment yesterday afternoon, authorities said. The girl, the daughter of Rose Delgavo of 810 Rivington Street, died of burns and smoke inhalation, firemen said, A spokesman for the Fire Department said that Mrs. Delgavo was taken to Beth Israel Hospital where she was treated for smoke inhalation.

title: Impact of the Program
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8President Ford's new economic program would make a modest difference to most taxpayers, a potentially significant difference to regular members of the labor force who have lost their jobs and have no unemployment compensation but apparently, according analysts, rather little difference to the current problems of the national economy, including inflation.

title: SHAH EXPANDING IRAN'S INFLUENCE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 8Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, on his recently concluded 17day trip to five Asian countries placed new emphasis on two of Iran's major foreign policy objectives.

title: Filming in City: Trend Is Down, but Hope Is Up
description: Film cameras, which used to grind in profusion on the sidewalks of New York, are a rare spectacle these days. But a new effort is being made to lure: back the movie industry.

title: Gentile Is Victor In Golf by Stroke
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Oct. 8John Gentile of the Round Hill Club of Greenwich, Conn., captured the ninth Port Jefferson open today by a stroke with a 36hole card of 142 over the par72, 6,810yard Harbor Hills course. He collected $1,200 in the $5,000 event.

title: Paul G. Hoffman Is Dead at 83; Led Marshall Plan and U.N. Aid
description: Paul G. Hoffman, the automobile executive who headed the United Nations Development Program and who was the first administrator of the Marshall Plan after World War If, died here yesterday in his sleep.

title: 6to6 Vote in House Rules Committee Blocks MassTransit Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The House Rules Committee today blocked the sixyear, $11.8billion masstransit bill, with a tie vote, 6 to 6, with three absences, denying the bill access to the House floor.

title: BEAME DEFENDS CITY IN REPLY TO WILSON
description: Apparently miffed at Governor Wilson's campaign criticism of the New York City government, Mayor Beame, who began his City Hall tenure by proclaiming a determination to practice bipartisan cooperation with Albany, issued a statement of his own yesterday.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: West's Regional Brokerage Firms Developing Formula for Survival
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8The thinnedout ranks of the regional securities brokerage firms in the West think of themselves as survivors. They have trimmed costs and increased their sales forces, and some of them are even making money.

title: Montoya Says Rate Of U.S. Aid to Nixon Is $2Million a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Federal Government is now spending at the rate of almost $2million a year on personnel and support services for former President Richard M. Nixon, according to Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico.

title: INDIAN CONFIDENT ON THE FOOD CRISIS
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 8India's Food Minister said today that the Indian Government had taken adequate steps to cope with the shortages caused by drought in the northern, western and eastern parts of the country.

title: Ford's 10 Proposals
description: 1. FOOD  Removal of remaining acreage limitations on rice, peanuts and cotton to increase production and lower prices, with assured allocations of needed fuel and fertilizer. Council on Wage and Price Stability to expose restrictive practices that raise prices.

title: SUFFOLK TO SEEK 8,000 PARK ACRES
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Oct. 8In zn effort to establish guidelines for the preservation of open space in this Increasingly sulfurbanized county the Suffolk Planning Department today unveiled a master plan for the acquisition and develop. ment of 8,000 acres of parks and recreation areas.

title: AMEX PRICES GAIN AS VOLUME SLIPS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to rise yesterday for the second consecutive day as traders remained convinced that President Ford's speech, which was delivered after the close, would have some encouraging news. However, traders in the overthecounter market evidently lost their optimism as prices there closed lower after rising Monday.

title: Income Tax Sought In Jersey City Suit For State Residents
description: An income tax heretofore limited to outofstate residents who work in New Jersey would be extended to residents of the state to pay for public schools, if a suit filed in Superior Court yesterday is successful. The suit was filed by Jersey City.

title: Mihajlo Mihajlov, Yugoslav Writer, Is Arrested Again
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 8Mihajlo Mihajlov, a writer on Russia and communism, was arrested yesterday at his home in Novi Sad, He was charged with disseminating hostile propaganda and associating with foreign migr organizations.

title: Dorothy Kirwan, 62, Who Owned McSorley's Old Ale House, Dies
description: Dorothy O'Connell Kirwan, the owner of McSorley's Old Ale House, who had never set foot during business hours in what until four years ago was an exclusively masculine refuge, died yesterday at her home in Flushing, Queens, She was 62 years old.

title: A CALL FOR ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8President Ford, urging a new mobilization against inflation, proposed today a broad, basically conservative program ranging from reducing oil imports to a oneyear tax increase for corporations, as well as many private citizens.

title: Transit Bill Blocked
description: The House Rules Committee yesterday blocked the sixyear, $11.8billion masstransit bill, but the committee chairman and supporters of the legislation predicted that the vote would be reversed today. Page 18.

title: Cornell Back Honored
description: CENTERVILLE, Mass., Oct. 8 (AP)Don Fanelli, Cornell tailback, made the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I weekly football honor roll today for his performance against Bucknell last Saturday. He scored three touchdowns in Cornell's 240 victory.

title: What Leadership?
description: President Ford chose an unfortunate rhetorical device in opening his inflation message to Congress yesterday with a quotation from Franklin D. Roosevelt's first inaugural address. Now as in 1933, the nation does seek leadership and actionin a deepening crisis. But Mr. Ford's program and approach are in strikingand unflatteringcontrast to F.D.R.'s. Many of the specific recommendations in his 10point program are indeed laudable, but the overall impact of Mr. Ford's speech was weak, flaccid and generally disappointing.

title: Black to Head Guardsmen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)Brig. Gen. Cunningham C. Bryant will become the first black commanding general of the District of Columbia National Guard, the Pentagon announced today. He will be promoted to major general, the Pentagon said.

title: House Passes, 203 to 165, A Diluted Plan for Reform
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The House of Representatives, ending a sixday floor fight over how to reform itself, approved late tonight a drastically scaledclown reorganization plan that would make few changes in the existing committee structure. The vote was 203 to 165.

title: DAVID WALLACE, 66, SOCIOLOGIST, IS DEAD
description: David C. Wallace, a sociologist and marketing research specialist, died of a stroke Sunday at Taomina Sicily. He was 66 years old and lived at Westport, Conn.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: Continued on Page 14, Column 1

title: CONGRESS IS COOL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Congress gave a restrained reception today to President Ford's grand design to cure the nation's economic ills.

title: Ford and Gierek Stress Friendly Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8President Ford and the Polish Communist party leader, Edward Gierek, stressed friendship and friendly ties between the United States and Poland in their first meeting today.

title: Jurgensen to Start In Redskins Game
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) Coach George Allen confirmed after practice today that Sonny Jurgensen would start for the Washington Redskins at quarterback Sunday against the Miami Dolphins.

title: Pittsburgh Gets 5 in First to Win by 7
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8A threerun homer by Willie Stargell and a tworun shot by Richie Hebner before the Los Angeles Dodgers got to bat, followed by one  hit pitching for six innings by Bruce Kison, allowed for no suspense today as the Pittsburgh Pirates prolonged the National League championship playoff with a 70 victory.

title: MRS. FORD'S DOCTOR TO CALL ON EXPERTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)Betty Ford's personal physician plans to assemble a team of medical specialists to chart her treatment for breast cancer.

title: People Known to Police Back Casinos
description: TRENTON, Oct. 8 (AP)  A routine police check of people waiting to run training schools for dealers and croupiers for gambling casinos in New Jersey is turning up a lot of names familiar to the police.

title: Advertising Good News From New England
description: This month's issue of Blair & Ketchum's Country Journal is its sixth and William S. Blair, its publisher, was down from Battleboro, Vt., yesterday looking as pleased as punch about the way things are going.

title: PublicTV Crime Series Stirs Fund Controversy
description: A proposed national series on crime and criminal justice in the United States has stirred a controversy within the publictelevision industry because the financial underwriting for it will come from the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, a Federal agency whose specific interests correspond with the subject matter of the series.

title: On Pardons and Testimony
description: WASHINGTON  Before they question President Ford, House Judiciary Committee members ought to look at an obscure clause in Article II, Section 2, of the Constitution. It says that the President may pardon except in cases of impeachment.

title: Pressmen Authorize Strike At The Long Island Press
description: William J. Kennedy Jr., president of Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2, said yesterday that pressmen employed at The Long Island Press had voted to authorize a strike against the newspaper.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. to hear Bangladesh, Iraq, the President of Somalia, Sri Lanka, Cambodia, Libya, Lesotho, Chad and Malta in general debate.

title: Net Climbs 121% For Paper Maker
description: Earnings of the International Paper Company in the three months ended Sept. 30, were the highest for any quarter in the company's history, while profits for the first nine months exceeded those for any full year on record, according to results issued yesterday by J. Stanford Smith, chairman.

title: Miss Furness Warns Business Of Possible Consumer Revolt
description: Three women who at one time or another have served as the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs aimed a fusillade of criticism yesterday at both government and business for its neglect of consumers.

title: SEYMOUR PACK
description: Seymour Pack, an engineer and founder of the Institute of Computer Technology, a school teaching computer programing, died yesterday of cancer at Brunswick Hospital, Amityville, L,I, He was 46 years old and lived at Massapequa, L.I.

title: Transfer of Prisoners to Ancora Called a Risk
description: CAMDEN, Oct. 8A New Jersey psychiatrist predicted today that if state prisoners were shifted to Ancora Psychiatric Hospital, pregnancies among patients would skyrocket, patient deaths from overdoss of illegal would increase significantly, and anxiety among patients would rise.

title: Jury Clears 2 Detectives Implicated By Testimony of Corrupt Policeman
description: Rejecting the testimony of a corrupt policeman who turned around, a jury cleared two narcotics detectives yesterday of stealing money from drug addicts during raids.

title: UAL REOPENS TALKS WITH I.T.T. ON AVIS
description: UAL, Inc., said last night that discussions had been reopened with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation on possible acquisition of Avis, Inc., by UAL. A spokesman for I.T.T. confirmed the renewal of discussions.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: Panel Told Why Ford Halted Grain Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 President Ford cited a political problem with Congress and political problem with the people in demanding cancellation of two large grain deals with the Soviet Union, the Senate permanent subcommittee on investigations was told today.

title: Cuba Seems to Vanquish Racism
description: HAVANA, Oct. 2  The revolution that triumphed 15 years ago in Cuba under Fidel Castro is still going on in some remarkable and some peculiar ways.

title: Erving and Kenon Pace Nets' Victory
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 8 (UPI)Julius Erving scored 20 points and Larry Kenon added 18 as the New York Nets defeated the Spirits of St. Louis, 10288, in an American Basketball Asociation exhibition game tonight.

title: NOBEL AWARD WON BY SATO, MACBRIDE
description: OSLO, Norway, Oct. 8 (AP) The Nobel Peace Prize for 1974 was awarded today to former Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan and to Sean MacBride of Ireland, the United Nations commissioner for SouthWest Africa.

title: New U.S. Plan Set on Soviet Emigration
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Secretary of State Kissinger and three key Senators agreed today on a new formula to salvage a compromise that would allow the Soviet Union trade benefits in return for a liberalized policy on emigration of Jews and others.

title: Dartmouth Tries Script From 1973
description: And how does Jake Crouthamel, coach of the defending Ivy champion Dartmouth eleven, feel about his team's successive nonleague losses to Massachusetts and Holy Cross? No worse than he felt at this time last year. The same thing happened to us then, he said yesterday. We lost our two tuneups. Then we even got beaten by Penn in our first Ivy League try. Still we won the title. I feel our season is at an early turning point. Which way we go remains to be seen.

title: A REBATE ON OIL TAX PLANNED IN CANADA
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 8 (AP)Canada will rebate 50 cents of a $5.20a barrel tax on heavy and medium crude oil exported to the United States, a spokesman for the Department of Energy Mines and Resources said today.

title: OAPEC and E.E.C. Set Regular Talks After 2Day Parley
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 8The European Economic Community and the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed today to maintain regular contacts, thus opening up a new line of communication between Europe and its chief oil suppliers.

title: SAMUEL SAVITZ
description: Samuel Savitz, founder and owner of the Strand Stitching and Pleating Corporation, 255 West 36th Street, died yesterday at University Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Hollis, Queens.

title: HENRY J. CADBURY, BIBLICAL SCHOLAR
description: Dr. Henry Joel Cadbury, a prominent Quaker and Biblical scholar, died Monday at Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Haverford, Pa.

title: Ford's 10 Proposals
description: 1. FOOD  Removal of remaining acreage limitations on rice, peanuts and cotton to increase production and lower prices, with assured allocations of needed fuel and fertilizer. Council on Wage and Price Stability to expose restrictive practices that raise prices.

title: Minibus to Serve Garment Area
description: Free minibus service to transport outoftown buyers from midtown hotels to the garment district will be opened next Tuesday.

title: 8 of Today's Artists Exhibit at the Modern
description: Eight Contemporary Artists at the Museum of Modern Art is a considerable undertaking on the part of the museum. It will occupy through Jan. 5 the sequence of rooms that was recently given to Picasso, to Mir and to Marcel Duchamp. It is the museum's answerthough it is not put forward as suchto persons who say that it sticks with the great and the safe. It is also the museum's answer to those who say that it exists to push artists around. Much of the work was made expressly for the show, and the artists had the kind of freedom that a good dealer would give them. Walls came down; machinery came in; games were played with aspects of the building that are normally held sacred.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: About New York
description: The curtain fell, an,d then it rose, and the members of the company came out, taking bows and being applauded. Angela Lansbury, however, came out alone, the way a big Broadway star does, and when she did, the applause became louder. It was louder than it had been in Dallas, Los Angeles or even London. Broadway, after all, is something else.

title: Advertising Council to Aid Ford's Drive
description: Toward the end of President Ford's speech yesterday, when he was asking all of the American people to become volunteer inflation fighters and energy savers, he pointed out a apel button on his jacket.

title: Dow Index Slips by 4.93; Advances Top Declines
description: The stock market played mostly a waiting game yesterday after Monday's sharp rally, and finished mixed in active trading.

title: SWISS GROUP DENIED HESSISCHE BANK AID
description: PARIS, OCT. 8  The Hessische Landesbank Girozentrale has freed itself pf any responsibility for rescuing the International Credit Bank of Geneva, centerpiece of a financial empire now being investigated by Israeli and Swiss authorities as well as the interests of Baron Edmond de Rothschild.

title: Wozzeck, Berg's Masterpiece, Returns at the Met
description: Alban Berg's Wozzeck is one of the 20th century's masterpieces of the operatic stage, It is also an inandout opera, never really in the repertory, yet never far away. Last seen at the Metropolitan Opera during the 196869 season, Wozzeck returned there on Monday night with a new conductor and a virtually new cast.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The District Attorney's office is investigating a charge that two defendants indicted with four others in the kidnapping of an undercover policeman were beaten by police officers after their arrest.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the partnerships that captured the first PanAmerican Invitations Pair Championship in Mexico City during the weeknd has few bridge peaks left to scale. Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman of Dallas have won both the World Team Championship and the World Pair Championship, a claim to fame shared only by the French stars Pierre Jais and Roger Trzel.

title: New Energy Director Rogers Clark Ballard Morton
description: Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton, the man designated by President Ford yesterday to head a new national energy board and serve as overall boss of the nation's energy program, should have no problem squaring his own views with the President's directive to reduce oil imports and develop the country's coal reserves. Just two weeks ago, in a speech to the Economic Club of Detroit, Mr. Morton urged that very objective as the most constructive thing the United States could do to alleviate the current economic crisis.

title: 2 Share Peace Prize
description: The Nobel Peace Prize for 1974 was awarded yesterday to former Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan and to Sean MacBride of Ireland, the United Nations commissioner for SouthWest Africa. Page 5.

title: Electric Rates Are a Connecticut Issue
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 8In the uproar over rising electric bills, the Connecticut General Assembly appeared today to be gathering behind the idea of calling itself into special session to deal with the issue.

title: State Arts Council Replaces Acting Program Director
description: The New York State Council on the Arts has replaced David Payne as acting program director for the performing arts with Hugh Southern, who will take a leave of absence from his as executive director of the Theater Development Fund.

title: Rockefeller Gifts Queried; $550,000 Went to Ronan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Senator Howard W. Cannon, chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, has asked Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller to supply detailed background information about the financial gifts he has made to his aides and associates.

title: Men's Room Fight Fatal
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 8 (AP)One man was stabbed to death when six men tried to crowd into the men's room at a South Side bar early today and got into a fight because it was too small for all of them, the police said. The victim was identified as Juan Amador, 25 years old, of San Antonio. Henry Mesa, 28, suffered stab wounds in the chest, abdomen and back, the police reported.

title: 11 Coal Mines Shut As Textbook Dispute Stirs West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 8 (UPI)Eleven mines were shut down, three women pickets were arrested and school buses were vandalized today in the latest antitextbook demonstrations that erupted anew yesterday after two weeks of calm.

title: Rangers to Open Season Here Tonight
description: Now that the exciting part of the hockey season is over the exhibitionsthe National Hockey League will begin the yawning part todaythe regular season.

title: Fossils, 60 Million Years Old, Discovered in Baja California
description: A team of American and Mexican scientists reported yesterday that it had discovered what might prove to be one of the largest still unexplored deposits of marine and terrestrial fossils in North America.

title: Robert G. Robinson Dies; World War I Hero Was 78
description: ST. IGNACE, Mich., Oct. 8 (AP)Robert G. Robinson, a World War I Medal of Honor winner, was found dead Saturday night in the garden outside his rural cabin 10 miles north of here. He was 78 years old.

title: Nursing Homes Here Linked by Interlocking Leadership
description: In an effort to block the growth of a cartel that by its size could virtually dictate rates for care of the aged, New York State has barred corporations from operating nursing homes here.

title: State Seeking to Replace Director of Willowbrook
description: The state's Department of Mental Hygiene is seeking a replacement for Dr. Miodrag Ristic, director of Willowbrook, the state institution for the retarded on Staten Island.

title: Cornwall Liberal Seeks Votes One by One in Party's Heartland
description: LISKEARD, Cornwall, Oct. 6The Liberal party in this. South Cornwall constituency has an office beside the local candy store. But the real working headquarters of Paul Tyler, the 32yearold Liberal candidate, is his small red automobile.

title: ANTIABORTION DRIVE SUFFERS A SETBACK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The campaign to override the Supreme Court's ban on antiabortion legislation by amending the Constitution ran into an unexpected obstacle in Congress today.

title: 5 SENATORS ASK CUT IN IMPORTEDOIL USE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, and four other Democratic Senators called today for a reduction of one million barrels a day in the use of imported oil.

title: IU MAY SEEK HELP OF C.A.B. ON DEAL
description: The IU International Corporation, a diversified company in metal products, food distribution, paper, trucking and ocean shipping, said yesterday, that it would ask the Civil Aeronautics Board to take action on its proposed acquisition of the Airborne Freight Corporation The board of Airborne last Friday announced that it had rejected a proposal by IU to offer for each of Airbome's 2.7 million shares 0.6 shares of IU common, plus one share of a new series of IU 6 per cent voting preferred, redeemable in six years at $6.50.

title: LOUISIANA DEATH CLOSES SCHOOLS
description: DESTREHAN, La., Oct. 8Fearful of more racial outbursts of the sort that left a white student fatally shot yesterday, the authorities, closed all schools today in this Mississippi River town about 20 miles north of New Orleans.

title: Sugar Producers Widen Price Rises; Newsprint Raised
description: Three more sugar companies raised their prices yesterday, indicating a general industry trend that is expected to mean higher prices for many products made with sugar. The Sucrest Corporation and CPC International, Inc. said they would raise their prices on finely granulated sugar by $1.35 to $42.20 per 100pound bag.

title: 140 ARE ARRESTED IN NARCOTICS RAID
description: NEWARK, Oct. 8Officers from the Essex County Sheriff's Department fanned out through 14 local communities and towns in five adjoining counties before dawn today in a massive effort to arrest 126 adults and 14 juveniles for the sale of narcotics.

title: SENATE APPROVES CAMPAIGN FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) The Senate approved a compromise package of political reforms today that would give the Democratic and Republican Presidential nominees $20million each in taxpayer funds to wage their 1976 campaigns.

title: CONGRESS IS COOL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Congress gave a restrained reception today to President Ford's grand design to cure the nation's economic ills.

title: Del Gaizo Is Ready For Call
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 8The chances are that Bill Arnsparger, the New York Giants' coach, will be coy all week about naming the starting quarterback for the game against the Eagles in Philadelphia on Sunday. So it could be a time of insecurity for Norm Snead and Jim Del Gaizo.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals here has set aside a precedentsetting 73 per cent increase for new natural gas that was approved by the Federal Power Commission.

title: Mills Called Occupant Of Car Police Stopped
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)The Park Service police have identified Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas as one of five occupants of an automobile that was being driven at an unreasonable speed with its lights off yesterday at 2 A.M.

title: Rodriguez Beats Weston on Points
description: With a furious finish, Fausto Rodriguez of the Dominican Republican scored a majority decision over Harold Weston Jr. of Greenwich Village last night in a 10round welterweight bout before a crowd of 2,402 at the Felt Forum.

title: Flanigan Nomination Likely to Die Procedural Death
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is expected to withhold final action on the confirmation of Peter M. Flanigan, President Ford's nominee as Ambassador to Spain, when it meets tomorrow in a closed session. Senate sources said the nomination would probably die a procedural death during next month's Congressional recess.

title: Islanders Opening in Montreal
description: Denis Potvin, last season's rookie of the year, will play in the Islanders' opening game of the 197475 season in Montreal against the Canadiens tonight despite a hairline fracture of his left hand. The defenseman will be joined by the Islanders' highpowered right wing, Billy Harris, whose right ankle was injured by a flying puck early in training camp, forcing him to miss all but one game in the exhibition season.

title: Stargell's Homer Long Overdue
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8Wilver Dornel Stargell is one of baseball's authentic sluggers, a 33yearold lefthanded batter who has hit 346 National League home runs in a 12year career with the Pittsburgh Pirates. He has been in the running for mostvaluableplayer awards, he can wear a world championship ring earned in 1971, and he has been on allstar teams seven times.

title: Japan Tennis Rained Out
description: TOKYO, Oct. 8 (UPI)Rain today forced postponement of the secondday matches in the 1974 Tokyo open tennis tournament. Play will be resumed tomorrow.

title: A Parade, and Other Fun
AN EXDETECTIVE CLEARED OF LYING
description: A State Supreme Court Justice yesterday acquitted a retired city detective charged with lying before a grand jury that was investigating possible interference with the prosecution of a murder suspect.

title: Dirks, Who Uncovered Fraud At Equity, Is Gratified by Plea
description: Raymond L. Dirks, the man who uncovered the massive fraud at the Equity Funding Corporation of America, was in court yesterday to hear Stanley Goldblum, its onetime president and board chairman, plead guilty to one of the biggest frauds ever perpetrated.

title: CLARENCE C. SIMONI
description: Clarence C. Simoni, who was general manager of the packings and frictions materials division of the JohnsManville Corporation at his retirement in 1963, died on Monday in Stamford, Conn. He was 75 years old.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Thiokol Corporation has been awarded a $44.8million Air Force contract for Minuteman III missile motors.

title: Islanders Opening in Montreal
description: Denis Potvin, last season's rookie of the year, will play in the Islanders' opening game of the 197475 season in Montreal against the Canadiens tonight despite a hairline fracture of his left hand. The defenseman will be joined by the Islanders' highpowered right wing, Billy Harris, whose right ankle was injured by a flying puck early in training camp, forcing him to miss all but one game in the exhibition season.

title: BALAGUER'S OFFER ACCEPTED IN SIEGE
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 8  The six leftwing terrorists holding seven hostages in the Venezuelan consulate here have accepted an offer of safe conduct out of the country, the United States Ambassador, Robert A. Hurwitch, announced late today.

title: Carey Disputes Wilson on Inflation
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey, the Democratic candidate for Governor, denied yesterday charges by Governor Wilson that he and other Democrats in Congress and recent Democratic Presidents were primarily responsible for inflation,

title: Britain's Election
description: Britain's second election campaign of 1974 is ending as it beganin paradox. The three big parties agree that the nation is heading for its most severe economic testing since World War II; but the voters seem massively indifferent to this rerun of the February contest and highly skeptical that the balloting tomorrow will produce a government capable of ruling effectively.

title: A New Name in L.I. Banking
description: The European  American Bank and Trust Company, which yesterday acquired the Franklin National Bank's deposits and branch operations, may not be a household word on Main Street in Long Island, but it has longestablished roots in the international banking community.

title: Kissinger's Tour Begins Today in Cairo
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 9Secretary of State Kissinger took off for Cairo early this morning to start a Middle East tour aimed at setting a time and a framework for a new round of ArabIsraeli negotiations.

title: FRANKLIN POUND INSOLVENT BY U.S. AND TAKER OVER
description: The Franklin National Bank was declared insolvent yesterday in the largest bank failure in American banking history.

title: Pittsburgh Gets 5 in First to Win by 70
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8A threerun homer by Willie Stargell and a tworun shot by Richie Hebner before the Los Angeles Dodgers got to bat, followed by one  hit pitching for six innings by Bruce Kison, allowed for no suspense today as the Pittsburgh Pirates prolonged the National League championship playoff with a 70 victory.

title: Hispanic Office Plans Are Mired in Red Tape
description: NEWARK, Oct., 8Plans for the establishment of an Office of Hispanic Affairs, regarded the city's Spanishspeaking as a major concession made to community by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson after last month's racial disturbances, appear to be languishing in a morass of bureaucratic red tape and opposition.

title: House Votes to Revamp
description: The House of Representatives, ending a sixday floor fight over how to reform it self, approved last night, by a vote of 203 to 165, a drastically scaleddown reorganization plan that would revise some House procedures starting next year; but would make few changes in the existing committee structure. Page 16.

title: Pentagon Sees a Likely Bid for More Saigon Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Deputy Defense Secretary William P. Clements Jr. said today there was a strong possibility the Administration would ask Congress early next year for additional military aid for South Vietnam.

title: 2 NEW WITNESSES IDENTIFY PHILLIPS
description: A slightly built doorman and a whitehaired john, neither of whom had testified in the first trial of William R. Phillips, yesterday linked Mr. Phillips with meetings with James Goldberg in 1967 and 1968.

title: Javits Assails Clark Idea To Abolish Transit Fares
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits charged yesterday that Ramsey Clark's suggestion, coming fight now, that there could be free bus and subway fares in this city was a cruel hoax on senior citizens and lowincome families.

title: 1YEAR, 5% SURTAX AT $15,000 AND UP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Congress received from President Ford today a manyfaceted tax program that would give a small tax reduction to the working poor, impose a oneyear tax increase on corporations and on most individuals above bare middleincome levels and provide two permanent programs of tax relief for business.

title: Dave Anderson
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 8In the fourth inning Bobby Grich poked a single to center field. In the seventh Don Baylor sliced a single to right. Those were the only hits for the Baltimore Orioles against Vida Blue today as the Oakland A's won, 10, on Sal Bando's home run for a 21 advantage in their American League championship series. For almost any other pitcher it would have been a game. for smiles and laughs. But for Vida Blue there was no joy. Whatever fun exists in baseball on a major league level deserted him in 1972 during his bitter salary dispute with Charles O. Finley, the A's stubborn owner. The fun hasn't returned. Maybe it never will. As a rookie he had thrived on success. But today he treated success indifferently as if it were a stranger intruding on his privacy. Still in his green and gold uniform, he dissected his performance for newsmen as clinically as a surgeon might discuss an operation.

title: 5% Less Driving, ColdWater Laundry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8President Ford called on the American people today to adopt a variety of voluntary energysaving measures, including driving 5 per cent less and washing the laundry in cold water.

title: Hepatitis Hospitalizes 78 At San Diego Naval Base
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 9 (AP)An epidemic of infectious hepatitis left 78 sailors hospitalized today, but a spokesman at the Naval Training Center said the cases of the liver disease virus were mild.

title: Advance Is Best in 17 MonthsDow Up 28.39
description: Investors' hopes that President Ford's new economic pro. gram might curb inflation enabled the stock market yesterday to post its biggest gain in almost 17 months in heavy trading.

title: 2 CHOREOGRAPHERS IN 4 LIKABLE DANCES
description: The modest program at the Cubiculo on Tuesday evening by Barbara Berger and Betty Salamun had a likable ingenuity if not a powerful creative surge. It was nicely conceived and well danced.

title: Rapist, 15, Gets 30 Years Despite Plea by the Victim
description: MIAMI, Oct. 9 (AP)A 15yearold convicted rapist has been sentenced to 30 years in prison despite a leniency plea from his victim.

title: Allied Chemical Raises Earnings 111%
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation reported yesterday an earnings increase of 111 per cent for the third quarter and a 46 per cent increase in sales. The sharp gain lifted ninemonth earnings above those for any previous full year.

title: To Israel and Back
description: The firsttime visitor arrives in Israel troubled by deep and conflicting emotions. I had come as a seeker after truth, intending to ferret out the determining realities from the multifaced myths and the conscious propaganda that smother them.

title: 22 Food Outlets Cited as Violators Of City Health Code
AlbanytoNew York Route Will Get 6th Daily Train
description: ALBANY, Oct. 9 (AP)The state will subsidize a sixth daily train between Albany and New York City, the Governor's office announced today.

title: Record Pact Reported
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 9 (UPI) Johnny Rodgers signed a new longterm pact with the Montreal Alouettes today that reportedly made him the highest paid player in the Canadian Football League. The former Nebraska star was said to have agreed to more than $1million over seven years.

title: The Best And Richest
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  Suppose President Johnson had made personal loans totaling $550,000 to an associate in public life, then appointed him chairman of a Federal regulatory agency and written off the loans. When the facts became known, would leading Senators and other weighty voices have said that there was nothing wrong in the arrangementthat it was just a way to keep a man of modest means in the public service?

title: The Election at a Glance
description: Forty million Britons are eligible to vote today for 2,192 candidates running for the 635 seats in the House of Commons. Labor and Conservative candidates are running every constituency in England, Scotland and Wales. Northern Ireland the Ulster Unionists (no longer so identifiable with the Conservatives as they used to be) will have Social Democratic and Labor party candidates as their main opponents. The Social Democratic and Lator party independent of the British Labor party.

title: Lotteries in 13 States Aided In Bill Voted by House Panel,
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) A House judiciary subcommittee approved today legislatioi designed to save 13 states from the threat of a Federal lawsuit challenging the legality of their fuidraising lotteries.

title: SOVIET GAIN SEEN ON A MOBILE ICBM
description: The Soviet Union, according to wellplaced sources in Washington, has developed a mobile intercontinental ballistic missile and has built 151 new silos for emplaced ICBM's.

title: Hyland to Hold Hearings On Sales of Propane Gas
description: TRENTON, Oct. 9 (UPI)The State Attorney General said today public hearings would be scheduled to investigate alleged irregularities in the marketing of liquefied propane gas.

title: Yonkers Car Dealer Indicted on Charge Of Odometer Fraud
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 9One of Westchester County's largest automobile dealers, Parkview Lincoln Mercury, Inc., in Yonkers, has been indicted on charges of victimizing 29 customers by changing odometer readings.

title: Nixon Property Tax Up
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 9 (UPI)The Orange County tax collector has increased the valuation of former President Richard M. Nixon's oceanfront estate at San Clemente from $1.37million to $1.53million. Robert Citron, the collector, said that brought the property tax to $37,300.

title: Town Is Losing Water
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., (UPI)This town has discovered it has a major leak problem. A report to city Council indicated that pearly half the water the city buys from the Greenbrier resort hotel leaks out of the municipal water lines.

title: Mrs. Hibbs's 77 Leads Senior Golf
description: POINT CLEAR, Ala., Oct. 9 (AP)The defending champion, Gwenn Hibbs of Long Beach, Calif., shot a 77 today and shared the firstround lead in the annual women's senior amateur golf championship.

title: Columbia to Recall '34 Glory
description: Columbia has had so few big moments in its football history that Lion alumni are easily distinguished at a sports smoker as the ones over in the corner discussing inflation and the bestseller list. But there were past highlights, such as Bill Swiacki's catch against Army in 1947.

title: Cambodian Bids U.N. Not to Oust Lon Not Regime
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9Premier Long Boret of Cambodia told the General Assembly today that it would be playing with fire to expel the present Government of Marshal Lon Nol and seat instead the Chinesebacked governmentinexile of Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: Brezhnev Reported to Seek Asian Meeting With Ford
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, was reported today by reliable sources to be pressing for a meeting with President Ford this fall, during Mr. Ford's visit to Asia.

title: Ekblom: LowKey Chief Of EuropeanAmerican
description: Harry E. Ekblom, chairman, president and chief executive officer of the EuropeanAmerican Bank and Trust Company is wasting no time in getting acquainted first hand with the bank's newly acquired personnel and properties.

title: Mrs. Roosevelt Memorial To Be Held at Hunter
description: The 90th anniversary of the birth of Eleanor Roosevelt will be observed today at 8 P.M. at the Hunter College auditorium, Park Avenue at 69th Street.

title: Byrne Seeks to Learn If Ronan's Port Role May Be Affected
description: Governor Byrne of New Jersey said yesterday that he would watch closely for additional details of the $550,00C gift from Nelson A. Rockefeller to Dr. William J. Ronan, his longtime aide who is now chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: PORTUGUESE BAR ANGOLA PARTITION
description: LUANDA, Angola, Oct. 9A spokesman for the Portuguese armed forces here, commenting on the fears of some that Angola might be partitioned on obtaining independence, has declared that Portugal would never accept such a development.

title: Voters in Rural New England Apathetic and Cynical
description: CANTERBURY, N.H.One day last week, the little bell tinkled over the door to Carl Peterson's grocery here and Dr. Hampton Moody walked in limping.

title: Rising Costs Imperil Harkness Ballet
description: The Harkness Ballet will disband in April unless it raises $1million by March 31. Citing severe stockmarket losses by Mrs. Rebekah Harkness, the troupe's sole patron, company spokesmen announced yesterday that the funds would be sought immediately from Government agencies and private sources.

title: CUBA IS RELEASING FOUR U.S. CITIZENS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Cuban Government notified Senators Claiborne Pell and Jacob K. Javits today that it was releasing four United States citizens from prison as a gesture of goodwill to the two legislators.

title: LEFKOWITZ VOWS WIDE MILK INQUIRY
description: ALBANY, Oct. 9Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today that an imminent grand jury inquiry on any criminal aspects of the adulteration of milk by the Dairylea Cooperative would also consider how officials of the State Agriculture and Markets Department conducted the civil investigation into the Dairylea case.

title: Senate, Faced Witha Veto, Avoids Turkey Aid Cutoff
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Senate voted today to cut off military aid to Turkey, thus defying threats of a Presidential veto. But several hours later, in an effort to avoid a veto, the Senate voted to allow the President to delay the cutoff.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Charges were dismissed in Buffalo yesterday in the first case to go to trial as a result of the 1971 riot at Attica State Prison. Justice Frank R. Bayger dismissed two charges of sodomy and two charges of sexual abuse in State Supreme Court, freeing Willie E. Smith, who had been accused of attacking another prisoner during the riot.

title: Advertising
description: It may be but a flyspeck on the big picture so far, but a number of public relations firms are increasingly creating and placing advertising. And, if not that, they are at least writing it or giving advice on the content.

title: Chicago Official Found Guilty Of Mail Fraud and Conspiracy
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9Alderman Thomas E. Keane, second in Power to Mayor Richard J. Daley in Chicago's government, was fond guilty today by a Federal District Court jury of mail fraud and conspiracy.

title: Notes on People NeWborn Baltimore Quintuplets Get Names
description: Michelle Lynn, Sandra Elizabeth, Belinda Ann, Jennifer Louise and Russell Charles Rohrer are the names of the quintuplets born to a Baltimore couple Tuesday. They received their names yesterday, along with an optimistic health report.

title: NEW LOFTS TO AID GARMENT CENTER
description: Mayor Beame announced a proposal yesterday that could lead to the creation of Garment Center West, a galaxy of new, efficient loft buildings and truck terminals west of Eighth Avenue, to revive the city's sagging apparel industry.

title: Buying Interest Abroad Lifts Wheat Futures
description: Although the Soviet Union appeared to have moved out of the wheat market in the United States after the cancellation of big contracts at Washington's request, a number of other nations were unusually active yesterday.

title: Passaic Told to Turn Over Secret Data in Carter Case
description: Lawyers appealing the triplemurder conviction of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter won a legal victory yesterday when a New Jersey judge ordered the Passaic County prosecutor to turn over to the defense previously secret police records.

title: Violence is Deplored
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9President Ford said today that he disagreed with the school desegregation order of a Federal judge in Boston, but stressed his concern over the racial violence there and called on Boston citizens to respect the law.

title: Niels H. Larsen Is Dead; Boston Architect Was 89
description: Niels H. Larsen, formerly a wellknown Boston architect, died Tuesday at the Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 89 years old and lived at 22 Sagamore Road, Bronxville, N.Y.

title: British Election Campaign Ends With Labor Ahead
description: LONDON, Oct. 9The British election campaign came to a close tonight, with the governing Labor party holding a clear lead in the polls but with many voters professing to be undecided.

title: Bridge: Book by a Columnist Shows Brilliancies and Blunders
description: To insure that their deathless prose is not lost to posterity, most bridge columnists succumb, sooner or later, to the temptation to publish a book of columns.

title: PRESEASON BASKETBALL
description: New York (ABA) 102, St. Louis (ABA) 88. Buffalo (NBA) 119, New York (NBA) 83. Kentucky (ABA) 109, Detroit (NBA) 100. Los Angeles (NBA) 116, Phoenix (NBA) 113 (OT).

title: City Officials Seek Federal Aid To Bolster Building Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Top New York City officials told President Ford's economic advisers today tha the city's construction industry was in a devastated condition and they urged Federal assistance.

title: Books of The Times
description: LOOK AT THE HARLEQUINS! By Vladimir Nabokov. 253 pages. McGrawHill. $7.95.

title: Vermont G.O.P. Gains
description: SHELBURNE, Vt., Oct. 9 (AP)The Vermont Republican party collected about $90,000 Monday night at its testimonial fundraising dinner at which President Ford spoke. The dinner chairman, State Representative Richard Snelling of Shelburne, said that after expenses were paid the party would have about $63,000 more in its general election campaign fund.

title: Chad's Hungriest See Little of Food Given by World
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, Oct. 6  At a cost of more than $1million, the United States is airlifting 2,000 tons of sorghum to Chad. Half is being flown to a remote desert region that has suffered only marginally from the great African drought and has little immediate need of relief.

title: Pirates Routed, 121, as Garvey Smashes 2
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9No sooner had the Oakland A's recorded the final out in Baltimore to clinch the American League playoff than Steve Garvey hit his second tworun homer of the game against Pittsburgh here and locked up the National Leagut playoff for the Dodgers. Thus, baseball will have its first allCalifornia World Series. It opens Saturday afternoon here.

title: WARRANT SEEKS SINDONA ARREST
description: ROME, Oct. 9A Milan magistrate has issued a warren?? for the arrest of Michele Sindona, the Sicilianborn ?? who pyramided pittances into an international banking empire.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)  The Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments on the constitutionality the Regional Rail Reorganization Act passed last year by Congress.

title: Taxi Unit Said to Study 15% Fare Rise
description: The city's Taxi and Limousine commission was reported yesterday to be considering a tentative staff proposal for a 15 per cent increase in taxi fares, according to industry sources.

title: ACTION BY TURKEY ON POPPY LAUDED
description: GENEVA, Oct. 9United Nations officials involved in the fight against the illicit drug trade have expressed satisfaction with the new method of processing opium poppies that Turkey has decided to impose on her farmers.

title: '74 Dodgers A Youthful, Proud Team
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9I'm so proud of this young team, a beaming Manager Walt Alston said today. We've won pennants before and been in the World Series, but not with a team as young as this one all the way down the line. They had the lead, but they had to hold it and they did a great job.

title: Growth Here Seen By European Bank
description: The EuropeanAmerican Bank and Trust Company, the bank that took over much of the insolvent Franklin National Bank Tuesday afternoon, said yesterday it planned to remain in New York City and probably expand.

title: Myrdal and von Hayek Share a Nobel
description: The 1974 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science was awarded yesterday to Dr. Gunnar Myrdal and Dr. Friedrich A. von Hayektwo 75yearold social economists who have won international recognition for differing views.

title: Greece Ends Martial Law After New Cabinet Is Sworn
description: ATHENS, Oct. 9 (UPI)The Government today lifted martial law throughout Greece, except for areas along the GreekTurkish border and five islands in the Aegean off the coast of Turkey.

title: SCHOOLS DAMAGED IN BOOKS PROTEST
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 9 One school was dynamited before dawn today, a second was damaged by fire and a third's windows were smashed as a protest continued by Fundamentalist parents over what they calld antiChrist, dirty and Godless textbooks in Kanawha County's public schools. There were no injuries.

title: Rockefeller at Hearing: A Partial Picture
description: WASHINGTONOnly a partial picture of Nelson A. Rockefeller's 15 years as Governor of New York State has emerged in the Senate Rules Committee hearings on Mr. Rockefeller's nomination for Vice President. The more persistent inquiries made of the former Governor during his two and a half days of testimony last month focused on his vast wealth, on possible conflicts of interest if he were confirmed as Vice President, on his views about the doctrine of executive privilege, and on other areas with national and international, rather than state or local overtones.

title: Westar Launching Delayod
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fia., Oct. 9 (AP)The launching of Westar II, scheduled for today, has been postponed for at least 24 hours because of a possible problem in the communications satellite's Delta rocket.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: ARTS COUNCIL SAID TO LAG IN FUNDING
description: An official of the state's Division of the Budget says that the New York State Councilon the Arts has failed to come up with a satisfactory plan for allocation of $21.8million so far appropriated to the arts council. The inaction, he said, has resulted in delays in funding councilsupported arts organizations throughout the state.

title: CUBA RELEASING 4 U.S. CITIZENS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 9The Cuban Government notified Senators Claiborne Pell and Jacob K. Javits today that it was releasing four United States citizens from prison as a gesture of goodwill to the two legislators.

title: ABC Cancels Two Series And Shifts Some Programs
description: ABCTV has canceled two of the Friday night series it introduced in September, The Texas Wheelers and Kodiak, and has shifted programs in the Friday and Saturday night schedules in an effort to improve its ratings. The network has been running a poor third since the start of the season, with particular problems on those two nights.

title: Dahlia Here in Fine Fettle
Essex H.S. Denies Any Wide Marijuana Use
description: NORTH CALDWELL, Oct. 9Students and school administrators at the West Essex Regional High School today bitterly denounced an allegation by the Essex County Sheriff that the school had a serious problem of marijuana use.

title: Alternatives Seen to NursingHomes for Aged Infirm
description: How should our society care for the aged infirm? Social workers and other specialists asked this by The New York Times over the last two months say that old people are generally better off in philanthropic nursing homes than in proprietary ones, but they are best off in their own homes. That is also by far the cheapest solution to the taxpayer.

title: Lawrence L. Shenfield, 83; Philatelist and Ad Executive
description: Lawrence L. Shenfield, a philatelist and an advertising executive for 30 years, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: Roving Nixon
description: Julie Nixon Eisenhower would like to see her father serve the nation as a roving ambassador. If he is well enough to rove, the place to start will be a trip Washington to testify in the Watergate coverup trial. His gift for communicating, as his daughter describes it, can most usefully be applied there.

title: Will Energy Plan Work? Recent Study of Family Attitudes Hints at Rough Going
description: How seriously will Americans take President Ford's request to pitch in and help abate the energy shortage? Will they heed his pleas to reduce the use of their automobiles and appliances? Will they cut hack on heat and air conditioning? Will they install insulation and storm windows it their homes?

title: Study Says Developing Nations Must Get Extensive Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9A planned world economy whose sectors would be assigned complementary roles was proposed today in an international study as the most effective way to avert a breakdown in global stability.

title: Orioles Yield 11 Walks, One Hit in 21 Defeat
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 9The Oakland A's managed only one hit today, but stilll won their third straight pennant when they defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 21, for their third straight victory in the American League playoff.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Mondale's '76 Presidential Campaign Gets Lift From Kennedy Withdrawal
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 9 Things are different in the nascent Presidential campaign of Senator Walter F. Mondale, Minnesota Democrat, since Senator Edward M. Kennedy announced his unavailability.

title: IRAQ ASKS REVIEW OF ISRAEL BY U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9The Foreign Minister of Iraq called on the United Nations today to reconsider its position concerning the membership of the fascist, racist regime now established in the land of Palestine. he meant Israel.

title: Holiday Mail Schedule On Oct. 14 and Oct. 2
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (A?? The United States Post ?? Service has announced th?? regular And business mail d?? liveries will be suspended f?? the Columbus Day (Oct. 1?? and Veterans Day (Oct. 2?? holidays.

title: ASSEMBLY'S LEADER URGES CRIME CURBS
description: John E. Kingston majority, leader of the State Assembly, charged yesterday that plea bargaining and illegal sentences have dangerously undermined the criminal justice system in the state.

title: Sharing the Burden
description: President Ford was notably unresponsive in his replies to two questions at his news conference yesterday as to why he was seeking a corporate and personal income surtax when many if not most economists agree that the country is not suffering primarily from a demandpush inflation. He was similarly vague as to why he describes inflation in apocalyptic language but shies away from gasoline rationing or a stiff tax on gasoline or petroleum imports.

title: Griffith Outpoints Briscoe
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 (UPI)Emile Griffith, a former world champion, captured the North American middleweight boxing crown tonight by scoring a 10round decision over Bennie Briscoe, the defender, of Philadelphia. The referee, Pete Tomasco, scored it 4541 for Griffith and Judge Lou Tress had it 4843 for the winner. Judge Earl Vann scored it a draw, 4545.

title: Wall Streeters Say Recession Is Possible
description: Many Wall Street professionals expressed skepticism yesterday about the President's economic proposals. Some asserted his program would have only a moderate impact on corporate profitability and securities prites.

title: Transit Bill Backed By President Stalls In Rules Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The House Rules Committee declined today to send an $11.8billion mass transit bill to the house floor in a move that took supporters of the legislation by surprise.

title: Fallopian Tube Transplant Is Reported in Germany
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 9 (Reuters)A 31yearold West German woman was reported doing well today after undergoing what is believed to be the world's first fallopian tube transplant to enable her to have more children.

title: Freedom. Now for the Next Joke.
description: DETROIT  Life's unpredictable. When you think you've just about got it made, something comes along and shatters the crystal.

title: AMEX REGISTERS SHARP PRICE RISES
description: Encouraged by President Ford's plans for meeting inflation, traders on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market sent prices sharply higher yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Total of Reported Rapes Rose 13% in 7 Months
description: The number of rapes reported to the police in the city in the first seven months of this year was 13 per cent higher than in the same period a year ago, Lieut. Mary Keefe, commanding officer of the Sex Crimes Analysis Unit, reported yesterday.

title: Despite Success, AllNews Radio Admits Editing Faults
description: The sin of dead air is almost never committed on WCBS Newsradio's morning shift. Lou Adler's voice comes up the instant Jim Donnelly's goes out, as the dual anchormen alternate sentences in their breathless dispensing of messages for the weekday working force.

title: Youth and a Boy Arrested In Coop City Racial Clash
description: A 19yearold youth was arrested on a charge of assault and resisting arrest and a 13yearold boy was accused of juvenile delinquency for possession of an air rifle in what the polic said was an altercation between black and white youths at Coop City in the Bronx last evening.

title: A HEALTH EFFORT GIVEN EMPHASIS
description: A monthlong effort begun last week to decrease infectiousdisease immunization among preschool children is seeking to ward off what public health officials fear may he epidemics of polio, measles or diphtheria, potentially crippling, killing diseases that are preventable.

title: Football Team at Tay side Is Broke
description: Bayside, the defending Public Schools Athletic League champion, has a 15game winning streak, the best in the city. The Commodores, however, have been having more trouble behind the scenes than on the field. We get no cooperation in funding from the school, complained Coach Neal Nelson. We get no recognition, not even major letters or an assembly in school to acknowledge our team. It's not only us, it's the swimming team, too. They were also city chainpions last season.

title: Personal Finance
description: There's an old saying that insurance is never boughtit is sold. But these days, when doubledigit inflation has seemingly become the norm rather than the exception, perhaps the best salesman for property insurance is the knowledge that replacement costs are likely to be substantially higher than existing coverage.

title: Screen: Passer's 'Law and Disorder':Farce Slides Between Humor and Despair The Cast O'Conner Is a Cabbie Borgnine a Coffeur
description: Ivan Passer's "Law and Disorder" is a gentle, touching, sometimes disruptively funny movie aboutamong other things  ignorance, prejudice, rape, larceny, the failure of small dreams, about people trying desperately to cope and often coming apart.It stars Carroll O'Connor as a taxicab driver and Ernest Borgnine as an ex-Marine, who is a hairdresser with a passion for guns. They are the nucleus of a small group of outraged tenants of a housing project called Co-op Village, set on the Lower East Side of a New York City that bears some superficial resemblance to the setting of the inexecrable "Death Wish.""Law and Disorder," which opened yesterday at the Coronet and Little Carnegie theaters, is the second American film by Mr. Passer (his first was "Born to Win") whose "Intimate Lighting" is regarded as one of the major achievements of the brief, mysterious renaissance of Czechoslovak films in the nineteen-sixties.His new film is a poet's appreciation of lives lived on the edge of the precipice by people whose finger-holds are giving out.Willie (Mr. O'Connor) and Cy (Mr. Borgnine) and their friends are threatened as much by the onset of barren middle age as they are by the collapse of civil order. Thus, when they form a police auxiliary unit to protect their neighborhood, they are as invigorated by the opportunity to wear uniforms as they are by the opportunity to bring peace to the community.Perhaps more so. The uniforms define purpose. They recall a more innocent time, say World War II, when there was never any question as to who was right and who was wrong.The ultimate failure of Willie, Cy and the others is less a comment on their inadequacies, often hilariously detailed, than on the overwhelming complexity of the urban problems they face. It's this awareness on the part of Mr. Passer, as well as on the part of William Richert and Kenneth Harris Fishman, who collaborated with the director on the script, that separates "Law and Disorder" from exploitation junk like "Death Wish."It also dictates the mood of a film that slides between farce and melodrama, between high good humor and enervating despair. Some of Mr. Passer's characters, like Willie, continue to try to improve things. Willie dreams of a new career. He wants to sell his taxi medallion and buy a lunch counter, much to his wife's horror. Says Willie in desperation: "I ain't a failure, Sally, I just ain't on time."Cy, the hairdresser, is a hunter. He keeps an entire stuffed deer in the bedroom and has a piranha fish in a tank in the living room. He doesn't hunt people, however, and he hasn't quite arrived at the point occupied by most of the other citizens of the city whose motto, repeatedly expressed, is an obscene two-word imperative.The film is not perfect but I couldn't care less. A number of characters are as dimly seen as faces across a subway car. The sense of alienation that grips the city at times seizes the film itself, though almost always in fascinating ways. A film of less consistent intelligence would probably be destroyed by a scene so pricelessly funny it's almost a specialty number, when the auxiliary policemen and their wives attend a lecture on rape by "the author of the best-selling book, 'Sexual Deviations of the Seventies.'""Law and Disorder" is full of eccentric things, one of the most marvelous being Karen Black, who plays a lasciviously lunatic beautician who simply can't keep her tongue in place. Mr. O'Connor reins in his familiar Archie Bunker personality to give a fine, controlled performance as the stalwart Willie, while Mr. Borgnine is inspired casting as the unhappy hairdresser."Law and Disorder" has none of the vicarious thrills of "Death Wish." It's thoughtful about people, even vicious hoods. It's also very, very funny.

title: DR. A. I. ROSENSTEIN
description: Dr. Abraham I. Rosenstein, who had been on the staffs of Morrisania, Mount Sinai and FlowerFifth Avenue Hospitals, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 18 East 77th Street. He was 71 years old.

title: Alleghany Concern Reconsiders a Bid For MSL Industries
description: The Alleghany Corporation said yesterday that it was reconsidering its offer to purchase all the shares of MSL Industries, Inc., at $50 a share.

title: Baseball Playoffs
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: HOUSE REFORMERS TO TRY NEXT TERM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Backers of a reorganization of the House of Representatives said today that they would renew their efforts in the next Congress despite their defeat last night when the House voted to keep the committee structure largely as it is now.

title: Some Benefits for Utilities Are Seen
description: The nation's costpinched electrical power utilities should benefit from President Ford's antiinflationary proposals, an. alysts said yesterday, but many are unlikely to be able to switch their fuel from oil to coal and uranium by 1980, as the President proposed.

title: Portugal's Navy Selects Leftist to Sit on Junta
description: LISBON, Oct. 9 (Reuters)Officers of the Portuguese Navy have chosen a leftist commander as their representative on the ruling sevenman military junta.

title: FED IS CONTINUING EASIER POLICIES
description: The Federal Reserve acted yesterday to continue maintaining monetary policy in its somewhat easier stance.

title: 2to1 Opposition Found In Sampling on a Surtax
description: Americans interviewed in a dozen communities, large and small, across the country yesterday expressed opposition, by a margin of two to one, to Presdent Ford's proposed antiinflation income surtax.

title: Music: A MiniFestival Around Ives
description: A surprisingly small audience was on hand for the opening of the MiniFestival Around Ives on Tuesday evening in Avery Fisher Hall. This is the festival, ending Saturday, sponsored by the New York Philharmonic in collaboration with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. It is built around the great American iconoclast, but in reality is just as much a festival of early 20thcentury music in general.

title: Theater
description: The Casts

title: NEW LOFTS TO AID GARMENT CENTER
description: Mayor Beame announced a proposal yesterday that could lead to the creation of Garment Center West, a galaxy of new, efficient loft buildings and truck terminals west of Eighth Avenue, to revive the city's sagging apparel industry.

title: William R. Biggs Is Dead at 73; Retired Banker and Economist
description: William R. Biggs, a retired banker and economist and member of the inner circle of friends and advisers to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey when the Minnesota Democrat was his party's nominee for President in 1968, died suddenly yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Charles Rapp, 71, Dies; Broadway Talent Agent
description: Charles Rapp, the Broadway booking agent who started many a big name in show business from the Catskills on the way to Hollywood and television, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 19 West 55th Street.

title: Harry Carney Dead Here at 64; Was Saxophonist With Ellington
description: Harry Howell Carney, a jazz musician and a lohgtime associate of Duke Ellington, died Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital, Second Avenue and 18th Street. He was 64 years old and lived nearby.

title: Greece's Election Test
description: In the face of severe trials, including humiliation on Cyprus, the Greek people have been exhibiting a remarkable degree of national unity and maturity while working their way out of the wreckage left by seven, years military dictatorship. Now those qualities of unity and maturity will he subjected to another exacting test: the first free elections for more than a decade.

title: HELEN SCHNABEL, 63; CONCERTPIANIST DIES
description: Helen Schnabel, the pianist, daughterinlaw and student of Artur Schnabel, died of cancer on Sept. 29 in a hospital at Gravedona, Italy. She was 63 years old and lived with her husband, Karl Ulrich Schnabel, at Lake Como.

title: Byrne Seeks to Learn if Ronan's Port Role May Be Affected
description: Governor Byrne of New Jersey said yesterday that he would watch closely for additional details of the $550,000 gift from Nelson A. Rockefeller to Dr. William J. Ronan, his longtime aide who is now chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Rockefeller's Largesse
description: The openhandedness with which Nelson A. Rockefeller has distributed money to political allies and former associates now in positions of high public trust raises some troublesome questions.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TORONTO, Oct. 9 (UPI)Team Canada arrived home from its European exhibition hockey tour today to a subdued welcome that rankled at least one member of the World Hockey Association allstar squad. Only about 200 persons greeted them on arrival at Toronto airport in contrast to the tens of thousands who welcomed Team Canada in 1972 after they defeated the Soviet Union in an eightgame series. The 1974 team won 1 game, tied three and lost four to the Soviet.

title: House Tax Panel Greets Ford Plan With Restraint
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The House Ways and Means Committee gave a mildmannered reception today to President Rord's proposed tax program. Criticism from Democratic members was less unanimous and less truculent than had been expected, but support from Republican members was also muted.

title: Nixon Fund Bill Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today an $8billion supplemental appropriation bill including $200,000 for former President Nixon's transition to private life. The committee decided last week to limit th Nixon fund to $200,000, although President Ford had asked $850,000 for the purpose.

title: World Football League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: 3 Major N.Y. Banks Report Higher Net
description: Three major New York banking concerns reported sharply higher thirdquarter earnings. The reports of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, J. P. Morgan & Co., Inc., and the Charter New York Corporation showed, however, that profit margins had declined in the first nine months, while the rate of return on stockholders' equity was higher.

title: Quick U.S. Inquiry Is Requested Into FireBombing in Glen Ridge
description: NEWARK, Oct. 9United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein said today that he had asked the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to conduct an immediate investigation into the firebombing of the home of a local Democratic official in Glen Ridge early Friday.

title: Marceau in Dual Roles in 'Shanks':The Cast
description: If Marcel Marceau, the greatest of mimes, and William Castle, the prolific producer of such spellbinding horrors as "Rosemary's Baby" and "The House on Haunted Hill," are an obviously off-beat team, "Shanks," their first joint effort, which opened yesterday at the Beekman, makes a decidedly strange combination of their talents. They and their company are as unusual as might be expected but they leave a viewer uncommitted, if not confused, by their largely far-out, somber fiction.The script by Ranald Graham, a young newcomer to films, is described as "a grim fairy tale," and it is just that. It involves Mr. Marceau in the dual roles of a mute puppeteer and as his employer, an odd, aged inventor, Old Walker, of gadgets, who can revive the dead. These improbable, but handy, tools enable him to animate Old Walker, his wicked sister-in-law and her drunken husband and a young girl who adores him, after they have died, to successfully fight the forces of evil represented by a gang of wild motorcyclists.Mr. Marceau, who has been seen in several films including "Barbarella," does not achieve the remarkable illusions he has created on stage. But his silent performances as the wistful, badgered Shanks and the wonderfully made-up senile Old Walker are, nevertheless, strikingly charming pantomimes on screen.He is ably abetted by Tsilla Chelton and Philippe Clay, French mime artists who are making their movie debuts here as the relatives with as much dedication as Mr. Marceau, and Cindy Eilbacher, a newcomer from TV, as the wide-eyed youngster in love with the puppeteer's magic.But the magic here is diffused. The succession of grim, cute or gimmicky approaches to this "fairy story" make it an extraordinary but only intermittently edifying fable.

title: Pickets Charge Agency Failed To Deliver Jobs They Paid For
description: About a dozen persons who said they had paid hundreds of dollars as fees for overseas jobs they had never received picketed yesterday at the offices of Gateway Overseas, Inc., at 1501 Broadway, near 43d Street.

title: Celtics Lose Cowens for 2 Months
description: The Boston Celtics, who have lived in pro basketball's world of outstanding centers since the coming of Bill Russell in 1956, will learn during the next two months what it is to play with a journeyman big man in the middle.

title: Alexander C. Herman, 77, Dies; ExOfficer of National Container
description: Alexander C. Herman, retired vice president of the National Container Corporation and former newspaperman, died Tuesday of h heart ailment at his home, 22 East 8th Street, He was 77 years old.

title: Last 2,500 Draftees to Get Releases by Thanksgiving
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) The Army announced today that it would discharge its last 2,500 draftees before Thanksgiving.

title: HAROLD A. TAYLOR
description: Harold A. Taylor, a retired executive of the Concrete Steels Company of Chicago and New York, died yesterday of cancer, at his home, 135 Dellwood Road, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: State Aids Mayor
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9  Three hundred state police, 100 Metropolitan District Commission police and their supervisory personnel will be placed under the command of Police Commissioner Robert J. diGrazia at 6 A.M. tomorrow, the Mayor's office said tonight.

title: India Is Told She Faces Ouster From Davis Cup
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Oct. 9 (AP)Basil Reay, secretary of the Davis Cup Nations Committee, warned India today that she risked expulsion from cup competition if she did not play South Africa in the 1974 final.

title: Europe Finds Ford Program Modest But Promising
description: PARIS, Oct, 9Many Europeans today saw President Ford's economic program as too modest an effort to make much of an impact in the immediate future, but they added that the eventual overall effects should be positive.

title: Canadiens Tie Islander's With 2 Late Goals, 55
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 9Some brazen fans Yelled, You stink, Ken Dryden, but for the most part it was a warm welcome back for Dryden from 16,491 fans in the Forum tonight as the Montreal Canadiens salvaged a 5.5 tie with the New York Islanders.

title: Passaic Told to Turn Over Secret Data in Carter Case
description: Lawyers appealing the triplemurder conviction of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter won a legal victory yesterday when a New Jersey judge ordered the Passaic County prosecutor to turn over to the defense previously secret police records.

title: State Moves to Protect Rare Wild Flowers
description: ALBANY, Oct. 9In a few weeks, it will be illegal to pick pleurisyroots, wahoos, adder'stongues, scarlet beebalms, stinking benjamins, fairy slippers and about 200 other wild flowers in New York State.

title: State High Court Upholds A Harlem Six Conviction
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the conviction of Robert Rice, one of the Harlem Six, who were accused of having killed a Harlem shopkeeper in 1964.

title: Mills in Seclusion After Report He Was Intoxicated in Car Stopped by Police
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, was in seclusion today following reports that, intoxicated and bleeding from the a face he was a passenger in speeding car that was stopped by the police here early Monday morning.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
Two Bodies Found In Basement Grave Of Brooklyn Club
description: Special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and investigators of the Brooklyn District Attorney's office uncovered two bodies yesterday afternoon buried tin shallow graves in social club in Brooklyn.

title: Unretiring Economists Whose Energy Defies Age
description: By most American standards, Dr. Gunnar Myrdal is in the autumn of years, when retirement from the demands of daytoday work becomes a matter of growing personal concern. But the 75yearold author, who was yesterday named to share the 1974 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, has no such thoughts, and in fact is laying the groundwork, along with the psychologist Dr. Kenneth Clark, for another major study of the Negro in America. That subject won Dr. Myrdal international recognition in 1944 with the publication of An American Dilemmathe Negro Problem and Modern Democracy.

title: STRIKERS ABOARD, FRANCE IN LE HAVRE
description: PARIS, Oct. 9  The liner France steamed to her home port of Le Havre today after almost a month in the English Channel with only a striking crew aboard and its future still undecided.

title: Ford Asserts He Sees Nothing Improper in ExGovernor's Acts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller's expected replies to questions about his financial gifts will be made public by the Senate Rules Committee, its chairman said today amid growing indications that Mr. Rockefeller's confirmation, once apparently assured, was likely to become increasingly controversial.

title: Senate, Faced With a Veto, Avoids Turkey Aid Cutoff
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Senate voted today to cut off military aid to Turkey, then few hours later bowed to threats of a Presidential veto and voted to delay the cutoff.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 49

title: Inviting Places to Live
description: AUGUSTA, Me. (UPI)  If Maine place names can be trusted, it's a nice place to live. There are towns named Haven, Harmony, Hope, Friendship, Unity and Liberty.

title: What Recession?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9I do not think the United States is in a recession, said President Ford stoutly this afternoon, looking at a half year of declining real growth through rosegardencolored glasses.

title: Ad Spending Law Voided
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 9 (UPI)A law requiring newspapers to report how much political candidates spend on advertising was declared unconstitutional yesterday by District Court Judge Joe Pavlikowski.
