title: Governor Urges Establishment Of Housing Development Agency
description: TRENTON, Oct. 9Warning that New Jersey faced a housing crisis that promised to get worse before it got better, Governor Byrne today urged the creation of a state development corporation to encourage urban redevelopment and housing construction in the state.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Education Commissioner, Fred G. Burke, proposed yesterday to eliminate the jobs of at least four county school superintendents by a state takeover of all 21 county superintendents' posts and by combining eight smaller, largely rural counties into four pairs, each to be headed by a deputy state education commissioner. Sussex and Warren Counties, under Dr. Burke's plan, would be combined into one regional office. The other pairings would be Atlantic and Cape May Counties; Salem and Cumberland, and Hunterdon and Somerset.

title: Law Teachers Urge Congress To Block Shift of Nixon Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Society of American Law Teachers has called on Congress to block the proposed transfer of White House tape recordings and documents to former President Richard Nixon on the ground that they legally belong to the people.

title: To British Family Inflation Is the Key Issue
description: LONDON, Oct. 9  The postman brought bad news the other day to the Victorian row house where Bernard and Stella Doogan live with their two young children in the suburban section of London called Hither Green.

title: Rangers Triumph Over Capitals, 63
description: For two periods of their first regularseason game of the season last night, the New York Rangers found themselves in a slump. Behind most of the first 40 minutes against the Washington Capitals, one of the two new teams in the National Hockey League, the Rangers outshot the expansion, team, 194, in the final period to win, 63.

title: Guides Near Completion On U.S. Exports of Grain
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Guidelines for export sales intended to assure an adequate but not excessive flow of grain from the United States to its traditional customers were nearing completion in closely gruarded conferences of high agricultural officials here to day.

title: Pollution Agency Accuses U.S. Steel Plant in Duluth
description: DULUTH, Minn., Oct 9 (AP) The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency today charged United States Steel with 11 counts of violating state air and water quality regulations at the company's cokemaking plant in Duluth.

title: Record Low Vote Next Month Seen In 2 Gallup Polls
description: A record low turnout in the November elections for Congress is Indicated, the Gallup Poll said yesterday.

title: People in Sports Aspromonte: I Tried My Best
description: In his first public statement since Frank Robinson replaced him as manager, Ken Aspromonte conceded yesterday he was disappointed, but added he would walk away with my head up high. Aspromonte had led the Cleveland Indians to a fourthplace finish before Robinson became the first black manager in major league baseball history.

title: 7 Hostages Are Freed in Santo Domingo
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 9 (UPI)Seven hostages held since Sept. 27 in the Venezuelan consulate here were freed tonight by their seven guerrilla captors, who went immediately to Las Americas airport and left by air for political asylum in Panama.

title: New Energy Research Agency Approved, 37 11 by the House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The House approved tonight by a vote of 371 to 1 a bill to create a new energy research agency and to replace, the Atomic Energy Commission with a new Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Big Board Seat Sale Rise
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday a seat sale at $80,000, up $5,000 from the last sale on Sept. 25. Seats now are quoted $75,000 bid and $90,000 offered.

title: Prof. Stephen P. Marion, Brooklyn College Chemist
description: Stephen P. Marion, an associate professor of chemistry at Brooklyn College, died Monday. He was 63 years old.

title: Brennan Meets Sharp Criticism as He Outlines Ford Jobless Plan to Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brenhan gave a joint Congressional hearing details today of President Ford's unemployment proposals, and they were immediately attacked as insufficient by legislators of both parties.

title: DR. EMIL A. HAVACH
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 9 (AP)Dr. Emil A. Havach, head) trainer of Lehigh University's athletic teams for 25 years, died today at a hospital here. He was 64 years old.

title: Mrs. Keating in Campaign Here Calls Midtown Slime Square
description: After a tour of the Times Square area yesterday, Mrs. Barbara Keating, the Conservative party candidate for United States Senator, declared that Times Square is now Slime Square.

title: Expansion Program Delayed
description: CHATTANOOGA, Oct. 9 (AP)  A $55million expansion program announced earlier this year by the Combustion Engineering Company has been delayed because customers have asked for later delivery of equipment ordered. A Combustion spokesman said yesterday, however, that a moderate expansion program at the Chattanooga plant would be pursued to handle an anticipated increase in orders.

title: Chess: 10th Game Is Adjourned Korchnoi Is a Pawn Ahead
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9Viktor Korchnoi, a pawn ahead, adjourned the 10th game of his final candidates match for the world championship with Anatoly Karpov after 41 moves here in Tchaikowsky Hall tonight.

title: Astor Library's 125th Year: First Show of Some Items
description: The Astor Library, one of the larger literary acorns from which the mighty oak of the New York Public Library has grown, is celebrating its 125th birthday, or one of them, and is marking the occasion with an exhibition that exceeds a booklover's fondest dreams.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1974

title: Filion Drives to 5,000th Victory
description: YONKERS, Oct. 9Herve Filion succeeded tonight in attaining the goal that had been eluding him these past few days. The 34yearold native of Angers, Quebec, drove the winner of the first race at the Yonkers Raceway tonight, and lifted his career victory total to 5,000. He is the first North American driver to score so many successes, and ranks third among the world's reinsmen.

title: A Nightclub Owner Says He Has Woesthe Mafia
ANTIINFLATION PLAN PUSHFSDOLLARDOWN
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 9 (UPI)The dollar declined today in all world money markets,. European bankers and currency dealers said the dollar dropped because President Ford's antiinflation measures were considered too weak.

title: In Soviet Interview, Tito Rebuts View on War Aid
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9The Soviet armed forces newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda published today an unusual interview with President Tito of Yugoslav in which he reminisced about aspects of World War II to remind Soviet leaders of Belgrade's independence from Moscow.

title: Police Unveil Speedy Fingerprint Identity System
description: An automated system of scanning fingerprints of suspects so quickly that officers will be able to identify a criminal in a few minutes was unveiled yesterday at Police Headquarters.

title: A Nightclub Owner Says He Has Woesthe Mafia
description: When Shamsher Wadud, a 29yearold native of Bangladesh, opened a $250,000 discothque last May on the East Side, he envisioned himself as the man who would introduce Bengali food, music and culture to New York's best society. The young entrepreneur already owned a luxurious penthouse restaurant on Central Park South and a boutique on East 58th Street.

title: 13 Senators Urge a Delay In Offshore Oil Lease Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) Thirteen Senators from coastal states introduced legislation today calling for a delay Government offshore oil and gas leasing plans.

title: Wilson Uses Bible in Defending Rockefeller Gifts
description: AMSTERDAM, Oct. 9Citing Biblical exhortations to forgive us our debtors, Governor Wilson todaydefended the $550,000 gift by former Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller to aide, Dr. William J. Ronan, as a gift to a friend out of love.

title: Cards Elect Two Officers
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 (UPI)The St. Louis Cardinals announced today the election of Margaret M. Snyder and Fred L. Kuhlmann as vice presidents of the baseball club. Both officers are currently vice presidents at AnheuserBusch, Inc., owner of the Cardinals.

title: Court Merges 6 Appeals In Wounded Knee Cases,
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit has consolidated six Government, appeals of acquittals of four persons arising from the Indian uprising last year at Wounded Knee, S.D.

title: 3 Detectives Convicted of Taking Bribe to Free Cigarette Smuggler
description: Chester Dorris, John McElhearn and Emmet Cusack, three suspended detectives from the Police Department's safe, loft and truck squad, were convicted late yesterday on all counts of an indictment charging bribery conspiracy. Their lawyers said they would probably appeal.

title: Mrs. Ford Reported To Seek a New Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Betty Ford is reportedly making plans to hire a new staff member, Nancy Lammerding. Some say she will be in charge of social functions at the White House while other informed sources understand that she will be a new director for Mrs. Ford's staff.

title: Sales of Savings Bond Set 3dQuarter Record
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) Sales of E and H Series Savings Bonds totalled $1.62billion in the third quarter, setting a record for the period, according to the Treasury Department. But the combined sales fell below the second quarter total of $1.81billion.

title: CUBAN REFUGEES APPEAR RESIGNED
description: MIAMI, Oct. 9Cuban refugees in the Miami area appear to have resigned themselves to what a few years ago most of them regarded as unthinkable: the resumption of United StatesCuban relations.

title: 14,000 LaidOff G.E. Workers Seeking Jobless Pay
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 8To people on indefinite layoff report to the rear table and leave your pencils on the table, the voice on a microphone echoed in the gym of the hall of Local 761 of the International Union of Electrical Workers.

title: Hearing Set in Coast Killing
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 9 (UPI)  A preliminary hearing was set for Oct. 28 for Deborah Joy Kantaeng, 19 years old, who was arraigned yesterday on a charge of killing a man she said had earlier abducted and raped her at knife point. Mrs. Kantaeng was released on $10,000 bail. She is accused of killing Danny Charles Allen, 21, who died after being struck by a bast from a 410gauge shotgun Thursday night at the young woman's home.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: People and Business
description: A prime rate between 8 per cent and 8 per cent is not beyond the realm of possibility by mid1975, Nicholas J. DeLeonardis, vice president of the First National Bank of Chicago, said yesterday addressing the Financial Analysts Federation in Detroit, he forecast general declines in shortterm interest rates by the middle of next year. He mentioned in particular 90day Treasury bill rates of 5 to 6 per cent in contrast to the present 7.3 per cent leveland suggested that 90day commercial paper could reach a level of 7 per cent to 8 per cent. At present this rate ranges between 9 per cent and 11 per cent.

title: Mrs. Ford's Doctor Pleased
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) Doctors at the Bethesda Naval Hospital said today they continued to be pleased with the recovery of Betty Ford from breast cancer surgery. Dr. William Fouty said that Mrs. Ford was very active and that her spirits and condition were excellent.

title: Textile Workers Reach Labor Accord in Paterson
description: The Textile Workers Union of America reported yesterday that it had reached contract agreements with five companies in the New YorkNew Jersey area. However, the union said the threeday strike of 8,000 workers was continuing at 145 dyeing and finishing plants in the midAtlantic region.

title: JEAN S. LOW
description: Jean S. Low, manager of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra since 1970, died yesterday in Hartford Hospital. She was 53 years old and lived in Hartford.

title: 5,000 CATHOLICS PROTEST IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 9 About 5,000 South Korean Roman Catholics demonstrated against President Park Chung Hee today in the largest antiGovernment outburst since Mr. Park declared martial law two years ago.

title: Comic Books Displaved as Serious Art
Ford and Gierek Sign 2 Pacts For Friendship and Commerce
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9President Ford and Edward Gierek, the Polish Communist party chief, signed two documents today expressing their determination to improve economic and political relations on a basis of friendship between Poland and the United States.

title: Stockton, Calif., Schools Ordered to Desegregate
description: STOCKTON, Calif., Oct. 9 (AP)A Supreme Court judge ruled, today that the Stockton Unified School District had arti. ficially separated the races and ordered it to desegregate the city's 28,000 elementary and high school students.

title: PRESEASON BASKETBALL
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Yes, ColdWater Wash Can Do the Job
description: If the households of the nation follow President Ford's advice, laundering with hot water may soon be a thing of the past.

title: Wilson's RailBond Plan Wins Beame's Approval
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday his hearty endorsement of Governor Wilson's proposed $250million rail preservation bond issue for major passenger  and freight  service improvements.

title: Myrdal and von Hayek Share a Nobel
description: The 1974 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science was awarded yesterday to Dr. Gunnar Myrdal and Dr. Friedrich A. von Hayektwo 75yearold social economists who have won international recognition for differing views.

title: Dave Anderson
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 9In a relaxed moment before today's American League championship series ended, a prejudiced witness, Alvin Dark, was testifying why the Oakland A's play baseball so well.

title: M.I.T. Strike Ends
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 (AP)Building service employes at Massachusetts Institute of Technology have ended their fourweek strike. Members of Local 254 of the Service Employes International Union voted 343 to 195 yesterday to accept a new twoyear contract reached Monday.

title: Ford Asserts He Sees Nothing Improper in ExGovernor's Acts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller's expected replies to questions about his financial gifts will be made public by the Senate Rules Committee, its chairman said today amid growing indications that Mr. Rockefeller's confirmation, once apparently assured, was likely to become increasingly controversial.

title: Aborted Grain Sale
description: President Ford, an old football player, was forced to do some impromptu scrambling on the food front last weekend, principally because his Administration has been unable to develop a coherent policy to deal with the world food crisis.

title: Antoine Oberding, 81, Dies; An Opera and TV Costumer
description: Antoine Oberding, a retired opera and television costumer, died Tuesday at Flushing (Queens) Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 25 West 64th Street.

title: Thousands Strike In 3 Spanish Cities; Arrests Protested
description: MADRID, Oct. 9 (AP)Thousands of workers went on strike in Barcelona and two other Spanish cities today, many over new labor Contracts. Strikes are illegal in Spain.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: The Dedication and Patience Of a Terrific Dessert Cook
description: For Freudian reasons all our own, we've been haunted through the years by two characters in fact and fiction. One of them was the mythological old king named Sisyphus, who was condemned to roll a boulder up a hill in Hades only to have it tumble back unvaryingly just as he reached the top.

title: JUDGE BACKS MOTION THAT NIXON TESTIFY
description: MIAMI, Oct. 9 (AP)  A circuit judge has agreed to the first step in a public defender's attempt to have former President Richard M. Nixon; his daughter, Julie Eisenhower, and her husband, David, testify in the trial of a man accused of writing $4million in bad checks.

title: Approval of Contraceptive Is Blocked by Weinberger
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, today blocked immiment approval of a longacting contraceptive because of lingering suspicious that it may cause cervical and breast cancer. Mr. Weinberger told Representative L. H. Fountain, chairman of a House Government Operations subcommittee, that the North Carolinian's fears about the safety of Depo Provera are significant and demonstrate a justifiable concern over possible cancercausing agents.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Ford's news conference yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: JUNK'S CREW SAFE IN PACIFIC RESCUE
description: A sevenman crew of anthropologists and adventurers was safely rescued yesterday in a remote area of the North Pacific by a passing freighter from the crippled hull of a sailpowered vessel modeled, after a 2,000yearold Chinese; junk.

title: Temptations Open at the Uris; 50Minute Show Has $12.50 Top
description: The Temptations opened their six  day, eight  performance stand at the Uris Theater on Tuesday night with a performance that raised some questions about the purpose of pop music Broadway.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Thursday, Oct. 10, 1974

title: Xerox Offers Plan To Settle Complaint Filed by the F.T.C.
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 9 (UPI)The Xerox Corporation offered today to issue royaltyree licenses under some of its copying machine patents to United States competitors in order to settle the Federal Trade Commission's complaint against the company filed in January, 1973.

title: 7 Hostages Are Freed
description: Guerrillas freed seven hostages they had been holding in the Venezuelan consulate in the Dominican Republic since Sept. 27. The guerrillas were on the way to asylum in Panama. Page 16.

title: Airline Employe Arrested In $440,000 Platinum Theft
description: DENVER, Oct. 9 (UPI)A 34yearold airline employe has been arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges that he stole 20 pounds of pure platinum worth $440,000 from a flight shipment.

title: College, School Results SOCCER
description: Colleges

title: Contract Awards
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation has received six Navy contracts, totaling $58.9million, providing increases in advance procurement funds and lead time authorizations for a number of different type planes.

title: GOLDMAN, SACHS LOSES RAIL CASE
description: Goldman, Sachs & Co., one of the nation's leading investment bankers, lost a landmark case here yesterday with a unanimous jury verdict that it be made to give three investors their money back on promissory notes of the Penn Central Transportation Company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Charges were dismissed in Buffalo in the first case to go to trial as a result of the 1971 riot at Attica State Prison. Justice Frank R. Bayger dismissed two charges of sodomy and two charges of sexual abuse in State Supreme Court, freeing Willie E. Smith, who had been accused of attacking another prisoner during the riot.

title: House Unit Clears Water Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The House Rules Committee voted today to send to the floor a hill that would make Federal drinking water purity standards mandatory throughout the country. The House leadership scheduled consideration of the bill for tomorrow.

title: FORDSAYSHISPLAN CAN CUT INFLATION BY EARLY IN 1975
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9President Ford, whose new economic program has been attacked in some quarters over the last 24 hours as too weak, declared today that his proposals could achieve a meaningful reduction in the rate of inflation by early next year.

title: Sugar Price Rises Spark 1% Increase In Market Basket
description: The spiraling cost of sugar and crop shortages caused by bad weather drove the cost of feeding a family of four here up 1 per cent last week, according to the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Israel Turns Back 5,000 Trying to Settle West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 9Police and army units today turned back a determined effort by several thousand young Israelis to establish new Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River in advance of Secretary of State Kissinger's arrival here Saturday.

title: Kissinger, Voicing Confidence, Meets Sadat in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Oct. 9Secretary of State Kissinger returned to the Middle East tonight, expressin confidence that he woul?? achieve his goal for an agree?? ment on the timing and formal for the next round of Arab?? Israeli negotiations.

title: It's a Coast Series: A's to Play Dodgers
description: The first allCalifornia World Series was assured yesterday when the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Oakland A's won their league playoffs.

title: Inquiry on Abuse of Patients At Pilgrim State Widening
description: An inquiry into allegations of patient abuse at Pilgrim State Hospital in Brentwood, L.I., has spread to encompass several employes and several incidents, a source in the Suffolk County District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Violence Is Deplored
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9President Ford said today that he disagreed with the school desegregation order of a Federal judge in Boston, but stressed his concern over the racial violence there and called on Boston citizens to respect the law.

title: Israel Turns Back 5,000 Trying to Settle West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 9Police and army units today turned back a determined effort by several thousand young Israelis to establish new Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River in advance of Secretary of State Kissinger's arrival here Saturday.

title: Soviet Shifts Aide Linked to BreakUp Of Art Exhibition
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9The Soviet Communist party disclosed today the removal of a Moscow party official in charge of the district where authorities forcibly broke up an unofficial art exhibition in September and provoked an international outcry.

title: Environmental Group Divided Over Impact of Ford Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  Reaction among environmental groups to some of President Ford's new economic proposals ranged today from indignation and uncertainty to the view that any major changes in current conditions are remote.

title: Ailing Snead Skips Drills
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 9The plot thickened in the New York Giants quarterback sweepstakes today as Coach Bill Arnsparger announced that Norm Snead, his No. 1 signalcaller, had a sore right knee.

title: Kennedy's Wife Faces Drunken Driving Count
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Joan Kennedy, the wife of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, was arrested today and charged with drunken driving after her automobile was involved in a threecar accident in Fairfax County, Va.

title: Franklin in Transition: Business Nearly Usual
description: FRANKLIN SQUARE, L. I., Oct. 9It was very nearly business as usual today at what was the Franklin National Bank: there was no run, there was no panic and most all customers expressed confidence, although some were fearful,

title: Stocks Up Sharply On Investor Hopes For Ford Program
description: Investors hopes that President Ford's new economic program might help curb inflation enabled the stock market yesterday to post its biggest gain in almost 17 months and its sixth largest advance in history. The prospect of lower interest rates helped the surge.

title: Savings Bank Outflow Slowed in September
description: The net outflow of deposits from the 119savings banks in New York State totaled $365million in September, according to the Savings Bank Association of New York State. This compares with an outflow of $514million in August and $602million in July. In September, 1973, the outflow was $293million.

title: State Agrees to a Meeting On BilingualClasses Cut
description: NEWARK, Oct. 9State officials agreed today to intervene in the dispute over proposed cuts in the bilingual classes as parents of more than 2,000 Hispanic elementary school pupils continued their boycott of the program for the third day.

title: Willowbrook's Director Shifted to a 2d Institurion
description: The director of Willowbrook the scandalriddled state institution for the mentally retard ed, has been transferred to another state job a short distanc?? from his present office on Staten Island.

title: BIG GENEVA BANK CLOSES ITS DOORS
description: GENEVA, Oct. 9Caught in a squeeze between Israeli and West German financial authorities, the banque de crdit International of Geneva announced tonight that it had closed it doors and applied for a moratorium.

title: Bird Lovers Are Urged To Halt Swallow Airlift
description: PARIS, Oct. 9Bird lovers of northern Europe were asked by the French Bird Protection League today to halt the campaign of airfreighting swallows trapped north of the Alps by early cold and snow to the French Riviera and Italy.

title: House Cuts $192Million from a Bill Nixon Vetoed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UN) The House trimmed $192million today from a $13.4billion bill funding agriculture, environment and consumer programs and sent It to the Senate by a vote of 366 to 24.

title: Joffrey Season Opens With Pulcinella
description: The Program

title: 100 Pickets Disrupt Jersey City Traffic
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 8 (UPI) Some 100 offduty Jersey City fire and police officers protesting a contract impasse disrupted morning rush hour traffic at three busy intersections today.

title: Nelson and David Rockefeller Reported Principals in Secret 1968 Transit Pact
description: On Feb. 9, 1968, the Governor of New York and the chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank met at the Governor's townhouse on West 55h Street and apparently signed a secret agreement that paved the way for the takeover later that year of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Senate voted, 62 to 16, to send legislation cutting off military aid to Turkey to the White House. It later eased this challenge to President Ford's threat of a veto by passing an amendment, which goes to the House, giving the President authority until Dec. 15 to suspend the provisions of the foreignaid laws with respect to Turkey. He would have to determine that the suspension would help settle the Cyprus problem. [Page 1, Columns 34.]

title: Mrs. Grasso Acts to Block Rise in Power Rates
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 9In an attempt to keep electricity bills from going up even more in Connecticut, United States Representative Ella Grasso planned today to join the city of Hartford and at least one consumer activist group in seeking an injuction that would block a rate increases granted two days ago by the Public Utilities Commission.

title: 3 Divide Duties at Establishment for Gordon Setters
description: Believing that three heads are better than one, the Sangerfield Kennel has three ownersJean Look, her sister Maragaret Sanger, and Fred Itzenplitz.

title: 7 Hostages Are Freed
description: Guerrillas freed seven hostages they had been holding in the Venezuelan consulate in the Dominican Republic since Sept. 27, The guerrillas were on the way to asylum in Panama. Page 16.

title: Nobel Choice: Economists in Contrast
description: The following article was written by Paul A. Samuelson, professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1970.

title: 2 SEIZED IN BRONX IN A ROBBERY RING
description: A 26yearold Bronx man and his 28yearold woman friend were arrested yesterday after burglary squad detectives allegedly found more than 2,500 pieces of allegedly stolen jewelry and other articles in the woman's apartment.

title: Geneva Bank Closes
description: The Genevabased Banque de Crdit International has closed its doors and has applied for a moratorium on payments. Details on Page 79.

title: Patriots' Defense: Showbis
description: Fresh from a losing encounter with the team that not long ago had a noname defense, the Jets face a defense on Sunday that really has a bunch of noname players. But no one has placed that tag on the New England Patriots.

title: SIRICA IS ASKED FOR SHIFT OR JURY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The special Watergate prosecution indicated again today that the pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon was posing a serious problem in the trial of the five former White House and Nixon campaign aides accused in the Watergate coverup case.

title: State Aids Mayor
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9This city will get 400 extra policemen tomorrow under a plan worked out by Mayor Kevin H. White after the Mayor's request for Federal marshals to control violence was rejected.

title: GAS PRICE IS CUT BY RIVALRY UPSTATE
description: UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 9 (AP)What appeared to be an oldfashioned gasoline price war was waged today along N. Y. 5A in Utica, where drivers could buy regular gasoline for as little as 47.9 cents a gallon, no strings attached.

title: No Legal Bar to Transfer Of Prisoners to Hospital
description: CAMDEN, Oct. 9Frank M. Lario, former solicitor for Winslow Township, testified under crossexamination today that the township placed no legal restriction en how the state could use land deeded to New Jersey for a mental hospital in 1951.

title: U.A.W. Strike Is Averted
description: JANESVILLE, Wis., Oct. 9 (AP)An 11thhour agreement latter an allnight bargaining, session ended the threat of al United Auto Workers strike to day at the General Motors plant here. No details of the tentative agreement were announced.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Oil and the U.S.: A 2Pronged Strategy

title: Astor Library's 125th Year: First Show of Some Items
description: The Astor Library, one of the larger literary acorns from which the mighty oak of the New York Public Library has grown, is celebrating its 125th birthday, or one of them, and is marking the occasion with an exhibition that exceeds a booklover's fondest dreams.

title: JOSEPH ROISMAN, VIOLINIST, 74, DIES
description: Joseph Roisman, first violin ist of the Budapest String Quartet, died at his home in Washington yesterday of a heart attack. He was 74 years old.

title: Famed Biomedical Group Says Basic Research Is Periled by Government Funding for Specific Diseases
description: SHREWSBURY, Mass.  In 1944, two eager young scientists who were fed up with what they regarded as the rigid, unimaginative thinking of the academic establishment, left their secure university positions and set up without endowment or income an independent research facility in an empty old barn.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: MASKS An exhibition of 83 Mexican masks dating from 1000 B.C. to 1970 opens today at the Museum of the American Indian, Heye Foundation, at 155th Street and Audubon Terrace.

title: Transit Bill Backed By President Stalls In Rules Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The House Rules Committee declined today to send an $11.8billion mass transit bill to the house floor in a move that took supporters of the legislation by surprise.

title: Ford Still Expects to Run for a Full Term in 1976
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 President Ford, obviously still intent on seeking a full term in 1976, flew here tonight to implore Pennsylvania Republicans to help head off a Democratic landslide this fall.

title: Carey Calls the Surtax A Blow at Middle Class
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Oct. 9  President Ford's proposed 5 per cent surtax is a hammer blow aimed at the middle class, Representative Hugh L. Carey said today.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: SENATE FAILS TO ACT ON NAMING FLANIGAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (Reuters)The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today virtually killed President Ford's nomination of Peter M. Flanigan to he Ambassador to Spain.

description: It was a crazy thing, James Thomas Flexner, the historian and Pulitier Prizewinner, said. It showed a little streak of madness.

description: New Summary and Index, Page 49

title: WHITE HOUSE WEIGHS LIMITATION ON C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) 1The Ford Administration may soon introduce legislation that would put strict limits on the amount of time the Civil Aeronautics Board could spend in approving mergers or route exchanges of United States interInational airlines.

title: Quake Hits North Japan
description: TOKYO, Oct. 10 (Reuters)Two moderate earth tremors within 10 minutes shook a wide area of northern Japan today. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.

title: RoncalloCase Rebuke
description: The two assistant United States attorneys who handled the unsuccessful prosecution of Representative Angelo Roncallo were censured. Page 19.

title: 425 Uri Policemen
description: BOSTON, Oct. 10  Mayor Kevin H. White lashed out at President Ford today for his antibusing statement yesterday, saying the President had fanned the flames of resistance to school integration and possibly contributed to the endangerment of Boston's schoolchildren.

title: Most Rev. Theodore Foley, Leader of Passionist Order
description: The Most Rev. Theodore Foley, Superior General of the Congregation of the Passion, died Wednesday in Rome at the age of 61.

title: Saigon Police Attack During a Censorship Protest
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 10Several demonstrators and three American newsmen were attacked by Saigon policemen today as antiGovernment street protests continued to gain momentum.

title: ITALY TRIES AGAIN TO UNITE PARTIES
description: ROME, Oct. 10President Giovanni Leone, who has conducted more than three days of consultations on the formation of a new coalition government, asked the President of the Italian Senate today to explore the chances of ending the political crisis.

title: Special Albany Session Urged To Bar 2d Markup on Goods
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 10Milton Jonas, chairman of the State Assembly's Standing Committee on Commerce, Industry and Economic Development, said today that he would ask Governor Wilson to convene a special session of the Legislature to act on a bill to protect consumers against unjustifiable markups on items that have already been priced on supermarket shelves.

title: Chase Earnings Up 8.3% in 3d Quartet Despite Bond Drop
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the holding company that owns the Chase Manhattan Bank, reported yesterday that its thirdquarter earnings rose 8.3 per, cent despite the downward revision in the value of the bonds in its trading account that the bank disclosed last week.

title: People and Business
description: Mary Joan Glynn, the 45yearold vice president of communications at Bloomingdale's, will become president of the Simplicity Pattern Company Inc. on Jan. 1.

title: CITY COLLEGE GUARD IN JURED BY INTRUDER
description: A plainclothes officer was Shot and critically wounded on the City College campus last night, apparently by a youth he had chased off the campus the day before.

title: Ford Not Dismayed by Election Odds
description: DETROIT, Oct. 10President (Ford said here tonight that he was not dismayed by what he called the supposed odds against Republican candidates in this fall's elections.

title: 3 Share Nobel Prize
description: Three scientists whose work began the modern science of cell biology 30 years ago have been awarded the 1974 Nobel Prize for medicine or physiology. Page 22.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Board of Estimate Heeds Queens Plea

title: Edwards & Hanley and 2 Are fined by Big Board
description: A fine of $26,000 has been levied by the New York Stock Exchange against Edwards & Hanley, the brokerage house, and two employes, the Big Board said yesterday. The two are Arthur Foote, a general partner, who was fined $1,000, and Ivan Boesky, who was fined $10,000. The balance was levied against the concern itself.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
Bill Giving States a Veto On Deepwater Ports Hailed
description: LONG BRANCH,, Oct. 10New Jersey environmentalists and legislators today hailed the Senate passage yesterday of a bill that would give virtual veto powers to the states over the construction of deepwater ports on their coasts.

title: The Pop Life
description: Labelle, the spaceage rhythm and blues trio consisting of Patti LaBelle, Nona Hendryx and Sarah Dash, has been often reviewed and written about. But the trio's concert last Sunday night at the Metropolitan Opera was still capable of provoking some thoughts not directly related to the group or its music.

title: Ashe Opens Tennis for. U.S. Today
description: NASSAU, Bahamas Oct. 10 (AP)Arthur Ashe leads the United States Davis Cup squad into the first round of the American Zone competition tomorrow against the Commonwealth Carib team.

title: SCRUTINIZE POLICE, KUH ORDERS STAFF
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan said yesterday that the members of his office were not partners of the police and ordered his 200 assistants to scrutinize police performance from arrest through court testimony for possible misconduct.

title: Port Authority Will Prepare Site Near Liberty Is. for State, Park
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed yesterday to do the engineering and design work for preparation of a 500acre strip along the New Jersey shore near Ellis and Liberty Islands as the site, id the future Liberty. State Park.

title: MEXICANS CHANGE POLITICAL STYLE
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10 When heavily armed policemen and soldiers took up positions around the Plaza of Tlatelolco a week ago yesterday, there were no demonstrators to mark the anniversary of the 1968 massacre there, when the Mexican Army shot down more than 250 people and crushed a student protest movement.

title: Resurgent Spiral?
description: Of all the many weaknesses in President Ford's antiinflation program, the most glaring is the absence of any direct pressure for moderation an the pricewage front, much less any mechanism for enforcing restraint.

title: City to Join Social Service Project for Chelsea Area
description: Twelve employes of the City Human Resources Administration are to be deployed to work with 16 staff members of the Community Service Society in a precedentsetting joint public and private effort to improve social services for the Chelsea neighborhood.

title: Brothers Clash in PrincetonDartmouth Game
description: Probably the only neutral observersexclusive of the officials, of courseattending tomorrow's Ivy League football struggle between Dartmouth and Princeton at Hanover, N. H., will be Mary and Walter Snickenberger.

title: Woman, 66, Knifed To Death in Hotel; Neighbor Is Held
description: 24yearold man who, the police said, has a history of psychiatric trouble was arrested last night and charged with the fatal stabbing of a 66yearold woman who was his neighbor in a West Side singleroomoccupancy hotel.

title: Javits Accuses Clark of Taking Fuzzy Position on Middle East
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday accused Ramsey Clark, his Democratic opponent, of taking a fuzzy and ambiguous position on the problems of the Middle East and of gambling on the survival of Israel.

title: Education Board Urged to Act On Closing Underused Schools
description: The City Planning Commission urged the Board of Education yesterday to stand up to community resistance to closing underused schools now that the city, school population is declining.

title: Prices of Bonds Surge
description: Corporate and municipal bonds made impressive gains yesterday in response to a slowing in wholesale price increases and to the recent decline in shortterm interest rates. Details on Page 53.

title: Kissinger Meets Sadat on Next Stage
description: CAIRO, Oct. 10Secretary of State Kissinger said tonight that after five hours of talks with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt he was encouraged by progress made toward reaching a formula for the next round of ArabIsraeli negotiations.

title: DepositInsurance Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The Senate passed and sent to the White House today legislation raising deposit insurance for banks and thrift institutions from $20,000 to $40,000. The bill also has provisions barring credit discrimination on the basis of sex or martial status.

title: Screen: 'La Circostanza':Olmi Work Is Shown at Film Festival
description: "La Circostanza" (The Circumstance), which was shown at the New York Film Festival last night and will be repeated there, is another unsuccessful attempt by Ermanno Olmi, the Italian director, to rise above the banality of the subjects that have occupied him in recent years.The film is about one summer in the lives of the members of an upper-middle-class Milan family, each of whom faces his or her teeny-weeny crisis with the kind of gravity that a more idiosyncratic, less schematic film maker might have made seem important, maybe even funny. Middle-class life is wretched, says Mr. Olmi. It's dehumanizing. We're almost like cattle, he goes on to say, showing us scenes in the stockyards in which cattle are led up ramps, then slaughtered. Mr. Olmi is not a director to let a clich die peacefully.He makes movies with a petty file clerk's love for the nonessential detail and a bad writer's total inability to fabricate spontaneity. The festival program describes Mr. Olmi's editing technique in "La Circostanza" as "more aggressive" than it's been in the past, in his earlier, much better films, like "Il Posto" and "The Fiancs."I don't know if it's really more aggressive or just film-school fancy. There are lots of fragmented flashbacks and flash-forwards, but they don't add anything. It just takes one a little longer to realize fully the film's complete lack of excitement."Lacombe, Lucien," which opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, was shown at the 12th New York Film Festival. Vincent Canby's review of the film appeared in The New York Times last Sept. 30.

title: Welfare Ineligibles Face Crackdown
description: New York City and New York State agreed to hire 120 additional city investigators a month to track down welfare cases in which an allegedly absent father may actually be available to support his family.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Cahill's '69 Campaign Is Target Of Jersey Embezzlement Inquiry
description: TRENTON, Oct. 10William F. Hyland, the State Attorney General, said today that his office was investigating the possible embezzlement of funds from the 1969 campaign of former Gov. William T. Cahill.

title: SHERWIN WINS STAY OF HIS PRISON TERN
description: Paul J. Sherwin, the former New Jersey Secretary of State who was scheduled to begin serving a twoyear sentence for bribery and conspiracy yesterday, won a stay at the last minute of at least four days.

title: House Unit Backs Revamping on Stocks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 Legislation authorizing sweeping reforms in the rules, structure and regulatory system of securities markets was approved today by the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS Oct. 10, 1974
description: All six wins ... $50,000

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Theater owners rerpesenting 354 houses around the country, anticipating audience interest in The Godfather, Part II, have paid Paramount Pictures, the producers of the sequel to The Godfather, and unprecedented $26,825,500 in advance guarantees, according to Frank Yablans, president of Paramount. The figure, Mr. Yablans says, surpasses the previous high in advance receipts of $19.2million by The Great Gatsby and represents the longest advance receipts in the history of motion pictures. The Godfather, Part II, which cost about $14million to produce, will have its world premiere here in midDecember at Loews State 1, Loews State II, the Orpheum, Cine and Tower East theaters. Marlon Brando, who starred in The Godfather, does not appear in the sequel, which features some of the cast from the earlier film.

title: Eleanor Roosevelt Honored at Hunter
description: The oncefamiliar voice of Eleanor Roosevelt, captured on longago newsreel disks as well as in later taped reminiscences, was heard again at Hunter College last night as part of a multimedia celebration on the eve of today's 90th anniversary of her birth.

title: Congress Passes Bill Banning Bias Against Women on Credit
description: The Senate yesterday passed legislation that will outlaw credit discrimination based on sex or marital status, The passage followed similar action by the House Wednesday night.

title: City to Join in a Social Service Project
description: Twelve employes of the City Human Resources Administration are to be deployed to work with 16 staff members of the Community Service Society in a precedentsetting joint public and private effort to improve social services for the Chelsea neighborhood.

title: Consultants Urge Overhaul Of Hudson's Government
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 10 Charging that there was inefficiency, waste and costly duplication of effort, a management consultant firm today gave the Hudson County Board of Chosen Freeholders a plan for a drastic overhaul of the county's $72millionayear operation.

title: A 2d Daley Ally in 2 Days Convicted in Federal Court
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP)Alderman Paul T. Wigoda, a /political ally of Mayor Richard J. Daley, was convicted today in Federal court of income tax fraud.

title: Staid Image of Mills in Arkansas Damaged by Incident in Capital
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 10 The latenight incident involving Representative Wilbur D. Mills has demolished his staid image among voters in the Second Congressional District and also his prospects for an easy reelection, politicians here agreed today.

title: Search for Protein Crucial In Struggle Against Hunger
description: Scientists are juggling plant genes, squeezing juice out of leaves and growing microorganisms on manure in a wideranging assault on one of the most fundamenta problems of the world's food shortagehow to get more protein for more people.

title: Banker Uses $35,000 in Vault To Ransom Wife and 2 Children
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., Oct. 10 (AP)A bank manager's ordeal of terror ended today after he took money from the vault of his bank to meet the demands of his family's abductors.

title: FORD GETS A BILL TO FINANCE RACES FOR PRESIDENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The most extensive reform of Federal campaign financing practices in American history was cleared by Congress today and sent to the White House.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Exxon Corporation has shut down all its oil and gas fields in Libya as well as its liquified natural gas plant there in a threeway dispute between Libya, the oil company and the Italian Government.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Prison Psychiatrist Ordered to Trial

title: 2 Nursing Homes Censured by State
description: The State Welfare Inspector General, William F. Meyers, charged yesterday in a report that there were grave irregularities at two nursing homes in Queens, and he accused the City Department of Social Services of callous indifference toward the elderly poor.

title: A Confident Carey Lauds Running Mates
description: Obviously confident that he is the frontrunner in the gubernatorial race, Representative Hugh L. Carey repeatedly praised his Democratic running mates in campaigning yesterday in Nassau County as he has done even in upstate areas where the popularity of some of his running mates is at least questionable.

title: JAMES H. DECKER
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 10 (AP) James H. Decker, former athletic director at Syracuse University, died today at the age of 63.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Carole Meyers, trailed by, her husband, Martin, who often goes shopping with her, bubbled up to Viola Sylbert in Henri Bendel's fur salon the other day. What I want is something very casual, an everyday coat, nothing princessy looking, she explained.

title: Steve Cady
description: The young desk clerk in the carpeted lobby of the New York Health Club didn't recognize him.

title: ABUSES REPORTED IN FEDERAL HIRING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 Federal investigations into the alleged appointment of political favorites to career Civil Service jobs have uncovered widespread abuse of the: Federal hiring system during the Nixon Administration, the chairman of a House Civil Service subcommittee reported today.

title: Soviet Bloc's Israeli Ties Seen in 1975
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Sovietbloc officials said today that the Soviet Union and four of its East European allies were considering the resumption of diplomatic relations with Israel some time next year. The five countries broke relations with Israel during the Middle East war of 1967.

title: ExBroker Charged By S. E. C. on Sales Of Stock to Mobil
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, in its first use of a fiveyearold securities law, charged a former stockbroker yesterday with selling stock he did not own and then buying the stock to cover the deal.

title: 74 Superb Works From Louvre at the Met
description: Among recent human adventures none has been more clearly or more promptly to our advantage than the love match between the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Louvre. So much has come of this, and so much more is expected, that it almost goes without saying that the show of Italian Renaissance Drawings From the Louvre, which has just opened at the Met and will be on view there through Jan. 5, is one of the noblest things of its kind: superlative in quality, ideal in scale (74 items in all) and catalogued with due attention to the antlike activity of AngloAmerican scholarship. How often do we see a show that has in it four drawings by Raphael and five by Michelangelo and yet goes on its way through a large group of lesser names with no sense of anticlimax? Faced with such things we look, marvel and we learn.

title: 3d Period Net Cited
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday reported an earnings increase of 16.4 per cent for the third quarter of 1974.

title: 425 Extra Policemen
description: BOSTON, Oct. 10  Mayor Kevin H. White lashed out at President Ford today for his antibusing statement yesterday, saying the President had fanned the flames of resistance to school integration and possibly contributed to the endangerment of Boston's schoolchildren.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Core Banks
description: CORE BANKS, N. C.  It was the right time of year to catch small channel bassor puppy drum as they are called throughout the statebut after a few hours of fishing chunks of cut mullet on the bottom to no avail, we began to think of lesser prey.

description: The Dow Chemical Company formally terminated its agreement yesterday to merge the General Crude Oil Company into Dow.

Rockefeller's possible involvement with a derogatory biography of Arthur J. Goldberg published when Mr. Goldberg was his Democratic opponent for the New York governorship in 1970.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The Senate has started an investigation of condominiums that could lead to the first significant legislative effort to control alleged abuses associated with this increasingly popular form of housing.

title: Bridge: Attendance at Tournaments Shows Inflation's Effect
description: There are some indications that tournament bridge is becoming, to a slight degree, a victim of inflationary pressures. After a decade of steady growth, tournament attendances here dropped in the last year by some 5 per cent.

title: Wilson Calls Carey a Clear and Present Danger
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 10With United States Senator James L. Buckley at his side, Governor Wilson today accused Representative Hugh L. Carey of advocating publicemploye strikes and posing a clear and present danger to the voters of the state.

title: Staff Cuts Forcing 3 Library Closings
description: Distressed by what it called the city's unbelievable staff cuts, the Public Library announced yesterday that three large neighborhood branches would close indefinitely on Nov. 18.

title: Kissinger's Popularity Is Off Sharply in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 10 (UPI)The popularity of Secretary of State Kissinger has plummeted among Israelis since the 1973 Middle East war, according to a poll published today by the newspaper Haaretz.

title: MRS. FORD READY TO LEAVE HOSPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Betty Ford will return to the White House tomorrow afternoon, 13 days after having undergone surgery for removal of her right breast at Bethesda Laval Hospital.

title: Laker Wins Pace Stakes At Yonkers
description: YONKERS, Oct. 10The third of the New York Sire Stakes occupied the main. event spot on the program at the Yonkers Raceway tonight. Although the onemile race for 3yearold fillies had only six entrants, and hence was rim as a nonbetting event, it nevertheless had a value of $100,000.

title: Democrats Hopeful Inlowa Campaigning
description: COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 10 A gentle Indian Summer sun tas bathed the Iowa prairies all this week, and the bright skies offered an ideal setting for harvesting soybeans, hunting ducks, watching football games and politicking.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: SAIGON APPLAUDS GRAM DANCERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 10The Martha Graham Dance Company came to Saigon this week, and for two fleeting days the United States showed a new face in Vietnam.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: TOKYO, Oct. 10 (UPI)Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., defeated Jun Kamiwazumi of Japan, 60, 60, today in the third round of $100,000 Japan open tennis tournament.

title: SCHOOLS PROLONG BILINGUAL POLICY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 10School officials here and representatives of the State Department of Education agreed tonight to continue the city's Federally financed bilingual teaching program while they determined how many Hispanic children should be allowed to remain in the classes.

title: About Real Estate People With a Plan Buy Hotel
description: The Hotel Taft, one of the better known tourist meccas the Times Square area, has changed hands.

title: Joyful Chinese Parade Marks Manchu Ouster
description: Hundreds of jubilant Chinese  Americans paraded through Chinatown yesterday to celebrate the 63d anniversary of the 1911 Nationalist revolution that ousted the Manchu Dynasty and led to the founding of the Republic of China under Sun Yatsen.

title: Rally Leaves Wall Street Jubilant, If Bewildered
description: The mood on Wall Street, which has been shrouded in gloom in recent months, ranged from jubilant to bewildered yesterday as stock prices surged for the second consecutive day, completing one of the largest twoday advances in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Rally Leaves Wall Street Jubilant, If Bewildered
description: The mood on Wall Street, which has been shrouded in gloom in recent months, ranged from jubilant to bewildered yesterday as stock prices surged for the second consecutive day, completing one of the largest twoday advances in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: ...and a Different One
description: The view from George Washington's home in Mount Vernon is almost unspoiled. It is that way because of the efforts of a large number of people, most notably the Mount Vernon Ladies Association, to maintain for the million Americans who visit the estate each year a vista across the Potomac faithful to that which the Washingtons saw when they lived there nearly two centuries ago.

title: Restraint by Rabin
description: Israelis still speak in muted sadness about one of the most traumatic moments of their modern history, the socalled Altalena affair of June 1948. With their republic in its first days challenged on all fronts by combined Arab armies, the new leader, David BenGurion, issued the drastic orders to open fire and destroy a munitions vessel attempting to land a cargo of sorely needed weapons for the Jewish fighters. The Premier argued that his young Government's authority was at stake, for the supplies on the Altalena were destined not for the national army but for the Irgun, one of the militant factional armies operating outside the Government command.

title: For a Merger of Two Major U.S. Airlines
description: Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines, the principal international air carriers of the United States Flag, have been flying into a deadly storm.

title: A Price That's Held
description: ST. CHARLES, Mich. Oct. 10The experts may think President Ford proposed too little in his antiinflation program and the politicians may say he proposed too much. Either way, Roy and Eunice Chamberlain have already decided to hold the line on one important item that will soon be in hot demand. They're not going up this year on the price of the beautiful spruce and Scotch pines they grow on their Wolf Creak Christmas tree plantation near here.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Overhauls India's Cabinet to Deal With Economic Crisis
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 10Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, worried about food shortages and India's economic drift, drastically overhauled the nation's Cabinet today.

title: Ford Qualifies Stand on Oil Allowance
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10President Ford qualified his support for repeal of the oil depletion allowance today by saying it should be linked to removal of Federal controls on oil prices.

title: Congress Passes Bill Banning Bias Against Women on Credit
description: The Senate yesterday passed legislation that will outlaw credit discrimination based on sex or marital status. The passage followed similar action by the House Wednesday night.

title: WHOLESALE INDEX HAS LOWEST RISE IN LAST 11 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Wholesale prices remained almost unchanged overall in September, the first month in almost a year in which they did not rise substantially. The rise was only onetenth of 1 per cent.

title: Jets Set to Use Word, Wise
description: As a group of reporters clustered around Roscoe Word the rookie cornerback, in the Jets' locker room the other day, Joe Namath strolled by and observed the scene.

title: LABOR IS VICTOR INBRITAIN; WILSON REMAINS IN POWER, GAINS WORKING MAJORITY
description: LONDON, Friday, Oct. 11The governing Labor party led by Prime Minister Harold Witson has won Britain's second general election this year.

title: Iran's Help to Kurds Fighting Iraq Includes Arms, Secret Agents and Public Relations
description: WITH THE KURDISH FORCES, Northeast Iraq The Kurdish guerrillas here are being aided by Iran with guns and ammunition and even public relations, as the Iranian secret police have been helping Western correspondents slip across the border to report on the war against Iraqi Government forces. There Is a certain irony in this.

title: Kalmbach Seeks a Cut In 18Month Jail Term
description: WASHINGTON, Pct. 10 (UPI)Herbert W. Kalmbach, a principal fundraiser and former personal lawyer for Richard M. Nixon, has filed, a motion for the reduction of the 6month to 18month sentence he is serving for Watergaterelated crimes.

title: PLUTONIUM FOUND IN PLANTS' ROOTS
description: Researchers near the plant where plutonium was first produced as atomic bomb fuel have discovered that, with surprising efficiency, this highly toxic element is picked up from the soil by plant roots.

title: Clyde C. Williams, 93, Alaska Sourdough, Dies
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP)Clyde C. (Slim) Williams, who traveled in the nineteenthirties by dogsled from Copper Center, Alaska, to Washington, died yesterday. He was 93 years old. Mr. Williams was the subject of a biography, Alaska Sourdough, as well as explorer, hunter, guide and lecturer.

title: Lease Signed Approving Red Hook Containerport
description: New York City and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey executed a lease yesterday giving final approval to a project to create a modern containership port in the depressed Red Hook section of Brooklyn.

title: Senate Delays Legislation Curbing Nixon Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The Senate agreed tonight to put off until, net month legislation providing money to pay for former President Richard M. Nixon's pension and other expenses.

title: Isaak S. Bruk, 72, Dead; Soviet Computer Scientist
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10 (UPI)Isaak Semenovich Bruk, a leading Soviet computer scientist, has died, the Government newspaper Izvestia said yesterday. He was 72 years old.

title: TV: The Basic Patterns
description: On commercial television, the fare is still more fraudulent sociology. On public TV, it's serious anthropology. Names change, but the basic patterns remain remarkably steady.

title: Rider's First Race Proves a Winner
description: John Czarnecki, a triplebug apprentice jockey, made It look easy at Belmont Park yesterday by winning with the first mount of his ?? career Sleering Hobeau Farm's Spiked Apple in the opening race of the card, 19year  old Czar necki scored by five lengths. His mount, a 5yearold horse trained by Allen Jerkens, returned $14.80 for $2 to win as fourth choice in field of 10.

title: U.S. Aide Calls Dominican Captors Kind
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 10 (UPI)An American woman official freed from 13 days as a captive of leftist guerrillas, says she was treated like a lady and diplomat and grew to like her kidnappers.

title: Jets, Giants Face Formidable Foes
description: It could be a difficult Sunday for the Giants and the Jets, who between them have won only two of eight games. Both are three games behind the undefeated leaders in their divisions. The Giants face a mean Philadelphia team on the road while the Jets take on unbeaten New England on home grounds at last. The game at Shea Stadium is sold out, so it will be telecast locally, Channel 4, 1 P.M. At the same time, Channel 2 will carry the Eagles and Giants from Philadelphia. There will be no second, late game on television here. The Monday night contest matches two losers, San Francisco at Detroit, Channel 7, 9 P.M.

title: Trading in Futures Dull, Awaiting a Crop Report
description: Most commodity futures exchanges were quiet yesterday before the release of the Government crop report after the close of trading.

title: BURNS FINDS LAG IN MONEY GROWTH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said openly today for the first time that his agency regarded the recent rate of growth of the nation's money supply as too low. He also said he felt the nation was in a recession, albeit a most unusual one.

title: Citicorp Earnings Rose By 21% in Third Quarter
description: Citicorp, the nation's secondlargest banking concern and parent of the First National City Bank, reported yesterday a 21 per cent gain in thirdquarter operating earnings to $79million, or 65 cents a share. This compared with $65.4million, or 54 cents a share, in the 1973 period.

title: A's Against Dodgers: An Unpredictable Series
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10For two reasons, careful analysis of the teams is not likely to prove enlightening about the outcome of the 1974 World Series, which will pit the Oakland A's, defending champions, against the Los Angeles Dodgers in baseball's first totally transSierra championship.

title: MAFIA DISCIPLINE LINKED TO KILLING
description: Dominick Scialo, whose partially decomposed body was found in a Brooklyn basement Wednesday evening, was slain three weeks ago by members of his own Mafia family because he had become impossible to handle, according to sources close to the case.

title: The National Health a Play of Genius
description: The Circle in the Square last night formally opened its season at its Joseph E. Levine Theater with Peter Nichols's brilliant if deathly comedy, The National Health. The months ahead of us look gratifyingly promising, but this has got to be one of the best plays of the season. It is a flawed work of pure genius, and should be Seen by anyone with an interest in the contemporary theater.

title: Reversible Lanes End On West Side Highway
description: Starting tomorrow, traffic oh the Henry Hudson Parkway between 72d and 79th Streets will once again be southbound only at all times, Transportation Administrator Michael J. Lazar said yesterday. His decision ends an experiment of reversible lanes in effect for more than a month.

title: Player Ousts Crenshaw In World Match Play
description: VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 10The underrated Americans placed Hale Irwin and Jerry Heard in the semifinals of the 11th Piccadilly World Match Play golf tournament today, but most of the thunder was provided by Gary Player and a revivified Tony Jacklin.

title: Paul J. Jones, 77, Wrote A Column on Philadelphia
description: Paul J. Jones, a former Philadelphia newspaper columnist, died Wednesday at his home in Penn Valley, Pa. He was 77 years old.

title: Advertising
description: Leonard Riggio grew up in Brooklyn and didn't quite graduate from New York University. His father, Steve, was once a welterweight prize fighter and cab driver.

title: Hardy First in Jump in Coast Show
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 10 (UPI)Thom Hardy of East Moline, Ill., placed first aboard his horse, Commin Attraction, in the open ??mper competition with a time 27.78 seconds at the seventh annual Forum International horse show.

title: Polish Party Chief, In U.N. Assembly, Praises Detente
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10The Polish Communist party chief, Edward Gierek, told the General Assembly today that his country and the United States were opening up new opportunities for further cooperation.

title: Ronan Denies Impropriety In Gift From Rockefeller
description: Dr. William J. Ronan said yesterday that there was nothing immoral or illegal about his accepting a gift of $550,000 he had borrowed from Nelson A. Rockefeller over a 17year period.

title: As Gierek Visits U.S., Poland Basks in Stability and Economic Prosperity
description: WARSAW, Oct. 10  As Poles turned on color television sets to watch their leader touring the United States this week, the Polish Government basked in an image of political stability, economic prosperity and friendship with most of the world.

title: Frost Cuts Corn Crop Outlook
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 Damage from early frosts have further reduced the outlook for corn production 277 million bushels, to a total 16 per cent below last year's crop, the Ag?? Department reported today. The reduced crop dims consumer hopes for a levelingoff in the foodprice spiral.

title: Two Teams Are dropped By W.F.L.
description: ANAHEIM,. Calif., Oct. 10 (AP)  The financially troubled. World Football League announced tonight it was removing the Jacksonville and Detroit franchises from the remainder of its 1974 schedule. But the league said it would attempt to keep the teams intact in hopes of finding new investors.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic, on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.2 billion tonmiles, 1.7 per cent below the corresponding week year ago. Carloading in the same period totaled 541,321 cars, 2.9 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 5.4 per cent below last year.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Retaliatory Quotas On Imports of Hogs And Cattle Looming
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The Government started proceedings today that could lead to imposition of retaliatory quotas on imports of cattle and hogs and their products from Canada.

title: Fire Official Indicted
description: TOMS RIVER, Oct. 10 (AP)The former president of a volunteer fire company has been indicted for allegedly embezzling $52,888 over three years from the company's weekly. bingo games. The man, Albert Cottrell, 41 years old, a painting contractor, was arrested Tuesday and charged with embezling the money from the Breton Woods Volunteer Fire. Company in Brick Township.

title: STATION SALE SET BY CITIES SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) The Cities Service Company of New York City today agreed to sell off a large group of its service stations in Massachusetts and New Hampshire in settlement of a Federal antitrust suit, the Justice Department announced.

title: City to Expand Relief Staff To Track Down Ineligibles
description: The city and the state agreed yesterday to hire 120 additional city investigators a month to track down welfare cases in which an allegedly absent father may actually be available to support his family.

title: You Wouldnt Call It Dining, but They Serve Good Food
description: Danny's Brown Jug, at 1122 First Avenue, is not so much a restaurant as a pub. Give it one more decibel and it would be not so much a pub as a joint. Eating there could never be called dining, but if you can take uninterrupted assault and battery by the sound of music, mostly rock, overwoofed and undertweeted, you can get good food there until 2 A.M. at prices low for New York. The music is part of thewell, why not?the joint's cultivation of an uptown bohemian atmosphere.

title: Judge Rules in Favor of Auto Tracks
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 10 (AP)A federal judge ruled yesterday that a stock car race track could not be held liable for accidents if the drivers sign waivers releasing the track from fault.

title: Snead Is Given Backup Role
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 10A strange sequence of events that started as far back as summer training camp has led to a change in quarterbacks for the New York Giants this week.

title: Ayckbourn, ExActor, Now Plays Singular Writer of Comedies
description: Before Alan Ayckbourn became a playwright, he was an actor with a provincial company. As Vladimir in Waiting for Godot, one, evening during Pozzo's speech, he fell asleep on stage. It was only for two seconds, he says somewhat sheepishly, but I wondered where the hell I was.

title: Music: Illuminating and Nostalgic Ives at Festival
description: Retrospectives of revolutionary periods in the arts are common enough except where music is concerned; the problems of performance preparation are too great. The particular pleasure of the New York Philharmonic's MiniFestival Around Ives is in having this lack made up for once. While the music of Charles Ives is the springboard for the five programs, it is heard in the context of the ultramodern (yesteryear's word for avantegarde) works of his era. The result is illuminating as well as somewhat nostalgic.

title: Senate Backs Measure On Commodity Trading
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)The Senate completed Congressional action today on a bill to establish a full time independent commission to regulate commodity futures trading.

title: Senate Votes Postal Aid Of 35Million for Pan Am
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) The Senate voted by 72 to 2 today to help Pan American World Airways with its financial problems by requiring that discriminatory postalrate and landingfee practices against the airline be stopped.

title: A Tense, Troubled City
description: BOSTON, Oct. 10Only a few cities  Chicago, Philadeldelphia, New Yolk, Bostonhave kept the structures built by immigration, have retained the real ethnic blocs that support the whole fabric of those communities. Boston's strengths come from those neighborhoods with roots, tradition and history. They are also enclaves that resist change.

title: Notes on People
description: The American Lutheran Church yesterday elected the Rev. David W. Preus to a sixyear term as its president. The 1,196 delegates to the seventh general convention of the church, in Detroit, gave Mr. Preus a full term in, the office he has held since the death of Dr. Kent Knudson in 1973. The 52yearold Mr. Preus, who has a congregation in Minneapolis, had been heavily favored to win a full term, and he received 680 votes; two other contenders had a total of 275. The American Lutheran Church, with a membership of 2.5 million, operates in 47 states and overseas.

title: WHOLESALE INDEX HAS LOWEST RISE IN LAST 11 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Wholesale prices remained almost unchanged overall in September, the first month in almost a year in which they did not rise substantially. The rise was only onetenth of 1 per cent.

title: Calling All Scientists
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10If ever there was a time when the President of the United States needed the help of the best objective scientific minds to help him grapple with the problems of food, fuel, transportation, housing and many other things, it now; but he is a little shorthanded.

title: Contract Award
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has received $275.1million Navy contract for 46 submarine hunting planes.

title: Justice Department Rebukes 2 Prosecutors for Their Actions in Roncallo ExtortionConspiracy Case
description: The Justice Department has censured two assistant United States attorneys in the Eastern District of New York for their handling of the extortionconspiracy case against Angelo D. Roncallo, the Long Island Representative who was acquitted last May.

title: Drop Is 7th in Row
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, plagued by deepseated difficulties in many of its operations, reported its seventh consecutive decline in quarterly earnings yesterday.

title: Scandal Erupts in Israel Over Links to Rosenbaum
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 10  A major scandal erupted in Israel following the collapse of the central European business conglomerate of Tibor Rosenbaum, a prominent financier.

title: Ronan Denies Impropriety In Gift From Rockefeller
description: Dr. William J. Ronan said yesterday that there was nothing immoral or illegal about his accepting a gift of $550,000 he had borrowed from Nelson A. Rockefeller over a 17year period.

title: Sun Beats Steamer, Wins Title in West
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 10 (AP)  Tony Adams passed for 222 yards tonight and the Southern California Sun beat the Shreveport Steamer, 2523, to clinch the World Football League Western Division title and earn a berth in the playoffs.

title: Staff Cuts Forcing 3 Library Closings
description: Distressed by what it called the city's unbelievable staff cuts, the Public Library announced yesterday that three large neighborhood branches would close indefinitely on Nov. 18.

title: Eleanor Roosevelt Honoredat Hunter
description: The oncefamiliar voice of Eleanor Roosevelt, captured on longago newsreel disks as well as in later taped reminiscences, was heard again at Hunter College last night as part of a multimedia celebration on the eve of today's 90th anniversary of her birth.

title: LABOR IS VICTOR IN BRITAIN; WILSON REMAINS IN POWER WITH EFFECTIVE MAJORITY
description: LONDON, Friday, Oct. 11The governing Labor party led by Prime Minister Harold Wilson has won Britain's second general election this year.

title: State Backs Plan to Form Salt Marsh at Fire Island
description: ALBANY, Oct. 10 (UPI)The state has approved plans by the National Park Service to create a salt marsh along the shore of Fire Island National Seashore, Governor Wilson said today. The area is adjacent to the Islip town park at Barret Beach.

title: Jacqueline Susann's Will To Benefit Many Charities
description: About half of the late Jacqueline Susann's estate, estimated to be worth $1.5million, will ultimately go to charity, according to the novelist's will.

title: Blacks Watch More TV Than General Audiences
description: The black audience watches more television than the general audience, tends to favor television programs that feature blacks and spends more than 50 per cent of its radio listening time tuned to stations programed specifically for black audiences.

title: Ashe Opens Tennis for U.S. Today
description: NASSAU, Bahamas Oct. 10 (AP)Arthur Ashe leads the United States Davis Cup squad into the first round of the American Zone competition tomorrow against the Commonwealth Carib team.

title: Gifts of Steaben Glass Made by Rockefeller
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a Texas Democrat who serves with Nelson A. Rockefeller on the National Commission on Water Quality, said today that last Christmas he received from Mr. Rockefeller a piece of engraved Steuben glass, just like he'd give a $2 ashtray.

title: Approval of Contraceptive Is Blocked by Weinberger
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, today blocked immiment approval of a longacting contraceptive because of lingering suspicious that it may cause cervical and breast cancer. Mr. Weinberger told Representative L. H. Fountain, chairman of a House Government Operations subcommittee, that the North Carolinian's fears about the safety of Depo

title: JUDGE ROGER T. FOLEY
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 10 (UPI)  Senior United States District Judge Roger T. Foley, a pioneer in the Nevada legal profession, died last night at the age of 88.

title: Oriole Ownership Considers Selling
description: After an East Division championship that still, kept the teamin the red, and two playoff games inwhich 44,000 seats went begging, the Baltimore, Orioles' ownership is considering selling the team if a new stadium isn't built.

title: Dow Jones Index. Climbs 17.06 to 648.08 On the Heaviest Turnover of the Year
description: Stock prices soared yesterday for the second consecutive session in the heaviest trading of the year and the fifth largest in exchange history.

title: Milk Inquiry Seen Stalled By Agriculture Unit's Lag
description: The United States Department of Justice notified Representative Edward I. Koch yesterday that it could not decide if it should prosecute the Dairylea milkadulteration case because it had not received sufficient information from the Department of Agriculture.

title: State Studies Sales Of Shore Property To Crime Figures
description: TRENTON, Oct. 10Organizedcrime figures are investing in real estate, motels and bars, especially in the Wildwood area in Cape May County, Attorney General William F. Hyland said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Certainly the many and complex problems besetting our economy require more imaginative and direct solutions thin those proposed by President Ford this afternoon [editorial Oct. 9]. I don't pretend to have the answers to our problems, but would like to propose an important step in the right direction.

title: RoncalloCase Rebuke
description: The two assistant United States attorneys who handled the unsuccessful prosecution of Representative Angelo Roncallo were censured. Page 19.

title: PRESIDENT CHIDES CONGRESS ON AID
