description: DETROIT, Oct. 10President Ford attacked Congress tonight for attempting to cut off American military assistance to Turkey, calling the attempt a dangerous and misguided course of action, which tragically and catastrophically, will damage Greece and undermine the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: 3 Nobel Laureates in Medicine
description: When Albert Claude recounts the events that started him on a career in scientific research, he tells a little story that illustrates his quiet, subtle sense of humor. It was 1929. He had just completed his medical education at the University of Liege in Belgium and had a Government scholarship for overseas study. He wanted to come to Rockefeller University in New York (it was then called the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research) to begin his work.

title: Shorter Periods Of Service Possible For Draft Evaders
description: WASHINGTON, (AP)  The chairman of the Presidential Clemency Board announced today several factors that could lead to reduced alternative service and pardons for draft evaders and deserters.

title: Search for Protein Crucial In Struggle Against Hungert
description: Scientists are juggling plant genes, squeezing juice out of leaves and growing microorganisms on manure in a wideranging assault on one of the most fundamental problems of the world's food shortagehow to get more protein for more people.

title: Favorable Indicators on Economic Scene Buoy Prices of Corporate and Municipal Bonds
description: Corporate and municipal bonds scored impressive gains yesterday in response to a slowing in wholesale price increases and to the recent decline in shortterm interest rates. Dealers reported that a more favorably psychology crystallized among investors, as was apparent also in the sharp advance posted by the stock market.

title: Inflation Ease Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (Rtuter)Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Presidential Council of Economic Advisers, said to. day he expected to see some decline in the rate of inflation, perhaps 2 or 3 percentage points, by the spring of 1975.

title: 3 Share Nobel Prize
description: Three scientists whose work began the modern science of cell biology 30 years ago have been awarded the 1974 Nobel Prize for medicine or physiology. Page 22.

title: Evens Today
description: GOD OF VENGEANCE, a play presented by the Jewish Repertory Company, produced by John Fournier, directed by Ron Avni, at the Omol Theater Club, 145 West 18th Street. Performances Oct. 1013, 1720, 2427.

title: 3 CELL BIOLOGISTS GET NOBEL PRIZE
description: Three scientists whose innovations began the modern science of cell biology nearly 30 years ago and who have made numerous major contributions since to understanding the inner workings of living cells have been awarded the 1974 Nobel Prize for medicine or physiology.

title: Police Picket Mayor's Home
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 10 (UPI) Offduty Jersey City policemen and fire officers picketed the home of Mayor Paul T. Jordan and conducted a slowmoving, hornblowing motorcade around City Hall today to protest a contract impasse. A spokesman for the Mayor said a small group of pickets appeared at the Mayor's threestory West Side frame home about 7:15 A.M. and picketed for about an hour and a half.

title: Watergate Jury Quest
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10It Is virtually certain that Judge John J. Sirica will impanel a jury in the Watergate coverup case by tomorrow night, for when court closed tonight, he had formed a panel of 45 prospective jurors for the final screening. The question is whether it will be an impartial jury. Defense lawyers and other commentators have said that that seems improbable.

title: BUSINESS LOANS UP BY $64MILLION
description: Business loans were up a modest $64million at New York banks in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Two ExWhite Houses ...
description: San Clemente and Key Biscayne, though no longer the Western and Florida extensions of the White House, are still being maintained at a cost inappropriate for any former chief executive in a democratic nation, not to mention one who resigned under a cloud. As private residences of Richard Nixon, their extravagant staffing at public expense is at once ludicrous and offensive.

title: PRICES ON AMEX IAMB SHARPLY
description: With volume reaching the highest point in seven months, prices on the American Stock Exchange rose sharply again yesterday. Volume also was high in the counter market as prices continued to increase there for the second straight day, with investors apparently regaining confidence in the economy.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Union Carbide Expanding
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday it would spend $21million to develop a tungsten mine and mill 50 miles northwest of Alamo in Lincoln County, Nev. Startup of the underground mine and adjoining surface mill is scheduled for the third quarter of 1976, the company said.. Union Carbide said tungsten production capacity at the mine would be the second largest in the United States, exceeded only by its present Pine Creek, Calif., operation.

title: Chess: Korchnoi Show Determination But Allows Karpov to Draw
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10Viktor Korchnoi tried everything at his disposal in the style of Bobby Fischer, but he could not win his 10th finalcandidatesmatch game with Anatoly Karpov and it ended in a draw. Thus Karpov kept his two victoriestonone lead in the contest.

title: 71% in Poll Assert Nixon Should Face Questioning
description: Seventyone per cent of those surveyed believe former President Richard M. Nixon should be questioned at San Clemente, Calif., about the Watergate coverup even if he is too ill to travel to Washington for the trial of his former aides, the Louis Harris survey reported yesterday. Twentythree per cent said he should not and 6 per cent were undecided.

title: Ford's Edsel
description: President Ford has made two contradictory economic policy commitments: to sustain military spending and to combat inflation. That is like trying to drive a car with one foot on the accelerator and the other foot on the brakes.

title: 3 Brokers to Prospect for Prof its Gold.
description: Three of the nation's biggest stock brokerage houses announced plans yesterday to enter the gold business  including the biggest of them all, Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. The others are Bache & Co., Inc., and Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis. Inc. The brokerage houses are the first of at least 25 known to be interested in dealing in gold once public ownership becomes legal, now expected to happen in January.

title: 3 Debuts Liven Poppea
description: Monteverdi's L'Incoronazione di Poppea was given its only performance of the fall season Wednesday night by the New York City Opera with three cast members new to their roles and with Christopher Keene conducting the opera for the first time.

title: Holzman Ejected as Knicks Lose, 10192
description: Coach Red Holzman watched his Knicks reach some degree of respectability last night, first from the bench and later on cable television. At the same time the Boston Celtics may have found a temporary replacement at center for the injured Dave CowensJim Ard.

title: PreElection Politics
description: The House of Representatives is not distinguishing itself in these preelection days. Two of the most important bills that it has had before it throughout the sessionand that were considered almost sure to passare suddenly in deep trouble. A measure to provide long  term Federal assistance to mass transit systems, and another drastically to control stripmining, have been held up not because there has been mounting opposition in the House, but because of bungling in committee.

title: Reynolds Metals Earnings Up Sharply
A Tense, Troubled City
description: BOSTON, Oct, 10Only a few cities Chicago, Philadeldelphia, New York, Bostonhave kept the structures built by immigration, have retained the real ethnic blocs that support the whole fabric of those communities. Boston's strengths come from those neighborhoods with roots, tradition and higtory. They are also enclaves that resist change.

title: About New York Preserving a Nautical Heritage
description: The best place to remember that New York is a seaport is on Pier 16, sitting on a bench, watching the East River go by. The benches on Pier 16, in fact, may be the best benches in the city. Tugboats pass by them, and so do floating derricks, floating pile drivers, containerships, lighters, dredges, barges, fireboats, excursion Ships and Coast Guard cutters.

title: City Warned of Water Cut If Tocks Dam Is Defeated
description: TRENTON; Oct. 10A reduction in New York City's allocation of 800 million gallons of water a day from the upper Delaware River is a possibility if the controversial Tocks Island dam project is turned down, an official of the Army Corps of Engineers said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: Soviet Cautions Cairo on Shift to West
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10  With Secretary of State Kissinger meeting Egyptian leaders in Cairo, the Communist party newspaper Pravda today chastised Egypt for anew economic policy that opened the country to Western economic investment and influence.

title: Iran Denies Oil Prices Caused Inflation
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10Iran charged today that mismanagement of the economy and overconsumption in the United States and Europe, not the rise in oil prices, had triggered the current inflationary crises.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1974
description: International

title: Kennedy's Wife to Appear In Traffic Court on Nov. 6
description: McLEAN, Va., Oct. 10 (UPI) Joan Kennedy was ordered today to appear in Fairfax County traffic court Nov. 6 to answer a charge that she was driving under the influence of alcohol when her automobile struck another near here.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A management consultant firm headed by former Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton has been hired by New York State to make a study of its controversial state Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: Embarrassed Mills Acknbwledges That He Was in Limousine Stopped by Police
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Representative Wilbur D. Mills acknowledged today that he was a passenger in a limousine stopped by the police early Monday morning, for reckless driving and he attributed previous denials of his presence in the auto to a misunderstanding with his aides.

title: MINERS END STRIKE AGAINST TEXTBOOKS
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 10 (UPI)  Hundreds of coal miners returned to their jobs today, ending strikes touched off by roving pickets protesting socalled immoral textbooks used in Kanawha County schools.

title: Chairman of Joint Chiefs Says Inflation Could Alter Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Gen. George S. Brown, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs Staff, said today that the inflationary pinch on the defense budget could force significant changes in military forces and strategy.

title: Bangladesh Is Faced With LargeScale Deaths From Starvation
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Oct. 7  The people who survived months of floods in Bangladesh are now facing starvation.

title: Data Lag Seen Stalling Milk Case
description: The United States Department of Justice notified Representative Edward I. Koch, DemocratLiberal of Manhattan, that it could not decide if it should prosecute the Dairylea milkadulteration case because it had not received sufficient information from, the Department of Ag riculture.

title: U.S. Judge Bars Boycotts Of Denver School Busing
description: DENVER, Oct. 10 (AP)  A Federal court judge has extended a temporary restraining order prohibiting a citizens' group from promoting boycotts to protest busing to achieve racial integration in Denver's public schools.

title: Ronan and Port Authority
description: Q. Dr. Ronan, in view of the fact that you are receiving income from the Rockefellers and you're head of the Port Authority, isn't there a hard conflict right there? A. No. Let's look at the members of the board of the Port Authority. Who are they? Dr. William J. Ronan, who was holding his first news conference since it was disclosed that he had accepted $550,000 in gifts from former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, quickly an swered his own question.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Security at Schools Is Increased To Curb Outbreaks of Violence
description: Officials of the Board of Education said yesterday that the school system was taking all possible measures to curb current outbreaks of violence in several high schools.

title: Dutch Buy Control Of Bond Industries
description: Operating control of Bond industries, Inc., owners of the Bond clothing, stores, has been acquired by a Dutch company as a result of sales of stock by Bond's two top executives.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Atlantic City (Steel Pier), deduct 26 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: CAHILL CAMPAIGN IS STUDIED ANEW
description: TRENTON, Oct. 10William F. Hyland, the State Attorney General, said today that his office was investigating the possible embezzlement of funds from the 1969 campaign of former Gov. William T. Cahill.

title: Kings 5, flyers 3 In Opener
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 (UPI)Tom Williams got two goals, the second into an empty net from half the length of the ice with 20 seconds to play, as the Los Angeles Kings beat the Stanley Cup champion Philadelphia Flyers, 53, tonight in their opening National Hockey League game at the Spectrum.

title: State to Act on 62 Candidates For Lag on Financial Reports
description: ALBANY, Oct. 10The State Board of Elections will start civil proceeding in Supreme Court here tomorrow against 62 candidates for public office who, the board said today, failed to file reports of campaign receipts and expenditures or who filed late reports.

title: CONTINUED DEFENSE OF NIXON IS OFFERED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) The Justice Department has offered to continue representing former President Richard M.Nixon and his three closest advisers in civil suits pending against them, department officials acknowledged tonight.

title: State Hires Consultant Firm to Study Controversial MentalHealth Agency
description: A management  consultant firm headed by former Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton has been hired by New York State. to make a study of its controversial Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: People in Sports
description: Three of the most quicktempered figures in professional basketball were back in hot water yesterday as a result of their conduct in interleague preseason games etween the National Basketball Association and the American Basketball Association.

title: Rockefeller Gift to Logue Disclosed
description: Still another recipient of substantial gifts and loans from Nelson A, Rockefeller was made public last night.

title: Books of The Times
description: BED/TIME/STORY. By Jill Robinson. 307 pages. Random House. $7.95.

title: 100 Israelis Still on West Bank As Troops Round Up Settlers
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 10Israeli Army units, using helicopters, observation planes and command cars, searched ravines and dry river beds between Jerusalem and Jericho today, rounding up several hundred young Israelis who last night renewed attempts to establish unauthorized settlements in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: Cruel and Unusual Punishment
description: Since 1972, when the United States Supreme Court startled the legal world with a 54 decision invalidating almost all existing capital punishment laws, constitutional lawyers have pondered how the Court would respond, to the next death case to come before it. The country is about to find out.

title: SCRUTINIZE POLICE, KUH ORDERS STAFF
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan said yesterday that the members of his office were not partners of the police and Ordered his 200 assistants to scrutinize police performance from arrest through court testimony for possible misconduct.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Oct. 10Clary Anderson, football coach at Montelair State hasn't had a losing season in 32 years of coaching, but this year he established a personal record as the Indians opened with four straight victories.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOSTON, Oct, 10 (UPI)A Massachusetts judge extended today a temporary restraining order that blocks the sale of any stock owned by the Boston Celtics owner, Robert Schmertz, until a related case in California is settled.

title: Consumers With Complaints Can Let Their Fingers Do the Walking
description: New York consumers wondering about which government agency to call to file complaint, ask about the safety of a product, get information about a car warranty, find out about the wholesomeness of food or a gaggle of other inquiries can let their fingers do the walking these days.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON JERSEY PARK
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed yesterday to do the engineering and design work for preparation of a 500acre strip along the New Jersey shore near Ellis and Liberty Islands as the site of the future Liberty State Park.

title: $7.7BILLION VOTED AS MORTGAGE AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) The Senate passed unanimously and sent to the House today a $7.75billion emergency some mortgage bill that faced the threat of a veto by President Ford because of its inflationary nature.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
SpeedyTrial Bill Clears House Unit In Unanimous Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Controversial legislation to dismiss criminal charges against any Federal defendant who is not brought to trial within 100 days after arrest, already approved by the Senate, cleared its first hurdle in the House today.

title: Chess: Korchnoi Makes Another Bid As 11th Game Is Adjourned
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 11Viktor Korchnoi and Anatoly Karpov adjourned the 11th game of their final Candidates Match for the world championship in a difficult rookandminorpieces end game here in Tchaikowsky Hall tonight.

title: Player, Irwin Gain MatchPlay Final
description: VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 11Hale Irwin, a 91 shot at the teeoff yesterday, has reached the final of the Piccadilly World Match Play golf tournament, almost inevitably against Gary Player. And the reason he's there, Irwin said, is that part of the gallery cheered when he threeputted today, and that made me mad.

title: 3 Brands of Coffee Cut by 5c a Pound By General Foods
description: The General Foods Corporation, one of the nation's largest marketers of coffee, said yesterday that it had cut the prices to retailers for three of its brandsMaxwell House, Yuban and MaxPaxby 5 cents a pound to meet competitive conditions in the coffee business.

title: Business Leaders Expect Jobless Rise
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 11 (AP)The nation's top business leaders forecast today an increase in unemployment next year to 6.5 per cent but said they felt the country would avoid a serious recession.

title: Rockefeller Aide Is Linked To Book Scoring Goldberg
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The publishers of a derogatory biography of Arthur J. Goldberg said today that publication had been arranged by one of Nelson A. Rockefeller's close political associates, who offered to purchase 100,000 copies for distribution, mostly without charge, in the 1970 campaign for Governor of New York.

title: Candidates Fit District's 2 Faces
description: MOORESTOWN, Oct. 11The Sixth Congressional District zigzags across southern New Jersey as if it were torn from the pages of a political text on classical gerrymanders.

title: TURNPIKE SEEKING ITS FIRST TOLL RISE
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority proposed new toll rates yesterday that would increase the cost of trips for most New Jersey residents by 37 per cent and increase the cost of traveling the length of the highway by 54 per cent.

title: U.S. Takes Cup Singles For 20 Lead
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Oct. 11 (AP)  Arthur Ashe and Tom Gorman posted straightset victories today to give the strongly favored United States a 20 lead over the Commonwealth Caribbean team in a first round series of the 1975 American Zone Davis Cup.

title: COOK INDUSTRIES IN OPERATING LOSS
description: Cook Industries, Inc., one of the major grain companies which was prevented recently by the Government from exporting a total of 125 million bushels of wheat and corn to the Soviet Union, issued its unaudited report yesterday for the first fiscal quarter, ended Aug. 31.

title: Nation's Utilities Cut Back Construction Plans by 18%
description: The nation's electric utilities, hit hard by rising costs and slower growth in energy consumption, have cut back their construction budgets by 18 per cent for the next four years, a new study snows.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Saxbe Extends Furloughs For Freed Draft Evaders
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Attorney General William B. Saxbe today ordered a 30day extension of furloughs for draft evaders who were in prison until President Ford announced earned reentry program.

title: Protests Beef Retaliation
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 11Canada, which recently imposed severe import quotas on American beef and livestock, has protested to Washington against a White House proposal to place retaliatory restrictions on Canadian exports to the United States in the same categories.

title: Market Continues Its Climb To Achieve Best Week Ever
description: The stock market yesterday finished its best week in history. Some bullish economic news enabled the Dow Jones industrial average to climb 10.09 points yesterday to 658.17 and sent its advance for the week to 73.61 points, its largest weekly gain ever. The previous weekly record gain was 51.55 points set in the week ended June 7, 1974.

title: Russian Accuses Western Press of Campaign Against Detente
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 11  In a sweeping attack on the Western press, a senior Soviet commentator has charged major American, British, French and West German newspapers and especially The New York Times  with conducting a violent campaign against dtente.

title: World Series Opens Today With A's In Fighting Form to Meet Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11The Oakland A's, twotime champions of the baseball world who generate extracurricular controversies as naturally as they breathe, start trying to win their third straight World Series tomorrow as they face the Los Angeles Dodgers at 4 P.M., New York time.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city's Water Commissioner, Charles Samowitz, voiced alarm at suggestions that New York's water supply could be jeopardized if the controversial Tocks Island Dam on the Delaware River was not built Maybe it's a ploy maybe it's their way of enlisting our support for the dam, he said.

title: Notes on People
description: The resignations of two mainstays of the White House staff of Richard M. Nixon have been accepted by President Ford, it was announced yesterday. Fred Buzhardt, who as legal counsel to the former President fashioned Mr. Nixon's legal fight to stave off impeachment, left his post on Oct. 5. Patrick J. Buchanan, a publicrelations adviser and speechwriter who helped fashion the Administration's attacks on newsgathering organizations, has resigned effective Nov. 15, said Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary. Mr. Nessen said lie did not know the future plans of Mr. Buzhardt and Mr. Buchanan, who had been asked by Mr. Ford to stay on at the White House during the of transition.

title: Tocks Issue Alarms New York
description: TRENTON, Oct. 11A representative of the New York City Department of Water Resources will attend a hearing at the Delaware Water Gap in Pennsylvania tomorrow to protest any reconsideration of the amount of water available to the city from the upper Delaware River.

title: U.N. Assembly Elects Five Nations to Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N, Oct. 11The General Assembly elected five countries to the Security Council todaySweden, Italy, Guyana, Tanzania and Japan.

title: Dismissed Partner Is Accused Of $1.5Million Law Fee Theft
description: A former partner in a large Wall Street law firm has been charged with misappropriating more than $1.5million in fees paid his firm.

title: Third of Teachers Stay Out in Boycott On Bilingual Issue
description: NEWARK, Oct. 11  More than a third of the teachers involved in the city's troubled bilingual education program for Hispanic students stayed away from their jobs today in support of a boycott of the program.

title: The ForeignAid Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11For many on Capitol Hill, the current dispute between the White House and Congress over military aid to Turkey represents an assertion of Congressional prerogatives against Presidential predominance in national security policy. They see the dispute as an expression of the majority will against the prestige and control of Congressional leadership, as a debate over basic foreignpolicy priorities and simply as a test of whether the law will be carried out ?? ignored.

title: Baker Hints Repeal of Plan On Appointed Vice President
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 11 (UPI)  The constitutional amendment providing for the appointment of a Vice President should be repealed because it is unworkable, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, said today.

title: Text of Rockefeller Letter and a List of Recipients of Gifts and Loans by Him
description: Following is the text of a letter sent yesterday by Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller to the chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, and of the list of recipients of gifts and loans from Mr. Rockefeller as released by him. The list includes several corrections regarding transactions reported as gifts.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE QUIET WARRIOR: A Biography of Adm. Raymond A. Spruance. By Thomas B. Buell. 486 pages. Little, Brown. $15.

title: Revelations to Savor In David Smith's Art
description: When the American sculphe left an enormous body of work drawings and paintings as well as a considerable number of sculptures  that had seldom or, in some cases, never been exhibited in his lifetime. Despite the splendid exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum five years ago and frequent gallery shows over the years, there remain many aspects of his oeuvreone of the greatest to be created by a sculptor in this centurythat are familiar only to specialists who have studied his work closely. For many people, even those who think they know Smith's work on the basis of a few widely published masterpieces, there are still discoveries to be made and revelations to be savored.

title: City Council Urged to Co Slow On Bill to Recycle Excess Heat
description: A City Council committee was advised yesterday to exercise caution in considering a bill that would require systems that recycle excess heat in all new buildings to conserve fuel.

title: 4 Democrats Are Heard At Educational Alliance
description: Four Democratic candidates, including the gubernatorial nominee, Representative Hugh L. Carey, addressed an audience of 250 older men and wo, men last night in the Educational Alliance Building, at 197 East Broadway.

title: State, Contending Overcharge, Won't Pay Rent to Trade Center
description: The New York State Controller's office, contending the state has been consistently overcharged by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for office space in the World Trade Center, has refused to pay more than $3million in rent bills and is continuing to withhold payments at a rate of $115,000 a month.

title: 7 Indicted for Sale of 2.6Million in Stolen Securities
description: Seven defendants were named yesterday in a series of indictments involving. the alleged sale of $2.6million in stolen securities and $186,000 in hijacked cloth, as well as an alleged scheme to sell $12million in stolen United States Treasury bills.

title: Curb on Oil Prices to Be ChangedPlan for Gas Decontrol Defended
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) Treasury Secretary William E. Simon, said today the Administration was willing to accept legislation ending the oil depletion allowance and had no intention now of abandoning price controls on oil, But he added that the White House intended to change the price control system in a manner that, experts say would add $4.4billion to the nation's petroleum costs.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: House Supports Ford on $300Billion Budget Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11In a gesture of cooperation with President Ford, the House of Representatives passed by a vote of 329 to 20 today a resolution setting $300billion as the target spending ceiling for the Federal budget for the fiscal year 1975.

title: The Saga of Columbus Is ReEnacted at the Civic Center in Brooklyn
description: The front yard of the Brooklyn Civic Center, at Court and Montague Streets bcame San Salvador for a time yesterday as a modernday Christopher Columbus debarked from a 50foot model of his 117foot flagship, Santa Maria, and took formal possession of the island in the names of Their Most Catholic Majesties.

title: LABOR'S MAJORITY IN BRITAIN NARROW
description: LONDON, Oct. 11  Prime Minister Harold Wilson and his Labor party have been returned to power by the voters with a hairline margin of victory over all other parties.

title: Stage: An O'Neill First
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 11 It was Stark Young who once suggested that the special poignancy of Eugene O'Neill's plays had nothing much to do with the quality of the writing, but that the plays and the characters seem to have been torn out of O'Neill by force. We tremble at the suffering of the author rather than the sufferings of the characters. It is an acute observation and helps to explain the ferocious power O'Neill exerts on his admirers.

title: NORTHROP ADMITS TO A SECRET FUND
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11A vice president of the Northrop Corporation has admitted in deposition that the defense contractor maintained a secret political slush fund of up to $1.2million, according to documents filed in Federal District Court here this week.

title: EINAR G. CHINDMARK
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 11 (AP)Einar G. Chindmark, chief photographer of The Hartford Times for 31 years, died last night at Hartford Hospital. His age was 62. He retired in May.

title: 2 NIXON AIDES PUT COVERUP BLAME ON EXPRESIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 John D. Ehrlichman and H. R Haldeman contended in lega papers made public today tha they urged President Nixon in the summer of 1972 to mak( a full and complete dis closure of the Watergate affair.

title: Dahlia Is Brightest Star in Hunt's Stable
description: Two kittens scrambling for balance on a fence rail at Belmont Park caught the attention of Dahlia yesterday, and racing's top glamour girl craned her neck to watch.

title: Soviet Refuses to Lift Its Ban On U.S. Newsmen at Launching
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) The Soviet Union has repeatedly rejected requests that United States newsmen he permitted to view the launching of Soviet austronauts during next year's joint space effort. But Russian newsmen wil lbe able to view the liftoff of the American astronauts from Cape Canaveral.

title: Nuclear Plant Reopens
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 11 (AP) The Maine Yankee nuclear power plant at Wiscaset resumed operations today. The plant was closed in June for routine maintenance and inspection of the closed primary water system where radioactive leakage had been reported.

title: WINE TALK
description: The winemakers of the Sauternes region of France are sure that they make one of the great wines of the world and it vexes them no end that their work goes largely unnoticed by the people who should be their customers.

title: Antiques
description: AMHERST, Mass.  Some visitors to the folk art show here at the Mead Art Building of Amherst College may find their attention riveted on the walls where, among other rarely seen treasures, are five portraits attributed to Ammi Phillips and five more to Erastus Salisbury Field.

title: Bank Loans to 6 Union Aides Studied
description: A Federal grand grand jury ester is investigating the legality of bank loans totaling $200,000 to six officials of the carpenter's union, allegadly arranged by executives of the now bankrupt Stirling Homex Corporation.

title: Church Leader Disputes Pope Paul on Violence
description: ROME, Oct. 11The Rea, Philip A. Potter, a West Indian Methodist minister, who is head of the World Council of Churches, took issue here today with Pope Paul VI's recent strictures against violence and revolution.

title: Giants' Star Vexed by Inconsistency on Field Goals
description: At a time when the New York Giants need a big kick somewhere, Pete Gogolak conceded yesterday that he was in a slump.

title: STEVE HAMAS, BEAT SCHMELING IN 1934
description: NORTHPORT, L. I., Oct. 11 (AP)Steve Hamas, an athletic star at Pennsylvania State University who turned to professional boxing and once defeated Max Schmeling, died today at Northport Veterans Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: Napoleon's Patch on Uncle Sam's Breeches
description: PORT WASHINGTON, N. Y.Napoleon, who commanded the finances of a nation as well as its armies, once ordered his astounded tailor to patch pair of riding breeches that were worn through at the seat.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was

title: A's Are at It Again: Fingers Vs. Odom, Hunter Vs. Finley
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11As preWorld Series workouts go, the Oakland A's staged a tumultuous one today, even by their wellestablished uninhibited standards.

title: Choir Trip Hits Responsive Note
description: MERRICK, L.I., Oct. 11The letters keep comingfrom Japan and London and Greenwichmost of them with checks fluttering out of them.

title: In African Desert, Boom City of 1,198
description: GHANZI, BotswanaTravelers in the Kalahari Desert know they are in Ghanzi District when fences begin to appear on either side of the desert road.

title: Liberals' Hopes in Britain Dribble Away at the Polls
description: LONDON, Oct. 11The British election yesterday froze for any near future the hopes of the Liberals of breaking out of their perennial smallparty status.

title: Catholics and Jews Planning 3 InterReligious Study Tours
description: A Roman Catholic religious order and the American Jewish Committee plan three interreligious study missions to Jerusalem and Rome to investigate the Jewish roots of the Roman Catholic Holy Year.

title: Maurice Mermey, 73 Dies; A PublicRelations Figure
description: Maurice Mermey, who retired in 1970 as vice chairman of Edward Gottlieb & Associates public relations, died Thursday In Larchmont, N. Y., where he lived. His age was 73.

title: Radio
House Blocks Bid to Delay Cutoff of U.S. Aid to Turks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The House of Repjresentatives narrowly defeated today a compromise measure that would have enabled President Ford to delay until Dec. 15 a cutoff of military aid to Turkey. The vote was 187 to 171.

title: 2 SIDES IN BOSTON MEET AND BICKER
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11  Five white antibusing activists and five black community leaders met secretly in City Hall this afternoon and screamed at each other for nearly three hours.

title: Rockefeller Aide Is Linked To Book Scoring Goldberg
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The publishers of a derogatory biography of Arthur J. Goldberg said today that publication had been arranged by one of Nelson A. Rockefeller's close political associates, who offered to purchase. 100,000 copies for distribution, mostly without chirge, in the 1970 campaign for Governor of New York.

title: New Utrecht, Lane High Schools Resume With Light Attendance
description: Classes resumed yesterday at New Utrecht High School in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, but the normal attendance of about 4,300 students was cut by 50 per cent, school officials said.

title: 2 NIXON AIDES PUT COVERUP BLAME ON EXPRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 John D. Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman contended in legal papers made public today that they urged President Nixon in the summer of 1972 to make a full and complete disclosure of the Watergate affair.

title: People and Business
description: John W. Ingram, the Federal Railroad Administrator, is expected to be offered a top job with the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad, possibly on Monday, when directors of that financially failing system hold a special meeting in Chicago. Mr. Ingram, 45 years old, who started in 1943 as a brakeman with the Long Island Rail Road, worked for the New York Central, the Southern and the Illinois Central railroads before he was named the Railroad Administrator four years ago when Reginald N. Whitman left the post to become chief executive of the MissouriKansasTexas Railway, another financially pressed carrier. The Rock Island Railroad is seeking a $100million loan from the United States Railway Association to help it finance a capitalimprovement program.

title: System Is Devised for Gasification of Coal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 President Ford remarked in an address to a joint session of Congress last Tuesday that, among other things, we must work harder on coal gasification. By coincidence, a professor of chemical engineering at the City College of New York was granted a patent on the same day for a system of gasification from which he expects great speed and capacity. Dr. Arthur M. Squires received Patent 3,840,353 for a process that uses a fast fluidized bed and is said to produce a rich quality of fuel gas. The research is being financed by the Government.

title: Joffrey Begins Repertory With Exuberant Sparkle
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet swung into repertory Thursday night at the City Center with Robert Joffrey's Remembrances and two ballets by Gerald Arpino, Viva Vivaldi! and Trinity.

title: U.S. Officials Receive Reports Of a Major Mexican Oil Find
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 Highranking United States Government officials said tonight that they had recieved reports from sources in the oil industry of a major petroleum discovery in Mexico.

title: MRS. FORD HAPPY TO BE HOME AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 Betty Ford, looking radiantly happy, returned to the White House today after two weeks in the hospital.

title: Civil Defense Council Elects
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 11 (AP) Walter D. Hyle Jr. was elected president of the United States Civil Defense Council yesterday to take office at the start of next year.

title: FRANCIS J. McINTEE
description: Francis J. McIntee, who retired in 1972 as president of Consolidated Color Press, Inc., 50 West 17th Street, died yesterday at his home, 85 Mountain Avenue, New Rochelle, N. Y. He was 72 years old.

title: WEEDEN & CO. CITES 7.2MILLION NET LOSS
description: Weeden & Co., the largest of Wall Street's third market firms, reported yesterday a net loss of $7.2million for the year ending Sept. 30. A year ago, the firm lost $2.3million.

title: Two Indicted for Bilking Retail Stores of $700,000
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 (AP)A New York City lawyer and an Alabama merchant have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges they bilked retail stores in nine states of more than $700,000.

title: Man o' War Lists 14; Dahlia Rated Choice
description: Dahlia may have been somewhat fretful at her reception at quarantine after she arrived from France Tuesday night, but that experience has not affected her status as the 31 favorite in today's Man o' War at Belmont Park.

title: Fruits of '64 Speech Revolt Are Still Visible at Berkeley
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 11 No one saw where it came from but everyone felt its force; and when it had gone, things would never be same.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (Reuters)The chairman the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Thomas Bomar, announced today a proposed regulation lifting some restrictions on the acceptance of payment orders by Federal savings and loan associations.

title: S.E.C. Suit Settled By Sunshine Mining
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued the Sunshine Mining Company here yesterday for failure to make full disclosure and obtained a settlement in less than two hours.

title: LISBON AIDE SEES THREAT FROM C.I.A.
description: LISBON, Oct. 11 (AP)The chief of Portuguese military security said today that the United States Central Intelligence Agency was a gravel problem for his country.

title: Max L. Grant Is Dead at 85; Industrialist, Philanthropist
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 11 (AP)Max L. Grant, millionaire industrialist and philanthropist, died today. He was 85 years old.

title: Dismissed Partner Is Accused Of $1.5Million Law Fee Theft
description: A former partner in a large Wall Street law firm has been charged with misappropriating more than $1.5million in fees paid his firm.

title: Stage: The Possessed, Clear Vision of Torment
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 10Andrzej Wajda's The Possessed, which had its America premiere last night at the Yale Repertory Theater, is a deep excavation into the heart of Dostoyevsky's masterpiece. Drawing upon Albert Camus's adaptation (translated by Justin O'Brien), this play by the noted Polish film and stage director, is a tormented vision of a world consuming itself.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Full Game's Work on Tap For Ohio State, Oklahoma
description: Archie Griffin of Ohio State and Joe Washington of Oklahoma have been parttime runners so far this season, not because they are hurting or are unable to do their job, but because they and their teammates have been doing too good a job so far.

title: Cairo Seems Cooler About This Kissinger Trip
description: CAIRO, Oct. 11Egyptian sources said pointedly today that the outcome of the talks last night between President Anwar elSadat and Secretary of State Kissinger could not be assessed until the results of Mr. Kissinger's visit to Israel were known.

title: ROCKEFELLER LISTS GIFTS AND LOANS TO 20 RECIPIENTS
description: Vice Presidentdesignate son A. Rockefeller provides more detailed look at his gifts and loans last night, making public a list of 20 present and former public officials and staff assistants to whom he had given approximately $2million over the last 17 years.

title: S.E.C. MAY EXPAND DISCLOSURE RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today to require increased disclosure of relationships between registered corporations and their independent public accountants.

title: Fruits of '64 Speech Revolt Are Still Visible at Berkeley
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 11 No one saw where it came from but everyone felt its force; and when it had gone, things would never be the same.

title: Kissinger Steps Up Mideast Pace, but Acts With Care
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 11Secretary of State Kissinger flew to Damascus this morning and then to the Jordanian capital late tonight to seek support for his efforts to get a new round of ArabIsraeli negotiations started and to maintain momentum toward Middle East settlement.

title: Brezhnev Urges Talks on Mideast At Earliest Date
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 11Leonid L Brezhnev. the Soviet Communist leader, urged today that the Middle East peace talks in Geneva be reconvened at the earliest date. He contended that further delay would mean sitting on a powder keg which might blow up at any moment.

title: JOHN E. HEYKE JR., UTILITIES HEAD, 64
description: John E. Heyke Jr., board chairman and chief executive officer of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday. He was 64 years old.

title: Crop Report a Factor
description: The latest Government crop report, issued after the close of trading on Thursday, had its impact on many markets yesterday.

title: Dave Anderson
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11In discussing the World Series that begins tomorrow, a baseballphile who lives New York declared quite seriously, but quite forgetfully:

title: Price Stability Panel Pledges Vigorous Action
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The Council on Wage and Price Stability held its firs: meeting today, promised vigorous use of public hearings and said its initial price investigations might concern sugar and antifreeze:

title: Executone and Union Reach Agreement on 2Year Pact
description: Executone, Inc., and Local 431 of the International Union of Electrical Workers reached agreement yesterday on a twoyear contract, ending a strike that began Oct. 1.

title: Allan D. Cruickshank, 67, Dies; Noted Ornithologist and Author
description: Allan Dudley Cruickshank, a nationally known ornithologist who has been described as a modern Audubon with a camera, died yesterday in a Gainesville, Fla., hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Rockledge, Fla.

title: Pearl Buck Ruling Fought
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 11 (AP)The decision overturning the will of Pearl S. Buck, the deceased Nobel Prizewinning author, has been appealed to the State Supreme Court. Frederick Pope, a Brattleboro lawyer representing the executors of the will, filed the appeal this week.

title: Willowbrook Is Assailed By Unit on the Retarded
description: Operations at Willowbrook, the state institution on Staten Island for the mentally retarded, were assailed yesterday at the convention here of the New York State Association for the Mentally Retarded.

title: Looking Into An Aegean Crystal Ball
description: ATHENSThe solution of the Cyprus crisis is essentially predicated on three things: continuation of a Caramaalis regime in Greece; maintenance of some kind of cogent government in a confused Turkish political situation; and a successful American diplomatic intervention that produces tangible evidence of a desire for compromise on Turkey's part.

title: SALES INCREASES AT STORES SMALL
description: September sales of New York's seven largest stores showed the smallest monthly gain in the last six months, all but reversing a strong business trend that has been one of the city's brightest economic indicators.

title: Miss Hickey Bride Of John Galvin 4th
description: Suzanne Marie Hickey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Norman Hickey of Short Hills, N. J., was married there yesterday evening to John Thomas Galvin 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Galvin 3d of Baltimore.

title: Yugoslavia: Behind the Revelry, Retreat
description: NOVI SAD, YugoslaviaYugoslavia recently went through a period of official triumph concerning the successful consolidation of the League of Communists, the liquidation of all attempts at factional differences of opinion in the party and the reintroduction of orthodox Marxism and Leninism into all spheres of society.

title: After Breast Cancer Surgery, Exercises Become Way of Life
description: On a recent evening, Carole Schreck sat at the kitchen table in her small studio apartment on East 89th Street and remembered. Her memories weren't always pleasant. They were of the days when she was in the same situation that Betty Ford is in nowphysical rehabilitation following a radical mastectomy.

title: Bullets Capitalize On Nets' OffNight
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 11 Despite a 11094 preseason victory over the New York Nets before a crowd of 9,149 in the Nassau Coliseum tonight, Coach K.C. Jones of the Washington Bullets wasn't too pleased with his team's performance.

title: PRIME RATE IS CUT BY 2 LARGE BANKS
description: In a further move toward lower interest rates, two of the nation's largest banks the First National City Bank here and the First National Bank of Chicagoyesterday cut the rate they charge on loans to their best corporate customers.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Michael Chinigo, 66, Dead; A Foreign Correspondent
description: ROME, Oct. 11 (AP)Michael Chinigo, 66 years old, a longtime foreign correspondent, for the nowdefunct International News Service and United States newspapers, died today from a bullet wound in the head suffered two months ago. The police said then that the wound had been selfinflicted.

title: Variety Shows to Make Winter Comeback on TV
description: The television variety show, which went into a decline as a primetime staple when rock became the dominant form of popular music, will be making something of a comeback this winter when the networks make their midseason changes.

title: Servicemen's Clubs In Central London Hit by 3 Explosions
description: LONDON, Oct. 11 (Reuters) Three bombs exploded to night in two London military clubs, sending scores of men and women in evening dress fleeing into glassstrewn streets. One person was injured.

title: FRANK SLOAN WILE
description: Frank Sloan Wile, former United States Consul General in Zurich and Liechtenstein, died Monday in Walter Reed Hospital, Washington. He was 49 years old and lived in Kensington, Md.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 3??

title: DEFICIT IN BRITAIN WIDENS IN MONTE
description: LONDON, Oct. 11In its first eonomic report following yesterday's national election, the Government said today that Britain's trade position had deteriorated in September.

title: Bach v. Rock
description: Bach is still holding the fort against the rock disk jockeys poised for an assault upon WNCNFM in New York, The attempt by its owners to change the format of the stationone of the few on the radio dial playing classical musicis now before the United States Court of Appeals in Washington.

title: Clark Attacks High Food Prices and Monopolies
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 11Ramsey Clark turned his campaign to an attack on soaring food prices and agricultural monopolies in lowkey appearances yesterday in New York City and upstate areas.

title: Kitchen Opens 3d Music Season With Lectures by Tom Johnson
description: The Kitchenthat worthy locale for new music and video experimentation now at Wooster and Broome Streetsopened its third music season Wednesday with the first of three consecutive evening programs of works by Torn Johnson.

title: Soybean Has Become the Focus of Drive to Give More Protein to the World's Hungry
description: One of the geatest hopes in the drive to provide more and better protein for the peoples of the world is the soybean, a bittertasting legume that has been used by Asians for centuries as a major protein source.

title: Hesburgh Awarded Degree
description: SEWANEE, Tenn., Oct. 11 (AP)The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, Roman Catholic president of the University of Notre Dame, was awarded an honorary doctor of laws degree yesterday by the University of the South, operated by the Episcopal Church.. Father Hesburgh delivered the university's annual Founder's Day address.

title: Art : Liberman Paintings Keep Their Pristine Look
description: When it first comes out, the art of Alexander Liberman has a way of looking too sleek for its own good. It is the work of someone who has looked at everything, who knows exactly what can be done with any given materials, and who is not at all a fool. And of course the blankness and the impersonality are deliberate. Mr. Liberman wants his pictures to gleam like bathroom fittings and his sculptures to come out just right, without a rogue nut or bolt.

title: SUPPORT IS GIVER TO CONTRACEPTIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11A panel of outside experts has advised the Food and Drug Administration that the socalled Dalkon Shield appears to be about as safe as other commonly used intrauterine contraceptive devices.

title: Vice President Elected By American Lutherans
description: DETROIT, Oct. 11 (UPI)the general convention of the American Lutheran Church elected the Rev. Dr. Fred W. Meuser today as vice president and received a proposal that it budget $26.2million for the work of the church in 1975.

title: Elaine K. Siris Is Wed to Norman Winik
description: Elaine K. Siris of Rye, N.Y., national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal's women's division, was married yesterday noon to Norman Winik of Harrison, N.Y., in the Jewish Community Center of White Plains by Rabbi Maurice Davis.

title: Crafts of Israel, And Ruth Dayan
description: Ruth Dayan began the working part of a 10day visit to New York yesterday at her usual pace  jet speed. She spent much of the time recounting some of her experiences as the dynamic director of Israel's craft movement.

title: Credibility on Inflation
description: As President Ford suggested in his speech to Congress, one of the more effective ways to curb inflation is to make a concerted attack on the governmental and private institutional arrangements that prop up prices and protect cushy situations for the benefit of a few producers at the expense of all consumers. Such arrangements include import quotas, export subsidies, exemptions from the antitrust laws, price maintenance agreements between manufacturers and retailers, licenses and other restrictions on the access of newcomers into industries such as trucking, and Federal regulations that prevent price competition as in the airline industry. Lewis A. Engman, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, highlighted several of these anticonsumer arrangements in a remarkable public statement earlier this week.

title: STUDY ASKS EASING OF MARIJUANA LAW
description: TRENTON, Oct, 11A special legislative Narcotics Study Commission today urged the decriminalization of the use of small amounts of marijuana in New Jersey, making its use a civil matter no more serious than a parking violation.

title: Herzfeld & Stern Is Fined
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported Thursday that a member, Herzfeld & Stern, had been fined $10,000 for per. Imitting the comingling of customer and firm securities in hank loans. A spokesman said the firm had instituted new controls to prevent a recurrence.

title: The Bishops: Synod Shows a Human Side
description: ROME, Oct. 11Pope Paul VI attends most of the full sessions of the Synod of Bishops, facing the Bishops. When he hears a speech that impresses him by Its spirituality, he greets the speaker, arms extended forward, palms upward, hands fluttering slowly.

title: Miami Wins, 356, From U. of Pacific
description: MIAMI, Oct. 11 (AP)Woodie Thompson, Johnnie Williams and Kary Baker each ran for more than 400 yards as Miami defeated University of the Pacific, 35.6, tonight.

title: House Blocks Bid to Delay Cutoff of. U.S. Aid to Turks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The House of Representatives narrowly defeated today a compromise measure that would have enabled President Ford to delay until Dec. 15 a cutoff of military aid to Turkey. The vote was 187 to 171.

title: HERMIT QUOTAS OFFERED TO COURT
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Oct. 11 (Reuters)New quotas proposed for creditors of Bankhaus I. D. Herstatt have been made official, the office of the independent negotiator, Giinter Vogelsang, announced today.

title: AGENCY ASSAILED ON PROJECT POLICE
description: Joseph Balzano, president of the Housing Authority Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, angrily walked out of a meeting with Housing Authority officials yesterday. He charged the authority with refusing to add manpower to protect the lives of its patrolmen in the face of a 100 per cent increase in crime in the last eight years.

title: EARNINGS UP 7.5% AT BANKERS TRUST
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the holding company that owns the Bankers Trust Company, New York's sixth largest bank, reported yesterday that thirdquarter operating earnings rose 7.5 per cent.

title: Screens Alvin Purple
description: Alvin Purple is the playboy of the southern world, an unprepossessing young Australian who, for absolutely no reason brought forth by the makers of the movie that bears his name, is irresistible to women.

title: Nation's Utilities Cut Back Construction Plans by 18%
description: The nation's electric utilities, hit hard by rising costs and slower growth in energy consumption, have cut back their construction budgets by 18 pet cent for the next four years, a new study shows.

title: Jobless Rise Seen
description: The nation's top business leaders forecast yesterday an increase in unemployment next year to 6.5 per cent but said they felt the country would avoid a serious recession. Details on Page 44.

title: Patterson Captures Pace, Too
description: YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 11 John Patterson, Sr., the Baptist preacher from Dalton, Ga., gained his second windfall of the week tonight at Yonkers Raceway when he scored with Chief Rival in the $100,000 New York Sires Stakes Pace for 3yearolds colts and geldings.

title: Rockland Congress Race Is Rerun of '72
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 9 The campaign in the 26th Congressional District is in many ways a rerun of the local election in 1972, offering the voters a clearcut choice among a liberal Democrat, a moderate Republican and a Conservative party candidate.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FABULOUS? Downtown Flatbush Avenue has been called many things, many of them uncomplimentary, and seldom, if ever, fabulous. But forget all that because today the broad avenue from Grand Army Plaza westward to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Atlantic Avenue is the Fabulous Flatbush Avenue Festival complete with a proclamation from Mayor Borne.

title: Kissinger Bodyguard Grazed As Machine Gun Goes Off on Jet
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 11Secretary of State Kissinger's departure from Cairo this morning was delayed half an hour after one of his bodyguards was accidentally wounded as the Air Force 707 jet was taxiing for its takeoff.

title: Javits Sees Productivity As Way to Fight Inflation
description: JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Oct 11 Senator Jacob K. Javits urged here today the creation of regional labormanagement productivity councils as a means of fighting inflation.

title: NORTHROP ADMITS TO A SECRET FUND
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11A vice president of the Northrop Corporation has admitted in a deposition that the defense contractor maintained a secret political slush fund of up to $1.2million, according to documents filed in Federal District Court here this week.

title: TV: The Reflections of a 'Conscience of Our Time'
description: Tomorrow at 1 P.M., Directions, a production of ABC News, presents an unusually compelling halfhour called Simon Wiesenthai: A Conscience for Our Time. Mr. Wiesenthal, who has earned an international repu tation for locating and helping bring to trial the men who ran the Nazi death camps, is interviewed at his home in Vienna and at the

title: JOHN H. KREY
description: John H. Krey, long associated with investment banking concerns in this city, died Thursday evening in a hospital in Richmond. He was 73 years old and lived in Richmond.

title: Sherwin's Attorney to Ask Stay Monday
description: NEWARK, Oct. 11The attorney for Paul J. Sherwin, the former New Jersey Secretary of State, said today that he would appeal Monday for an emergency stay of his client's oneto twoyear sentence for bribery and conspiracy.

title: Farmers in India Ponder Gloomy Fate
description: SIKAR, IndiaThe earth is parched. The wheat crop has withered. The tough farmers, who eke out a living on the flat plains of the Rajasthan desert, are alarmed.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: A 74yearold woman, shot and critically wounded as she stood over her grandson's grave, died yesterday at Perth Amboy General Hospital. The police said they were certain the shooting had been done by the woman's soninlaw, who committed suicide seconds later. The two bodies were found Wednesday night a few feet apart at Holy Rosary Cemetery in Woodbridge.

title: West Side Man, 24, Arraigned In Killing of Woman Neighbor
description: A 24yearold man who is accused of stabbing an elderly woman to death in a shabby Upper West Side Hotel on Thursday was described by neighbors yesterday as a very bright and articulate person who began acting erratically several months ago.

title: CAREY SAYS BUSING IS OUTMODED TOOL
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey said yesterday that school busing was now an outmoded tool in New York City and that the emphasis should be oh providing quality education for all children.

title: Gurney Reply Scores U.S.
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 11 (AP)Senator Edward J. Gurney, who is charged with conspiracy, bribery and perjury, said today that the Federal Government wanted to humiliate him by trying to fingerprint and photograph him. The. Florida Republican, a member of the Senate Watergate cornmittee, made that reply to a Government motion asking a Federal judge to order him to go through the routine processing of a person accused of a crime.

title: SYLVANIA IN ACCORD FOR PHILCO'S NAME
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct 11 (AP)GTE Sylvania, Inc., will acquire the Philco name and distribution rights for home entertainment products made by PhilcoFord and sold in the United States and Canada, according to an agreement announced by the companies.

title: Brezhnev Urges Talks on Mideast At Earliest Date
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 11Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist leader, urged today that the Middle East peace talks in Geneva be reconvened at the earliest date. He contended that further delay would mean sitting on a pow der keg which might blow up at any moment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One of the measures that should be considered in the fight against inflation should be restrictions on the issuance and use of credit cards and checking accounts, or demand deposits.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: 7 Santo Domingo Terrorists Are in Hospital in Panama
description: PANAMA CITY, Oct. 12 (UPI) Seven terrorists granted political asylum by Panama after they released seven hostages they had held in the Venezuelan consulate in Santo Domingo in the Dominican Republic were under medical observation at Santo Tomas Hospital here today.

title: Farm Fair on L.I. Recalls Bygone Days
description: OLD BETHPAGE, L. I., Oct. 11 Farming, a steadily declining occupation on Long Island, was honored and highlighted here today.

title: MILLS AIDE REPORTS REPRESENT ATIVE ILL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) After promising to appear at his office for the first time since he had a runin with the police early Monday morning, Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, called in sick today.

title: State, Contending Overcharge, Won't Pay Rent to Trade Center
description: The New York State Controller's office, contending the ?? has been consistently overcharged by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for office space in the World Trade Center, h.as refused to pay more than $3million in rent bills and is continuing to withhold payments at a rate of $115,000 a month.

title: NIXON ACCEPTS AID FROM U.S. ON SUITS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) Former President Richard Nixon has accepted a Justice,, Department offer to continue defending him in civil suits that allege improper political harassment while he was in office, a spokesman for Mr. Nixon's attorney said today.

title: Says He Will Warn Ford. Against Crash Program to Develop Them
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The Federal Energy Administrator, John C. Sawhill, disclosed today that he would advise President Ford against a crash program to develop synthetic fuels in the next 10 years.

title: School Vote Reform
description: When the Legislature ignored the State Education Department's valid and urgent plea for reform of the city's Community School Board election procedures, it left in limbo the next round of balloting on May 1, 1975. Lack of proper preparation and supervision of these elections has been underscored by disclosure of irregularities, with their resultant confrontations, which in some instances required intervention by the courts.

title: Labor's Slim Victory
description: For the second time this year, the British people have delivered an indecisive verdict in a general election. They voted to continue in office the sevenmonthold Labor Government of Prime Minister Harold Wilson but provided it with only a minuscule majority in the House of Commons. They were much more emphatic about rejecting the Conservative party, which had lost power by the narrowest of margins in February, than they were about raising Mr. Wilson's administration from minority to majority standing.

title: PRIME RATE IS CUT BY 2 LARGE BANKS
description: In a further move toward lower interest rates, two of the nation's largest banks  the First National City Bank here and the First National Bank of Chicagoyesterday cut the rate they charge on loans to their best corporate customers.

title: Bridge: Phantom Created in a Game Can Be Difficult to Identify
description: In bridge as elsewhere it is not always easy to identify a phantom. If you sacrifice in four spades against four hearts and go down one or two tricks doubled, you can reasonably hope to show a theoretical profit, depending on the vulnerability. But if it proves subsequently that four hearts would have failed, then you have created a phantom and suffered a heavy loss.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INZAI. Japan, Oct. 11 (AP)Don Bies won the $2,000 prize for the day's low score of 67 and shared the lead with three other American pros and a Japanese after the second round of the $300,000 Pacific invitation golf tournament. His fourunderpar performance on the 7,187yard Tobu Country Club course today gave Bies a 36hole total of 140, two under par, and a tie with Hubert Green, Jim Simons, Bob Menne and Kosaku Shimada.

title: ABRAMS DEBATES WITH LEFKOWITZ
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx engaged in a vigorous debate before a City Club luncheon at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday in, facetoface confrontation of their contest for Mr. Lefkowitz's post.

title: Undermining the Law
description: Despite justified expressions of outrage from Mayor Kevin White and Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity, a Presidential spokesman says that Mr. Ford has second thoughts on his clumsy and harmful news conference remarks criticizing the Boston school decision.

title: Concert
description: In older musical histories Ives was discussed, if at all, as a composer who performed interesting experiments despite being trapped in the cultural backwaters of New England and New York City. We know now that the man whose centennial is being celebrated this year heard a great deal of what in his day was contemporary music, and must have been deeply influenced by it.

title: Neville Thinks Club Is Good Enough to Beat Jets
description: It was as if someone played a bad joke on Tom Neville, but he really had no one to blame but himself.

title: LABOR'S MAJORITY IN BRITAIN NARROW
description: LONDON, Oct. 11  Prime Minister Harold Wilson and his Labor party have been returned to power by the voters with, a hairline margin of victory over all other parties.

title: THREAT TO CLOSE LIBRARIES SCORED
description: Mayor Beame accused the New York Public Library yesterday of budgetary brinkmanship in its threat to close three large branches because of staff cuts.

title: Tina Niarchos Dead at 45; Wife of Greek Millionaire
description: PARIS, Oct. 11Tina NiarChos, wife of Stavros Niarchos, the Greek millionaire and shipowner, who figured prominently in the international jet set and was considered one of the world's most beautiful women, died yesterday at her home in Paris. She was 45 years old, and there were conflicting reports about the cause of her death.

title: A TIEUP AVERTED IN IRT LINE FIRE
description: Prompt action yesterday in diverting subway service to another line helped prevent subway trains of the Seventh Avenue IRT line from being stuck in the Clark Street tunnel under the East River after a small fire broke out.

title: Computer Aid for Manhattan Jams Is Far Off
description: Every workday an army of 750,000 vehicles rumbles, rattles and hornblasts its way into Manhattan to battle for position on streets with washboard or rollercoasterlike surfaces and to perpetuate an institution:

title: Unit in Albany to Inquire Into Misconduct by Police
description: ALBANY, Oct. 11 (AP)The Albany Police Department has established an internal affairs unit to investigate complaints of misconduct against police officers, almost a year after the State Investigation Commission recommended it.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The House of Representatives narrowly defeated a compromise measure that would have enabled the President to delay until Dec. 15 a cutoff of military aid to Turkey. After the 187 to 171 vote, Republican Congressional leaders said that the President would definitely veto a resolution continuing appropriations for foreign aid, which contains the disputed provision suspending aid to Turkey. [Page 1, Columns 34.]

title: Treasury Bill Rates Up on 3 and 6 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: They Aren't Dimes That Boy's Handing Out
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Jerry invited Rocky to the house for toast and pinochle and the toaster broke down.

title: Music: Mehta and Stern
description: Zubin Mehta, the Lochinvar of the West, brought his Los Angeles Philharmonic to Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening. In many respects he is to the West Coast what Leonard Bernstein has been to the Easta virtuoso conductor, a magnetic personality, a glamour boy, a conductor of obvious gifts blessed with a good ear.

title: Wilson Soberly Paints Rosy Picture Upstate
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 11Governor Wilson completed an upstate campaign tour today, maintaining in his sober, methodical style that the party's Buckley wing was safe, that the Duryea split was ended and that the Rockefeller shadow was not lengthening over him once again.

title: RALLY IS EXTENDED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Despite a brief period of profit taking in the first hour, prices rose for the fifth consecutive session in active but slightly decreased trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Similar conditions prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: People in Sports
description: After complaining that he should have been rehired as soon as the regular season ended, Manager Earl Weaver was retained by the Baltimore Orioles yesterday for at least another season.

title: Strong Protestant Vote in Ulster Affirms Opposition to Joint Rule
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 11The Protestant voters of Northern Ireland expressed their determined opposition to sharing power with Roman Catholics by returning to office all but one of their candidates in the British elections.

title: TURNPIKE SEEKING ITS FIRST TOLL RISE
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority proposed new toll rates yesterday that would increase the cost of trips for most New Jersey residents by 37 per cent and increase the cost of traveling the length of the highway by 54 per cent.

title: Rangers Face Old Rival Tonight
description: When the Rangers take on Toronto tonight at Maple Leaf Gardens in the second game of the National Hockey League season for both teams, the situation will be remarkably similar. Both New York and Toronto played new expansion clubs to open their seasons, both had to come up with big third periods to win and both look on tonight's game as a truer indication of what's in store for them this season.

title: Crowding and Lice Cited In Camden Jail Hearing
description: CAMDEN, Oct. 11Prisoners and officials at the Camden County Jail told a legislative study commission today that the 190inmate facility on the sixth floor of the combination city hall and county courthouse was crawling with vermin and so overcrowded that dozens of inmates must sleep in the floor.

title: Saigon Police Deny Role In Attack on CBS Newsmen
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 11A Government spokesman said today that the Saigon police had denied involvement in the attack yeserday on a correspondence of CBS.

title: Choir Trip Hits Responsive Note
description: MERRICK, L.I., Oct. 11The letters keep comingfrom Japan and London and Greenwichmost of them with checks fluttering out of them.

title: PAID $840,000 IN TAXES
description: Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller provided more detailed look at his gifts and loans last night, making public a list of 20 present and former public officials and staff assistants to whom he had given a total of $1,972,078 over the last 17 years.

title: Senate Ballot Revision
description: ALBANY, Oct. 11  The State Board of Elections said today that Percy L. Greaves Jr. of Irvington had not filed acceptance of the nomination of the Free Libertarian party candidate as United States Senate in the Nov. 5 election, The board indicated earlier that it had certified Mr. Greaves as the candidate.

title: The Man I Travel With Is Not at All Like My Husband
description: EACH year I spend my vacation with a slim, handsome man, dashingly dressed, debonair, witty, extravagant, worldly, impulsive and multilingual. Our days together are Tilled with romance and surprise as we walk hand in hand down cobbled streets in Paris, or scurry through the dark lanes of the Trestevere in. Rome. We drink champagne and eat breakfast in bed. Every day we cash a, check and spend all the money and then we cash another one. I call him Ricardo but that is not his real name.

title: A naughty goose, a wizard's daughter, a floating island
description: This morning I can assure you that what Henny Penny has been going around saying is wrong. The sky is certainly not falling. But there is some trouble with the moon. Listen to Little Goose. He notices a white fox in the sky, stalking, then swallowing the Little Goose gives the alarm to the moon. Squawking for all he's worth farmer. By this time the foxshaped. cloud has passed away. Well, everyone makes mistakes.

title: Turks Fire on 3 Cypriotes
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 12 (UPI) Turkish troops opened fire last night on three Greek Cypriotes who had come back to their Turkishoccupied village to feed their livestock, the Cypriote Government said today. It said a 25yearold woman was critically wounded, and one of the two men who accompanied her was missing.

title: Summit Routed, 50 to 20
description: What a difference a year makes.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Synthetic Sex Odor Is Used to Disrupt Gypsy Moth Mating
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 12 (AP)Connecticut scientists have successfully used a synthetic sex odor to disrupt the mating of gypsy moths, according to a researcher.

title: Dispute Over Printing Bill Snags Detroit Busing Case
description: DETROIT, Oct. 11 (AP)The Detroit school busing case may never be resolved unless somebodyagrees to pay an $89,864 printing bill.

title: 17 Repair Projects Slated For Port Channel System
description: The port's extensive channel system is about to receive a thorough overhaul.

title: Nuptials on Nov. 3 For Peggy Guttag
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Guttag of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Peggy Ann Guttag, to Stephen Paul Casper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Casper, also of New York. The wedding will take place Nov. 3.

title: QUEENS TO LOSE A MILK COMPANY
description: A Richmond Hill, Queens, milk processing plant, whin employes there said was once the largest processing facility in the city, will close before Jan. 1, 1975, its owner, Deltown Foods of Yonkers, told plant workers and drivers last week.

title: SUN RA'S JAGGED JAZZ AT BEACON THEATER
description: Stretching sound and occalsionally credibility to their limits, Sun Ra, once a founding father and now an elder statesman of the revolutionary genre of freewheeling freeform jazz, arrived at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street, on Friday with his power to provoke and surprise intact. The sight and sound of his Solar Arkestra, 19 musicians of decidedly jazz avantgarde inclination, improvising independently, notebending, bleating and dissonance much in favor, is an awesome experience, a blitzkreig of jazz modernism.

title: The World
description: By the narrowest of margins, Britain's Labor Prime Minister Harold Wilson has won a majority in Parliament, but he has made clear that he believes it is enough for him to push through several measures that were stalled in the previous House.

title: Southampton Records 100th Victory for Coach
description: Two major upsets marked league, play yesterday and. Herb Goldsmith of Southampton became the fifth coach in county history to win 100. games as his team beat Stony Brook, 20.0, in an A2 league genie.

title: Pilferage Rampant, and the Buyer Pays
description: They'll steal everything that's movable. That's how one Westchester County builder milted up the problems of thievery on the construction site.

title: Partial Transcript of an Interview With Kissinger on the State of Western World
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Following is a partial transcript of an interview conducted last week with Secretary of State Kissinger by James Reston of The New York Times:

title: Marcos Prepares to Pardon Communist Party Members
description: MANILA, Oct. 12 (AP)President Ferdinand E. Marcos directed the Government today to prepare an amnesty proclamation for all members of the outlawed Communist party, a move apparently aimed at helping pave the way for diplomatic relations with China.

title: Carnegie Foundation, Citing Decline in Assets, Trims '75 Budget by $500,000
description: The Carnegie Corporation of New York, a philanthropic foundation, has cut its program budget for the coming year by $500,000 and has warned of greater reductions until at least 1977.

title: Sato's Nobel Prompts Joy and Outrage
description: TOKYO, Oct, 12The award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Eisaku Sato, the former Premier of Japan, produced three days of Jively chatter here, ranging from expressions of nationalistic joy and restrained praise to bitter laughter and open outrage.

title: Connecticut Probate Candidate Wants the Job Done Away With
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 11While Connecticut's guberna torial and senatorial candidates battle away in lackluster statewide races, voters here arc being treated to an unusual local contest in which a lawyer is campaigning against excessive legal and court costs and running for a job he says he wants to abolish.

title: Dictionary of Antiques: A Conversation Piece
description: A crooked foot chair, several ambulantes, an ouche or two, a conversation piece and, probably, a virgin, were among the esteemed possessions of the 18thcentury householder. Under different labels these days, they are even more highly esteemed as antiques.

title: Hutcheson Forest Is Site of Tours
description: NEW BRUNSWICKFall and winter tours of Hutcheson Memorial Forest, one of the last virgin hardwood forests in the eastern United States, have been set for selected Sundays, beginning today.

title: Nassau Bus Study Begun
