description: MINEOLAThe Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority, which has been operating Nassau County's bus system since June, 1973, reported last week that it had started a comprehensive study to provide Nassau residents with better transportation.

title: A Little Hustle Pays Off For Table Tennis Hustler: Ball Climbs a Friendly Net, He Earns a Friendly $6,866
description: You Marty Reisman? the voice asked. The call was long distance.

title: Kissinger Ordered A Secret '69 Study On Southern Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Informed State Department sources said tonight that in 1969, when Henry A. Kissinger headed the National Security Council, he ordered a secret memorandum dealing with the blackwhite confrontation in southern Africa.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONOn Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, said one of the hundreds of financially wellinformed participants in the recent annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, I think we're all going to fall into some kind of chaos that I cannot exactly describe.

title: Saturday Night Out Is music to Auctioneers
description: RARITANNot everyone, it seems, stays home on Saturday night 63 watch Archie Bunker, Some people still go to the movies, and othersapparently many othersgo to auctions.

title: Barbara Contos, Bank Officer, Is Wed to Paul Wallace Henry
description: Barbara Christine Contos, daughter of Leonidas C. Contos and the late Mrs. Contos, was married here yesterday afternoon to Paul Wallace Henry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Henry of Middlebury, Conn.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: A number of paragraphs were omitted from the article I wrote on the Federal budget (The Art of Budget Cutting Oct. 6), The missing section made the following points:

title: Acrostic puzzle
FollowUp on The News
description: Just a year ago, when Spiro T. Agnew pleaded no contest to one count of incometax evasion, resigned the VicePresidency, paid a $10,000 fine and had all other criminal charges against him dropped, it was noted that the Internal Revenue Service could still bring a civil case against him for the taxes and penalties on his unreported income.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Musicians in Pursuit of Exotic Jazz
description: JAZZ musicians have been embracing the colorful, the foreign and the primitive for decades, but in the past their efforts amounted to little more than chinoiserie. Duke Ellington's jungle music of the twenties was no more African than Ethel Waters; now that the real thing is available on ethnic recordings, the chanted mumbojumbo of Dizzy Gillespie's Swing Low Sweet Cadillac sounds like so much doubletalk. From the Dixie Rhythm Kings' 1929 Congo Love Song to Tadd Dameron's 1950 Casbah the titles have been provocative, the music implacably AfroAmerican.

title: The Bobby Sox Have Wilted, But the Memory Remains Fresh.
description: AH, FRANKIE everlovin', here we are at the Garden dancing cheek to cheek and the lights are low and it's oh so sweet. We haven't been this close since the old days when played bookey from school to come see you in the RKOBoston. You remember me, don't you? I was the one in the bobby sox.

title: CONNECTICUT COUPLE DIE IN PLANE CRASH
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Oct. 12 (AP)  The bodies of a New York bank vice president, his wife and daughter were found today inside the fuselage of a small private plane, which crashed Friday night, the Coast Guard reported.

title: South Fork Conservation Group Director Resigns
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON Should private environmental organizations work within the local political system or attempt to influence it from the outside?

title: Jews' Science Seminar Assailed in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 12The official Soviet press agency Tass today sharply denounced group of unemployed Jewish scientists, dismissed after applying to go to Israel, for holding unauthorized seminars in an effort to maintain their professional skills.

title: Concert
description: The New York Philharmonic's MiniFestival Around Ives has as its worthy aim the placing of Ives's music in the context of other music of its period. If Friday evening's installment at the Juilliard Theater offered more context than Ives, the performances were of such quality that one minded not at all.

title: Planners Study Brooklyn's Broadway
description: Three city agencies are combining efforts to halt the deterioration of Brooklyn's Broadway, which was once the hub of the retail furniture industry in north Brooklyn.

title: University Gets $1Million
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 12 (AP)The University of South Carolina announced today a $1million gift from E. Smythe Gambrell to his sister, Mary Latimer Gambrell, memorializing the former president of Hunter College. Mr. Gambrell, an Atlanta lawyer of the Class of 1915, is a former president of the American Bar Association.

title: Relative youth and long sideburns notwithstanding, he has become the point man of the Supreme Court's right wing
description: WASHINGTON. One morning last April, a law school professor was trying to persuade the Supreme Court that the cause of press freedom was advanced by a Florida law requiring newspapers to print verbatim, at the same length and with the same prominence, any statement by a political candidate in reply to a news story or editorial that he regards as critical of his record.

title: A New Home for Rangers
description: LONG BEACHIce, lots of ice. Well, if that's what You suggest for treatment, Doc, that's what we'll do.

title: Boom Town In the Negev In Decline
description: MITZPE RAMON, Israel, The town swimming pool is closed for lack of a lifeguard. The oncehandsome Ramon Inn is shuttered for lack of customers. Several apartment buildings are empty and hundreds of families have moved away for lack of jobs.

title: Klein Cuts County Aides' Use Of Cars, Phones and Secretaries
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 12John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, has told his high echelon commissioners that from now on they will have to make do with fewer longdistance telephone calls, fewer county cars and fewer permanent secretaries,

title: Seminar Is Scheduled On Water Pollution
description: MAHWAH  A daylong training seminar, at which provisions of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act will be detailed, will be held at Ramapo College next Saturday.

title: Dear Ann Landers: Is incest hereditary?
description: The trouble was, he just wouldn't take her advice. Oh, I always found him fairly easy to talk to, says the dollsized woman in the leopardprint robe that reveals lot of cleavage. He was really quite a reasonable man.

title: Kissinger Says U.S Wants Jordan In On Any Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 12Secretary of State Kissinger assured Jordan today that the United States would continue to press for a role for Jordan in any peaca negotiation that may develop as the result of his current Middle East trip. He then flew to Israel.

title: Kissinger Sees the World On Verge of Historic Era
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Secretary of State Kissinger believes the nations of the world are now delicately poised on the verge of a new historic era, and that the next decade will either be one of the great periods of human creativity or the beginning of extraordinary disarray.

title: 3County Aid Unit Thriving at Age 10
description: PHILLIPSBURG  Although many similar economicassistance projects are being severely curtailed or phased out altogether because of diminishing funds, the Northwest New Jersey Community Action Program is thriving. And even better times are foreseen as the project eners its 10th year.

title: Dance
description: CARACAS DURING the summer, walking through the ruins of Persepolis in in Iran, my conversation with the guide turned to the theater festival in nearby Shiraz. I asked whether there was much local or domestic theater in Iran. The guide told me that there was not much happening outside the capital, Tehran, but all that was likely to change in the near future. To my innocent question Why? I received a smile and one word: Oil.

title: For Some, the Cost Is Secondary
description: Jack O'Connor, a Cincinnati telephone company executive, paid $18,000 two months ago for a copy of a 1936 Auburn Speedstera car built in 1974 with the exterior of the classic American roadster, and the insides o fa modern car.

title: E. C. Delafield Jr. Weds Ruth Hilfer
description: The marriage of Ruth Channell Hilfer, head librarian at the Weston (Conn.) Public Library, to Edward C. Delafield Sr., an editorial vice president at Crown Publishers, Inc., took place at noon yesterday in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Edwin. A. Lane of the Westport Unitarian Church performed the ceremony at the bride's home.

title: City Environmental Body Is in Turmoil Under Beame
description: Since Mayor Beame took office in January, the city's Environmental Protection Administration has been in turmoil.

title: Shopping For Cash Save
description: Shopping around for financing can save a newcar buyer as much as $165 on a $3,000 loan, a significant amount anytime, but especially so when automobile prices and interest rates are both going up.

title: Laurie Grayson Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Howard Grayson of Scarsdale, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Beth Grayson, to Jeffrey Alan Kunkes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Kunkes of Edison, N.J. A wedding next June is planned.

title: Magnus Wins Division In CrossCountry Meet
description: Albertus Magnus High School of Rockland County placed all of its seven entrants in the top 20 in the fourth Of six races yesterday in the Manhattan College scholastic crosscountry invitation run at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, the nation's largest scholastic run.

title: World Financiers Face Up to Mecca
description: Slightly embarrassed, the so  called major financial powers of the West came to realize last month that the annual weeklong meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank fell right in the middle of Ramadanthe most sacred period of the year for hundreds of millions of Moslems.

title: Holy Family Defeats Maria Regina, 288
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 12 Holy Family overpowered Maria Regina, 288, as Ed Cooney and Tom Donovan had two touchdowns each and a senior, middle guard, Frank Grilli, had 16 unassisted tackles today, Cooney, ha d147 yards rushing over 26 carries to put his pushing yardage at 450 on the season. The Holy Family defense all owed Only two first downs, one in each half.

title: ROCKEFELLER SAYS HE'S RESPONSIBLE ON GOLDBERG BOOK
description: Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller took full responsibility yesterday for the publication of a derogatory biography of Arthur J. Gold berg during the 1970 campaign in which the former Supreme Court Justice was the Democratic candidate.

title: CRITIC OF WASTE GETTING U.S. AID
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 12Agricultural business concerns operated by a Republican Congressional candidate here who advocates elimination of wasteful spending programs have received almost $15million from the United States Government in the last 10 years.

title: Atlantic City Seeks Rail Improvements
description: ATLANTIC CITY  The Atlantic City Improvement Association has asked the state's Department of Transportation and Governor Byrne to earmark $10million in bonds or general funds toward the Construction of an electrified highspeed rail line between this resort and Philadelphia.

title: New in Paperback
description: It is always fascinating to watch a successful playwright take a first fling at the novel. This debut by Robert Anderson, author of Tea and Sympathy, is no exception. After is the story of a writer named Christopher Larsen, who flays himself a little and cheats a little while his wife slowly dies of cancer; who then, after her death, writes movingly about her and establishes scholarships in her name even as he licks his wounds with a chick who has held one of the scholarships. Marian Engel, who reviewed the book here, acknowledged that Anderson handles the hero's complex ordeal with luminous understanding and an easy loping style... . It's a smooth read ... and often moving. Yet she felt that Anderson pulled his punches, making death sentimental and the world more attractive than it is.

title: A Bit of Larceny, With Compassion
description: IF there is a gardener anywhere who scrupulously obeys the Eighth Commandment, he must love honor more than plants. Almost every interesting garden has been enriched by theft, and candid horticulturists admit that larceny is a practice they could not dispense with. Rather than give up stealing, they would abandon composting.

title: Union Vote Is Set For L.I. Hospital
description: MANHASSETTwo organizations seeking to serve as the collective bargaining representative for interns and residents at North Shore University Hospital have agreed to a secret election Oct. 30 to resolve the dispute.

title: In Liliana Cavani's Love Story, Love Means Always Having To Say Ouch
description: Picture the scene. Dirk Bogarde, playing a former Nazi concentration camp guard, lies in bed starving to death with Charlotte Rampling; the woman he tortured and molested when she was a teenager in the camp 15 years before. While he sleeps, she realizes there's some jam left in a jar by the bed, reaches for it, slops it up hungrily with her fingers before he wakes, then fights with him over the jagged jar's remains. Before you can say bring on the peanut butter, the two of them are on the floor, smearing and licking one another until she crawls on top to make passionate, sticky love to him.

title: Mary Ellis Is Married to Harry Hile 3d
description: Mary Christine Ellis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence D. Ellis of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday morning to Harry Eugene Hile 3d of Hastings, N. Y., son of Dr. and Mrs. H. Eugene Hile Jr. of Pittsburgh. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Leo V. Vanyo and the Rev. Robert J. Meyer in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Cathedral in. Pittsburgh.

title: Y Series To Open With Piano Concert
description: DEAL PARK  The Monmouth Y.M.Y.W.H.A. will open its new finearts music series Thursday night with a piano concert by Conrad Strasser of New York. Mr. Strasser will perform at the Y, 100 Grant Avenue.

title: EDGAR H. DAVIS
description: Edgar H. Davis, a former teacher of English at Columbia and New York Universities and Queens College, died here Friday. He was 84 years old and lived at 1 University Place.

title: Landmark Action For Queens Sites
description: The Steinway area of Queens moved closer to designation as a historic district last week when the Landmarks Preservation Commission held public hearings no proposals to give official recognition to several historic areas and individual landmarks in the borough.

title: Ferguson's Peg a Hit, but Not His Bat
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12Joe Ferguson made the throw from right field that produced a big out for the Los Angeles Dodgers, but he also struck out for the final out today in the Oakland A's 3.2 victory in the World Series

title: Penn State Romps to 4th Victory
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa,, Oct. 12 (AP)Tom Shuman threw a pair of touchdown passes today and Jim Cefalo and Duane Taylor each scampered for two more scores as Penn State walloped Wake Forest, 550.

title: MentalHealth Action Taken
description: TRENTONA number of state legislators long have Considered the care and treatment of mental patients in county andstate hospitals a national scandal.

title: Equestrian Meeting Set Tuesday
description: The annual meeting of the Bureau of the Federation Equestre Internationale, the world governing body of equestrian sports, will meet at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel Tuesday through Saturday. Prince Philip, who is starting his secand decade as president of the organization, will preside at the meetings. This marks the first time the bureau, which functions as sort of an executive committee, has scheduled a meeting in the United States.

title: Mills Pledges Tax Program To Meet Serious Recession
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)  Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that the nation is do a serious recession and he promised to work for a tax program to help Meet the economic problems.

title: Marlene Hirt Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Hirt of Syosset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marlene Hirt, to Ronald Benkoe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Benkoe of Encino, Calif. Miss Hirt is a senior at California State University. Her father is a staff writer with The Daily Racing Form. Mr. Benkoe's father is a former vice president of the Ideal Toy Company here.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ADDS NONWHITES AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12For the first time in its history, South Africa is officially represented at an international forum by a multiracial delegation.

title: Morristown Temple Lists Wiesel, Eban
description: MORRISTOWN  Elie Wiesel, the author, and Abba Eban, the former Foreign Minister of Israel, will speak here next Sunday and Nov. 3, respectively, in programs sponsored by Temple B'nai Dr. Both programs will begin at 8 P.M. and tickets cost $5.

title: Roadside Stands Luring Shoppers
description: HOLMDEL  New Jersey's numerous roadside farm markets are increasingly attracting welltodo suburbanites and outofstate city residents in search of fresh produce and bargains no longer available in the supermarkets.

title: Missouri Tops Nebraska; Oklahoma 16to13 Victor
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 12 (AP)Steve Pisarkiewicz, a reserve quarterback, sparked Missouri to three touchdowns in the final period today and lifted the Tigers to a 2110 upset victory over Nebraska. The game was the first of the season for each team in the Big Eight Conference.

title: 6,500 Aged Poor In Utah Receiving New Kind of Help
description: CEDAR CITY, Utah, Oct. 12 A federally funded pilot project is underway to improve the nutritional level and to change the life style of more than 6,500 lowincome senior citizens residing in five southern Utah rural counties.

title: Caution: Apocalypse
description: Invoking memories of Franklin D. Roosevelt's Depression leadership, President Ford has conjured a vision of potential economic doom and at the same time proposed remedies that are anything but drastic. The most immediately controversial was for a surtax on all incomes from the middle class up, but even that was likely to be revised if it is adopted at all in the form he proposed it.

title: 3 Late Scores Win for MacArthur, 2014
description: Bob Lewis picked up yardage on the ground all afternoon against Long Beach yesterday, but Macarthur still trailed, by 14 points until Roy Kleshefsky passed for three touchdowns in the final 5 minutes to pull out a 2014 victory for Macarthur in a Nassau Conference III game for the Generals.

title: Paperbacks Best Sellers
description: 1 ONCE IS NOT ENOUGH, by Jacqueline Susann. (Bantam, $1.95.) More mental bubblegum from Miss Susann, about a movie producer, his Electral daughter and a rich lady.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market last week achieved its biggest weekly gain in history and its heaviest volume of this year.

title: CropExport Guidelines
description: The rapidfire series of events associated with cancellation last weekend of the sale of 3.4 million tons of corn and wheat, worth about $500million, to the Soviet Union disclosed two things above all.

title: The first of three from the Fiction Collective
description: The Fiction Collective, as explained by Ronald Sukenick (The Guest Word, Sept. 15). sounds marvelously sane, and it may strike a responsive chord, or nerve rubbed raw, in authors who have had wounding encounters with the publishing industry. What could be better than a group of writersespecially respected authors such as Sukenick himself, Jonathan Baumbach, Jerome Charyn, Leslie Epstein, Mark Mirsky and othersbanding together to select, edit, produce and distribute the books of its peers on the basis of literary merit, free from the implicit commercial standards of the book business? Why shouldn't the fate of fiction rest with those who produce it, those who presumably know what the art is all about? Well, unhappily there are reasons why it might be wise to reconsider the idea. Some questions arise from Sukenick's article, but the most serious doubts come directly from the Collective's first three.

title: RELIEF ELSE WHERE IS CALLED BETTER
description: Thousands of New York City's blind, aged and disabled residents receiving Federal Supplemental Security Income payments of $206.85 a month to cover their living expenses could do much better outside the city, according to an official of the Human Resources Administration.

title: The Future of the West Bank and Gaza Is at Stake
description: JERUSALEMThe political future of the Palestinians is today as much an internal Arab problem as an issue between the Arabs and Israel. Egyptian President Anwar elSadat admitted this last week when he said that the main obstacle on the road to Geneva was now the rival Jordanian and Palestine Liberation Organization claims to represent the Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza. There nothing Israel can do to prevent the probable granting of observer status to the Palestinians at the United Nations next month, and thus international recognition of their right to self determination. Nor, were Israel to return parts of the West Bank to Jordan's King Hussein, could he prevent the subsequent setting up there of a Palestinian state.

title: For Football Fans Only
description: Many fans have grown disillusioned with professional football as sports entertainment. The value of winning once so appealing, now seems to be viewed with cynicism. It's as if spectators suspect that football is a business first, that the players' attitude is one of selfinterest and that winning isn't as important as the point spread. The better paperback books on football published this fall reflect this attitude; their subjects center on the unconventional elements and personalities of the game.

title: Flyers Beat Sabres, 61; Crisp Stars
Second Avenue: Ultimate Test
description: Undaunted, unseeing, Deborah Dakunchak steered her way down Second Avenue amid trucks and taxis with her driving instructor in the front seat smiling jovially and a reporter cowering in the back.

title: Where Will Northern Electric Strike Next?
description: MONTREAL  Northern Electric. Remember the name, proclaimed an advertisement that ran last spring in American newspapers. You'll be hearing more about us.

title: Miss Bibb Wed to T. W. Brazeau
description: Barbara Anne Bibb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas G. Bibb of Troy, N.Y., was married at noon yesterday to Thomas Willoughby Brazeau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willoughby F. Brazeau of Garden City, L. I.

title: JURY LIST IS FOUND UNFAIR TO THE POOR
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12A trial court judge in Los Angeles has held that the poor are discriminated against in Los Angeles County because they are not fairly represented on juries.

title: Rockefeller's Largesse
description: The Rockefeller family's prestige as patrons of arts and letters has not been enhanced by the disclosure that Rockefeller money financed a scurrilous biography of Arthur J. Goldberg, brought out in 1970 when the former Supreme Court Justice was unsuccessfully campaigning against Nelson A. Rockefeller for Governor of New York.

title: Bomb in Pakistan Kills Two
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 12 (Reuters)  Two persons were killed and 19 injured today when a time bomb exploded in a bank at Mardan, in NorthWes Frontier Province.

title: How to Drive a Golf Ball Farther: Watch Jim Dent
description: Lives there a golfer who would not trade his kingdom for an extra 20 yards off the tee? Everyday wants to hit the ball farther, and on outsized modern courses that's understandable.

title: What's Doing in PARIS
description: BEFORE IT'S TOO LATEThe charm of the Streets of Paris is ??dly waning under the onslaught of min??ess nickeiandplastic modernization of pleasantly oldfashioned storefronts and the suffocating increase of automobiles, either advancing painfully through the bottlenecks of narrow streets or abandoning the battle and parking on sidewalks, thus spreading traffic jams to pedestrians as well. Such streets as Rue Mouffetard, in the heart of the Left Batik (Mtro: Gabelins), remain as a reminder of what once made Paris a great city where one could live amid the homely pleasures of a village. All day, except for a long, midday break, shopkeepers displaying and hawking their wares from tantalizing displays on the sidewalks turn the winding old street into a cheerful marketplace. The street cries of Paris survive there as merchants striving to reduce mountains of mussels try to outshout sellers of artfully dressed rabbits to gain the attention of choosy housewives and as women vaunt the ripeness of their Camemberts in competition with others offering the last of their string beans at reduced prices. Street children can still be caught chalking uncomplicated words on sidewalks and cheerfully thumbing their noses at their elders. But hurry: signs of fashionableness are appearing, houses are being modernized, Greek restaurants and antique shops are opening, and an offboulevard theater has even arrived.

title: Texas A.&M. Wins, 287; Walker Stars
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 12 (AP)  Skip Walker slipped through and around ninthranked Texas Tech for three secondquarter touchdowns today and led 16thranked Texas A. and M. to a 287 victory in a key Southwest Conference football game.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I have been saddened recently by several letters characterizing me as a male chauvinist pig. What has become of elegance? These letters come from welleducated women with sound argumentative powers, yet they cannot resist making their points in the coarse, loudmouthed style we now take for granted in professional athletes, TV clowns, Congressional candidates and almost everybody else who craves attention.

title: Numismatics
description: QUITE a few readers have expressed bewilderment and distress about the evergrowing crop of local, state and even national medalsall of them supposedly official medals  commemorating the 200th anniversary of the American Revolution What shall I collect? is usually followed by I can't begir to know about much less buy, everything that's being issued. The best answer to such appeals for guidance is simply this: Buy what you like, but don't let yourself be deceived about what is official and what isn't.

title: Relief Plan Tested for Honduras
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10Americans traditionally respond with heartwarming largesse when a natural disaster strikes another country. But peanut butter sandwiches and frozen pizzas?

title: Brown Beaten, 240, On Doyle Passing
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 12Four big plays gave Yale its third straight victory today, the Elis defeating Brown, 240. The scrappy Bruins deserved a better fate but turnovers and penalties went against them as they lost their second Ivy League game of the season.

title: The Nation In Summary
description: Racial tension and violence, as well as highlevel rhetoric, have increased considerably in Boston, raising the possibility that matters may get worse before they improve and the City's Mayor blamed President Ford for contributing to that possibility.

title: Feminist Goal: Better Image At the Movies
description: It has struck many women as a contradiction: At a time when feminism seems to be in full flower, there is a dearth of good roles for women in American films. And when women do get parts at all, they are usually cast as prostitutes, emptyheaded blondes, sex kittens or neurotic housewives.

title: STANLEY P MEAD, 84, CONNECTICUT JUDGE
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 12Stanley, P. Mead, a judge in Connecticut's juvenilecourt system for 19 years and a former majority leader in both houses of the state's General Assembly, died today in Norwalk. He was 84 years old and lived at 30 Mead Street.

title: A Fair Bet: Official Gambling Will Grow
description: At the moment there are only lottery drawings for the sedentary plungers of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. But if one is to judge by proposals coming from legislatures and betting commissions, the tristate area could become a gamblers' Nirvana.

title: SAN DIEGO FIGHTS FRUIT FLY INVASION
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 12An emergency quarantine was im posed on a large residential area of San Diego this week in an effort to stamp out the first infestation of breeding Oriental fruit flies ever reported in the United States.

title: Washington Columnist Got Rockefeller Loan to Buy Newspaper in California
description: Thomas Braden, a Washington columnist for the Los Angeles Times Syndicate, said yesterday that Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller had lent him $100,000 in 1954 to purchase a small daily newspaper in Southern California.

title: Westfield Stays Unbeaten; So Do Colonia, Plainfield
description: Although Glen Kohler was limited to placekicking by a wrist injury, unbeaten Westfield powered to a 4214 victory over Thomas Jefferson yesterday in Westfield, its third triumph.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Continue all outdoor planting  bulbs, evergreens, trees, shrubs, perennials.... Rake leaves and start general fall tidy up.... Start compost.

title: Mazda's Hmmm Sours
description: LOS ANGELES  Four years ago a littleknown Japanese auto maker, Toyo Kogyo of Hiroshima, brought to the United States what some observers called a revolution in automotive technology: the rotarypowered Mazda.

title: Nabokov as his own halfhero
description: After Joyce with his portrait of Stephen, after Proust with his remembrance of Marcel, there are few reasons to be surprised, and many reasons to be disappointed, by the complicated interplay between Vladimir Nabokov and the narrator of this, his 37th book. Vadim Vadimovitch is a Russian emigr writer and a mirror image or double of Nabokov as man and writer; but unlike Proust or Joyce, Nabokov never uses this version of himself as a way of questioning the authenticity of his own identity. The fictional self never challenges the real or authorial self. Nabokov and his works hover on the margins of the text, so to speak, as a static reality against which Vadim is to be measured. So that while the style of the novel is characteristically brilliant when it comes to erotic comedy or setting a scene or sketching in minor figures, it is deficient in another and far more important way. It lacks the dramatic intensifications, the exploratory feeling that in Joyce and Proustand in our own time very often in Maileris a consequence of their wonderfully vital, vulnerable, intimidated (and not simply intimidating) relationship to fictional copies of themselves.

title: ROWLEY W. PHILLIPS, BROKER, DEAD AT 83
description: Rowley Wilhelm Phillips, a retired investment banker, a director of the Bridgeport Brass Company and a consultant to the United Stock Yards Corporation; died Friday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 60 Otter Rock Drive, Greenwich.

title: Can we buy dtente?
description: There are two possible approaches to the Soviet Union. Powerful voices, of which Senator Henry M. Jackson's is the best known, are basically skeptical, and others, typified by Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, are more hopeful regarding the longerrun effects of economic interdependence. This debate is paralleled by the reported differences of view, this time between Kissinger and Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger, over armslimitation agreements. Of course, we must not oversimplify issues or attitudes. No doubt Kissinger is fully aware of the many difficulties and uncertainties involved in negotiating with the Soviets, and Senator Jackson is not an oldstyle cold warrior, though such warriors still exist, and they argue simply that trade with the enemy is bad, and that dtente is either a fraud or a misdescription of a state of continuing conflict.

title: Time to Tuck, in the Vegetables
description: THE gardener who wants Ia better vegetable plot next year  preferably with less work  can improve the chances for success. What is called for is a good autumn job of tucking it in.

title: FIREMAN COLLECTS FOR FALSE ARREST
description: A $30,000 judgment for false arrest has been awarded a former city fireman who was jailed briefly in 1968 on charges stemming from his rescue of a honeymooning couple trapped in an elevator at the Aberdeen Hotel at 17 West 32d Street.

title: IMMUNITY FAULTS LINKED TO GANG
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 12 Serious defects in immunity and a heightened risk of cancer often go together, according to a report to the National Cancer Advisory Board.

title: New Abstract Paintings A Variety of Feelings
description: RECENT abstract painting in America, particularly in New York, is the subject of Continuing Abstraction in American Art at the Whitney Museum Downtown Branch. This is a very large, vital subject that has been shamefully neglected by our museums of late, for reasons I'll get into later. Unhappily, the Whitney exhibition is a disappointing, rather muddled affair, but one made important by its timeliness. And, since we are unlikely to have a more substantial show of its kind soon, we had best seize the present occasion for what it's worth.

title: Charles Terrell Cooper Weds Nancy S. Hovey
description: Nancy Scott Hovey, daughter of Chandler Hovey Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Terrell Cooper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Cooper 3d of Waltham and Rockport, Mass.

title: A Visit to Ancient Greecein Italy
description: FROM Naples, we decided to make the 50mile journey down the Tyrrhenian coast to Paestum to see the Greek temples there. Our train was a local with only secondclass cars, which suited me fine. The whole spirit and excitement of the Italians are nowhere so evident as when they are en route from one place to another. Just the number of small bundles pressed into a single string bag, the countless small children arranged to fit on one seat, the colorful crescendo of voices, movements, shouts that fill the air, and the sheer good humor of it all enchant met.

title: Why Boutiques?
description: They can be Madison Avenue designer showcases, thrift shops on Upper Broadway, remote recesses within huge department stores and funky head shops scarcely bigger than walkin closets. They may be as austerely mannish as San Francisco Clothing, as romantically nostalgic as Agora or as determinedly mod as Serendipity 3. They may seem to have nothing in common but their category: boutique.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IF President Ford was as surprised as he was reported to have been by the depth and the breadth of public criticism after his pardon for his predecessor in the White House, he may be equally shocked at the reaction his 10point economic program has drawn.

title: Timothy Wolf, Virginia Knapp Plan Marriage
description: C. Virginia Knapp, a student at the Northwestern University School of Management, and Timothy Van de Wint Wolf, who is attending the University of Chicago Business School, plan to marry next June.

title: Peking Reports Big Gains In Curbing Urban Pollution
description: PEKING, Oct. 12 (Reuters)China has successfully been curtailing pollution in industrial cities, the party newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao said this week.

title: Joan Kimm Is Married in Jersey
description: Joan Suzanne Kimm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Kimm Jr. of Short Hills and Spring Lake, N. J., was married at noon yesterday to Donald Emerson Lewis Jr., son of Mrs. Albert M. Slaght of Short Hills and Normandy Beach, N. J., and the late Mr. Lewis.

title: Three Seized in a Fatal Shootout in Montgomery, Ala.
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 12 Three young black men surrendered early this afternoon following a threehour gun battie in which a retired policeman, a white man, was killed.

title: Jennifer A. Davoud Will Marry Dec. 7
description: Jennifer Anne Davoud and the Rev. Henri Morton Whitman plan to be married Dec. 7 in the Bruton Parish Church in Williamsburg, Va.

title: Jersey Hunter, 18, Killed
description: HAINEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 12 (UPI)An 18yearold Kearny youth was shot and killed today when he was struck by a bullet fired by one of four of his friends while hunting in a forest, the police reported. The police said the youth, Gregory M. Pavlosky, was killed about 1 A.M. when he was shot once in the back of the head as his friends apparently fired at a raccoon in a state forest park.

title: Syracuse Defeats Navy; Pitt Beats West Virginia
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 12 (AP)Jim Jenkins's fourthperiod touchdown run and John Rafferty's interception that stopped a lastditch Navy drive helped Syracuse preserve a 179 homecoming game victory over the Middies today.

title: Middlebury Beats Williams by 2520
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 12  Middlebury came from behind with two touchdowns in the fourth quarter and defeated Williams, 2520, today.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 12 A fighting player is often an asset to a hockey club, not only for the damage he inflicts on his opponents but also for the inspiration he provides his team. Thus it was that the New York Islanders owed something in their decisive 62 victory over the Kansas City Scouts tonight to Bob Nystrom, the right wing whom fans have dubbed Knuckles.

title: DEMOCRATS LEAD IN POLL ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12Voter opinion surveys indicate that the California Republican party this year will lose most of the offices that it captured in a resurgence that began eight years ago, Mervin Field, operator of the California Poll, reported this week.

title: U.S. Captures Doubles, Takes Davis Cup Series
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Oct. 12 (AP)  The United States clinched its firstround series of the 1975 Davis Cup tennis competition today when Erik van Dillen and Charles Pasarell soundly defeated the Commonwealth Caribbean doubles team of Leo Rolle and John Antonas, 62, 61, 61.

title: The Summit, From the Valley
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio  Mr. Simon, Mr. Seidman, Mr, Greenspan, now that the economic summit's over, would you like to know. its impact on us ordinary Americans? Would you be surprised to hear that, despite your good intentions; one main effect was to make onceproud citizens feel shabby and powerless and hopelessand pitiful?

title: Dorothea Straus examines and interprets people
description: I like the title Showcases. Encompassing though it is, conjuring up thoughts of enameled ?? boxes or inaugural gowns of the wives of former presidents, Dorothea Straus makes clear at once the kind of exhibit she has in mindpeople. This is a collection of portraits, not of figures behind glass or posed in museums, but of real persons abundantly alive in her mind, gathered together because she knew and (generally) liked them. It is a book full of memories, following Mrs. Straus's first volume Thresholds, a piece of autobiography told through revealing pictures of other people. And it is delightful.

title: The Coming Congress Will Be Both Younger and More Liberal
description: WASHINGTONThe 94th Congress taking office next January will be more Democratic than the 93d. The question these days is only by how much. The informed predictions are that the Democrats will add from 15 to 40 seats to their 248187 majority in the House and from two to six seats to their 5842 majority in the Senate.

title: L.I.R.R. Adding Service
description: Hoping to tap a Sunday market that may be short on gasoline but is still ready to travel, the Long Island Rail Road will add six new Sunday trains, starting today, on its Port Washington branch.

title: Park Carousel Reopening
description: Sixtysix wooden horses, two giraffes, one lion and two chariotsall of them carved in Brooklyn 60 years agoare to whirl back to life to the music of John Phillip Sousa today as the Prospect Park Carousel reopens, three years after it was closed for renovation.

title: Grant to Aid Cahn's Office
description: MINEOLA  The Nassau County District Attorney's office has received Federal funding to set up a majoroffense bureau, according to aides of District Attorney William Calm.

title: The Curse Of Fisher Hall's Acoustics
description: AVERY FISHER HALL, originally named Philharmonic Hall, has had its share of troubles from the beginning. And now comes the news that the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Boston Symphony are leaving Lincoln Center for Carnegie Hall. The managers of both orchestras are carefu?? to say that many other considerations besides acoustic ones dictated the move But there is no doubt at all, reading their polite and guarded statements, that in their opinion Carnegie Hall is a better place to make music.

title: Small Cities, Big Crime Rates
description: SAN PABLO, Calif.In 1823, Don Francisco Maria Castro, a government official, moved here across the bay from San Francisco, in search of the peaceful life, free of the chaos, the crime and the fear of the city.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in lime to appear in Section 2:

title: Carton of Haig's Files Was Removed From White House but Was Returned Sealed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Despite assurances by President Ford's counsel that all Nixon Administration papers would remain intact at the White House, at least one carton of papers has left the White House and been returned, a spokesman said today.

title: Blast Ruins Car of Woman Held in Textbook Protest
description: CEDAR GROVE, W. Va., Oct. 12 (AP)A car belonging to one of three women arrested this last week for picketing in the Kanawha County textbook protest was destroyed today by an explosion. There were no injuries.

title: New Type of Horse Thief
description: EDMOND, Okla. (AP)Ronald Reed, 22 years old, reported to the police that a white pony with a brown saddle had been stolen from the patio of his apartment. The theft was found to be of a wooden rocking horse valued at $24.

title: The European Discovery of America
description: With this book, the indefatigable Admiral Morison completes his account of the discovery of the New World by European voyagers. In The Northern Voyages, A.D. 5001600, published three years ago, he covered voyages to Canada and the northern United States; in the present volume he recounts voyages of discovery to the rest of the Americas.

title: D. L. de Milhau Fiance Of Marjorie Munson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sherwood Munson Jr. of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Smith Munson, to David Livsey de Milhau, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. de Milhau of Riverside, Conn. A Dec. 7 wedding is planned.

title: The bottleneck in bodies has created the agonizing ethical dilemma: Who shall live and who shall die?
description: Ever since April of this year, William O'Neill, a 44yearold assistant general sales manager for the Titanium Metals Corporation of America, has been living without his kidneys, the result of an operation to save his life. Three times a week this tall, onceenergetic man travels from his apartment on East End Avenue to Columbia Presbyterian's hemodialysis center on the West Side; here, for six hours, he stretches out in a reclining chair while blood is drawn from his veins and circulated through the filtering mechanism that does the work of the human kidney. O'Neill submits to this uncomfortable treatment between midnight and 6 A.M. (the only time a machine is available to him), one of 12 patients being dialyzed simultaneously at the center.

title: REPORT ABOUT OIL IN MEXICO SCORED
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct., 12A high Mexican Government source said today that recent published reports of a large oil strike in southeasten Mexico were an absolute exaggeration.

title: Exercises Offered In Heart Program
description: HIGHLAND PARK  Another eightsession series in a postcardiac exercise program for hied and women will begin on Oct. 30 at the Y.M. and Y.W.H.A. of Raritan Valley, 2 South Adelaide Avenue.

title: Dear Sam Spade, the PrivateEye Business Is Just About Shot
description: IT was, of course, Oscar Wilde who said: Death and vulgarity are the only two things in the 19th century that one cannot explain away. In the 20th century, death and vulgarity are principles of television programing (as paranoia and adultery are principles of novelwriting). If this is progress, then I am Captain Video. Moreover, the TV actionadventure series inconveniences a reviewer. After one paragraph on the obligatory car chase, the obligatory rape scene and the obligatory freezeframe, what remains to be discussed?

title: Olaf Holvick 2d and Tina Fisher Are Planning to Marry Dec. 6
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Fisher Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Fisher, to Olaf Holvick 2d, son of Mrs, Holvick, also of Grosse Pointe, and the late Mr. Holvick.

title: Text of Jaworski's Report to Attorney General
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Following is the text of a status report by Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, submitted to Attorney General William B. Saxbe today along with his letter of resignation:

title: U.S. Pop Troupe, Novelty in Soviet, Thrills the Elite
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 12  An American musical troupe, billed in Russian as The Country Music Show U.S.A., today wound up a monthlong tour of the Soviet Union, offering the musical sounds of middle America to curious audiences composed mostly of the Soviet elite.

title: Law Student to Wed Elizabeth Harvey
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Collins, Harvey of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Viola Renner Harvey, to Charles Edward Yon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Italo Yon of Mattoon, Ill.

title: Catalytic Converter: Big If of 1975
description: DETROITThis is a tremendous achievement on the part of all concerned, says Charles Heinen, Chrysler Corporation's emission expert, something the industry can be proud of.

title: American Adjusts to a Paris Suburb
description: SEVRES, France  Each weekday Thomas Dresner bids his wife goodby, takes a brisk walk to the train station and commutes behind the morning, paper to his downtown office. But, while his job draws him daily into the heart of Paris instead of New York or Chicago, he has learned that life overseas offers all he drawbacks and rewards of living back home,

title: The Night Porter' Is Romantic Pornography
description: LET us now consider a piece of junk. Soberly. Without snickering. Which is not easy to do when the movie is about the ups and downs of e, hectic love affair involving a former concentration camp officer and the little Jewish girl he raped, tortured and knocked about, humiliating her in those funny, thoughtful little ways that only she understood as the gestures of a fully ripened affection.

title: Home Rule Facing Kindergarten Test
description: HOHOKUSA challenge to New Jersey's homerule tradition has been filed on behalf of a bright, young boy who was denied admission to the first grade here because his sixth birthday falls 15 days after an admission cutoff date of Oct. 1.

title: Kerry J. Kelly, Daniel A. Jost Are Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William M. Kelly Jr. of Grymes Hill, S. I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kerry J. Kelly, to Daniel A. Jost, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Jost of Lavallette, N. J. The wedding is planned for next June.

title: Encounter: Police Circled the Plaza. This Was Not Harvard Square
description: IN the spring the riverbeds are stone dust dry, the winds are not yet enough to bring the rainclouds across the Sierras, and the sun has already gained its summer strength. Durango is one of Mexico's flat, harsh towns, proud of its two hills and the new application of neon to the selling of drygoods and automobile tires. There is nowhere to wander in the town; it is as glamorous as Rapid City, S.D.; life is fervent only in the bank and Benavides's Drugstore.

title: Animal Kingdom: 3 Chimps Get Sitter
description: WHITEHOUSE  Diaperchanging is different at the Connie Collings home here. The babies are tiny chimpanzees.

title: Sylvia Whitman Playful, Funny In an HourLong Dance, Going
description: Fun is beautiful is what Sylvia Whitman seemed to be saying in a concert Friday night in a fifthfloor loft at 541 Broadway with her hourlong dance piece, Going.

title: TV BLITZ TO END GOVERNOR RACE
description: The gubernatorial contest moved into its final and most visible phase this weekend as both candidates began a new blitz of television commercials.

title: Indian Reservation Fracas
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D., Oct. 12 (UPI)One resident of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation I was shot and seriously woundled and another beaten today.

title: Shift of A's to Seattle Next Season Rumored
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12Even while the Oakland A's were playing their third straight World Series opener today, in their seventh year since reaching California from Kansas City and just 20 years after leaving their original home in Philadelphia, a persistent rumor insisted that they would start the 1975 season in Seattle.

title: Music in Review
description: The Metropolitan Opera is having good fortune with some of its new singers this season. Recently, Nancy Tatum, a soprano from Memphis who was relatively unknown here, made an impressive debut in the title role of Turandot. On Friday night, Rachel Mathes, a soprano who grew up in Birmingham, Ala., and had never sung here before, proved to be a fine artist in her Met debut, as Donna Anna in Don Giovanni. Like Miss Tatum, her early studies were in this country, and experience was gained in the opera houses of Europe.

title: Historic Data on Slave Found
description: PATERSONA slave was given his freedom in Passaic County at ?? eight years before New Jersey abolished slavery and 25 years before Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation, according to court records discovered here recently.

title: Miss Prendergast Becomes a Bride
description: Maureen Prendergast, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael H. Prendergast of Haverstraw, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon, to James Woodward Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodward of Stony Point, N.X. The ceremony was performed at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church In Haverstraw by the Rev. Charles Genet.

title: People/Business
description: Three years ago, four New Jersey residents decided to go into business together. Today, the company they formed makes and markets a new system to reclaim copper and other semiprecious metals from industrial waste.

title: BRITAIN IS FACING A CRITICAL PERIOD
description: LONDON, Oct. 12Worsening inflation, rising unemployment, more Government intervention in private industry and a squeeze on corporate profits are in prospect for Britain as she faces her most critical period since World War II.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Oct. 6 news report that unemployment is up and that, as always, the worst sufferers are youngsters trying to break into the job market for the first time should come as no surprise to anyone who followed last summer's debate on the minimum wage. September's inflated teenage unemployment rates were preordained by Congress' vote to increase the minimum wage by the largest initial increment ever and then by smaller increments over the next few years.

title: Conlan Is Stricken At Series Opener
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct, 12 umpire, John B. (jocko) Conlan, 74 years old, suffered a coronary occlusion today and taken to a hospital from Dudger Stadiu mwhere he had come to watch the World Series.

title: Next Best Thing to a Bugatti: A Bugatti Kit
description: The automobiles produced by Conrad K. Weiffenbach in Buffalo are rakish, lowslung 1931style racers.

title: 400,000 Expected At the Danbury Fair By Close Tomorrow
description: DANBURY, Conn.  The 105th Great Danbury State Fair, 290 acres here of rides. games, amusements and commercial exhibits, is expected to draw almost 400,000 visitors before it closes its 10day run Monday evening.

title: NATO BUILDS UNITY IN AIR COMMAND
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies are gradually strengthening the link between allied air forces on the northern and southern flanks of West Germany in a way that American defense officials believe will greatly enhance the air power of the alliance.

title: Newark Medical College Gives $411,000 for Statewide Consumer Health Project
description: NEWARK  Community hospitals throughout the state will benefit from a decision to establish a preventivemedicine program that is said to be one of the largest and most diversified in the nation.

title: The Nation/Continued
description: WASHINGTONIn a sentence that may well have gone unnoticed by most of the public, President Ford, in his speech to Congress on Tuesday, endorsed one of the longest, most complicated, most wideranging and potentially most controversial bills ever considered by Congress. It is also one of the least publicized.

title: Julie Jordan Bride Of Barry Sneider
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L. I., last night, Julie Mayo Jordan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Jordan of Westbury, L. I., was married to Barry Lee Sneider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Sneider of Woodmere, L. I., and North Miami Beach. Rabbi Joel Zion performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Cantor David Benedict.

title: The Ballet: Monotones
description: The American repertory has so few ballets by Sir Frederick Ashton that any addition to our slender store must be regarded as a major event. This is particularly true in the case of Sir Frederick's Monotones, which was given its premiere by the City Center Joffrey Batlet at the City Center 55th Street Theater on Friday night.

title: State at Standstill On Vehicles' Laws
description: TRENTONAlthough New Jersey runs the risk of losing millions in Federal subsidies it does not come up with substantial changes in its motorvehicle laws by 1976, the whole revision is still idling in neutral.

title: A Very Careful Tour by Bus of Harlem As It Is
description: THE song says the A train is the way to go to Harlem, but the view's a lot better on a Penny Tour. Penny's not the price but the boss. Penelope Ruffin, along with her husband, Claude, and several guides, all of whom live in or come from Harlem, sends three busloads of tourists uptown every week on her threehour General Tour of Harlem As It Is. She also sets up specialinterest tourslike the visits to black funeral homes she once put together for 11 undertakers from France.

title: Who are they now?
description: The sixties have almost receded far enough into the vaguely remembered past to become the subject of nostalgia. The rush of new eventsWatergate, the Middle East War, the energy crisis, inflation, the advent of a new Presidentseems to have pushed Vietnam and antiwar protest, the civilrights movement and the counterculture out of the national consciousness.

title: JAMES S. HULME
description: James S. Hulme, an artist who depicted historic buildings and landmarks of New York, died yesterday at his home, 36 Doyer Avenue, White Plains. His age was 73.

title: OSKAR SCHINDLER, SAVED 1,200 JEWS
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 12 (UPI)Oskar Schindler, a wartime Nazi intelligence officer who saved more than 1,200 Jews from the gas chambers, has died at the age of 66, his family announced today.

title: '74 Backlog Delays '75 Imports
description: With a few important exceptions, the 1975 import story has a familiar linemore of the same, only a little bigger in the engine and a little heavier on the customer's wallet.

title: Flatbush Ave. Celebrates Revival With Festival
description: In an exuberant show of local booster spirit, Brooklyn's downtown neighborhoods put on their first Flatbush Avenue Festival yesterday as part of an effort to revitalize the borough's most important thoroughfare.

title: BONN BILL UPSETS U.S. BUSINESSES
description: BONN, Oct. 12The American Chamber of Commerce in Germany, representing 1,460 American companies and businessmen here, said today that it was awaiting intervention from the State Department against a proposed West German law that would give worken a bigger voice in management.

title: News Summary and Index
The Quiet Comes
description: Hard frost has come, back in the hills, and the quiet of autumn deepens. It is quiet, not silence, for the crows are loud in proclaiming their possession, and the jays are shouting at each other and the world at large. In the stillness of the night the red fox barks at the starlight and the barred owl hoots at its own echo.

title: Book Ends
description: Bunny Hop. Fall is the time for changing jobs, apartments, mistresses or boyfriendssomething to do with the cooler weather, no doubt, the blood flowing faster and all that. This applies to authors too, and we know of a couple who have or are about to change publishers. In the have category is Richard Adams, author of Watership Down and a valuable literary property, to put it materialistically. Mr. Adams has moved from Macmillan to Simon & Schuster, taking his second book along. In its contract with Mr. Adams, Macmillan had the option to make him an offer for the second book, with final topping privileges, which means that they had the right to top any higher bid. Simon & Schuster joined forces with Avon, however, and made a bid said to be $500,000, although Simon & Schuster would not confirm this figure. At any rate it was considerably higher than Macmillan's bid and the company dropped out of the Can You. Top This Game. Mr. Adams's new novel, which is completed, is called Shardik and instead of rabbits features an ursine heroa big bear who hugs children. When Mr. Adams first came to this country to publicize Watership, he established, early on that he takes only champagne with his meals; now, with all the money from Watership and Shardik he can no doubt afford it by the magnum.

title: TinMala of Asia Society Bride of A. L. Strasfogel
description: TinMala, daughter of U Kin Oung and Mya Mya Kin of West New York, N. J., was married here yesterday at the Cosmopolitan Club to Andrew. L. Strasfogel, son and Mrs. Ignace Strasfogel of Strasbourg, France.

title: LINE FORMS EARLY FOR 500 JOBS HERE
description: By last evening, Louis Ortiz had been sleeping on and off under a plastictopped leanto on Parsons Boulevard off Jewell Avenue in Flushing, Queens, for 48 hours.

title: They See Strengths, But Also Missed Chances in Basically Modest Plan
description: Inflation may improve next year, but it will be the recession rather than President Ford's new prosposals that will be the cause. His program recognizes the full range of problems which surfaced at the summit meetings, but the proposed measures are modest indeed.

title: Knicks Defeat Braves, 119106 In Exibition Finale as Subs Star
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Oct. 12  Salvaging a lot of pride through a lot of hustle, the New York Knicks ended their preseason National Basketball Association play tonight with a rousing 119106 victory over the Buffalo Braves at Monmouth College.

title: Will Losers Provide Thrills?
description: Tomorrow night's game, the 49ers against the Lions in Detroit, matches on national television (Channel 7, 9 P.M.) a team that has yet to win this season, the Lions, against one that pay not 49ers. As with every football contest, there are other details to look for apart from the standings. Will Danny Abramowicz break the record? Who is Dennis Morrison? What did Rick Forzano mean when he said, I don't think there are any good 04 teams. I'd rather be the lousiest 4.0 team in football.

title: Physician to See Nixon at San Clemente to Check on Phlebitis and Lung Clot
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Oct. 12Former President Richard M. Nixon's doctor plans a house call to check on how well Mr. Nixon's leg and lung have responded to blood thinning therapy since he was discharged from a Long Beach hospital eight days ago.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than 260 bookstores in 110 communities throughout the United States. Weeks are not necessarily consecutive.

title: Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Three Zoos Preparing For Winter Visitors
description: WEST ORANGEAt least three of the state's larger zoos are planning to be open the year round. Most of the animals do not seem to mind cold weather, and the zoo managers hope that people feel the same.

title: News of the Camera World
description: A WORKSHOP entitled Studio LightingSubject People will be taught by Alan Dennis and Jeff Perkell at Actuality, Inc., 25 East Fourth Street, Manhattan, during evening and weekend meetings, starting this Friday. To consist of seven sessions, the workshop will cover all studio lighting and the fee will be $100. For more information call (212) 4756010.

title: QUEENS YOUTH SHOT BY POLICE OFFICER
description: An 18yearold Queens youth was shot yesterday when he reportedly attempted to assault and rob yesterday a police officer in civilian clothes in the Queens Village area.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Auto Graveyards on Core Banks
description: CORE BANKS, N. C.Nearly everyone has heard of North Carolin's Cape Hatteras National Seashore, but relatively few are acquainted with the 35mile extension of that beach known as the Core Banks.

title: JAWORSKI QUITS, ASSERTS HIS TASK IS LARGELY DONE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Leon Jaworski, saying that the work of the Watergate Special Prosecution Force was largely finished, announced today that he would resign as special prosecutor as of Oct. 25.

title: CORNSTALKS USED FOR CATTLE FEED
description: VAN METER, Iowa, Oct. 11 On the Robert Baur farm this week, the harvest machines were trundling back through the cornfields a second time, a step Iowa farmers rarely take in normal years.

title: Churches Fault Ford Amnesty Plan
description: The National Council of Churches, a federation of more than 30 major Protestant., and Eastern Orthodox denominations, said yesterday that President Ford's earned reentry program for war resisters falls far short of healing the wounds of the Vietnam war.

title: Mrs. Resnick Has Son
description: A son was born Sept. 26 to Mr, and Mrs. Michael Resnick of Hopewell Township, N.J., at the Middlesex General Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. The child has been named Christopher Michael. Mrs. Resnick, the former Sharon Volodkevich, is a nurse. Mr. Resnick is a sales representative with Sea Land Service, North Atlantic division, at the World Trade Center.

title: For Indians, Less Than a Day of Thanksgiving
description: Thanksgiving is the most festive day of the year in Plymouth, and the events include a Thanksgiving dinner served to thousands in Memorial Hall. However, the descendants of the Indians who attended the first Thanksgiving, in 1621, are boycotting the affair.

title: Watchword for '75: Economy
description: DETROITDetroit took a great leap forward in fuel mileage with its '75 models, and not just by adding small cars in its lineup.

title: Fuel: Optimism on supply, Not Price
description: American motorists should not face long lines to buy gasoline this year, next year, or any year in this decade.

title: Sara Troy Has Nuptials
description: Sara Vanessa Troy, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William D. Troy of Stamford, Conn., and John Lewis Machir, son. of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis W. Machir of Washington, were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. William Nagle, assisted by the Rev. John Jazowski and the Rev. Martin J. McDermott and Msgr. John J. Toomey, performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford.

title: One by a master, one by a patzer
description: Reading at length about the unattractive Bobby Fischer brought back an old story my grandfather used to tell. Seems there was this romantic chap who fell in love with a noted soprano. Her voice was glorious. He tracked his soprano from stage door to stage door and finally by strong perseverance won her hand. On their wedding night he waited, expectant and worshipful. His soprano bride came in stage left. And removed her hair. And removed her upper plate. Also, my grandfather embroidered, she had something of a modest hunchback. Her new husband took one short glance, closed his eyes and said: For God's sake, sing.

title: Susan Lingle Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Lingle Jr. of Cincinnati of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lee Lingle, to David William Moeller, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Moeller of Cincinnati and South Yarmouth, Mass. The wedding is planned for Nov. 30.

title: Giants to Face New Eagle Image
This Week in Sports
description: Bettors can win more (or lose less) at Aqueduct, which opens a 71day meeting (through Jan. 4) tomorrow. For the first 21 days they will continue to get the same experimental 3 per cent reduction in the mutuel takeout14 per cent instead of 17 per centthey got at Belmont. That break resulted in an 8.5 per cent jump in attendance and a 12.6 rise in handle compared with last year's figures at Belmont.

title: The World/Continued
description: WASHINGTONFidel Castro once called the Organization of American States the whorehouse of imperialism. But the handsome vaulted O.A.S. building with its palmstudded courtyard on the corner of 17th and Constitution in Washington looks much more like a retirement home for the 23 ambassadors who meet there occasionally.

title: A Thriller Set in Hamptons
description: AMAGANSETT For Berton Rouech, The New Yorker medical writer, this superficially quiet community is not only a yeararound home, but it has also given him the setting for an actionpacked suspense novel in which some residents may find their likenesses.

title: CITY CONSTRUCTION WILL BE CUT BACK
description: Some projects that New York City already has promised to build, including schools and hospitals, will have to be called off because of an exceptional squeeze on construction money, according to Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh.

title: How to Order Tickets For Winter Olympics
description: There will he only one source for United States fans who want to buy tickets to the 1976 Winter Olympic Games.

title: After 41 Years The Depression Finally Ending
description: At his first inaugural, on March 4, 1933, President Franklin D. Roosevelt warned that the United States was a stricken nation in the midst of a stricken world, and that he might soon have to ask Congress for broad executive power to wage war against the enemy. The enemy was economicthe great Depression.

title: Klamath Falls, Ore.Living in Hot Water
description: KLAMATH FALLS, Ore.If you have ever been through this beautiful part of the country before, there is nothing much different at first blush about Klamath Falls: Tractortrailers rumbling through town all day on their way to the big Weyerhaeuser plant south of town, lumber stacked high in yards along the Southern Pacific's tracks, people who say hi even when they don't know you.

title: Opal Woodley Sherman Dead; Y.W.C.A Board Member, 66
description: Opal Woodley Sherman, a member of the national board of the Young Women's Christian Association and chairman of its world service Council, died yesterday of cancer in the Community Hospital, Brown wood, Tex. She was 66 years old and lived in Brownwood and at 150 East 69th Street.

title: Districting at Issue in Nassau
description: MINEOLAShould Nassau County retain the Board of Supervisors form of government, with its complex weightedvoting system, or should it follow the lead of Suffolk with a legislature made up of representatives of districts with approximately equal population? This question will goindirectly to the voters next month as Nassau Proposition No. 1.

title: News of the Screen
description: Although Carol Burnett's considerable talents are available largely to television audiences, Miss Burnett, who is rarely seen on the big screen, says she loves movies and has now done something about it. Reached in Hollywood, she disclosed that she had acquired America's Sweetheart, an original screenplay by George Furth in which she will star for her own company, Punkin Productions.

title: Tessa Gellman Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gellman of Valley Stream, L. I., have made known the engagement of their, daughter, Tessa Ann Gellman, to Gerald Greaney, son of Mrs. Vincent Greaney of Flushiing, Queens, and the late Mr. Greaney. The future bride's father is executive director of the Jewish Memorial Hospital here.

title: Carol Good Married to Timothy Welch
description: Trinity United Methodist Church in Hackettstown, N. J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Carol Ann Good, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Good of Hackettstown, to Timothy Jay Welch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Welch of Holyoke, Mass.

title: Suffolk Using Computer to Aid Jobless
description: HAUPPAUGE  Suffolk County, which has an unemployment rate of 6.2 per cent, 0.8 per cent higher than the national average, is trying to reduce the number of unemployed through a new system in which people who want jobs can be matched up by a computer with jobs that seem to meet their qualifications.

title: Teresa Weinick to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Weinick of Hillside, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Teresa Weinick, to Kenneth Beskin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Beskin of Wantagh, L. I. The future bridegroom is a lawyer here.

title: Thief Is Selective
description: ALAMOSA, Colo. (AP)County Sheriff Ben Phillips reported a trailer thief with an odd taste. The thief ignored money and valuable jewelry in plain sight. Instead the made off with an afghan, a rug, a mplifiertapedeck combination, a bottle of men's cologne and a pair of women's underpants.

title: Museum Draws on NineteenthCentury Artists
description: NEWARK  Those who wish to explore the byways of 19thcentury American art will revel in the exhibition of landscapes, stilllifes, portraits and genre scenes at the Newark Museum.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: An unmistakable smell of garlic is wafting through the grain markets these days because some 15 per cent of the nation's soft red winter wheat crop has been found to contain large amounts of the pungent herb.

title: Montana Wins by 270
description: MISSOULA, Mont., Oct, 12 (AP)Rock Svennungsen, a senior quarterback, passed for 105 yards and a touchdown today to, lead Montana to a 270 Big Sky Conference victory over Northern Arizona University.

title: Youth, 17, Charged With the Shooting Of C.C.N.Y. Guard
description: A 17yearold youth was arraigned yesterday? in Manhattan Criminal Court on a charge of attempted murder in the shooting of a City College security guard Thursday night.

title: At 96, She Is Still a Coed
description: SCHENECTADY, N Y., Oct. 12 (AP)Alice Scudder, who may be the nation's oldest college student, has returned for another term at Schenectady County Community College. Mrs. Scudder, who turned 96 on Sept. 8, enrolled last spring in a creative writing course offered by the college's Continuing Education program. She is taking another writing course this term that meets one evening a week for 10 weeks.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: The Animals at Shea/Scoreboard at Yankee Stadium
description: To the Editor: The fracas at Shea Stadium on Sept. 24 was just a slight exaggeration of what has become normal at almost all professional sports.

title: Assembly Post in Doubt
description: TRENTON  Assembly Democrats are preparing for another power struggle, this one to determine the possible new Speaker in the lower house.

title: Greek Politicians, Squelched for Years, Find Time Has Changed, Their Style
description: ATHENS, Oct. 12  Shortly after Constantine Caramanlis returned to Greece last July and became Premier, he addressed the nation on television. His advisers were astonished at how stiff and nervous he seemed.

title: N.B.A. Opens Play Thursday With 5 Big Names Gone, 2 Big Men Arriving
description: Can the Knicks regroup without Willis Reed and Dave DeBusschere? Can Bill Walton turn the Portland Trail Blazers from the worst team in the National Basketball Association into one of the best? What effect will the addition of Nate Thurmond have on the Chicago Bulls? Can Bill Russell of Seattle make Tom Burleson into a center in his own image?

title: Ellen Bauman Is Married to Dr. Robert Scalettar
description: Ellen Bauman was married yesterday evening to Dr. Robert Scalettar of Great Neck, L. I.

title: SCHOOL DATA LAW DRAWS CRITICISM
description: Senator James L. Buckley of New York has announced that he will introduce legislation next month to qualify a recently enacted Federal law giving parents the right to inspect, challenge and protect the school records of their children.

title: Ideas &Trends Education, Economics, Crime
description: Like it or not, moviegoers increasingly are finding themselves captive audiences for commercials they may not want either to pay for or to see.

title: NEW STUDY BACKS VITAMIN C IN COLDS
description: A Canadian researcher has reported finding therapeutic value in using vitamin C to treat symptoms of the common cold in much lower doses than had been previously recommended.

title: Janet Tenney Wed To Thomas J. Foltz
description: In the Friends Meeting House in Chappaqua, N. Y., yesterday afternoon, Janet Elizabeth Tenney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvan H. Tenney of Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., became the bride of Thomas James Foltz. He is the son of Jane C. Foltz of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Warren D. Foltz.

title: Koch Catch Sparks Brick's Triumph
description: Unbeaten Brick Township pulled out its third victory yesterday in the final four minutes when Paul Durkin passed 34 yards to Dale Koch and Tony Aulisi kicked the deciding point for a 2120 decision in Neptune.

title: The OilPrice Solution
description: Some three weeks ago President Ford publicly warned the oilproducing nations that their extortionate prices threatened to trigger a general depression and produce a breakdown of the world's order and safety. A few days later, Secretary Kissinger privately urged the main oilimporting countries to cut petroleum consumption substantiallyas much as 15 per centas part of a determined strategy to force prices down. A few days ago, Mr. Ford finally revealed his own conservation target for the world's most profligate oilRonsumer, the United States, which uses two to three times as much energy per capita as the other industrial countriesmuch it wastefully.

title: Education Through Art
description: Herbert Read's Education Through Art, originally written more than 30 years ago in England during the Second World War, still has the power to move, inspire and illuminate. The book is both more and less than a treatise on the arteducation of children: Although Read makes many concrete suggestions in the latter part of the work about the actual school curriculum and has obviously consulted many professional educators, he openly admits that discussion of specific teaching methods is outside his competence. What is actually stake is vast reform not merely of artteaching but of human nature and society through a wholly revised conception of education.

title: Sinatra in Top of Form at the Garden
description: Frank Sinatra, by now long removed from his supposed retirement of just last year, rmains the consummate showman. He made his comeback last January in Las Vegas, and at his first New York concert, April 8, there were reportedly signs of rustiness. But last night at Madison Square Garden, as part of a ninecity national tour tha began Oct. 2 in Boston, Mr. Sinatra seemed on top of his presentday form.

title: Capital Mood Turns
description: WASHINGTONThe tide Is running with the automobile industry in its battle against new Government restraints.

title: Coliseum Alters Ticket Policy
description: UNIONDALE  The management of the Nassau County Veterans Memorial Coliseum said this week that a new policy on the sale of tickets has been implemented as a result of pressure from the State Attorney General's Office, stemming from more than 150 complaints about sale of tickets for April's series of concerts by Frank Sinatra.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WHOLESALE PRICES rose onetenth of 1 per cent. September, seasonally adjusted, the smallest increase 11 months, to 167.2 per cent of the 1967 base. . . The First National City Bank and the First National Bank of Chicago dropped their prime rate to 11 per cent. . . Arthur F. Burns, Federal Reserve chairman, told Congress that the Fed would pursue a policy to increase the money supply and would be less restrictive in its monetary policy.

title: Mack & Mabel Makes Gloomy Stage Music
description: I HAVE rarely seen so much talent so dispirited as the creative souls peering through the gloom at the Majestic. There it all is. Robert Preston to play Mack Sennett, the dumb Irishman who was so busy inventing Keystone Kops that he forgot to tell Mabel Normand he loved her, ready to put his restless buzz saw of a voice behind the whole lumbering business and push. Bernadette Peters, pale as a silent film but topped with massed curls that halfsuggest she has a nest of ravens in her hair, perfectly prepared to leap from a catwalk and ride down a scaffoldingpipe if that will help any to get things going. Gower Champion, master of the production number that builds and builds and builds, watching sequence after sequence come apart in his hands as though the world was made of matchboxes with nothing inside. And all of them turning to composerlyricist Jerry Herman as if to say You tell the story, we'll just sit.

title: Gary David Rheinwald Weds Leslie A. Daum
description: The marriage of Leslie Ann Daum to Gary David Rheinwald took place at noon yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Warren Robert Daum in Lawrence, L.I. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Rheinwald of Brockport, N.Y. Judge Charles Heine of the Nassau County District Court performed the ceremony.

title: Rosamond Prout Becomes a Bride
description: In the Dover (Mass.) Church at noon yesterday, Rosamond Prout, daughter of Dr, and Mrs. Curtis Prout of Dover, was married to George Hilliard Warren 2d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth Warren of Wellesley Hills, Mass., and Dublin, N.H. The Rev. Deene D. Clark performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: StateMunicipalities Battle Over Zoning Is Heading for Another Showdown
description: TRENTON  Whether the state or individual municipalities will have final say over local planning and zoning laws appears to be heading for another confrontation in the Legislature and, possibly, the courts.

title: McBurney Conquers Horace Mann, 386
description: Whether running or throwing, it was Jim DeCalogero's day as he led McBurney past Horace Mann yesterday, 386. The senior quarterback, who plays cornerback on defense tossed three touchdown passes of 28, 25, and 57 yards, and ran in for two more tallies.
