Horace Mann's sputtering offense could not get going as McBurney stopped drive after drive.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS ANTIPOLLUTION PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)The Supreme Court has refused to restore an injunction prohibiting the Reserve Mining Company from disCharging allegedly hazardous wastes into Lake Superior and into the air.

title: A's Triumph Over Dodgers in World Series Opener, 32
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12The Oakland A's, the Lavender Hill Mob of baseball, won the opening round of the 71st World Series today by edging the Los Angeles Dodgers, 32, in the major leagues' first allCalifornia series.

title: CHAD TRIBAL RITE DISRUPTING NATION
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, Oct. 6A compulsory revival of a longneglected tribal rite is disrupting Chad's public life, terrorizing members of the small educated lite and, according to informed sources, has caused a number of deaths.

title: Detroit Faces '75 Fit for Any Shift
description: ETROITA toughened auto Industry more responsive to the shifting moods of the market is emerging from the crucible of 1974, a year of energy crisis, soaring material costs and falling sales.

title: Oil Issue Aids Soviet
description: While Western leaders have been struggling against the impact of higher oil prices, the Soviet Union has welcomed the price increases for both economic and political reasons. Page 2.

title: Long Lafayette Pass Play Helps Beat Hofstra, 177
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 12 Dave Del Bello's 83yard touchdown pass play in the third quarter helped lift Lafayette College to a 1717 victory over Hofstra University today.

title: Bank Installs Floating Floor
description: The trust and investment division of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has moved into new quarters at 9 West 57th Street that include a floating floor. The bank had been unable to find a floor big enough for its 50 investment man agers and an equal number of research specialists, and it wanted them in close proximity. Its architect, Bernard M. Deschier, found that the second floor in the 57th Street building had 26foot ceilings, and he designed the 18,000squarefoot mezzanine, which is suspended by cables from the building's structural members. The steel cables and turnbuckles are covered with cast aluminum.

title: University to Honor Liberia's President
description: RUTHERFORD Fairleigh Dickinson University will award an honorary Doctor of Laws degree to William R. Tolbert, President of Liberia, on Nov. 1. The degree will be conferred by Jerome M. Pollack, president of the university, in a special ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church.

title: Dennis Dolan: Unemployed Since June
description: GARDEN CITY, Mich.Dennis Dolan, a 31yearold journeyman plumber who wears his red hair moderately long and his mustache short, is one of those straightforward, self  confident young workers who seem increasingly to populate the industrial landscape today. They are sure of themselves and their abilities, hip to the modern world, articulate and versatile enough to put on a neat shirt and tie and make a whitecollar living (as Mr. Dolan once did) if they so chose.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Last Week's Tally for Metropolitan Area

title: Linda K. Doll Has Nuptials
description: Linda Katherine Doll, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Walter Doll of Manchester, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Erich Loflin Cluxton, son of Dr. H. Hayes Cluxton of Westerly, R.I., and Nell Cluxton of Providence, R.I.

title: New & Novel
description: Before the student uprisings of the late 1960's sink completely into the bog of memorabilia, comes an artful novel to capture that strange ambience in amber. The winds of change are blowing on the campus of Henry Thoreau College, but what do they portend? Participatory democracy? Coed dorms? An end to tenure? Who cares? What is in the cards is a showdown between a resistible force (students) and moveable object (administration).

title: Manhattan Beaten In CrossCountry
description: Peter Squires and Tony Colon finished first and second for Manhattan College but William and Mary broke the Jaspers' crosscountry, dualmeet winning streak at 39 with a 3029 upset.

title: Inflation, Riots, Public SafetyAll Important in 1836
description: America was in the throes of an inflation that saw the price of basic foods more than double in two years. Rioters roamed the streets of some cities. People complained that muggers and robbers made it unsafe to go out at night. The leaders of Massachusetts decided that the times required a new approach providing quality education for the children of all people.

title: Chess: Korchnoi Labors Mightily, But Brings Forth a Draw
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 12  Victor Korchnoi pressed his pawnahead end game as hard as he was able today, but he still was not able to defeat Anatoly Karpov in the 11th game of their final Candidates Match for the world championship.

title: U.S. Plane Missing Off China
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 12 (AP)An Air Force weather reconnaissance plane with six men aboard was missing and presumed down in the South China Sea, a Coast Guard spokesman said today, The fourengine C130 aircraft from the Air Force 54th Weather Wing on Guam was involved in updating information on Typhoon Bess in the South China Sea when it disappeared between Hong, Kong and Taiwan, the spokesman said.

title: Mary Weiss Plans Wedding Next June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Weiss of Sewickley, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Carroll Weiss, to Richard Alvey Jamison Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jamison of Baltimore.

title: Planners Preparing for Starrett City's Tenants
description: Governor Wilson, Mayor Beanie and a number of other dignitaries are scheduled to go to the southeastern edge of Brooklyn this morning to dedicate Starrett City, the largest housing development to be opened in New York thus far in the nineteenseventies.

title: Love letters, some not so loving
description: It is necessary for the writer of fiction not to argue with his characters: he must not like them too much, not dislike them at all, and the good writer knows this by instinct and does not often have to think about it. But the historian or biographer cannot afford to rely on instinct: he must make sure, every word examined, that the people he is writing about are not the victims of his loving or unloving heart. Nobody outside of a baby carriage or a Judge's chamber can believe in an unprejudiced point of view but, simply in selfinterest, the biographer must try for one, or make us believe he has, or tell that he hasn't.

title: In This Corner, The A's
description: LOS ANGELES. Oct. 12When the World Series opened today, the Oakland A's should have been wearing green and gold bathrobes. Instead of a water cooler in their dugout, they needed Dick Sadler holding a gray pail with a bottle in it. They needed Angelo Dundee as cutman. Instead of Alvin Dark as their manager, they should have imported Arthur Mercante as their referee. They should have worn gloves on both hands, eightounce gloves. The lament in boxing is that there aren't any heavyweights in the gyms anymore. That's only because the best prospects are playing baseball, in their spare time, for the Oakland A's.

title: Oriental Galleries Opened
description: The Brooklyn Museum opened four new galleries this week devoted to Korean and Japanese art and this welcome, addition secured a distinctive place for the institution. Brooklyn has become the only museum in the Metropolitan area where a comprehensive display of Korean and Japanese art can be seen.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star must be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Paperbacks
description: It is hard to believe that these freshminted, sassy and insightful short stories, with their silvery ring of authority, are almost exactly 40 years old. The original title of the collection or, rather, selectionwhen it appeared in 1935 was Time: The Present, and so alive is Tess Slesinger's voice that she makes her times, which were intensely important to her, seem present again to us, dwellers in a very different decade. Yet Tess Slesinger died of cancer in 1945, at the age of 39. She had been considered one of the more promising young writers of the 1930's (as well as one of the most personable, according to Twentieth Century Authors, with a smile as vivid as her literary style) on the basis of her stories and her one ovel, The Unpossessed. (Alas, it is out of print.) But the last 10 years of her life, spent writing screenplays in Hollywood (The Good Earth, A Tree Grows in Brooklyn), did not live up to the rough promise of the novel or the more finished brilliance of her best stories. A lesson in carpe diem if there ever was one. But such times of silence in a writer's life often bear riper fruit, and premature death is cruelest when it decrees barren what may have been time of growth and gathering forces. Tess Slesinger left notebooks that suggested she meant to get back to fiction and I believe she would have, in her forties, and further that she would have outgrown the slight tendency to mannerism and the bright and strenuous consciousness that occasionally mar her early fiction. We'll never know. Reviewing her gives me a particular sense of futility because in her writing she is so very much alive.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The New York Telephone Company has purchased more than a third of the block between 46th and 47th Streets and Eleventh and Twelfth Ave nues for use as Its main coin collection facility in the city.

title: Still getting the ink
description: Babe

title: West Essex Regional Upsets Bloomfield
description: West Essex Regional pulled off a major upset and stamped itself as a New Jersey power yesterday when it defeated previously unbeaten Bloomfield, 120, in North Caldwell for its third straight victory.

title: Food
description: We were about to state that ground beef has more uses than plastic. We will revise that to say it has more uses than filet mignon or sirloin. A hamburger, perfectly made, can be one of the glories of a grill, and a meat loaf is, as we've noted often, only one version of pate. Ground beef is given an uncommon stature in the recipes on this page. There are hamburgers  la russe, groundmeat patties with a cream sauce (flavored with a trace of Cognac) and beef balls Stroganoff.

title: Santana's Octet Reaching Beyond Formulas of Past
description: Just three years ago, Santana was an enormously popular rock band, the most prominent and the most stylish of those to merge rock, African drumming and Latin rhythms. But then the group was beset by internal conflicts and managerial confusions, and Carlos Santana, the lead guitarist and central figure, got religion. The commercial Impetus was lost and many of the original musk cians drifted away.

title: An Aluminum Boardwalk?
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Will this resort's famous Boardwalk ever have to have its name changed to Alurniwalk?

title: RV Market Survives Shakeout
description: CHICAGO  The dinosaur vanished wins ago for reasons still unclear, and this year the huge motor homes and travel trailers were supposed to follow for obvious reasons: the fuel crisis and financing problems.

title: Rosemary McCarty To Wed in Winter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Patrick McCarty of River Forest, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosemary Catherine McCarty, to Richard Turner of Stanway, Essex, England, son of Mrs. Sidney Turner and the late Major Turner of the Royal Horse Artillery.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: First of all, let me say that I am totally and completely shocked that The Times, a publication that prides itself on printing only news fit to print, would publish such garbage as Winthrop Griffith's article on Cesar Chavez and the United Farm Workers Union (Is Chavez beaten? Sept. 15). While one might be led to give Mr. Griffith credit for what appears to be an innocent job of reporting, the article is very cleverly written with the obvious intention of being misleading and harmful to the whole struggle of the United Farm Workers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR: Hospitals, like families, are the victims of the current inflationary spiral, but reports out of Washington indicate that many Government officials fail to understand this.

title: New Models: Plush, With a Foreign Look
description: DETROITMaybe, Ford executives thought, with our new car the size of a Mercedes, disguised as a Mercedes, it ought to have a German name.

title: A Year of Costly Oil And Abrupt Changes
description: WASHINGTON  Fueloil companies used to come around in summer and clean the furnacefree. This year they sent a notice offering the service for $28. Also they have begun slapping a service charge on customers who don't pay their bills in 30 days.

title: Mary Hannah Von Culin Married
description: Mary Hannah Von Culin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Von Culin of Pottersville, N.J., and Christopher Eric Herold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Herold of Far Hills, N.J., were married yesterday afternoon. Gen. G. W. Hyatt of Washington, the Army's chief of chaplains and a friend of the bride's family, performed the ceremony in the Zion Lutheran Church. Oldwick, N.J.

description: SOUTHAMPTONA free lunch program for senior citizens, discontinued by the Town Board two weeks ago, will resume on Nov. 1 under the sponsorship of the Red Cross.

description: Battle lines are being drawn for a public information meeting Wednesday at the Suffolk County Planning Building in Hauppauge on a controversial landuse bill proposed by State Senator Bernard C. Smith of Northport.

title: Jerry on the Hustings
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12In the last few days, President Ford has been out campaigning in Vermont, Pennsylvania and Michigan, and in the next few days he will be back trying to drum up votes for the Republicans in Missouri, Nebraska, South Dakota, Indiana, North and South Carolina and Kentucky.

title: Photography
description: THE few photographs by Ralph Steiner that everyone knows are documentary photographs that tend to fix him permanently in the few years around 1930. They are all in the sharply focused style that came in during the 1920's. The subjectsan automobile fender, an ornate wicker rocking chair on a smalltown front porch, the keys of a typewriterare taken from ordinary life rather than from fantasy or fairy tales.

title: EXPO '74 SHOWING SIGNS OF THE END
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 12 (AP)  Expo '74 has three weeks to live, and its imminent death is noticeable.

title: Flash a Bit Wins Horse Show Title
description: GLADSTONE, N. J., Oct. 12Flash A Bit, a smartstepping bay gelding owned by Mrs. M. Kane Hofmann's Windy Acres Farm, won the regular working hunter championship today at the Gill SchoolSt. Bernard's Horse Show.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Original Fiction Boom In Paperback
description: The paperback houses are suffering a little social angst these days. Here they are not only originating and launching more original fiction than ever before but also lavishing as much editorial and promotional skills and money on at least some of the books as do the hardcover houses. But, like the newrich family who moves into an established neighborhood only to be snubbed by the Old Moneyin this case their hardcover peers, not to mention the book world's social arbiters, the critics and book reviewers the paperbook houses are hungering for more respect and trying to live down their image as literary parasites, sucking the creative juices of their betters.

title: Karen Bednarski to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bednarski of Bradford, Vt., have announced the engagement of  their daughter, Karen Bednarski, to Bradley A. Blackburn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Blackburn of Manhasset, L. I., and West Brattleboro, Vt. The couple are seniors at the University of Vermont.

title: Five. Blocked Punts Help Clinton Romp
description: Clinton worked its best playthe blocked puntto perfection yesterday as it swamped Lehman, 610, in a Public Schools Athletic League Bronx Division game at Clinton.

title: A Bank in Jersey City Converted to Housing
description: JERSEY CITYFour young business executivesnone of them expert in constructionare converting an old bank in the Paulus Hook section of Jersey City into a 13apartment condominium.

title: Dartmouth Bows to Ivy Rival, 147

It was served by a determined Princeton eleven that processed two fumbles into its two touchdowns to emerge with a 147 triumph. The success for the Tigers, marring the Indians' opening defense of its title, was their first over the Big Green since 1969.

description: An 84yearold widow who lived alone was found stabbed to death late last night in her sevenroom apartment in a tenement in Harlem.

title: Foundations and Colleges, Among Others, Live and Die With Dow Jones
description: The institutional beggars of American society  thousands of nonprofit organizations, including schools, libraries, hospitals and foundationsare studying the daily stock market tables with a growing sense of horror. Last week's rally must have pleased them. But for investments that have lost half their value, a rise of 10 to 15 per cent wasn't enough to allay the gloom.

title: Once Active Colorado Campus Little Moved by Poll in '74
description: BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 10Once upon a time, the University of Colorado campus bristled with political activity. Not this year.

title: A classic at 25
description: It has only four walls, and they are all of glass, and there are no interior partitions. It should be the simplest sort of building to analyze, but it has kept architects and critics talking for 25 years now. The building is Philip Johnson's Glass House in New Canaan, Conn.a modern classic, and in every sense one of 20thcentury American architecture's truly great houses.

title: Social Announcements
description: Births

title: Television
description: BY almost anyone's definition Herb Alpert looks super. California tan, shiny white teeth, a firm, assertive jaw and the kind of lithe muscles that come from long afternoons on the tennis courts with pals like songwriter Burt Bacharach and his wife, actress Angie Dickinson. I guess, Alpert told me recently, you could say I've been pretty lucky. A lot of really nice things have happened to me.

title: Hardy of Army Runs 100 Yards For Score, but Duke Wins, 3314
description: DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 12 (AP)  Oncebeaten Duke rolled to a 3314 triumph over Army today for its fourth consecutive victory.

description: CAIRO, Oct. 12Egypt re fuses to make any politica concessions in exchange for new partial withdrawal of Is raeli forces in the Sinai, well informed Egyptian sources sail today.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12An effort to enlist Congressional support for giving all public school pupils a realistic picture of how the law and the justice system operate was begun this week by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

description: TRENTON  The annual display of fall foliage in New Jersey should be exceptionally good this year, according to Secretary of Agriculture Phillip Alampi.

description: Two persons were killed last night when a fire, touched off by a series of mysterious explosions, roared through a Bay Ridge toy store in Brooklyn's Fifth Avenue.

title: Cook College experiment a Success
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  An experiment in the blending of agricultural and liberalarts curriculums has proved spectacularly popular as Cook College enters its second year of existence.

title: Where the Action Is
description: Nearly 40 years ago Cyril Connolly cited journalism as one of the chief enemies of promise (in his memoir of that name) which a young writer ought to steer clear of. Although the magazine hackwork and book reviewing he was particularly referring to does remain a rather unfruitful endeavor, it is unlikely he or any other observer could so crisply dismiss journalism now. Any number of first books by eely, quick and yet encompassing new talents would refute the idea. If a tugofwar were waged between the young and serious novelists round about and the serious young journalists, the latter might well win, both with respect to giftedness and numbers. They are beset with opportunitiesup to the Adam's apple in opportunitiesperhaps including the possibility of accomplishing something. Journalism itself in fact is the theater of operations toward which a literary youngster who still believes in the American dream would naturally incline: where it might appear to him that if he tackles a large project and works hard at it he can become rich and famous, though he may be writing about the overall destruction of the American dream. (Novelists get rich too, but by a much more whimsical process.)

title: What's Opened at the Movies?
description: THE TAKING OF PELHAM ONE TWO THREE, (R) dirocted by Joseph Sargent from a screenplay by Peter Stone and starring Walter Matthau, Robert Shaw, Martin Balsam and Hector Elizondo, was generally well received by the critics, including ours.

title: Turnaround in Big Board Seat Prices
description: There has always been a fairly close correlation between the level of stock prices and the going rate for seats on the New York Stock Exchange. In 1968, with the Dow Jones industrials in the high 900's, a seat was sold for a record price of $515,000. In contrast, during World War II, a record low of $17,000 was set in 1942, with the Dow at that time stagnant at about 100.

title: Former Assistant to Daley Is 3d Convicted in 3 Days
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (UPI)Earl Bush, former press assistant to Mayor Richard J. Daley, was convicted yesterday on 11 counts of mail fraud. He was the third former Daley aide in three days to be convicted of a felony.

description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.What Sassoon is to hair, what Elizabeth Arden is to faces, Ken Young is to cars.

title: Inflation, a Time to Think of Switching to LIFO
description: The current economic environment is causing many corporations to consider changing methods of inventory evaluation. Hundreds have already switched from FIFO (firstin, firstout) to LIFO (lastin, firstout) as a means of tempering the effects of inflation on reported earnings.

title: Nixon Papers Moved
description: Despite assurances by President Ford's counsel that all papers from the Nixon Administration would remain intact at the White House, at least one such carton of papers has left the White House and been returned. Page 74.

title: RETAILING
description: The fashion industry, which has been buffeted by skirt  length changes, by fierce competition and more recently by erratic sales, was rocked last week by a Government bombshell for the second time in less than a month.

title: Scientists Hint Explanation to Extinction of Mammoth
description: Over the years archeologists, digging up Ice Age relics in areas as widely scattered as Alaska, Florida and New Mexico, have found shafts of straight bone worked so uniformly and carefully that they must have played an important role in the perilous life of that time.

title: Tsuris in the City
description: New York is the only city in the world with traffic signals that flash tsuris.

description: SAN FRANCISCO (UPI)The University of the Pacific school pharmacy has reported development of a new dry foam preparation for burn treatment that eliminates the need to apply ointmnt. The foam is sprayed on the burn.

description: Tickets for the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) President. Ford marked National Newspaper Carrier Day today by greeting three youngsters who deliver newspapers, including. Lu Ann Leno, 13, a New York Daily News delivery girl.

description: WASHINGTONIn practically all of the domestic field offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, there is, in some quiet corner, a tiny, tightly controlled area called the Sutech room. The term stands for Technical Surveillance, which to anyone outside the F.B.I. is known as wiretapping.

Jacobson in the grand ballroom of the Copley Plaza Hotel in Boston. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Ruhenfeld of Peekskill, N. Y.

description: HAUPPAUGE  Suffolk County's new master plan for the acquisition and development of parks and recreation areas, released last week, has acquired a highly influential criticJohn V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, who says that he has serious reservations about certain aspects of the document.

title: No Policy For School Integration
description: Mayor Kevin White of Boston has properly rebuked President Ford for statements lending aid and comfort to those resisting a court order for the desegregation of Boston schools. But the fact is that the Federal Government no longer has a policy for achieving school desegregation, and Mr. Ford's unfortunate remarks only reflected that lack,

description: WYCKOFF  To most people, whittling is a hobby pursued only by Boy Scouts or perhaps tobaccochewing elderly men who live in rural areas.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, who leaves office at the end of this year, is actively pursuing the possibility of a 1976 campaign for the Republican nomination for President.

title: WESTCHESTER GRIP TIGHTENED BY MOB
description: Despite years of investigation by Federal and local lawenforcement agencies, the domination by organized crime of commercial garbage carting in Westchester County is spreading.

title: Bargains in Used Cars Hard to Find
description: There aren't many bargains in the used car market, either, and there may not be many for a while. The great panic, set off by the fuel shortage last winter, that cut tags on big and luxury used cars is over.

title: HOSPITALS SEEK $10MILLION IN AID
description: Representatives of the city's leading voluntary hospitals have told Mayor Beame that without $10million more from the city or state they will have to institute immediate drastic reductions in their services to municipal hospitals.

title: Michigan Wins, 217, for 5th Victory
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich, Oct. 12 (AP)Michigan took advantage of Michigan State fumbles to score twice in the second quarter  once When Dan Jilek recovered a bobble in the end zoneas the Wolverines posted a 217 Big Ten victory today.

title: Alabama Wins, 87, With, Kick
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 12 (UPI)  Buckey Berrey kicked a 36yard field goal. with 33 seconds remaining today, giving Alabama an 87 victory over Florida State after the Seminoles had gambled by giving the Crimson Tide a deliberate safety.

title: Policeman Reinstated
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Oct. 12 (AP)Wallace J. Vance, a Coral Gables policeman, was reinstated with back pay after he agreed to stop living with his girl friend. Mr. Vance, 25 years old, said he would temtorarily make other living arrangements but he said he and his girl friend, Rebecca Frizelle, were considering marriage.

title: At Seton Art Center, StudentRestored Madonna
description: SOUTH ORANGEVisitors to Seton Hall University's new Art Center will receive an unusual greeting. On entering the reception room of the gallery, they will encounter a statue whose authentication and restoration are largely the work of students.

title: COURSE IS GIVEN FOR TOUR GUIDES
description: ORONO, Me. Every Tuesday; Marjorie Sewell leaves her home in Caribu and drives 200 miles to the University of Maine's largest branch here for her tourguide class.

title: Recordings
description: IF chanting the name of the Lord can set you free  as George Harrison once sang  then we should remember that the Lord has many forms and that chanting is a universal phenomenon, occurring as it does in Tibetan and in Japanese Zen monasteries, in the Russian and Byzantine churches, in American Indian rituals, in Jewish liturgy, and, of course, in Catholic monasteries all over the world.

title: Lehigh Fag By 3716. To Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 12It took the Rutgers' offense a while to get untracked today but the defense held Lehigh until the Scarlet Knights could rally to a 3716 victory before an apperciative crowd of 17,500 at Rutgers Stadium.

title: Veterans Caught in City Welfare Battle
description: At 3 A.M. on a recent Friday, 35 young men were huddled around a fire in an open trash can in front of 90 Myrtle Avenue, a welfare center in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Spotlight on Cars, Eyes on Their Prices
description: THE curtain's up on Detroit's 1975 models, but it's their price and not their looks that dominates the stage.

title: Clarkstown South Triumphs, 37 to 6
description: Clarkstown South gained sole possession of first place, and preserved its undefeated record in Rockland County Public School Athletic League football by trouncing previously undefeated North Rockland Red Raiders, 37:6 yesterday at North Rockland.Billy McDonald paced Clarkstown South with touchdown runs of 22, 16, and 12 yards. Other scores for Clarkstown South were Tony Sigillito's 73yard punt return and Mike Condon's 8yard run.

title: Holy Family Defeats Maria Regina, 288
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 12 Holy Family overpowered Maria Regina, 288, as Ed Cooney and Tom Donovan had two touchdowns each and a senior, middle guard, Frank Grilli, had 16 unassisted tackles today, Cooney, ha d147 yards rushing over 26 carries to put his pushing yardage at 450 on the season. The Holy Family defense all owed Only two first downs, one in each half.

title: Room for One More
description: Halfway across the Interstate 74 bridge that links Iowa and Illinois over the Mississippi, 22yearold Mary Atkins told her husband, Steve, to stop the car. She just couldn't make it, and there she gave birth in August to their third daughter on the front seat of the family Volkswagen.

title: GIFT LIST TERMED A LIMITED PICTURE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The list of gifts totaling about $2million that was released yesterday by Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A Rockefeller does not give a true, picttire of the Rockefeller interests and how they prosper in part through loans and gifts, a Congressional source said today.

title: Turkey: Still Ineligible
description: The virulent White House opposition to efforts by decisive majorities in both houses of Congress to suspend military aid to Turkey has no basis in either law or logic. President Ford's repeated threats to veto a bill requiring such a cutoff can only be seen as an attempt to block Congress from a meaningful role in the shaping of foreign policy and a move to fend off a blow at the prestige of Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: EDEMA FOUND CAUSE IN NIARCHOS DEATH
description: PARIS, Oct. 12An autopsy of the body of Tina Niarchos, 45yearold wife of the millionaire Greek shipowner Stavros Niarchos, showed that the cause of her death Thursday was a pulmonary edema, a spokesman at the Paris morgue said today.

title: Rockefeller and Money: Not the Usual Problem
description: To many, the accumulation of money is an end in itself. Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller achieved that end at birth. For him, money must have another end, whether it is personal comfort and convenience, charity or power.

title: Bridge
description: The view that bridge even in its competitive forms, is a game of pure skill is easily refuted. Bad contracts sometimes succeed; good contracts sometimes fail; and not infrequently success or failure will depend on the toss of a coin.

title: Big Queens Project Near Completion
description: A 200,000squarefoot Queens site, unused for the last seven years, is about to become the focus of the biggest single development in downtown Flushing.

title: Grand Prix Drivers Questioning Safety Merits of Guardrails
description: The second fatality in two years at the United States States Grand Prix last weekend has left drivers with the feeling that something is wrong with the guardrails at Watkins Glen. About Several drivers, Motor including Denis Hulme, a former Sports president of the safety  conscious Grand Pric Drivers Association, inspected the site of the accident that took the life of 25yarold Helmuth Koinnigg of Austria last weekend, and reported:

title: Headliners
description: Some of the choices for the three Nobel Prizes awarded last week reflect the committee's concern over controversial choices in previous years. The prize in economics will be shared by two economists who represent virtually opposite schools of thought, thus blunting charges that the committee often preferred liberal candidates to conservative ones. The Peace Prize was awarded despite some speculation that none would be given this year. Last year's selection of Henry Kissinger and Le Duc Tho, for negotiating a peace settlement in Vietnam, was criticized, and two of the five members of the Nobel Committee resigned. The Medicine Prize went to three pioneers in cell biology. The winners:

title: Priest Urges Catholic Church to Shift Teaching on Remarriages
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 12A leading Roman Catholic theologian, in an address to the annual meeting of the Canon Law Society of America, has advocated changing the Catholic Church's teaching about the indissolubility of marriage.

title: WATTS, MEHTA TEAM IN STORMY CONCERTO
description: A stormy performance of Beethoven's Emperor Concerto on Friday night was the main feature of the Los Angeles Philharmonic's second Carnegie Hall concert.

title: Boston Businessman Heads 1975 Heart Fund Campaign
description: The appointment of Paul D Slater, head of a Boston realestate investment firm, as national chairman for the 1975 Heart Fund Campaign was announced yesterday by Ross Reid, board chairman of the American Heart Association.

title: BRITON TO SPEAK IN WESTCHESTER
description: Hugh R. TrevorRoper, the British historian and bestselling author, is scheduled to begin tomorrow night a lecture series that, its sponsor hopes, will help advance the cultural greening of Westchester County.

title: Andretti Gains Pole for Coast Race
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 12 (AP)Mario Andretti of Nazareth, Pa., won the pole position today for the Formula 5000 series race at Laguna Seca Raceway tomorrow.

title: Archdiocese Sells Buildings
description: The former headquarters of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, at Lexington Avenue and 22d Street, has been purchased by a group of investors for conversion into a luxury apartment building. The price was $1,771,000.

title: ALBERTA FLOODED WITH OIL REVENUE
description: EDMONTON, AlbertaAt time when most governments at every level, are struggling hard to stay solvent, Alberta, which produces 83 per cent of Canada'' oil, has more money than it knows what to do with.

title: Total imaginative truthprose
description: Writing far faster than he can thinkspeedwriting near, on, over the edge of hysteriaSeymour Krim, the man who stayed behind to mop up after the big Beat Generation bash was long since over, has evolved a badmouthing sortofstyle calculated to set the teeth on edge by offending against right reason, sound judgment, literary manners and the languige itself, ordinary decorum, civility, taste, intelligence, sensibility and much more as these qualities are normally understood and valued in New York, London, Barcelona, Paris, San Juan, Iowa City, the bases from which these periodical pieces, devoted mostly to forgotten contretemps, transient trivia, minor writers and now collected between stiff boards, were originally sent out into the world, let the chips fall where they may and the devil take the hindmost.

title: Music
description: WHEN the curtain rises on th?? American premiere of Benjami Britten's Death in Venice a?? the Metropolitan Opera Hous?? Friday night, the audience will see stark blackandwhite representation ?? Munich's suburbs on a spring evening The atmosphere is restless and uneas?? as a famous poet and author, Gusta von Aschenbach, muses distractedly t?? himself over a nervous pulsation of sol?? woodwinds: My mind beats on and ?? words come ... taxing, tiring, unyield ing, unproductive.

title: Lincoln Captures 3d Straight 306
Stamps
description: A TIME of changeperhaps radical changein the ways of collectors of Americana, stamps and postal stationery, may be drawing nigh if the glints in the eye of the United States Postal Service turn out to be not merely glints, but for real.

description: The Brooklyn Public Library, seeking to reduce theft of books and other materials, has asked the city for $440,000 to install an electronic detection system.

title: Lead Poisoning Is Curtailed in Newark
description: NEWARKIn the course of an eightyear study that is now being completed, a team of publichealth physicians from the New Jersey Medical School has sharply reduced the incidence of crippling lead poisoning among, children in Newark's ghetto areas.

title: COURT EDICT CURBS U.S. ROLE ABROAD
description: A bizarre tale of international kidnapping has resulted in significant court decision here against illegal searches and seizures by United. States agents in foreign lands.

title: Suffolk's Apple Varieties Are Now Ready for Tables
description: During the fall harvest season, the apples are always fresher and more enticing, superior in texture and flavor. Later on, after the apples have been in produce bins for months, the fruit's texture becomes soft and its taste muted.

title: JAPAN IS UNEASY ON AARMS AGAIN
description: TOKYO, Oct. 12Japan teetered on the brink of a political explosion today as an official statement from Washington failed to quell suspicions and charges that the United States had brought nuclear weapons into this nuclearsensitive country.

title: STEELE TELLS ROW HE'D PICK JUDGES
description: HARTFORD, Oct, 12United States Representative Robert H. Steele, the Republican nominee for Governor of Connecticut, has proposed establishing a state commission to name candidates among whom a Governor would have to choose in making appointments to the bench.

title: Andover Defeated By Lawrenceville
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 12Hardrunning Dave Singleton continued to wreak havoc on Lawrenceville's opponents as he carried for one touchdown, caught a pass for another and threw 15 yards for another as he sparked Lawrenceville past Andover today, 2113. He had 121 yards in 12 carries. Dan Dilorati swept right end for 43 yards and Andover's first score. Mike Neborak added 6 points on a 1yard sneak.

title: Former Stars See Lions Lose, 346;
description: Harvard had more difficulty overcoming its own early mistakes than it had with Columbia's football team yesterday. But once it was organized out, the Crimson rolled to a 346 triumph over the Lions, who have not won this season.

title: Princeton Borough and Township in Merger Talks
description: PRINCETON  For the third time in 21 years, residents of Princeton Borough and Princeton Township are considering consolidating the communities into a singie municipality.

title: Phone Company To Provide Scores
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide World Series scores. The number is 6371212. The scores will be updated after each halfinning and final scores will be carried for several hours after the end of each game.

title: COURT EDICT CURBS U.S. ROLE ABROAD
description: A bizarre tale of international kidnapping has resulted in a significant court decision here against illegal searches and seizures by United States agents in foreign lands.

title: Safety Puzzle: Deaths Down More Than Traffic
description: Automotive safety expert say they are beginning to solve what amounts to a crime that didn't happen: Why have so many fewer people died on the nation's highways this year?

title: In Edison, Land Use Is a Matter of Pride
description: EDISON  While mos people think of this sprawl ing, 32squaremile townshiy as the place where Thomas Alva Edison developed the electric bulb, residents pay little attention either to the. old Menlo Park section of the area, where Edison actually worked, on to any other facet of the township's history. Instead, their pride centers on what they have been able to do in the development of houses, industry and recreational facilities, and it is probably no exaggeration to say that Edison has been successful in working out a program of land use that is one of the best in the state.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As planning consultant to the Office of the Mayor, I advanced the city's first major planned unit development, Village Greens, on Staten Island [Out of Town Builders Falter in City, Sept. 15].

title: Art
description: THE Japanese, wrote Henri Michaux in A Barbarian in Asia, has been modern for 10 centuries. So, correctly or not, it has often seemed to the Western eye. Confronted with certain examples of traditional Japanese art and architecture, in which simplicity of design and delicacy of expression are carried to the most radical and ingenious extremes, we tend inevitably to invoke the concept of the modern. No other period in Western art offers anything like a close parallel to what Michaux, in speaking of Japanese theater, described as the emptiness, which one ends by liking.

title: Penn Central Is Sidetracking Old Reds
description: SOUTH AMBOY  The grinding, rasping and often grudging start of an old red is a familiar sound to thousands of Penn Central commuters, especially those who ride the South Amboy locals.

title: A 2d Battery Case at Belmont
description: A parttime stablehand was seized with a supply of battery devices at Belmont Park yesterday and admitted, according to the police, that he manufactured them and hoped to sell them at the track.

title: Vietcong Official Bars Talks Until Thieu Is Overthrown
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 12 (UPI)A Communist spokesman said today that the Vietcong Would refuse to negotiate on peace enforcement or missing Americans until the South Vietnamese President, Nguyen Van Thieu, was overthrown.

title: Victory After 43 Losses
description: JERSEY. CITY, Oct, 12The longest losing streak in New Jersey came to an end today when Dickinson scored with 27 seconds left to beat Emerson, 127, at Roosevelt Stadium. Dickinson had dropped 43 consecutive games.

title: Leslie Mitchell To Be a Bride
description: Leslie Gray Mitchell, an assistant account executive with Jack Byrne Advertising, Inc., and Thomas Booth Britton, a realestate appraiser with Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., plan to marry next March.

title: Filion Wins 500th As Yonkers Closes
description: YONKERS, Oct. 12Herve Filion, who scored the 5,000th victory of his career aceearlier this week at Yonkers Rway, won his 500th of the year tonight as he steered Susie Flame to a threequarter length decision in the sixth race. Filion's record for most victories in a single season is 605.

title: New Caanan Wins in Last 5 Seconds
description: New Canaan's Kirk Shouvlin tallied on a 4yard rollout with fewer than 5 seconds remaining and the Rams beat Wilton, 2826, yesterday keeping New Canaan atop the Eastern Division of the Fairfield County Conference. New Canaan rallied from deficits of 120 and 206 to take a 212Q lead. Wilton re captured the lead with 3 minutes to go as Mark Reed scored on a 37yard pass from Mike Faught.

title: Pepperdine's Gets Coach
description: MALIBU, Calif. (UPI) Rick Rowland, a former allAmerica swimmer at Oklahoma, will coach Pepperdine's first swimming and water polo teams in the 197576 school year. The 40yearold Rowland has been coaching the University of California at Santa Barbara squads since 1966.

title: Word fractures
description: ACROSS

title: Chart of Man o' War
Bukowiec Spells Kielbasa
description: NEWARKNo matter how you slice it, either in chunk, or as a paperthin cold cut, it is still kielbasa. And no matter how you spell itkielbasa, kielbasas or kielbasythe spicy sausage is still a principal means of income for the Bukowiec Brothers at their Newark and Irvington stores.

title: Landlords Reminded Of City Heat Laws
description: The city's Department of Rent and Housing Maintenance has issued a reminder to residential landlords that as temperatures go down, the heat supply in apartments must go up.

title: News of the Stage
description: Jose Quintero's next Broadway venture will be a new musical called Becaud Tonight, opening early in January under the sponsorship of Neal Du Brock and Paul Repetowski, executive and associate producers of Buffalo's Studio Arena Theater.

title: Chilean Wrongly Expelled And Detained Returns Home
description: Carlos Choy, the 37yearold Chilean who was expelled by his country and then held here, on narcotics charges although it turned out that he was not the person sought, returned to Chile last Thursday, Federal officials reported yesterday.

title: Suffolk College Opens Campus
description: BRENTWOOD The sprawling 185acre farm that nourished the patients and staff of Pilgrim State Hospital for decades began providing educational sustenance to 1,300 Suffolk residents last month when the farm was officially transformed into the western campus of Suffolk Community College.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Can't blame publishers for trying. Every month sees new entrants into the violentaction paperback sweepstakes, hailed as the first of a series. This time we have The D.C. Man and The Smuggler, and more of their adventures are promised.

title: A Parking Dispute Worsens in Queens
description: The increasingly bitter controversy over traffic and parking problems faced by residents living near Queensborough Community College in Bayside moved even farther from settlement last week despite a special study of the situation.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Bilingual Program For Schools Gains
description: TRENTON  Beginning with the 197576 school year, the state's school districts will be required to offer fulltime bilingual programs in any classes where the Englishspeaking ability of at least 20 students is limited.

title: Irwin Upsets Player In MatchPlay Final
description: VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 12For the first time, Gary Player the fivetime defender, has lost a Piccadilly World MatchPlay golf final. He was beaten by Hale Irwin, 3 and 1, in a wildly fluctuating match today in Which the lead changed seven times.

title: Ford Asks Residents of Boston To Reject Violence on Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) President Ford asked the people of Boston today to reject violence of any kind in the current school desegregation conflict.

title: Letters: How Real is Philipsburg Manor?
description: To the Editor: Was Dorothy Evslin, author of StainedGlass Windows and StoneGround Corn in Westchester (Travel Section, Sept. 29) unaware that she was looking at an almost wholly new reconstruction at Philipsburg Manor; when she came unstuck in time, 200 years away? The house, which had acquired two additions built on in later periods, was demolished except for, one original wall in the earliest section. The structure visitors see today was rebuilt around one wall.

title: Music
description: Ives and Schoenberg were born in 1874, and we are hearing a lot of their music just now. As it happens the two together on the same program complement each other neatly. At least that is what the Rutgers University Chamber Ensemblea group of mostly Rutgers musicfaculty members making their first Manhattan appearance yesterday at Carnegie Recital Hallthought, and by and large the result was an effective afternoon of musicmaking.

title: U.S. AID SOUGHT TO HELP DROPOUTS
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 12Westchester County officials are seeking Federal assistance for a program intended to achieve zero dropout rate among high schools in the country.

title: How much for a new heart?
description: Transplants are expensive. A new heart, if all goes well in the operating room, costs about $20,000 but, if there are complication, the price can run to $100,000. This does not include postoperative hospitalization. During one transplant at the Texas Heart Institute, 141 persons, including 21 physicians, were involved over a fiveday period.

title: 21 Dahlia Is First in Man o' War
description: Dahlia flourished munificently in the $119,500 Man o'War Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The Kentuckybred 4yearold filly owned by Nelson Bunker Hunt beat a dozen rivals in the 1mile turf event, under a splendidly judged ride by Ron Turcotte.

title: UPSTATE BACKING SOUGHT BY CLARK
description: Ramsey Clark sampled a crisp fall day and some rural upstate pleasures yesterday in his campaign for the United States Senate.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two Trenton State Prison guards have been suspended without pay following their indictment on charges of beating an inmate with a blackjack and steelreinforced leather gloves. A Mercer County grand jury returned indictments against the two, Lieut. Charles A. Trautman and Walter Wise, in connection with the Sept. 28 beating of Arnold Banks, 42 years old, of Newark.

title: Wendy Troutt, C. S. Rowe 3d Have Nuptials
description: Wendy Lou Troutt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Emerson Troutt of Greenwich, Conn., and Charles Spencer Rowe 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rowe Jr. of Old Greenwich, were married yesterday afternoon at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich by the Rev. Dr. Bradford Hastings and the Rev. Clifford Samuelson.

title: ...While Ford Does What He Can With a Blotter
description: WASHINGTON  In Indiana last week, L. Keith Bulen, the state's flamboyantly successful Republican national committeeman, announced that the was quitting at the end of the year. The reason: his party's morale, he said, was absolutely shot.

title: A Governor Is Defended
description: CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 12 (AP)Attorney General Warren B. Rudman says that Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. did not violate state campaign laws when he accepted contribuitons from people who had lent him money for a previous campaign. He said that it was not unlawful for him to pay off 1972 campaign debts and then receive contributions from the people who had lent the money.

title: Since World War II, Nothing Else Has Worked
description: ROMEA year ago, when Italy's Communist party Secretary Enrico Berlinguer spoke of a historic compromise, the term was widely interpreted as a bid by the party to participate for the first time since 1948 in the running of the government.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may he obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The Beetle's Successor?
description: After more than a decade of guesses, predictions and false starts, Volkswagen is about to introduce a new small car into the American market.

title: You Can't Find What Really Matters in Statistics
description: Today, for one day, I am a writer, and there are so many things I want to say about sports and the athlete in general.

title: Missouri Court Orders License for Dr. Finch
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 12 (UPI)The Kansas City Court of Appeals has turned down all appeals by the state and ordered a medical license issued to Dr. R. Bernard Finch, allowing him to practice medicine in Missouri.

title: TALKS SCHEDULED IN AREA STRIKES
description: Negotiations are scheduled to resume this week in efforts to end parceldelivery and schoolservice strikes that have caused inconveniences and some hardships to residents of the New York metropolitan area.

title: Notre Dame Struggles To Defeat Rice, 10 to 3
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 12 (UPI)Wayne Bullock capped an 80yard scoring drive with a 2yard touchdown plunge with 3:08 to play today to pull heavily favored Notre Dame to a 10.3 victory over Rice.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONGovernor Byrne has suffered more than his share of defeats this year. The biggest one, of course, occurred last July, when the State Senate killed his taxreform program and the income levy that it embraced.

title: 'Artrain' Making 5DayLong Cultural WhistleStops on Eastern Long Island
description: GREENPORTAn Artrain bearing the works of 35 major American artists such as William Merritt. Chase, Childe Hassam, Jackson Pollack and Willem de Kooning is making a whistlestop tour of Eastern Long Island.

title: Javits Is Considering Return Of Rockefeller's Contribution
description: BETHPAGE, Li., Oct. 12Senator Jacob K. Javits told questioners today that he was considering returning a $15,000 campaign contribution from former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, but that the decision would not be made soon.

title: Paramus Shutout Stuns Hackensack
description: Paramus stunned previously undefeated Hackensack, 230, yesterday inHackensack as Ken Maxwell, a speedy halfback, rushed for 100 yards and all three of his team's touchdowns in 12 carries.

title: Miss Brigham Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morison Brigham of Upper St. Regis, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Barker Brigham, to Michael Grant Reardon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Reardon Jr. of Guilderland, N. Y.

title: New Christmas Seals
description: This quartet of the Joys of Christmas brings a feeling of festive gaiety to the 1974 Christmas Seals that will become available shortly in the annual campaign in support of a matter of life and breath by the Lung Associations. They are the work of Mrs. Rubidoux Johnson of Fairfield, Conn.  Rubidoux, as she is known in the art world.

title: Los Angeles Buses Halted Ninth Week As Strike Goes On
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12The Los Angeles transit strike moved into its ninth week this week amid signs of growing impatience and restlessness on the part of the public. However, there were indications the strike could be settled soon.

title: Brooklyn Man Killed in Fight
description: A 30yearold Brooklyn man was fatally stabbed with an eightinch butcher knife during a fight wth another man who was arrested in the Williamsburg section. The victim, Frank Graves, lived in the Sumner Houses Project at 10 Lewis Avenue. Eddie Robinson also 30, of 101 Waverly Avenue, Brooklyn, was charged with homocide.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Professor Eric F. Goldman in his review of F.D.R.'s Last Years by Jim Bishop (Sept. 1) raises the question which has been posed many times, namely: Why should not candidates for the Presidency and incumbentsfor their own good and that of the nationbe required to have health examinations that are independently conducted and candidly reported to them and to the public?

title: Blame It on O'Malley
description: The headline proclaimed California Series! and roars that once welled from Ebbets Field and echoed off the ramparts of Grand Army Plaza begin again as whispers in mute memory. California Series, indeed! By what divine decree does this Pacific wasteland monopolize baseball's climactic moments, which, as everyone knows properly belong in New York. How could anyone write of the tinseled Sunset Strip and Hollywood's plastic fans as Meyer Berger once wrote of Brooklyn fans: From Fulton Ferry to the nether tip of Canarsie, hysteria spread and crackled like wildfire.?

title: hail to the (lowercase) chief
description: Dear Joe: Now that you have won the presidency here in 1976, perhaps we can talk about what you can do to save the country. I have some unvarnished truths to pass on.

title: The ExMichigan Football Player Uses an Ohio State Approach
description: WASHINGTONPresident Ford's economic program, by the admission of his own advisers, would not do very much to improve the stagflation of the American economythe rising prices combined with flat or declining output and an increase in unemployment.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The economic program presented by President Ford last Tuesday had many of the characteristics we have already come to associate with the Ford presidency.

title: Miss Friend Bride of Robert Wise
description: Kathleen London Friend, a social worker on the staff of the psychiatric clinic of Lenox Hill Hospital, was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert George Wise, a partner in the law firm of Rosen, Wise, Felzer & Salomon.

title: W. R. Kehoe, a Medical Student, Marries Suzan von Lengerke
description: Suzan von Lengerke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Justus von Lengerke of Essex Fells and Stag Lake, N. J., and William R. Kehoe, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Kehoe of Davenport, Iowa, were married yesterday afternoon outdoors at the family home at Stag Lake by the Rev. George Watt of the Ridgewood Methodist Church.

title: Levittown Division Holds Off South Side
description: Levittown Division defeated South Side yesterday, 2215, in a game that figured to be just what it was, a knockdown, dragitout fight between two teams expected to contest for the top spot in Nassau Conference VI.

title: Curtain Is Up on the Arts at William Paterson
description: WAYNELearning in the arts is flourishing at William Paterson College under the tutelage of a faculty that includes such visiting theater luminaries as Maureen Stapleton, Alfred Drake and Shepperd Strudwick.

title: Beirut Judge Asks Terms For 7 in U.S. Bomb Case
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 12 (Reuters)  A military judged today sent for military trial and asked penalties from seven years to life imprisonment for seven men accused of having hurled explosives at United States institutions here.

title: Rockaway Protest Blocks Apartments
description: Two hundred residents of a corner of Far Rockaway that nestles along the border between Queens and Nassau County won a victory at City Hall last week by gaining final passage of a zoning change intended to prevent construction of a sixstory apartment house among their singlefamily homes.

title: Aristotle and De Gaulle
description: ATHENSAlthough exile is traditionally a bad counselor and Constantine Caramanlis spent eleven years as an unhappy political migr in France, Greece's once and future strong man regards that period as a useful if terrible phase of his life.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: Black Women Getting Job Help
description: For four years after she got her Master's degree, Barbara Hall taught mathematics in an Atlanta high school. Her base salary was $9,500.

title: PlymouthWhere Legend and. Fact, Image and Reality Have a Way of Plaiting Their Threads
description: THE billboards read: WELCOME TO PLYMOUTHAMERICA'S HOME TOWN. And the painting of the black Pilgrim hat conjures up memories of all those Thanksgiving pageants in school when Priscilla said: Speak for yourself, John.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: TORONTO, Oct. 12After introducing the National Hockey League to the new Washington Capitals last Wednesday, the New York Rangers took a lesson tonight from the Toronto Maple Leafs on how hockey is played by an oldline club. Unable to win here in the last two years, the Rangers found not much had changed as they lost, 73.

title: Finest Play: Dark Call in 5th for Bunt
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12 The finer points of managerial maneuvers were spelled out in greater detail than usual by Alvin Dark today after his Oakland A's had opened the World Series with a 32 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. And what made the recital especially interesting was its revelation of typical, rather than exceptional, thought processes.

title: Ousted St. Peter's Profesor Fights to Retain Post
description: SOUTH ORANGE  St. Peter's College of Jersey City has refused to renew the contract of Dr. Renee Kogel, the head of its History Department, chairman of the New Jersey Committee for the Humanities and an ardent feminist.

title: Home Improvement
description: ASPALT roof shingles are presently being used on more than 80 per cent of the homes in this hemisphere, so chances are that any homeowner in the market for a new roof will wind up ordering one made of asphalt roofing shingles (unless his house has a flat roofshingles are only used on roofs with a slope of at least four inches per horizontal foot).

title: Curbs Fail to Cool Ardor for Exotics
description: Why would anyone spend $8,000 to $30,000 for a car that seats two, carries about as much luggage as a lady's handbag, and, as a major claim to fame, is designed to run two to three times over the nation's 55mileanhour speed limit?

title: Buckeyes' Machine Rolls Up No. 5
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 12 The Machine, otherwise known as Ohio State, ran off another routine victory today, 527, at the expense of Wisconsin.By the final period, the most interesting speculation was whether Archie Griffin would reach 100 yards rushing for his 16th consecutive gamehe didand which book about The Machine had the real story of Ohio State football.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1974

title: LIBRARY OPENED IN CAMPUS FETE
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 11 Sarah Lawrence College completed a $10million development program today, dedicating a library and performing arts center intended to serve as focus of community as well as student life.

title: Alcoholism Rising Among the Aged
description: LAKEWOODJohn Jones had been a model member of the Establishment during his years as a stockbroker in New York. His problem did not start until he was 62 years old and he had retired to live what he thought would be the utopian life of a welltodo senior citizen.

title: Sea Research Cut By High Cost of Oil Needed by Vessels
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., Oct. 12 The vastly increased cost of fuel to run ships has forced the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution here to reduce its offshore research.

title: This One Here Runs Just Fine
description: CRETE, Neb.Frank Tisher, like many Americans, is increasingly concerned over the quality and cost of automobiles today.

title: Gene Richardson Will Be a Bride
description: The engagement of Gene Richardson to John Whittingham Wilmer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilmer of Delray Beach, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Imogen Earp RichRichardson of Lexington Ky., and Henry Ferguson Richardson of Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Engineering Runs In Bergen Family
description: TEANECK  In 1945, Columbia University awarded an engineering degree to 19yearold Gloria Brooks, its first such woman graduate. It could not have known then what it was starting.

title: New Patriots Hit Town
description: With the World Series in California instead of New York this year, the Jets get an early start on their home football season today. By the time they arrived at Shea Stadium last year, they had reached the midpoint of their season, they had only two victories in six games and who cared? This time, they have played just four games, they have one victory in four games and who cares?

title: JESUIT WAS ORDERED TO QUIT AS FORD AIDE
description: BOSTON, Oct. 12 (AP) The Rev. Dr. John J. McLaughlin was ordered by his Jesuit superior to quit his post as a White House aide, an official Jesuit newspaper says.

title: Ellen Myers Wed to David Brown
description: The First Congregational Church of Chappaqua, N. Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Ellen Jo Myers, daughter of Mrs. Otto Jay Myers of Chappaqua and the late Mr. Myers, to David Eugene Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Brown of Stevensville, Mich. The Rev. Vernon Loescher performed the ceremony.

title: Bartenders Being Trained to Provide Counseling as Well as Drinks
description: RACINE, Wis.  LaVerne Kowalski never went to college. But she's got a diploma anyway. And it's a special one at that.

title: Wesley Cullen Is Bride
description: Wesley Graham Cullen, a model with the Zoli Agency here, and Norton Alexander Davidson 3d, an assistant vice president with Blyth Eastman Dillon & Co., Inc., were married yesterday afternoon in the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Arnold C. Miller. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Brendan Rafferty of Greenwich and the late John Wesley Cullen of Haverford, Pa. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Davidson Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: LONDONAccording to an old saying in the moneytrading business here, the first cut is the sweetest cut. Essentially, it means cut your losses early if you find that a currency transaction is not going the way you expected.

title: Van Arsdale to Be Opposed
description: Thomas M. Iandoli, secretary of the New York City Taxi Drivers Union Local 3036, announced yesterday that he would run against Harry Van Arsdale Jr. who is seeking reelection as president of the union. At a news conference in the Biltmore Hotel, Mr. Iandoli charged that Mr. Van Arsdale had been an absentee president and that the 36,000 metbers of the union had suffered economically. Mr. Van Arsdale is also president of the New York City Central Labor Council, treasurer of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and recording secretary of its Local 3 here.

title: Appoggiatura, Tempo Rubato, PortamentoHe Uses 'Em All
description: FRANK SINATRA, as he sang in his prime in the fifties, represented, I think, a summation of all that was best and most original in American popular singing.His singing reflected the ultimate perfection and refinement of that Afrotinged oratorical approach to song, that had been pioneered in premicrophone days by Al Jolson, Sophie Tucker, Fanny Brice, Ruth Etting, Bessie Smith and Ethel Waters.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

SOUTH AFRICA SAID TO EASE ITS RULE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12All options are open for the disputed territory of SouthWest Africa, according to the Foreign Minister of South Africa.

title: JAWORSKI URGES DEPUTY GET POST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12In resigning as the Watergate special prosecutor today, Leon Jaworski recommended as a successor Henry S. Ruth Jr., who had shared the top responsibility in the investigation that helped to topple a President and bring some of the highest officials in Government to trial.

title: A.B.A. Puts on New Look After Shifts in Owners, Players, Coaches and Clubs
description: The American Basketball Association will open its eighth season Friday night with a new look but with its champion, the New York Nets, favored to repeat. The new look includes Moses Malone, of the Utah Stars, who is the youngest player in its history.

title: Doris Zimmermann Wed to Paul Taylor
description: Doris Zimmermann and Paul E. Taylor were married here yesterday afternoon in the. Episcopal Church of the Epiphany by the Rev. Ernest F. Hunt, assisted by the Rev. Henry Lavin.

title: A Farm for Striped Bass
description: SHELTER ISLAND  Two thousand striped bass fingerlings swimming in cages submerged in a quiet lagoon off Smith's Cove here could play a major role in the economic and ecological future of Eastern Long Island.

title: PLEA BARGAINING UPHELD BY COURT
description: The State Court of Appeals last week handed down a decision that reaffirmed its approval of the pleabargaining process while strongly enoouraging that the details of each negotiation appear on the court record.

description: How It Was for Mr. Humphrey

title: Sara W. Burnett Is Bride of John P. Sloan
description: Sara Wall Burnett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Dallam Burnett Jr. of Bronxville, N. Y., was married there last night to John Patrick Sloan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Forbes Sloan, also of Bronxville. The Rev. Christopher L. Webber performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Can Public Television Be Bought?
description: THE wa??g signals for public television were there for some time, but with The Way It Was they no longer could be politely ignored.

title: 500 Protest Nonunion Labor At Jersey Shopping Center
description: About 500 angry trade unionists demonstrated at the construction site of a new shopping and office center in Fairfield, N.J., yesterday to protest what they called the hiring of nonunion labor at the project.

title: Fair Lawn Is Celebrating
description: FAIR LAWNLocal residents will cap their yearlong celebration of the town's 50th anniversary next month by indulging in a giant sixbysixfoot cake that was made solely from ingredients raised on a makeshift farm here.

title: Duck Season Opens On L.I. Next Month
description: ALBANY  For the sixth consecutive year, Long Island waterfowl hunters will have a season separate from those of upstate New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, according to an announcement by the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: If They Could Use All the Money, Fine
description: PARISThe nonCommunist world today is confronted by the greatest and most sudden shift on national wealth that it has ever known as money pours into the coffers of a few select states that happen to be lucky enough to export oil.

title: Ford's Gallup Rating Off 21 Points After Pardon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 President Ford's rating in the Gallup Poll has dropped 21 points since he took office Aug. 9.

title: Soviet Welcomes the Increase in Oil Prices
description: While the leaders of the Western world have been struggling against the impact of the higher cost of oil, the Soviet Union has welcomed the recent price increases by the cartel of producing countries on both economic and political grounds.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: These remarks are taken from a memorandum by Dean Witter, a founder of the investment concern of Dean Witter & Co., Inc., to the company's brokers and management in May, 1932. Mr. Witter died in 1969 at the age of 81.

title: Notes: A Plethora of Purloined Passports
description: AU.S. passport costs $10 if obtained legally, but it has become a redhot item in criminal circles around the world and currently commands a price as high as $2,000. Indeed, underworld demand has become so great that Government officials have issued a warning to travelers to be particularly on guard against loss or theft of their passports.

title: WOMAN'S DEATH LAID TO A RARE DISEASE
description: A fatally stricken 22yearold Bronx mother, who was twice refused admission to Jacobi Hospital one weekend last month, died of massive internal bleeding caused by a very rare disease, the Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Barbara J. Rushmore Is Bride Of Thomas L. Child, a Student
description: The Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church in Plainfield, N. J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Barbara Joy Rushmore to Thomas Lyon Child.

title: Bernards Library Moving
description: BASKING RIDGE  The whole town will have a hand today in moving the Bernards Township Public Library.

title: Canada's BestKnown, And Angriest, Playwright Is Coming to Broadway
description: BACK in 1971, Canada's promising yew theatrical boom was paid a singular compliment. JeanLouis Barrault came to Montreal to direct a French classic, and spent one of his free evenings watching a play by a young Canadian dramatist. Overwhelmed by both the performance and the play, Barrault invited the company to come to Paris under the auspices of the Thatre des Nations, the international theater festival which he then ran. Both the players and the dramatist were delighted, but the Minister of Culture of the Province of Quebec refused to grant funds to support their journey, and the arrangement fell through. It seems that the Minister of Culture felt the play did not offer a sufficiently complimentary picture of life in Quebec, and, in particular, its language was objectionable. The dramatist, a Quebec separatist named Michel Tremblay, had done something quite unprecedented. He had used the actual language of Quebec's working class. Apparently the Minister of Culture wanted to preserve the illusion in Paris that the citizens of Montreal sound exactly like members of the French Academy.

title: New Black Regimes to the North Are Clear Signals
description: JOHANNESBURGA black leader, Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, head of the Zulu homeland Government, told an African audience the other day that everyone knows that things in Southern Africa will never be the same again.

title: Bridgeport Beats Wagner by 3519
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 12 (AP)  Mitch Sanders threw two touchdown passes and Nick Giaquinto threw a third and scored twice on runs to give Bridgeport a 3519 victory over Wagner tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: What happened to the Administration's number one goal of fighting inflation? President Ford's program is a step in the right direction for improving the national balance of payments but offers virtually nothing to reduce our rampant rate of inflation.

title: Pamela Miller Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Pamela Price Miller, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Edwin Haviland Miller of Riverdale, the Bronx, to Paul Marc Ness, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Ness of Rochester, took place at noon yesterday.

title: Western Nations Doing Little to Conserve Energy
description: Secretary of State Kissinger's suggestions that Western nations cut back their oil consumption by 10 to 14 per cent appears to be falling on deaf earseven here at home.

title: Beame Style Making Its Mark
description: Mayor Beame, as he enters the second fiscal cycle of his budgetminded mayoralty, has placed his mark on the administration of the New York City government. A return in some ways to the style of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, the Beame technique of running the vast city government is a mixture of pesky but hardtotrace executive control, of unobtrusive but apparently effective political marnpulation.

title: KISSINGER OBTAINS ACCORD IN ISRAEL ON MIDEAST PLAN
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 13Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he had reached agreement with Israeli leaders on the principles and procedures that might be followed in the next round of ArabIsraeli negotiations toward a Middle East settlement.

title: FREDERICK KOGOS, EXPERT ON YIDDISH
description: Frederick Kogos, author of three books on Yiddish and the editor and publisher of apparel magazines and textbooks, died Friday of a heart attack. He was 67 years old and lived in Great Neck, L. I.

title: DAIRY COOPS KEEP MILK PRICES HIGH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) Big dairy cooperatives are using their bargaining muscle to hold milk prices above Federal minimums by as much as 11 cents per halfgallon.

title: InterestRate Drop Lifts Market Gloom
description: The classic remedy to an ailing marketa drop in interest ratesbegan to take hold dramatically last week and the prospect is for further drops in shortterm rates.

title: The Dance
description: A capacity audience filled the New School's auditorium Saturday night for the opening of the new Choreoconcert series. Four premieres by as many choreographers, followed by a question period, made up the program.

title: Revival of the West
description: The critical dilemmas confronting the United States, the other industrial nations and the world as a whole the last quarter of the twentieth century center on problems that are essentially economicenergy, money, food, population, resources, trade and slumpflation.

title: Woman Recalls 25 Years Aiding Retarded
description: Ann Greenberg, a small, middleaged woman, beamed yesterday as she walked slowly around the second floor of the New York Hilton Hotel, where the New York State Association for the Mentally Retarded was winding up its 25th anniversary convention.

title: Sports News. Briefs
description: A remarkable performance yesterday by Tony Alguero of Cardinal Hayes and a remarkable comeback by Holy Cross Saturday night highlighted Catholic Schools Football League play over the weekend. Alguero accounted for all his team's points in a 327 rout of Stepinac in White Plains, He ran for five touchdowns, a conversion and had 202 yards in 22 carries.

title: Swiss to Vote on Bid To Reduce Numbers Of Foreign Workers
description: GENEVA, Oct. 13The Swiss Cabinet has taken the unusual step of appealing to the nation to vote down a proposal that would cripple its farms, factories and service industries by expelling some 350,000 foreign workers.

title: Borg Falls To Nastase In Five Sets
description: MADRID, Oct. 13 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania won the men's singles title in the Melia International open tennis tournament today with a grueling fiveset victory over Bjorn Borg of Sweden.

title: Leeds Victor in Tennis
description: Cary Leeds of Collegiate School won the singles title in the Eastern tennis championships for private schools by defeating James McNamara, Fordham Prep, 61, 62, at the Queens campus of St. John's University yesterday.

title: Lebanese Tell of Shelling
description: SAIDA, Lebanon, Oct. 13 (AP)  Israelis shelled five border locations along Lebanon's southern border today, destroying several houses and farms, but causing no causualties, residents there said.

title: Hunter's Refusal of Settlement Payment by Finley Disclosed
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13The Jim (Catfish) Hunter contract dispute with Charles O. Finley seemed to become more complicated today.

title: KILLING OF CALVES IS AGAIN POSTPONED
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 13  A plan by cattlemen and dairymen to slaughter 3,000 calves in protest against rising feed grain prices and depressed beef and dairy prices has been put off again.

description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Protestants Kill 4 in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 13 (AP)The battered body of a young man was found outside this city today. His was the fourth Roman Catholic death in 72 hous, the police said. The Protestant Ulster Freedom Fighters claimed responsibility for all four murders.

title: Bridge Some LeadDirecting Doubles ?? Often Prove Misdirecting
description: It is not at all surprising that the leaddirecting double generates a great deal of confusion Since the two main types have diametrically opposite meanings. Against a highlevel suit contract, the doubler asks for an unusual lead but against three notrump he asks for an obvious lead. The obvious lead is construed to mean the leader's bid suit, failing which the doubler's suit, and failing which dummy's first suit.

title: COAST PHILHARMONIC ENDS ITS SERIES HERE
description: Zubin Mehta and the Los Angeles Philharmonic ended a sixweek tour Saturday night in Carnegie Hall with the third of three concerts meant to mark the beginning of an annual New York series.

title: A Year After Uprising, Uneasy Thais Take First Steps Toward Democracy
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 13 One year ago, thousands of students and ordinary people milled in the charred streets of Bangkok, astonished and jubilant. With critical backstage help from their King, they had just forced the military regime of Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn from power.

title: Events Today
description: HOSANNA, a play by Michel Tremblay; directed by William Glassco; at the Bijou, West 45th Street, 7.

title: 5,881 UNIT PROJECT IS DEDICATED HERE
HAROLD ABRAMSON, PEDIATRICIAN, DEAD
description: Dr. Harold Abramson, a pediatrician here for 47 years, died yesterday at his home, 1230 Park Avenue. He was 75 years old.
