description: There is no dream that cannot be defeated by inflation and bureaucracy. But nothing is more vulnerable to rising costs and red tape than the dream of a better place to live.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Faced with the heaviest accumulation of unresolved cases in Supreme Court history, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger called on Congress and the legal profession today to find some way to keep the Court's continually expanding workload under control.

title: PRESEASON BASKETBALL
description: Indians (ABA) 110; New York (ABA) 105.

title: BrilliantB un u el Film Closes 12th Festival:The Cast
description: After 17 days of good, bad, and mostly indifferent films, the 12th annual New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center closed triumphantly last night with the American premiere of Luis Buuel's brilliant, anarchic new comedy, "Le Fantme de la Libert" (The Specter of Freedom"), which will begin its commercial run at the Paris Theater here on Oct. 27.The premiere of "Fantme" came the day after the festival's homage to Mr. Buuel in the form of the retrospective showing of four of his earlier works, "L'Age D'Or" (1930), made in collaboration with Salvador Dali, "The Exterminating Angel" (1962), "The Milky Way" (1969) and "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" (1972). This had the effect of italicizing what we have all been saying for years: the Buuel talent has continued to grow and refine itself at that period in a film maker's life when he is ordinarily expected to taper off, if not retire to campus or swimming pool.Mr. Buuel must be awfully tired of people going on and on about his age. (He'll be 75 nex February.) Yet the subject is pertinent when so few film makers have endured long enough to give us the benefit of the wit and wisdom that come only from living through decades of changing fashions. Writers, painters, musicians and composers survive into creative old age. Film makers have a way of wearing out too soon, like American automobiles. Not Luis Buuel.In "Le Fantme de la Libert" Mr. Buuel and Jean-Claude Carrire, who has collaborated with the director on all of his feature films since "Diary of a Chambermaid" (1964), contemplate man's survival in spite of his idiocies. I'm not at all sure the film has as much to do with specific ideas about freedom as the title would imply. Rather, I suspect, the concept of freedom as touched upon in the film is just another in the system of reversalsone of dozens of dumbfounding paradoxes  that so fascinate and amuse this most free yet most disciplined of film makers."Le Fantme de le Libert" is not for people who see movies as butterflies, trophies to be netted, pinned down, then pulled apart with tweezers. The movie can't be pinned down. There's no single correct way to read it, which is not a rationale for its ambiguities, but a rigorous instruction to those who would enjoy all that is most marvelous and poetic in surrealism at its best.The film opens in Toledo in 1808 as Napoleon's soldiers attempt to liberate Spain and summarily shoot all citizens who refuse to be liberated. "Down with liberty!" is the heroic cry of one of the victims standing before a Goya-like firing squad.Thereupon the camera follows a French officer who, being slightly drunk on communion wine and stuffed with communion wafers, becomes enchanted by the beauty of the statue of a knight's wife on a sepulcher in the cathedral they're then violating. As the officer bends to kiss the statue, the stone hand of the knight's figure gives the officer a terrific swat, so enraging the officer he vows to take his pleasure with the dead lady, whose coffin, they find, is filled with paraphernalia."Paraphernalia?" asks a woman sitting in a park in modern-day Paris. "What is par-a-pher-na-lia?" The woman, a nanny, has been reading aloud to a friend the story we've been watching, at which point "Le Fantme" moves into another story, that of the nanny, her small charge, a little girl who is given what seem to be obscene postcards by a strange man, and the girl's parents, who are so outraged by the postcards (pictures of Ntre Dame, Sacr Coeur and the like) that they sack the nanny on the spot."Le Fantme de la Libert" is dozens of stories that lead from one to another with a dreamlike logic, and a dream-like way of never quite arriving at a neatly satisfactory conclusion. Among the characters who turn up are a courteous sniper, who shoots a couple of dozen people from the top of Montparnasse sky-scraper at the edge of Paris and becomes a celebrity; a group of poker-playing monks, a little girl who vanishes from school but is able to accompany her parents to the police station where she gives her own vital statistics, even though no one acknowledges her presence.More than any other Bunel film "Le Fantme" recalls "L'Age D'Or" with its riddles, jokes, outrageous associations, contradictions and dim view of reason's power. "Le Fantme" is no less dense with symbols (for those who care about such things), but the style is more precise, less heavy, much funnier, no less mysterious, yet so economical that when he ridicules the arbitrariness of a social convention, like table manners, he manages also to make a few pithy observations on ecology.The physical production is stunning to look at. The cast is large, first-rate, but the presence that dazzles us is that of the Old Master, just off screen, mercilessly testing our senses of sanity and humor.

title: Hazel Weisburst Bride of Importer
description: Hazel Weisburst, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Forrest T. Weisburst of East Rockaway, L.I., was married here yesterday at the Park Lane Hotel to Arnold L. Manheimer, son of Mrs. Bernice Schwartz of Princeton, N.J., and the late Edwin Manheimer. Rabbi Morris Goldberg performed the ceremony.

title: MRS. ALFRED M'CORMACK
description: Winifred Smith McCormack, widow of Alfred McCormack, New York corporation lawyer and director of intelligence of the Military Intelligence Service in World War II, died Wednesday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Tapes and Impeachment in Penn State's Watergate
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Oct. 13The pesident was accused of misconduct in offce, he refused to honor a subpoena for secret tape recordings, aticles of impech ment were drawn, and major resignations followed.

title: Blacks Rally at Boston Common; Protest Effort to Halt Busing
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13  About 700 blacks marched two miles through the streets of Boston to the Common today in the first black demonstration since the current turmoil over school integration began a month ago.

title: 2 Young Argentines Shot
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 13 (UPI)The bodies of two young men, blindfolded and shot repeatedly a close range in gangland style, were found this morning in a residential area in the center of Buenos Aires. Tht polict said the murder method indicated that the men were victims of the political violence that has taken at least 154 lives this year.

title: 15 INJURED IN BLAST AT TOKYO COMPANY
description: TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 14 This city was rocked with its second large bombing in two months today with an explosion on the third floor of the Mitsui Trading Company's head office. Reports said that 15 persons had been injured.

title: CRESCENS HUBBARD
description: Crescens Hubbard, a White Plains lawyer for 70 years, who specialized in estate work, died Saturday in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 97 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Ruptured Water Main in Flushing Floods 5 Blocks of Residential Area
description: A 20inch water main ruptured early yesterday morning in Flushing, Queens, flooding a fivesquareblock residential area and causing heavy damage to basements of several hundred onefamily homes.

title: Subcontinent Telephone Link
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 13 (AP)India and Pakistan have agreed to resume telephone and telegraph communications starting Tuesday, an official announcement sai dtoday. The facilities were suspended at the time of the 1973 IndianPakistani war over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.

title: Hearingson the Elderly. Will Begin Tomorrow
description: The first of five public hearings on problems of the city's elderly will begin tomorrow at 10:30 A.M. in the amphitheater of the New Technology Building of the New York City Community College, 186 Jay Street, Brooklyn.

title: SHOP TALK
description: There's an elegant new shop at 41 East 78th Street. It's called Delle Celle and the owners, Tony Leiva and Ed Borella, have designed such items as classic silk blouses with Lalique crystal buttons ($125 to $145).

title: MARGETSON WORKS PLAYED AT CONCERT
description: Edward H. Margetson, a West Indian composer who died here din 1962 at the age of 70, was honored yesterday afternoon by the performance of several of his works in Alice Tully Hall. The program was presented by the Triad Chorale, directed by Noel Da Costa, assisted by the Schubert Music Society, which Mr. Margetson founded in 1927.

title: Larchmont Sail Goes To Hanson
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 13George W. Hanson of the Horse Shoe Harbor Yacht Club of Larchmont won the HerreshoffClass S national championship on Long Island Sound off Larchmont Y.C. today by placing second and first in the final two races of the fourrace regatta.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1974
description: Secretary of State Kissinger, on leaving Tel Aviv for a flight to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, said he had reached agreement with Israeli leaders on principles and procedures that might be followed in the next round of ArabIsraeli talks toward a Middle East peace agreement. Mr. Kissinger went to Saudi Arabia for talks with King Faisal before returning to Egypt to meet President Sadat again. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: SENATOR CANNON SAYS ROCKEFELLER MAY BE RUED
description: Senator Howard W. Cannon, chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, said yesterday that in all probability he would recall Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller to testify before his committtee.

title: ELECTION DISPUTE ANGERS THE SHAH
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 13Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi has interjected himself into the case of a disputed election result that has brought a touch of scandal to the normal torpor of political life in Iran.

title: Sinatra at the Garden Is Superb TV as Well
description: Frank Sinatra's hourlong live telecast last night from Madison Square Garden turned out to be quite show, both for television watchers and for those actually at the Garden. It was certainly a high point in Mr. Sinatra's career, and it came, of all eves, on the eve of Columbus Day.

title: HOSPITAL FORGERY ALLEGED AT TRIAL
description: MIAMI, Oct. 13The prosecution has presented most of its witnesses in its case against Sanford K. Bronstein, former president of the federally financed and now bankrupt Cedars of Lebanon Hospital.

title: 2 More Give Up in Alabama Shootout
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 13The Montgomery police said today that two more men involved in a threehour shootout with the police yesterday had surrendered.

title: Stock Markets Open
description: Major stock exchanges will be open today, Columbus Day, btu banks in New York State and several commodities markets will be closed. The commoditis exchanges that are closing for the day are: The New York Cocoa Exchange; The New York Commodity Exchange and the New York Coffe and Sugar Exchang as well as New York foreign markets. In Canada, securities and commodities markets, banks and most businesses will be closed as the nation's Thanksgiving Day is celebrated.

title: THOMAS H. PHELAN
description: Thomas H. Phelan, who retired last year as director of technical facilities and maintenance for the National Broadcasting Company, died yesterday in Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune, N.J. He was 66 years old and had moved) recently from Maywood to Lakehurst, N.J.

title: 10 Years Later, Khrushchev Is Still Debated
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 13  Ten years ago today, Nikita S. Khrushchev ruled over the Soviet Union with an outward show of confidence and power. Within 24 hours, he was deposed by a meeting of his own Communist party subordinates and isolated in official oblivion.

title: Ford to Speak in Indiana
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 13 (AP) President Ford will speak at a Republican fundraising dinner here on Wednesday, state GOP officials said. The dinner is $100 a plate, but tickets to a cocktail hour and reception, which includes the dinner, are selling for $500. Officials said they hope to gross between $400,000 and $500,000.

title: Advertising: Choice for Amtrak
description: The threeyear contract between Ted Bates & Co., and Amtrak, the Governmentfinanced operator of most of the nation's passenger railroads, has ended and, as required by law, the railroaders have opened up for bidding from other agencies.

title: CAREY IS CAUTIOUS ABOUT ROCKEFELLER
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey said yesterday that he might not vote in Congress to confirm Nelson A. Rockefeller as Vice President if the former Governor did not provide a detailed account of his gifts of some $2million to aides and public officials.

title: Ives Symphony No. 4 Is Eloquent End to Philharmonic Festival
description: It was billed as a MiniFestival Around Ives, but there was nothing mini about the ending at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday night. With Pierre Boulez and David Gilbert conducting simultaneously, the New York Philharmonic gave an eloquent performance of Ives's monumentally complex and cacophonous Symphony No. 4, and the predominantly young audience that filled the house remained in place for several minutes to applaud the musicians.

title: Bruins Tie Leafs on Late Goal
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)Ken Hodge's goa with less than nine minutes remaining tonight enabled the Boston Bruins to tie the Toronto Maple Leafs, 22, in the Bruins' National Hockey League home opener.

title: 5,881 UNIT PROJECT IS DEDCATED HERE
description: Starrett City, the largest housing development to be built in New York since CoOp City, was officially dedicated yesterday in Brooklyn, even though its first families will not move into their apartments until next month.

title: CHANGES SOUGHT IN LIQUOR FEES
description: Controller Arthur Levitt has urged the State Liquor Authority to seek changes in its 40yearold fee structure for retail and wholesale liquor licenses and permits and argued that its commissioners bed paid $150 a day rather than $32,250 a year.

title: Leafs Rout Rangers, 73
description: TORONTO, Oct. 12After Introducing the National Hockey League to the new Washington Capitals last Wednesday, the New York Rangers took a lesson tonight from the Toronto Maple Leafs on how hockey is played by an oldline club. Unable to win here in the last two years, the Rangers found not much had changed as they lost, 73.

title: The Rockefeller Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13It begins to seem easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter into the VicePresidency of the United States by way of the 25th Amendment. Neison A. Rockefeller's wealth, which used to look tike a political asset, now looks more and more like a liability.

title: D.W. Shetler Weds
description: Suzanne Elaine Parillo, daughter of Emilia Parillo of Glen Ridge, N.J., and Christopher D. Parillo of Brookside, N.J., was married yesterday evening to D. Wayne Shetler of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Willis Shetler of Johnstown, Pa.

title: Goldin Asks Mayor to End OTB Tax to Cut City Loss
description: Asserting that the city had lost more than $1.5million in anticipated revenue in the three months since a 5 per cent surtax was imposed on off track betting, Controller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday called again on Mayor Beame to seek repeal of the tax.

title: Panel Says Ecumenical Drive Has Lost Joy and Excitement
description: A panel of church leaders agreed yesterday that the ecumenical movement, or the search for Christian unity, had lost the excitement and the joy of its early days and was in dire need of more vision and less legalism.

title: Home Furnishings: Producers Get Set For Bicentennial
description: It's called bicentennialitis and, for good or for bad, it's galloping through home furhishings collections with the speed of Paul Revere.

title: Three Protests in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 13 (AP)Three protest groups held rallies in the Saigon area today, demanding an end of political corruption, the freeing of political prisoners, and a better standard of living, The rallies were organized by a Roman Catholic movement, a militant buddhist group and the recently formed Front Against Hunger.

title: PRINCETON HAS PLAN FOR A FUSION DEVICE
description: Princeton University announced yesterday the completion of preliminary plans for what would be the largest fusion device of its kind in the world. Its estimated cost would be $215million.

title: ISRAELIS HOPEFUL ON PEACE TALKS
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 13After nearly six hours of closeddoor talks with Secretary of State Kissinger, senior Israeli officials said today that they thought there was a good chance that a new round of negotiations between Israel and Egypt would get under way after the Arab summit conference later this month.

title: Byrne's Advisers Credited With Ambitious Programs
description: TRENTONGovernor Byrne's chief advisers are credited here with considerable skill at devising ambitious programs, although after almost nine months in office, they have not been able to get major programs through the State Legislature.

title: Faisal Assures Kissinger Of Aid to Cut Oil Prices
description: CAIRO, Oct. 13.King Faisal of Saudi Arabia assured Secretary of State Kissinger today that his country would use its influence to try to bring down the world price of oil. He authorized Mr. Kissinger to state that he would take constructive steps in that direction.

title: Dodgers Beat A's, 32, Tying Series At a Game Each
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13Don Sutton, who hasn't lost a game in two months, outpitched Vida Blue today and evened the first allCalifornia World Series as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Oakland A's, 32.

title: InflationConscious Australians Attack $850,000 Art Purchase
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 13 A flurry of criticism has been aroused here by the Government's purchase of a painting by an American abstract expressionist artist for $850,000 at a time of severe inflation and other economic ills.

title: FOOD STAMP FUND FREED BY JUDGE
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 13  A Federal district judge has ordered the Department of Agriculture to spend nearly $280million of 1973 funds on the food stamp program instead of returning the money to the United States Treasury.

title: Horse Owner Tries to Nullify Hialeah Deal
description: MIAMI, Oct. 13John Bigman, a Miami horse owner, said today he was attempting to form a group to raise $7million to lease the Hialeah Park race course and nullify the pending sale of the track's dates to Gulfstream,

title: Pickoff Play: Master Gives Pupil Lesson
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13The largest Michigan State alumni reunion ever held on the field during a World Series game acted out a ninthinning pickoff play that dominated postgame conversation today.

title: Faisal Pledge on Oil
description: King Faisal of Saudi Arabia assured Secretary of State Kissinger yesterday that his country would use its influence to try to lower world prices of oil. Details, Page 12.

title: KISSINGER OBTAINS ACCORD IN ISRAEL ON MIDEAST PLAN
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 13Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he had reached agreement with Israeli leaders on the principles and procedures that might be followed in the next round of ArabIsraeli negotiations toward a Middle East settlement.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beame was honored at a testimonial dinner at the Americana Hotel by the City of Hope as its man of the year. The award cited the Mayor's concern for the sick, the poor and the disadvantaged. The dinner was sponsored by the 93 auxiliaries of the City of Hope, located near Los Angeles and devoted to various phases of medical research. Milton Berle, the entertainer, was master of ceremonies. The dinner chairman, John Kluge, said the event recognizes the spirit of idealism and human compassion that characterizes the Mayor.

title: For the Elderly Nowadays A Lamb Shank Is a Treat
description: It was 10:30 A.M. and the pedestrian traffic outside the storefront office of the Mayor's Bronx Office for the Aging was a little like a plainclothes pageant, a rich mixture of persons of visibly African, European and Asian descent.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Tallahto, Favorite, Santa Anita Victor
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Oct. 13 (UPI)Laffit Pincay guided Tallahto to the front and maintained her lead to beat High Protein by a length in the $54,800 Carleton F. Burke Handicap at Santa Anita racetrack today.

title: President Spends Day Just Relaxing at Home
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)  President Ford spent today like millions of other Americans  sleeping late, reading newspapers and watching football on television.

title: Money in Politics
description: After nearly threequarters of a century, a dream of President Theodore Roosevelt will become a reality when his successor signsas he is expected to do in the next few daysthe most sweeping reform of campaign financing in the country's history. The bill, which has had an agonizing legislative history, would pay for Presidential elections with public money, drastically limit contributions to Congressional candidates and go far erase the taint of money from the national political process.

title: Dave Anderson
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13In the empty stillness of the dugout, Walter Alston slid a cigarette out of a pack of Tarreytons and flicked the flame from a blue lighter. Even the lighter was the shade of Dodger blue, matching his cap, his stockings and the lettering on his uniform. It also was only a shade darker than his clear blue eyes which seem to stare out of his tanned 62yearold face. He is completing his 21st consecutive year as the manager of the Dodgers, and only Connie Mack, austere in a high stiff white collar, and John McGraw, arrogant and combative, ever managed the same majorleague team for a longer span of time. Mack guided the Philadelphia A's for 50 years, McGraw bossed the New York Giants for 31 years. But now the A's are in Oakland, the Giants are in San Francisco and Alston, hired when the Dodgers were in Brooklyn, is here in Los Angeles where the Dodgers evened the World Series today with a 32 victory on Joe Ferguson's tworun homer.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: TV: The Daughter of the Regiment
description: One way to make opera successful on television is to grab the services of a superstar. That is precisely what the Public Broadcasting Service does tonight at 8 with a production of Donizetti's The Daughter of the Regiment. The quite solid cast is headed by the quite extraordinary Beverly Sills, whose zest and vivacity prove infectious with the other performers and the entire audience.

title: JAWORSKI'S AIDES PUSH TRIAL PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 Leon Jaworaki's a resignation as special prosecutor later this month should have no effect on the Watergate coverup trial, officials in Mr. Jaworski's office said today.

title: 'A Woman Under Influence' Stars Gena Rowlands as Frenetic Wife:The Cast
description: When a husband and wife need to keep saying how much they love each other, something's apt to be awfully wrong. That nervous repetition is one of the danger signals in John Cassavetes's "A Woman Under the Influence," and it contains all the warning urgency of a siren. The movie played on Saturday at the New York Film Festival.Throughout, the film dwells on the abrasions of daily living, centered in the domestic world where each individual grinds on the other's nerves. Gena Rowlands plays a woman adrift. Her manic, likable, hard-hat husband (Peter Falk) quite hysterically keeps assuring her that everything's fine. Meanwhile, she looks to him for her identity, asking him to tell her "what" to be, insisting that she'll "be anything" he wants. Later, he punctuates a horrendous uproar by shouting "Just be yourself!" But she hardly has a selfbeyond the bundle of symptoms that make up her hectic public persona.Miss Rowlands unleashes an extraordinary characterization of a harried, anxious creature, who's convinced that she "makes a jerk of" herself every day. (The actresses' style of performing sometimes shows a kinship with that of the early Kim Stanley or the recent Joanne Woodward, but the notes of desperation are emphatically her own.) Despair lurks behind her smilewhich often collapses suddenlyas she jabbers, hums or retreats to a little-girl manner. Pantomime is one of her defenses. She mugs with exasperation, working her jaw and rolling her eyes when she's annoyed or throwing indignant punches into the air. When frenzy gives way to apology, her mouth tightens with resentment, which then yields to a miserable leer. With her three small children, she's wildly demonstrativeshe seems to be pleading for their affection; trying to be a fellow-child who plays their games.A troubled person, yes, and certainly an insecure one. But she doesn't seem sick or crazed enough to justify the crack-up that's awaiting her, nor to spend six months in a sanitarium. And that's the hitch in the movie: you can't really tell how the director regards this character. Mr. Cassavetes is unquestionably sympathetic to the rootless state of the middle-American housewife. (Moreover, the hospitalization is meant to seem like a betrayal by the husband.)Butperhaps unintentionallyhe has made the man appear much crazier than his wife; are we supposed to assume that his frantic nature has driven her over the edge? Or are we meant to see madness as contagious? Ultimately, the essential problems of this woman remain unclear: we're shown her behavior, but not what inspired it.The movie is also a study in embarrassmentsince that's the dominant emotion shared by everyone who encounters this head-long person. There's also a conscientious effort to show a continuing relationship, but the picture doesn't touch a common nerve in the way that Ingmar Bergman's "Scenes From a Marriage" doesbecause a number of moments that could be moving or touching are made to be farcical.Peter Falk gives a rousing performance as the man who lives at a perpetual bursting point, and the children are very well directed. But the movie didn't need to be 2 hours and 35 minutes long: there's too much small talk, which doesn't really reveal character. Still, the most frightening scenes are extremely compelling, and this is a thoughtful film that does prompt serious discussion.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FINDERS KEEPERS Today is Columbus Day in honor of the man who, it is said, found the New World, although others say the Vikings found it first. Together with the debate over who really found what and when, there has been a parallel discussion over who Columbus really was. He was Italian, most people believe, although other nationalities have registered claims to him and his crewmen. At any rate the whole subject is a fit one for New York where everyone from everywhere lives, so let us say he belongs to all of celebrate.

title: Truth as a TwoWay Street...
description: Much of the public discussion during the Watergate period (or, perhaps should say, the earlier phase of the Watergate period) seemed to reflect in assumption by most Americans that the telling of a deliberate falsehood by a Government official would not be crime unless the lie had been told under oath, or it were part of a coverup of another crime. In short, the telling of a deliberate lie in a press release or a news conference, while reprehensible, would not be actionable.

title: About New York
description: An elderly Dutch woman, who lives alone on East 78th Street, came home one day last week, picked up the keys from the mailbox where the maid had left them, and opened the downstairs door. Then she went upstairs, and opened the door to her apartment. When she got inside, she saw a young: man. He was tall and thin, and he Was standing very quietly.

title: WOLFGANG STECHOW, AN ART HISTORIAN, 78
description: Dr. Wolfgang Stechow, professor of art history at Oberlin College from 1940 to 1963, died Saturday in Princeton, N.J. He was 78 years old and his home was in Oberlin, Ohio.

title: Miss Signoret Excels in 'Widow Couderc':The Cast
description: Since Simone Signoret appears in all too few movies these days, it's so good to see her on the screen that one tends to be almost undemanding of the picturewhich, in this case, is a modest film of high quality that never quite gets off the ground, despite its many fine details and a beautiful evocation of the French countryside.In Pierre Granier-Deferre's "The Widow Couderc," which opened yesterday at the Playboy Theater, Miss Signoret is a widowed farm woman who shelters a murderer on the lam (Alain Delon). With deft, swift movements, she conveys the authority of a person who has wrenched a living out of the land. Cutting hay, digging or hoeing, washing laundry in a stream, slicing meat, she makes us momentarily forget all the worldly or urban roles that she has played so superblyhere, she's the total peasant.Hard work and hard times have armored the widow against almost any form of indulgence. Hence Miss Signoret is also very touching as a stern, aging woman who falls reluctantly in love with a footloose young man. As in some of her other movies, there's the hopeful half-smile that appears when she likes someone, or the wistful appreciation that she reveals after making love.The man also sleeps with a mindless adolescent (Ottavia Piccolovery good.) Then the widow's in-laws, who hate her, identify him to the police. The movie was adapted from a novel by Georges Simenon; the director is respectful of its characters, and their situation might even have the stuff of tragedy. However, Mr. Delon's role and his performance are too thin and elusiveso we can't care greatly when his life's in jeopardy.The actor just doesn't use the vitality that he has brought to some of his earlier parts; instead, he's almost phlegmatic, andnot for the first timehe seems to be thinking of James Dean. (A nice thought, admittedly, but one that's hardly rooted in the French working class.) Since Miss Signoret has all the strength to move us, it's worth wishing that the director had made her opposite number more substantial.

After the torpedo was reported by the fishing vessel, a Coast Guard rescue boat evacuated the three crew members while the naval ordnance men were flown to the boat by helicopter.

I., youth, who was shot in the face last Tuesday when a shotgun accidentally discharged, died last night in Good Samaritan Hospital here, the Suffolk County police reported. The youth, identified by the police as Steven D'Amico of 40 Mohawk Drive, was shot in the face with birdshot when a 12gauge shotgun that a youth was showing him at his home accidentally discharged. The police said the youth, Dennis Traina, 19, was arrested on a charge of seconddegree assault.

The 30minute plan obviously; failed, so yesterday they abandoned it and tried something different: they played zero minutes of football. Next Sunday maybe they won't even bother showing up.

title: Mets Finally Get Torre in Trade for Sadecki and Minor Leaguer
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13The New York Mets acquired Joe Torre from the St. Louis Cardinals today for Ray Sadecki and Tommy Moore in the first of the many trades that are expected to revamp majorleague baseball rosters this winter.

title: EAGLETON ASKS HALT IN WORK ON NAVY JET
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) Senator, Thomas F. Eagleton said today that a secret flyoff had shown the Navy's new fighter plane, the F14, to be less than half as effective as the Air Force's version, the F15.

title: Clark Voices Doubt on Rockefeller Confirmation
description: Ramsey Clark, the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate, said yesterday he seriously doubted whether former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller should be confirmed as Vice President.

title: Exit Mr. Jaworski
description: After nearly a year of exemplary performance as Special Watergate Prosecutor, Leon Jaworski is leaving office under conditions that border on desertion of duty. Too many strands of the legal tangle left by the Nixon Presidency remain unraveled to justify Mr. Jaworski's assertion that his task is largely finished now that the jury in the Watergate coverup trial has been chosen and sequestered. Indeed, some of the statements made by the Special Prosecutor in his letter of resignation will contribute to making Watergate's final unraveling difficult, if not impossible.

title: Soviet Returns to Newsmen Protest on Police Violence
description: MOSCOW Oct 13 (AP)Soviet authorities have returned without comment a, letter from a group of Western correspondents protesting mistreatment while covering an unofficial art exhibition on the outskirts of Moscow four weeks ago.

title: Super Sunday Cheers Philadelphians
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 Today, for the second time in three weeks, thousands of people jammed into the center of this old city to celebrate  well, to celebrate whatever struck their fancy.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: ENGELHARD RAISES IRIDIUM PRICES $100
description: The Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation said yesterday that it was increasing its worldwide iridium prices to a range between $500 and $510 a troy ounce. The former price was $400 to $410 an ounce.

title: You Can Beat Dead Horse, If It's a Federal Court Case
description: What official body do you appeal to if you want to be declared King of the World?

title: D. A. LOWRIE, LEADER IN WAR RELIEF WORK
description: Dr. Donald A. Lowrie, a leader in war prisoners' aid and relief work in both World Wars, died Saturday in the Meadow Lakes Extended Care Facility, Hightstown, N. J. He was 85 years old.

title: PALESTINIANS WIN RIGHT TO APPEAR IN U.N. ASSEMBLY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14The United Nations General Assembly overwhelmingly endorsed today an Arabled move to give a voice in its meetings to the Palestine Liberation Organization, the main coordinating organization of guerrilla groups.

title: Events Today
FOOD TALK
description: James Farrell is not one to let a business opportunity slip by. There he was, operating a liquor store in the Grand Central area and listening to some of his customers complain that if they wanted quality pots or pans, knives or other cooking aids it would involve a trip downtown or uptown.

title: Library, Due to Cut 3 Branches Plans to Build at Least 5 Others
description: The New York Public Library, which plans to close three large neighborhood branches on Nov. 18 because of a shortage of payroll funds, is currently planning construction of at least five new branches.

title: 2,000 Sign Up for Apprentice Jobs
description: Two thousand young men and women, many redeyed from lack of sleep and chilled from street dampness, registered yesterday for 500 potential jobs as electrician apprentices with Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York City Controller Harrison J. Goldin warned that unless the city changed its borrowing practices and cut back on borrowing in general, real estate taxes could rise by 45 per cent over the next six years.

title: E.P.A. Is Curbing Sewer Main Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The Federal Government is tightening up on its billiondollar program of grants to localities for sewer mains because of findings that the projects are encouraging unsound community growth.

title: BRITISH GET PLEA TO UNITE IN CRISIS
description: LONDON, Oct. 14With his arrow election victory behind him, Prime Minister Harold Wilson turned today to the task of finding broad support for his Government's efforts to deal with the nation's economic crisis.

title: Stocks Rise Sharply For 4th Day in Row
description: The stock market, buoyed by investors' hopes for lower interest rates and oil prices, made its fourth consecutive sharp advance yesterday in continued heavy trading.

title: MEXICO TYING OIL TO NATIONALISM
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14Mexico's President, Luis Echeverria Alvarez, has affirmed that Mexico's oil reserves, which are proving larger than previously estimated, will be exploited in a profoundly nationalist and antiimperialist manner.

title: Ronan Is Afraid Congress May Stall on Transit Aid
description: Dr. William J. Roman warned yesterday that it's going to be hard to energize Congress at its lameduck session to act in time on a masstransit aid bill to keep New York's transit fare from rising sharply.Dr. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, also said that the longstalled plan to build a passenger rail spur to Kennedy International Airport faced a delay of at least another year.He spoke at a news conference at the 93d annual convention of the American Transit Association, an organization representing the transit industry, and transitoperating officials.His sobering comments came in, the midst of optimistic talk by various speakers that mass transit was on the threshold of a new era of vast Federal aidnot just for construction and equipment but for operating subsidies.Fare Increase Predicted

title: Most Markets Open
description: Major stock exchanges were open yesterday, Columbus Day, but banks in New York State and several commodities markets were closed. The commodities exchanges that closed for the day were the New York Cocoa Exchange; the New York Commodity Exchange and the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange as well as New York foreignexchange markets. In Canada, securities and commodities markets, banks and most businesses were closed as the nation's Thanksgiving Day was celebrated.

title: U.S. DOCTOR CHARGES HONDURAS HOARDING
description: An American physician has charged that Honduran officials ara hoarding floodrelief supplies for themselves.

title: Javits Will Retain $15,000 Received From Rockefeller
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits, the Republican incumbent who is running for reelection, yesterday rejected demands by his Democratic opponent, former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, that Mr. Javits return $15,000 in campaign contributions from Mr. Rockefeller.

title: Americans in Minisub Rescued in North Sea
description: DUNDEE, Scotland, Oct. 14 (AP)  Divers rescued two Americans trapped for six hours 275 feet down in the North Sea today after their midget submarine got tangled in an anchor line.

title: Nixon's Doctor Says Patient Is Responding
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 14 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon continues to respond well to treatment for phlebitis and is following doctor's orders to restrict his physical activity, his physician said today.

title: W.H.A. To Start Tonight
description: Even though every franchise in the league lost money; even though the league has no team in the rich television markets of New York and Los Angeles, and even though it lost its series to the Soviet Union, the World Hockey Hockey Association says it's here to stay. Tonight it opens its third season with the first of 1,092 games.

title: Notes on People
description: Sam J. Ervin Jr., the retiring Democratic Senator from North Carolina, and Elliot L. Richardson, the former Attorney General, will join John V. Lindsay, the former Mayor of New York, as regular contributcrs on the new ABCTV morning news program, AM America it was announced yesterday.

title: Contract Awards
description: A contract worth about 1 billion marks, or about $40million, has been won by DaimlerBenz, A.G., of Stuttgart, Germany, to deliver 10,000 trucks in 1975 to Iraq's stateowned vehicleimport agency.

title: Hasenohrl and Hornsby Hurt
description: The New York Giants will start shopping this week, but not for a quarterback.

title: Robert Kleberg Jr. Dies; Owned Huge King Ranch
description: Robert J. Kleberg Jr., president of the King Ranch, Inc., which Owns 960,000 acres of cattle and oil lands in Texas and operates an additional 11.5 million acres of ranches abroad, died Sunday night of cancer of the stomach in St. Luke's Hospital, Houston. He was 78 years old and lived near Kingsville, Tex.

title: Horses Take Back Seat At Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 14 A cab driver who practices eating at bar mitzvahs scored an upset tonight by setting a world record in consuming oneounce hot dogs.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Doar Takes a Temporary Post At Princeton's Wilson School
description: John Doar is cleaning up the tagend details of his job as special counsel on impeachment to the House Judiciary Committee and hopes that what he learned in the post will be of use in his next assignmenta temporaxy two and a half month post as a senior fellow of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University.

title: Rangers Refute Smokey Bear and Let Forest Fire Spread
description: JACKSON, WyoThe fire danced across a bed of pine needles and surrounded the base of a distinguished old spruce. Within minutes, the tree was a crackling torch of flames and smoke.

title: COAL TALKS HELD AMID STRIKE FEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14Net gotiations on a new coal miners' contract resumed today amid increasing doubts on both sides about avoiding a nation. wide strike and could seriously affect electric power supplies.

title: IRAN REAFFIRMS STANCE ON AARMS
description: TOKYO, Oct. 14  Foreign Minister Toshio Kimura came under vigorous attack in Parliament today as members of his own and opposition parties sought to determine whether the United States had brought nuclear weapons into Japan.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1974

title: HOCKELLER '72 AID MAY FACE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The House Judiciary. Committee plans to investigate whether there was any connection between a large Rockefeller family contribution to President Nixon's 1972 campaign and the President's reversal of a ruling by the Civil Aeronautics Board against Eastern Airlines, according to committee sources.

title: A Delectable, Neglected Opera Given
description: For such a delectable and accessible work, Rossini's La Cambiale di Matrimonio has been unnecessarily neglected here. Its first performance in New York in 1937, by the Salzburg Opera Guild, of all groups, was followed in 1958 by a Hunter College Opera production. It has now become the second production of the Opera Buffa Company of New York and is being shown at the Finch College Auditorium on Friday, Saturday and Sunday evenings through Oct. 27.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
A TIMES REPORTER IS BARRED BY CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 14 (UPI)  The military Government announced today that a New York Times correspondent, Jonathan Kandell, had been permanently banned from the country. Mr. Kandell was turned back when he arrived at the airport.

title: BRITISH WILL TAP WAVES FOR POWER
description: LONDON, Oct. 14A project to produce electric power from the waves of the ocean has won the support of the British Government.

title: Sam Rice, Hall of Fame Outfielder, Dies
description: AOSSMOR, Md., Oct, 14 (UPI) Sam Rice, a member of the Baseball Hall of Fame who collected 2,987 hits in a 20year career, died here yesterday of cancer. He was 84 years old.

title: ROCKEFELLER '72 AID MAY FACE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The House Judiciary Committee plans to investigate whether there was any connection between a large Rockefeller family contribution to President Nixon's 1972 campaign and the President's reversal of a ruling by the Civil Aeronautics Board against Eastern Airlines, ac cording to committee sources.

title: Stonewalk Equals Record In Winning Stakes at Big A
description: Stonewalk, with Angel Cordero in the saddle, posted a brilliant victory in the $57,450  Jerome Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. With a crowd of 36,566 turning out for the opening day of the meeting that will run through Jan. 4 Stonewalk pleased the favorite players by beating Best of It by threequarters of a length in the onemile test for 3yearolds. Heir to the Line was third in the field of nine.

title: Production of Steel Increases in Week, But Is Off From '73
description: Steel production continued its upward trend in the week ended Oct. 12, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: Alaska Ferry Is Damaged
description: SITKA, Alaska, Oct. 14 (UPI) The Alaska ferry Columbia, carrying 300 passengers and 58 vehicles, was damaged today when she grazed a rock in Sturgis Narrows a few miles out of Sitka on a run to Juneau. A state spokesman said that there had been, no injuries and that the doublebottomed motor vessel, the newest and largest in the state ferry system, was not in any danger of sinking. She was routed back to Sitka.

title: Cornell Isn't Complaining About Penn's 12th Player
description: Adolph Bellizeare, Pennsylvania's spectacular little tailback, returned a Cornell punt for 61 yards and a touchdown last Saturday without the help of a single block. But had the shifty back needed Interference, he would have had more than enough because the Quakers had 12 men on the field for that play in the second quarter.

title: U.S. Confident on Trade
description: TOKYO, Oct. 14President Ford's special representative for trade, William B. Eberle, indicated here today that the Administration is unconcerned about an alleged Japanese export drive to make gains in foreign markets, including the United States.

title: Top '73 Filly Scores in Matchmaker
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 (AP)Desert Vixen took her third straight stakes victory today, winning the Matchmaker Stakes by  of a length over Coraggioso. The 4yearold daughter of In RealityDesert Trail equaled the stakes record of 1:55 1/5, under 123 pounds, in winning the 1 3/16mile test for fillies and mares.

title: Top '73 Filly Scores in Matchmaker
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 (AP)Desert Vixen took her third straight stakes victory today, winning the Matchmaker Stakes by  of a length over Coraggioso. The 4yearold daughter of In Reality Desert Trail equaled the stakes record of 1:55 1/5, under 123 pounds, in winning the 1 3/16mile test for fillies and mares.

title: People in Sports
description: Emphasizing the bleak prospects of the Knicks as they approached the beginning of the National Basketball Association season were two surprising developments yesterday.

title: Weather: OctoberNovember
description: These charts, based on information supplied by the National Weather Service, show for the next 30 days expected departures from normal temperatures and from normal precipitation. Normal temperatures for this period for five key cities are as follows: New York, 53.0; Chicago, 410; Denver, 44.3; San Francisco, 57.5; Anchorage, 29.0.

title: The Wine Festival, Or Whatever It Is, Is Crowded Again
description: There are Tshirts with witty inscriptions. There are even cooking mittsthe successors to potholdersimprinted with Yiddish witticisms.

title: People and Business
description: The current world oil price has emerged as a result of a world petroleum revolution against the established order, the international oil companies and their home countries, according to John Lichtblau, executive director of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.

title: Stonewalk Equals Record In Winning Stakes at Big A
description: Stonewalk, with Angel Cordero in the saddle, posted a brilliant victory in the $57,450 Jerome Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. With a crowd of 36,566 turning out for the opening day of the meeting that will run through Jan. 4, Stonewalk pleased the avorite players by beating est of It by threequarters of a length in the onemile test for 3yearolds. Heir to the Line was third in the field of nine.

title: Newcombe Subdues Rosewall
description: TOKYO, Oct. 14 (AP) John Newcombe relied heavily on a powerhouse serve to defeat his fellow Australian, Ken Rosewall, 36, 62, 63, today and capture the $100,000 Japan open tennis tournament.

title: NIXON PORTRAYED BY PROSECUTION AS CONSPIRATOR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The special Watergate prosecution opened its case in the Watergate coverup trial today with an account to the jury that portrayed former President Nixon as one of the central conspirators.

title: STUDY FINDS RISK IN SURGERY WORK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14A nationwide survey indicates that women who work in hospital operating rooms run a sharply increased risk of spontaneous abortion, birth defects in their children, and cancer, liver and kidney disease.

title: CORPORATE BONDS CONTINUE RALLY
description: Corporate bonds, extending their strong rally of last week, posted good gains yesterday while municipal, bonds, in lighter trading that reflected the semiholiday status of the credit markets, displayed a firm tone. Banks in New York City and in some other important money centers were closed in observance of Columbus Day. The Government securities markets also were shut down.

title: Onward, Buttoned Soldier
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14At the White House they gave me a button that said WIN.

title: 2,000 Sign Up for 500 Apprentice Jobs
description: Two thousand young men and women, many redeyed from lack of sleep and chilled from street dampness, registered yesterday for 500 potential jobs as electrician apprentices with Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: AQUITAINE ADDING TO THERMAL BID
description: The Aquitaine Company of Canada, Ltd., an oil and gas exploration company, has reentered the contest to acquire the Thermal Power Company of San Francisco.

title: Illustrious Shirtmakers for Almost a Century
description: Back in 1967, when London was really swinging, Turnbull & Asser, the venerable shirtmakers, ran up a white satin turtleneck to show with a dinner suit, instead of the traditional shirt with pleats and ruffles. It ceded no great stir until Davki.Frost and Lord Snowden were refused admission to the Running Footman in New York and the press picked it up.

title: Ford Vetoes Spending Bill That Halts Aid to Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 President Ford vetoed today a spending authority measure requiring a halt in United States military aid to Turkey.

title: Chess: Pyrotechnical Draw Leaves Korchnoi's Lot a Bit Better
description: MOSCOW, Oct 14Viktor Korchnoi and Anatoly Karpov drew the 12th game of their final Candidates Match for the world championship in a rapidfire 1 hour 38 minutes for 23 moves in Tchaikowsky Hall tonight.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Reluctant Fanfani Sets Out to Form Coalition for Italy
description: ROME, Oct. 14With prospects dim for reconstitution of Italy's centerleft coalition, Senator Amintore Fanfani reluctanctly accepted the post of Premierdesignate today.

title: TV: expert Pacing and Polish of the Sinatra Show
description: As a television event, the live transmission of SinatraThe Main Event from Madison Square Garden on evening was accomprofessional polish or, if you prefer, hustle. Once ABC and Boone Arledge, producer, moved into the occasion, the setting, complete with 20,000 enthusiastic spectators, became little more than a gigantic prop for a TV spectacular. Smile and whoop it up, you're on national television.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: Soybean futures dropped the daily limit of 20 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, amid reports of weak cash prices for the beans at New Orleans, and some other exporting points. November delivery beans closed at $8.68 down from $8.88 on Friday.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Powerless Opposition in Singapore Challenges Government in Libel Suit
description: SINGAPORE, Oct. 14A trial that opened here today could provide a rare glimpse into the tightly controlled political system of this small is land state, where opposition to governing party is so stifled that is is nearly moribund.

title: Marconi Bust Unveiled In Cape Cod Ceremony
description: SOUTH WELLFLEET, Mass., Oct. 14Near the crumbling foundations of the old Marconi station here, officials unveiled today a bronze bust of the man who started the age of electronics with his Invention of wireless telegraphy.

title: EXMANAGER SUES DAIRY COOP IN TEXAS
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 14 (AP)The former general manager of Associated Milk Producers, Inc., contends that the board of directors of the cooperative acquiesced and participated with him in making itlegal contributions to political candidates.

title: Bridge: Right Actions Can Turn Out To Be WrongLabeled RW
description: Unlike chess, bridge is not a game in which justice prevails. Rather it is a dificult game of chance. Right actions turn out to be wrong in the circumstances, and we may call them RW. Wrong actions turn out to be right in the circumstances, and we may call them WR.

title: Olympic Advertising Is Planned
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 14Determined to make the 1976 summer Olympic Games in Montreal selffinancing for the first time in the history of the expensive quadrennial competitions, the organizing committee here has for the first time opened the event to international advertising of commercial products.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: French Plan for Jobless. Provides Up to Year's Pay
description: PARIS, Oct. 14French management and labor, prodded by the Government of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, today signed an agreement to provide improved security for the unemployed.

title: Philip Morris Expands Profit; Others Also Report
No, Actually Crowding Isn't Bad
description: It is common knowledge that crowding is bad for people. Our own intuitions are backed up by the assertions of experts: Sociologists, cityplanners and especially ethologists have declared that living under conditions of high population density makes people aggressive and can lead to divorce, crime, mental illness and suicide. It is a wonder that the cities survive at all.

title: You Can Beat Dead Horse, If It's a Federal Court Case
description: What official body do you appeal to if you want to be declared King of the World?

title: $1Million Lottery Ticket Shared by 2 L.I. Women
description: Two women who are longtime friends and nextdoor neighbors in West Hempstead, L.I., were joint winners yesterday of $1million in the New York State lottery.

title: Princetonians Honored
description: CENTERVILLE, Mass., Oct. 14 (AP)Tom Snickenberger, a Princeton halfback, and a teammate, Tom Schalch, a defensive tackle, topped the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I football allstar team this week. Snickenherger rushed for 100 yards and scored the winning touchdown against Dartmouth last Saturday, while Schalch had 15 tackles and a fumble recovery.

title: Saxbe Setting Up a Panel On False Identifications
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 14 (UPI)Attorney General William B. Saxbe said that he was creating an advisory committee to tackle the problem of false identifications increasingly used by criminals to escape detection.

title: Salesman Slain in Queens, Apparently in Holdup
description: A Wise Potato Chip salesman who had just made a delivery to a store in St. Albans, Queens, was slain yesterday afternoon in a closerange gun fight, apparently with a robber, in the back of his parked delivery truck.

title: KING OF THAILAND HONORS 1973 DEAD
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 14 King Phumiphol Aduldet of Thailand has spent the last year trying to stay out of a democratic order that many Thais regard as his personal gift to the nation.

title: A Heyday on Display: Glass Architecture in 1800's
description: It is common to think of glass structures as being very much of our own time. A small but excellent exhibition of drawings of the New York Crystal Palace, now at the City University of New York Graduate Center on West 42d Street, is an apt reminder of the heyday that glass architecture enjoyed in the mid19th century.

title: Horses Take Back Seat At Westbury
description: WESTBURY, Oct. 14 A cab driver who practices eating at bar mitzvahs scored an upset tonight by setting a world record in consuming oneounce hot dogs.

title: Impoundment Suit Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP)  The Congressional Rural Caucus has decided to drop a lawsuit filed last May that sought release of $4.5billion in funds impounded by the Nixon Administration. Representative John B. Breckinridge, Democrat of Kentucky, who is chairman of the caucus's impoundments committee, said today that the court action is no longer necessary because the Ford Administration had complied substantially with requests to release necessary funds.

title: America Adrift ...
description: The political leadership of the nation is proving inadequate to cope with the nation's economic and social problems. In the White House and in Congress, in both political parties, there is a failure of nerve, of imagination, of competence.

title: PRESEASON BASKETBALL
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Macmillan Book Divisions
description: Macmillan, Inc., one of the nation's largest publishers, abruptly dismissed more than 100 employes in its book divisions here yesterday, citing poor business conditions.

title: Advertising
description: No doubt many of you were wondering over the weekend if any trends were developing in sponsorship of network television specials. If you were, don't worry about it. It's a natural thing to think about.

title: Food Stamp Fund Will Be Increased Starting on Jan. 1
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) A lowincome family of four will have its food stamp benefits raised about $4 a month beginning Jan. 1, according to new figures released today by the Agriculture Department.

title: Olympic Unit Hit Hard by Stock Drop
description: The United States Olympic Committee, which is under scrutiny from Congress, the courts and the American public, has taken its toughest pounding over the last two years from a different set of numbers, those on the Wall Street ticker tape.

title: Hunter Vs. Downing as Series Resumes for Game 3 Tonight
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 14 Jim (Catfish) Hunter, a reluctant rebel and perhaps the best pitcher now active, and Al Downing, an allbutforgotten, 33yearold lefthander, move into baseball's center stage tomorrow night as the World Series resumes at its second site. The Oakland A's and Los Angeles Dodgers are tied at one victory apiece in the four  of  seven  game competition.

title: Tax Experts Call Rockefeller's Deductions for Business Expenses Large
description: Some tax experts who have scrutinized the financial information that was provided by Nelson A. Rockefeller to Congress and subsequently released to the public say they believe the Vice Presidentdes ignate's deductions for business and office expenses were exceptionally large.

title: Electricity Rates Jumped 55.4% in 1974 Half
description: Electricity rates of the nation's 50 largest utilities rose by an average of 55.4 per cent during the first half of this year. This compared with average increase of 12.3 per cent for all of 1973, according to the National Utility Service, Inc., which keeps records of rates to help its clientsindustrial and commercial consumersobtain the lowest possible rates.

title: SCHMIDT WILL SEEK SOVIET COOPERATION
description: BERLIN, Oct. 14  A West German official said today that Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, during his visit to Moscow at the end of this month, expected to discuss with Leonid L Brezhnev, Communist party secretary, longrange projects for economic cooperation.

title: Wilson and Carey Debate State and National Issues
description: In their first confrontation of the gubernatorial campaign, Governor Wilson and Representative Hugh L. Carey heatedly debated yesterday for nearly two and a half hours on a dozen state and national issues ranging from amnesty co taxes.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Tokyo's Police Hunt 3 Suspects in Blast At Trade Company
description: TOKYO, Oct. 14The police are searching for three suspects in the bombing today of the home office of Mitsui & Co. here. It was the second bombing of a giant business organization in a month and a half.

title: Shah Pushing Plan to Aid Poorer Lands
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 14Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi is pressing in international circles for a revival of his eightmonthold proposal for the creation of a development fund of several billion dollars to ease the problems of poorer countries caused by high oil prices.

title: Nation's Charities Feel Economic Pinch and Are Devising New Techniques to Raise Funds
description: A substantial number of the nation's charities, now entering the busiest time of year for raising funds, are finding themselves confronted by reluctant potential donors who are squeezed by inflation, stung by higher costs, shaken by lower stock values and seemingly afflicted with cynicism.

title: FORD MAKES APPEAL TO CONSERVE ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) President Ford asked the nation's Governors, big city May, ors and major county officials today to conserve energy by enforcing the 55mileanhour speed limit and to fight inflation by eliminating outmoded rules on production and supply of services.

title: Infants Detected With Type of High Blood Pressure Once Found Only in Adults
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14Pediatricians have made the surprising discovery that children even infants a few months oldcan suffer a form of high blood pressure hitherto considered limited to adults.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: F.C.C. Likely to Set Guidelines for Young
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The Federal Communications Commission has rejected requests that it hand down concrete rules aimed at improving children's television. It has tentatively decided, however, to publish a general guideline asking stations to devote a reasonable amount of programing to children.

title: BOARD IS ASSAILED IN LANE VIOLENCE
description: Assemblyman Vito P. Battista, speaking to a crowd of more than 600 at a rally he held yesterday on the baseball diamond behind troubled Franklin K. Lane High School, blamed the central Board of Education and city officials for the violence last week at the school.

title: Dole Is Seeking to Revive Sagging Drive in Kansas
description: DODGE CITY, Kan.Senator Robert Dole took his fight for reelection last week to Dole country the sprawling, fertile farmland and small towns of the, huge First Congressional District that takes nearly twothirds of Kansas.

title: NIXON PORTRAYED BY PROSECUTION AS CONSPIRATOR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The special Watergate prosecution opened its case in the Watergate coverup trial today with an account to the jury that portrayed former President Nixon as one of the central con spirators.

title: Edmund Christopherson, 56, Freelance Travel Writer
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 14 (AP)Edmund Christopherson, a freelance writer who came here for a convention of American travel writers, died today of injuries received on Oct. 5, when he was caught in heavy surf at a beach. He was 56 years old and lived in Missoula, Mont. His wife, Joan was with him when he died.

title: Saigon Denies Visas To Times Reporter Aid Paris Newsman
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 14  Two foreign correspondentsJean Claude Pomonti of Le. Monde and Sydney H. Schanberg of The New York Timeshave been denied permission to enter South Vietnam.

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Confident that the economy is on the road to recovery, traders sent prices up again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market, despite the Columbus Day holiday.

title: GAINS IN MIDEAST SEEN BY KISSINGER
description: CAIRO, Oct. 14Secretary of State Kissinger, in his most optimistic public statement since the start of his present Mideast tour, said today he saw indications that we are making progress toward peace in the area.

title: GAINS IN MIDEAST SEEN BY KISSINGER

title: 800 DEMONSTRATE FOR SCHOOL PLAN
description: NEWARK, Oct. 14About 800 persons, most of them children, held a peaceful but noisy march and demonstration in the downtown business district in support of their demands for continuation of the full 3,000student bilingual program in the city's schools.

title: Boy Killed by Sandpile
description: GOFFSTOWN, N.H., Oct. 14 (AP)A Manchester boy was killed yesterday when a pile of sand at the Goffstown sanilary landfill collapsed on him.

title: FIRST BOSTON CORP. SHOWS PROFIT RISE
description: The First Boston Corporation, a leading investment banker, reported yesterday that earnings rose sharply for the third quarter despite what it termed a difficult economic climate.

title: Excerpts From the Gubernatorial Campaign Debate Between Wilson and Carey
description: Following are excerpts from yester?? debate between Governor Wilson and Representative Hugh L. Carey, the Democratic candidate for Governor, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Vote for Railroads
description: The railroads of New York State, like those elsewhere in the country, are dangerously close to collapse. The Federal Department of Transportation, whose general remedy for deteriorated railroads is to make them worse by cutting service, is ready to see 34 per cent of the current network abandoned, with grave potential consequences to employment and the entire state economy.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 14 (AP)Ron Mix, general manager of the Portland Storm, said today the World Football League team had missed only one pay period this season and there's absolutely no talk of a boycott. Mix. called a newt conference after published reports yesterday said the Storm players hadn't been paid in two weeks and were considering boycotting Wednesday night's game against the Hawaiians.

title: French Plan for Jobless Provides Up to Year's Pay
description: PARIS, Oct. 14French management and labor, prodded by the Government of President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, today signed an agreement to provide improved security for the unemployed.

title: Jane S. Niedringhaus,
description: Jane Switzler Niedringhaus of St. Louis and Nantucket, Mass., widow of Lee I. Niedringhaus, was married yesterday morning to John Macrae Jr., a widower, of Naples, Fla., and Nantucket, who is chairman of the board of E. P. Dutton & Co., Inc., publishers.

title: Shrinking Giants
description: Money troubles at the Ford Foundation may seem to some about as plausible as Nelson Rockefeller's going on welfare. Yet, the Ford Foundation has, in fact, been hit by the Wall Street slump. Within a year, the market value of its assets has dropped from $3 billion to $2 billion, and the foundation is considering a drastic cut in its $200millionayear grants.

title: Dr. A. Irving Hallowell, 81, An Anthropologist, Dead
description: Dr. A. Irving Hallowell, professor emeritus of anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania and a past president of the American Anthropological Association, died last Thursday at his home in Wayne, Pa. He was 81 years old.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Monday, Oct. 14, 1974

title: Wilson and Carey Debate State and National Issues
description: In their first confrontation of the gubernatorial campaign, Governor Wilson and Representative Hugh L. Carey heatedly debated yesterday for nearly two and a half hours on a dozen state and national issues ranging from amnesty to taxes.

title: SHERWIN IS DENIED STAY OF SENTENCE
description: NEWARK, Oct. 14A Federal Appeals Court Judge denied request today by former New Jersey Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwn for a stay of his oneyear to twoyear jail term for bribery and conspiracy.

title: Albany Environment Chief Opposes Tocks Proposal
description: ALBANY, Oct. 14New York state's top environmental conrervation official said today he row opposed construction of he $370million Tocks Island lam along the Delaware River.

title: Veterans Medical Records Help Case
description: A 26yearold Veterans Administration medical report has been discovered that opens new chapter in a long fight by decorated World War II veteran of the Army Air Forces to have his leftside paralysis recognized as serviceconnected.

title: BankAmerica, First Chicago and Mellon Report Increases
Football Ratings
description: The top teams, with points figured on 10987654321 basis for first through 10th places (firstplace votes in parenthesis and wonlosttied records:

title: Phillips Petroleum Payout
description: The hoard of directors of the Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday increased the regular quarterly dividend paid on common stock to 40 cents a share from 35 cents, payable Dec. 2 to holders of record Nov. 8. The company noted it was its second dividend increase in 1974 and said earnings had shown substantial improvewent.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Sullivan Mass Tomorrow
description: A requiem mass will he offered for Ed Sullivan, the retired Broadway columnist of The Daily News who died of cancer Sunday night at the age of 73, at 11 A.M. tomorrow in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Cooke will preside, and Msgr. James F. Rigney, rector of the cathedral, will offer the mass.

title: Leftist Alliance in France Shows Strain
description: PARIS, Oct. 14Strains have developed in France's Alliance of the Left after recent National Assembly byelections in Communist candidates ran behind Socialists in most of the contests.

title: Chicago Options Peak Is Set
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (UPI)The Chicago Board Options Exchange of the Chicago Board of Trade today set its second record trading volume in the last three sessions when 60,842 options were traded. The previous high of 57,482 was set in last Thursday's session. The 17monthold exchange trades options in 32 highly volatile stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Amnesty Group Scores Prisoner's Plight Here
description: Amnesty International, which is observing Prisoner of Conscience Week this week, has chosen an American as one of 13 prisoners. to dramatize the plight of hundreds of thousands of prisoners of conscience throughout the world.

title: BIG OIL COUNTRIES CUTTING OUTPUT
description: BEIRUT, Oct. 12Moves by some industrialized countries to reduce oil imports are pushing the major oilexporting countries toward a coordinated reduction of production to maintain current prices.

title: BIG BELGIAN BANK DISCLOSES LOSSES
description: PARIS, Oct. 14The 103yearold Banque de Bruxelles, second largest bank in Belgium, disclosed today that it had suffered potential losses, the dimensions of which are yet unknown, because of irregular, unrecorded and unauthorized dealings in foreign currency. The bank has turned the case over to judicial authorities.

title: Erotica Publisher Tries Today To Win Rehearing in High Court
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct, 14A millionaire publisher of erotica, who refuses to watch Xrated movies and is pretty straitlaced about the books his nine grandchildren read, will make a final effort in the Supreme Court tomorrow to escape going to prison as a conviceted pornographer.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Snagging Fluke
description: CORE BANKS, N.C.Sometime in the early morning hours, two of my fishing companions at the Core Banks rose, slipped out of the camp, and walked 300 yards to the stiff to fish for channel bass under the brilliant light of a nearlyfull moon.

title: Suppliers Charged With Diluting Coal
description: A number of coal companies have been accused by electric utilities of deliberately failing to live up to delivery contracts and, in some instances, rounding out tonnages with lower grades of coal than were orderedand sometimes mixing in excessive amounts of rock and dirt.

title: Rockwell Admiral Unit Reduces Its Production
description: Production of its home entertainment division has been reduced by 50 per, cent, the Admiral Group of the Rockwel International Corporation announced yesterday.

title: Probable LineUp for Third Game
Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 800 people, most of them children, held a peaceful but noisy march and demonstration yesterday in the business district of Newark in support of their demand for continuation of the full bilingual program in the city's schools. They vowed to continue their boycott of the program in nine elementary schools until the Board of Education agreed to provide bilingual education to about 1,200 Englishdominant children who are to be dropped from the federally supported program.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: If things continue at their present pace, Jerry Eure of Pennington School will win the scoring race among New Jersey schoolboy football players, and then, once again, lead the schools basketball and baseball teams as he completes his senior year.

title: Misplaced Payoff
description: The 5 per cent offtrack betting surtax that Governor Wilson sold to Mayor Beame last spring as part of budgetbalancing tax package has paid off handsomely but not for New York City.

title: Goldstein Broadens Attack on Casinos
description: United States Attorney Jonathan Goldstein yesterday broadened his attack on proposed casino gambling for New Jersey, attacking supporters of the plan for lulling the public into the belief that it would provide easy answers to serious fiscal problems facing the state.

title: It Happened One Nightand All Day
description: Lured by the prospect of watching 10 of Columbia Pictures' greatest hits at no charge during a 19hour weekend marathon, several hundred New Yorkers lined up outside the Columbia II theater Saturday night and spent the better part of Sunday massaging swollen feet, stretching aching backs and rubbing bleary eyes into a state of semiwakefulness.

title: ROCKEFELLER AIDE SILENT ON BOOK
description: John Ashley Wells, an attorney and longtime colleague of Nelson A. Rockfeller, declined yesterday to say how much he had told Mr. Rockefeller in 1970 concerning a derogatory book about Arthur J. Goldberg that was financed by Laurance S. Rockefeller that year.

title: High Beef Demand Seen
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (Reuters)  Beef consumption in the United States is likely to reach a record of more than 116 pounds a person this year. Assistant Agriculture Secretary Richard Feltner said today at the American Meat Institute's annual Meeting.

title: Business Briefs
description: PARIS, Oct. 14 (Reuters)France's trade gap narrowed last mouth because of a drop of over 5 per cent in imports, the Foreign Trade Ministry announced today.

title: John Macrae Jr. Wed
description: The Rev. Robert Metters and the Rev. Herbert Stevens officiated at the ceremony in the chapel of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Nantucket.

title: Into the Minefield
description: Arab and Israeli leaders are giving strong initial signs of cooperating in Secretary of State Kissinger's latest initiative toward another round of peace negotiations. So they should, for there is simply no viable choice.

title: LAGLETON DISPUTED BY JAVITS ON JETS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said tuday that a contention that secret tests had shown the Navy F14 jet fighter to be far inferior to the Air Force F15 was erroneous.

title: Javits Is Briefed on Perils of Asbestos
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits conferred with medical officials of Mount Sinai Hospital and with labor leaders yesterday about what he called the sleeping peril of asbestos particles in the air.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE SIXTEENTH ROUND. From Number 1 Contender to #45472, By Rubin (Hurricane) Carter. 339 pages, Illustrated. Viking. $11.95.

title: Western Canadians Plan Own Party
description: CALGARY, AlbertaBecause of a feeling that none of the established political parties in Ottawa are fairly representing western Canada, an oil executive, John E. P. Gallagher, is starting a new one, with its roots out here in the heart of the country's mineral wealth.

title: Intricate Street Games for Saigon's Children
GIBSON APPOINTS A HISPANIC JUDGE
description: NEWARK, Oct. 14Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson today acceded to demands by the Puerto Rican community and appointed the city's first judge of Hispanic origin.

title: CLINIC GIVES UP PLANS TO MOVE
description: Bowing to community pressure, the Arnoldo Mora Methadone Clinic has abandoned plans to move from its present site in an apartment house at 1230 Park Avenue near 96th Street to larger quarters in a brownstone at 1453 Lexington Avenue near 94th Street.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state has been paying rent of more than $15,000 a month since April on a vacant building in Paterson, and State Treasurer Richard C. Leone blames the previous administration for the waste of funds. Responding to published reports of a sweetheart lease for the building, signed in 1971 under the administration of Gov. William T. Cahill, Mr. Leone said in a statement that New Jersey would lose $160,000 by renting offices in the building, the Broadway Bank building.

title: 25 Are Arrested On Madison Campus During a Drug Raid
description: MADISON, Oct. 14A predawn raid on the Florham Park campus of FairleighDickinson University here this morning resulted in the arrest of 25 persons, identified as students, by the Morris County Prosecutor's police.

title: Market Place
description: A scenario for the solution of the energy crisis may involve increasing conservation by the oil havenotsboth developed and developing nations includedthat would put pressure on the oilducing cartel to reduce prices in 1975 or 1976.

title: Blacks Seek Solution to Rising Crime and Lack of Faith in System of Law
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14Deand Motivated by what they say is a concern for the rising rate of crime in minority communities and a growing lack of faith in the law enforcement system, black community leaders are planning a series of meetings throughout the country to formulate strategy for solving the problem.

title: E.P.A. Is Curbing Sewer Main Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The Federal Government is tightening up on its billiondollar program of grants to localities for sewer mains because of findings that the projects are encouraging unsound community growth.

title: State Environmental Chief
description: ALBANY, Oct. 14New York State's top environmental conservation official said today he now opposed construction of the $370million Tocks Island dam along the Delaware River.

title: MIGRANT RULES FACE CHALLENGE
description: Two migrantaid agencies, disturbed by proposed changes in Federal housing standards for seasonal farm workers, called today for public hearings on the revisions in New Jersey and neighboring states.

title: Chief of Loan Bank Decries Tax Plan
