description: HONOLULU, Oct. 14Thomas R. Bomar, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said here today that Federal legislation to exempt some interest on savings from income taxes is Band Aid treatment compared with other alternatives to beefing up the savings and loan industry.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FILMS The New American Filmmakers Series at the Whitney Museum of American Art is in its fourth week, and tomorrow one of the more controversial of its entries will begin a week's run. A documentary by E. J. Vaughn entitled America's Pop Collector: Robert C. Scull, on the events before, during and after last October's $2.2million auction of modern art belonging to Mr. Scull, the taxifleet owner, will be shown daily in the museum's secondfloor theater. The film explores, through Mr. Scull's words and the words of artists and dealers, the irksome question of whether artists ought to share in royalties as the prices of their works rise.

title: Phone Company To Provide Scores
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide World Series scores. The number is 6871212: The scores will be updated after each halfinning and final scores will be carried for several hours after the end of each game.

title: Cardinals' Coach Pinching Himself
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14Don Coryell, the mild, modest coach of the Cardinals who Will be 50 years old on Thursday, is awed, apologetic and anxious about the surprising achievements of his team in the National Football League this season five victories, no defeats. He is pinching himself. Anyone can beat us real easily, he said today in the wake of the Cardinals' impressive 3128 decision over Dallas, the first St. Louis triumph against the Cowboys in seven games over the last four years.

title: Hunter Vs. Downing as Series Resumes for Game 3 Tonight
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 14 Jim (Catfish) Hunter, a reluctant rebel and perhaps the best pitcher now active, and Al Downing, an allbutforgotten, 33yearold lefthander, move into baseball's center stage tomorrow night as the World Series resumes at its second site. The Oakland A's and Los Angeles Dodgers are tied at one victory apiece in the four  of  seven  game competition.

title: Club Is Torn by BlamePlacing
Orchestra Auditions: The Old Systems Are Changing
description: When the National Urban League and the Symphony of the New World accused the nation's symphony orchestras the Other day of using racism, cronyism, nepotism and unionnonwhites, the targets actually under fire were the audition systems by which musiclans are hired. As any musiclan who has survived one could tell you, auditioning for a symphony or opera orchestra can be an experience combining the worst features of a debut recital, a commando obstacle course and a kangaroo court trial. Until recent years, the men of fairness or equal opportunity scarcely were thought necessary, or even desirable.

title: Simon, in Moscow, Backs U.S. Grain Sales to Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 14Treasury Secretary William E. Simon, in a justification of grain sales to the Soviet Union, said today that the jump in world prices on such commodities as oil was impelling the United States to export more.

title: WHITES IN BOSTON SCORE DEMOCRATS
description: BOSTON, Oct. 14 About 1,500 parents and their children from white sections of Boston rallied in front of the SheratonBoston Hotel here tonight to deliver a message to. Democratic political leaders: Stop courtordered busing to desegregate the city's schools.

title: Hosanna, Witty Play From Quebec
description: Hosanna is a drag queen, a transvestite with a tongue of acid and a heart of stone. She wants to be something she isn't. She is a man. A man who wants to be Elizabeth Tayor, playing Cleopatra, yet. He wants to enter in Rome in triumphinstead .... But instead is the story of Michel Tremblay's play Hosanna, which opened last night at the Bijou Theater.

title: B. ALTMAN EXPANDS MEN'S WEAR SECTION
description: B. Altman & Co., the Fifth Avenue department store, opened yesterday an expanded men's wear section on the main floor, erected and assembled at a cost of almost $1million. Management called the investment our biggest in the last few years.

title: Northrop Preparing A Report on Fund Used for Politics
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 (Reuters)The Northrop corporation today said two independent auditors are now completing reports  which should be released in a few weekson all facts pertinent to the use of corporate funds for political purposes.

title: ... Bipartisan Failure
description: The fumbling on mass transit is only one instance chronic failure of leadership by both the President and the Democraticcontrolled Congress on crucial questions of inflation control, tax reform and energy conservation. The cautious mixture of economic incentives, restraints and concessions contained in Mr. Ford's message Congress provides little ground for hope that the nation any time soon will change direction away from rising prices and rising unemployment;

title: Columbus Day Parade Called the Longest Ever Here
description: What city officials called the longest Columbus Day parade ever was a vibrant melange yesterday of 100,000 marchers, along with politicians, majorettes and mounted policemen, bands, cheerleaders and floats, all overlaid with a green, white and red ItalianAmerican ethnicity.

title: Rockefeller Gave Steuben. Glass to 5 Senators
description: Former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's gifts to his associates included Steuben glasscrystal engraved with fish and valued at $2,350 eachsent as a Christmas present last year to all of his 14 fellow members of the Commission on Water Quality.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: FEWER DIRTY TRICKS REPORTED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The Fair Campaign Practices Committee said today that complaints of political dirty tricks were down 50 per cent this year because of the backlash from the Watergate scandal.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Harris Poll Finds 18% Dip In Backing for President
description: The Louis Harris Poll has found that confidence in President Ford's job performance has dropped 18 percentage points since he pardoned former President Richard M. Nixon, United Press International said yesterday.

title: Dance: Nureyev, Taylor
description: There could not have been a more fitting day for Rudolf Nureyev to make his first stage appearance here with a moderndance company than yesterday's Columbus Day matine at the Alvin Theater with the Paul Taylor Dance Company.

title: Joseph Durso
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 14Baseball turned its back on all that Hollywood jazz today and brought the World Series 440 miles up the California coast to Oakland, the city across the bay, the haven of rebels, the land of the poor people, the home of the country mouse and also the ball park of the Oakland A's, the happy revolutionaries professional sports.

title: $5Billion Forecast
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 14 (Reuters)Secretary of Commerce Frederick Dent told the Business Council, an economic research group, today that the United States' balance of trade could show a deficit of as much as $5billion in 1974.

title: Rangers Refute Smokey Bear and Let Forest Fire Spread
description: JACKSON, Wyo.The fire danced across a bed of pine needles and surrounded the base of a distinguished old spruce. Within minutes, the tree was a crackling torch of flames and smoke.

title: PALESTINIANS WIN RIGHT TO APPEAR IN U.N. ASSEMBLY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14The United Nations General Assembly overwhelmingly endorsed today an Arabled move to give a voice in its meetings to the Palestine Liberation Organization, the main coordinating organization of guerrilla groups.

title: Theater: Storey's Farm
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12David Storey's The Farm, Which had its American premiere last night at the Folger Theater Group, is a family play, suffused with humanity and truth, is a beautiful play, one of Mr. Storey's finest. The dramatic situation jig specifica strong willed Yorkshire farmer is saddled with three unfulfilled daughters and a prodigal sonbut its reverberations are universal: The values, dreams and defeats of parents have an influence on and help to define their children.

title: CostPrice Squeeze Cited by SarnoffSales Set Record
description: The RCA Corporation had record sales in this year's third quarter and first nine months, but profits ran behind the yearearlier pace, the company reported yesterday.

title: Seeking An Impact On Events
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C.Back in the late forties, a journalism student at the University of North Carolina was a member of a small if not very select group, some of whom thought they had found the ideal crip course, since there were virtually no tests or final examinations. A devoted few were seriously interested in Walter Spearman's news writing classes or Phillips Russell's lectures on creative writing or O. J. Coffin's course in editorial writingactually an exciting study of the uses of language. Even these few sometimes felt themselves a bit on the edge of things at a great liberal arts university.

title: Annenberg Leaving London With Critics Mellowed
description: LONDON, Oct. 14After two dozen parties and a couple of false starts, and after contributions of more than $1million to British organizations, Walter H. Annenberg announced definite plans to give up his post as United States Ambassador to Britain.

title: Kissinger, Mideast Tour Nearing End, Is Wary and Optimistic
description: ALGIERS, Oct. 14  Secretary of State Kissinger, near the end of his latest Middle East mission, is hinting broadly that he has worked out an ArabIsraeli consensus on how to resume negotiations. But as he prepares to return to Washington, he is mindful that his carefully workedout mosaic might fall apart in coming weeks.

title: Lowenstein Returns to L.I. to Oppose Rep. Wydler
description: LONG BEACH, L.I.Allard K. Lowenstein, who went to Washington in 1968 as a determined opponent of Lyndon B. Johnson and the Vietnam war, has apparently outlived his radical reputation and emerged this fall as a lowkey candidate of middle America in the Fifth Congressional District.

title: 35 City Food Spots Listed as Violators Of the Health Code
description: The Health Department released yesterday the names of 35 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The present oil crisis reveals, and is aggravated by, a grave flaw in Henry Kissinger's theory of modern international relations. The Secretary of State is a student of balanceofpower diplomacy, a concept which reaches for its inspiration into the last century when the great concert of major European nations could and did, by way of a fairly stable balance of international monetary and military power, maintain almost a century free of any general European conflagrations.

title: Ford Vetoes Spending Bill That Halts Aid to Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 President Ford vetoed today a spending authority measure requiring a halt in United States military aid to Turkey.

title: No Leads Found on Batteries
description: While racing shifted from Belmont Park to Aqueduct yesterday, investigators continued searching for the persons to whom Juan Cardona might have sold illegal batteries.

title: After 10Month Beame Tenure, Press Room at City Hall Is Quiet but Uneasy
description: In the 10 months since Abraham D. Beame has been Mayor, the daily, outpouring of City Hall press releases has nearly ceased, and a somewhat uneasy calm has settled over Room 9, which is where the reporters work.

title: Confirmation Doubts Rise On House Judiciary Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14Several members of the House Judiciary Committee, which had always been considered likely to take a hard look at Nelson A. Rockefeller's nomination as Vice President, said today that recent disclosures about the way Mr. Rockefeller and his family spent their money had deepened their misgivings.

title: Lions Beat 49ers for First Victory
description: DETROIT, Oct. 14 (AP)A disputed pass interference penalty, set up a 1yard touchdown plunge by Steve Owens in the second period and the Detroit Lions added a fourthquarter touchdown on a 13yard pass from Bill Munson to Larry Wjalton to defeat the San Francisco 49ers, 1713, in a National football League game tonight.

title: GOLDIN CRITICIZES CITY'S BORROWING
description: City Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that, unless the city changed its borrowing practices and cut back on borrowing in general, real estate taxes could rise by 45 per cent over the next six years.

title: Chemical Disposal to Begin
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 14 (AP)The Dutch incinerator ship Vulcanus sailed today into the Gulf of Mexico to start the first disposal burning of chemical wastes in American waters.

title: Macmillan Book Divisions Sharply Cut Their Staffs
description: Macmillan, Inc., one of the nation's largest publishers, abruptly dismissed more than 100 employes in its book divisions here yesterday, citing poor business conditions.

title: GLENN JEPSEN DIES; PALEONTOLOGIST, 71
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 15Dr. Glenn L. Jepsen, a paleontologist in Princeton University's geology department for four decades, died today of cancer. He was 71 years old and lived here at 144 Patton Avenue.

title: Dow Average Off 15.10  Computer Failure Causes Trading Halt
description: Profit taking ended the stock market's recent sharp advance yesterday as prices tumbled in an erratic session interrupted by equipment problems.

title: Israeli Fear of New Pullbacks Stirring Criticsm of Kissinger
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 15  A new, conspicuously critical view of Secretary of State Kissinger and the role he is playing in the diplomacy of the Middle East came to the surface in Israel during his visit here last weekend.

title: Auto Safety Bill
description: The House of Representatives passed and sent to the White House compromise auto safety legislation that would eliminate the seat belt interlock system. Page 86.

title: FORD URGES STEPS TO CURB INFLATION
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 15  President Ford proposed to the nation tonight a series of voluntary measures to fight inflation and save energy. Many of his proposals, including the possible sale of Government bonds, were reminiscent of World War II programs.

title: Worker Charged in 2 Killings Of Women at Georgia Malls
description: DECATUR, Ga., Oct. 15 (UPI) The police yesterday charged a 23yearold construction worker with the deaths of two of four women who were killed after apparently being accosted at nearby shopping malls.

title: PROFIT SOARS 150% AT MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lynch & Co., bouncing back dramatically from a poor six months, reported yesterday that thirdquarter profits at the big financial services company soared by nearly 150 per cent.

title: Bryant Park Exhibition Celebrates Idea Of Ending Auto's Domination of Streets
description: Ending the automobile's domination of downtown streets and opening them up for more relaxed human use has been a goal of most enlightened urban planners since the midnineteen  sixties. During that period, planners finally realized that ramming highways through old streets was doing little except bringing the sterility of the suburbs into the city. In fact, the concept of improved plazas, trafficfree zones, and malls now has become such a part of the common wisdom that a set of such proposals has been put together in a special exhibition as a New York City bicentennial project, More Streets for People.

title: Brezhnev to Meet With Sadat in Cairo Next Januar
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, will visit Egypt next January to meet with President Anwar elSadat.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Daylight Time

title: Cliched and Casual, Wakeman Rocks In Garden Concert
description: Rick Wakeman, a classically trained keyboard player who has been part of two British rock groups, Strawbs and Yes, is now off on his own. Monday night he brought his new band, a symphony orchestra, a small chorus and some props to Madison Square Garden. Given the overstuffed, turgid quality of the music, what was most interesting about the affair was the audience's ecstatic response.

title: Auto Safety Bill
description: The House of Representatives passed and sent to the White House compromise auto safety legislation that would eliminate the seat belt interlock system. Page 86.

title: HOUSE LETS STAND VETO OF A CUTOFF OF AID TO TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The House of Representatives today failed to override President Ford's veto of a stopgap spending measure that would have cut off United States military aid to Turkey.

title: Moslems End Ramadan, Holy Month of Fasting
description: CAIRO, Oct. 15 (AP) With a burst of feasting and merrymaking, Moslems today wound up the holy month of Ramadan, the season of sunrisetosunset fasting that Is one of the pillars of their religion.

title: NEWS INDEX
Jaworski's Record: A Dissent
description: History will not be kind to Leon Jaworski. The question it will ask will not be, Was he an overcautious prosecutor? But rather, Was he a sham?

title: Merrill Lynch Gains
description: Merrill Lynch & Co., holding company for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the brokerage house, reported yesterday that the concern's profits climbed by nearly 150 per cent in the third quarter. Details on Page 58.

title: 150 Picket in Newark For Bilingual Schools
description: NEWARK, Oct. 15More than 150 Hispanic parents and students picketed City Hall this afternoon, voicing concern about the future of the publicschool system's bilingual education program for more than 3,000 pupils at nine grammar schools.

title: KENT STATE WARNING IS LINKED TO RHODES
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 15 (UPI) Former Gov. James A. Rhodes allegedly told officers of the Ohio National Guard to. use any amount of force necessary to break up student antiwar, demonstrators at Kent State University on May 3, 1970, The Cleveland Plain Dealer reported today.

title: City Schools to Enroll 45,000 With Handicaps
description: The City Board of Education, complying with state orders, plans to provide special education in the public school system this year for 45,000 handicapped children15,000 more than a year agoat an added cost of $42million.

title: PAUL W. MORENCY, 74, RADIO, TV EXECUTIVE
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 15 (AP) Paul W. Morency, who retired in 1967 as president of Broadcast Plaza, Inc., died today at his home in Avon. He was 74 years old.

title: MORE MINORITIES EMPLOYED BY CITY
description: The number of black and Hispanic employes reported in survey of municipal workers here increased from 43,952 in mid1973 to 52,958 last June, indicating a 20 per cent rise in minoritygroup employment.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1974

title: City Police Start Guided Tours
description: The policeman in the threepiece gray flannel suit knew that the London police force, with 28,000 people, was the second largest in the worldafter the force in New York, which has 31,000.

title: Charles Powell Dead at 70; Aide of Lawn Tennis Group
description: Charles D. Powell, a longtime official of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, died Monday of a liver ailment in Queens Memorial Hospital at the age of 70. He resided in Kew Gardens Hills, Qtieens.

title: Bystander Killed at Holdup Apparently Shot by Police
description: ROSELLE, NI., Oct. 16More than 200 friends and relatives, including his wife and seven children, attended a funeral service today for 45yearold Lucius Harrell, who the police say was an innocent bystander apparently killed by police bullets during an attempted holdup of an Elizabeth tavern early Friday morning.

title: A JERSEY INQUIRY ON RONAN BACKED
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15The New Jersey Assembly today voted for a legislative investigation of Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller's $550,000 gift to Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: FLEDERMAUS GIVEN WITH 5 NEWCOMERS
description: If you don't mind domestic champagne now and then, you probably will find the New York City Opera's production of Die Fledermaus palatably fizzy stuff. In the sixth performance of the season on Sunday night, five singers new to the cast worked valiantly to keep Strauss from going flat.

title: Bewildered Husbands Seek Family Therapy
description: Men, many of them bewildered and confused about their role in society today, are seeking help from family and marriage counselors in greater numbers than at any time in the past.

title: Speculum Group's Forte: WellPlayed New Music
description: Not many years ago, a commonly heard complaint among composers was that modern music, when it was played at all, tended to be played sloppily. Conservatively trained musicians often treated the performance of new music as a tiresome duty at best, and at worst as a penance.

title: Atlantic City Aides Lose Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to review the extortion convictions of three former public officials of Atlantic City. The court let stand a ruling of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Third District in Philadelphia upholding the convictions of former Mayor William Somers, Arthur Ponzio and Karlos R. LaSane.

title: Value of Human Body Also Hit, by Inflation
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 15 (AP)Like many other things nowadays, the material that makes up the human body has risen steeply in price.

title: ARSON DESTROYS GAY ACTIVIST SITE
description: An early morning fire set by an arsonist yesterday destroyed the offices and social center of the Gay Activists Alliance in former firehouse at 99 Wooster Street, in the SoHo section.

title: People in Sports
description: James (Doc) Counsilman, swimming coach at Indiana University, was named yesterday as head coach of the 1976 United States men's Olympic swimming team. Counsilman coached the highly suscessful men's team in the 1964 Games. At Indiana, his squads won six National Collegiate titles in a row until beaten by Southern California last March by a point.

title: Part of Highway Closed After Detour Causes Jam
description: The northbound lanes of the West Side Highway were jammed with cars and then temporarily closed to traffic last night as once again the northbound section of the roadwaythe Henry Hudson Parkway  between 72d Street and 96th Street was closed.

title: Suspect's Case in Police Slaying Typifies Revolving Door Justice
description: On Sept. 30, the day of his arrest in the murder of a policeman whose dismembered body was found on West 79th Street a few days earlier, Julio Vasquez was to have been in court on a gun charge that had been hanging in legal limbo for nearly eight months.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An Essex County Superior Court judge, Irving I. Kimmelman, ruled that opponents of a raise for Newark's Mayor and City Council members need the signatures of 5 per cent of the city's 133,000 registered voters to put the issue on a referendum, and not 15 per cent as contended by lawers for Newark. Under a measure approved by the Newark City Council Oct. 2, the Mayor's salary would go to $50,000 from $35,000 and the Councilmen would get $23,500 instead of $15,000. The ruling may be appealed.

title: Surprising Seals Skate In Tonight
description: Occupying unexpected positions in the standing, the lastplace Rangers play the secondplace California Golden Seals tonight at Madison Square Garden, starting at 7:35 o'clock.

title: Reform on Wall Street
description: Gloom returned to Wall Street yesterday after four days of soaring stock prices, but of far greater longrange significance to the securities industry and the investing public is the comprehensive stock market reform legislation now up for final passage by the House of Representatives.

title: A's Win, 32 to Lead Series, 21
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 15 California's first World Series moved 440 miles up the coast tonight and the Oakland A's promptly struck the first blow by defeating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 32, and taking a lead of two games to one.

title: Life for Israelis in Border Settlement Is a Tense Vigil
description: ZARIT, Israel, Oct. 14The powerful mercuryvapor lights switch on at sunset, casting a cold, bluish light on the barbedwire fence that encircles this village 200 yards from the Lebanese border.

title: A's Win, 32, to Lead Series, 21
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct 15California's first World Series moved 440 miles up the coast tonight and the Oakland A's promptly struck the first blow by defeating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 32, and taking a lead of two games to one.

title: Investors Concerned Over Pike Toll's Fare
description: When the New Jersey Turnpike Authority opens public hearings in Jersey City tonight on a proposed 37 per cent average toll increase, one of the most forceful voices to be heard will be that of the financial community.

title: Shortage of Materials Easing
description: Many of the shortages of basic materials that plagued the nation's economy a year ago are dissipating as a result of the business slowdown and new production capacity added by industry.

title: Independent Arts Agency Wins Backing of Beame
description: Mayor Beame endorsed a program yesterday that would establish a Cultural Affairs Administration on an equal footing with other muncipal agencies.

title: Student Body Officer Listed Mistakenly in Drug Raid
description: As a result of incorrect information from the police, Karen Robinson, vice president of the Fairleigh Dickinson University student body, was listed in The New York Times as being among 25 students arrested in a drug raid on dormitories and residences on the Madison campus of the university Monday morning.

title: $5Million in Israeli Bonds Bought by Business Leaders
description: The purchase of $5million in State of Israel bonds by more than 500 business, civic and leaders of Jewish organizations was announced last night at a Plaza Hotel dinner honoring Alan King, the entertainer.

title: SOVIET WARNS U.S. ON TRADE STRINGS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15Contending that it is high time that there should be a clear understanding, Soviet leader Leonid

title: Publishers Offer Views About Campaign Books
description: Prominent figures in the book world expressed differing notions yesterday of what constituted ethical practice in pubdishing political candidates biographies.

title: Ashe, Borg and Nastase Score in Spanish Tennis
description: BARCELONA, Strain, Oct. 15 (AP)Arthur Ashe, Tile Nastase of Rumania and Biorn Borg of Sweden advanced to the third round of the Spanish open tennis tournament today.

title: Col. John Griffith, Aviator In 2 World Wars, Dies at 75
description: Col. John S. Griffith, an aviator who served in the two world wars, died Monday at Central Suffolk Hospital, Riverhead, L. I. He Was 75 years old and lived on Ogden Lane, Quogue, L. I,

title: World Bank Gets Iran Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (Reuters)  The Iranian Government is lending the World Bank $150million, the bank announced today. The bank, formally known as the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, and Iron have signed an agreement for a loan maturing in 12 years at 8 per cent annual interest.

title: 4 IN CABINET LOSE IN KENYA ELECTION
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 15The voters of Kenya, in a oneparty election, have turned out several Cabinet ministers, ineluding Foreign Minister Njoroge Mungai, who had sometimes been discussed as a successor to President Jomo Kenyatta.

title: Bradley Dewey, 87, Dies; Industrialist and Inventor
description: Bradley Dewey, the chemical engineer, industrialist, inventor and management man, whose work ranged from developing gas masks and synthetic rubber to sealants for metal cans and plastic film for packaging food, died on Monday at his home in New London, N.H. He was 87 years old.

title: 22 Columbia and Barnard Students Form Coed Commune to Replace Inhuman Dorm
description: Twentytwo Columbia and Barnard students have estabfished a coed communal residence hall to replace what one of the students called the cold and inhuman experience of dormitory life.

title: Marshall Possible Starter
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 15 The question, was put tonight by Richie Ashburn, once a National League bitting champion, an original Met, a broadcaster and now a sports writer in Philadelphia. It was adressed to Manager Walt Alston, whose Los Angeles Dodgers had just lost the third game of the World Series, falling behind, 21, in the fourofseven competition.

title: Blacks Reported Resigned To Giving Vote to Carey
description: Blacks have no choice, Basil A. Paterson was saying the other day by way of explaining why he thought the overwhelming number of blacks who vote would cast their ballots for Representative Hugh L. Carey.

title: DOMESTIC FLIGHTS REPORTED DELAYED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) Sporadic slowdowns by dissident air traffic controllers, runway construction problems and weather conditions have resulted in delays in flights to several major cities in recent weeks, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Paul J. Sherwin, former New Jersey Secretary of State, yesterday began serving a sentence of one to two years at Trenton State Prison. Mr. Sherwin and two others had been convicted of bribery charges in connection with a state highway contract.

title: Stadium Authority: A's Will Not Shift
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 15  An ironclad contract prevents the A's from being moved out of Oakland, or from being sold to anyone who would move them out, before 1987, the OaklandAlameda County Coliseum, said today.

title: Knicks Near Getting McGinnis and Carter for Monroe
description: The Knicks are on the verge of putting George McGinnis into a New York uniform next season, Fred Carter immediately and sending Earl Monroe to the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Police in Jersey Believe They Killed a Bystander
description: ROSELLE, N.J., Oct. 16More than 200 friends and relatives, including his wife and seven children, attended a funeral service today for 45yearold Lucius Harrell, who the police say was an innocent bystander apparently killed by police bullets during an attempted holdup of an Elizabeth tavern early Friday morning.

title: FOES FAIL TO CURB BILL ON MIGRANTS
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15State legislators and farm owners from South Jersey were unsuccessful today in an 11thhour bid to defeat or modify a migrantlabor reform bill that would hold the state's produce growers responsible for the activities of their crew leaders.

title: Wilson Cuts TV Campaign And Carey Lists a Deficit
description: Governor Wilson's campaign aides reported a cut of onethird in their candidate's televisioncommercial budget yesterday, and Representative Hugh L. Carey listed a net deficit of $360,000 in his gubernatorial campaign.

title: Chile Tells Why Reporter For Times Was Barred
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 15 (UPI)A spokesman for the Chilean Government said today that Jonathan Kandell, a correspondent of The New York Times, was denied permission to enter the country because of his tendentious dispatches in previous visits.

title: Bridge: Bids at Pan Am Tournament Recall Paul Stern Theory
Fire Damages Wallace Home
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 15 (AP)A fire erupted at the Governor's Mansion today, damaging large portions of the main floor and injuring a worker and a mansion attendant. The fire was caused, officials said, by an electrical spark igniting fresh paint striping on the walls of the mansion lobby.

title: Grain Purchasers Asked To Exercise Restraint
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (Reuters)All foreign buyers of American feed grains and soybeans are being told to restrain their purchases or run the risk of having to deal with tighter export controls, United States officials said today.

title: ADRIAN E. JACOBS
description: Adrian E. Jacobs, who retired in 1966 as executive vice president of the MillmastersOnyx Corporation, chemical manufacturer of 99 Park Avenue, after 50 years with the company, died yesterday at his home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 78 years old and lived lit 2030 Arrowood Drive, Scotch Plains, N. J.

title: Islanders Set Back Canadiens
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 15 It was a replay of last Wednesday night in Montreal, but the Islanders gave it a new ending tonight as they defeated the Canadians, 63, before a crowd of 11,479 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: After having threatened the oil producers to lower prices, our President has appealed to the consumers to conserve. Neither group, however, is easily persuaded. The task of cutting use of energy is left to rising prices, and expediency remains the rule.

title: HOUSE LETS STAND VETO OF A CUTOFF OF AID TO TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The House of Representatives today failed to override President Ford's veto of a stopgap spending measure that would have cut off United States military aid to Turkey.

title: City Arts Projects Require 71 Steps, Start to Finish
description: To build something new with city aid, arts institutions move through the equivalent of a giant 71step board game with municipal officials, according to a detailed outline in the report of the Mayor's Committee on Cultural Policy.

title: Aid Efforts Falter in a Town in Chad Where Breeze Is a Hot Gust of Sand
description: FAYA LARGEAU, Chad, The United States Air Force cargo plane bringing a load of sorghum, droughtrelief aid, to this Saharan oasis made a low pass over the landing strip before touching down, briefly frightening camels in caravans that were crossing and goats that were grazing.

title: Sprawling Seoul Market Is Filled With Goods, Not With Buyers
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThe Southgate Market here resembles the set for a movie about Asia sprawling, crowded, noisy, smelly, a warren of stalls packed with all sorts of food, clothes, pots and pans, watches, toys, even CocaCola.

title: CARTER REVISES ITS FRASER OFFER
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores, Inc., of Los Angeles announced yesterday that it had revised the terms for the purchase of a large block of shares of the House of Fraser from Scottish and Universal Investment, Ltd., of Glasgow, Scotland. Under the new terms, Carter will buy immediately 21.26 million shares of Fraser common stock, representing 17.5 per cent of the total outstanding for approximately $60million in cash, or $2.83 a share.

title: Divided Democrats Face Major Fight At Charter Convention in Kansas City
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Democrats preparing for their national charter conference at Kansas City in December have begunto take sides, as if by an unshakable habit, across the great divide that has split the party since the start of the Vietnam debate nearly a decade ago.

title: Monzon Is Honored
description: PANAMA CITY, Oct, 15 (AP)  Carlos Monzon of Argentina, the world middleweight champion, was voted fighter of the month today by the World Boxing Association. He beat Tony Mundine of Australia in the title fight.

title: Kissinger Returns After Progress With Algerians
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Secretary of State Kissinger returned to Washington tonight, ending a Middle East tour in which he worked out plans to restore AlgerianAmerican relations in a few weeks, discussed with President Houari Boumediene of Algeria ways of easing the oil crisis and conferred with King Hassan II of Morocco.

title: Josephthal Branch Closed
description: A London branch of Josephthal & Co., the New York brokerage firm, has been closed, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday.

title: Wright's 66 Takes Long Island Golf
description: CEDARHURST, L. L, Oct. 15Jimmy Wright of Inwood won the Long Island Professional Association championshp today wth a fouroverpar 66, over the 6,207yard Rockaway Hunting Club course.

title: Gains Early in Session Erased For Grain and Soybean Futures
description: A surge of buying dominated earlymorning trading in grain and soybean futures markets y.esterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, followed by enough. profit taking and commercial selling to cut prices back to Monday's levels at the close.

title: A Heart Implant Pacemaker
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 15 (Reuters)Surgeons at the Medical College of Virginia Hospital have implanted a pacemaker in Louis B. Russell Jr., the world's longest living heart transplant patient. Mr. Russell, 49 years old, an industrial arts teacher from Indianapolis, was reported in satisfactory condition. The pacemaker is to help Mr. Russell's heart pump blood. The heart was implanted on Aug. 24, 1968.

title: Canada Bank Cuts Prime
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 15 (Reuters)The Royal Bank of Canada said today it had lowered its, prime rate to 12 per cent from 12, effective immediately.

title: TOM PHELAN
description: MAYWOOD, N. J., Oct. 15 (UPI)  Tom Phelan, former chief facilities engineer for the NBC television network, died Sunday at Jersey Shore Medical Hospital in Neptune. He was 66 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WORKHOUSE. By Norman Longmate. 320 pages. Illustrated. St. Martin's Press. $8.95. Though some of Charles Dickens's most pathetic scenes take place in Victorian workhouses, it would appear that, for once, he understated his case. According to Norman Longmate's elaborately documented study, The Workhouse, that institution exceeded even Dickens's imagination. Lumping together infants, children, adults, the elderly, the infirm, the insane and the delinquent, the Victorian workhouse was a kind of garbage can, reluctantly supplied by society, as a place to throw away the lives of anyone answering to the dread description of pauper.

title: S.E.C. Plans Phase I Of Joint Tape Friday
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that Phase 1 of the Consolidated TransactionReporting System would begin Friday regardless of New York Stock Exchange objections to the uniform shortselling rule recently promulgated by the agency.

title: Legal Aid to Open Office for Elderly, City Conference on the Aging Is Told
description: The first Legal Aid Society office here devoted specifically to problems of the elderly will be opened in Brooklyn within two weeks, a spokesman for the society told the first of five citysponsored conferences on the elderly yesterday.

title: $1Million Asked Injuries In S.L.A. Food Giveaway
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 15 (UPI)A 50yearold Alameda, Calif., woman has asked $1million in damages for injuries suffered during a People in Need food distribution program set up last winter on a demand by the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: Satellite Launched in Kenya
description: MALINDI, Kenya, Oct. 15(AP)Italian technicians using a United States rocket launched a British scientific satellite today from a Kenyan offshore firing platform. A British spokesman said that the 286pound UK5 satellite was in orbit and performing its assigned function of studying Xrays from space. The firing platform for the fourstage Scout rocket is a converted oil rig in Ngwana Bay, 22 miles north of Malindi, an Indian Ocean resort.

title: The Election Trends
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Two trends are noticeable in this year's Congressional and gubernatorial elections: A preference for Democratic party candidates but a lack of enthusiasm for most candidates in both parties. So fax the election has been a doter.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Chemist, 2 Astronomers Are Given Nobel Prizes
description: An American chemist whose ideas and techniques made possible the wide range of plastics and other synthetic polymers in common use today and two British astronomers who have investigated the distant reaches of the universe received 1974 Nobel Prizes yesterday.

title: TV Networks, in a Shift, Air Ford at His Request
description: The television networks yesterday reversed a decision not to carry the President's economic address before the Future Farmers of America in Kansas City after having received a formaland some felt, irritatedrequest by the White House for live coverage. When the request was made, by Ron Nessen, Mr. Ford's press secretarry, all threenetworks immediately complied.

title: About New York
description: At the entrance to the Dr. Connie Guion wing of New York Hospital there are three doors. The one on the left says, Women, while the one on the right says, Men. The one in the middle, however, says, Doctors.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER DIP
description: Profit taking trimmed the recent advances on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market yesterday as volume declined slightly.

title: 12 BUS LINES SEEK MORE STATE HELP
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15  The Byrne administration warned New Jersey legislative leaders here today that 12 of the state's subsidized commuters bus lines would stop running Nov. 1 unless they were promised swift financial aid.

title: Rockefeller Asks Two Congress Panels For Immediate Hearing on Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller asked the chairmen of the Senate Rules Committee and the House Judiciary Committee today to convene immediate hearings on his nomination because it is being tried in the press...without my having the opportunity to present all the facts.

title: Oil Promises, Promises
description: Secretary of State Kissinger's latest mission to the Middle East has elicited yet another expression of intent by Saudi Arabia to work for a lower world oil price. This time the pledge came from King Faisal himself, and the King encouraged Mr. Kissinger to publicize the Saudi intentions. This sounds like good news for those who groan under the heavy burden of the fourfold increase in the price of crude oil over the past 12 months: as the world's largest single exporter of oil, Saudi Arabia is in a position to be a leader.

title: All Quiet A Giants' Wife Is Sad, Too
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 15 Charley Winner wanted to make one thing perfectly clear: he wasn't talking about last Sunday's disaster.

title: Stolen Refuse Truck Rams Bus, Injuring Driver in Brooklyn
description: A young man calling himself Black Samson and shod in black boats adorned with pink polka dots, stole a Sanitation Department truck loaded with garbage yesterday in the Bedford  Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and subsequently rammed it into a Transit Authority bus.

title: Bars Trap Home Owner
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 (Reuters) A 29yearold man, trapped inside his home by metal bars he had installed on his windows to keep out burglars, was burned to death when his house caught fire early today. Shepard Mouldin wa sovercome by smoke while trying to force apart the bars with.his hands.

title: Summary of the Various Actions Taken by the United States Supreme Court on Opening Day of Its Term
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: An Airplane Maker Denies Accusations of Bribery
description: PARIS, Oct. 15The DassaultBreguet Aviation Company has denied accusations in the Netherlands that it had attempted to bribe two members of the Dutch Parliament in efforts to win a major warplane contract, and said it had been subjected to a campaign of calumnies.

title: 3 Winners of Nobel Prizes
description: After the news conference yesterday morning and before the celebration party last night, Dr. Paul J. Flory sat by his pool in Portola Valley, Calif., trying to relax.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PLAINFIELD  While the Plainfield High School athletic field was being renamed Hub Stine Field in pregame dedication ceremonies last Saturday morning, 82yearold Herbert Alpheus (Hub) Stine kept choking back tears. He had spent 37 years at Plainfield High, had developed one of the best high school athletic complexes in the nation, had coached without pay, had taken the teams' sweaty uniforms home for his wife to wash and had secured scores of college scholarships for his boys. The memories came rushing back as the speakers took turns at the microphone.

title: HOUSE VOTES REPEAL OF THE NOKNOCK LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) The controversial noknock law that allows Federal agents in some instances to search residences without first identifying themselves was voted down today by the House.

title: Ford Energy Plan: Conversion of OilFired Plans to Coal Held Unrealistic by Experts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15President Ford's proposals for saving large amounts of oil by converting the nation's oilfired power plants to coal or by replacing them with nuclear power are not being taken very seriously by many knowledgeable industryofficials, the Federal Power Commission, the Environmental Protection Agency and Congressional committees dealing with energy problems.

title: INDUSTRY OUTPUT UP IN SEPTEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Industrial production rose 0.3 per cent to 125.5 in September, largely because of the settlement of strikes in several major industries, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: People and Business
description: The international banking empire of Michele Sindona has begun unraveling in recent weks but the Sicilianborn financier evidently has no intention of merely standing by. Mr. Sindona, the largest shareholder in the Franklin New York Corporation, whose subsidiary, the Franklin National Bank, was declared insolvent last week, issued a statement yesterday through his soninlaw in Milan, in response to an arrest warrant issued for him last week by a Milan magistrate. The warrant charged irregularities in 197071 in the Sindonacontrolled Banca Uni.

title: Kings Play Capitals to 11 Standoff
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 15 (AP)A rookie goalie, Ron Low of Washington, survived 16 shots by the Los Angeles Kings in the final period tonight and preserved a 11 tie for the Capitals in their National Hockel League home opener. Low faced 33 shots for the game.

title: EMMONS BRYANT
description: Emmons Bryant, vice president of Thomson & McKinnon, Auchincloss & Kohlmeyer, Inc., investment brokers, died Monday of a heart attack at his home, 1172 Park Avenue. He was 64.

title: Iranian Denies Talk of Cutting Oil Prices
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 15A ranking Iranian official said today that Iran has no intention of reducing basic oil prices.

title: Notes on People
description: After 26 years of marriage there are few surprises, but President Ford managed to spring one yesterday as he and his wife, Betty, celebrated their 26th anniversary at the White House before he left on a twoday speaking tour.

title: The Elegant HandMeDown Lures Hundreds of Shoppers
description: Mary Lindsay donated a long woolen evening suit, Betty Ford sent a blue and white silk scarf, Arlene Dahl gave a glittery beaded gown and Helen Gurley Brown contributed a flowered silk caftan. Not to mention the hundreds of less famous women who thinned out their wardrobes and contributed designer clothes, furs and accessories as well as luggage, household items and children's wear.

title: FRANK KOWALSKI, 66, AN EXCONGRESSMAN
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Oct. 15 (AP)Frank Kowalski, a former Democratic Representative from Connecticut and a retired Army colonel, died Friday of a heart ailment at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived here.

title: $200Million Amtrak Bill Passed and Sent to Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) The House passed today and sent to President Ford a bill authorizing $200Million for Amtrak, the national passenger train corporation, for the current fiscal year.

title: R.P.I. Picks Hockey Aide
description: TROY, N. Y., Oct. 15 (AP) Louis Frigon was named today as assistant hockey coach at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Frigon succeeds John Marks, who resigned to play hockey professionally.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COCKTAILTIME CANARY Hildegarde Loretta Sellmake that anythingbutplain Hildegardeis back and Town Hall has her. Caressing her keyboard, waving that lace hankie and cooing songs in a Continental flavored intimacy nobody else has quite surpassed, the Wisconsin born Hildegarde today will daintily kick off Town Hall's new season of 60minute concerts of jazz, cabaret, dance, poetry and pop. Time: 5:45 P.M. Admission: $2.50.

title: Advertising Irish Agency Opens Office Here
description: New York may be the Big Apple of the entire advertising world but few independent foreign agencies have offices here.

title: Denenberg Gets Post
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (AP)Herbert S. Denenberg's stormy three months as Public Utility Commission counsel ended today when he was named special consumer adviser to Gov. Milton J. Shapp. The appointment, announced by Mr. Shapp and Mr. Denenberg at a news conference, will be interim until Mr. Denenberg takes a seat on the Public Utility Commission, the Governor said.

title: Business Briefs
description: All told, foreign governments transferred a total of 2,006,308 ounces of, gold from the Federal Reserve's vaults here in that period.

title: PHILLIPS LINKS TO PIMP AFFIRMED
description: A second prostitute yesterday repeated previous testimony at the retrial of William R. Phillips, a suspended police officer, that she had overheard the defendant and a slain pimp loudly arguing over money demands.

title: Bronx Library Silence Broken By Protest on Branch's Closing
description: The silence rule was not enforced at the Baychester branch of the New York Public Library at Coop City yesterday morning as community leaders and 200 residents of the. Bronx housing development gathered for a loud protest on the planned closing of the library, one of three neighborhood branches scheduled to be closed on Nov. 18.

title: Industrial Sugar Will Be Increased By Utah Idaho Co.
description: Industrial and wholesale sugar prices were raised yesterday by a number of large producers, portending a rise in price not only in sugar purchased in supermarkets but also in numerous products utilizing the product as a sweetener. The Amstar Corporation upped the price of industrial sugars by $2.25 per 100 pounds, raising the extrafine sugar price to $44.45 per 100 pounds and that of bulk to $44.05 for 100 pounds. It also raised the wholesale price of grocery bagged sugar to $27.27 from $25.68 for twelve 5pound bags and to $27.21 from $25.62 for the six 10pound bags.

title: Dow Chemical Net Climbs 129.3% in Third Quarter
description: The Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday that its thirdquarter profits were ups 129.3 per cent and ninemonth net was 100.4 per cent ahead of last year.

title: ALLEGED MOB FIGURE BALKING AT INQUIRY
description: Court papers submitted yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn maintained that Anthony Abbatemarco, reputed underboss of the Joseph A. Colombo Sr. Mafia family, was psychologically unfit to testify before a Federal grand jury.

title: High Level of DDT in Sheep Sets Off Monitoring Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) The Agriculture Department said today that it had begun a monitoring program in three Northwestern states after high DDT levels had been detected in some sheep that grazed on sprayed rangeland.

title: In Modern Poland
description: WARSAWThe visit to the United States by Edward Gierek, First Secretary of the Communist party, has been watched with great interest here. I am certain that it has turned new attention to Poland and the character of its people.

title: Inflation Is an Oft Told Tale At Big Frankfurt Book Fair
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany It's not a very good year to be a first novelist, said James Price, managing editor of Penguin Books, Ltd., summing up what seems to be a widely shared feeling, born of economic uncertainty, at the Frankfurt Book Fair this week.

title: Rams Bench Hadl, Give Harris Shot
description: The Los Angeles Rams, consensus choice of writers last month to win the Super Bowl this season, changed quarterbacks yesterday following a weak offensive display in the team's 176 loss to Green Bay Sunday. To the bench goes John Hadl, the 34yearold who was the most valuable player in the National Conference last season, and from the wings comes James L. Harris. The name is familiar around Buffalo if not everywhere else. Harris was the first black to begin a National Football League season as a regular at quarterback. That was with the Bills in 1969. He lasted two games and seldom played again, being signed as a free agent by the Rams last year.

title: WARNING IS GIVEN ON NEW SINAI
description: A top Federal transit official warned yesterday that it could easily take an extra five years beyond the 1981 target date to finish the Second Avenue subway if the city used its Federal transit aid largely to meet operating deficits.

title: CHARLES MERRITT, LAWYER, 70, DEAD
description: Charles W. Merritt, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord, died yesterday at his home, 11 Warren Road, CrotononHudson, N. Y. He was 70 years old,

title: BIG SPANISH PLANT HAS TOUGH CHOICES
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct, 15  Spain's biggest industrial plant, the SEAT automobile works, is confronted, like the rest of the country, with the problem of navigating between a political system trying to perpetuate itself and a leftist opposition trying to bring it down.

title: Gun Goes Off Accidentally And Injures IND Rider
description: A woman subway rider was shot in the thigh early yesterday when a pistol in the pocket of a man sitting across from her accidentally discharged as the train lurched into a station in the Bronx, the Transit Authority Police reported. They said that Esther McKay, 30 years old, of 333 East 181 Street, the Bronx was reading) a book on the IND D train at about 12:40 A.M. when she suddenly felt a sharp pain in her right thigh.

title: HAROLD WILLIAMSON
description: Harold Long Williamson, retired United States Foreign Service officer, died Sunday at his home in Bedford Hills, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Japan's Nuclear Ship Returns to Port
description: TOKYO, Oct. 15After drifting for weeks in the North Pacific, Japan's first nuclearpowered ship was finally allowed, back in port today.

title: TV: Rubinstein in Great Performances Series
description: Music, any kind of music, is still a tricky commodity for television, The speakers in most TV, sets cannot begin to compete with the sound quality of even modest stereo reproduction systems. And strictly in visual terms, standard practices are generally limited. From a rock musician plucking on a guitar to the string section of a symphony orchestra sawing away on their violins, the threshold for visual fatigue is discouragingly low.

title: Nigh Court Studies FundShare Resale
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The Supreme Court agreed today to consider the Government's complaint that the mutual fund industry is illegally restricting the resale of its shares and fixing resale prices.

title: Steele Asks Laws to Cut Connecticut Electric Prices
description: HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 15United States Representative Robert H. Steele, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, today proposed an 11point package of legislation aimed at reducing the rapidly rising cost of electricity in the state and at reforming the Public Utilities Commission which is charged with overseeing Connecticut's electric companies.

title: Harvard and Cornell: Like Old Times
description: The best attended HarvardCornell football game in Cambridge, Mass., since the terrible thirties is in prospect Saturday. More than 30,000 spectators are expected at Harvard's big cement League horseshoe on the banks of the Roundup Charles. This will be the key Ivy League football game this week since unbeaten Princeton, the only team with two league victories, will be spending the afternoon at home for a non conference game with Colgate. The other two unbeaten elevens in the Ivy LeagueYale with perfect record in one start rind Pennsylvania with one triumph and a tie  seem to have assignments of only passing interest. The Elis take on Columbia in their big bowl in New Haven while the Quakers meet Lafayette in a nonleague affair at Easton, Pa.

title: A POLICE CAPTAIN TELLS OF BRIBERY
description: Police Capt. Daniel Tange, for almost two years the commander of an elite 73man unit assigned to arresting major heroin dealers, testified yesterday as a witness at a departmental hearing for Detective John F. McClean, charged with accepting bribes to hinder the prosecution of narcotics dealers.

title: Poet, 55, Is Named Editor Of Soviet Literary Monthly
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15 (UPI)The editorship of Novy Mir, the liberal literary monthly, has changed hands, a literary source said today.

title: Two Editors Quit Macmillan in Protest
description: Two editors resigned from Macmillan, Inc., yesterday to protest staff and publishing cuts, and substantial picketing was expected today at the Third Avenue offices of the huge publishing concern in the wake of the sudden dismissal Monday of some 200 Macmillan employes here.

title: 658 Calves Killed At Wisconsin Site In Protest on Costs
description: CURTISS, Wis., Oct. 15 UPI) Members of the National Farmers Organization, protesting against rising feed costs and lower prices for farm products, slaughtered more than 650 calves today and dumped the carcasses into a big trench.

title: Ship Heading for Gulf Site To Burn Chemical Waste
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 15 (UPI)An incinerator ship carrying 4,200 tons of chemical wastes is heading for a site 135 miles south of Galveston, Tex., where the cargo will be burned in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: FEDERAL TROOPS ASKED FOR BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Oct. 15Gov. Francis W. Sargent requested President Ford today to send Federal troops into Boston and mobilized two National Guard military police units totaling 400 men in the wake of renewed racial violence in the schools.

title: Mavros Quits to Campaign
description: ATAENS, Oct. 15 (Reuters)Foreign Minister George Mavros reigned today to concentrate on the parliamentary election campaign of his Center UnionNew Forces party.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Political and Security Committee10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DISPUTE SNAKING CREEK COLLEGES
description: ATHENS, Oct. 15A controversy is building up in the nine Greek universities over the fate of more than 100 professors accused of collaborating with the military junta that governed for seven years.

title: CODD EASES RULES FOR SUSPENSIONS
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd issued a new set of internal departemntal regulations yesterday, overturning an automatic suspension rule that had been a foundation of the department's anticorruption machinery since shortly after the police scandals of the mideighteennineties.

title: Trifecta Pays $11,437
description: SALEM, N. H., Oct. 15 (AP)  An unidentified woman won $11,437.20 on a $2 bet at Rockingham Park tonight by correctly picking the first, second and third place finishers in the fifth race. It was the largest trifecta payoff in state history.

title: Rockefeller Brother Says He Asked Aid Of Nixon in Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Laurance S. Rockefeller, said today that he sent a telegram to President Nixon in August, 1972, urging Mr. Nixon to allow Eastern Airlines, in which the Rockefellers have an interest, to acquire Caribair, an airline based in Puerto Rico. Seven months later, Mr. Nixon reversed a decision by the Civil Aeronautics Board and approved the acquisition.

title: Strauss Predicts Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) Robert S. Strauss, Democratic national chairman, predicted today that his party would win at least four and maybe five new Senate seats, 28 to 32 House seats and three or more Governorships in the Nov. 5 elections.

title: PAN AM AND T.W.A. PLAN ROUTE CUTS, DIVIDING MARKETS
description: Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines have tentatively agreed on a plan to halt headtohead competition on thousands of miles of air routes between this country and points in Europe and Asia.

title: Serzes Standing, Figures
description: (Players' share based on first four games.)

title: A JERSEY INQUIRY ON RONAN BACKED
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15The New Jersey Assembly today voted for a legislative investigation of Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson. A. Rockefeller's $550,000 gift to Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: SALES OF AUTOS SHOW OCT. 110 DIP
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15Newcar sales in early October were off 15.5 per cent from last year, a performance auto analysts, called mediocre since it marked, the first 10day period in which all the 1975 models from the Big Three makers were on sale.

title: Foreign Companies Aided AntiAllende Strikers, Chileans Say
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The widespread strikes that set the stage for the military coup that overthrew the late President Salvador Allende Gossens were partly financed by, funds provided by companies based in Mexico, Venezuela and Peru, according to leading Chilean businessmen.

title: France Scores 12  Nation Energy Unit
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 15 France today told her Common Market partners that she believed the proposed 12nation energy consumers group was the wrong instrument to solve Europe's energy problems. She said that it could conflict with efforts of the nine members of the Common Market to create their own energy policy.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Culture Means Money, City Told in Report
description: New York reaps as much of a financial as an esthetic reward from the cultural activities that take place in the city, according to a wealth of unusual statistics in the report of the Mayor's Committee on Cultural Policy.

title: Javits Scores U.N. Role for Palestine Group
description: United States Senator Jacob K. Javits last night denounced the decision of the United Nations General Assembly to give the Palestine Liberation Organization a role at its meetings and accused Ramsey Clark of having espoused the creation of a West Bank Palestine state, a charge that Mr. Clark denied.

title: FEDERAL TROOPS ASKED FOR BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Oct. 15Gov. Francis W. Sargent requested President Ford today to send Federal troops into Boston and mobilized two National Guard military police units totaling 400 men in the wake of renewed racial violence in the schools.

title: Teachers in 4 L.I. Communities End Their SevenDay Walkout
description: MERRICK, L.I., Oct. 15A sevenday strike by teachers in the BellmoreMerrick Central High School District ended today when both the Board of Education and the union accepted factfinders' recommendations for a new twoyear contract.

title: McGovern Favoredin Long, Grueling Race With War Hero
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., Oct.For nearly two years now, since he lost the Presidency in a landslide to Richard M. Nixon in 1972, Senator George McGovern has been running for reelection in South Dakota.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Three decades ago, Charles Ives's Piano Sonata No. 2, the Concord, was so fearsome a work that only John Kirkpatrick, who gave its premiere, dared play it in public. Times have changed. Between now and Sunday, which is the 100th anniversary of Ives's birth, the Concord will have five performances by five pianists in five different New York halls.

title: To Ease a Cash Squeeze, Both Bills and Notes Will Be Auctioned
description: The Treasury, which finds itself in a temporary cash squeeze, announced plans yesterday to sell $2.5billion in bills and notes later this month. The size and timing of these offerings came as no surprise to Gov. ernment securities dealers, but most of them had not been thinking in terms of a note sale.

title: New York Car Race Flagged Down
description: The Grand Prix of New York remains an idea whose time has not come.

title: Pakistani Leader Reports Baluchistan Rebellion Ended
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 15 (AP)  Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto said today that organized tribal insurgency against the Government in the troubled province of Baluchistan has come to an end.

title: Sports Nevers Briefs
description: ST. LOUIS,. Oct. 15 (UPI)Busch Stadium, pride of St. Louis and home of three professional sports teams, has termites, it was revealed today. Its owners said there were termites in the offices, that the area under the stands behind home plate was infested, and that the bugs might even have worked their way through the ground to the Astroturf. Glennon F. Walsh, executive vice president of Civic Center Redevelopment Corporation, owner of the 8yearold stadium, described the problem as negligible. However, Chester W. Robinette, president of an extermirating, company called in after the first discovery of termites, wasn't so sure. He estimated that as many as 5 million termites may be in the stadium. Some termites could have worked their way up to the Astroturf playing surface, he said. The stadium is built chiefly of concrete and steel. Most of the woodwork is in offices. The baseball Cardinals, football Cardinals and soccer Stars play their home games Busch Stadium.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The New Mail
description: On Sept. 19, a pipe shop in Palo Alto, Calif., dispatched two identical packages by thirdclass mail. Each contained eight ounces of the same tobacco, addressed to recipients on the same floor in an office building in midtown New York. One of these twin missives was delivered on Oct. 2, the second on Oct. 12.

title: Independent Arts Agency Wins Backing of Beame
description: Mayor Beame endorsed a program yesterday that would establish a Cultural Affairs Administration on an equal footing with other municipal agencies.

title: Confrontation by Byrne
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15Gover nor Byrne, according to aides has decided to force a Senate vote on extending to cam paigns for party primaries the public financing of guberna torisl election campaigns, which goes into effect in the next state election.

title: Ford Gets Bill to Put $8Billion In Depressed Mortgage Market
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 15 (AP)  Congress sent President Ford legislation today to put as much as $8billion in Federal funds into the depressed housing market, making it easier for homebuyers to find credit,

title: Funds for Goldberg Book Channeled Via Law Firm
description: Funds to finance a corporation that produced a Rockefellersponsored derogatory biography of Arthur J. Goldberg were channeied by a Rockefeller family adviser through distinguished Philadelphia law firm, the adviser and the firm said yesterday.

title: Nassau Report Urges Creation Of Offtrack Betting Next Year
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct., 15A report uriging the establishment of offtrack betting in Nassau County next was submitted today to the New York State Racing and Wagering Board for approval.

title: LUTHERANS FOCUS ON WOMEN'S ROLE
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15 (UP)The American Lutheran Church, the ninthlargest Protestant body in the United States, ended a weeklong convention today by voting to establish an organization to give women a greater voice in church affairs.

title: To Wilson, Carey Victory Would Be State Disaster
description: Governor Wilson said yesterday, that Representative Hugh L. Carey as Governor would be a disaster for the State of New Yorle, who would triple state income taxes for people earning more than $25,000 a year.

title: Liddy Released on $5,000 Bond; Lawyers Pledge He Won't Flee
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) G. Gordon Liddy, a member of the original Watergate breakin team, was released, from jail today on a $5,000 bond after his attorneys promised a Federal judge that he would not flee the country.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1974

title: Mr. Fanfani's Task
description: The significance of Amintore Fanfani's attempt to form his fifth Cabinet and Italy's 37th postwar Government is clear: If he fails to reconstruct a viable ministry from the ranks of Italy's democratic parties, the next Government is virtually certain to include representatives of the most powerful Communist party in the Western world.

title: Pottsville Club Burns
description: POTI'SVILLE, Pa., Oct. 15 (AP)The Pottsville Club, historic landmark referred to in several John O'Hara novels, burned today. Officials said arson might be involved. O'Hara, a native of Pottsville, referred to the town in many of his books as Gibbsville, and the Pottsville Club as the Gibbsville Club. The club was founded in 1888 and was a favorite dining spot for the wealthy.

title: Chase Is Cleared On Bank in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Oct. 15The Chase Manhattan Bank obtained formal permission today from the Egyptian Government to open a commercial bank in Cairo in a joint venture with the National Bank of Egypt, according to Guenter H. Neubert, Chase's representative here.

title: Olympic Stocks: 7 Had Splits
description: A chart published in these columns yesterday listed 15 common stocks held by the United States Olympic Committee and gave the prices of those stocks on Oct. 31, 1972, June 30, 1974, and Sept. 30, 1974. No adjustment, however, was indicated for stock splits and stock dividends paid on seven of the issues during 1973 and 1974.

title: Justices Decline to Settle Espionage Wiretap Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  A divided Supreme Court declined today an opportunity to resolve the question of whether the President can legally order wiretaps when he finds them necessary to detect and counter foreign espionage.

title: Justices Decline to Settle Espionage Wiretap Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. A divided Supreme Court declined today an opportunity to resolve the question of whether the President can legally order wiretaps when he finds them necessary to detect and counter foreign espionage.

title: Chemist, 2 Astronomers Are Given Nobel Prizes
description: An American chemist whosel ideas and techniques made possible the wide range of plastics and other synthetic polymers in common use today and two British astronomers who have investigated the distant reaches of the universe received 19741 Nobel Prizes yesterday.

title: Reynolds Appeal Allowed
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Oct. 15  A Supreme Court judge granted permission today to Reynolds Guyana Mines, Ltd., to defend itself against the governments claim of $3.5million, half of a levy imposed on the American company's 1974 bauxite production.

title: RIDER'S PROFESSORS VOTE FOR A STRIKE
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15 (UPI)A decision to strike Rider College tomorrow morning was voted by 120 professors today, after an 11thhour negotiation session failed to produce the teachers first contract or resolve wage issues.

title: Siamese Twin Girls Dead; Had Respiratory Trouble
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 (AP) Siamese twin girls, joined at the chest and abdomen, died tonight.

title: EHRLICHMAN BLAMES NIXON; COUNSEL SAYS THAT CLIENT WAS DECEIVED AND MISLED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15John D, Erhlichman opened his defense at the Watergate cover up trial today by placing the blame for the coverup and for his own disputed actions squarely upon former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Fugitive Is a Most Wanted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) The F.B.I. added Melvin Dale Walker to its list of 10 most wanted fugitives today, He broke out of the Lewisburg, Pa., Federal prison last. Aug. 10 after he and several other inmates commandered a garbage truck at gunpoint, the F.B.I. said. He bad been imprisoned for burglaries, bank robberies and escapes.

title: SOLOMON GREENFIELD
description: Solomon C. Greenfield, a retired teacher and administrator who spent more than 50 years with the New York City Board of Education, died Saturday of cancer at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 78 years old and lived at 44 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

title: 2% PAY BOARD CUT MAY BE RESTORED
description: The 2 per cent portion of a pay increase blocked by the FeFederal Pay Board in 1972 may pay increase blocked by the vice employes of New York City, according to a decision of the Office of Economic Stabilization in Washington.

title: Zaire Authorizes 3 Travel Tours for Title Fight
description: In an apparent response to lagging sales and complaints about high price tour packages for the rescheduled Muhammad AliGeorge Foreman heavyweight championship fight on Oct. 29 (New York time), the Government of Zaire has stepped into the travelarrangements picture.

title: G.S.A. Official Defends Document Center on Coast
description: LAGUNA NIGUEL, Calif., Oct. 15A Government official said today that the huge newt federal document center here instead of being a white elephant, ranked as one of the best deals ever made by the Government.

title: Nomination Overturned In fast Harlem District
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday annulled the nomination of Angelo Del Toro and ordered a new primary election Oct. 25 for the Democratic party's candidate in the 72d Assembly District in East Harlem.

title: Three Die in Chelsea Fire Near Site of '73 Disasters
description: CHELSEA, Mass., Oct. 15 (UPI)  Three persons were killed early today and several firemen were overcome by smoke when fire swept a threestory brick rooming house near Chelsea Square, lust one day, after the first anniversary of the great Chelsea fire. Twentysix persons fled to safety.

title: Oklahoma Crude
description: By bulldozing six sound buildings that it owns on Wall Streetalmost half the north side of the famous canyon between Pearl and William Streets, covering more than an acre of landthe Cities Service Company of Oklahoma will save about $280,000 a year in taxes. Demolition will also avoid maintenance and liability costs on property that Cities Service has deliberately emptied of tenants to make it more attractive to speculators. Since no buyer has materialized and vacant land is even more attractive than empty buildings, these structures will now be torn down.

title: Congress Clears Auto Safety Measure Eliminating Seat Belt Interlock System
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The House of Representatives passed and sent to the White House today compromise legislation that would eliminate the highly unpopular seat belt interlock system on automobiles.

title: CHASE REALTY CITES DEFICIT IN 1ST PERIOD
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, the largest real estate investment trust n the nation, announced yeserday a revision of its earnings for the first quarter ended Aug. 31, to a 3centashare deficit from a 5centashare profit.

title: PAN AM AND T.W.A. PLAN ROUTE CUTS, DIVIDING MARKETS
description: Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines have tentatively agreed on a plan to halt headtohead competition on thousands of miles of air routes between this country and points in Europe and Asia.

title: Dave Anderson
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct 15He grew up on a farm in Hertford, N.C., where his chores with the cows and the crops came first. On a farm you learn to do today's work today, Jim (Catfish) Hunter was saying. You learn to get your job done. His job is baseball now, but his upbringing is perhaps more important to him than ever. Catfish Hunter is involved in a contractual dispute with Charles O. Finley over $50,000 in deferred income that the owner of the Oakland A's allegedly has declined to pay. But the 29yearold righthanded pitcher, who shared the spotlight with Ferguson Jenkins of Texas as the major leagues' leading winner during the recent season with 25 victories, is working to confine the squabbleto the toolshed of his mind. In a rare appearance as a relief pitcher in the World Series opener, his job was to get the final out of the A's 32 triumph. He struck out Joe Ferguson on five pitches. In the third game tonight, his job was to supply the A's with a 21 advantage over the Los Angeles Dodgers. He had a threehit shutout for seven innings, was removed after a home run by Bill Buckner in the eighth but was credited with the 32 victory for his fourth World Series triumph without a loss. Only three other pitchers in World Series history have better Unblemished recordsLefty Gomez with six victories and Jack Coombs and Herb Pennock with five. But none of the others had to cope with Charles O. Finley's distractions.

title: MEXICO ACCEPTS OILPRICE SYSTEM
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15Mexico tonight announced that she will seek observer status in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is a result of important new oil discoveries in the southeast part of the country.

title: CURBS ON ECONOMY URGED BY MANSFIELD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) Fuel rationing and tough controls on wages, prices and profits are necessary to solve the ration's economic problems, the Genate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, said today.

title: Bill to Reform Campaign Funds Signed by Ford Despite Doubts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15President Ford signed with reservations today legislation for the most extensive reform of Federal campaign  financing practices in American history.

title: FORD URGES STEPS TO CURB INFLATION
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 15  President Ford proposed to the nation tonight a series of voluntary measures to fight inflation and save energy. Many of his proposals, including the possible sale of Government bonds, were reminiscent of World War II programs.

title: WESTCHESTER BODY OUSTS PARKS AIDE
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 15The Republican majority on the Westchester County Board of Legislators ousted Joseph Halper today from his post of Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Conservation.

title: F.A.A. SPEEDS RULE ON WARNING ALARM
description: Under prodding from a House committee alarmed about airline landing accidents, the Federal Aviation Administration has agreed to speed work on a proposed rule requiring use of an automatic warning device on all this country's airliners.

title: SHOUTING PARENTS DISRUPT A MEETING
description: A noisy protest by more than 100 parents from School District 1 on Manhattan's Lower East Side disrupted a public meeting of the Central Board of Education in Brooklyn last night, causing board members to adjourn the meeting early.

title: Owner of Bronx Building Injured in Boiler Explosion
description: An explosion yesterday, at a building at 349 East 139 Street, in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx, seriously burned the owner. Four others, including a policeman required treatment for smoke inhalation.

title: 6Foot Bogus Wife Robs Singer's Room While He Showers
