description: Andy Williams was taking a shower at the SherryNetherland Hotel yesterday afternoon, while, according to the police, a 6foottall woman was robbing his rooms after having told a maid, I'm his wife.

title: Effort to End Price Fixing of Milk Is Blocked by Assembly Committee
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15Efforts to repeal New Jersey's 33yearold system for the price fixing of milk suffered a major defeat today when the Assembly Agriculture and Environment Committee blocked release of the bill, thus preventing it from coming to a vote in this legislativc session.

title: Stage: Draina by Brecht
description: Joseph Papp and his Public Theater will always try to be contemporary, even if it means going backward. Now, in this Weimarshadowed autumn of 1974, it offers us the Shaliko Company in Bertolt Brecht's 1930 play The Measures Taken. It opened last night in a very effective cubbyhole of a theater, which I swear I have never seen before, in the Shakespeare Festival's happy rabbit warren of a building on Lafayette Street.

title: Police Open Inquiry Into Death Of Woman and DrugSale Link
description: CLIFTON, Oct. 15The police here were investigating the possibility today that the shooting death of a 46yearold woman on Friday might have been linked to investigations into drug sales in the area.

title: ARMY CURB ORDERED ON CIVILIAN SPYING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP)  After a long controversy, Secretary of the Army Howard H. Callaway has ordered a curb on spying by Army intelligence on United States civilians.

title: Xerox Net Up Slightly
description: The net income of the Xerox Corporation rose by 6.5 per cent to $82million, or $1.04 a share, in the third quarter of 1974, the business equipment company reported yesterday.

title: Austrians Win Tornado Class Title
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 15 (UPI)  Robert Jessenig and Hans Polashmegg of Austria won the Tornado Class world sailing championships yesterday at Waikiki. After seven days Jessenig and Polashmegg had the lowest scores for six of the seven races. The boat with the smallest point total in six races wins the championship. Jessenig's Hastanix led with 37.7 points. Second was Paul Allen of Del Mar, Calif., and Woody Cox, sailing the Rapid Transit System, with 51.1 points.

title: Prison Disturbance Quelled
description: McALESTER, Okla., Oct. 15 (UPI)About 60 Oklahoma State Penitentiary inmates barricaded themselves in a basement of the prison today, but prison guards returned the inmates to their cells peacefully after more than four hours, a spokesman for Gov. David Hall said. The Governor's spokesman said that Roger Webb, the Oklahoma Public Safety Commissioner, told him that corrections personnel were able to handle the situation. He said the inmates took no hostages.

title: Arms Talks Intensified
description: GENEVA, Oct. 15, (Reuters) The United States and the Soviet Union stepped up nuclear arms negotiations here today and agreed to meet again tomorrow instead of Friday in a departure from routine.

title: NEWS INDEX
LEFKOWITZ STRESSES HIS AID TO WORKERS
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz told a tradeunion meeting yesterday that since he became State Attorney General 18 years ago, his office had handled 12,000 workmen's compensation cases and had obtained more than $7million in settlements and back pay.

title: ExSoninLaw Is Indicted In Connecticut In 2 Killings
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 15 (AP)  Murray Gold of New York City was indicted today on two murder counts in the stabbing deaths here of his former wife's parents, Mr. and Mrs: Irving Pasternack.

title: Bryant Park Exhibition Celebrates Idea Of Ending Auto's Domination of Streets
description: Ending the automobile's domination of downtown streets and opening them up for more relaxed human use has been a goal of most enlightened urban planners since the midnineteen  sixties. During that period, planners finally realized that ramming highways through old streets was doing little except bringing the sterility of the suburbs into the city. In fact, the concept of improved plazas, trafficfree zones, and malls now has become such a part of the common wisdom that a set of such proposals has been put together in a special exhibition as a New York City bicentennial project, More Streets for People.

title: CREDIT TIGHTENING WAS VOTED BY FED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (Reuters)  The Federal Reserve Board reported today that its Open Market Committee voted to pursue a slightly more restrictive shortterm monetary policy at its July 16 meeting.

title: UNION URGES COURT TO AID ON BACK PAY
description: The Textile Workers of America said yesterday that it was seeking court action to enforce payment of back pay claims estimated at $20million for 500 former employes of the Darlington Manufacturing Division of the Deering Milliken Corporation.

title: 35 Homeless in Fire
description: A threealarm fire spread through four storefronts on Lee Avenue near Ross Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn last night, forcing the relocation of 35 tenants. Witnesses told fire officers inevestigating the blaze that they heard an explosion before the fire broke out shortly after 8 P.M.

title: Exacta Is $6.60 For '74 Low Here
Grandparents Get Equal Status With Others in ChildCare Cases
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that grandparents who had custody of their grandchildren in New York State were eligible to receive the same socialservice benefits as would other relatives or nonrelatives caring for the children.

title: Country Music Honors NewtonJohn and Milsap
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 15Olivia NewtonJohn and Ronnie Milsap, two performers who never worked the cramped stage of the Grand Ole Opry, took major honors in last night's Country Music Association's awards, the first ever held at the lovely new Opry building.

title: Mr. Ford and the Pardon
description: When President Ford appears voluntarily before a House Judiciary subcommittee tomorrow to explain why he prematurely granted Richard Nixon an unconditional pardon, his questioners should not allow the commendable Presidential gesture to overshadow the need for specific answers.

title: Plan for City U. Tutors In Clemency Setup Falters,
description: A proposal that City University hire those seeking amnesty, as tutors to meet requirements for clemency was given little chance last night of going into effect.

title: ISRAEL DENOUNCES PALESTINIAN VOTE
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 15Israel denounced today as illegal the decision of the United Nations General Assembly to invite the Palestine Liberation Organization to participate in debate on the issue of Palestine.

title: Rockefeller Brother Says He Asked Aid Of Nixon in Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Laurance S. Rockefeller said today that he sent a telegran to President Nixon in August 1972, urging Mr. Nixon to allow Eastern Airlines, in which the Rockefellers have an inter est, to acquire Caribair, an air line based in Puerto Ricd Seven months later, Mr. Nixon reversed a decision by the Civi Aeronautics Board and approved the acquisition.

title: Deserter Center Is Closed In Shift to Indianapolis Site
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 15 (AP)  Thirtynine military deserters were transferred from Camp Atterbury to Fort Benjamin Harrison at Indianapolis today, closing out the joint clemency processing center at the central Indiana military post.

title: Fishing for Bass in the Hudson, and Other Fun
description: Fishing may sound like a parentandchild pastime that has to be reserved for holidays at the lake. But fish, as improbable as it may sound, are actually running in the Hudson River.

title: Life for Israelis in Border Settlement Is a Tense Vigil
description: ZARIT, Israel, Oct. 14The powerful mercuryvapor lights switch on at sunset, casting a cold, bluish light on the barbedwire fence that encircles this village 200 yards from the Lebanese border.

title: S.C.L.C. Closing in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 15 (UPI)The Atlanta chapter of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, victimized recently by a $10,000 burglary, is shutting down because of some $12,385 in debts.

title: Exacta Is $6.60 For'74 Low Here
A Distant Achilles' Heel
description: JERUSALEMOne bit of good news Secretary Kissinger brought to Israel at the start of this week was that United States production of tanks and armored vehicles was being considerably increased and would soon rise to three or four times the rate prevailing two years ago.

title: Attendance Is Down as Peace Returns to Franklin K. Lane
description: Attendance was off but classes were held without major incident yesterday at Franklin K. Lane High School in Brooklyn, the scene of recent fights between white and minority students.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SYLVIA L. RAVITCH
description: Sylvia Lerner Ravitch, a trustee since 1952 of the New School and chairman since 1973 of the board of overseers of the affiliated. Parsons School of Design, died Sunday in Beth Israel Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived at 955 Fifth Avenue.

title: Elizabeth Trapier, 81, Dead; An Expert on Spanish Art
description: Elizabeth du Gu Trapier, an authority on Spanish art, died yesterday in Hightstown, N. J. She was 81 years old.

title: M.T.A. Now Sees a 60c Fare In 1975 Unless U.S. Gives Aid
description: David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, produced new deficit estimates yesterday to show transit and bus fares soaring to 60 cents in 1975 if there was no Federal subsidy.

title: St. Regis Dividend Up
description: St Regis Paper Company increased the quarterly dividend yesterday on its common stock to 35 cents a share from 30 cents. The dividend is payable Dec. 1, to shareholders of Nov. 4.

title: LANDLORDS STAGE OILPRICE PROTEST
description: About 50 apartmenthouse landlords tried unsuccessfully yesterday to enter the midtown offices of the Saudi Arabian mission to the United Nations as part of a protest against sharply increased heatingoil prices.

title: A Former Counsel In Congress Linked To Book on Goldberg
description: A former counsel for a House Judiciary subcommittee and Senate subcommittee on Investigations was identified yesterday as the sole officer and stockholder of Literary Productions, Inc., the corporation that arranged for the Rockefellerfinanced derogatory biography of Arthur J. Goldberg.

title: Swindlers and Evictions Add to Woes of ScandalTainted LowIncome Federal, Housing Program in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Oct. 16The man said he was a real estate agent. He had a key to the neat little brick house on a peaceful, leafy street in northwest Detroit. So Jacqueline Thomas had no rea. son to Suspect that anything was wrong.

title: PreElection Mood: There's No Time for Dreams
description: DETROIT  There was a time in his life when, Dewey David Burton chased the American dream.

title: A's Get No Respect But Enough Breaks
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 16 After three straight 32 decisions, two won by Oakland, the Los Angeles Dodgers thought the A's were lucky and the A's thought the Dodgers were terrific.

title: Carey Pledges Fast Action On Governmental Reform
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey, the Democratic Liberal mididate for Governor, promised yesterday that if elected he would seek major changes in governmental operations during his first 100 days in office.

title: 100 Leaders Join In a Fight to Save Library in Village
description: Outraged by a budget cut ordered by Mayor Beame that led to a decision to close their neighborhood library, 100 Greenwich Village community leaders met at the Jefferson Market Library last night to organize a fight to save the library, which many of the leaders had fought to bring to the neighborhood seven years ago.

title: PENTAGON REPLIES ON PERIL TO OZONE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The Defense Department estimates that an allout nuclear war would significantly deplete the protective layer of ozone in the stratosphere but not to the point of endangering the continuance of life on earth.

title: DEPRESSION IN '75 SEEN FOR JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Oct. 16After a year of gloomy assessments on the Japanese economy, the gloomiest of all was delivered today by Eimei Yamashita, Vice Minister of International Trade and Industry and one of the, four most influential men in the prestigious Japanese bureaucracy.

title: O'Dwyer Assails Clinton Zoning Plan
description: Invoking the name of the man who built the Erie Canal, City Council President Paul O'Dwyer criticized yesterday a zoning scheme that he said would inhibit waterborne commerce in the Clinton area on the West Side.

title: STATE IS LIMITED IN GIFTS INQUIRY
description: The lawyer who is heading a state investigation into the propriety of gifts and loans made by former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller said yesterday that his sevenmember committee had only very limited powers.

title: U.S. WILL AWAIT ENERGY RESULTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton said today the Administration would wait three or four months to see how well voluntary energy conservation works before deciding whether tougher measures were needed.

title: A's Beat Dodgers, 52, For 31 Lead in Series
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 16 California's first World Series threatened to become a short one tonight when the Oakland A's overpowered the Los Angeles Dodgers, 52, and moved to within one game of their third straight championship.

title: Books of The Times
description: Books should be found guilty or innocent according to their own merits, I suppose, and so it probably isn't fair to burden these three novels with the onus of their being the first works to be published by the Fiction Collective, a new, cooperative notforprofit publishing venture In which writers (as opposed to entrepreneurs) will finance, edit and promote their own work. Still, something has to be eaten if the pudding is to be proven, so why not the first three spoonfuls? Besides, I find it impossible to resist responding to a manifesto for the collective that was written by Ronald Suckenipk and appeared in The Guest Word column of The New York Times Book Review of last Sept. 15. For in his manifesto, Mr. Suckenick announced that The publishing industry can no longer support quality fiction and that serious fiction . . of literary merit . . . [and] inventiveness can flourish only where commerical pressures are not applied. And as easy and fashionable as it may be to toss off such an assertion, it is worth examining in the light of the evidence.

title: 250 Missing in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Oct. 16 (AP)About 250 persons were missing after bandits shot up a motor launch yesterday 150 miles north of Dacca and the boat capsized, newspapers said today. The reports, which could not be confirmed officially, said the bandits looted the boat, then fired into the hull with automatic weapons.

title: Notes on People Martha Mitchell Will Get $1,000 a Week for Now
description: In State Supreme Court here yesterday, Justice Manuel A. Gomez awarded Martha Mitchell temporary alimony of $1,000 a week, onethird the sum she had demanded from her husband, John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General. Justice Gcrnez noted that in the last year, in which the Mitchells have been separated, Mr. Mitchell had spent about $51,000 for Mrs. Mitchell's maintenance, and it is the court's view that pending the trial of the [legal separation] action, the defendant's obligations should continue at such a rate. Justice Gomez said that Mr. Mitchell's gross income totals $5,281 a week. He awarded Mrs. Mitchell's lawyers $3,500 in counsel fees, instead of the $35,000 they had asked, an amount Justice Gomez termed comdivorced from reality.

title: Death in Venice Will Test OperaticLiterary Waters
description: The Metropolitan Opera marks two firsts tomorrow nightthe season's first new production and the first American performance of Death in Venice, Benjamin Britten's adaptation of the Thomas Mann novella. Two notable aspects of Death in Venice are the problem of translating a literary classic into opera and the multiple roles given to one singer.

title: Major Depression Predicted by 51 %, Gallup Poll Says
description: The Gallup Poll said yesterday that its latest nationwide survey indicated that the American people did not share President Ford's optimism regarding the nation's economic outlook.

title: Purchase Campaign to Secede Is Doomed by Vote in Harrison
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Oct. 16Residents here voted overwhelmingly tonight to establish a Village of Harrison with the same borders as the town, a move intended to bar the Purchase community from seceding by forming its own village.

title: Ford Stays at Landmark
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 16 (UPI)The Hotel Muehiebach added President Ford today to its list of 12 Presidents to stay overnight at the Missouri landmark. The Presidential party used the 11thfloor penthouse Presidential Suite made famous by the late President Truman. It was in that suite that Mr. Truman learned that he had won the 1948 election over Thomas E. Dewey.

title: MORE PRODUCERS CUT COPPER COSTS
description: More copper companies lowered prices yesterday following cuts announced on Tuesday. Sales companies of the Kenncott Copper Corporation and the Anaconda Company, along with the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company and the Magma Copper Company, a subsidiary of the Newmont Mining Corporation, reduced electrolytic copper cathodes to 75 cents a pound, a 4centapound cut. This followed the initial action by the Phelps Dodge Corporation on Tuesday.

title: A's Beat Dodgers, 52, For 31 Lead in Series
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 16 California's first World Series threatened to become a short one tonight, when the Oakland A's outmaneuvered the Los Angeles Dodgers, 52, and moved to within one game of their third straight championship.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS WIN FREE FLIGHTS
description: The nation's airlines have bowed to pressure by dissident air traffic controllers, who have delayed hundreds of airline flights recently, and restored a plan allowing the controllers to make eight free flights on commercial jets annually.

title: 40% IN POLL RATE FORD FAIR OR POOR
description: Only 30 per cent of 1,005 Yew Jersey residents asked to rate President Ford's performance since taking office have cermed it excellent or good, according to a poll conducted by the Eagleton Institute of Rutgers University. Forty per gent scored the President only fair or poor.

title: FORD'S TAX PLAN IS CALLED UNFAIR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16A leading liberal economist told Congress today that President Ford's proposed tax program was questionable on equity grounds.

title: The Need to Know
description: WASHINGTONThe Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Wilbur Mills, who has long been regarded as one of the hardest working members of Congress, is now the butt of jokes. A minor driving violation uncovered an apparent peccadillo, and the Wags of Washington snicker: The strippers of the. Mills grind slowly.

title: Advertising
description: Judging everyone else's reading habits by your own can be one of the great dangers in media selection. It can also be harmful to a publication that has a good readership, but not in ad agency circles.

title: Irish, Illinito Honor Legends
description: Notre Dame and Illinois will commemorate the 50th anniversaries of two famous football games played Oct. 18, 1924, during ceremonies at South Bend, Ind., and Champaign, Ill., Saturday. The Irish will celebrate the day Grantland Rice christened the Four Horsemen backfield that beat Army, 137, in the Polo Grounds that day. The Illini will stage Red Grange Day, honoring the dedication game of Illinois Memorial Stadium when the Galloping Ghost scored five touchdowns, passed for one and ran for 402 yards against Michigan.

title: A Real WIN Program
description: Salesmanship is not going to rescue this country from either inflation or recession. Regrettably, in his televised address from Kansas City this week, President Ford revived advertising slogans of World War II to dramatize the urgency of the nation's economic ills, then passed to the American people the primary responsibility for triumphing over the inadequacy of Government programs to cure them.

title: SOVIET QUESTIONS COST OF U.N. FORCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16The Soviet Union is objecting to the cost of maintaining United Nations buffer forces between Israeli and Egyptian troops in the Sinai Peninsula, and between Israeli and Syrian troops on the Golan Heights.

title: Barge Sinks Off Alaska
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 16 (UPI)An abandoned barge loaded with urea and liquified ammonia sank in 20 fathoms off Kekur Point 70 miles south of Sitka early today. The Coast Guard said the chemical, used for manufacturing fertilizer, was not enacted to cause any ecological damage.

title: 3 Nominations by Liberal Party Ruled Invalid in Supreme Court
description: The State Supreme Court reversed the City Board of Elections yesterday and declared invalid the Liberal party's nominations of three candidates on the ground that the party had not filed the proper document authorizing the candidacies.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A strike by 93 per cent of the faculty and a simultaneous student boycott virtually brought classes to a halt on the 3,500student Rider College campus near Trenton. The walkout followed a breakdown in yearlong negotiations in which 120 members of the American Association of University Professors sought to gain a 13,5 per cent increase in salaries, a greater voice in college administration and a closed shop.

title: British Workers' Club Allowed to Bar a Black
description: LONDON, Oct. 16Britain's highest court ruled unanimously today that a workingmen's club in industrial Lancashire was entitled to apply a color bar on membership since it is a private place.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Beame Leads 2,000 Mourners At Sullivan Rites in St. Patrick's
description: Ed Sullivan's friends picked their way across rainsoaked sidewalks yesterday morning to pay their last respects to the 73yearold columnist and television host, who died here Sunday of cancer.

title: Movie Documents Auction of Scull's Art
description: Many people are going to enjoy "America's Pop Collector: Robert C. ScullContemporary Art at Auction," but I especially recommend it to publishers and movie makerssince this documentary makes the book or film industries look pure and pastoral in comparison to the art world. The movie, which was "conceptualized and co-ordinated" by E. J. Vaughn and John Schott, and filmed by Susan and Alan Raymond, opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art and will run until Tuesday.Once you've witnessed the October, 1973, auction of 50 works of art from the collection of the taxi tycoon Robert Scullthe sale brought him $2,240,900you may be glad that you don't paint, sculpture, own, sell, or buy contemporary artwhich appears to addle many who come in contact with it. In fact, the movie makes the audience feel superior to those on screena sensation that's always pleasing, whether it's justified or not.The sale included works by Willem de Kooning, Frank Stella, Robert Rauschenberg, Franz Kline, Barnett Newman, Larry Poons, Andy Warhol and James Rosenquist. When asked why he chose to sell his possessions, Mr. Scull answers repeatedly that the exhibition at Parke Bernet was the only way that he could see these paintings, sculptures and constructions together; he emphasizes the lack of space in his apartment, remarking that many pieces had been in storage. (Apparently, he had to part with these things in order to look at them.) He adds that owning art is "a different kind of high." Others criticize him for loving publicity, though he's also credited for his adventurousness in buying difficult works when they weren't popular, and Robert Rauschenberg stresses that the Sculls helped artists at a period "when there wasn't enough activity to support them."Meanwhile, some are distressed at seeing these works leave the country. And although the question of artists' royalties isn't discussed in this film, it does raise the issue of a collector's making such gargantuan profits when the artists receive none. (Mr. Scull, who dodges queries about art as an investment, gets quite huffy about profits; he insists that he's raising the artists' price for their future work.) Throughout, he comes through as jovial and benign; though the film mocks him, he's allowed to appear likable.In this documentary, the works of art are definitely treated as objectsthey're filmed very casually, without perception or respect. It's hard to tell if this was totally intentional  if the film makers deliberately presented paintings and sculptures in the spirit of the market place, or if they were also somewhat insensitive. However, it's gripping to see the stuff handled about as tenderly as the airlines treat your luggage: a Larry Poons painting slips while it's being hung, and two Jasper Johns beer cans are shoved around as though they came straight from Ballantine's. All in all, there's a sense of no deposit, no return.Some of the best parts of the film are the preparations for the auction; the ushers are instructed to "be forceful without being rude" and to make people sit in their assigned seatswhich were "thoroughly researched" in light of most individuals' bidding records. The film is a very amusing putdown of an occasion that doesn't inspire reverence. Of course it's an easy target. But since the artists' talent or diligence are made to seem irrelevant, our laughter at those who were enriched by their work can refresh us in fierce economic times.

title: U.S. Begins Its Dairylea Investigation, Focusing on Federal Lunch Program
description: The United States Department of Agriculture has started an inquiry to determine if the adulteration of millions of quarts of milk by the Dairylea cooperative from 1967 through 1973 had any adverse effects on the federally financed school lunch program and other Federal programs in which dairy products are used.

title: Aluminum Gian Has 82% Gain in Quarter
description: Afflicted by rockbotto prices and sagging demand ur til just recently, the Aluminur Company of America yesterday repprted an 82 per cent gain thirkquarter earnings.

title: Perennially Ailing Kerala Shows Hint Of Gains Against the Problems of India
description: TRIVANDRUM, India  In the morning radical demonstrators sit beneath parasols and nap outside the white stone secretariat building in this tropical corner of South India. At midday children surge into the streets to protest a decrease in school holidays and an increase in examinations. By dusk fishermen and peasants peer into the narrow bookshops decorated with photos of ChairMao and Lenin.

title: Astronomers Film Biggest Object Yet
description: Dutch radio astronomers have photographed the largest object yet discovered in the universe. They used a multiple. antenna system of the type that won a Nobel Prize in Physics this week for Sir Martin Ryle, head of a radio astronomy group at Cambridge University in England.

title: Berridge Memorial Set
description: A memorial service for Dr. William A. Berridge, who was the economist of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, will he held tomorrow at 3 P.M. lat the Congregational Church in South Egremont, Mass. Dr. Berridge, who died Sept. 24 at the age of 81, was the author of Purchasing Power of the Consumer and a developer of the Federal Government's index of employment.

title: PRICE RISE SHOWN IN SUGAR FUTURES
ExPolitician Convicted
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) Oct, 16 (AP)Gerald Dressner, a former police sergeant, has been convicted in connection with the possession and sale of confiscated heroin.

title: Abrams Charges G.O.P. Chiefs Plan to Raise Mortgage Rates
description: Robert Abrams, the Democratic candidate for State Attorney General said yesterday that there were growing indications that Republican leaders of the Legislature planned to call a special session after Election Day to raise mortgage rates or abolish mortgage controls entirely.

title: Jail Riots Sweep Ulster; Women Release Hostages
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, Oct. 17Prison riots and other disorders have swept Northern Ireland since Tuesday night in apparent protest against the policy of detaining terrorist suspects without trial.

title: FORD TALK FOUND TO DRAW CRITICISM
description: Public reaction around the country to President Ford's appeal for voluntary measures to fight inflation suggests that Americans are already doing with less and resenting it more.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: Mills Says He's Still Embarrassed
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 16 (AP)Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, said today he was still embarrassed about his encounter with Washington Park police nine days ago and said I felt like I was high during the incident.

title: Dow Drops by 16.11 On Bad Oil News
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday for the second consecutive session in less active trading as bearish economic developments depressed the market. The Dow Jones industrial liaverage dropped 16.11 points to close at 642.29, its low for the day. Its high for the day Was set at 1:30 P.M., when the average was off 2.74 points at 655.66. Yesterday's loss in the Dow was the largest since Aug. 23, when it fell 17.83 points.

title: Independence?Idea Is New Inside a Black Slum in Angola
description: LUANDA, Angola  Indeed pendence? a young unemployed black asked, in this city's vast slum district. A black and white coalition? Our own Government?

title: Apparel Industry Shows Biggest Rise In Debt Among Bankrupt Businesses
description: Apparel retailers, producers and textile companies had the biggest increase in debts among bankrupt businesses of any American industry in the first seven months of 1974.

title: F. T. C. STAFF ASKS DRUG PRICE ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  A confidential staff report has recommended that the Federal Trade Commission invalidate state laws and regulations that prohibit the advertising of retail prices of prescription drugs.

title: I. J. ALEXANDER
description: I. J. Alexander, a writer and advertising man, died yesterday at New York Hospital of cancer of the liver. He was 69 years old and lived at 350 West 55th Street.

title: Bystander's Shooting Tied To Police in 2d Radio Car
description: ELIZABETH, Oct. 16Preiminary investigations into the shooting death of an innocent bystander early last Friday by the police at the Midtown Tavern where a holdup was in progress indicates that patrolmen in a second radio car responding to the scene fired the fatal shot, Police Director Joseph Brenner said today.

title: President Gets Drug Bill Repealing NoKnock Law
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP)I A compromise drugcontrol bill containing a repeal of the controversial noknock law was, passed by the Senate and sent to President Ford today.

title: A Night in the Lives of John Aubrey
description: Why is Brief Lives, which opened last night at the Booth Theater, so absolutely enthralling? It really has no right to be. It is a onecharacter play about a dirty, rambling, inconsequential 17thcentury gossip.

title: Connecticut, New York in OTB Link
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 16Connecticut and New York officials signed an agreement today that will permit offtrack betting parlors to operate in Connecticut with closedcircuit television from five New York race tracks.

title: CONGRESS LIMITS TURKEY AID ANEW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Despite warnings of another Presidential veto, Congress approved legislation today that would immediately cut off military aid to Turkey if she shipped any American equipment to her forces on Cyprus.

title: Rise in U.S. Exports To Soviet Predicted
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 16  The United StatesSoviet trade and economic council, winding up its annual meeting here, predicted today that American exports to the Soviet Union in the 197680 period, which encompasses the next Soviet fiveyear plan, would total $9billion.

title: FacultyStudent Strike Halts Rider College Classes
description: TRENTON, Oct. 16A strike by 93 per cent of the faculty members and a simultaneous. student boycott brought classes virtually to a halt on the Rider College Campus area here today.

description: Apparel retailers, producers and textile companies have registered the largest increase in debts among bankrupt businesses of any American industry in the first seven months of 1974. Details on Page 71.

title: Judge Travia, 63, Is Resigning From U.S. Court to Seek Rest
description: Judge Anthony J. Travia, saying he wanted a little rest an more time for his family, announced yesterday his intenLion to resign from the bench of the Federal Court for the EasternDistrict District of New York at the end of November.

title: Dog World Enlisted to Save Power
description: Measures that the dog show fraternity can adopt to help fight inflation and conserve energy were outlined by Tom Crowe in a talk at the Dog Fanciers Club here last week. Crowe, whose organizations superintend more than 400 shows a year, urged shows be made more accessible by having several on one location. Over Labor Day weekend, four clubs used one facility in Gorham, Me., for a fourday circuit, and in Greensboro, N. C., there were three shows in three days, he said.

title: CLARK STEPS UP JAVITS ATTACK
description: Ramsey Clark took his liberaloriented campaign for the United States Senate into conservative Democratic territory in Buffalo yesterday with a steppedup attack on Senator Jacob K. Javits for accepting a $15,000 campaign contribution from former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: Taylor Genesis Feels Nation's Pulse
description: Once upon a time, people found it possible to create dances about America the Beautiful. Paul Taylor, however, has been creating dances about America the Real for several years. Perhaps Watergate would hold fewer riddles if American Genesis, Mr. Taylor's moral view of this country and its history, had wider exposure.

title: Exchange Network Started
description: The Transamerica Corporation's Tafex Systems unit said trading began yesterday on the new nationwide computerized network for foreign exchange dealings. The first transaction was a trade between United States and Canadian dollars at $101.835, down from Tuesday's, closing of $101.840.

description: HARTFORD, Oct. 16In an action brought by two Connecticut consumer groups and United States Representative Ella T. Grasso, two of the state's major power companies were enjoined today from applying higher rates approved last week by the State Public Utilities Commission.sations and her demand that the P.U.C. be abolished for permitting the alleged overcharges.

title: Mexico to Assume Control of Indetel, Subsidiary of I.T.T.
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16The Mexican government announced today that it was assuming control of International Telephone and Telegraph's Mexican subsidiary, Indetel, following several months of cordial negotiations with the United States conglomerate.

title: Rule Out Marijuana Law, Prosecutor Asks Court
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 16 (UPI) Leslie Bradshaw, a Monroe County assistant public defender, has asked an appeals court to rule unconstitutional laws classifying possession of marijuaba as a felony.

title: City Market Basket Rose 1c to $63.17 Last Week
description: After an almost continuous 15week climb, the cost of feeding a family of four here held virtually steady last week, but the city warned consumers about getting their hopes up.

title: C.A.B. Says It Has No Record of Rockefeller Telegram
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Officials of the Civil Aeronautics Board, which maintains comprehensive public records of all its cases, said today they had no record of atelegram sent by Laurance S. Rockefeller to President Nixon urging approval of Eastern Airline's acquisition of Caribair.

title: Evidence of Nixon Guilt Is Foreseen by Jaworski
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) Leon Jaworski, the outgoing special Watergate prosecutor, and his former top assistant, Philip A. Lacovara, said today that substantial evidence would soon be made public showing that former President Richard M. Nixon had played a major role in the Watergate coverup.

title: Maury John, 54, Coached At Drake and Iowa State
description: AMES, Iowa, Oct. 16 (UPI)Maury John, former national basketball coach of the year who led Drake University to the National Collegiate Athletic Association finals in 1969 and former head coach at Iowa State University, died last night of cancer. He was 54 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your editorial prescription for tying up the loose ends of Watergaterelated matters (Oct. 5) seems inadequately considered. You endorse the MondaleBrooke proposal to authorize the special prosecutor to report on Mr. Nixon's role in Watergate. You then find that proposal far superior to others which call for convening major national commission; a prosecutor's study, you say, would make any new commission redundant.

title: Beauty Is Fine, But the Function Is What Matters
description: We were recapitulating recentlyfor the several hundredth timethe scope of the cooking revolution in America during the last two decades. It seems light years since crepes and souffls and wellmade omelets were a novelty. Steak tartare has become a standard businessman's lunch and pesto genovese has almost become commonplace. The beef Wellington syndrome is, Lord willing, happily receding and rank amateurs are turning out quiches, Lorraine or otherwise. Many of today's quiches seem made of almost anything that isn't nailed down, as someone once remarked of cafe society.

title: AZNAYOUR SINGS FAMILIAR LYRICS
description: Charles Aznavour has composed, according to his biography, some 1,000 songs. He may not have composed that many melodies to go with them but this is perhaps immaterial to the faithful who flocked to the Minskoff Theater Tuesday when Mr. Aznavour opened a short season but his longest stay here in many years. (He'll be there until Oct. 27.)

title: C. CLARK STOVER
description: C. Clark Stover, a member of the law firm of Gifford, Woody, Carter & Hays, died Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 31 Warwick Road, Colonia, N. J.

title: 2 State Inquiries Ordered On Nursing Home Control
description: Two state investigations have been ordered into the control of New York nursing homes by an interlocking syndicate of operators who trade properties back and forth, allegedly to increase profits derived from Medicaid payments.

title: John W. Riday Jr., 44, Dies; Officer of Chemical Bank
description: John W. Riday Jr., manager of public relations and an officer of the Chemical Bank, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived at 16 West 16th Street.

title: Colts Acquire Fan for Jet GameYogi
description: A year ago at this time, Yogi Berra was still working at Shea Stadium because the Mets were playing in the World Series. Yogi will be at Shea this Sunday, but he won't be working. Another Berra will be.

title: Goldberg Book Notable Only for Impact Now
description: A photograph of Arthur J. Goldberg looking puffily pompous on its green and black cover, the book appeared during Mr. Goldberg's foredoomed 1970 campaign as the Democratic candidate for Governor of New York against Nelson A. Rockefeller. If the book had any political impact, no one noticed at the time. But now, amid the retrospective political morality of the postWatergate era, the derogatory biography, Arthur J. Goldberg, the Old & the New, suddenly has taken on importance with the concession made by Vice Presidentdesignate Rockefeller last week that Laurance S. Rockefeller, his brother, had invested $60,000 in the book distributed free by the Republicans in the 1970 campaign.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market continued to decline in light trading yesterday for the second straight session.

title: House Panel Will Question Ford About Pardon Today
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16President Ford, in a historic appearance tomorrow morning before a House subcommittee, will be questioned about the discussions, negotiations, legal advice and other circumstances that preceded his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Remington Painting Fetches $175,000, A Record, at Sale
description: A record price of $175,000 for a painting by Frederic Remington was set last night in an auction of Western paintings and watercolors at Sotheby Parke Bernet. The painting, a slambang scene of cowboys pitted against a bucking bronco was bought by the Kennedy Galleries of New York. The same painting was sold in 1893 for $170.

title: State Issues: Crime A Perennial Priority
description: While Governor Wilson and Representative Hugh L. Carey have spoken frequently about the crime problem during the gubernatorial campaign, the winner in November's election will have limited tools to work with in delivering campaign promises.

title: Economic Crisis Besets Producers of TV Series
description: The Hollywood film companies that produce primetime television series are up against an economic crisis, brought on in part by inflation, whose effects may show up on the television screens next September unless the television networks, substantially increase their payments for shows.

title: Penn Dean to Retire
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 16 (AP)  Bernard Wolfman, dean of the University of Pennsylvania Law School, says he will resign in June 1975. He has asked to return to Penn in the fall of 1976 as a member of the faculty.

title: OIL LEASES SOLD ON ROYALTY BASIS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 16 (AP Oil men offered the Government $1.4billion in cash immediately on 149 offshore leases today, plus a buy now, pay later gamble on eight others.

title: RADICAL SURGERY ON BREAST BACKED
description: The American Cancer Society said yesterday that it was con??muing to recommend radical surgery for most cases of breast cancer, despite the preliminary findings of a nationwide study indicating that less extensive surgery may give as good results in early cases of the disease.

title: DEAN IMPLICATES 40F 5 DEFENDANTS IN COVERUP TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16John W. Dean 3d led off the Government's case in the Watergate coverup trial today with three and a half hours of testimony in which he implicated four of the five defendants in the coverup.

title: Networks to Televise Ford's House Testimony
description: President Ford's appearance before the House Subcommittee on Criminal Justice to answer questions about his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon will be televised today, beginning at 10 A.M., by Channels 2, 4 and 7.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DAYS OF YORE The works of two prominent American illustrators reflecting 20thcentury eras will go on display today at the Society of Illustrators, 128 East 63d Street in tribute to J. C. Leyendecker and James Montgomery Flagg. The display will feature 100 original works, 50 by each artist.

title: Avis Trading Ban Ended
description: The ban on trading in the securities of Avis, Inc., ordered on Oct. 1, has been terminated, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday. The ban had been imposed because of unsubstantiated rumors of the possible purchase of I.T.T.'s majority interest in Avis. It was lifted, it was said, because I.T.T. has now announced that is exploring the possibility of selling its 52 per cent ownership of Avis to several prospective purchaseers, including U.A.L., Inc.

title: Nadjari Jury Investigating Concerns Tied to Goldman
description: The chief assistant to Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, disclosed yesterday that a special grand jury was investigating possible criminal activities, including payoffs, by companies be heved to be headed by Irving Goldman, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner.

title: 16 Die in Hotel Fire in Seoul As Guests Leap Out Windows
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Oct. 17 (UPI)A fire swept through two floors of a ninestory downtown hotel here early today. The police said that 16 people had been killed and about 30 injured. Several died leaping from the fourth and fifth foors; others perished from burns or suffocation.

title: Kodak Net Drops by 14% on Rising Sales
Cruise Colt Captures Slow Trot
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 16 How to earn a big purse with a minimum amount of effort could well have been the theme of tonight's New York Sire Stakes trot for 2yearold colts and geldings at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: DEPRESSION IN '75 SEEN FOR JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Oct. 16After a year of gloomy assessments on the Japanese economy, the gloomiest of all was delivered today by Eimei Yamashita, Vice Minister of International Trade and Industry and one of the four most influential men in the prestigious Japanese bureaucracy.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at noon to hear address by President of Portugal.

title: Funds for Cahill Missing, G.O.P. Senator Charges
description: TRENTON, Oct. 16  A Republican State Senator charged today that $80,000 collected for the 1969 election campaign of former Gov. William T. Cahill was missing or unaccounted for.

title: Market Place Pay and Payouts at Macmillan
description: There was anguish at Macmillan, Inc., on Monday when the company suddenly dismissed 200 of some 1,300 employes in this country.

title: Lincoln Keeps Winning Ways
description: At Abraham Lincoln in Brooklyn the tradition of the football team tossing good luck pennies at Lincoln's statue has gone the way of the McDonald Avenue trolley and the Dodgers. But winning football teams are still on the scene at the Coney Island school. The Abes are unbeaten in three games and lead their Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn West Division with victories over Madison and Midwood. Lincoln is working its magic with a firstyear coach and an alljunior backfield.

title: SENATE UNIT BARS NEW HEARING NOW FOR ROCKEFELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Senator Howard W. Cannon, chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, said today that he does not plan to resume hearings on Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller's nomination until after the Nov. 5 Congressional elections, despite Mr. Rockefeller's request for immediate hearings.

title: Sports Today
description: World Series, fifth game, A's vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Oakland, Calif. (TelevisionChannel 4, 8:30 P.M.) (Radio WNBC, 8:30 P.M.)

title: Anker Cuts Choice For Key Assistant To a Field of Four
description: Of the four, two are now district superintendents in the city system, one is an official of the State Education Department in Albany and the other is an assistant superintendent with the Detroit public schools. The new city post will pay about $40,000 a year and will carry the title of senior assistant to the Chancellor.

title: I.R.A.: Known butstill Unknown
description: YOUGHAL, Ireland  Perhaps the most important thing about the Irish Republican Army is that hardly anyone, except its enemies, ever talks about it, although everyone knows about it.

title: Franklin Corps. Files Bankruptcy Petition
description: The Franklin New York Corporation, the holding company that owns the Franklin National Bank, which was declared insolvent on Oct. 8, filed for bankruptcy itself yesterday morning in Federal District Court here.

title: FORD WARNS G.O.P. ON RIVALS SWEEP
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct, 16President Ford, campaigning for Republican candidates in the Middle West, said today that massive Democratic victories in November's Congressional election could create a legislative dictatorship.

title: FREDERIKA FOX DIES; MAGAZINE EDITOR, 72
description: Frederika Fox, a former editor for Vogue, House and Garden, House Beautiful, Good Housekeeping, Harper's Bazaar and Woman's Home Companion magazines, died Tuesday in Connecticut after a long illness. She was 72 years old.

title: P.S.C. Examiner Urges $22Million More for LILCO
description: ALBANY, Oct. 16 (AP) An examiner for the Public Service Commission recommended today that the Long Island Lighting Company increase its electric rates to obtain $22.1million more in annual revenue.

title: Personal Incomes Rose in September
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) Personal income increased $8.8billion in September but for the first nine months of 1974 the booming growth began to slacken, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Few Precedents for President on Capitol Hill Today
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 16When President Ford goes before a Congressional subcomMittee tomorrow, there will be few paths to guide him, for the history of such events holds only murky precedents.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1974
description: International

title: BOND PRICES SUP ON RECENT ISSUES
description: Prices of recent issues in the corporate and taxexempt bond markets closed slightly lower yesterday in moderate trading as participants turned their attention to several large new offerings. In the shortterm Government market prices of threemonth and sixmonth Treasury bills rose slightly during the day, but declines ranging from 1/32d to 9/32ds were evident in the intermediate Government list.

title: CLAUDE CROSS, 80, COUNSEL FOR HISS
description: Claude B. Cross, who was chief counsel for Alger Hiss at the former State Department official's second trial for perjury in 1949, died yesterday of cancer of the throat. He was 80 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass., near Boston.One of Boston's bestknown trial lawyers, who specialized in civil litigation and who had a reputation as a superb crossexaminer, Mr. Cross entered the Hiss case, one of the major courtroom dramas of the coldwar era, in mid1949. At the first trial, which ended in July, 1949, the jury was deadlocked. The chief defense counsel was Lloyd Paul Stiyker.

title: BERT KINDIG DIES; EXU.P.I. REPORTER
description: Bert C. Kindig, retired political reporter for United Press International, died yesterday at his home. He was 63 years old and lived at 281 Pindle Avenue, Englewood, N. J.

title: Brazil Drops PanAm Games: No Funds, Epidemic
description: Money problems and a mounting meningitis epidemic forced Brazilian Olympic officials yesterday to request the cancellation of the 1975 PanAmerican Games scheduled April 26 through May 10 in So Paulo or a change of site.

title: Earnings at E. F. Hutton Up Fivefold in 3d Quarter
description: E. F. Hutton Group, Inc., parent of the brokerage house, said yesterday that thirdguarter earnings rose more than fivefold to $732,000, or 16 cents a share, from $125,000, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose to $44million from $36.3million.

title: Fibak, 19, Upsets Ashe In Tennis at Barcelona
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 16 (AP)Tom Okker and Bjorn Borg, the topseeded players, swept to the fourth round of the Spanish open tennis tournament today, but fifthseeded Arthur Ashe and Brian Gottfried of the United States were toppled.

title: Jail Riots Sweep Ulster; Women Release Hostages
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, Oct. 17Prison riots and other disorders have swept Northern Ireland since Tuesday night in apparent protest against the policy of detaining terrorist suspects without trial.

title: People and Business
description: The United States Controller of the Currency, James E. Smith, has told a group of bank customers in Houston that he feels savings and loan associations should be permitted to broaden their services.

title: Nadjari Jury Investigating Concerns Tied to Goldman
description: The chief assistant to Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, disclosed yesterday that a special grand jury was investigating possible criminal activities, including payoffs, by companies believed to be headed by Irving Goldman, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner.

title: How Many Collegians Can Fit in 5x7x10 Cubicle?
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 16 Students at Yale University have updated the traditional campus diversion of fitting a maximum of human bodies into an enclosed space by taking the sport out of telephone booths and Volkswagens and into the library.

title: Rockefeller Hearings
description: Nelson A. Rockefeller is justified in urging that Senate and House committees proceed with all possible speed to hold open hearings at which the questions raised about his nomination to the VicePresidency can be fully explored.

title: Poem With One Fact
description: At pet stores in Detroit, you can buy frozen rats for seventyfive cents apiece, to feed your pet boa constrictor back hotne in Grosse Pointe, or in Grosse Pointe Park, while the Tree nation of rats in Detroit emerges from alleys behind pet shops, from cellars and junked cars, and gathers to flow at twilight like a river the color of pavement, and crawls over bedrooms and groceries and through broken school windows to eat the crayon from drawings of ratsand no one in Detroit understands how rats are delicious in Dearborn.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: The signs hanging on the locker room wall tell the story: Lawrence 21, Mountain Lakes 20, Morristown 13, Red Bank 11.

title: DEAN IMPLICATES 4 OF 5 DEFENDANTS IN COVERUP TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16John W. Dean 3d led off the Government's case in the Watergate coverup trial today with three and a half hours of testimony in which he implicated four of the five defendants in the coverup.

title: Rockefeller Donates To State G.O.P. Drive
description: ALBANY, Oct. 16 (UP1)Former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller has contributed $12,000 to the State Senate and Assembly Republican campaigns $6,000 to each house.

title: Rep. Roe Is Favored Over 2 Rivals in Lackluster Campaign in the Eighth District
description: CLIFTON, Oct. 16  The campaign to represent the Eighth Congressional District has thus far been generally lackluster and low key, with the Republican challenger, Herman Schmidt, charging that Representative Robert A. Roe, the favored incumbent, refuses to debate him and Mr. Roe, saying his duties in Washington prevent him from going on the circuit.

title: M.T.A. Now Sees a 60c Fare In 1975 Unless U.S. Gives Aid
description: David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, produced new deficit estimates yesterday to show transit and bus fares soaring to 60 cents in 1975 if there was no Federal subsidy.

title: DR. FREUDENFALL
description: Dr. Benjamin Freudenfall, an ear, nose and throat specialist, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 230 Central Park West.

title: Newark Hispanic Council Discharges Its Chairman
description: NEWARK, Oct. 16Charging that no one person could speak for the entire Hispanic community here, the executive corn mittee of the Hispanic Emer gency Council ousted its chairman and announced today that henceforth a new spokesman for the group would be appointed every three months.

title: Sales Display at Metropolitan Is a Showcase for Art Dealers
description: Unaccustomed as it is to giving dealers public mention, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will open Saturday The Grand Gallery, a selling exhibition that turns the museum into a vast show case for dealers' wares.

title: MIXUP PRECEDES 7.3% BOND SALE
description: A syndicate headed by First National City Bank appeared to have won the largest bond sale in the city's history yesterday, but then lost out to its rival syndicate when the city Controller found a mistake on First National City's bid.

title: Con Ed Lists Ways It Says Rates Could Be Reduced
description: The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that it could save its customers almost $500million a year if it were ?? more equitably and had Federal backing of its annual bond sales and if the high cost of foreign oil were averaged with lowerpriced domestic fuel on a nationwide basis.

title: Chesss: Korchnoi and Karpov Level As 13th Game Is Adjourned
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 16After a hardfought timepressure battle, Viktor Korchnoi and Anatoly Karpov adjourned the 13th game of their final candidates, match for the world championship in an anticlimactic level position here in the House of Unions tonight.

title: Morris Twists Knee
description: MIAMI, Oct. 16 (AP)Mercury Morris twisted his left knee during a workout today and was declared doubtful for the Miami Dolphins game against the Kansas City Chiefs Sunday. The running back already has missed three games and saw limited action in a fourth this season.

title: High Tides Around New York
North Trade Center Tower to Get TV Transmitters
description: The longrunning controversy over relocation of television transmitters and antennas to the World Trade Center came to an apparent end yesterday when the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced plans to erect transmission equipment atop its 110story North Tower building.

title: Contract Awards
description: A contract for a project estimated to cost about $160million will be awarded by the American Smelting and Refining Company to a joint venture consisting of Brown & Root, Inc., Houston, and S. N. C., Ltd., Montreal. Brown & Root, a subsidiary of the Halliburton Company, is sponsor of the joint venture, which comprises the design and engineering of Asarco's new electrolytic zinc refinery.

title: Kettentanz Performed By Joffrey
description: Featherheaded ballets like Gerald Arpinos Kettentanz occasionally make good dancing sense, but only when enlivened by the special performing energies of their casts. Tuesday evening at the City Center 55th Street Theater, the Joffrey Ballet wove the slender threads of its choreography into a design evocative of an old Vienna that probably never was but should have been.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given In Eastern Daylight Time
description: AMERICAN ACCORD (U.S. Lines), Havre Oct. 29 and Hamburg Nov. 3; sails from Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Highsmith's Runs Help Hornets Top Fire, 270
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 16 (AP)Don Highsmith scored two touchdowns tonight and led the Charlotte Hornets to a 270 World Football League victory over the Chicago Fire.

title: CONGRESS LIMITS, TURKEY AID ANEW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Despite warnings of another Presidential veto, Congress approved legislation today that would immediately cut off military aid to Turkey if she shipped any American equipment to her forces on Cyprus.

title: Chief's Wife Dies in Leap
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 (UPI)Barbara Baker, 49yearold estranged wife of Bruce Baker, the Portland, Ore., police chief, leaped to her death from the Golden Gate bridge over the weekend, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Million Illegal Handguns Are Reported in the City
description: Despite tough gun laws, there are an estimated total of 1 million illegally possessed pistols in New York City, according to a special state study released today, which recommends that prompt, effective measures he taken to reduce the menace.

title: After 3 Years, Queens Project Agrees to Shift to Compactors
description: After a delay of about three years in complying with Environmental Protection Administration regulations requiring them to convert their airpolluting incinerators to dry compactors, the 2,400apartment Electchester Housing Cooperatives in Flushing, Queens, have agreed to make the conversion.

title: Carter Group and Unit Consent to Order by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The Carter Group, Inc., and its subsidiary, the Utilities and Industries Corporation, consented in New York Federal District Court today to a permanent injunction against further violation of the Investment Company Act.

title: Rangers Tie Seals, 55, on Vickers's Goal
description: The New York Rangers gained a tie on a late Steve Vickers goal last night in game they lost on television.

title: Ford Veto Overridden
description: Congress overrode yesterday for the first time a veto by President Ford and enacted a $7billion railroad retirement bill. [Page 18.]

title: A Filly Bought Before Feature Triumphs
description: Abraham Savin, successful contractor and horse owner, came down from his home in Hartford yesterday and sold a filly. Then he sat among the 12,076 damp customers at Aqueduct and watched his erstwhile possession win the $39,850 Rare Treat that featured the program.

title: Anger Yields Hope In Stirring Songs Of Chilean Group
description: If me must wait for hope, we will wait for it singing. Those words, from Oscar Matoa's Zamba de los Humildes (Song of the Poor), summed up the concert Tuesday night at Hunter College Playhouse by the Chilean folksong group called IntiIllimani. The six singers, each of whom played one or more folk instruments, presented a stirring program of protest music aimed chiefly at the military junta that now rules their country.

title: Women ObservedIn Pictures, and at a Party
description: Carolyn Wechsler, serenely elegant in her printed green velvet pants and chiffon blouse by Dior, marveled at the crowds.

title: William Klopman Sr., 74, Dies; Pioneer in Synthetics Weaving
description: William Klopman Sr., textile executive and a pioneer in the weaving of synthetic fabrics, died of a heart ailment Sunday at his home. He was 74 years old and live in Lloyd Neck, L.I.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: City and 4 Unions to Raise Productivity Jointly
description: Mayor Beame and the leaders of four unions representing 165,000 city workers agreed yesterday to set up a joint productivity program aimed at getting better service without spending more of the city's money.

title: A Rainy Day, and Some Improvised CoverUps
SHOP TALK Handcrafts: Show and Tell
description: Would you believe crocheted hamburgers? A satin station wagon with a tailgate that unzips? Woven buildings? Printed fabric bottles?

title: A's Traumas Linger Despite Triumph
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 16A lineup change, one player's traumatic reaction to it, and an owner's inspirational speech were the main topics among the Oakland A's tonight after their 52 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers had given them a 3.1 grip on the World Series.

title: Britain's Third Parties
description: Britain's election has demonstrated once again how difficult it is for a third force to make an effective national challenge to a wellestablished twoparty system. What is possibleand what happened in Britainis a series of limited challenges by relatively small specialinterest parties which under certain circumstances can have substantial impact on national policy and even on political stability.

title: Pam Am and T.W.A. Sign a Flight Pact On Overseas Service
description: William T. Seawell and Charles C. Tillinghast Jr., the Chairmen, respectively, of Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines, signed an agreement yesterday exchanging rights to serve more than a dozen cities in Europe and Asia.

title: Portuguese Military Select Five New Junta Members
description: LISBON, Oct. 15. (Reuters)Portugal's Council of State approved the appointment of five new members to the governing military junta tonight to replace Gen. Antnio de Spinola and three of his conservative supporters.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: After a delay of about three years in complying with regulations of the Environmental Protection Administration requiring them to convert their airpolluting incinerators to dry compactors, the 2,400apartment Elchester Cooperatives have agreed to make the conversion.

description: At Abraham Lincoln in Brooklyn the tradition of the football team tossing good luck pennies at Lincoin's statue has gone the way of the McDonald Avenue trolley and the Dodgers. But winning foot ball teams are still on the scene at the Coney Island school. The Abes are unbeaten in three games and lead their Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn West Division with victories over Madison and Midwood. Lincoln is working its magic with a firstyear coach and an alljunior backfield.

title: Death in Venice Will Test OperaticLiterary Waters
description: In a word association test, you would probably not automatically link the words opera and literature. A few operatic masterpieces have been built around librettos that are highly literate (Verdi's Otello, Boito's Mefistofele, Berg's Wozzeck and a few more), but most attempts to graft literature onto notes have proved only that, in music, graft does not pay.

title: Let the Truth Come Out
description: The opening days of the Watergate conspiracy trial have already provided proof that former President Richard Nixon, though unindicted thanks to a technicality and immunized by a premature pardon, is in fact the irremovable principal figure in the dock. The prosecution's description of Mr. Nixon's active role in the coverup set the stage for what can only be described as Mr. Nixon's trial in absentia. The stunning charge by defense lawyer William Frates that Richard Nixon deceived, misled, lied to and used John Ehrlichman to cover up his own knowledge and actions propels the legal drama further along toward its central theme the documentation of Mr. Nixon's involvement.

title: GilliganRhodes Contest Fails to SpurOhio's Voters Out of Political Apathy
description: COLUMBUS, OhioJohn J.Gilligan is a quickwitted, politically ambitious 53yearold incumbent Democrat. James A Rhodes; is an ebullient 65yearold Republican longing for a political comeback.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Rail Worker Who Kept Kidnap Ransom on Trial
description: NEWARK, Oct. 16 (UPI)A former railroad brakeman went on trial in Federal District Court today, portrayed by his lawyer as an individual who kept his share of a $50,000 ransom raised for the return of young kidnapping victim because he became terrified and thought it was Mafia money.

title: More Open Government
description: The Freedom of Information Act web passed by Congress in 1966 on the assumption that the public should have broad right of access to information about the workings of its Government. The act hasn't functioned particularly well since it went into effect because of the Federal Government's use of a variety of obstructionist tactics ranging from forcing those seeking information into long and costly litigation to plain old bureaucratic footdragging.

title: Irish, Illinito Honor Legends
description: Notre Dame and Illinois will commemorate the 50th anniversaries of two famous football games played Oct. 18, 1924, during ceremonies at South Bend, Ind., and Champaign, Ill., Saturday. The Irish will celebrate the day Grantland Rice christened the Four Horsemen backfield that beat Army, 137, in the Polo Grounds that day. The Illini will stage Red Grange Day, honoring the dedication game of Illinois Memorial Stadium when the Galloping Ghost scored five touchdowns, passed for one and ran for 402 yards against Michigan.

title: Scientist Sees World Ready for New Mode of Life
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16The ethics of triagea term heretofore used only in times of war or disaster to mean that aid should be given first to those who have the best chance of survivalbecame the underlying theme of discussions at a twoday scientific conference at The Franklin Institute here.

title: People in Sports
description: Arthur Ashe, the AfroAmerican tennis star who has been a strong critic of South African racial policy in the past, will play in that country's. open tennis championships Nov. 14 to 26 for the second year in a row, the tournament director, Owen Williams, announced yesterday.

title: The Presidential Engine: Where the Power Comes From
description: WASHINGTON  Any President's legitimacy results from responsibility for political stability and unity (United) and for imperial expansion (States). A President believes that being concerned with these responsibilities is the very meaning of the law and the Constitution.

title: Congress Overrides Veto and Passes A $7Billion Railroad Retirement Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) Congress overrode a veto by President Ford for the first time today and passed into law a $7billion railroad retirement bill.

title: TEST DRUG ERASES OPERATION MEMORY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) Doctors are experimenting with a memoryerasing drug that can rid a surgical patient of unpleasant recollections about, the operating room.

title: Head of Panel Ford Will Face William Leonard Hungate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Mark Twain's old home town, Hannibal, Mo., is in Representative William L. Hungate's Congressional district. Portraits of Samuel L. Clemens hang in his office. The Representative quotes passages from Twain novels from memory. And, in his public and private manner, Mr. Hungate reflects some of the whimsy and mischief of Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn.

title: Kissinger, Here, Asks a Reconciliation
description: The focus of the annual Alfred E. Smith memorial dinner turned last night from the customary concentration on domestic politics to more global concerns.

title: BIG BOARD TO ASK HEARINGS ON S.E.C.
description: The New York Stock Exchange, fighting a delaying action against Government regulation, disclosed yesterday that it would ask the Securities and Exchange Commission to conduct a full hearing on the agency's right to force price competition on Wall Street by May 1.

title: DOUBT ON U.S. ROLE IN CHILE RECALLED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Ray S. Cline, a former highlevel intelligence official in the Nixon Administration, said today that he was dubious about the ultimate wisdom of the Administration's covert intervention against President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile but that he supported it because he feared snore serious intervention by the Soviet Union.

title: Gianelli Puts Lessons to Work Tonight
description: John Gianelli walked off the Monmouth College court Tuesday night more knowledgeable and aware of what it takes to be the overpowering center the Knicks lack. Gianelli had just finished two days of intensive tutelage under Willis Reed in preparation for the Knicks' season opener tonight at Madison Square Garden against the New Orleans Jazz, the National Basketball Association's newest team.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Team Tennis Franchise to Hartford

title: F.B.I. Arrests 2 in Boston Assault Linked to Busing
description: BOSTON, Oct. 16The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested two white South Bos ton men today, charging their with civil rights violations it the beating of a black man.

title: Screen: No-Karat 'Gold':Adventure Overacted and Overwritten The Cast
description: "Gold," which opened at three theaters here yesterday, is an overwritten, overacted, overdirected, overproduced adventure film that, like many much better, much simpler B-movies of the nineteen-thirties and forties, is about men doing a job. This time the job is goldmining in South Africa, where most of the film was made with, I suspect, lots of cooperation.The story is about an evil plan to control the international price of gold by sabotaging one of the country's largest gold mines by flooding it with an underground sea. The plan is nicked in the last reel by Roger Moore, standing up to his neck in swirling mineshaft waters, with the help of Simon Sabela, who plays his trusted black friend. Because "Gold" has the social conscience of a dim-witted ostrich, you expect Mr. Moore at any minute to refer to Mr. Sabela as a good darkie.In addition to Mr. Moore and Mr. Sabela, the cast includes Ray Milland, as the kind, crusty old white millionaire who owns the mine and is called "Pops" by his bored, beautiful granddaughter, Susannah York, who is married to cold, mean Bradford Dillman, one of the chief plotters along with elegant, detached John Gielgud, an international tycoon not above a little murder. Without exception they all are dreadful.The movie was directed by Peter Hunt, who directed "On Her Majesty's Secret Service," the worst Bond film ever. Mr. Hunt's sense of style is summed up in his decision to photograph the beginning of one scene through a brandy glass. It could have been, of course, that he was only embarrassed by the content of the film and trying his best to hide it.

title: Questions
description: BOSTON, Oct. 16What did Nelson Rockefeller know about the hatchet biography of Arthur Goldberg, and when did he know it?

title: City to Receive $25Million From State for Medicaid
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday that the state would reimburse city hospitals $25million in. Medicaid payments to cover an eightmonth period in the current fiscal year.

title: Wings Top Flames On Rookie Goal, 42
description: DETROIT, Oct. 16 (AP)Bill Lochead, a rookie, scored on at 20foot slap shot with 31 seconds.left in the second period tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 42 National Hockey League victory over the Atlanta Flames.

title: Gould Plans $30Million Loan By Foreign Banks for ITE Bid
description: Gould, Inc., a manufacturer of batteries and electrical products, said yesterday that it expected to borrow $30million from four foreign banks to finance its tender offer for onequarter of the outstanding shares of the ITE Imperial Corporation. On Tuesday, Gould made known its intention to offer $18 a share for 2 million common shares of ITE, a manufacturer of equipment for electric power transmission and other electrical products.

title: A Former Counsel In Congress Linked To Book on Goldberg
description: A former counsel for a House Judiciary subcommittee and Senate subcommittee on Investigations was identified yesterday as the sole officer and stockholder of Literary Productions: Inc., the corporation that arranged for the Rockefellerfinanced derogatory biography of Arthur J. Goldberg.

title: Personal Finance: How Safe Are Banks' Lock Boxes?
description: How safe is a safe deposit box?

title: Colts Acquire Fan for Jet GameYogi
description: A year ago at this time, Yogi Berra was still working at Shea Stadium because the Mets were playing in the World Series. Yogi will be at Shea this Sunday, but he won't be working. Another Berra will be.

title: Ronan and Authority Aide Clash on Rockefeller Gift
description: TRENTON, Oct. 16  Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller's gift of $550,000 to Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port. Authority of New York and New Jersey, caused a dispute today involving Dr. Ronan and the leading New Jersey Commissioner on the authority.

title: U.S. Officials Debate Possible Arms Sales to Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 10A debate over the issue of United States arms sales to Pakistan has broken out among American officials in India and Pakistan.

title: AIRLINES ARE HURT BY HIGH FUEL COSTS
description: The burden of the increased cost of airplane fuel was stressed yesterday by both American Airlines and Trans World Airlines in their income accounts issued for the quarter ended Sept. 30.

title: COMMUNISTS OPEN PARLEY IN POLAND
description: WARSAW, Oct. 16With European Communist parties in greater apparent disarray than at any time since World War II, party representatives from 28 countries convened here today to make arrangements for a fullscale Communist meeting.

title: TWO FILM MAKERS FASTING IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 18  Two Jewish film makers and a journalist began a hunger strike today timed to the Soviet Union's participation in the San Francisco Film Festival.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 16President Ford, campaigning for Republican candidates in the Middle West, said today that massive Democratic victories in November's Congressional election could create a legislative dictatorship.

TopNotch Leipzig Orchestra on Visit
description: The first orchestra from East Germany to come to these shores gave a concert in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. It was the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig, conducted by Kurt Masur. Which meant that the orchestra was one with a distinguished tradition in a city of a glorious musical tradition.
