description: Congress overrode yesterday for the first time a veto by President Ford and enacted a $7billion railroad retirement hill. [Page 18]

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MIAMI, Oct. 16 AP)A high school football coach who was shown shoving and slapping his players in a nationally televised program says he expects to be criticized, but his actions were for the good Of the team.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Four prisoners who escaped from the Camden County jail Tuesday night are still at large, officials said yesterday. The men escaped from their sixthfloor cells by climbing down a makeshift rope of bedsheets to a fourthfloor window. Then they apparently broke a window, reentered the building and continued down a stairway.

title: Dave Anderson
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 16Mike Marshall was dressing hurriedly when a Los Angeles newsman of his acquaintance approached his locker.

title: SENATE UNIT BARS NEW HEARING NOW FOR ROCKEFELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Senator Howard W. Cannon, chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, said today that he does not plan to resume hearings on Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller's nomination until after the Nov. 5 Congressional elections, despite Mr. Rockefeller's request for immediate hearings.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (Reuters)The Treasury issued new regulations today requiring United States banks report their positions in nine major currencies on both weekly and a monthly basis, beginning in December.

title: EFFORT ON PRISONERS REPORTED IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 16 (Reuters)  An International Red Cross representative arrived here from Geneva tonight amid reports that he was acting as a confidential intermediary for an exchange of political prisoners between Chile, Cuba and the Soviet Union.

title: Series Standing, Figures
description: Series Standing, Figures

title: Sales Mark Is Set
description: The Monsanto Company, a leading diversified chemical producer, achieved record sales and earnings in the third quarter and first nine months of this year, according to results reported yesterday.

title: Giant Job Eludes Hyland
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 17In the four years Bob Hyland has been with the New York Giants, the startingcenter job has been an elusive plum he's still hoping to nail down.

title: World Series Schedule
description: Los Angeles vs. Oakland

title: OilPrice Mirage
description: The optimistic noises about a reduction in oil prices that accompanied Secretary Kissinger's Mideast travels undoubtedly need to be taken with a barrel of salt. Mr. Kissinger's diplomatic offensive and other forms of jawboning are unlikely to have much effect so long as the fundamental power balance and supplydemand situation remain unchanged.

title: A.A.U. Sets New Rules On Travel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17The Amateur Athletic Union approved legislation today to suspend any American' track and field athlete who violates travel  permit moratoriums before national championships and international meets.

title: Dow Rises 9.15 to 651.44 Despite Inflation Report
description: The stock market managed to post its first advance in three sessions in slower trading yesterday despite some unfavorable economic news.

title: The President Testifies
description: President Ford's appearance before a House Judiciary subcommittee, commendable and historic though it was, failed to clear up the deep and troubling doubts raised by his precipitate pardon of former President Nixon.

title: Dreyfus in Rehearsal a Wry Comedy
description: At one point in JeanClaude Grumberg's comedy Dreyfus in Rehearsal, which opened at the Ethel Barrymore Theater last night, someone says, Theater is pleasing the public. Later on someone else refers to oldfashioned theater for oldfashioned people. In the nicest possible way, both phrases sum up Garson Kanin's adaptatibn of a seriously aspiring comedy that is full of Yiddish humor, Yiddish sentimentality and Yiddish irony. It is a kind of Fiddler on the Roof without the fiddle.

title: A.T.&T. Expands DebtFinancing Plan
description: Citing improved market conditions, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday a $100million increaseto $600milionin its previously disclosed plans for a debt financing next month. A.T.&T. said its $600million offering would be made up of $300million of sevenyear notes and $300million of 32year debentures.

title: Negro College Fund, a Success At 30, Running Harder Now
description: Thirty years ago, Dr. Frederick D. Patterson, then president of the financially beleaguered Tuskegee Institute in Alabama, went to Boston on a fundraising trip and was rebuffed by people who had been the traditional allies of Southern black higher education.

title: Advice to Democrats
description: WASHINGTONWith a Presidential resignation behind us and with the approach of the November elections, attention is turning to the Presidential election of 1976 and the state of our national political parties.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Student groups at Rider College in Trenton put their support behind faculty members who are on strike for 10.8 to 12 per cent pay increases. The executive committee the Interdormitory Council, representing 2,000 boarders the school, and the Student Government Association, representing all 3,400 Rider students, issued separate statements of support and sympathy for the teachers. Some 1,000 students marched around campus demanding a meeting of the school's directors to settle the dispute.

title: STUDY ASKS DELAY ON FUMES CONTROL
description: The Federal deadline for a 90 per cent reduction in air pollutants emitted by new automobiles should be relaxed until 1980, it was proposed in a study released yesterday by three leading universities.

title: A's Win World Series For Third Straight Time
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 17 The Oakland A's, fussing and feuding to the end, swept to their third straight baseball championship tonight when they defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 32, and won the 71st World Series.

title: Police Inspector Here is Accused In Payoff Case and Is Demoted
description: One of the city's highest ranking police officers, Inspector Maurice McAuley, has been accused of accepting more than $1,500 in payoffs from a corrupt sergeants' club in Queens and demoted to captain.

title: Computer View of Disaster Is Rebutted
description: BERLIN, Oct. 17A new Club of Rome study that says mankind can only avoid a worldshattering catastrophe by narrowing the gap between rich and poor lands was challenged by a number of participants at the international group's meeting here.

title: Beame Wants to Review the M.T.A.'s Deficit Estimate
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he wanted to take another look in the transit till to see if the deficit projection for 1975 announced by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was really that bad.

title: 9 on Firefighters Board Sign A Letter Critical of Vizzini
description: The nine members of the executive board of the Uniformed Firefighters Association have signed a letter sharply critical of the union president, Richard J. Vizzini, and have sent copies to the more than 400 firehouses throughout the city, apparently in an effort to obtain his resignation.

title: Negro College Fund, a success At 30, Running Harder Now
description: Thirty years ago, Dr. Frederick D. Patterson, then president of the financially beleaguered Tuskegee Institute in Alabama, went to Boston on a fundraising trip and was rebuffed by people who had been the traditional allies of Southern black higher education.

title: Bruins Win As Esposito Scores Two
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 (UPI)Phil Esposito, the National Hockey League's scoring champion, scored two secondperiod goals tonight and led the Boston Bruins to A 41 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Jets' Game Dialed Off Channel 4 Sunday
description: Channel 4, the local NBC station, will pay the Jets the ultimate insult on Sunday by choosing not to televise their game at Shea Stadium with the Baltimore Colts. Channel 4 prefers to show its audience the late game from the West Coast between playoff candidates, Cincinnati and Oakland, starting at 4 P.M.

title: LISBON PRESIDENT IS HEARD AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17  The new President of Portugal, Gen. Francisco da Costa comes, in an address to the United Nations General Assembly today invited delegates to visit his country and see for themselves that alarmist appraisals of its situation were unfounded.

title: Compromise Is Reported On Soviet Trade and Jews
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  The White House and key Senators were reported tonight to have reached agreement on a compromise that will provide trade benefits to the Soviet Union in return for major liberalization of Moscow's emigration policies.

title: Nature and the Price of Oil Plague Bangladesh
description: PANCHASARI, BangladeshThe Bangladesh Glass and Metal Industries in this town 207 miles southeast of Dacca has been turned into a poorhouse. The $60,000 plant no longer makes glass or metalware. Its chimneys, billowing with thick smoke until two months ago, are cold.

title: Camera Concern Off
description: Net income of the Polaroid Corporation fell 37 per cent in the third quarter as sales of old model cameras continued to decline and costs on new models increased, company results showed yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: Washington's 5.8 In Dash Accepted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Herb Washington may have been the goat in the second game of the World Seriesafter having been caught off base last Sundaybut he was a hero today when the Amateur Athletic Union Track and Field Committee certified his national indoor record of 5.8 seconds for the 60yard dash. The mark is accepted as a world best since there are no official world indoor records.

title: A's, Dodgers See Rematch in '75
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 17 The Oakland A's think so highly of the Los Angeles Dodgers, and the Dodgers are so convinced of the excellence of the threetimechampion A's, that they fully expect to meet each other next October in the same World Series setting.

title: Malone Star Attraction In Nets' Opener Tonight
description: A harried Moses Malone begins the arduous task tonight of trying to prove that a 19yearold can survive in the world of pro basketball.

title: SCHOOL BOYCOTT IS ENDED BY PACT
description: NEWARK, Oct. 17Almost half of the youngsters enrolled in the bilingual program here returned to classes today after agreement was reached among parents, the Board of Education and the state on maintaining the program for the remainder of the year.

title: FORD DEFENDS PARDON BEFORE HOUSE PANEL AND SAYS THERE WAS NO DEAL WITH NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 President Ford, in a historic appearance before a House subcommittee, attempted today to lay to rest suspicions raised by his unconditional pardon of his predecessor, Richard M. Nixon.

title: Santa Fe Advances
description: Santa Fee Industries, Inc., the parent of the Atchison, Topoka & Santa Fe Railway, benefited in the last quarter from higher rail freight rates as well as sharply higher prices its petroleum subsidiaries received for their crude oil.

title: Vatican Is Criticized For Insisting on Latin
description: ROME, Oct. 17 (Reuters) The head of the Greek Catholic Church complained to the world Synod of Catholic Bishops here, today that their proceedings were not sufficiently lively because of the Vatican's insistence that they be conducted in Latin.

title: Leipzig Orchestra Plays Piece Ending In a Satirical Joust
description: What is the symphonic music of East Germany like? So little of it is played here that we do not know. In its second concert in Carnegie Hall, on Wednesday night, the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra introduced Siegfried Matthus's Violin Concerto, written in 1968. A work that was hard to take seriously, it did not really increase our knowledge of what is going on there.

title: Inflation Is Turning Japan From Affluence to Economic Gloom
description: TOKYO, Oct. 17A retired building superintendent, Tatsugoro Murayama, went back to work at the age of 73. Eiji Matsunaga, a factory worker, gave up indulging his penchant for sake, Japanese rice wine, and stopped buying new clothes for his famfly.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the temporary suspension of its recently adopted uniform shortsale rule governing securities in the consolidated transaction reporting system.

title: KUH DEMANDS END OF SHERIFF'S JURY
description: Richard H. Kuh, the Manhattan District Attorney, yesterday called for the abolition of sheriff's jury panels.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Rockefeller Helped Carey in '72 To Speed Revenue Bill in House
description: Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller covertly helped insure the 1972 reelection of Representative Hugh L. Carey, who is now the Democratic gubernatorial candidate favored to defeat Mr. Rockefeller's handpicked successor, Governor Wilson.

title: Artistic Riches in a Dealer Show at the Metropolitan
description: It is not uncommon for art dealers to stage lavish exhibitions as benefits for deserving institutions, but it is fairly rare, to say the least, for a major museum to mount a benefit exhibition for art dealers. Yet this is more or less what the Metropolitan Museum of Art has done in collaborating on The Grand Gallery, a survey of 317 works of art opening tomorrow in the museum's special exhibition galleries.

title: Books of The Times
description: Lost battles exert a peculiar fascination on the historian. Bataan, Dunkirk, Singapore, Pearl Harbor have been the subjects of more and better books than many of the notable victories of World War H. Now, Cornelius Ryan, the chronicler of DDay, has turned to the Battle of Arnheim and Operation Market Garden for a vivid, highly charged account of one of the war's most spectacular failures.

title: COAST BUS DRIVERS VOTE TO END STRIKE
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 (UPI) The longest California bus strike in 15 years ended today, with drivers accepting a 24 per cent pay rise that will give them base pay of $272 a week within 18 months.

title: Honduran Minister Resigns
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 17 (AP) Foreign Minister Cesar A. Batres submitted his resignation today following charges that the Government had mishandled relief efforts for victims of a recent hurricane.

title: History Played Out On Familiar Stage
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17John M. Doar was there. The television cameras were on again, the 28 klieg lights dazzling. The President's conduct was in question once more. But the drama was enacted differently today before members of the House Judiciary Committee.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS Oct. 17, 1974
description: New York514070

title: Market Place
description: A common view among businessmen who have sold shares to the public is that if they had it to do over again they would not go public and thus expose themselves to stockholder critics and the regulators.

title: AutoEmployment Pattern Mixed in New York Area
description: Although the auto industry's sales are down sharply, conversions to smaller cars and the first production runs of the 1975 models have kept some assembly plants in the New YorkNew Jersey area on a full work week.

title: MARCOS MENDING RELIGIOUS FENCES
description: MANILA, Oct. 15The martiallaw regime of President Ferdinand E. Marcos has been trying to mend its fences with the Roman Catholic hierarchy after a protest on behalf of truth and justice by the new Archbishop of Manila that seemed to stir a deep current of popular feeling.

title: Advertising
description: After a year of thought, four months of careful research and screening, just a bit of cloak and dagger stuff and a lot of interviews, the Continental Can Corporation has selected Young & Rubicam for its first major corporate communications effort in many years.

title: About New York
description: Once someone wrote a fantasy about New York's ultimate traffic jamthe day the cars finally stopped. Locked in a death grip from the Battery to the Bronx, unable to move either back or forth, immobile, the cars simply sat there, and Manhattan became one great parking lot.

title: 50% CUT PROPOSED IN ENERGY GROWTH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17A major energy study sponsored by the Ford Foundation recommends a Governmentled national commitment to conserve energy and argues that by such an undertaking the United States can put off for 10 years massive new commitments to offshore drilling, oil imports, nuclear power or development, of coal and shale in arid areas, of the West.

title: BOSTON SCHOOLS CALM FOR 2D DAY
description: BOSTON, Oct. 17Racially tense Boston schools passed a second day of relative calm today with more than 400 National Guardsmen, mostly military policemen, garrisoned in and near the city for deployment if necessary and some students entering one high school subjected to a spot search for weapons.

title: JUSTIN BRADSHAW
description: Justin Bradshaw, a vice president of Broadcast Music, Inc., the musiclicensing organization, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack; while in Nashville for meetings of tfie Country Music Association. He was 59 years old and lived at 19 Moonedge Road, Northport, L. I.

title: Fillol Victor Over Okker By 61, 63
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 17 (AP)Jaime Fillol of Chil toppled topseeded Tom Okker of the Netherlands, 61, 63, today and moved into the quarterfinals of the Spanish open tennis tournament.

title: 4 Teachers Return to Jobs Despite Parents' Protest
description: Escorted by security officers and despite protests by parents, who threatened a lockout today, four teachers returned yesterday to Public School 46 in Harlem, where they had been forced out three weeks ago by parent pressure.

title: Woman Friend Retains No Show Job On Maraziti's Congressional Payroll
description: BOONTON, Oct. 17Representative Joseph J. Maraziti, Republican of the 13th District, has retained a longtime woman friend on his Congressional payroll in a no show job for most of his first term in office, an investigation of records in New Jersey and Washington has shown.

title: The Chief Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17His friends say that James Foster Neal thrives on competition and he hates to lose. Flip him to see who buys lunch and he losesthe day's a disaster, says his Nashville law partner, Aubrey B. Harwell Jr. Mr. Neal, one of the few lawyers who signed on at the special prosecutor's office on a temporary basis, heads the prosecution team for the Watergate coverup trial. It is the set piece of the Watergate affairthe biggest trial to grow from the worst political scandal in American history.

title: Mills Apologizes to His Constituents
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 17  Representative Wilbur D. Mills apologized to his constituents tonight in his first speech and first formal appearance since he was involved in an incident with a former night club stripper in Washington on Oct. 7.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS Oct. 17, 1974
description: New York514070

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Wood, Field and Stream: HomeHeating by Wood
description: The September, and fifth, issue of Blair and Ketchum's delightful Country Journal, published at 139 Main Street, Brattleboro, Vt., took more than an hour from my day recently, but I embraced the diversion warmly.

title: Nickel Maker Gains
About Real Estate
description: WALNUT CREEK, Calif.The adult community called Rossmoor Walnut Creek hugs the craggy hills of the Contra Costa region northwest of San Francisco. The tall grass along the hillside is pale brown at this time of year, and the lowlying housing seems to melt into it.

title: California High Court Rejects Kalmbach Bid
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 (AP)The California Supreme Court turned down today a request by Herbert W. Kalmbach to lift his interim suspension from law practice.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK MORE WITNESSES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Dedaring that President Ford's testimony today concerning his pardon of Richard M. Nixon had raised new questions, four Democrats on the House Judiciary subcommittee that heard him said they would press to call additional witnesses.Ford in early August of damaging evidence against the then President; Benton L. Becker, Washington lawyer who negohand, said that he was not sure that further inquiries would prove useful.

title: 14Million Loan to Indonesia
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (Reuters)The World Bank today announced a $14.5million loan to Indonesia to improve water supplies for eight cities.

title: Democrats Vote to Limit Debate At Party Meeting in December
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Democratic party officials adopted rules today to restrict debate and dissent at their charter conference in Kansas City in December.

title: ESTHER APPELBERG OF YESHIVA U. DEAD
description: Dr. Esther Appelberg, a professor of social work at the Yeshiva University Wurzweiler School of Social Wink, died yesterday at her home, 400 Central Park West. She was 51 years old.

title: TALENTS DISPLAYED BY HARPSICHORDIST
description: Lionel Party, a Chilean harpsichordist who has studied with Albert Fuller at the Juilliard School, won a Leipzig Bach Competition in 1972 and recorded for the Musical Heritage Society, gave his second New York recital Wednesday night. The performance was in the LatinAmerican series sponsored at the Hunter College; Playhouse by the Center for InterAmerican Relations.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Service was halted on Staten Island's 14mile Rapid Transit Railroad by a strike of 37 employes, forcing more than 17,000 riders to find other transportation, until a Federal judge ordered restoration of service, which came too late for the evening rush hour.

title: Peking Denounces Report That Mao Suffered Stroke
description: PEKINGA Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman today described as out and out rumormongering a report in a London newspaper that Chairman Mao Tsetung suffered a stroke last month.

title: Caledonian Airways Sets Halt on Oct. 31 To Atlantic Flights
description: British Caideonian Airways, which inaugurated service between the United States and Britain 19 months ago with a $1million promotional campaign and a slogan about The Airline That Other Airlines Hate, announced yesterday that it would end the service Oct. 31.

title: Oklahoma Governor Race May Go to an Unknown
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 13Inflation, beef prices on the farm, racial unrest and the Watergate scandal have created a political turmoil in Oklahoma that is almost certain to put al virtual unknown in the Governor's office and threatens to topple Senator Henry Bellmon, a Republican.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beame, calling the Fire Department the greatest organization of its kind in the world, said that there is no question in my mind about the hazardous aspects of the fire fighters' jot. The Mayor made his remarks at memorial services for deceased members of the department at the Firemen's Monument, 100th Street and Riverside Drive.

title: A Conservative to Oppose Rockefeller in Senate Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Senator William L. Scott of Virginia today became the first member of the Senate to announce that he would vote against the confirmation of Nelson A. Rockefeller as Vice President.

title: Long Live Shame!
description: SAN FRANCISCOThe ancient Hebrews were alone in envisioning a troubled paradise. The Garden of Eden was not an abode of bliss but a place tense with suspicion and anxiety. For no sooner did God, in a moment of divine recklessness, create man in His own image than He was filled with misgivings. There was no telling what a creature thus made would do next. So God placed Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden where he could watch them.

title: Congress Warming To a LongHeld Gift Of 1876 Mementos
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 17 (AP) After 97 years, Congress has finally accepted a massive gift of 19th century memorabilia, but it has to wait until July 4, 1976, to be sure exactly what it contains.

title: Dividing the Airlanes
description: The fiveyear agreement made by Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines to divide up major routes across the Atlantic and Pacific makes good business sense for both financially troubled carriers. A heavy responsibility now rests on the Civil Aeronautics Board and President Ford to review each specific exchange of routes in terms of its potential impact on the public.

title: Daniel McC. Peterson, 57, An Early TV Broadcaster,
description: Daniel McCloud Peterson, an early television broadcaster, died Tuesday of cancer at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 55 East End Avenue.

title: Ches: Korchnoi's Latest Bid to Win Is Still Going at 96(!) Moves
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 17Viktor Korchnoi threw everything he had into the attempt to win the 13th game of his final Candidates Match with Anatoly Karpov here in the Central Chess Club tonight, but after six hours of play the game was adjourned a second time.

title: A's Win World Series For Third Straight Time
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 17 The Oakland A's, fussing and feuding to the end, swept to their third straight baseball championship tonight when they defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 32, and won the 71st World Series.

title: Blacks Complete the Purchase Of BlackOriented FM Station
description: The Innercity Broadcasting Company, all of whose 58 shareholders are black, yesterday completed purchase of WBLSFM, a blackoriented station that has developed a following among youthful whites. The purchase price was $1.350million.

title: For Loving Clientele, Good Food Served With the Amenities
description: In its brief life, the Experience Restaurant, which opened about seven months ago at 406 East 64th Street between York and First Avenues, has acquired a lovmg but secretive clientele. One of them let the cat out of the bag a couple of weeks ago and I can report that the affection is justified. This is very pleasant spot.

title: UTILITIES MAY CUT CONNECTICUT JOBS
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 17Connecticut's major electric power companies, denied the rate increases they asked for and caught now in the cross fire of a gubernatorial campaign, have begun posting notices on bulletin boards in their plants that as many as 700 jobsnearly a 10th of the staffwill have to be out to reduce operating expenses.

title: FREDERICK E. KERN
description: Frederick E. Kern, who retired in 1965 as head of the transit department of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died Wednesday in Bergen Pines Hospital, Paramus, N.J. He lived in Palisades Park, N.J.

title: TV: An Unusually Active Time for News Specials
description: For no other reason than that's the way the schedule crumbles in television, this has turned out to be an unusually active week for the news departments.

title: Wilson Says He Got $500,000 Law Fees While Lieut. Governor
description: Governor Wilson has affirmed that during his 15 years as Lieutenant Governor he practiced law as a member of his White Plains firm, for which he received an approximate total of $500,000.

title: The Public and Private Happy Rockefeller
description: On the one hand, there is the ebullient tawnyhaired woman with the deep tan and the wonderful smile who seems the embodiment of what has been traditionally considered the American dream.

title: Rosewall Wins 2, Gains Quarterfinals
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 17 (AP)Ken Rosewall survived two tough matches today in the $75,000 Australian indoor tennis turnament to advance to the quarterfinals.

title: New Greek Foreign Chief
description: ATHENS, Oct. 17, (AP)  A career diplomat, Dimitri S. Bitsios, was sworn in today as Foreign Minister in the interim government preparing Greece for its first general election in almost 11 years.

title: NATION'S OUTPUT SHOWS A DECLINE; G.N.P. DROPS 2.9%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 17 The nation's total output declined during the JulySeptember period for the third consecutive quarter, and the inflation rate worsened, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Rafael Druian, former concertmaster of the Cleveland and New York Philharmonic Orchestras, has joined the National Symphony as a special assistant to Antal Dorati, its music director, it was announced here yesterday.

title: Dr. Stefan Serghiesco, Led Math Library at Columbia
description: Dr. Stefan Theodor Serghiesco, retired director of the Mathematics Library at Columbia University, died Tuesday at the age of 85 after a long illness. He lived at 417 West 120th Street.

title: Pro Transactions
description: ST. LOUIS (ABA)  Activated Gil McGregor, forward Placed on injured waiver list Dennis Wuycik, forward. SAN DIEGO (ABA)Waived Billy Shepherd guard, and Rich O'Connor, forward.

title: BACK PAY GIVEN TO APPRENTICES
description: Back pay and supplements totaling $63,500 have been recovered by the State Labor Department for 70 minoritygroup workers and two unions as the result of an investigation that found the contractor on a state project to be paying fess than the required prevailing wage.

title: Ford Reported to Oppose Lifting Sanctions on Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (Reuters) President Ford reportedly told visitors today that the United States would emphatically oppose any move by the Organization of American States to lift economic sanctions against Cuba.

title: New Jersey Sports Kean Gains Respect
description: NEWARK, Oct. 17Kean College has never won more than once in conference play in the past, but things have changed this season, not only in conference competition, but also in overall performance.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Ronan Asked to Take A Post in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 17 Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, has been asked to serve as a $36,000ayear consultant to Puerto Rico's Department of Public Works and Transportation.

title: To Nichols, Life's a Play And Funny
description: It's a funny old world we in, and you're lucky to get out of it alive, says the highspirited hospital orderly in Peter Nichols's The National Health, now running on Broadway at Circle in the Square. In this and his other plays, Mr. Nichols (who is one of Britain's most acclaimed playwrights) meets despair and even death head on with laughter. His plays are seriocomic and drawn directly from their dour author's life.

title: People in Sports
description: Jacques Richard, a left wing on the Atlanta Flames, suffered a broken nose and a fractured eye socket when he was struck by the stick of Jim Rutherford, the goalie of the Red Wings, in a National Hockey League game at Detroit on Wednesday night. He will be out of action for two or three weeks.

title: Opera
description: When the Metropolitan Opera revives Janacek's Jenufa next month it will be the work's first appearance there since the 192425 season. New Yorkers, however, have not been entirely deprived of the chance to hear this powerful music. The Little Orchestra Society presented it here in 1966, and againbrilliantlyon Wednesday night. The Met has been given something to shoot at.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES MADE AT DAILY NEWS
description: Four executive changes at The Daily News were announced yesterday by W. H. James, president and publisher of the newspaper.

title: Brezhnev Reported to Plan Visit to Syria in January
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 17 (Reuters)  Informed sources here said today that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, will visit Syria in January, the same month he is to visit Egypt.

title: Soviet Tries Jew Whose Car Hit Daughter of an Official
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 17A prominent Jewish activist went on trial here today for having struck a young woman who he contends leaped in front of his car in a suicide attempt.

title: The Pulpit Magnified
description: President Ford has set a notable example, and taken a long step toward an open Presidency by his appearance before a Congressional subcommitteea precedent that may have much meaning for the future. But just two days before, Mr. Ford had demonstrated the extent to which Presidential powers are still unchecked and may be subject to political abuse.

title: Calzadilla RansomFinder Is Freed of 3 of 5 Charges
description: NEWARK, Oct. 17A Federal judge today dismissed three of the five counts against Richard Ventola, a 27yearold former railroad worker from Weehawken, who is on trial for allegedly finding and keeping ransom money raised in the kidnapping of 8yearold John Calzadilla of Dix Hills, L. I.

title: Transcript of President's Testimony to Panel of House on Pardor
Virginia Otto Smith Dead; Publisher of Suffolk Citizen
description: Virginia Otto Smith of Sayville, L. I., a realestate broker for the lift 15 years and for two decades publisher of the now defunct Suffolk Citizen, a weekly newspaper in Sayville, died Wednesday in St. Clare's Hospital here at the age of 74.

title: BIG ILLINOIS BANK SHOWS 18,4 GAP
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, parent of the country's eighth largest bank, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, reported yesterday an 18.1 per cent rise in thirdquarter operating earnings and a 13.1 per cent increase for the first nine months of 1974.

title: A SANDWICH SPREAD RECALLED BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) The Foood and Drug Administration announced today the recall of newly 12,000 cans of a sandwich spread that it said was underprocessed, creating a potential health hazard.

title: Sagner Opposes Agency On South Jersey Transit
description: GLASSBORO, Oct 17Transportation Commissioner Alan Sagner told a regional planning conference here today that there was no need for a South Jersey public transportation authority that is called for in a State Senate bill. Instead, he recommended the creation of a network of county transportation planning boards.

title: Nadjari Seeks New Inquiry on Goldman
description: The state's special anticorruption prosecutor began an effort yesterday to revive an investigation of Irving Goldman, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, that was abruptly suspended on Wednesday by Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Some Africans Wary On PostDrought Aid

title: PRESIDENT AGREES ON AID FOR TURKEY

title: MAILON INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Dizella Slabe picked a letter from the top of a huge stack of mail; opened it, read it, and then put it in a pile with others going to the President.

title: Courage vs. Cancer
description: The incredible coincidence of Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller's surgery for cancer of the breast, less than three weeks after Mrs. Gerald R. Ford had to face the same ordeal with equal suddenness, emphasizes the unpredictability of the disease and the need for constant vigilance. As the American people extend to Mrs. Rockefeller their sincere wishes for a speedy and complete restoration of health, they may be encouraged by the fact that early detection makes exceedingly favorable the prospect of such a recovery. These two prominent and appealing women have, by their strength, courage and forthrightness, set an admirable example for the response to the disease with the means now available, while adding urgency to the search for better weapons in the constant battle against cancer.

title: Simon Gallet Dead at 60; Senior Law Partner Here

title: Air Strike Talks to Resume
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) Negotiations to end a threemonth strike of National Airlines machinists will resume in Washington Saturday at the request of the White House. W. J. Usery, special assistant to the President for labor relations and director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliations Service said today. Before the strike, the airline and union, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers had bargained for a year. The chief issues are pay, work rules and the airline's practice of subcontracting work.

title: Dave Anderson
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 17In the seventh inning tonight, as the Los Angeles Dodgers trotted to their positions, a premature celebrant in the leftfield bleachers at the Oakland Coliseum tossed a whisky bottle onto the grass. Bill Buckner, the Dodger left fielder, was offended. So much so that he complained to Doug Harvey, the foulline umpire, and then retreated toward the infield where he was intercepted by Tom Gorman, another umpire, and a covey of Dodgers including Walter Alston, their manager, and Mike Marshall, their Ph.D. candidate in physiology. It was not one of Marshall's most intellectual moments. While he persuaded Buckner to return to his target area, he was neglecting to continue his warmup pitches. Near the plate, Joe Rudi, who long ago completed a Ph.D. in clutch hitting for the Oakland A's, was aware that Mike Marshall was impersonating. Henry Kissinger instead of tending to his profession as a Pitcher with a rude screwball as wel as a rude manner.

title: People and Business
description: Henry H. Fowler, chairman of the Goldman Sachs International Corporation and a former Secretary of the Treasury, predicted yesterday that shortterm interest rates would probably decline to between 9 per cent and 10 per cent by early next year and that they would continue in this range for four to six months.

title: Ford Before Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17When Former President Richard M. Nixon first became mired in the Watergate charges early in 1973, some friendly Republican leaders told him that all a President needed to do to disarm a hostile Congress was to meet humbly with a Congressional committee and answer questions, Mr. Nixon could never bring himself to accept that advice. Mr. Ford did, and the result was as predicted: Members of a subcommittee  with the notable exception of Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, Democrat of Brooklynseemed so overwhelmed by the gesture of a President submitting to an open Congressional inquiry that much of the rancor caused by Mr. Ford's pardon of Mr. Nixon seemed to have evaporated, at least while Mr. Ford was in the room.

title: Notes on People
description: A new Elizabeth has come into the life of Richard Burton, a Princess Elizabeth related to the British royal family, and he intends to marry her as soon as she can get a divorce. The 49yearold actor, divorced four months ago from Elizabeth Taylor, announced yesterday, with the 38yearold Yugoslav princess at his side, we are going to get married as soon as it is practicably possible. With the couple was one of Princess Elizabeth's two daughters by an earlier marriage, Catherine Oxenburg. The princess, whose parents are Prince Paul and Princess Olga of Yugoslavia, who fled their homeland during World War II, is now married to a British banker, Neil Balfour. Previously she was the wife of Howard Oxenburg, a New York clothing manufacturer.

title: The Screen:Dodes'ka-den' Reflects Shanty Life in Japan
description: Never having read Shugoro Yamamoto's "The Town Without Seasons," I cannot be too certain how faithfully Akira Kurosawa has followed its text in his adaptation, "Dodes'ka-den," now playing at the First Avenue Screening Room.But judging by what is visible on screen, the novel must have been a rather slick, episodic work, one of those "good reads" that pokes its nose behind closed doors into the lives of "little people" to sniff out a heady mixture of scandal, sentiment and spiritual uplift.These, certainly, are the principal findings of "Dodes'ka-den" ("The Song of the Trolley), as it weaves its way through a shanty town sprouting out of a wasteland of refuse. Among the characters in the forefront is the demented boy who spends his days commanding an imaginary trolley into and out of the town; the father and son who inhabit the shell of a car and plan a dream house; the wise and compassionate old artisan who is kind to burglars and confounding to enraged drunks; the two drunken laborers who swap wives; and the cuckold who illustrates the distinction between parenthood and fatherhood.There is also the spiritually dead man who will never forgive his wife her indiscretion; the deformed, tic-ridden clerk and his surly wife; and the frail, unhappy girl who makes artificial flowers and is abused by her stepfather And, out in the midst of all the shanties, a group of women spending all day at the communal water spigot acts the role of a chorus.The unifying image is that of the trolley, and the trolley is on a shuttle run. Like the people in the movie, it is going nowhere. All are anchored in their poverty. Some are oblivious to it; some dream their way above it; some are afflicted with more distractingeven more agonizingburdens."Dodes'ka-den" is smooth, Mr. Kurosawa's first color film, and he is clearly enchanted by its possibilities, drenching the screen with hues, using them to establish mood and identify characters; to transport the audience into surreal realms dominated by dreams and death.Dodes'ka-den is smooth, handsome and well-acted. Those caret its virtues. Its overriding fault is an acceptance of superficiality. In place of profundity, it gives us gossip."

The Soviet Union has never publicly acknowledged its role, but Secretary Kissinger has assured the Senators that the Soviet Union will dramatically liberalize its immigration policies. description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Harry S. Truman played the piano for Lauren Bacall there. Nikita Khrushchev warned the West from its platform that we will bury you. President Ford is on the waiting list for membership.

title: New Ticker Tape Testedon Big Board
description: A ticker tape with considerably more market information than before began operating experimentally on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, but Wall Street was not sure whether it liked it or not.

title: Ethiopian Province Official Says Million Lack Water
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 18 (AP)Nearly a million persons are close to starvation and need emergency water supplies in the vast arid Ogaden, region of east central Ethiopia, the Ethiopian News Agency said today, quoting a provincial official.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A group of neighborhood businessmen has formed a committee to getBroadway reopened to traffic between 135th and 145th Streets, in an effort to recoup losses resuiting from a water main break at 137th Street.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and ?? Page 33

title: TOUFIC MIZRAHI
description: Toufic Mizrahi, who in 1929 founded Le Commerce du Levant, an economic and financial newspaper in Beirut, Lebanon, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Brussels on Oct. 5. He was 75 years old.

title: PHILHARMONIC FINE IN BRUCKNER WORK
description: The best way to perform Bruckner's music is to let it unfold at Its own tempo, never pushing it or trying to reduce its longueurs by speeding. Carlo Maria Giulini's conducting of the composer's Ninth Symphony in the New York Philharmonic's concert Thursday night was eloquent testimony to this truth. There were even measures where the conductor slowed down, without indications in the score, to clarify a musical detail or make a smooth bridge between sections.

title: Screen:'Airport 1975' Is aSilly Sequel With a 747
description: "Airport 1975," which opened at three theaters yesterday, is a silly, jumbo-size sequel to the original film adaptation of Arthur Hailey's "Airport," which was about the trials of a Boeing 707 that had the misfortune to have a mad bomber aboard. The two films are very much alike; only, the planes and the names of the characters have been changed to amuse the innocent.Like its predecessor, "Airport 1975" is carefully designed not to bring up any subject as touchy as air safety and traffic control, even though it's about a midair collision. A great deal is made of the fact that the collision is a result of what might be called a private failing, and that, anyway, the 747 is "the best aircraft ever made."The crisis in "Airport 1975" occurs when the pilot of a private plane has a heart attack and plunges his small craft into the cockpit of a 747 en route from Washington to Los Angeles, either killing or maiming the members of the jetliner's flight crew.Who is left aboard the big plane to handle the controls until some sort of help can arrive?Who will be able to steer it, more or less, through mountain passes, receiving her instructions through the headphones of the damaged radio, looking distraught from time to time, but game and pretty throughout?By golly, you've guessed it, but I shouldn't give away any more of the plot. He who gives away the plot of a movie like this gives away its soul.Karen Black plays the spunky stewardess, and Charlton Heston plays her boyfriend, the man who saves the day in a daring plane-to-plane pilot transfer that prompts someone to say in all seriousness: "This is plain suicide, sir!"There are a lot of exclamation points in this movie, which is also extremely polite, even in its crises. Worse failings are its smugness ("The public's right to know gives me huge pain in the ," says a righteous airline executive of a pushy TV reporter) and a total lack of awareness of how comic it is when it's attempting to be most serious.The supporting characters include a little girl en route to a kidney transplant (played by Linda Blair with all of the navet of a Vegas showgirl); a singing nun (Helen Reddy), a lady who drinks with two fists (Myrna Loy), another nun who doesn't sing (Martha Scott) and Gloria Swanson (played by Gloria Swanson in what amounts to ferocious self-parody).The screenplay was written by Don Ingalls, and Jack Smight was the director. The plane is by Boeing.

title: Little Action Seen In Racing Inquiry
description: Recent disclosures of wrongdoing in thoroughbred racing here have touched off inquiries by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and three other agencies.

title: Bhutto Strengthening His Grip on a Troubled Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan Prime, Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto is strengthening his grip on Pakistan, a splintered, troubled but economically resilient, nation.

description: Two more major extensions of Amtrak's rail passenger networka Washington to Denver route and a link from Portland, Ore through Idaho to Ogden, Utahappear ready for formal announcement soon.

title: Text of Letters Exchanged by Kissinger and Jackson
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Following is an exchange of letters between Secretary of State Kissinger and Senator Henry M. Jackson on the agreement relating to Soviet trade benefits and emigration policy:

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.3 billion tonmiles, 1.6 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 537,234 cars, 3.9 per cent below last year.

title: Port Agency Says Jersey Plan Will Delay Extension of PATH
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said last night that the controversial plan to extend its PATH rapidtransit line from Newark to Newark International Airport and then another 15 miles to Plainfield, N. J., is being delayed.

The board estimated November production at two million barrels a day and domestic requirements for the month at just over one million barrels.

title: When You Go to Zaire for the Fight, The $2.40 Dinner Is Worth a Detour
description: If you happen to be going to Zaire for the George ForemanMuhammad Ali fight on Oct. 30, I've got a couple of gastronomical hints for you.

title: New Space for Children

Such acquiescence may temporarily win friends; but to leave the budgetcutting to a host of noneducational city agencies can only have the effect of substituting political for educational criteria in the ultimate budgetcutting decisions.

title: Art: A Glimpse of Asger Jorn
description: The development of European painting in the period since World War II has sometimes been difficult to keep in proper focus on this side of the Atlantic. American painting became an international force in these years, and the attention paid to European achievements inevitably suffered at times as a result. Nothing significant has been wholly missed, I think, but certain careers have been given the kind of fitful treatment reserved for artists who we do not feel are crucial to our own history.

description: FIRST BASESteve Garvey, Los Angeles.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: CHAMPAGNE, ANYONE? Twentysix songsno wornout standards, half of them obscure and most of them delightfulmake An Evening of Cole Porter a 90minute bargain, as sung by five young people in the cabaret room of the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street (near First Avenue). General admission is $3; drinks are $1.25 ($1 to club subscribers). But the flow of music suffices.

Killed with Phillip Morgan, 45 years old; Robert Derobtertis, 38; Peter Tillson, 38, and Chauncey Whipperman, 49. James E. Reynolds, 46, Cerritos, Calif., suffered internal and head injuries.

And a bombing outside a school in a Roman Catholic area of Belfast injured 12 persons, including several children, authorities said.

title: Recession by Any Name
description: The economy keeps sliding downhill, but the Administration still insists there is no recession. The nation's total output of goods and services has declined for three consecutive quarters, the longest dip since the end the Eisenhower Administration well over a decade ago. Unemployment has risen by more than a million in the last year, with one worker in every seventeen now jobless. Doubledigit inflation has become institutionalized, even though high prices and high unemployment supposedly never go together.

It shares the easternmost island of the Malay archipelago with Indonesia and is about 9,000 miles from its supposed mother country.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1974
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson in an announcement made at the White House, said that President Ford and Congress had formally agreed on a compromise to provide trade benefits to the Soviet Union. In return, he said, there will be a substantial relaxation in Moscow's emigration policies. Secretary of State Kissinger said he had assurances from Moscow there would be an end to harassment of wouldbe Soviet emigrants and Senator Jackson said he understood this to mean that at least 60,000 Jews and others could leave the Soviet Union annually. Passage of the trade bill is expected soon after Congress returns from recess on Nov. 18. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: Art: Calder Crags and Critters
description: If public opinion were polled as to who was the bestloved living American artist, Alexander Calder would be way up near the top. As an artist, as a man and as a citizen, Mr. Calder has deserved well of us all. Yet in the magazines that pride themselves on being up to the minute, you'll get shown the door if you mention his name. People who dare not write a sentence without 19 footnotes will wince at the sound, and people who have never in their lives taken a stand about public events will look out of the window when they hear the name of the man who once took a full page in this newspaper, at his own sole expense, to say, Reason is not treason.

description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 18A labor dispute involving uniformed police and firemen and the city administration here has taken an unusual twist, with bands of offduty men staging daily, goodnatured picketing of Mayor Paul T. Jordan at his home, at City Hall and at all his public appearances.

title: Series Aftermath: Quotes and Gloats
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 18 The 1974 World Series was over, with the Oakland A's crowned as champions for the third straight year, but the comments still shimmered in the warm California air today. Such as:

title: Is There Baseball After Death?
description: BASEBALL goes on, essentially unaltered, though the nation itself goes through violent historical upheavals and the times are always changing. Violence is on the land today. But the game of baseball remains its peaceful self. It's constant, enduring, and links the century together in our landthe twentieth century, when so much happened and baseball remained essentially placid in the midst of all. It's dependable, and goes on. Fashions come and go, and wars, and social problems, economic crises, political climates. Baseball outlives them allin our midst. A steady constant that retains its own slow unfolding patterns, while convulsions grip the land outside and tear out the old to plant in the new. Baseball serenely glides bypermanent, beautiful, ever itself: insular, yet mildly reflecting, in a peaceful way, in its own terms, the changes going on outside. The world's cataclysms come about, and subside. But every summer is played the same eternal baseball game. We can time our lives, to its peaceful eternity. We can trust to its repose, and security. It's always going on.

title: New Jersey Briefs.
description: Bowie Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, came out against casino gambling in an interview on a Princeton radio station. He said approval of a state casino referendum in the Nov. 5 election could lead to gambling on athletic events that would undermine the public's confidence in baseball and other sports. Mr. Kuhn, who lives in Ridgewood, also said he felt casinos will open the doors to organized crime.

description: BUENOS AIRES (UPI)The authorities of the small, town of Chajari, 240 miles north of here, have ordered a onetimeonly tax of 230 pesos. ($23) for each of the community's television antennas.

Legislators who oppose aid to Turkey contended that the measure actually contained more restrictive provisions than the bill that Mr. Ford vetoed yesterday.

title: Unity in Diversity

The work of a Landmarks Commission is to protect that total image as much single structures, and New York has been moving thoughtful, creative ways to a kind of environmental or cultural preservation.

title: Persuading the Turks
description: The public debate between President Ford and Congress about suspending American military aid to Turkey, though not very enlightening, did serve one useful purpose. The Turkish Government and armed forces can no longer be in doubt about the depth and breadth of out rage aroused in this country by their massive military offensive on Cyprus, which killed thousands of innocent civilians and left a quarter of a million people homeless.

title: Better Way Found to Use Sun for Heat and Cooling
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The sponsors of a new system for heating and cooling buildings with the sun's rays believe it overcomes two usual drawbacks  the high initial cost and the need of wide flat plates to collect the energy. Patent 3,841,302 was granted this week to Gerald Falbel of the Wormser Scientific Corporation, Stamford, Conn., for what is called a pyramidal optic focusing system. A prototype that Mr. Falbel has added to his home in Stamford provides most of the hot water that the house re quires.

title: Notes on People
description: The valet and maid long in service to the family of Richard M. Nixon have not been on the Federal Government payroll since Oct. 5, it was announced yesterday. The couple, Manolo and Fina Sanchez, had been listed on the payroll of the National Park Service at annual salaries of $13,000 and $8,000 respectively. The Sanchezes, now listed on leave without pay, are in that status because of some Government benefits to which they are entitled. Last month it was disclosed that the two servants were being paid with public funds even though they left the White House Aug. 9, which resulted in criticism during a Senate appropriations subcommittee's considerationand reduction of a requested $850,000 in transition funds for the former President.

description: ALBANY, Oct. 18 (AP)New York State can expect a critical shortage of anthracite coal this winter, according to the stat's emergency fuel chief, Gn. A. C. O'Hara.

description: Representative hugh L. Carey said yesterday that New York State was in serious trouble on its housing and would need 200,000 new units a year just to keep pace with new families and the rate of wornout old units.

description: Women crowded into a small storefront on Lexington Avenue yesterday to learn the technique of examining their breasts.

description: Despite the President's appeal for price restraint, prices are rising from 5 per cent to as much as 30 per cent on a wide variety of consumer goods to be sold this winter and next spring.

title: The Screen: Neame's 'Odessa File':Thriller About Secret SS Society Opens
description: When a thriller is built entirely around one star, you know that he's not going to vanish, that he simply can't get bumped offhence the suspense sags. And that's one of the many flaws in Ronald Neame's "The Odessa File," which opened yesterday at Loews State, Loews Orpheum, and Cinema 2. The movie is so dependent on Jon Voight's presence that he's hardly allowed off the screen. So the threats to his life are no more exciting than watching a shopper being elbowed at a January white sale.The pictureset in Germany in 1963, and based on Frederick Forsyth's novelis concerned with a secret society of former SS men. Equipped with new identities, they're conspiring to produce rockets that will destroy Israel. Mr. Voight, a German journalist obsessed with tracking down a sadistic war criminal, finally infiltrates the organization by masquerading as an alumnus of the SS. (He's asked if he's willing to risk his life to crack the case. Whenever that demand is made of a reporter in a movie, I picture trouble at the story conference.) Naturally, the villains are eager to erase himunlike the audience, they don't know that he's unkillable, or that every trap set for him has to fizzle.The film makes its points methodically, almost academically. It also drags because there are many unnecessary transitional passages, devoted to moving the characters from one situation to another. Almost every occurrence is predictable. But at least there are no cabaret scenes; these Nazis don't have as much fun as those in "The Night Porter."Mr. Voight is not at his besthe's just too thoughtful a performer for a mere action part, which offers too little scope for the variety of his talents. He hasn't much to do beyond conveying worry, weariness and patience; he's rarely allowed to smileand it's a deprivation not to see this actor smile. He's quite skillful at impersonating a 40-year-old Nazibut throughout, his German accent comes out Chermann.Maximilian Schell does transcend the banality of the script; he's very good indeed as the dexterous survivor who was once the concentration camp butcher. Mary Tamm, as Mr. Voight's girl-friend, is colorless in a colorless part; almost her only function is to chide him for living dangerously. Meanwhile, moviegoers who crave dazzling suspense should see Claude Pintoteau's "Escape to Nowhere" instead of "The Odessa File."

title: French Suggest Closer Ties far Europe
description: Paris, Oct. 18France has presented to her partners in the European Common Market proposals for closer political ties. But the ideas, which run counter to French policies of the Gaullist era, have stirred little enthusiasm in member countries.

description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 18 (AP)Bjorn Borg reeled off four straight games today after losing the first eight and went on to beat Jan Kodes, 06, 97, 75, in the quarterfinals of the Spanish open tennis tournament.

Sidney Eden, producer of the twocharacter drama, attributed the delay to a prior television commitment by Mr. Gazzara. Martin Fried is the director.

description: This is the 250th anniversary of Remy Martin, one of the great names in Cognac. This makes the company older than George Washington and a great deal older than the United States.

description: PARIS, Oct. 18About four weeks ago Baron Edmond de Rothschild received a telephone call from a business associate who was worried about unauthorized foreign deposits of an Israeli investment company.

The trend of contemporary opera has been toward naturalism. Even to have people singing is dangerous; to let them dance might prove fatal.

description: There is a specter haunting the worldthe specter of food shortages, widespread hunger and, in some areas, mass starvation. It is a terrible and complex problem because it involves millions of human lives.

description: BOONTON, Oct. 18Representative Joseph J. Mariziti, Republican of the 13th District, issued a statement today in which he said the woman he hired as a research assistant on his Congressional payroll earned $19,970 working on project basis over the last 20 months.

description: A year ago the Brooklyn Museum treated us to the appetizerthe superb Donald S. Morrison collection of English 18thcentury silver. The assemblage of 80 pots, salts, bowls and salvers emphasizes Huguenot craftssmanship and the evolution of British styles from classicism to fullblown rococo.

title: Dark at the Top of the Stair
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 18Alvin Dark's assignment had been cruelly simple: Win the World Series, and in less than seven games. Anything less would be short of success, and not winning it at all would be total failure, even if a firstplace finish in the division and an American League pennant in the playoff preceded the Series.

title: Egypt and Soviet Join in Demanding Palestinian State
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 18 (AP)The Soviet Union and Egypt agreed today to support the creation of a Palestinian state as a prerequisite for an overall peaceful settlement in the Middle East.

title: Joyous Cairo Holiday Comes With a High Price Tag
description: CAIRO, Oct. 17  Happy Christmas! Happy Christmas! cried Hassan, the parking attendant in front of the office this morning. Hassan is an old man and usually saves his strength with weary deliberation. But today he bounded joyfully across the street to shake hands with his regular customers.

title: Troubles Beset a $20Million CountryHome Project
description: COXSACKIE, N. Y., Oct. 17For months last year and the year before, hundredi of buyers flocked to Sleepy Hollow Lake here, lured by a sales campaign that promised a second home in the country near what it said was the largest manmade recreational lake in the state.

title: Parkinson Son Injured Trying to Burn a Turtle
description: GLEN ECHO, Md., Oct. 18 (UPI)The 9yearold son of a Watergate coverup defendant, Kenneth W. Parkinson, was seriously burned yesterday when he and some friends were trying to set a turtle on fire, the police reported.

title: PRIME RATES CUT BY MAJOR BANKS
description: The trend to lower shortterm interest rates in the money markets continued yesterday with a new round of reductions in the prime rate by several of the nation's leading commercial banks.

title: Opera: Death in Venice
description: Benjamin Britten's Death in Venice, his most recent opera, received its first American performance last night at the Metropolitan Opera, and it was a genuine event. Whatever one may think of the score, this kind of first night is what the Metropolitan Opera should be having much more often than it has in recent years. A new work by a major composer; new talent all over the place; critics from all over the country; a distinguished audience; a buzz of anticipation.

title: Arab Rumors Lift I.B.M. Stock Price
description: A report that an Arab consortium was negotiating to buy the International Business Machines Corporation caused a flurry of buying yesterday of the giant computer company's stockon European markets as well as on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: F.B.I. MAN ACCUSED AT RANSOM TRIAL
description: NEWARK, Oct. 19A youthful lawyer who represented a man charged with finding and keeping $50,000 in ransom money intended for the kidnappers of an 8yearold Dix Hills, L.I. boy last March testified today that an F.B.I. agent had instructed him on how his client should launder the money and secretly return it in order to be immune from prosecution.

title: Nets 105, Stars 89; Moses 19
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 18 Moses Malone made his pro debut tonight amid qualified raves. The 19 year  old Malone, who graduated from the high school ranks to the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association, stood in judgment before the New York Nets, who defeated his team, 10589; his teammates and a crowd of 10,463 at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Security Tightened at Troubled School
description: PERTH AMBOY, Oct. 18Perth Amboy's public high school, which was closed for two days this week because of student disturbances, will reopen next Monday under what Mayor Alexander F. Jakowski termed today a hardnosed plan to prevent troubles on the city's streets from interfering with our education system any longer.

title: BOND DEALER GUILTY OF CHEATING P.O.W.S
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)  A bond dealing concern was convicted today of horrible, vicious, brutal and diabolical fraud of 20 to 30 Vietnam prisoners of war, the Securities and Exchange Commission said.

title: Ford to Campaign for Dole
description: WICHITA, Kan. Oct. 18 (UPI)  President Ford will campaign for Senator Robert Dole, Republican of Kansas, at a fundraising rally on Nov. 2, the Senator's campaign chairman announced today.

description: The 70yearold owner of an Upper West Side butcher shop and two butchers were locked in a refrigerator for about 40 minutes last night while the police negotiated two gunmen into surrender.

title: Lingual lapses
description: ACROSS

title: A rich talent Ark of Bones By Henry Dumas. Edited by Eugene Redmond. 139 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $5.95. Paper, $2.95.
description: There is a shape to this posthumously published collection lent by the order in which the stories occur. Beginning with a simple, stunning fantasy of two black youths who are taken aboard an ark in the Sippi river, the imagination of the author moves steadily through a series of ideas that are more complicated, characters who are richer and better defined, all within the realm of black experience in the rural South and the urban North. The final, story, Fon, returns to a traditional Southern situationthe seemingly uppity black youth confronting rednecks. But nothing about it will tolerate comparison to its predecessors. Dumas had a rich and varied talent, and he was foremost original.

title: Notre Dame Picks Trustees
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 19 (UPI)  John D. Rockefeller 4th, president of West Virginia Wesleyan College, and Dr. Percy A. Pierre, dean of the Howard University School of Engineering, were elected trustees of the University of Notre Dame yesterday. Jane P. Cahill, a vice president for International Business Machines, also was elected a trustee, and Dr. 0. C. Carmichael Jr., of South Bend, chairman of the Board of Associates Corporation of North America, was reelected.

title: Ideas &Trends Education, Speech, Religion
description: Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks and Lillian Gish, stars of silent movies more than half a century ago, are now, through their films, helping a group of slowlearning ninthgraders in Queens with their reading and writing.

title: Bleak View From Masada
description: MASADA, Israel Both geographically and historically the grimmest view in Israel is that from the mountain fortress of Masada where less than a thousand fanatical patriots, known as the Zealots, held out for three years against the Roman Empire, after its legions took Jerusalem. Then, rather than yield, they slew each other and themselves.

title: Primitive Textiles on Display in Peters Valley
description: PETERS VALLEY  A colorful collection of primitive textiles, all of which were gathered during 3,000mile journey through droughtplagued West Africa, is now on display at the Peters Valley Crafts Gallery.

title: Korean Women's Leader Criticizes Ford Plan for Visit
description: Most South Koreans strongly oppose the planned visit of President Ford to their country next month, unless the visit is accompanied by a fundamental easing of political repression there, a Christian women's leader from Seoul said here last week.

title: Epilogue A Glance Back at Some Major Stories
description: President Ford has vetoed new legislation that would have made Governmentheld information more accessible to the public. The legislation was in the form of 17 amendments to the 1966 FreedomofInformation Act that authorizes persons to file a complaint in a Federal District Court to force a Government agency to produce information. It also authorizes the courts to punish officials if they did not comply. The bill, however, exempts foreignpolicy and nationaldefense information that has been classified secret by Executive order. One of the 17 new amendments to the bill would enable a petitioner now to ask that a Federal judge privately review classified information being sought and rule on whether it should in fact be classified or be made public. In vetoing the legislation that was passed overwhelmingly by Congress, but opposed by nearly all Government departments and agencies, President Ford said that he objected to the courts being permitted to make the initial classification decision in sensitive and complex areas where they have no expertise.

title: Nancy Olins Is Bride
description: The marriage of Nancy Jane Olins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Olins of Boston, to Jonathan Gans Axelrod, son of Mrs. Arthur Axelrod of New York and the late Dr. Axelrod, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. Rabbi Irwin M. Blank of Ohabei Shalom Temple in Brookline, Mass., performed the ceremony. The bride is a legislative assistant to Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin. Her husband is assistant general counsel for the Eastern conference of Teamsters in Washington.

title: Unbeaten Princeton Wins, 3324
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 19 Walt Snickenberger, latest in a long line of big name Princeton rushers, scored three touchdowns today and moved up three notches on the school's career rushing list while helping the Tigers defeat Colgate, 3324, and remain undefeated.

title: U.S. Judge Dismisses Suit On Dossiers of Dissidents
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP) A Federal judge has dismissed a threeyearold suit charging the police with unlawfully maintaining dossiers on dissidents.

title: Kissinger to Seek Arms Progress in Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Secretary of State Kissinger, will carry to Moscow next week concrete propositions on how to break the deadlock in the SovietAmerican talks on strategic nuclear arms, according to Administration officials.

description: The Daily News today endorsed Senator Jacob K. Javits for reelection, arguing in an editorial that the election of Ramsey Clark, his Democratic opponent, would be a shame upon the state and a danger to the nation.

title: Playground To Bombay Duck, $12.80
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 19 (AP)Bombay Duck took the lead shortly after the start and then held off High Steel, who rallied from last place with a halfmile left, to win the $87,700 World's Playground Stakes today at Atlantic City.

title: HARRY BERKEN
description: Harry Berken, a retired trumpet player and teacher, died Friday in South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside, L.I. He was 84 years old and lived at 869 Herman Avenue, Franklin Square, L.I.

title: Handbook on Birds For New Watchers Is in Heavy Demand
description: A handbook for beginning birdwatchers on one of the Federal Government's bestseller lists.

title: Nancy B. Brewster Wed to Ralph Ellis
description: Nancy Buell Brewster was married yesterday afternoon in Greenwich, Conn., to Ralph Edgar Ellis. The ceremony was performed in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. George A. Pera.

title: Early Electronic Items Given to Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Some early communication and computing products, ineluding at least seven that were the first inventions of their kind, were donated yesterday to the Smithsonian Institution by the Sony Corporation of Tokyo.

title: Book Ends
description: November. An uncommonly large number of biographical writings dominate the month of November, and a confessional note permeates some of the other major titles.... Traditional examples of the form are Sybille Bedford's life of her friend Aldous Huxley and Jean. Renoir's autobiography My Life and Films. ...William Manchester's The Glory and the Dream, a social history of America from 1932 to Watergate, covers the events of the author's own conscious lifetime.... Helter Skelter by Vincent Bugliosi with Curt Gentry recounts a California prosecuting attorney's biggest casethe Charles Manson murders.... Then there is A Time to Die by Tom Wicker, a soulsearching account of The New York Times columnist's involvement in the Attica uprising, during which he acted as an intermediary.... Myron (Myra) Breckinridge has his (her) story continued in a novel by Gore Vidal that is already being reported as a best seller by some stores.

title: How it is playing in Emporia
description: EMPORIA, Kan. When outsiders think of Kansas at all they are apt to dust off shopworn images of cow towns before the turn of the century, William Allen White's Emporia Gazette, Alf Landon in 1936, or the type of changeless life depicted in the movie Picnic with its opening longshot of mammoth Hutchinson grain elevators looming beside the Santa Fe tracks that stretch endlessly away into an allpervading flatness, moral, cultural, social, topographical, political.

title: Headliners
description: A mayor who is pessimistic about his city's future is no novelty, but Edward A. Hanna, mayor of Utica, N.Y., has gone a step further. In a news conference held last week, he called Utica a lousy place to live and urged its young people to leave. The mayor, a political maverick elected nine months ago to serve in the $1ayear job, has been embroiled in an ongoing battle with the city's business community. He has been upset with what he termed obstructionism toward any new business development in the city. The business community, he said, is just out to grab all the bucks. The fat enemies of our community are strangling the underdog and controlling the lives, the future and the destiny of the fine and wonderful little people.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: I don't know anything about Anne Hollander, but I do know that she doesn't know what she is talking about when she says in her review of Geoffrey Squire's Dress and Society (Aug. 25): The subject of dress has been largely neglected by serious students of art history.

title: Greenwich Foils Rally To Go 6D
description: Greenwich and Brien McMahon of Norwalk disposed of strong opposition yesterday to continue unbeaten.

title: Search for Subversives: Dwindling, but Not Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19In the House of Representatives' Cannon Office Building, Room 305 seems like many another in the rabbit warren of highceiling cubicles, but its contents have provoked more criticism and wrath than anything like it on Capitol Hill.

title: A Prixview
description: Charles Filandreux, celebrated authorphilosopher, addressed an American Legion meeting in Paris to promote his candidate for the Prix des Petits Monstres, an annual award for the best children's book: It is about the unmasking of a C.I.A. agent at BormeslesMimosas by a gang of small children and how the children roast the agent to death in a slow oven: Asked if he did not think the book a shade advanced for readers from 7 to 10, M. Filandreux assured.his American Legion audience, It will warm the cackles of heart.

title: Richard Miller Fiance of Isabel McCall
description: Mrs. John A. McCall has announced the engagement of her daughter, Isabel Ann McCall, to Richard Thomas Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin H. Miller of Medina, N.Y. Miss McCall is also a daughter of the late John A. McCall of New York.

title: 600 Contaminated Teabags Are Sought in F.D.A. Recall
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration is trying to track down 600 bags of burdock root tea that are contaminated with the drug atropine.

title: Javits Charges Clark Is Wrong On Issue of a Palestinian State
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits, in allday campaigning in the Bronx and Queens yesterday, reiterated his contention that the creation of a Palestinian state posed a grave threat to Israel's security.

title: Grange, Galloping Ghost, Reappears for an Award
description: Spry and wry, carrying his exact playing weight of 50 years ago, 170 pounds, Harold (Red) Grange bounded out of the stands yesterday at halftime of the IllinoisMichigan State game at Champaign, Ill., to receive yet one more award. This one was the understatement by half a century: the distinguished achievement citatation of the board of trustees of Grange's alma mater, the University of Illinois.

title: Questions & Answers
description: Q: CLEMATIS PRUNING Can clematis be pruned severely each year? My Jackmani flowers every summer but all the growth and flowers are at the top onethird. Can anyone tell me how pruning might correct this, and when? Mrs. R. B. T., West Hempstead, N. Y.

title: Grain Traders Believe Curb on Food Use In U.S. May Follow Ford Export Policy
description: The traditional flow of basic foodstuffs from American farms to the world market has been radically altered by President Ford's recent moves to monitor exports of grains and soybeans.

title: Valley Stream Wins, Perhaps
description: LYNBROOK, L. I., Oct. 19 Valley Stream North beat Lynbrook, 1210, in a Nassau Conference VII game here today, but then again, maybe it didn't.

title: The Man From Grand Rapids Is Still the Man From Gr...
description: WASHINGTONAlthough Gerald R. Ford has been President only a little more than two months, his public image has already been on a roller coaster. In August, he was widely viewed as a surprisingly able leader, saying and doing precisely what was required of a President in the wake of Watergate. Recently, he has been seen more as a politician of limited scope and purpose.

title: Pardoner and Pardoned
description: On the very day that President Ford triedin his historic appearance before a House committeeto persuade Congress and the American people that his grant of an unconditional pardon to Richard Nixon had been an act of statesmanship as well as compassion, Mr. Nixon responded by virtually taking the President to Federal court.

title: New Political Morality
description: WASHINGTONThe Committee on the New Political Morality will come to order. Our job is to screen all candidates for Federal office and we're going to clean up this country even if there is nobody left to run it. The first nominee will state his name.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The calendar of numismatic events for collectors is in its usual autumn conditionchock full.
