Major coin conventions, important auctions and small local shows all combine to create a situation in which any collector who wants to can be numismatically occupied every weekend for at least the next couple of months.

title: Carey Notches Fourth Shutout in a Row
description: Great Neck South found the Carey defense impregnable yesterday in a 36.0 defeat, but so has everyone else this season. Carey has racked up four straight shutouts.

title: With his ears on right Charles Ives Remembered
description: In the 1630's, William Ives, a ship's captain, brought settlers from England to New England, where he himself settled. One of his descendants, George Ives, became, at 17, the leader of a Civil War band (the First Connecticut Heavy Artillery). After the war, George Ives went home to Danbury, where he took a job in his father's bank to support his family and worked as the town's bandmaster to sustain his own quixotic spirit. He kept hearing sounds no instrument could play, so he invented several that could play them. He also liked to split his band in two, giv each half a different tune and send them off in different directions around the park. He wanted to hear how the music sounded as they came together. The town didn't take him seriously; but his son Charles, who as a boy played drums in his father's brass band, thought he was a great man.

title: Improving the Worker's Role
description: KRISTIANSAND, Norway To Einar Thorsrud the world is full of latent human potential just waiting to be discovered and unlocked.

title: Corrections
description: A sentence in Richard Elman's review of Vern E. Smith's The Jones Men (Sept. 29) read, It is a large accomplishment in the craft of fiction, providing once again that there isn't any substitute in novel writing for accurate, clear observation of people in action. The word.. providing should have been proving. In the issue of Oct. 6 the title of Tennessee Williams's Eight Mortal Ladies Possessed was incorrectly given as Eight Moral Ladies Possessed.

title: In Kerala, Smallest and Most Literate State in India, a Breakthrough in Birth Control Is Taking Place
description: TRIVANDRUM, India  A breakthrough in family planning is taking place in Kerala, the smallest and most literate state of India.

title: Rural Vernon Is Home, for Now, to a Restless Artist
description: VERNONErnst Aebi, a Swiss painter and graphic artist whose name is known both in this country and Europe, has designed and built his own home in the rural hills of Northwest Jersey. He is reasonably happy, but restless as an artist, and he is seeking new horizons.

title: Letters: Would Marx Tell Spencer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman M.P. Totes Gun and Plays a Mean Tackle
description: When Marlene (Mickey) LaMothe was attending Allentown High near Trenton, the varsity football coach wouldn't let her try out for the team. After graduation, she tried to join the Trenton police force but was refused because she was too short. So she joined the Women's Army Corps and satisfied both desires. Now she's a Military Policewoman, carries a.38 caliber pistol, a night stick and plays the defensive line in the Fort Monmouth sixWomen in Sports

title: An Assembly Report Ties Gang Rise Here To Movies and Media
description: Movies and the mass media have strongly influenced the resurgence of youth gangs the city, according to a report issued yesterday by the State Assembly's Subcommittee on the Family Court.

title: Jaworski Urges Watergate Disclosure
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 19 (AP)Leon Jaworski, the special prosecutor, in urging full disclosure on Watergate, said, There are some matters that the public has never heard about.

title: Jets and Colts Discover Victory Elusive in a Long, Long Season
description: The Jets meet the Baltimore Colts at Shea Stadium today in the. National Football League's Game of the Weak.

title: The World
description: Gloom remains the mostused word to describe the international economic outlook, and the gloomiest outlook last week was in Japan, where a key official said that his onceprosperous country was almost certainly heading for a depression.

title: Kings Rally To Defeat Suns, 9491
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 19 (AP)  Don May and Nate Archibald led a 40point team scoring spree in the fourth quarter that gave the Kansas CityOmaha Kings a 9491 victory over the Phoenix Suns in a National Basketball Association game today.

title: WILSON STRESSES INFLATION ISSUE
description: PORTCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 19 Governor Wilson contended today that his administration was better equipped than his Democratic rival's would be to deal with inflationrelated problems that affect the people of New York State.

title: Tristate Congressional Races: Outlook and Issues
description: In the Congressional campaigns in the tristate area of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the outlook is considerably bullish for Democrats and bearish for Republicans,

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Block Houses Tell Children Where to Turn in an Emergency
description: OSSINING, N. Y., Oct. 19No sooner did school start than the little red signs began appearing in windows around town. They popped up in the picture windows of the ranch houses on the hill, in the older Tudors and Cape Cods below, even in the grocery stores along the blighted downtown business district.

title: Two More From Britain: Not Good Theater
description: One reason we are so sorry to part with the invalids who die one after another in Peter Nichols's The National Health is that, for all their suffering, no play has ever happened to them. They have had spasms of pain, bouts of delirium, cardiac arrests, quarrels over nothing. They havein Arvin Brown's Long Wharf production, now transplanted to Circle in the Square uptown  interested us in their quirks, their unpredictable furies, their impatience at being kept alive by the dogoodery of British socialized medicine (You can't cure loneliness or ugliness or boredom.) And they have often been funny. How is the old fella? a senile wreck of a man wants to know after he has himself collapsed trying to help a chap running amok, catheter tube in hand. Humor is legitimately born of whatever can't be helped.

title: Can Valerie Harper, who is neither Jewish nor from New York, find happiness (and maintain her ratings) playing the role of a prototypical Jewish girl once she marries Joe, the buildingwrecker?
description: Valerie Harper was the only one on the Rhoda set who didn't seem to be overwhelmed by the fact that her new show was Number One in the Nielsen ratings that week. She was more concerned with the flies buzzing abcut her dressing room. She told the set decorator, an affable man named Warren Welch, I don't like the color of my flies. They don't match the lamps and the rug. Could I please have the flies in beige and yellow? Next, she worried about her father, who was returning to New Jersey after three months on his prune ranch in Santa Rosa in northern California. The other nine months of the year, she said in her exquisite Jersey City (not Brooklyn or New York) accent, he has a woman up there looking after the place. She's his prunesitter. After that, her thoughts drifted to her older sister Leah (a folksinger) and her younger brother Don (in the logging business in Oregon). What a crazy family, Valerie chuckled throatily. She's a conservationist and he's up there chopping down trees. She then settled down to her principal problem of the dayhow to get through her lunch of sliced turkey, salad and cantaloupe with enough moral strength to resist ordering more food, which would add to the admitted avoirdupois of five pounds she already is carrying on her oncesleek hips.

title: Betsy Spalla Plans Dec. 14 Bridal
description: Betsy Spalla, editor of The Pictorial, a weekly newspaper in Old Saybrook, Conn., will be married on Dec. 14 to Thomas Avery Whidden 2d, a partner in Sobstad Sailmakers, Old Saybrook.

title: Miss Aspinwall Becomes Bride
description: In the First Church of Christ (Congregational) in Farmingdale, Conn., yesterday morning, Susan Edith Aspinwall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Aspinwall of Farmington and Mystic, Conn., was married to John Michael Dann, son of Mr. and Mrs, John Hopkins Dann of Penn Hills, Pa. The Rev. Harland G. Lewis performed the ceremony.

title: Speeding Tickets Rise 100% in Suffolk Crackdown
description: It is Friday evening on the Long Island Expressway, and Suffolk County Police Officer John Newhoff, riding in an unmarked police car with Officer Rudolph Lazina, has just spotted a Cadillac that is weaving through the heavy citybound traffic at about 90 miles an hour.

title: Output of Industry In Soviet Up 8.2% In First 3 Quarters
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 19The Soviet Union today reported an industrial growth for the first three quarters of 8.2 per cent, well above the reduced growth rate planned for 1974.

title: Jewish history larger than life
description: Even within the turbulent context of Jewish history, the nineteenforties stand apart, larger than life. The holocaust, followed by the resurrection of the Jewish state, made those years the, ultimate challenge to Jewish existence, permanently changing the nature and meaning of Jewish life.

title: WILSON ASSAILED BY CAREY UPSTATE
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Oct. 19  Representative Hugh L. Carey charged here today that Governor Wilson was trying to pit New York City against the rest of the state.

title: Only Faye Dunaway Knows What She's Hiding
description: Bonnie and Clyde put Faye Dunaway on the cover of almost every major magazine. She became a fashion stylesetter, an Oscar nominee, and one of the most soughtafter stars in Hollywood. The height of Miss Dunaway's fame may have been reached the afternoon that Arthur Penn, the director of Bonnie and Clyde, turned to Warren Beatty, the film's costar, in a London restaurant and asked, Isn't that Faye over there? indicating a lovely blonde in a Bonnie beret and blouse. No, said Beatty. That's Brigitte Bardot.

title: 2,000 AT FUNERAL FOR DR. ARBOUIN
description: Two thousand persons attended a funeral service yesterday for Dr. Uvee Mdodana. Arbouin, copastor of Zion Temple Baptist Church, Richmond Hill, Queens, in Concord Baptist Church of Christ, Mercy and Putnam. Avenues, Brooklyn. Mrs. Coretta Scott King, widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and the Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. were present.

title: Rochester Reaches Hospital Pact Under New Labor Relations Act
description: A contract negotiated last week a Rochester hospital and the union representin its 680 employes is the first in the nation negotiated under newly enacted provisions of the NaNational Labor Relations Act (Taft  Hartley) for resolving healthcare dispute.

title: Model Home Heaves To in the Thames
description: LONDONOn a brilliant late September morning, London's Tower Bridge rose and a threebedroom house, complete with garage and landscaping, floated up the Thames. Fifty tons of cozy tract house, bolted to a catamaran, found a snug harbor at the end of Tower Pier in the heart of London tourist territory, hard by The Bloody Tower.

title: Paula Bromberg Wed To Irwin Weisbuch
description: Paula C. Bromberg, daughter of Mrs. Helen Bromberg the late Mr. Jacob Bromberg, was married here yesterday evening to Dr. Irwin Weisbuch, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Weisbuch. Rabbi Israel Miller performed the ceremony in the Fifth Avenue Synagogue.

title: Barbara Krussman Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Krussman of Harrison, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Marie Therese Krussman, to Frank A. Shea 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shea Jr. of Rye, N. Y. A wedding in May is planned.

title: Long Plays Decisive for N. Babylon
description: Six of Suffolk's 13 unbeaten teams lost yesterday, but North Babylon, the defending AA Conference champion and 1973 Rutgers Cup winner, extended its streak to 12 games with a 3412 victory over Brentwood Ross as Rich Freyer scored three touchdowns.

title: Southampton Limits Cluster Zones
description: SOUTHAMPTON  The building of apartments, already restricted in this East End community, was further curbed last week when the town board voted to limit cluster zoning to singlefamily residences. The clustering concept, which seeks to preserve open space, will no longer apply to multiple dwellings and condominiums. The new zoning ordinance amendment follows previous legislation that limited multipledwelling density to four units an acre.than the number Jot apartments called for by our master plan in the different hamlets, said Dr. Richard Nigro, the councilman who led the fight for the new zoning restrictions.

title: Theater/A virtual anatomy of social laughter. (Walter Kerr)
description: The very structure of laughter is caught in Alan Ayckbourn's range finder is the way Walter Kerr describes in the adjacent column Absurd Person Singular, which opened Oct. 8 at the Music Box to a chorus of chuckles from Mr. Kerr and other members of the generally delighted critical fraternity. Mr. Ayckbourn, the British author of Absurd Person Singular, has boldly put pen in hand and tongue in cheek to answer some questions submitted by the editors, as follows:

title: Energy, Utilities and the Cost of Money
description: Something new and important is happening to the electric utility industry.

title: 200 Policemen and Firemen Recover 120 Pounds of Explosives in Car on F.D.R. Drive
description: Nearly 200 policemen and firemen rushed to a Lower East Side section of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive late Friday to recover 120 pounds of high explosives that had been left in an abandoned car, the police said yesterday.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I have heard that wood radiator covers can decrease the amount of heat available by as much as half, so in view of the current energy crisis I'm thinking of taking mine off. However, the radiators need to be painted again. What kind of paint should use, and when is the best time to paint them?W.J.C., Mahwah, N. J.

title: Blue Shield Rise Rejected
description: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 19 (AP)  Without waiting for hearings, New Hampshire Insurance Commissioner Frank E. Whaland rejected yesterday the request of New HampshireVermont Blue Shield for a 28.7 per cent emergency rate increase.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The current surge of interest in photography as art is frequently hailed as something new and unprecedented, though in fact it is merely the latest upswing of a pendulum that has been tictocking up and down for over a contury. Wayback in 1885 the pendulum was also swinging up, and giving it a good push was the AngloAmerican physician and ethnographer Dr. Peter Henry Emerson. A group of his works is on exhibition at the Scott Elliott Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, through Nov. 9.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayWaterfall, Spring Valley Road, Ridgefield, Conn. Regular, local and children's working hunters; open and preliminary jumpers, adult horsemanship, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Mrs. Keating Carries Senate Campaign to Brooklyn
description: Barbara Keating, the Conservative candidate for the United States Senate, made an leightstop motorcade tour of Brooklyn yesterday in which she pressed her antibusing, antiabortion and antigovernment spending campaign themes and shook the hands of hundreds of friendly people.

title: Dance Pulcinelia' is one of those ballets that always seems to sound better than it looks. (Clive Barnes)
description: For an opera or a theater company, the basis of a classic repertory is no further away than. the nearest library. But in dance,, the difficulties of maintaining the past, or even preserving the present, are enormous. Yes, there are systems of dance notation that apparently work, but not even the Benesh and Laban methods, the two most widely distributed systems, are known by more than a relative handful of dancers. Certainly the past cannot really be referred to anywhere but on the stage.

title: Clarkstown South Wins Fifth, 276
description: Clarkstown South, the newest and winningest team in Rockland county Public School Athletic League football, registered its fifth straight victory, 276, over Ramapo, yesterday. North Rockland tied Tappan Zeee, 00, and Nyack was clobbered, 296, by Suffern.

title: Harris Replaces Hadl At Rams' Helm Today
description: The Los Angeles Rains' offensive machine, which rolled in high gear last season but is off to a sputtering strat this year, will have a new driver today.

title: Robbers Slay Man Aiding a Neighbor
description: A Richmond Hill man drawn from his home by the shouts of a neighbor who was being robbed on the street last night was shot to death by the robbers, who then fled, the police said.

title: Linda Rich Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Rich of North Woodmere, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Ann Rich, to Robert Gross, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Gross of Woodmere, L. I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: The Nation.
description: Congress will resume its consideration of Nelson Rockefeller's nomination for Vice President in about a month, having rejected his appeal for immediate hearings. But continuing revelations of his personal finances have increased prospects that the hearings will be lengthy and the substance controversial.

title: Richey Tops Rosewall by 76, 57, 61
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 19 (AP)Cliff Richey upset Ken Rosewall in the semifinals cif the $75,000 Australian indoor tennis championships today, 76, 57, 61.

title: Nuptials for Gail Lee Keenan And Paul Taylor Zantzinger
description: Gail Lee Keenan, daughter of Mrs. Albert J. Keenan Jr. of New York and the late Mr. Keenan, was married here yesterday afternoon to Paul Taylor Zantzinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Zantzinger of New York. The ceremony was performed in St. Thomas' Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Andrew, the rector. A reception was given at the Metropolitan Club.

title: An Aegean Festival Is Set in Wyckoff
description: WYCKOFF  Exotic foods and Middle Eastern artifacts will prevail at the second annual Aegean Festival that St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church will hold in the church hall next Friday And Saturday.

title: Growing Your Own Apple Harvest
description: Growing apples in the home garden is an absorbing and rewarding hobby, but it requires dedication. Otherwise, the enthusiast will not succeed. Most important, the home apple grower should be acquainted with the basic principles of success.

title: Crimson Rallies in ErrorFilled Game
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 19Who said Ivy League football was dull?

title: Ford Aide Predicts G.O.P. Will Lose 25 Seats in House
description: PASCO, Wash., Oct. 19 (AP) A political adviser to President Ford predicted today thatthe Republicans will lose about 25 House seats and three or four Senate seats in next month's election.

title: N. Carolina Turns Back N.C. State
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 19 (AP)  North Carolina scored three quick firstperiod touchdowns and went on to upset North Carolina State 3314, today behind the direction of Chris Kupec at quarterback.

title: Signs Here Shout Shush, As City Marks Quiet Day
description: Shhh said the big orange and red sign on the lamp post. Shhh read the cluster of balloons tied to the park bench. Shhh said one father to his son as he sounded out the word tacked to an iron fence.

title: ARMAND GREGOIRE, LAWYER, DIES AT 80
description: Armand Grgoire, a lawyer wno specialized in French and German cases, died Wednesday, in Rottenbuoh, Germany, at the home of his sister, Mrs. Suzanne Sperling. His age was 80, and he was a partner in Grgoire & Sargent, 200 Park Avenue.

title: Foster Parents Help to Increase Peregrine Falcons
description: PROVO, Utah, Oct 19Ornithologists have come up with a foster parents plan to increase the peregrine falcon population in the United States, which has declined drastically over the last 25 years.

title: ROCKEFELLER LISTS $24MILLION GIFTS TO AID CHARITIES
Blending Automation and Aesthetics
description: RICHMONDPhilip Morris, Inc., spent $200,000 last year to sponsor museum exhibitions and crafts shows but that sum is a small fraction of the corporation's support of the arts. The nation's second. largest cigarette company applies a full range of the visual arts, from architecture to landscaping and industrial design, in all of its operations.

title: Corona Garage Plan Fought
description: Plans for a public doityourself car repair facility are being opposed by angry residents of Corona, Queens, who will argue against the proposal at a city Board of Estimate hearing Thursday.

title: Economic Jitters Are Spreading Among Fishermen in a Booming Florida Town
description: APALACHICOLA, Fla. Daybreak is heralded at the Gibson Hotel in Apalachicola by the pigeons that roost under the hotel eaves. Their cooing starts tentatively as the first pigeon awakes, and then becomes a chorus. The first coos intrude only onto the third floor, and as all the pigeons join in, the sound spreads throughout the structure.

title: SEX BIAS CHARGED AGAINST 2 PAPERS
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 15Eighteen women reporters and editors for The New Haven Journal Courier and The New Haven Register filed sexdiscrimination charges against the two newspapers with the Federal Equal Employment Opportunities Commission in Boston this week.

title: Irate Fairfield Talks Secession Again
description: FAIRFIELD  For the second time in a decade, this borough is threatening to secede from Essex County in a dispute that centers on what local officials describe as home rule. The current argument can be traced to a move by the Essex County Improvement Authority, an autonomous body established by the state, to acquire Caldwell Airport; the airport, which is owned by the Curtiss Wright Corporation, is situated in Fairfield. It is not clear what the authority would do with the 278acre airport if and when it did take over the site.

title: Revisions in Mexican Laws Proposed To Aid Women and End Machismo
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 19The ancient and sacred Mexican cult of machismo'male superiorityis being threatened from a most unlikely quarter, the maledominated Mexican Government.

title: Buckeyes Win
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 19 (AP) Archie Griffin of Ohio State became the greatest rusher in Big Ten football history today as Ohio State routed Indiana, 499. Griffin gained 146 yards and scored two touchdowns.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
Shop Talk
description: With designers reviving all those peasant blouses, flapping capes and clunking boots, it was inevitable that the fad for things Russian would find its way to the head.

title: Rome Still Fiddles While Venice Sinks
description: We contributed to the saving of the temple of Borobudur with the help of the Indonesian Government, and the Egyptians cooperated in the international campaign for the Nile valley temples. In Venice we've spent hundreds of thousands of dollars and the time of our best people, and what has been accomplished? Zero. We feel like saying to the Italians, We'll stay friends, but let's not talk about Venice anymore.

title: Rangers Win, 42 On Islander Lapse
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 19 It is a harsh judgment to blame the loss of a game on one hockey player, but responsibility for the Islanders' 4.2 defeat at the hands of the New York Rangers tonight in Nassau Coliseum rests squarely on the shoulders of Dave Fortier.

title: The Region/Continued
description: Five and a half minutes of finished film. Here, 30 seconds showing Representative Hugh Carey posing with his 12 children. There, 30 seconds showing the panoply of a policeman's funeral, while a toughtalking expoliceman praises Governor Malcolm Wilson for supporting capital punishment for copkillers.

title: STAMPS
description: With the issue of souvenir cards for two major international philatelic exhibitions, the 1974 program of stamps and postal stationery of the United States Postal Service has come to a close. The first exhibition to be honored was that of the Philatelic Society of Sweden, STOCKHOLMIA 74, which was held in Stockholm in the latter part of last month. The card was made available at the show.

title: ART VIEW
description: American painting in the last two decades has passed through a period of unprecedented expansiveness  unprecedented, at least, in the history of American art. The success of the abstract expressionist movement in New York  coinciding, as it did, with the tragic decline of the School of Paris created an atmosphere of ambition unlike anything our native painters had known in the past. Since the midfifties, certainly, American painterseven,those who chose not to take abstract expressionism itself as their point of departurehave approached their task with the exhilarating sense of operating on a world stage.

title: Popgun Scarecrow Stirs Controversy
description: EAST BRUNSWICKThe battle of farmers to survive the onslaught of suburbia is being reflected here in a controversy over an explosive device used by local farmers to scare blackbirds away from their crops.

title: Connecticut Scores
Wende Devlin, Geoffrey Gates Married on L.I.
description: Wende Elizabeth Devlin, a freelance writer here, was married yesterday afternoon in Wainscott, L.I., to Geoffrey Gates, an investment banker here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:.

title: Bulldogs Set Back Columbia, 422
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 19 There was more than a shade difference today when the Old Blues of Yale met the Light Blues of Columbia in football. Undefeated Yale mauled Columbia, which has yet to win, 422.

title: Red Smith
description: For the first time in more than 40 years, the World Series was watched on an 18inch screen, measured diagonally, instead of from a seat behind a post. It was educational. One of the lessons learned by listening attentively was that pitchers in 1974 do not have speed, as they used to. Not even pitchers like Vida Blue. They have either velocity or acceleraSports tion and some have both.

title: LETTERS
description: I am writing to take exception to some of the remarks of Peter Weaver about economizing on life insurance, (The Personal Level: 10 Ways to Economize at Home, Oct, 6).

title: Carmen Biller Fiance Of Ann Louise Nenno
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Peter Nenno of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Louise Nenno, to Carmen George Biller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Biller of Westfield.

title: Murderer of Seven Women Is Reported Loose in Moscow and Wide Police Manhunt Gets Under Way
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 19Moscowployes policemen are conducting manhunt for a man apparently wanted for the murder of seven women in the Soviet tal, Soviet sources reported day.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: New Hampshire Warden Praises Report on Prison
description: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 19 (AP)  The warden of the New Hampshire State Prison says that a report recommending sweeping changes at the prison would probably be used in proposing legislation for reforms at the institution.

title: A Pervasive Fear Stalks Wards I. Mental Centers
description: Fear has become pervasive at the three massive state mental institutions on Wards Island where patients have been robbed, assaulted and raped, and where inadequate security enables criminals from the outside to enter the hospitals, sometimes with keys to the wards, and to victimize inmates and employes.

title: Big Green Edges Brown by 76
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 19  Some things never change. Brown, which has not been able to defeat Dartmouth in football since 1955, lost to the Big Green again today, 76, but only by the margin of a narrowly missed field goal attempt by Jose Violante early in the fourth quarter.

title: Marlboro Bows to Red dank
description: Undefeated Red Bank, ignited by two firstperiod touchdowns, blanked previously unbeaten, untied and unscoredupon Marlboro, 260, in Red Bank. It was Red Bank's 12th straight victory, and fourth this year.

title: Seattle Pioneer Is 105
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 19 UPIJoshua Green, Seattle pioneer and banker who has outlived all his insurance policies, celebrated his 105th birthday Wednesday holding hands with his wife, Missy, who will be 101 on Dec. 21. Mr.  Green, who began a second career as a banker when he bought the Peoples Savings Bank in 1926, was born in Jackson, Miss., and came to Seattle in 1886.

title: Petty, Stock Car Racing King Wants to Win Crown on Track
description: RichardPetty can virtually clinch his record fifth Grand National stock car championship by getting out of bed on time today and going over to the American 500 starting line at Rockingham, N. C. With ohly one other race remaining this season, Petty holds a 609point lead over Cale Yarborough in the complicated scoring.

title: FEW ISSUES FOUND IN EJECTION RACES ACROSS THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The year of the first doubledigit inflation in peacetime, the year of Watergate reckoning and of the first Presidential resignation in American history, has also become a campaign year in which national issues, in the conventional sense, have almost disappeared.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
A dancing, betting, racing, indispensable man
description: Few more formidable tasks, confront a biographer than to write a life of George Washington. The man had a long public career, the bibliographical materials are enormous, and the public conception of him as monument remains an obstacle in spite of efforts in recent years to establish his humanity. Such problems impress but do not daunt James Thomas Flexner, whose fourvolume biography of Washington won the 1973 National Book Award in Biography and a Special Citation of the Pulitzer Prize Committee for 1973.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Basketball

title: Dave Anderson
description: In winning a third consecutive championship, the Oakland A's accomplished in the World Series what the Miami Dolphins hope to accomplish in the Super Bowl game.

title: Nanette Guenther Wed To Matthew De Luca
description: In St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church here yesterday morning, Nanette F. Guenther of New York became the bride of Matthew J. De Luca, also of New York.

title: Planners Study Belmont As Transportation Hub
description: Preliminary plans being developed by Nassau County and New York City envisage turning underused Belmont Park raceway property into one of the nation's most advanced coordinated transportation centers.

title: C.A.B. Approves Increases In Air Fares and Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics board approved yesterday fuelrelated increases in air fares and rates in the Pacific and western hemisphere, while rejecting proposed 5 per cent rise in North and midAtlantic cargo rates.

title: RollsRoyce Plans Car To Sell for $72,000
description: LONDON, Oct. 19 (UPI)RollsRoyce, Ltd., is planning to bring out what its managing director says will be the most beautiful car in the world. It will be priced at $72,000.

title: Irish Rout Army, 480, On 4 Horsemen Day
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 19 On a dark and snowy October afternoon, 50 years after Notre Dame's most famous backfield had helped to beat Army and been christened the Four Horsemen, the latest version of Notre Dame football power trounced the Cadets, 480; today.

title: Jaworski Leaving Few but Big Issues
description: WASHINGTONThe day that President Ford pardoned Richard M. Nixon, lawyers at the Watergate special prosecution force were stunned. But it wasn't the pardon that stunned them. It was another announcement that same day that was the shocker: the agreement on Presidential tapes and papers. It had been drawn up in secret two days earlier without even consulting the Special Prosecutor.

title: Betty Blumstein To Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman L. Blumstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Betty Ann Blumstein, to David Andrew Sokol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barney Sokol of Edison, N.J. A December wedding is planned.

title: Band Goal: $60,000 for Orange Bowl
description: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIPThe Franklin Township High School Marching Band has new uniforms, an allnew show and a very special slogan: Our Goal, the Orange Bowl!

title: Mr. Overnite Wins
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 19 (AP)Mr. Overnite won the $8,000 Richfield pace by half a length at Freehold Raceway today, returning $6.40 for $2. Driven by Jim Larente, the victor covered the mile in 2:02 2/5. Wico Dares was second.

title: Rutgers Bus Plan Is Shelved
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A plan designed to allow elderly residents to ride free on Rutgers University campus buses has been shelved temporarily.

title: Blacks Desperate and Bitter Over the Effects of Inflation
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 19Richard Hebron, unemployed and looking for work since last December, admitted that he was getting desperate because of the nation's economic problems.

title: Port Unit Members May Face Inquiry
description: TRENTONThe ongoing controversy over a $550,000 gift from Nelson A. Rockefeller, the Vice Presidentdesignate, to Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, has generated demands for a legislative investigation in New Jersey and a possible confrontation involving Governor Byrne.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed ?? are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star must he translated as fair, two stars as good three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Exhibit Is Tribute To Corporate Art
description: SUMMIT  An interesting experiment in corporate art collecting is now on view at the Summit Art Center.

title: What's Doing in UTAH
description: THIS IS THE PLACEThese words uttered by Brigham Young when he first set eyes on the wilderness that was Utah in the mid19th century still hold true today. The state is considered the place by thousands of vacationers. And with the help of the jet age and the increasing popularity of winter sports, Utah has managed to shatter its old textbook image as a vast, inaccessible desert wasteland. The state encompasses no fewer than five great national parks, six national monuments and segments of nine national forests and three national recreation areas. The canyoncountry national parksZion, Bryce, Arches, Canyonland and Capitol Reefare open the year round, as are the Rainbow Bridge National Monument in the Glen Canyon Recreational Area and Dinosaur National Monument to the east. Estheticians insist the parks are at their best when snow covers just the tips of the Great White Throne, or the rim of Bryce Canyon, and the floors of the valleys remain snowfree, but for winter sportsmen skiable snow is the big attraction from midNovember to early May. Snow usually lathers peaks and canyons before Thanksgiving and lingers into summertime atop the mountains.

title: Echeverria and Ford Meet Tomorrow
description: MEXICO CITYFor a few brief hours tomorrow, the attention of the United States will focus fleetingly on her southern neighbor as President Ford and Mexico's President, Luis Echeverria exchange embraces and toasts during a oneday meeting at the Arizoria border.

title: Black Music '75, A Jazz Vaudeville, At Apollo Theater
description: Black Music '75 is an interesting experiment that does not quite come offit opened at the Apollo Theater on Friday. The format idea by the producermanager John Levy is to present known jazz artists of compatible musical styles, mainly modernist of the nineteensixties, on stage, one following another. Each plays a couple of pieces, and they all unite for a very brief jam session at the end.

title: U.S. Chooses 4 Riders for The National
description: Frank Chapot, a fivetime Olympic competitor, heads a group of four riders named by the United States Equestrian Team for the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, Nov. 512.

title: Folk Art on View At State Museum
description: TRENTONAn exhibition of folk art that opened at the State Museum yesterday is the biggest and most representative such display ever mounted in New Jersey. More than 3,000 objects from countries as diverse as Nigeria, Ethiopia, China, India, Iran, Turkey and Guatemala are on view.

title: Mary Burgess Is Wed to Scientist
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., yesterday afternoon, Mary Wysor Burgess became the bride of Dr. Edwin Manville Kellogg of Boston.

title: P.A.F. Cuts Budget But Keeps Its Season
description: HUNTINGTON STATIONThrough a number of major organizational changes, including the departure of its director and the dismissal of several technical personnel, the Performing Arts Foundation, generally known as P.A.F., has taken steps during the last two weeks to consolidate its efforts and give its operation a more secure base.

title: POLICE STUDYING JEWISH CUSTOMS
description: The habits, customs and religious observances of Jews in New York City are being studied by 3,000 policemen through A Guide to the Jewish Community of New York, published by the American Jewish Congress.

title: AtomicPlant Hearing Begins Wednesday
description: RIVERHEADThe Long Island Lighting Company will present its arguments for building two nuclear generating plants at Jamesport when the first combined state and local hearings proposed nuclearpower plants open here Wednesday.

title: LETTER
description: To the Editor: Twice within a matter of weeks, I've been grossly disappointed by two of the year's most colossal theatrical blockbusters, the revivals of A Moon for the Misbegotten and Gypsy. These two shows nave one thing In common that, I think, accounts for their successthe audience in each case is responding to a work's reputation, and to its stars, rather than to what is onstage before its eyes.

title: ...But in Minnesota's 6th, They Talk Economics
description: ST. CLOUD, Minn.A hint of snow dampens the air in the upper midlands these days, the messenger of an unyielding winter. It is a melancholy season, but it seems suitable to the mood of the electorate of Minnesota's sprawling Sixth Congressional District.

title: Adult Education: Tennis Is a Favorite Class
description: FORT LEE  If a spot check of adult schools throughout the state is any indication, more New Jersey residents than ever will be spending their leisure time on tennis courts.

title: Top Hydros Ready for Final Duel
description: Pride of Pay 'N Pak and Miss Budweiser, the boats that have monopolized the winnings on the unlimited hydroplane circuit for the last two years, meet today in the final regatta of the season in Daytona Beach, Fla. George Henley has piloted Pay 'N Pak to a national highpoint total that Miss Budweiser cannot make up in this last race. Pay 'N Pak was the winner of the Gold Cup in Seattle two months ago. At the last meeting of the thunderboats, in Madison, Ind., last Sunday, they dueled to what has become their accustomed finish  Pay 'N Pak first, Miss Budweiser second.

title: Carteret Loses to Unbeaten Colonia, 216
description: Colonia gave up its first touchdown of the season yesterday but rolled to a 216 victory over Carteret in a battle of unbeaten teams at Colonia.

title: Letters
description: Hedge against inflation

title: Food
description: Sydney Smith, the English essayist, once described how far distant he was from civilization by noting he was 12 miles from a lemon. We feel similarly. The lemon, like the raspberry and the lime, is one of God's finest creations. With out it some of the world's greatest sauces would be impoverished. There would be no such thing as a cold lemon souffl, which makes a pleasant ending to a dinner. Happily, lemons are in good supply 12 months a year.

title: But They Talk in Rome of Laity, Liturgy, Family and Youth
description: ROME  When the Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops opened here last month, it was inevitable that the church which calls itself universal and apostolic, but which resembles other institutions in depending on fragile men for its noblest purposes, should show the seams in its garment.

title: Susan Klein Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Klein of New Hyde Park, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Linda Klein, to Douglas H. Firestone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Firestone of Bellerose, L. I.

title: Midtown Ft. Worth Gets Water Garden Of Unusual Design
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 19The Fort Worth Water Garden, a $6.5million quiet spot covering four and a half blocks of the downtown area, was opened to the public today after ceremonies marking its presentation to the city.

title: Antaeus Magazine
description: Despite some recent testimony (The arts, you knowthey're Jews, they're left wing in other words, stay away), the activity most practiced nowadays among consenting American adults is literature. Last year we published fifty novels a week, for instance. The short story is out of fashion, and yet literary journals report that they often have as many contributors as subscribers, while poetry magazines are as abundant, if as transient, as dewdrops. These underworlds of literature, the journals that pay contributors mainly in fame and offprints and that suffer from a chronic shortage of advertisers and subscribers, still enjoy a reputation left over from the 1920's, when Joyce, Pound, Eliot and the rest were to be found there; they are thought to be places where the weirdest flowers of literature grow wild in a kind of Rappacini's garden. They are not, however. Truly innovative writers soon rise to the top nowadays; even the staid New Yorker quickly gave houseroom to Donald Barthelme's complex pastiches and Ann Beattie's sophisticated neorealism. The quarterlies function differently,

title: Dry Spell Is Over For Dobbs Ferry
description: It took six years, four coaches and 48 games before Dobbs Ferry ended the longest streak wthout vletory in New York State.

title: Coast Jews Tested for Rare Disease
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 19Louis Weinstein and his wife, Laura, who is two months pregnant, sat in a crowded room at the Jewish Community Center here, staring at a fourpage questionnaire while they nervously waited their turn to give blood samples.

title: News of the Stage
description: Ten years ago, Dustin Hoffman assisted Ulu Grosbard in the direction of a successful Off Broadway revival of Arthur Miller's A View From the Bridge.

title: All the World's a Game Board
description: For an example of life mimicking art, take the case of Ralph Anspach.

title: LABOR SHORTAGE PLAGUES PRAGUE
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 19 (AP)A ??rious labor shortage is playing havoc with Czechoslovakia's consumer and service industries.

title: Notes: A Boston Park In the Spirit of '76
description: FOR many a pilgrim, attempting to assimilate Boston's wealth of Revolutionary history has been like trying to drive a car around the city: it takes an expert to find his way. Little has been done to bring cohesion to Boston's string of scattered properties that are closely associated with the earliest history of the United States. The deterioration of some of the buildings, notably the Old State house (1713), has further spoiled the experience. The lack of central authority for the sites, which are owned by a variety of public and private agencies, has contributed to the malaise.

title: Kidnapping Hoax by Girl Sends 25 Detectives on Search for a Gang
description: A 15yearold girl who has a commonlaw husband and a child staged an elaborate kidnapping of herself here that sent 25 detectives on a search for a nonexistent Bronx street gang. The girl concocted the hoax early this month to cover up the fact that she had lied when she said she had a job. When pay day came, she knew her husband and her family would expect her to come home with money, which she did not have.

title: Sobell, in New Book, Says He and Wife Fled Country to Avoid Perjury Charge
description: Morton Sobell, who was convicted in 1951 with Julius and Ethel Rosenberg of conspiracy to commit espionage, says he and his wife had feared perjury prosecutions for having falsely signed nonCommunist affidavits in defense work. He says they went to Mexico in June 1950, for that reason.

title: St. Joseph, Barringer Win With Standout Aerial Shows
description: Mike Tanner of St. Joseph of West New York and Pete Velardi of Barringer staged impressive passing shows yesterday to keep their teams unbeaten.

title: Dr. Edward A. Burkhardt, Internist Here, Dies at 70
description: Dr. Edward A. Burkhardt, specialist in internal medicine and a past president of the New York County Medical Society, died Friday at his home at 17 East 75th Street. His age was 70.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: LOS ANGELEShiles C. Stein, by his own admission, never was a good musician, never had a hand in making a movie, a television series or a record album. Nor dots he consider himself particularly close to the big names of the Hollywood establishment, although he and his wife, Doris, are well known for frequent lavish parties in their Beverly Hills mansion.

title: Dance: The Joffrey as Social Historian
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet as social historian was one aspect of the company that came to mind again Friday night at the City Center when two of its ballets were seen for the first time this season.

title: Roger Harris Marries Rosalie Morosani
description: Rosalie Morosani, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rmy Edmond Morosani of Litchfield, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Roger Douglas Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Potter Harris Jr. of Essex, Conn. The ceremony was performed in St. Michael's Episcopal Church by the Rev. David Gurniak.

title: A U.S. Company Spread News of Mexico Oil Find
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19By offtherecord telephone calls and selective distribution of an internal memorandum, a major United States oil company has brought to the world's attention the discovery of what the company says is a major oil field in Mexico.The Government of Mexico has said that newspaper accounts of a field with 18 billion to 20 billion barrels of oil  twice the reserves of Prudhoe Bay, Alaska  were exaggerated, but it has not released other estimates. The memorandum that inspired the initial press accounts said that its conclusions were partly based on information obtained indirectly from officials of Pemex, Mexico's state oil monopoly.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: We have a recession. But it is a most unusual recessiona recession for which there is no precedent in history.

title: Augustana Runners Win
description: LOMBARD, Ill., Oct. 18 (AP)Augustana College and St. Francis College dominated a fivemile crosscounty event today in qualifying for the national meet next month in Salinas, Kan. Augustana won the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics meet with low score of 27 points with five runners in the first 15 finishers. St. Francis was second with 29.

title: The Nation /Continued
description: WASHINGTONIs it pure coincidence that some of the most compelling views about political people this fall are or over the borderline of their private livesNelson Rockefeller's giftgiving and Wilbur Mills' nightlife?

title: B. U., Harvard and Cornell Again Loom As College Hockey Leaders in the East
description: Featuring soaring attendance, growing national attention and markedly improved personnel, American college hockey opens its longest season ever with a major intersectional clash this weekendtwo games between Vermont and Wisconsin at Madison, Wis.

title: After War and Watergate: The Sounds of Music
description: John Adams, writing to his wife from France in 1780, cast the ultimate objectives of the American Revolution in cultural terms. He predicted that their grandchildren would live in a nation in which the arts would be central. But Adams's dream was not fulfilled. Indeed, as it turned out, one of his great grandchildren, Henry Adams, felt that his education, modeled after the precepts of John Adams, had illprepared him for life. He became so disgruntled, in fact, that he once scathingly characterized his estheticallyinclined father as bricabrac from the time of Louis Phillippe.

title: Evelyn Oakes, Peter Buswell Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Oakes of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., have made known the engagement of Mr. Oakes's daughter, Evelyn Anderson Oakes, to Peter Croft Buswell. He is the son of Mrs. Henry Leslie Croft Buswell of Gloucester, Mass., and Surfside, Fia., and the late Mr. Buswell.

title: Michigan Governor Signs Car Repair Shop Regulation
description: LANSING, Mich., Oct. 19 (AP)A tough state law regulating auto repair shops was signed yesterday, with its provisions taking effect piecebypiece until 1978.

title: E. CHARLES CONWAY
description: E. Charles Conway, who had been president and a director of AID, Inc., of Philadelphia from its inception in 1964 until 1970, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 61 years old.

title: CITY IS CRITICIZED ON BUDGETMAKING
description: Conscious deception is part of New York City's budgetmaking, the chairman of the State Charter Study Commission said yesterday.

title: The Whole Truth Is Not the Aim
description: The continued seclusion of Richard Nixon at San Clemente, as the Watergate coverup trial opened last week, raised again the question whether this trial can expose the whole truth of what happened in the White House in 1972 and 1973. So did the apparent intention of defendant John Ehrlichman to picture Mr. Nixon as having been architect and manager of the coverupa version of events quite different from the one he gave the Ervin committee in 1973.

title: Clam Areas Are Reopened
description: BOSTON, Oct. 19 (AP)Two soft shell clam harvesting areas in Ipswich, closed in August because of paralytic shellfish poisoning, were reopened by the State Department of Public Health yesterday.

title: State's Community Mayors Name Wilson Man of Year
description: The Community Mayors of New York State named Governor Wilson man of the year last night during its annual charity ball at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: News of the Screen
description: The dramatized lives and times of a halfdozen classical composers are headed toward the screen in feature films now being started by Ken Russell (Women in Love, The Devils, etc.) for the Britishbased Good Times Enterprises. The agreement, according to a Good Times spokesman, is the result of the boxoffice success in Britain, France and Austria of Mahler, with Robert Powell as the composer, in a feature that Mr. Russell wrote and directed for the company.

title: Fairleigh Alumni Put to Test
description: RUTHERFORD  Fairleigh Dickinson University has adopted an unusual procedure for admitting secondary school graduates to its branches in Teaneck, Madison and Rutherford.

title: Union and Voters League Join Inquiry
description: RIVERHEAD  Two unusual interventions by citizens organizations are to mark the first combined state and local nuclear power plant hearing, which begins here Wednesday.

title: Lone Davis Betrothed
description: The engagement of Lorie Robin Davis, a student at Herbert H. Lehman College, to Randy David Wald has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Davis, parents of the future bride. Her fianc, also a student at Lehman College, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Wald. Both families are of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: New MedicalCare Plan Is Proposed in Assembly
description: TRENTON A new effort to promote better medical care in congested cities and isolated rural areas has been proposed by the Assembly's minority leader.

title: LAW ON LANGUAGE STIRS MONTREAL
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 19  A group of Englishspeaking businessmen were meeting with a French Canadian municipal official here the other day, speaking in English, as the same group had done in the past. Suddenly, the official halted the discussion.

title: Oklahoma Trounces Colorado; Air Force Wins
description: BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 19 (AP)Secondranked Oklahoma uncorked four lethal, long, rapid fire scoring drives in the first half and routed Colorado 4914 today as Joe Washington carried 18 times for 200 yards and four touchdowns.

title: Dark Hired To Manage A's Again
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 19 (4P)Charles O. Finley, owner of the world champion Oakland A's, said today that Alvin Dark had accepted his affer to manage the team again during the 1975 baseball season.

title: The Region In Summary
description: The national economy, about which state leaders can do relatively little, Is nonetheless the issue that is dominating the gubernatorial campaigns in both New York and Connecticut.

title: Another Shutout Upset for Paramus
description: Paramus staged its second major upset in two weeks yesterday when it defeated. powerful Passaic Valley, 220, in Paramus behind a twor touchdown, 110yard performance by Ken Maxwell.

title: Kenneth Oppenheimer to Wed Elizabeth Blanchard, Teacher
description: Elizabeth Brooks Blanchard, a teacher at the Shepherd School in Cupertino, Calif., and Kenneth Ralph Oppenheimer, a candidate for a Ph.D. at the Stanford University School of Engineering, will be married in December.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: GROSS. NATIONAL PRODUCT fell 2,9 per cent in real terms in the third quarter; it rose 8.3 per cent in current dollars. . Personal income rose $8.8billion [annual rate] in September, but a slackening in the rate of increase was noted for the first nine months of this year. .. . Industrial production rose 3.3 per cent in September to 125.5 per cent of the 1967 base but was 2.2 per cent below the yearearlier level.

title: Students Helping Consumers
description: MOUNT HOLLYThe Burlington County Office of Consumer Affairs, having failed in one effort to discover false or deceptive advertising, has reoriented its program and is still optimistic of success.

title: The WorkingClass Majority
description: By Andrew Levinson. 319 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $8.95.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Books: Three Looks at Horse Racing
description: Five years after tucking their hair under a crash helmet and breaking the sex barrier, America's women jockeys have become an accepted part of the racing world.

title: SWISS BALLOTING ON ALIEN OUSTERS
description: BERNE, Oct. 19The people of Switzerland are being asked this weekend to vote on a referendum that officials and clergymen say could result in economic suicide, cause untold human misery, soil their flag and their souls and stai?? their world reputation as a nation of neutrality and refuge.

title: Beats Far Rockaway, 228, for 17th Straight Bayside
description: Unbeaten Bayside breezed to a decisive 228 victory over previously undefeated Far Rockaway yesterday as the visiting Commodores racked up their 17th consecutive victory over a threeseason span.

title: Drake Edges Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 19 (UPI)Drake won its first game of the season today, 3835, from Louisville and set three school records: most rushes (71), most yards rushing (445) and total offense (579).

title: 32 Nations Close to Starvation
description: In the judgment of United Nations experts, 32 countries in the world are so poor and so short of food that crop failures and the high prices of grain, fertilizer and petroleum threaten them with bankruptcy and their people with starvation.

title: MILDRED K. CORNWELL
description: Mildred Kirkham Cornwell, widow of Dean Cornwell, the muralist and magazine illustrator, died at her home in Glens Falls, N.Y., yesterday. She was 80 years old.

title: Newspaper to Close
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Oct. 19 (UPI)  Inflation and low reader interest were reasons cited today by the publisher for the discontinuation of the San Bernardino Telegram, effective Monday. It is an afternoon paper,

title: Brandt on Mission in Lisbon
description: LISBON, Oct. 19 (AP)Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, flew into Lison today to give a helping hand to the Portuguese Socialist party in its coming electoral contest with Portugal's wellorganized Conlinunists.

title: CHESS
description: MOSCOWLev Polugaevsky has earned the reputation among his Soviet compatriots as a player who falters when the chips are down, but who is capable of great success when less is at stakehis recent results bear that out.

title: Special Band Wins Success
description: GREAT NECKWhen The Hotshots rocked into a swinging version of Leroy Brown and later eased into the quiet, soulful strains of Killing Me Softly, listeners might justifiably have assumed they were hearing a nicely meshed, talented dance band.

title: State G.O.P. Is Pessimistic on congressional Races
description: TRENTONWith Election Day just two weeks off, the state's Republican leaders are expressing deep concern over the chances of a majority of New Jersey's seven incumbent G.O.P. Representatives.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1974

title: Getting the Jump On Spring Planting
description: Soil is much easier to work now than in spring when everything tends to be cold and muddy from winter freezes and heavy spring rains. There is another advantage, the garden will be ready to plant earlier in the season.

title: Mrs. Frankel, Designer, Wed
description: Virginia Frankel and Benjamin Vaiden Wright Jr. were married here yesterday afternoon by Paul Milgiore of the Ethical Culture Society at the home of the bridegroom.

title: Uniform State Code On Obscenity Due
description: TRENTONThe State Attorney General's office plans to draft a uniform obscenity enforcement code so as to insure that New Jersey's 21 counties receive equal treatment under the law.

title: Democrats' Outlook Bright in Illinois
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 19If this were a normal political year it would be difficult to find anyone in the 10th Con. gressional District willing to bet on a transplanted liberal from Chicago in a race against a proudly conservative Republican incumbent.

title: FlightInstruction Law Is Challenged
description: LINDEN  On July 12, 1973, Tom Brzoska, a federally licensed commercial pilot and flight instructor, received a summons at Linden Airport for giving flight instruction without a New Jersey fixedbased operator's license.

title: Audubon Unit to Hear Coheleach on Wildlife
description: DENVILL  Guy Coheleach, a wellknown wildlife artist, will be the guest speaker tomorrow at the monthly meeting of the Morris Highlands Audubon Society. The meeting will be held at 8 P.M. at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sci ences, Normandy Heights and Columbia Roads, Morristown.

title: Chemical Company to Build Shopping Center
description: The Drew Chemical Corporation has announced plans to construct a shopping center, an industrial park and a new corporate headquarters on a 100acre wooded site the company owns in Boonton, N. J., 10 miles west of Paterson in Morris County.

title: NEW BAIL PROGRAM RECEIVING PRAISE
description: We give defendants a second chanse, said Philip Leshin, director of the Bail Revaluation Program of the Department of Correction.

title: Wood, Field & Stream Thoughts for Under the Tree
description: A message to the women: Christmas isn't so very far away, and if your husband, son or boy friend is a fisherman or a hunter, a good book on the subject dearest to his heart would bring him pleasure.

title: Italian Bus Crash Kills 4
description: VENICE, Italy,. Oct. 19 (AP) A bus carrying Yugoslav tourists went out of control and overturned today on the VeniceTrieste highway, killing four persons and injuring 50.

title: Senate Sifts Watchdog Plan
description: TRENTON  Two resolutions seeking to create a watchdog over the progress of newly enacted legislation are before the Senate Committee on Conference and Coordinating.

title: The Dragon in The Ghetto Caper
description: His contemporaries are all jocks but not Andrew J. Chronister. At age eleven and one half he plans to be a detective Famous, tough and cool. Like Ellery Queen, fop God's sake. Andrew lives in Foxmeadow, a select community built around a golf course (physically and spiritually). It is not fertile ground for crime. To occupy himself Andy draws and paints dragons. That's how he meets Edie Yakots. She lives in Foxmeadow too and is very interested in dragons. Edie becomes Andy's secret sidekick. All the great detectives have had sidekicks but not one exactly like Edie. She is 29, a grownup pretty person .. for God's sake, and insistently fey.

title: A Spark, an Amis, a Rhys
description: A Modern Morality Tale, the subtitle of Muriel Spark's new short novel, would have wagged just as well behind the titles of her other novels, of which there are 12, some long, some short, most of them waggish moralities. In the first dozen, secular materials spell out lessons in theology. In the new novel, theological props point to immorality in politics. The setting, to mention names, is the Abbey of Crewe; the immoralities are those of Watergate.

title: Bellmore Kennedy Not Hurt by Layoff
description: Bellmore Kennedy had not played since Sept. 28, because of a strike by teachers in the BellmoreMerrick school district, but the strike has ended and Bellmore, judging by yesterday's 2812 victory over East Meadow, has not been wasting its time, between games.

title: In Chester, the Mayor Doubts It's Time for Change
description: CHESTERI'm probably a little bit different from the average guy who gets involved in politics, Joe Filiberto said. I don't go out seeking publicity. But I've got some guys on the Borough Council who get very upset if some other guy gets his name in the paper more than they do.

title: Thassos, the Greenest of All the Fabled Isles of Greece
description: SAY Thassos to a Greekin New York, Paris or Athensand there will be a flush of ethnic pride a smile, a wistful sigh: It's so green there! Among all the islands in that vast sea from Gibraltar to Anatolia, Thassos is the greenest. And it is otherwise blessed: Fragrant honey, peaches and grapes ... a constant fresh wind from the Bulgarian hills, only 40 miles away ... a score of beaches and dozens of protected coves ... a surprising number of modern comforts for the visitor, in a setting rich in the traces of the just.

title: Susan Iles Is Bride Of Paul O'Leary
description: Susan Gray Iles and Paul Howard O'Leary, 1974 graduates of Syracuse University, were married last evening in St. Albans Episcopal Church in Syracuse. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald R. Grindy, rector of St. Albans, and the Rev. Joseph P. Schick of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Margaret Mary in South Windsor, Conn.

title: Kathleen Gorman Bride Of Meredith B. Colket 3d
description: The marriage of Kathleen Stevens Gorman to Meredith Bright Colket 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Colket Jr. of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, took place in Princeton, N.J., yesterday afternoon.

title: Jane Phillips, Richard Dillon Have Nuptials
description: Jane Anderson Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Creighton W. Phillips Jr. of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday noon to Richard Charles Michael Dillon, sales manager of the Goffstown (N.H.) News Corporation, publisher of four weekly newspapers in New Hampshire.

title: Law Student Fiance of Nikki Finke
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Finke of Sands Point, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nikki Jean Finke, to Jeffrey Wayne Greenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice R. Greenberg of New York.

title: Is Ended By Clemson
description: CLEMSON, S. C., Oct. 19 (AP)Clemson's sometimes porous defense repelled Duke three times inside the 10yard line today as the Tigers ended a fourgame winning streak by the Blue Devils, 1713, in an Atlantic Coast Conference football game.

title: No Respite in Ulster
description: If Prime Minister Wilson had expected Britain's general election to produce even a brief respite from violence and murder in Northern Ireland, he was soon disabused. The very first postelection meeting of his Cabinet was an emergency session on Ulster which resulted in the decisions to send 600 more British soldiers to the troubled province and to continue the policy of interning suspected terrorists without trial.

title: CLARK VOWS FIGHT TO PROTECT WOODS
description: Dappled by sunlight in a wooded glade, Ramsey Clark told 200 hikers on Staten Island yesterday that he would, fight to protect the Greenbelt and other natural areas from the enchoachment of highways.

title: The Diary of a TeaMad Tour Through the Scottish Highlands
description: AS we set off for the Scottish Highlands, the prediction is sunny with thunderous intervals. Our course lies vaguely north from Glasgow. We go without compass, folded four deep into a borrowed car; wife Mary, daughter Susan and son Mark are all in good folding spirits.

title: Music/Recording
description: When Charles Ives died 20 years ago, he must have sensed that the world was beginning to catch up with him. His Third Symphony (190112) had won the Pulitzer Prize in 1947, the Second Symphony (1901) finally received its first full performance in 1951, and in John Kirkpatrick he had found a masterful interpreter of his piano music, particularly the devilishly demanding Concord Sonata. There was even a fair amount of his music available on records in those daysNicolas Slonimsky's pioneering disk of Washington's Birthday was the first composition by Ives to be recorded, in 1935, and by 1954 there were versions of such important Ives works as the two piano sonatas (William Masselos and Kirkpatrick), the Second String Quartet (Walden Quartet), the Second Symphony (conducted by F. Charles Adler on SPA), Three Places in New England (Walter Hendl leading the American Recording Society Orchestra) and a magnificent collection of songs sung by Helen Boatwright accompanied by Kirkpatrick on the Overtone label.

title: The Harkness Doesn't Deserve To Go on Welfare
description: For more than a decade Rebekah Harkness has been pouring dollars into ballet. Ballet has not received anything of any particularly lasting value from this, so one trusts that Mrs. Harkness has had a swell trip, A few days ago the Comptroller of the Harkness Ballet Foundation, Theodore Bartwink, announced that the Harkness Ballet was on the skids. It will disband unless it can raise $1 million by March 31, 1975. The organization is said to be seeking funds from public and private sources. After years of unsuccessful endeavor, Mrs. Harkness is letting her pet plaything attempt to welfare.

title: Poly Prep Turns Back McBurney
description: Poly Prap scored an 80 victory over McBurney in a hardfought contest at Poly Prep yesterday. Ben Preziosi and Jerry Del Core, safeties, led the Poly defense and Dennis Fiorentino scored the touchdown on a 1yard sneak.

title: Museum's Young Acquisition
description: People are always rediscovering the Brooklyn Museum, says Michael Botwinick, new director of the great but impoverished treasure house that sits across the river from Manhattan's glamorous Metropolitan. They ooh and ah about its collections, then go away and forget it. When they come back five years later, they're dazzled all over again.

title: Wesleyan Defense Stops W.P.I., 2112
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 19  An alert Wesleyan University defense picked off four passes and recovered two fumbles by Worcester Polytechnic Institute to give the Cardinals a 2112 triumph over the Engineers today.

title: City Council Sessions Scheduled This Week
description: The City Council will meet on Tuesday at 1:30 P.M. in City Hall. It will also hold several committee meetings open to the public, all in City Hall.

title: WHAT WE HAVE LOST
description: We are living in an epoch of great disillusionment. We are beginning to suspect that to fulfill a hope is to defeat it, and to make a dream come true is to turn it into a nightmare. For a moment, it seemed to us that we had arrived, that we had solved all material problems and could sit back and enjoy an eternal Sabbath. But we are discovering that the more triumphant our techology the less does society function automatically. In a time of widespread automation nothing happens automatically. You have to push and pull, threaten and beg if you want anything done. By mastering matter we have drained material factors of their potency to shape events. Look what has happened to money! Money cannot induce people to work harder or longer hours. Money cannot cure chronic poverty. Money cannot buy personal security. It was a shock to a materialistic civilization to discover that the most important facts about a human entity are its illusions, its fictions, its unfounded convictions. A society without illusions is without vigor and without order and continuity. It took a triumphant technology to demonstrate the truth of St. Paul's words that things which are not are mighter than things that are.

title: Police Officer Weds Marita A. McGrath
description: In St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Marita A. McGrath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. McGrath of Marco Island, Fla., and Milford, Conn., formerly of Greenwich, was married to William G, Kristoph, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Kristoph of Byram, Conn. Msgr. James J. McLaughlin performed the ceremony.

title: Lorene Stefan Wed To Peter Y. Gevalt
description: Lorene Claire Stefan, a mortgageloan officer with the Chemical Bank of New York, and Peter Young Gevalt, a senior associate of the Eastdil Realty Company, Inc., were married yesterday afternoon at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Charles Ives, Musical Inventor
description: It is by now a commonplace that the one man who established and transmitted the laws of American musicsinglehandedly and seemingly parthenogeneticallywas Charles Ives (18741954), the hundredth anniversary of whose birth we celebrate today. In an appropriately pragmatic American manner, Ives created a selfbegotten musical tradition simply by abrogating the prevailing esprit de docher provincialisms and the cozy Teutonic harmonies and forms of orthodox nineteenth  century American composers like Paine, Chadwick, Foote, and Ives's own teacher Horatio Parker.

title: 76er's Sink Knicks; Cunningham Stars
description: Billy Cunningham had to look at the uniform numbers to make sure they were still some of the same Knicks he last saw before he jumped to the American Basketball Association two years ago. So did many of the 15,682 fans at Madison Square Garden last night as the Knicks faltered in the second half and were battered by the Philadelphia 76ers, 9986.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: When Henry A. Kissinger won the Nobel Peace Prize last year, he announced that he was donating his share of it (which he split with Le Duc Tho, of North Vietnam) to establish a scholarship fund for children of American servicemen killed or missing in action in Indochina.

title: Diagramless, 23 by 17
South Shore Defeats Canarsie
description: Richie Caracappa and Cecil Charter played on both offense and defense for undefeated South Shore yesterday and Carnarsie, their Brooklyn neighborhood rival, felt their presence both ways.

title: Auto Insurance: Rates May Rise
description: TRENTONThe next 10 days or so should tell whether it will he the state's motorists or the automobile insurance companies that will come out on the short end of a tugofwar between declining accident rates and rising costs generally.

title: Realties in Black and White uolsog
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C.Here I am, a transplanted Yankee down South watching the tube as a mob of angry whites in South Boston scream Nigger! and beat a black man who is on his way to pick up his daughter at school. I can't believe it. Are these ghostly flickerings of memory or old newsreel films played by accident? Wasn't this sort of thing over with years ago when smoldering racial hatred flared in the South and was snuffed out by the rest of the nation?

title: Alison Parker to Be a Bride Jan. 4
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Parker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Parker, to Kimball Lief Kenway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert P. Kenway of Marblehead, Mass.

title: Why Are College Kids in a Lather Over TV Soap Operas?
description: It's a gray afternoon in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The time is 1 P.M. A television set glowing dully across the room is tuned to All My Children, a serial tale of frustrated love among constantly distraught young adults.

title: Philippine Crop Is Damaged
description: MANILA, Oct. 19 (AP)Two typhoons that battered the Philippines' main island of Luzon early this week damaged about $17.8 million worth of rice crops, the Government said today. The typhoons, Bess and Carmen, left at least 30 persons dead and seceral others missing.

title: Jane Elizabeth Martin Is Bride Of Stuart Symington Orrick Jr.
description: St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Rochester was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Jane Elizabeth Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Harwood Martin of Honeoye Falls, N. Y., to Stuart Symington Orrick Jr., son of Mr, and Mrs. Orrick of Rochester.

title: Tossing the Bowls in Park
description: John Hallock has spent the last 30 years tossing the bowls at the Brooklyn Lawn Bowling Club, the oldest one of its kind in the United States. Mr. Hallock is one of only 29 elderly persons who still consider lawn bowling to be Brooklyn's most gentlemanly sport, and he remembers the days when doctors and lawyers waited in line to play at the borough's Bowling Green.

title: Portuguese Timor Is Told It Can Decide Own Future
description: DILI, Portuguese Timor, Oct. 19 (Reuters) The Portuguese Minister for Overseas Territories, Antonio Costa de Almeida Santos, flew into Timor, Portugal's most distant colony, today and promised the people they would he able to decide their own future.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: South Africa, India and Untouchables
description: To the Editor:

title: A house that kept designing itself
description: A blend of polished contemporary furnishings and sophisticated materials, creating a sleek, modern environment, is the hallmark of designer Tohn Saladino's work. However, when he and his wife had finished converting an 18thcentury forge into a livable weekend house, the result was an informal, rustic retreat full of familiar, everyday objects.

title: ROAD TO NIAGARA WILL BE REMOVED
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 19The State Department of Transportation hopes to have grass sprouting by this time next year on the bank of the world famous waterfall on the fourlane Robert Moses Parkway.

title: 3 juniors Winners In Run
description: Three juniors won individual titles, and Albertus Magnus High School registered a powerful, performance in the St. John's University interscholastic crosscountry meet yesterday at Van Cortlandt, Park in the Bronx.

title: Artificial Barriers Set for Races
description: FAR HILLSFor the first time in 54 years, artificial barriers will be used at the annual Essex Fox Hounds races, which will be held next Saturday at Moorland Farms.

title: Susan Fortuna Fiancee of Robert Klug
description: Susan Jean Fortuna, a senior at Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla., and Robert John Klug of Orlando, Fla., a graduate of Rollins plan to be married in June in St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Italy's Minor Masters Could Draw Like Angels
description: Any exhibition of 76 loans from the Louvre is an important exhibition. So is any that includes five works by Michelangelo. Or, for that matter, four by Raphael. The new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art scores on all three counts and a couple of others, as well.

title: San Clement Shadow
description: President Ford's appearance before a committee of Congress has turned out to be more substantial as political theater than revealing on the subject, the pardon of Richard Nixon. Mr. Ford declared again he had made no deal, the questions of the subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee produced no significant new information, and what one member called the dark suspicions about the pardon had been allayed only a little.

title: Vosburgh Handicap Captured by Forego
description: Forego made it again, and Laffit Pincay Jr. fell short by a slight margin, in the thoroughbred activities at Agueduck yesterday. With a crowd of 32,990, including Prince Philip of England attending the program, which was headed by the $59,250 Vosburgh Handicap, Forego established himself as the star of the show by viimling the sevenfurlong event by 3 lengths.

title: Many More Women Seek Breast Cancer Exams, but Find Few Places to Go
description: We've been in an explosion here since Mrs. Ford's operation, said Virginia Trent, director of patient service for the Long Island Division of the American Cancer Society, last week. We're absolutely inundated with calls from women wanting to know where they can get a complete breast examination.mammography, not just palpation [examination by touch] of the breast, Mrs. Trent said. Some are also asking for thermography. All these women are clamoring for screening devices and, they are just not available for most women on Long Island.There is no place that women can go on Long Island for a screening like they have in the city, Mrs. Trent said.eral cancer screening center operated by the Long Island Chapter of the American Cancer Society and the Nassau County Medical Society. But because of limited facilities at the center mammography is given only by order of the examining physician.

title: Change Is Reviving Spain's Political Life
description: MADRID, Oct. 17Spain has entered a period of intense political activity as groups and individuals from left to right seek to prepare themselves for a future power struggle.

title: Alabama Wins by 286; Auburn Tops Ga. Tech
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 19 (AP)  Willie Shelby scored two touchdowns and set up another with a 41yard punt return today, leading Alabama to a 28.6 Southeastern Conference victory over Tennessee.

title: Ideas & Trends Continued
description: Is philosophy, the exploration of alternative ways of doing and thinking, an activity for adults only? A growing number of educators believes that children should be taught philosophy as early as the elementary years, and there have been experimental programs in philosophy in several New Jersey schools.

title: Heroin Ring Based In a Mexican Prison Is Raided by Police
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, Oct. 19 (AP)Mexican police and army troops raided a prison here this week to break up what they said was a heroin smuggling ring.

title: TV VIEW
description: For all of public television's current troublesfinancial, administrative, and otherwiseNew York's WNET/13 has been putting together a schedule that makes the bulk of commercial prime time look like Ted Mack's Original Amateur Hour.
