title: ROCKEFELLER UNIT ENLISTS 139 AIDES
description: Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller has enlisted 139 university and other intellectual leaders coast to coast and overseas as consultants at a firstyear cost of $975,000 in contracts for his Commission on Critical choices for Americans.

title: Two Quintuplets Gaining
description: BALTIMORE, Oct, 20 (UPI)  Two of the 12dayold Rohrer quintuplets were placed on threehour feeding intervals today, which hospital officials said was a very good sign. The two, Russel and Sandra, were few milk formula every three hours while two of their sisters, Belinda and Jennifer, received formula every two hours. The fifth quintuplet, Michelle, was being given smaller amounts of formula every two hours in an effort to build up the water level in her body.

title: Book Warning Baptists About Smut Is Assailed
description: DALLAS, Oct. 20 (UPI)A religious handbook recently mailed to all Southern Baptist pastors in Texas to aid them in urging their congregations to oppose pornography is being criticized as too graphic and may be banned by the church as pornography.

title: Continuing Drop in Unclaimed Bodies Is Hindering Medical School Classes
description: A continuing decline in the number of unclaimed bodies in New York City is exacerbating the already critical shortage of cadavers for use in anatomy classes in New York medical schools.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: If Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran has his way, there will be a dramatic change in the way young drivers, old drivers, innercity residents, bartenders and other arbitrarily designated bad risks, buy automobile insurance.

title: Wife Beaters: Few of Them Ever Appear Before a Court of Law
description: When Maria G. asked her husband what time he wanted to eat after he returned home one evening from his job as a presser in a clothing factory, he punched her in the eye, then in the nose and the mouth, leaving her bruised and bleeding.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1974
description: Mexico's President, Luis Echeverria Alvarez, will give top priority to seeking a solution to the problem of illegal Mexican migrants in the United States when he meets with President Ford at the Arizona border, Mexican authorities say. Reports from Mexico City indicate that it would like an agreement permitting a fixed number of Mexican farm workers to enter the United States to work during the fruitpicking season. Congress, under pressure from the labor movement, is reported opposed to such an agreement. [Page One, Columns 12.]

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: JAMES REVILLE
description: James Revile, a past president of the New York State Association for Retarded Children and of the Welfare League, died Saturday in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 67 years old and lived at 1795 Riverside Drive.

title: Munson and Lions Top Vikings, 2016
description: Perhaps stirred by the occasion of playing 500th game since joining the National Football League in1934, the Detroit Lions celebrated by upending, the mighty. Minnesota, Vikings, 2016, yesterday at Bloomington, Minn.

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Asks Voters to Oust Gov. Shapp
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (UPI)  The Philadelphia Inquirer published today a halfpagelong editorial calling for Gov. Milton J. Shapp's defeat text month on grounds that he tolerated corruption.

title: Abrams Bids Lefkowitz Press Inquiry on Rockefeller's Gifts
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx yesterday called on State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's gifts to public officials and his role in the publication of a 1970 biography of Arthur J. Goldberg.

title: Oklahoma, Ohio State Again WinEasily; No Consensus on Which Is Better Team
description: Ohio State and Oklahoma have no common opponent this season so there is no chance to get a comparison of these powers from a victim of both. As a result, there may be long arguments over just which is the better of these strong teams.

title: U.S. Bishop Leads Catholics In a Protest March in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 20 (AP)An American Bishop led 500 chanting Roman Catholic priests, nuns and laymen today in an antiGovernment demonstration that the police tried to break up with tear gas.

title: Explanation Asked
description: ROME, N.Y., Oct. 20Representative Hugh L. Carey warned today that the tenure of Dr. William. J. Ronan as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. would be in extreme peril if I become Governor if Dr. Ronan refused to cooperate with legislative investigations into his receipt of more than half a million dollars in a gift from former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: Soviet ExitVisa Debate
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20The new trade  and  emigration comprobliss struck by the United States Congress and the Kremlin through Secretary of State Kissinger has revived the debate over just how many Jews and other Soviet citizens would actually apply to leave if the doors were thrown fully open and obstacles lifted.

title: Mrs. Rockefeller Gains; Husband Visits Twice
description: Margaretta Rockefeller was described as in good spirits yesterday as she continued her recovery as she continued her recovery from surgery at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseses here.

title: Western Nonpolicy on Oil and the Middle East
description: NEW HAVEN  At the moment, throughout the industrialized world, we face a situation in which nearly every country individually, and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development nations as a group, are paying for petroleum products not out of current income, but out of capital.

title: Margaret Hoyt Schifter, 43, Aide at Sarah Lawrence
description: Margaret Hoyt Schifter, director of development at Sarah Lawrence College, died yesterday of cancer in University Hospital. She was 43 years old and lived at 139 East 94th Street.

title: Court Set to Hear Nixon Discussion Of Sirica Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Sometime tomorrow morning John W. Dean 3d will step back into the witness box in Judge John J. Sirica's crowded courtroom.

title: Low Key Is Gone
description: Governor Wilson charged yesterday that a victory for Representative Hugh L. Carey, his Democratic opponent, would send an administration to Albany that would destroy the state government.

title: Screen: 'Julius Vrooder':Timothy Bottoms Plays Mad for Laughs
description: The charms of mental illness and the superiority conferred by psychic wounds are celebrated almost as whimsically in Arthur Hiller's "The Crazy World of Julius Vrooder" as in Phillippe de Broca's horribly winsome "King of Hearts." Timothy Bottoms plays a Vietnam veteran who frolics all over his hospital, convinced that he's far saner than the doctors who pronounce him "psychiatrically impaired." The moviewhich drowns its antiwar theme in a cataract of cutenessopened last Friday at neighborhood theaters.Mr. Bottoms is a beguiling actor, but here he has been directed to be elfin; with eyebrows perpetually raised, he seems in peril of turning into Peter Pan. He loves a dim-wit nurse (Barbara Seagull), who specializes in an amused maternal gaze and adoring smiles. They plan to escape the crassness of American society by snuggling into a little cabin in the woods, where their children will live off the land. The movie, which was produced by Hugh M. Hefner of Playboy, contains one of the silliest wedding scenes I've seen; hasn't Mr. Hefner heard that marriage is outmoded?

title: Israelis Said to Tie Withdrawal in Sinai To Oil Assurances
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 20Israel will insist on an assured supply of oil before she will consider any withdrawal from the occupied Egyptian fields at Abu Rudeis, in the Sinai Peninsula, high Government officials said today.

title: Alouettes Clinch First
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 20 (UPI)The Montreal Atouettes routed the Ottawa Rough Riders, 280, today to clinch first place in the Canadian Football League's Eastern Conference.

title: Kanins Cohfident of Dreyfus
description: Garson Kanin pointed at a mountain of flowers in the Manhattan apartment he shares with his wife, Ruth Gordon, and said, If I didn't know that we had just opened a successful play, I'd think we were dead.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: There's no room at the top in the City Division of the Catholic Schools Football League. Three teams, Cardinal Hayes, St. Francis Prep and Iona Prep, are tied for first with 31 wonlost records. Holy Cross trails with a 21 mark.

title: RULING EXPECTED ON DEATH PENALTY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Supreme Court will almost certainly be compelled to take a second look at its 1972 decision outlawing capital punishment during the next eight months, responding to attempts by state legislatures and courts to revive the death penalty.

title: Foyt Takes Sprint and Point Lead
description: LONG POND, Pa., Oct. 20 A. J. Foyt won a $25,000 ??print car race today and ??ook the lead in the selfproclaimed world serle of auto racing at Pocono In??ernational Raceway.

title: Study Projects a Future Suffolk: Less Suburban and More Urban
description: The Regional Plan Association has prepared a report suggesting ways for Suffolk County to overcome suburban drabness (develop downtown areas), curtail reckless growth (promote cluster housing) and to make the county more livable (set aside open space as a buffer zone against suburbanization).

title: Miss Goldsmith Bride of Joel Heymsfeld
description: Susan Marion Goldsmith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Goldsmith of Little Silver, N. J., was married here yesterday to Joel Heymsfeld, son of Eleanor D. Marvin of Woodmere, L. I., and the late Ralph T. Heymsfeld.

title: China Watchers Ponder Basis of Report on Mao
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 20Analysts here are not dismissing out of hand a long report last week in the Daily Telegraph of London about an intensified succession struggle in Peking following a severe stroke supon posedly suffered by Chairman Mao Tsetung at the end of September. Believing that the account was deliberately leaked by Chinese, the analysts view it as a calculated gambit by a faction hostile to Mr. Mao's wife, Chiang Ching.

title: Joan H. Nathan Has Nuptials
description: At Temple Beth El in Providence, R. I., yesterday afternoon Joan Hannah Nathan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Nathan of Providence, was married to Allan Gerson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Gerson of the Bronx and Netanya, Israel. Rabbi William G. Braude performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Rabbi Hershel Schachter.

title: FORD AIDE SCORES WIDER F.B.I ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20An unannounced decision by the Justice Department, giving the Federal Bureau of Investigation tentative approval to begin enlarging its communication system, has been denounced by the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy.

title: 2 Held in Fatal Beating Of 21YearOld Man
description: LONG BRANCH, Oct. 20 (UPI) Two persons were arrested here today and charged with the fatal beating of a Red Bank. man earlier in the day.

title: MARGARET MOORE
description: Margaret Foote Moore, eldest daughter of John D. J. Moore, Ambassador to Ireland, and Mrs. Moore, died yesterday of pneumonia in St. Patrick's Hospital, Dublin. She was 30 years old.

title: Jane Salzfass Is Wed to Allan G. Freiman
description: Jane Gale Salzfass, who is on the New York staff of Senator Jacob K. Javits, was married here yesterday afternoon to Allan Gordon Freiman, controller of Lester B. Knight & Associates, an international engineering consulting concern based in Chicago.

title: MINORITY SETBACK IN EDUCATION SEEN
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 20  Durini the last decade, doors that were traditionally closed to minori ties in the nation's institution of higher learning began to open, and growing numbers of black, brown, red and yellow faces were seen on campus.

title: New World Delights In a Solid Program Of Weber, Brahms
description: One founding principle of the Symphony of the New World is to provide minoritygroup musicians with an orchestra in which to play. Over the last few years, this ensemble has not only kept its ranks smoothly integrated but, under its present musical director, Everett Lee, has also developed into a responsive and sensitive performing body.

title: 3 Volcanoes in Guatemala Damage Villages and Crops
description: GUATEMALA CITY, Oct. 20 (AP)  Three volcanoes have erupted in Western Guatemala, raining hot ash and rocks on a nearby town and killing a baby, authorities reported today.

title: BENEFIT IS SEEN IN GRAIN RESERVE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 An internal study drafted in the Agriculture Department in preparation for the upcoming world food conference suggests that both the United States and its foreign customers could benefit from a national grain reservea view that conflicts with the position of Earl L. Butz, the Secretary of Agriculture.

title: Seized Peruvian Papers Carefully Limit Dissent
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 20During the 10 weeks since the military Government expropriated Peru's leading newspapers, those publications have demonstrated a strong bias in favor of the Government and its revolutionary programs.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOUR KEYBOARDS Some of the best, leastpublicized popular music pianists in town, all different, cluster within one short block off Greenwich Village's Sheridan Square, at reasonable prices in relaxing lairs. A short stroll and casual barperching these nights can yield a variegated earful by a quartet of playersmake that artistsborn to their keys.

title: ELIZABETH E. O'NEILL
description: Elizabeth Evans O'Neill, widow of Francis A. O'Neill, a lawyer and former United States Commissioner for the Southern District of New York, died yesterday in the Conva Center, Neptune, N. J. She was 89 years old and lived at 5 Ocean Avenue, Belmar, N. J.

title: FORD AIDE SCORES WIDER F.B.I. ROLE

description: Directors of BioMedical Sciences, Inc., last Frdiay removed Berel Weinstein from the offices of chairman, president and chief executive and elected a new slate.

title: Ford Meeting Echeverria At Mexican Border Today
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 20Mexico's President, Luis Echeverra Alvarez, will give top priority to seeking a solution to the problem of illegal Mexican migrants in the United States when he meets President Ford at the Arizona border tomorrow, according to authoritative sources here.

description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 20 (Agence FrancePresse) Ethiopia will soon set up military tribunals to try officials of the regime of the ousted Emperor Haile Selassie, who have teen charged with corruption and abuse of power, a spokesman for the Provisional Military Government said here today.

title: MALI SAYS NIGER DETAINS NOMADS
description: BAMAKO, Mali, Oct. 19Wall's Defense Minister accused Niger today of preventing the return of tens of thousands of Malian nomads who had taken refuge in the neighboring country during the drought and famine that afflicted this region in recent years.

title: SAIGON ASSEMBLY STONED AS YOUTHS BID THIEU RESIGN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20Youthful antiGovernment demonstrators pushed over thinly manned police barricades today and stoned the National Assembly building after one of their number was reported beaten by plainclothes policemen.

description: Beauty in music, said Charles Ives, is too often confused with something that lets the ears lie back in an easy chair. At the third major concert sponsored by the Ives Centennial FestivalConference, Saturday night at Brooklyn College, students and faculty performers got everybody's ears onto the exercise mat with a grand kaleidoscope of Ives's unpredictable wit and warmth.

description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 20 (AP)A powerplay goal by Johnny McKenzie late in the game helped give the Vancouver Blazers their first victory of the World Hockey Association season, a 31 verdict over the Chicago Cougars today. The Blazers had lost their first three games.

description: More than $400million was spent in New York City last year as a direct result of conventions, according to a survey by the International Association of Convention and Visitors Bureaus.

Rockefeller's back taxes and gifts and loans to public officials, he would still, vote to confirm the former New York Governor as Vice President.

title: Bridge: Knowing Opponent's Style On Defense Proves Helpful
description: There are times when it helps to know whether an opponent is a competent defender. If he is an unknown, put at your table by the tide of tournament play, he may already have furnished a clue to his ability.

It was resolved to curtail censorship on public performances, a Cabinet statement said.

title: Educators Assail Cay As Reinforcing Racism

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: The Theater: Moriarty as Richard III
description: Scholars always express surprise at the popularity of Shakespeare's Richard III, but theater people never do. It is a simply magnificent leading role for an actor, and from Burbage on through Garrick, Keane to Irving and later Olivier, actors have always loved it. Richard was the original antihero, the complete Machievel, the virtuoso of evil, an oddly attractive villain, a commonplace Lucifer reduced to a twisted human shape.

title: Decision on PATH Called a Surprise To Transport Chief
description: TRENTON, Oct. 20 (UPI)State Transportation Commissioner Alan Sagner said today he was not consulted before the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey decided last week to postpone extension of the PATH line to Plainfield. Mr. Sagner, who is a commissioner on the Port Auth. ority, said he was completely surprised by the announcement and would hold a news conference tomorrow to discuss the issue.

Rockefeller is confirmed, the country will have both a President and Vice President who have not been chosen by the people at the polls. The obvious question is whether two more years like this, under appointed and not elected leaders, is consistent with our democracy and the principle of government by the people.

title: Petty Wins NASCAR Title Again
description: ROCKINGHAM, N.C., Oct. 20 (AP)David Pearson won his seventh big track race of the season today as Richard Petty, finishing third, captured the Nascar Grand Na.. tional driving, title for the fifth year.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In their gradual deterioration, the New York Jets crumbled yesterday. They lost to the Baltimore Colts, 3520, a respectable score. But their performance deserved no respect. Somewhat poetically, the Jets were playing the Colts, as they did in Super Bowl III, the most glorious moment of the franchise. But yesterday the decay of six years was obvious. With only one victory in their first five games, the Jets were a 12point betting favorite over the Colts, the only National Football League team that hadn't won a game this season. But the Jets were never competitive yesterday. They might win a game or two of their remaining eight. But they might not win any more. Their worst wonlost record has been 410, both last season and 1970, but in each of those years Joe Namath missed at least half the schedule. The quarterback is healthy this year. So are his teammates. Injuries can't be used as an alibi as they have been so often. Incompetence is the only alibi now; incompetence that has filtered clown from the ownership through the coaches to of the player.

title: CAPITAL SQUEEZE AFFLICTS BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Oct. 20  British industry is experiencing a liquidity crisis that many necessitate massive Government assistance to the private sector of the economy.

title: THOMAS F. MITCHELL OF WALL ST. JOURNAL
description: Thomas F. Mitchell, news editor of The Wall Street Journal, died Saturday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 48 years oki and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: 2 Die and 2 Scouts Presumed Drowned Off L.I. North Shore
description: A man and a woman died and two Sea Scouts from. New Jersey were presumed drowned in two separate boating accidents over the weekend in rough waters off Long Island's North Shore.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New Rochelle officials obtained an injunction last night in an effort to halt an apparent job action over a contract dispute in which 41 of the city's 54 policemen called in sick for yesterday's shifts. Police Commissioner William Hegarty said an injunction signed by Supreme Court Justice Alvin Ruskin of Westchester would be served on the policemen today. Policemen on the midnight shift reported for duty.

title: Words Interplay With Dancers In Guy Solomons' Chapter One
description: Gus Solomons Jr. has been playing most interestingly with the associations of words and motion for the last halfdozen years. Once, he even presented a taped lecture as a dance event. On Saturday evening at the New School, he displayed Chapter One, a lovely quartet for a trio of dancers and a reader. It was the second of four programs in the Choreoconcerts and Critiques series.

title: New Yorkers, Like Parisians, Become a More OutGoing People on Sundays
description: PARISJuliette Greco sang I Hate Sundays, Charles Aznavour's prizewinning lyrics to a tune still popular here after two decades.

title: SHIP BURNS WASTES OFF LOUISIANA COAST
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 20 (AP) Vulcanus, the Dutch incinerator ship, began burning 4,628 tons of poisonous chemical wastes in the Gulf of Mexico today, spokesmen for the Shell Oil Company said.

title: Miss Goolagong Topples Chris Evert, Wins $32,000
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 (Reuters)  Evonne Goolagong of Australia defeated Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., last night in the final of the $100,000 Virginia Slims Tennis championship. The scores were 6.3, 6.4.

title: Ants Are the Stars of 'Phase IV':The Cast
description: The ominous possibility of insects threatening to dominate and perhaps destroy man is again posed in "Phase IV," which opened at local theaters last Friday. The adversaryin this case, it's the familiar, highly coordinated and indomitable antis less a threat than a problem created by a concept and a script that is initially spellbinding but then quickly turns into mystifying vacillations between fact and largely unconvincing fiction."Phase IV" is reminiscent of, say, those sobering ant sagas, "Them!" and "The Hellstrom Chronicle," and Stanley Kubrick's futuristic "2001" space odyssey. Elements of all are evident here as a couple of dedicated scientists do their learned best to combat various species of ants that, because of a vague interplanetary disturbance, have joined forces to cause a "biological imbalance" in a remote corner of the Arizona desert.In making his feature directorial debut after a succession of distinguished film titles, graphics and short subjects, Saul Bass, with the aid of special insect photography by Ken Middleham ("Hellstrom Chronicle"), has fashioned a pictorially persuasive adventure. His ants  in close-up and otherwise  make their awesome potential terrifyingly real, even if his principalsNigel Davenport and Michael Murphy, as the scientists, and Lynne Frederick, as the frightened young womanare merely onedimensional figures registering surface emotions.It's ungallant to reveal the denouement but, like a good deal of "Phase IV," it's beclouded by enigmas. For all of its good, scientific and human intentions, "Phase IV" cries for a Phase V of fuller explanations.

title: Conditions in Project Shock Atlanta Mayor
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 20 (AP)After spending the weekend at a public housing project, Mayor Maynard Jackson of Atlanta said today that he was shocked and angered at the conditions in which the residents of the complex live.

title: School Engineers to Hold Protest Today on Back Pay
description: School officials said last night that all public schools here would be open and heated this morning despite a planned job action by Operating Engineers Union Local 94.

title: Kuwaiti Ruler Meets Sadat
description: CAIRO, Oct. 20 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Sheik Sabah alSallem alSabah of Kuwait began talks here today. Use of Arab oil revenues is believed to be a topic in the talks.

title: About New York
description: Exactly when it happened nobody knows, but there came a time in the life of New York when Sundays somehow changed. Once there was a quiet about the day, and people more or less stayed home. Now Sunday really begins on Saturday afternoon, and more people, it seems, go out. Sundays, in truth, have somehow changed.

title: TV: Cay Looks at Prejudice, but Loses Message
description: On NBCTV tonight at o'clock, The Cay works quite nicely on its chosen surface level. The Bell System Family Theater production, adapted from a Theodore Taylor novel by Russell Thacher, offers an adventure yarn involving an aging black seaman and a poor little rich white boy. The roles are realized beautifully by James Earl Jones and young Alfred Lutter.

title: Levitt Declares That He Is Not Talking Re  election for Granted
description: Arthur Levitt, who has been State Controller since 1954, could have been reelected this year without opposition, but Democratic party officials decreed otherwise. They did not want his respected name lending luster to the tickets of the Republican and Conservative parties.

title: NEW STURMS SONATA PLAYED SENSITIVELY
description: Six musicians gathered in Carnegie Recital Hall late Saturday afternoon to play a selection of recent works by Arnolds Sturms, a composer born in Latvia who has been a resident of the Unite States since 1949. Valija Mellins sang 10 of Mr. Stunns's songs accompanied by Ilse Sass; Arthur Ozelins performed the Sonata da Chiesa for Piano (a premiere), and Litsa Gania Neidich (pianist), Masako Yanagita (violinist) and Irving Neidich (clarinetist) played a Trio composed in 1968. There was little in this spicily chromatic but tonally oriented music to offend conservative tastes brought up on Shostakovich or Prokofiev, two composers who appear to have considerably influenced Mr. Sturms. The songs sounded rather static and plain, kit the instrumental music generated a certain amount of propulsive motor energy and offered moments of thematic distinction.

title: A New Class of Debtors Costly to Bill Collectors
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20Gus R. Cohen got his first bomb threat when interest rates soared to record highs and unemployment lines lengthened. Then came the obscene letters.

title: Oil Price Decline Predicted
description: A secret Government study says the price of imported oil is likely to drop to $7 a barrel by 1985, Time magazine reports. The United States now pale $11 a barrel for imports of 6.3 million barrels of oil a day. Time said the study, for release in November, was prepared by 750 analysts for the Federal Energy Administration.

title: Gadfly of French Cabinet Franoise Giroud
description: PARIS, Oct. 20 When the patrician Valry Giscard d'Estaing was running for President last spring, during his manofthepeople period of playing the accordion and being photographed barechested in the locker room before a soccer game, a journalist named Franoise Giroud asked him on television what the price of a Paris subway ticket was.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The ingredients of a chicken dinner for a family of four in New York and northern New Jersey cost 7 cents less in August than they did in July, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. The August price of $5.54 reflected decreases in potatoes, green peppers, tomatoes and lettuce, and an increase of 11 cents for chicken. The office said the total price had declined 69 cents from August, 1973.

title: DECLINING OUTPUT IN TEXTILES SEEN
description: The textile industry will go through a period of declining demand and output for the next year, according to textile economists and mill executives. Total 1974 output will be 3 to 4 per cent lower than in 1973 and will remain flat for the first half of 1975.

title: Bills, Led by Simpson, Send Patriots to First Defeat, 3028
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Oct. 20After five victorious Sundays, the winning ways of the New England Patriots came to an end today as the Buffalo Bills beat them, 3028, in a game not as close as the final score hinted. The result left the two close in the standings, tied for first place in the Eastern Division of the American Conference.

title: Jesting Pilate
description: WASHINGTONWhat is truth? said jesting Pilate; and would not stay for an answer.

title: Police Give Descriptions of 3 New Britain Suspects
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 21The state and local police are looking for two men and a woman who they believe may be responsible for the slayings of six people in a bakery here Saturday night.

title: California G.O.P. Seen Cool To '76 Senate Bid by Nixon
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 (AP)Only one in four Republicans polled in former President Richard Nixon's native state say they would vote for him if he ran for United States Senate in 1976, the California Poll said today.

title: Million in Norton Simon Funds To Aid Pasadena Art Museum
description: A new, more public board of trustees and a clearer financial picture have been announced for the debtridden Pasadena Art Museum, since last April under the wing of Norton Simon, the West Coast financier and art patron.

title: Monmouth Feature To Courtesy Call
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Oct. 21 (UPI)  Courtesy Call, making his first start in more than nine months, rallied to win the $7,500 Raspar Purse for New Jerseybreds today as Monmouth Park opened a 30day fall meeting. Dropping into second place after breaking on top in the sixfurlong race for 3yearolds and up, the 4yearold San SueMaltzie colt rallied in the stretch to score by a head under Bill Tichenor.

title: Legal Aid Sues to Upset. Bail System
description: A statistical study released yesterday by the Legal Aid Society contended that defendants in Manhattan who could not post bail were convicted more frequently and sentenced more harshly than defendants who were released pending trial.

title: U.N.ACCORD NEAR ON MIDEAST FORCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21Members of the Security Council today appeared close to agreeing to renew the mandate for the United Nations peacekeeping forces in the Middle East for another six months.

title: HAIG ROLE REPORTED IN JAWORSKI'S MOVE
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21 (AP) Leon Jaworski says Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., former White House chief of staff, talked him into taking the job of Watergate special prosecutor, The Los Angeles Times reports.

title: Indignity Added to Navy Loss
description: Many Naval Academy midshipmen are walking around Annapolis with shaved heads while 40 happy Air Force Academy Cadets are planning a free vacation weekend because Air Force beat Navy, 1916, Saturday on Dave Lawson's field goal with eight seconds remainin. H. Ross Perot, a 1953 Navy graduate who is a wealthy Texas oilman, offered a bet to the student body of each academy. Those who accepted placed their names in a hat. After the game 40 names were picked out of the hat at the academy that had won the game. Perot was to pay all expenses for two for the 40 lucky Air Force Cadets.

title: PRICECHANGING IN STORES SCORE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 21Displaying a box of supermarket cake mix that had been repriced upward six times, James E. Picken, the Nassau County Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, today urged support for county law that would prohibit an increase in the price of an item after it had already been labeled with a price.

title: Fatal Glue Factory Blasts
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (UPI)A pair of explosions rocked a South Side glue factory yesterday, touching off a fire that threatened a storage tank containing nitroglycerine. One person was killed and five others were injured, one seriously. The body of Thomas Jenkins, 40 years old, of Chicago, was pulled from the rubble of the Darling and Co. glue factory.

title: Mrs. Rockefeller Improving
description: Margaretta Rockefeller was reported in excellent condition yesterday, her recovery progressing rapidly, according to officials at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, where she underwent surgery for breast cancer last Thursday. Yesterday, she ate lunch and dinner with her husband, Vice President  designate Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: Symington, at U.N., Offers U.S. Plan to Curb Spread of AArms
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21  The United States called today for a collective effort by nuclear and nonnuclear powers to curb the spread of nuclear weapons and offered a program to meet this goal.

title: Center Finds a Rise In Black Candidates, But Not in Hopes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) More blacks are running for major offices this year than in 1972, but it is not likely that there will be more winners.

title: CHESS GAME PUT OFF BY A KARPOV ILLNESS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21Anatoly Karpov was granted an illness postponement of the 15th game of his final candidates match with Viktor Korchnoi to pick a challenger or a successor to Bobby Fischer. The game, originally scheduled for this evening at 5 P.M., has been moved to Wednesday at the same time in Tchaikowsky Hall.

title: PRICES SHOW GAIN ON AMEX AND OTO
description: Prices rose yesterday on the American Stock Exchange arid in the overthecounter market.The Amex marketvalue index climbed 0.32 to 69.37 as the average share price was up cents. Advances outnumbered declines by 350 to 271, with 292 issues unchanged. Volume fell slightly to 1.78 million shares from 1.96 million shares Friday. Five large blocks were traded yesterday, compared with six on Friday.

title: A Confident Carey Weighs Prospects for State Posts
description: Two weeks before Election Day, Representative Hugh L Carey is giving serious thought to selecting the people who will make up the top levels of his administration if he is elected Governor on Nov. 5.

title: Paperback Houses Strengthen
description: Howard Kaminsky, the president of Warner Paperback Library, a paperback publishing house, is a far cry from the tweedy, stiff  upper  lip publishers of yore. He wears flashy suits. His talk is salty. His manners are sometimes Runyonesque. As one collegue said the other day, Alfred A. Knopf he is not. And yet when it came to negotiating for the memoirs of the 37th President of the United States, Richard M. Nixon, the first deal was pulled off, not by some Doubleday or Scribner scion, but by Mr. Kaminsky and another Warner executive, William Sarnoff, according to Mr. Nixon's literary agent, Irving Paul Lazar.

title: CARL DIXON, 75, DIES; PILOT FOR 50 YEARS
description: Carl A. Dixon, a pioneer aerial photographer who in 1919 was a pilot on a 52day goodwill flight made by Lawrence of Arabia from Paris to Cairo, died Saturday in the Vet??rans Administration Hospital in Rocky Hill, Conn. He was 75 years old and lived in New Britain, Conn.

title: SUCREST INCREASES CORN SYRUP PRICES
description: The Sucrest Corporation said it would increase the price of corn syrup used in blends in its Eastern marketing area to a range of $18.72 to $18.91.

title: $3MILLION STOLEN FROM CHICAGO VAULT
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP)More than $3million was stolen over the weekend from the Armored Express Company, and investigators said two weekend bombings may have been set to divert attention from the theft.

title: 2 Catholics Killed in Belfast By Shots Fired From a Car
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 21Assassins, apparently Protestants, struck again in Belfast today, shooting to death two Roman Catholic halfbrothers as they walked to work.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
MAJOR CUTBACKS DENIED BY ALITALIA
description: ROME, Oct. 21Spokesmen for Alitalia denied today a report by trade unions that the airline would sell half its fleet, cut its service considerably and lay off a large number of its staff. But the company did say it had a broad outline of plans for the restructuring its services.

title: U.S. Judge Delays Accord On Nixon Tapes and Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21A Federal judge ordered a delay today in carrying out the agreement on White House tape recordings and papers between the Ford Administration and former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Muslims Open a Fish House in Harlem
description: Hundreds of people in Harlem lined up yesterday for the opening of Muhammad's Fish House No. 1  the latest of a series of business ventures and the first in a projected chain of 40 fish restaurants owned by the Nation of Islam.

title: His Bid for Alimony Denied by a Court
description: A husband who is being sued for divorce by his wife is not entitled to alimony from her under New York State domestic relations law, the Appellate Division Second Department has ruled in a bitter Nassau County divorce case.

title: Student Is Killed in Fraternity Initiation Rite
description: BLUEFIELD, W. Va., Oct. 21 (AP)A 20  year  old college student was shot to death and another wounded during what the state police said was an initiation rite for a fraternity at Bluefield State College BLUEFIELD, W. Va., Oct. 21 (AP)A 20  year  old college student was shot to death and another wounded during what the state police said was an initiation rite for a fraternity at Bluefield State College.

title: MRS. HENRY H. REED SR.
description: Eleanor Beers Reed, widow of Henry Hope Reed Sr., a retired marine insurance execufive here who became trusteeinresidence at the American Farm School near Salonika, Greece, died yesterday at the school. Her age was 83. She had continued to serve as trustee since her husband's death.

title: New District 1 Principal Is Punched by a Parent
description: The new principal of Public School 34 in District 1 suffered a broken nose yesterday when he was punched by the vice president of the school's Parents Association, who was angered by the alleged mistreatment of his wife by school security guards.

title: TRIAL STARTS FOR 2 IN ACCOUNTING CASE
description: Two senior accountants went on trial here yesterday on charges by a Federal grand jury that they knowingly made and caused to be made false and miisleading statements to stockholders about the National Student Marketing Corporation.

title: Ali Says It Will Be Last Fight
description: In one more week, Muhammad Ali will float like a butterfly, sting like a bee for the last time.

title: Bank Is Installing Lighted Holdup Sign Outside Branches
description: In an effort to deter holdups, the Chemical Bank yesterday announced it was beginning to install a new external alarm system a sign on its buildings that will flash the words Robbery in Progress during holdup.

title: Physicists Test Telepathy In a CheatProof Setting
description: Scientists at the Stanford Research Institute who conducted experiments with a number of persons, including Uri Geller, the magician and purported psychic, report that Mr. Geller, and probably most people, have an ability to send and receive information by some as yet unidentified perceptual modality.

title: French Aide for Women Confers in the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) Francoise Giroud, France's Secretary of State for the Condition of Women, talked over women's rights today in the White House with the topranking woman in the United States Government, Presidential Counselor Anne Armstrong.

title: Castro Sees Hope for Better U.S. Ties
description: Premier Fidel Castro has said that he sees positive hope for closer relations between Cuba and the United States because President Ford is not involved with the Cuban counterrevolutionary elements.

title: MASCO IS GIVEN A 3MONTH TERM
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco of Brooklyn was sentenced in Federal Court here last night to three months in prison and a $10,000 fine for conspiring to take bribes to help a Mafiacontrolled, truck company get a contract with the Post Office.

title: Physicists Test Telepathy In a Cheat Proof Setting
description: Scientists at the Stanford Research Institute who conducted experiments with number of persons, including Uri Geller, the magician and purported psychic, report that Mr. Geller, and probably most people, have an ability to send and receive information by some as yet unidentified perceptual modality.

title: KUH SAYS JUDGE LACKED CANDOR
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan yesterday accused Owen McGivern, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, of an effort to cover up the improprieties in the selection of members to elite sheriff's jury panels.

title: Air Pollution Damage in '70 Put at $12.3Billion for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)  Air pollution caused some $12.3billion damage to human health and property in 1970, the environmental Protection Agency estimated today.

title: PORT AIDE CITES LACK OP WEALTH
description: A Jesuit priest yesterday became the second Port Authority commissioner to disclose his net worth.

title: Young Battles 2 to Retain North Dakota Senate Seat
description: BISMARCK, N.D., Oct. 18He campaigns like a bashful country boy trying to whisper his way into the United States Senate.

title: CHESS GAME PUT OFF 	BY A KARPOV ILLNESS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21Anatoly Karpov was granted an illness postponement of the15th game of his final candidates match with Viktor Korchnoi to pick a challenger or a successor to Bobby Fischer. The game, originally scheduled for this evening at 5 P.M., has been moved to Wednesday at the same time in Tchaikowsky Hall.

title: FOREST SETS SALE OF OIL PROPERTIES
description: The Forest Oil Corporation announced yesterday in Denver that it had executed a definitive agreement to sell substantially all of its oil producing properties in this country to the Sun Oil Cornpany (Delaware). It said it expected to execute a similar agreement with another unit of Sun Oil covering Forest's Canadian oil producing properties.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell 0.9 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 231.5 for the week ended Oct. 15 from 232.4 the previous week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 193.8 on Oct. 16, 1973.

title: Navy Lags in Recruiting
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The Navy, with a 92 per cent performance, failed to make its recruiting goal in September for the third consecutive month, the Pentagon said today. Meanwhile, the Army scored 103 per cent of its September objective, and the Marines and the Air Force reached 100 per cent.

title: Bridge: Right and Wrong Are Tricky And Depend on Circumstances
description: Right and wrong are tricky words to use, in bridge situations as well as in life. Circumstances cannot be ignored. The experienced player knows the right way to handle all common suit combinations, but he does not always realize that the appropriate play may depend on the number of entries available to one hand or the other.

title: State Psychologist Slain in Yonkers; Found by Parents
description: A 26yearold psychologist at a state hospital for the criminally insane was found dead yesterday, a stocking knotted around her throat and her head battered, in he bedroom of her Yonkers apartment.

title: Brasco Gets 3 Months
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco of Brooklyn was sentenced yesterday to three months in prison and fined $10,000 for conspiring to take bribes to help a Mafiacontrolled truck company get a Post Office contract. Page 35.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: The unbeaten streak for Lawrence Township's football team is 22 and the count is expected to reach 27 when they schoolboy season closes.

title: Business Briefs
description: PARIS, Oct. 21 (Reuters)Citron the French car manufacturer, reported today a loss of about $80million for the first half of 1974. The loss casts new doubt on chances of a possible merger with Peugeot the other French private car manufacturer. Citroen blamed difficulties stemming from the oil crisis for the big loss, which followed profit for all of last year of about $48million.

title: William Tabbert, Actor, Dies; Lieut. Cable in South Pacific
description: William Tabbert, an actor and lyric tenor who originated the stage role of Lieut. Joseph Cable in South Pacific, the Pulitzer Prizewinning musical, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Dallas.

title: Mrs. Marcos Says Visit to China Was Made Special by Chiang Ching
description: MANILA, Oct. 15Imelda R. Marcos, the First Lady of the Philippines, who was received more attentively in China Iass month than most visiting heads of state, attributes her welcome there to a shared Orientalness that she discovered in conversations with Chiang Ching, wife of Chairman Mao Tsetung.

title: Race Barred by Justices; Ravenel Is Disappointed
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 21Charles D. Ravenel learned today that he would be unable to run for Governor and said that he was very, very disappointed and saddened but that the decision is final and I accept it.

title: OldTime Jet Saddened by Team's Play
description: As each Sunday passes, it becomes more and more excruciating for Jet football players to subject themselves to public exposure.

title: EDITOR IS DISMISSED OVER WILSON TAPE
description: The editor of an upstate rural weekly has been dismissed because he made secret tape recordings of conversations in which Conservative party leader reportedly described a deal he had made with Governor Wilson to abandon a Conservative primary fight for the gubernatorial nomination.

title: LITTLE PROFIT SEEN AT LOEWS IN QUARTER
description: The Loews Corporation, in connection with its pending application to acquire control of the CNA Financial Corporation, stated yesterday that it has filed unaudited financial statements with the Pennsylvania Insurance Department showing that net income for the twelve months ended Aug. 31, 1974 will not be much higher o?? lower than for the first nine months of the fiscal year.

title: Sales in Advance
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., the world's largest chemical concern, reported yesterday an 18.5 per cent drop in earnings for this year's third quarter and its first domestic public debt offering since 1921. However, du Pont stock advanced 5 points despite the news.

title: Inquiry on Gift to Ronan Voted by Jersey Senate
description: TRENTON, Oct. 21The State Senate gave final approval today for a legislative investigation of the $550,000 gift by Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller to Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Expressway Lanes Closed
description: The highway department announced yesterday that the three southbound (Brooklynbound) lanes of the Brooklyn Queens Expressway between Kingsland and Metropolitan avenues in Queens would be closed daily from 10 P.M. to 5:30 A.M. until Saturday, to permit it the second phase of resurfacing work on the twomile section of the expressway.

title: Gerald Eskenazi
description: The grossness of it made Ralph Kiner chuckle. I never got a trophy, he said. No, wait a minute, added the man who, in the decade following World War II, hit more balls out of the park than anyone else in baseball. I once got a $500 War Bond for being picked as the most sportsmanlike player in the game.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: U.S. Registers Complaint Over E.E.C. Trade Accord
description: GENEVA, Oct. 21  The United States again registered today its disapproval of the preferential trade agreements concluded by the European Economic Community with nonmember states as contravening international rules.

title: Connors Vs. Laver for $100,000
description: Jimmy Connors and Rod Laver, who have never met on the tennis court, will play a $100,000 winnertakeall match in January.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DALLAS, Oct. 21 (AP)A sixth grade inventor, 11yearold Torn Perryman, has designed a machine to call strikes and balls so accurately there just couldn't be any arguments.

title: De mocratic Mayors Plan Hearings for Urban Plank
description: A group of Democratic mayors from Middle Atlantic states, led by Mayor Beame, will hold three public hearings on urban problems to prepare recommendations for the 1976 Democratic party platform.

title: Landlord Fatally Beaten Arguing With a Tenant
description: An elderly Queens landlord was bludgeoned to death last evening during a violent argument with a 20yearold tenant who has been under treatment for mental disorders, the police charged.

title: MEXICO'S NEW OIL FOR WORLD SALE, ECHEYERRIA SAYS
description: TUBAC, Ariz., Oct. 21President Luis Echeverra Alvarez of Mexico confirmed at a meeting with President Ford today that substantial amounts of oil has been discovered in southeast Mexico and said that it would be put on the world market when developed.

title: Morgenthau Vows Action on Landlords
description: Robert M. Morgenthau declared yesterday that landlords who jeopardized the lives of tenants by failing to correct hazardous conditions and who defrauded tenants by collecting rent increases to which they were not entitled should be prosecuted as criminals rather than just as civil offenders.

title: The Trend, Toward Bicycle Chic: Status Names and High Prices
description: If you yearn to be king of the road, but you can't afford a $54,000 Rolls Royce Corniche convertible or even $24,000 Ferrari Zagato, don't despair. Buy a bicycle.

title: AFTERNOON RALLY LIFTS DOW BY 14.94
description: A late surge in buying enabled the stock market to register its third consecutive advance yesterday in slower trading.

title: Stage: The Big Winner
description: The new Yiddish theater season began this week with perhaps the most polished production staged here in Many years. The Big Winner at the Eden Theater is on the scale of a latterday suburban bar mitzvah as compared with the modest todayIamafountainpen type of theater of yore.

title: Duck Farmers Find Pollution Curbs a Burden
description: AQUEBOGUE, L. I.  The soft, insistent humming of the huge antipollution devices on Lloyd W. Corwin. Jr.'s 100acre duck farm here is just as familiar to him these days, as is the constant quacking of his million ducks.

title: RONAN'S CAPACITY IS CAST IN DOUBT
description: TRENTON, Oct. 21Reacting angrily to an announced delay by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in the planned extension of its PATH rapid transit system in New Jersey, Governor Byrne and State Transportation Commissioner Alan Sagner raised considerable doubt today about Dr. William J. Ronan's cpacity to continue as chairman of the bistate agency.

title: Adequacy of Bank Capital Arousing Concern at Fed
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 21Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that it has become increasingly concerned about the adequacy of bank capital and that recent decisions have been designed to slow the expansion of bank holding companies.

title: Paterson's Mayor Rises Above Fear of Charges
description: PATERSON, Oct. 21There is a sign prominent displayed on Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer's desk here that reads, My job is secure, it's me they can do without.

title: U.S. ACTS TO RAISE AIR CHARTER FARE
description: In the first such move on record, the Civil Aeronautics Board took action yesterday in an effort to raise fares for transAtlantic charter flights.

title: Laws Prepared in Egypt To End Exchange Control's
description: CAIRO, Oct. 21 (Reuters) Egypt's Foreign Trade Ministries have drafted new laws aimed at the gradual removal of exchange controls on the Egyptian pound, the semiofficial daily AlAhram reported today.

title: Sony Sets Japan Venture
description: TOKYO, Oct. 21 (AP)  The Sony Corporation said today it had signed an agreement with Union Carbide Corporation to establish an equally owned subsidiary in Japan to market drycell batteries. The batteries would be sold under the name SonyEveready, the company said. An application for approval of the venture would be submitted to the Japanese Givernment shortly, Sony said.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE RIGHT WAY Shaw's Arms and the Man, his tartly mocking treatise on the sham of warfare and the vagaries of love, hasn't fared too well here in recent times. Unsurprisingly, the uptown Equity Library Theater (6632028), at 103d Street at Riverside Drive, has set things straight as a 32d season opener with a fine cast, a lovelytolookit mounting and sustained, witty bite that probably would make Shaw smile. Admission is $3.

title: A Message for Rock FansSequins Are Out
description: The game in any part of the fashion world is to keep one step ahead. When the players are leaders of the glitterrock brigade, it has to be a giant step. How they look is, after all, about as important as how they sound.

title: Assembly Extends Campaign Financing
description: TRENTON, Oct. 21A Byrne administration bill to extend public financing of gubernatorial campaigns to primary elections was approved in the Assembly today by a vote of 62 to 10.

title: Investors Funding In Chapter X Filing
description: The Investors Funding Corporation, a major realestate developer whose financial difficulties deepened after four of its officers were indicted on Federal charges of attempting to bribe public officials in Fort I Lee, N. J., filed bankruptcy proceedings here yesterday.

title: Inflation Is Noted
Secretary Leaves Tonight
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Secretary of State Kissinger flies to Moscow tomorrow night to test the willingness of the Soviet leadership to work with the Ford Administration for a curb on strategic arms and a settlement of European and Middle Eastern problems.

title: BISHOP LEO C. BYRNE OF MINNEAPOLIS DIES
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 21 (AP)The Most Rev. Leo C. Byrne, Coadjutor Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. PaulMinneapolis, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Purging Stag Words
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Everybody at some time has probably felt blood pressure rise and pulse when loaded words hive been used to diminish him. The laborer who is called a hardhat, the poor white who is called a redneck, the black man who is called boy, the intellectual who is called an egghead, the liberal who is called a bleeding heart, the policeman who is called a pigall these and many others, are, painfully aware how brutally the English language can be Used to humiliate them.

title: Issue and Debate
description: A decade ago, as the crash of the wrecker's ball and the flash of the demolition torch signaled the end of many old but architecturally valued buildings here, city officials began seeking ways to save such buildings.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1974
description: International

title: Abortion Hearing Delayed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (UPI)A threejudge Federal court today delayed until January another hearing on the state's new abortion control act, and continued its ban against enforcement of key provisions of the act. One requires the consent of a spouse or the parent or a guardian of a minor for an abortion.

title: DR. A. ROBERT PESKIN
description: Dr. A. Robert Peskin, an internist and cardiologist, died Saturday in Beth Israel Hospital. Fie was 75 years old and lived at 2 Fifth Avenue.

title: Duck Farmers Find Pollution Curbs a Burden
description: AQUEBOGUE, L. I. The soft, insistent humming of the huge antipollution devices on Lloyd W. Corwin Jr.'s 100acre duck farm here is just as familiar to him these days as is the constant quacking of his million ducks.

title: Hunt for a Reputed Slayer Under Way in Soviet Capital
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21 (Reuters) The police were searching for a killer today amid rumors that a psychopath was at large in the Soviet capital.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE GLORY OF THE HUMMINGBIRD. By Peter Do Vries. 276 pages. Little, Brown. $6.95.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: MURRAY SARGENT, EXHOSPITAL AIDE
description: Murray Sargent, former executive administrator of New York Hospital, died Saturday at his home, 155 East 72d Street. He was 90 years old.

title: HOUSE PANEL SCORES POSTAL OPERATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The Postal Service, in its first three years of operation, has abused its special legal position and has failed to noticeably improve the quality of mail service, a Congressional subcommittee has concluded.

title: COCOA CONTRACTS TOUCH NEW HIGHS
description: Cocoa futures touched seasonal highs during trading on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. Traders bought after hearing that Ghana's weekly purchasing from farmers totaled only 16,447 tons compared with an expected 18,000. Hol,tevef, the purchasing season has only been underway a few weeks.

title: Cost of Rockefeller's TV Series Was Deducted as Gift to State
description: Nelson A. Rockefeller, while Governor of New York, paid $274,704 for a series of television documentaries about state issues, called Executive Chamber, which were broadcast throughout the state in 196465 and in 1968. He then deducted the costs of the programs from his state and Federal income taxes as gifts to the state.

title: Restraining Wiretappers
description: The refusal of the Supreme Court to hear a case involving the Federal Government's authority to use wiretaps without first obtaining judicial warrants leaves the whole matter just where it was before the Court declined actin urgent need of Congressional scrutiny.

title: Jury Hears Tape of Nixon Urging Aides to Stonewall
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 Over the heated objections of defense counsel, the jury in the Watergate case heard today the tape recording in which Richard M. Nixon said he wanted his aides to stonewall it ... plead the Fifth Amendment, cover up or anything else, if it'll save itsave the plan.

title: H. CLIFFORD GAYLEY
description: H. Clifford Gayley, a former treasurer of Schenley Industries, Inc., who retired in 1966 as a consultant to International Business Machines Corporation, died of a heart attack Saturday in Buck Hill Falls, Pa. He was 73 years old and lived at 1105 Park Avenue.

title: Manhattan's Birds
description: Manhattan is not exactly a bird sanctuary, though surprising number of species have been seen in Central Park. But downtown, in such open spaces as the Battery and Trinity churchyard, urban birdwatchers often turn up birds that even outlanders have to look twice find at home. Lower Manhattan seems to be a kind crossroad on Several avian air routes.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1974

title: A Sale on Antifreeze Precipitates a Melee
description: FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 21 (AP)About 1,000 customers pushed into a department store this morning, pulled down displays and injured an employe during the opening minutes of a sale on antifreeze.

title: Pay Rule Altered By Olympic Unit
description: VIENNA, Oct. 21The International Olympic Committee gave an emphatic nod today to a new eligibility code which gives an athlete adequate time for training and payment for that time pending approval by the athlete's national federation.

title: McGinnis Slips Out of Knick Grasp Again
description: The Knicks have lost George McGinnis for the second time in three months. The latest deal to obtain the Indiana Pacers strongman fell through yesterday when he refused to sign an agreement that involved the Knicks and Philadelphia 76ers. McGinnis indicated he preferred to play in Indiana, his home state.

title: More Fertilizer for Farms, Less for Gardens Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) Americans may have to get along with browner lawns next summer so their gardensand farmscan be greener, the chairman of the Fertilizer Institute says.

title: Lisa Dresselhuys Bride of Director
description: Maria Luisa Dresselhuys, daughter of Richard Dresselbuys of New York and Camilla Martellini Dresselbuys of Geneva, was married in Paris on Saturday to PierreMain Jolivet, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Jolivet of Paris. The civil ceremony took place at the Mairie of the 15th Arrondissement.

title: France's Foreign Minister Meets Palestinian Guerrilla Chief
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 21 Foreign Minister Jean Sauvagnargues of France met today with Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, in a gesture of official recognition coupled with advice to the Palestinians to be more moderate in their tactics and demands.

title: Nashville Study of Poor Finds Few Have Proper Medical Care
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 21A Meharry Medical College study of the effectiveness of health and social services for poor milies in its neighboring communities in Nashville that only 13 per cent of in 1,266 households with nosed medical problems were. receiving the appropriate medical care.

title: PremierDesignate In Lebanon Drops Efforts for Cabinet
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 21Saeb Salam, a former Lebanese Premier, abandoned efforts today to form a government after 18 days of negotiations.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Woman Defense Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger announced the appointment today of Mrs. John G. Veneman of San Francisco as chairman of the Defense Advisory Committee on Women in the services.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Miss Moffat, the musical play, has permanently closed because of the illness of Bette Davis, its star, it was disclosed yesterday by Joshua Logan and Eugene V. Wolsk, producers. The musical, an adaptation of Emlyn Williams's The Corn Is Green, closed Friday in Philadelphia after twoweek run.

title: Police in Connecticut Alert State on Group of Con Men
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 21 (AP)The state police issued a warning today for a group of con men who victimize elderly women. The group was said to have moved into Connecticut after working in Maryland and New Jersey.

title: Shoe Manufacturers Hopeful Of Comeback Against Imports
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 21Encouraged by a 7 per cent dedine in imports for the first eight months of 1974the first such drop in more than a decadeAmerican shoe manufacturers and suppliers are generally hopeful about regaining markets lost to foreignmade products.

title: Soviet Fires Test Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (Reuters)The Soviet Union last night testfired an intercontental missile into the Pacific, the Defense Department reported today.

title: U. S Policy and Soviet Subs
description: WASHINGTON  Today marks the twelfth anniversary of the Cuban missile crisis. At its conclusion, in 1962, the Soviet Union conceded that would no longer deploy strategic offensive weapons in Cuba.

title: Aristocratic Life in 17th Century Is Evoked by Hilton Dance Group
description: It is easy to imagine life, aristocratic life, in 17th century Europe, with the melodies of the period in one's ears and the dances of the time being presented in the Tudoresque Synod House of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. The spirited program on Sunday evening resulted from the efforts of the Wendy Hilton Baroque Dance Company and the Ensemble for Early Music.

title: Miners' Injury Rate Highest
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (UPI)The National Safety Council called attention today to National Coal Mine Safety Week, Oct. 27 to Nov. 2, by noting that miners have the highest disabling injury rate in the na tion. The Council said figures for 1973 showed that the disabling injury frequency for underground coal miners was more than three times greater than the average rate for all private industry. The rate was 35.44 per million manhours worked compared with 10.55, the national average.

title: Monmouth Feature To Courtesy Call
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Oct. 21 (UPI)  Courtesy Call, making his first start in more than nine months, rallied to win the $7,500 Raspar Purse for New Jerseybreds today as Monmouth Park opened a 30day fall meeting. Dropping into second place after breaking on top in the sixfurlong race for 3yearolds and up, the 4yearold San SueMaltzie colt rallied in the stretch to score by a head under Bill Tichenor.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Trout Area Remains Open
description: If, sometime in November, a day dawns with no clouds in the sky and only a breath of wind, you may want to gather your flyfishing gear and head for the socalled quality fishing area of New York State's Battenkill River.

title: COMMON MARKET AGREES TO BACK JOINT OIL LOANS
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 21The Finance Ministers of the Common Market agreed this evening on a plan under which the nine member countries could jointly borrow up to $3billion from oilproducing countries to help members cover balanceofpayments deficits caused by oil imports.

title: FIGHTING ERUPTS IN MOZAMBIQUE
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Oct. 21 (Reuters)At least 14 people were killed and 66 wounded tonight in a clash between offduty Portuguese commandos and Mozambique Liberation Front forces, hospital officials here said.

title: 18 DEATHS IN GREECE LAID TO EXDICTATOR
description: ATHENS, Oct. 21 (AP)The chief Athens prosecutor today charged the former dictator, George Papadopoulos, and other junta chiefs with responsibility for the death of at least 18 persons in a student uprising.

title: 2 Men and Woman Sought in Slayings
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 21The state and local police are looking for two men and a woman who they believe may be responsible for the slayings of six people in a bakery here Saturday night.

title: Transit Grants for Elderly
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP)Four grants totaling $362,355 to provide transportation for the elderly were announced today by Gov. Francis W. Sargent. He said that $215,269 of the money would come from the Federal Government and that the remainder would be provided locally.

title: Inquiry on, Gift to Ronan Voted by Jersey Senate
description: TRENTON, Oct. 21The State Senate gave, final approval today for a legislative investigation of the $550,000 gift by Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller to Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Princeton Student Found Dead From Inhaling Nitrous Oxide
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 21James A. Vogel, a 20yearold Princeton University junior, was found dead in his dormitory room today after inhaling nitrous oxide, commonly known as laughing gas.

title: 2 RAILROADS LIFT 3DQUARTER NET
description: Burlington Northern, Inc., the nation's largest railroad system, and the Norfolk & Western Railway Company, the secondlargest coalcarrying road after the Chessie System, reported yesterday sharply higher results in the third quarter and nine months this year. The two carriers benefitted from rising coal traffic and increased freight rates.

title: Study for 3 Agencies Shows Community Planners How to Avoid the Evils of Urban Sprawl
description: Federal agencies are mounting their first attack on urban sprawlthe tendency of communities to, expand haphazardly in the form of singlethoroughfare strip cities and islandlike leapfrog developments.

title: Tax May Be Due on Rockefeller Gifts
description: Several experts on tax law have said that some of the gifts made by former Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller to his friends and associates might be subject to payment of personal income taxes by the recipients.

title: JUSTICES TO RULE ON MENTAL CARE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether involuntary patients in public mental hospitals have a constitutional right to receive some sort of psychiatric treatment, rather than merely custodial care.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
Arabs Prepare for Talks on Mideast Peace Strategy
description: CAIRO, Oct. 20The heads of state or government of 'almost all Arab countries gather this week in Morocco for a meeting potentially so important for the chances of peace in the Middle East that officials in the United States and Israel are delaying policy decisions pending its outcome.

title: L.I. Teacher Strike Halts Classes at Port Jefferson
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., (AP) A strike by about 160 teachers virtually halted classes at Port Jefferson's junior and senior high schools today and forced parents to help out at an elementary school.

title: Is Delayed as Fire Damages Scenery
description: The Broadway revival of the nineteen  twenties musical Good News, starring Alice Faye and John Payne, has been postponed because the show's scenery was heavily damaged before dawn yesterday in a truck fire near Los Angeles.

title: Steel Production Rose 1.3% in Week on Hedge Buying of Products
description: Hedge buying of steel products in anticipation of a possible coal strike next month helped push steel production higher last week for the seventh consecutive week.

title: ROME MORTGAGES SET BY U.S AT 8.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)  The Government announced today that home buyers will get a larger break than originally anticipated under new Federal legislation providing lowinterest loans.

title: DOUGLAS W. BARTON
description: Douglas Williams Barton, a retired vice president and director of the A. H. Bull Steamship Company, died Sunday at his farm in Drydon, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived at 515 Trotters Lane, Elizabeth, N. J.

title: Report Warns of Racial Hostility Festering in City's High Schools
description: The city's Human Rights Commissioner warned yesterday that racial hostility would become the central problem of New York City high schools unless there was immediate action to temper it. She urged the Board of Education, as well as individual schools, to initiate a fullscale drive aimed at preventing student racial clashes and calming neighborhood fears.

title: First Firing in 3 Weeks Is Reported in Nicosia
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 21 (Reuters)Greek and Turkish Cypriotes exchanged machine gun, mortar and rifle fire for one hour tonight along the Green Line dividing the two communities here the police said.

title: National Airlines and Strikers Agree
description: A tentative agreement was reached yesterday in a mechanics' strike that has grounded National Airlines planes for 98 days.

title: DEFENDANT CITES RANSOM PROBLEM
description: NEWARK, Oct. 21A former brakeman for the Penn Central Railroad who inadvertently stumbled onto $50,000 in ransom money intended for the kidnappers of an 8yearold Dix Hills, boy on March 7, testified today that he had kept his half of the missing money because he felt he had no other choice.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Both sides in the strike by most of the 200 faculty members of Rider College in Trenton met with a state mediator in an effort to end the sixdayold dispute. Fivemember negotiating teams for the teachers and the administration of the 110year old liberalarts school met separately with John J. Pearce Jr., the executive director of the State Mediation Board.

title: Quintuplets Gain Weight
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 21 (UPI) Doctors at University Hospital said today that the Rohrer quintuplets gained weight over the weekend. The premature quintuplets' weights today ranged between 2 pounds 7 ounces to 3 pounds 4 ounces.

title: Advertising
description: For many of the country's biggest advertisers the most attractive demographic group is women in the 18 to 49 age group. They are the decisionmakers and spenders for a wide variety of products.

title: N.L.R.B. Studies Macmillan Ousters
description: The National Labor Relations Board and the State Attorney General are investigating allegations that Macmillan, Inc., acted unfairly in its mass dismissal of employes in its bookpublishing divisions last week.

title: Republicans Offer Little Opposition For Congressional Races in the Bronx
description: Mario Biaggi borrowed hi greeting arm back from a thick et of voters' groping hands an draped it behind him on a gil sofa. With an exaggerated sigh of contentment, he summed up the election of 1974:

title: Philadelphia Air Cleaner
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (AP) Air in the Philadelphia area is about 38 per cent cleaner than it was nine years ago, environmental and health groups reported today. A study made by the Delaware Valley Citizens Council for Clean Air and by various chapters of the Lung Associations indicates that air pollution of all significant types but one, oxides of nitrogen, has been substantially cut. Nitrogen oxides, which are created when fuel is burned at very high temperatures, have increased 32 per cent in the area.

title: Packers Defeated By Bears, 10 to 9
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP)Gary Huff's 57yard touchdown pass to Charley Wade gave Chicago an early 100 lead, then the Bears survived three Chester Marcol field goals tonight to gain a 109 National Football League victory over the Green Bay Packers.

title: Independents Add Gusto, But Not Weight, to Election
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  A Milwaukee car dealer listed simply as Crazy Jim is runrung for the governor's office in Wisconsin, in Ann Arbor, Mich., a man named Ronald G. Ziegler, best known by confusion with Richard M. Nixon's press secretary, is the United States Labor party candidate for the House. In Atlanta, WilLiam Ogle is nominally diallenging Representative Andrew Young as the candidate of the In God We Trust Party for Purified Leaders.

title: Brasco Gets 3 Months
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco of Brooklyn was sentenced to three months in prison and fined $10,000 for conspiring to take bribes to help a Mafiacontrolled truck company, get a Post Office contract. Page 35.

title: Court Clears a Bank Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Supreme Court cleaned the way today for an antitrust challenge to a multiplebank acquisition by the Michigan National Corporation, a holding company that had successfully blocked the Government in Federal District Court.

title: MEXICO'S NEW OIL FOR WORLD SALE, ECHEVERRIA SAYS
description: TUBAC, Ariz., Oct. 21President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico confirmed at a meeting with President Ford today that substantial amounts of oil had been discovered in southeast Mexico and said that it would be put on the world market when developed.

title: Japanese Leftists Attack a Visit by Ford
description: TOKYO, Oct. 21Japanese leftists began a drive to stop President Ford's scheduled visit here next month with huge rallies all over Japan today.

title: Plan to Redevelop Piccadilly Adopted By London Council
description: LONDON, Oct. 22 (AP)Official approval was given tonight to a controversial plan to change the face of Piccadilly Circus, the neonlit hub of London's theater district.

title: 8 ExGuardsmen Go on Trial in Kent State Slayings
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 21Jury selection began today in Federal District Court in the trial of eight former National Guardsmen indicted for violating the civil rights of students at Kent State University on May 4, 1970, in a confrontation in which four students were killed and nine were wounded.

title: Pay Rule Altered By Olympic Unit
description: VIENNA, Oct. 21The International Olympic Committee gave an emphatic nod today to a new eligibility code which gives an athlete adequate time for training and payment for that time pending approval by the athlete's national federation.

title: Giants' Dying Offense Remains a Mystery
description: Whatever the New York Giant offense has been talking about during halftime intermissions this year appears to be left behind in the locker room.

title: Member of S. E. C. Denies Fixed Fees Are Aid to Brokers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  A member of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today the agency had no intention at present of modifying its demand for. an end of fixed brokerage commissions on May 1, 1975.

title: TV: NBC's Utterly Convincing Law
description: As if certain prominent aspects of the Watergate scandals didn't do enough to embarrass the legal profession, tonight at 8:30 NBCTV is unleashing a twoandahalfhour drama that should leave the American Bar AssoCiation begging to cop a mercy plea. The Law is produced by William Sackheim, written by Joel Oliansky and directed by John .Badham. The production is crisp, pungent and forceful. Its texture of reality is utterly convincing.

title: Herman A. Metzger Dies; Retired Oil Executive, 74
description: Herman A. Metzger, a retired oil executive, died Saturday at his home, 815 Park Avenue. He was 74 years old.

title: Moscow Seeks Summit
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21The Russians are hoping that Secretary of State Kissinger's visit this Week will demonstrate that the Ford Administration will carry forward the policy of dtente laid out under Richard M. Nixon.

title: Woman Who Scalded Singer Is Ruled Victim of Suicide
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 21 (AP)A medical examiner says that an autopsy confirms that a spurned woman died of a selfinflicted gunshot wound after she scalded Al Green, the pop singer with hot grits.

title: Shunned by TV, Maker of Rare Castro Film Will Close
description: After a frustrating experience with the news divisions of the television networks, Frank M. Mankiewicz and Kirby Jones have said they plan to dissolve their independent company, NEC Productions, which was formed to film exclusive television interviews with world figures who do not normally make themselves available to journalists.

title: RAY TO ASK COURT FOR A NEW TRIAL
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 21James Earl Ray, who pleaded guilty to the murder, in 1968 of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will go into court tomorrow to try to win a new trial.

title: KUH SAYS JUDGE LACKED CANDOR
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan yesterday accused Owen McGivern, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, of an effort to cover up.the improprieties in the selection of members to elite sheriff's jury panels.

title: Kelley Says F.B.I. Needs More Blacks and Women
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (UFOashe Federal Bureau of Investigation meeds more black, Spanishsurnamed and women agents to, help combat an accelerating crime rate, the agency's director, Clarence M. Kelley, said today.

title: Abrams Debates Only Himself at Lefkowitz's Office
description: Robert Abrams, the Democratic candidate for Attorney General, brought two lecterns to the office of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday in an attempt to publicize what he said was the Attorney General's refusal to meet him in debates.

title: Muskie on TV Tonight
description: NBCTV will televise tonight from 7:30 to 8 P.M., Eastern daylight time, a speech by Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, giving the Democratic leadership response to President Ford's speech last week on a voluntary antiinflation program.

title: Woman Gets 5 Years to Life In Killing Despite Rape Plea
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 21 (UPI)Inez Garcia, 30 years old, was sentenced to five years to life in prison today for shooting to death the companion of a man she said had raped her.

title: RATES OFF AGAIN FOR SHORT TERM
