description: More major banks cut their prime rates yesterday and other shortterm interest rates were also lowered. In the bond market, E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. announced plans to sell $500million of notes and debentures, its first trip to the straight debt market in 53 years. While credit market analysts debated rates were coming down because the Federal Reserve was easing monetary policy or simply because credit demand was diminishing in a sluggish economy, decline they did yesterday.

title: Wager Is a Dandy Comedy to Count On for Laughs
description: THE WAGER, a Play by Mark Medoff. Directed by Anthony Perkins; setting by David Mitchell; lighting by Nell Peter Jampolis; costume coordinator, Mary Beth Regan; Production stage manager, Tom Sawyer. Presented by Richard Lee Marks, Henry Jafte and William Craver. At the Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street.

title: People in Sports
description: For the 22d straight time, Walter Alston signed a oneyear contract yesterday to manage the Dodgers. The 62yearold manager of the National League pennant winners came to agreement in Los Angeles with Peter O'Malley, the president of the Dodgers.

title: Closure in London Set By EuropeanAmerican
description: The European  American Bank and Trust Company will close the London branch formerly operated by the Franklin National Bank within a week or two, Klaus Jacobs, vice chairman of EuropeanAmerican, said yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Wood Panel Kills Pratt Student

title: Dane Finds Mao ClearMinded and in Good Humor
description: PEKING, Oct. 21 (Reuters) Chairman Mao Tsetung was clearminded, wellinformed and showed a sense of humor when Premier Pout Hartling of Denmark met him at a secret rendezvous yesterday, the Dane said here today.

title: JUDICIAL REVIEW ADOPTED IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Oct. 21The French National Assembly and Senate, sitting as a constitutional convention, voted today to amend the Constitution of the Fifth Republic to permit judicial review of laws that may infringe on individual liberties. The action brings France closer to concepts long prevailing in the United States.

title: Moscow Seeks Summit
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21The Russians are hoping that Secretary of State Kissinger's visit this week will demonstrate that the Ford. Administration will carry forward the policy of dtente laid out under Richard M. Nixon.

title: DUAL VENTURE SET ON MEXICO COPPER
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21Large copper reserves in northern Mexico are to be exploited by a newly formed joint venture involving the Anaconda Company and Phelps Dodge Corporation as well as Mexican state and private interests.

title: MRS. WALTHER GOEBEL
description: Cornelia Van Rensselaer Robb Goebel, wife of Dr. Walther F. Goebel, emeritus professor of biochemistry at Rockefeller University, died Sunday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 333 East 68th Street and on Vineyard Lane in Greenwich.

title: SOVIET JEW SAID TO FACE CHARGES
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21  Nina Voronel charged today that Soviet authorities were continuing to harass her husband, who for the last 31 months has been denied an exit visa.

title: PORT AIDE CITES LACK OP WEALTH
description: A Jesuit priest yesterday became the second Port Authority commissioner to disclose his net worth.

title: Rice Farmers Fight to Keep Controls
description: JENNINGS, La., Oct. 19The last of the rice is coming in now, overflowing the hoppers of the highwheeled threshers that creep from sunrise to sunset across the muddy paddies of the Louisiana Cajun country.

title: GEOROETTE PISART
description: Georgette Pisart, widow of Fernand Pisart, a leading Belgian industrialist who was here on behalf of the Belgian Government at his death in 1941, died Sunday at her home in the Regency Hotel. Mrs. Pisart had long been active in the New York Association for the Blind. She received the medal of Chevalier of the Order of Leopold in 1959, in recognition of her work for friendship between Belgium and the United States.

title: Connors Vs. Laver for $100,000
description: Jimmy Connors and Rod Laver, who have never met on the tennis court, will play a $100,000 winnertakeall match in January.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Ford's economic summit meetings reveal the experts as being too close to the trees to see the forestthe professional economists enmeshed in statistics, and the representatives of specialinterest groups myopically involved in their problems.

title: U. S. Judge Delays Accord On Nixon Tapes and Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21A Federal judge ordered a delay today in carrying out the agreement on White House tape recordings and papers between the Ford Administration and former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: COMMON MARKET AGREES TO BACK JOINT OIL LOANS
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 21The Finance Ministers of the Common Market agreed this evening on a plan under which the nine member countries could jointly borrow up to $3billion from oilproducing countries to help members cover balanceofpayments deficits caused by Oil imports.

title: Wounded Robber Flees From Police In a Wild Chase
description: A wounded holdup man waiting to have his hand Xrayed after being shot by the police, bolted from the two officers who had captured him last night and led them on a wild chase through the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, and out onto the street, where he managed to make good his escape by ducking down one subway entrance and darting out another.

title: Steele Begins Ad Campaign to Restore Momentum to His Drive for Governorship
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 21Witt only two weeks to go to Election Day, United States Representative Robert H. Steele, the Republican candidate for Governor of Connecticut, began a heavy advertising campaign today to reverse the drift toward what has seemed from the beginning to be an inevitable Democratic victory.

title: Notes on People
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France made it clear yesterday that the two countries wished to end their long disagreement over the future of the Frenchspeaking Canadian province of Quebec, Mr. Trudeau and his wife, Margaret, arrived in Paris for a threeday official visit. He is the first Canadian Prime Minister to visit France since 1967, when Charles de Gaulle told FrenchCanadian separatists in Montreal, Long live free Quebec.

title: Stage: A Prison Comedy
description: Remember the movie Caged? Tom Eyen doesvividly. His new show Women Behind Bars, now running at the New York Theater Ensemble, is a travesty of that picture, in particular, and its genre, in general. Those movies, just like their men behind bars brothers, were mostly glosses, of course, never facing such crucial prison concerns as sex and where can you keep a chicken in a cell? This play is flashy and spicy and Mr. Eyen probably would not have it any, other way.

title: Excerpts From FordEcheverria News Conference
description: TUBAC, Ariz., Oct. 21 (AP)Following are excerpts from the text of today's joint news conference by President Ford and President Luis Echeverra Alvarez.

title: Javits and Clark Trade Charges Of Lack of Integrity in Campaign
description: The accusatory tone intensified in the campaign for United States Senator yesterday as Senator Jacob K. Javits and Ramsey Clark, his Democratic opponent, charged each other with a lack of integrity.

title: A Summary of Various Actions Taken by the United States Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: SPILLS FORECAST IN NEW OIL LEASE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The Interior Department said today that its proposed leasing of 10 million offshore acres for oil and gas drilling would inevitably bring major and minor oil spills.

title: ACTION EXPECTED ON JAWORSKI POST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Henry S. Ruth Jr., the deputy special. Watergate prosecutor, is expected to be named this week to succeed Leon Jaworski. Mr. Jaworski's resignation as special prosecutor takes effect Friday.

title: DR. MARIO OTTOLENGHI
description: Dr. Mario L. Ottolenghi, a chemical engineer and retired vice president of the Chemore Corporation, died Sunday in St. Claire's Hospital of a heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived at 552 Riverside Drive.

title: Threat to UNEF?
description: Renewal of the mandates of the United Nations buffer forces between Israeli and Arab troops in the Middle East is essential to preservation of the shaky armistice there and to the ultimate negotiation of a peace settlement. But concern about U.N. approval of the required renewal resolution has been aroused by private circulation of a Soviet draft criticizing the peacekeeping forces, their Finnish commander and the alleged insufficiency of their supervision by the Security Council.

title: EUROPEANS PLAN CUTS IN GRAIN USE
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 21 The Executive Commission of the European Economic Cornmunity announced new measures today designed to reduce grain consumption and to build up reserve wheat stocks against a possible shortfall of cereal imports from the United States.

title: Weaker Hockey Teams Are Surprising OldLiners
description: What's the only undefeated team in the National Hockey League? The Los Angeles Kings. Who leads the Conn Smithe Division by 2 points? The Vancouver Canucks. What team posted the first shutout in its history and is tied for first in the Lester Patrick Division? The New York Islanders.

title: Hearst FoodPlan Extortion Charged
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 (AP)The police are investigating an allegation that two Black Muslims extorted $99,600 from the food giveaway program set up to help free Patricia Hearst, The San Francisco Chronicle reported today.

title: Governor Vetoes Bill On Acquittal Notices
description: TRENTON, Oct. 22 (AP)Governor Byrne today vetoed legislation that would have required publication in daily newspapers of a notice of the acquittal of defendants in criminal cases. The Governor said that the measure, sponsored by Senator William V. Musto, Democrat of Hudson, raises the type of First Amendment issues that have been closely scrutinized by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Amex Seat Cost Unchanged
description: A membership seat on the American Stock Exchange sold for $40,000, is unchanged from the last sale on Oct. 18, the Amex announced yesterday. At present, the bid price for a seat is $34,000, and the asking price is $50,000.

title: 3 JUDGES ASSAIL CAMPUS RIOT UNIT
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 21 (AP) The officers on riot duty at Jackson State College overreacted when they fired into a dormitory on May 14, 1970, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: ACTION EXPECTED ON JAWORSKI POST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Henry S. Ruth Jr., the deputy special Watergate prosecutor, is expected to be named this week to succeed Leon Jaworski. Mr. Jaworski's resignation as special prosecutor takes effect Friday.

title: Students in South Boston Clash, Other Schools Calm
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP)An assembly of ninth graders at a small high school in South Boston erupted into racial fighting today as city schools entered their sixth week of courtordered integration.

title: CableTV Viewers Get Films
description: WALNUT CREEK, Calif. (AP) A closedcircuit network using General Electric Cablevision's airspace reported recently that 1,600 Walnut Creek TVcable users have signed up for a movie package that features firstrun films. The Walnut Creek channel carries 10 showings of 10 current motion pictures per month.

title: Strike Slows French Mail
description: PARIS, Oct. 21 (Reuters) Aboutu 90 per cent of the 85,000 employes of the mailsorting centers here are on strike over pay and working conditions, reducing deliveries to a minimom. The strike began Thursday.

title: 3 Accused of Negligence In Drug Death of a Man
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 21 (UPI)Two men and a woman face negligent manslaughter charges today for allegedly failing to get help for a suburban Los Angeles man dying of a drug overdose, the police said.

title: People and Business
description: Price stability, rather than a price decline, appears to be the best, hope in the world oil picture, according to J. K. Jamieson, chairman of the Exxon Corporation. At a news conference in Toronto, Mr. Jamieson said he could not foresee a decline in world crudeoil prices in the coming year and declined to predict when prices might stabilize.

title: Wilson Accuses Carey of Fakery on Vital Issues
description: CHEEKTOWAGA, N. Y., Oct. 21Governor Wilson charged today that Representative Hugh L. Carey, his Democratic opponent, was engaging in first degree fakery by being deliberately vague and dissembling when he discussed vital issues.

title: Earnings Climb to Record At A.B.C. in Third Quarter
description: Thirdquarter earnings of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., reached a records total of $11.4million, or 68 cents a share, compared with the yearearlier $7.8million, of 46 cents a snare, after an extraordinary loss of $2.3million.

title: RONAN'S CAPACITY IS CAST IN DOUBT
description: TRENTON, Oct. 21Reacting angrily to an announced delay by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in the planned extension of its PATH rapid transit system in New Jersey, Governor Byrne and State Transportation Commissioner Alan Sagner raised considerable doubt today about Dr. William J. Ronan's capacity to continue as chairman of the bistate agency.

title: Secretary Leaves Tonight
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Secretary of State Kissinger flies, to. Moscow tomorrow night to test the willingness of the Soviet leadership to work with the Ford Administration for a curb on strategic arms and a settlement of European and Middle Eastern problems.

title: Briage: Right and Wrong Are Tricky And Depend on Circumstances
description: Right and wrong are tricky words to use, in bridge situations as well as in life. Circumstances cannot be ignored. The experienced player knows the right way to handle all common suit combinations, but he does not always realize that the appropriate play may depend on the number of entries available to one hand or the other.

title: New Cultural Agency
description: Creation of a Cultural Affairs Agency for New York City apart from the Parks Administration is overdue recognition that while only God can make a tree it takes professionals to mount a play or run a museum or attract movie producers to shoot films here. While many cultural activities do take place in the parks, the complexities of New York as entertainment capital of the worda distinction it still enjoys despite the Gomorrah of grind houses in midtown Manhattanrequire an independent agency in another part of the forest of city bureaucracy.

title: McCrane Denied Venue Change In Conspiracy and Fraud Trial
description: NEWARK, Oct. 21a Federal district court judge today denied, a request by Joseph M. McCrane, the former New Jersey State Treasurer, for a change in venue of his Federal campaign fraud and conspiracy trial.

title: In the Season Of the Elk
description: ESTES PARK, Colo.This is the mating season of the elk and Rocky Mountain National Park is copiously posted with signs warning tourists to stay on the highways and well away from the herds; otherwise, there might be fewer elk for the future.

title: No WIN With Butz
description: A House subcommittee report released last weekend prophesies mass starvation and a world food crisis more severe than the current energy crisis if present trends in population and food production are not changed. Over the same weekend the Administration announced plans for grain sales to the Soviet Union, somewhat scaled down from the ones recently canceled at President Ford's urging, but still very substantial.

title: Dory Previn Fills Songs With Humor And SelfAnalysis
description: Dory Previn, in the best traditions of the singersongwriter, gives much of herself in her musicmusic as selfanalysis. What's more, she goes in foras she did at Avery Fisher Hall on Sundaylengthy freeassociation explanations of her songs, which are actually more than capable of explaining themselves.

title: Panel Studying City U. Tenure Rejects Quotas and Urges Present Policy Be Continued
description: A committee studying the tenure policies of the City University has rejected a quota system to limit tenure and called for what amounts to a continuation of most current practices, apparently ending a yearlong controversy.

title: JUSTICES TO RULE ON MENTAL CARE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether involuntary patients in public mental hospitals have a constitutional right to receive some sort of psychiatric treatment, rather than merely custodial tare.

title: Six Drawn to Death In Bakery by Chance
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 21The six people who died here Saturday night in a methodical executionstyle murder were drawn to their deaths together by the merest chance.

title: $93,500 Found in a Box
description: ELSMERE, Ky., Oct. 21 (UPI)  Police Chief William Hiler was making a routine search through the house of Jim Holloran; 68yearold bachelor who died earlier this month, when he spotted a docked fishing tackle box. Mtrigued, the police chief opened the box with a key and found more than $93,500 in cash in the box. Mr. Holloran, who had been a restaurant owner, was described by a friend as a very private person.

title: French Report 534,000 Jobless, Highest Level Since End of War
description: PARIS, Oct. 21The French Government reported today that the number of people looking for work at the end of last month topped 500,000 for the first time since World War II and was up more than 100,000 over the figure at the end of August.

title: Weinstein Says 2, As Protest, Left BioMedical Board
description: Berel Weinstein, who had been chairman, president and chief executive officer of BioMedical Sciences, Inc., until last Friday when he was ousted from these posts at a board meeting, said yesterday that two directors had resigned in strong protest over the actions and tactics of the board. Henry B. Makover and Frank Gabor, to whom he referred, are not new directors as inadvertantly stated in yesterday's newspaper.

title: Court Finds No Job Bias Against Black Applicant
description: The Appellate Division Second Department has ruled that a black employe of the Sperry Rand Corporation had not been discriminated against when the company turned him down in favor of a white man for a job as an automatic turret lathe operator.

title: No Political Endorsements
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21 (AP)The Pittsburgh Press says it will not endorse candidates for any office this year. In the wake of Watergate, the credibility of America's politicans has, I believe, receded to its lowest level in my lifetime, said John Troan, Press editor, in a column yesterday.

title: Wedding of Pop and Classical Music
description: Most composers who try to interbreed the types of music that in a simpler time we called popular and classical do not have enough talent in either line to make their experiments interesting. Stanley Silverman, on the other hand, might easily become, with a slight push in one direction or the other, either a poor, respected composer of academic esoterica or a rich, respected composer of show tunes.

title: Court Data Call Attention Again to Chandler's Role in Oil Drilling Investment Program
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21Court documents, which had been under seal, have called attention again to the role played by Otis Chandler, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, in a controversial oil drilling investment program set up by GeoTek Resources Fund, Inc.

title: Concorde in California After Trip From Mexico
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 (AP)The Concorde supersonic transport whistled into San Francisco International Airport today after an 1,880mile flight from Mexico City in 2 hours 19 minutes.

title: F.D.A. Chief Is Criticized Over a Sugar Substitute
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, has criticized Food and Drug Commissioner Alexander M. Schmidt for allowing the sugar substitute Aspartame to be manufactured and distributed before holding a public hearing on it.

title: 2 CHARGED IN MIAMI IN BEATING OF BLACK
description: MIAMI, Oct. 21Dade County State Attorney Richard E. Gerstein filed charges of assault and battery today against two white Miami policemen in the beating of an undercover black policeman.

title: Britain's Best Chance
description: In existing circumstances, Britain's recent election may have produced the best possibleor least badresult.

title: Raiders Beat Clock But It Was Close
description: The lead changed six times. Oakland scored the winning touchdown with eight seconds left and the quarterback, Ken Stabler, said later, We usually win those kind of games. But the Raiders, whose team motto is Pride and Poise, cut it a little close on Sunday against Cincinnati. With three minutes left, Oakland was behind, 2723, and stymied at the Bengal 32yard line. What to do? Coach John Madden ordered a punt. There was never any doubt in my mind, he said later. With three timeouts left, three minutes is a lot of time. So the Raiders gave the ball back to the Bengals, a powerful team. Would they ever get it back?

title: ANGOLA POTENTIAL IS TERMED GREAT
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 16Angola is not quite the colony it was a few months ago and yet it is still not independent, a young white businessman recently observed in that Portuguese colony's capital city of Luanda.

title: ALFRED B. KUPFERBERG
description: Alfred B. Kupferberg, a microbiologist, died Sunday at his home Sunday. He was 61 years old and lived at 2 Claire Drive, Somerville, N.J.

title: WILSON ASSAILS VOTES BY CAREY
description: Governor Wilson yesterday accused Representative Hugh L. Carey, his Democratic opponent, of having a poor voting record on environmental issues.

title: INSIDER IS HUNTED IN CHICAGO THEFT
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (UPI)Investigators, worked today on the assumption that a multimilliondollar vault burglary, believed to be the biggest cash looting in, American criminal history, was masterminded by an insder who knew the lock's Combination and how to bypass a sensitive alarm system.

title: ExPrincipal and 3 Arrested at P.S. 34 As Security Is Stepped Up in District 1
description: The former principal of Public School 34 and three other men were arrested and charged with criminal trespass yesterday morning as they tried to entet the troubled school on the Lower East Side.

title: Maryland Election Races Produce Little Prospect of Any Upsets
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 22Statewide election campaigns in Maryland this fall were expected to generate unusual verve and content and to pose welcome, if difficult, choices for voters among attractive candidates. But thus far they have been producing more laughs than highminded debate.

title: Jaworski Tells of First Hint on Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Less than two months after he became special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski reached the conclusion, he says, that Richard M. Nixon was involved in the Watergate coverup.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: EAST ORANGE, Oct. 23  Charles Lundgren, the tongtime Upsala College tennis coach, is a man of innovations. Sometimes his philosophy and theories astonish his players. For instance, he has tried hypnosis rand contends that it has worked, instilling a sense of confidence and mental superiority on the court.

title: Rutherford Wings Stop Capitals, 30
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 22 (UPI)Bill Lochead tallied twice within 29 seconds in the first period tonight to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 30 National Hockey League victory over the Washington Capitals.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This may sound strange, but my contention is that China should have the potentiality and willingness to bail the United States out from a serious economic downturn, despite public statements to the contrary.

title: Packers Get Hadl
description: In National Football League trades yesterday the Los Angeles Rams sent John Hadl, the quarterback, to the Green Bay Packers.

title: Ashe Upset, Gottfried Tops Kodes
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 22 (AP)Arthur Ashe was upset, 61, 76, by Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia in the second round of the $100,000 Iranian tennis tournament today.

title: Center of Carmel Desttoyed in Fire
description: CARMEL, N. Y., Oct. 22A string of six stores that had formed the heart of this Putnam County hamlet's business district for more than a century was destroyed last night in a swiftmoving fire that drew volunteer fire departments from half a dozen surrounding communities and caused damage estimated at $1million.

title: FORD SEES THREAT TO FOREIGN POLICY
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 22President Ford contended today that if the Democrats gained a wide margin of Congressional seats in the election next month the chances for a bipartisan foreign policy would be threatened and peace could be in jeopardy.

title: Oil Money May Make the Mideast's Deserts Bloom
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 21The countries of the Middle East and North Africa have a potential for food production] that many agricultural experts believe could make a substantial contribution to meeting the world's food needs.

title: Stopping the Endless FoodPrice Spiral
description: WASHINGTONIn the last three years, food prices have leaped 34 per cent. In 1973 our total food bill jumped $14 billion, from $125 billion to $139 billion.

title: Man Guilty of Rape Under Law Waiving Corroboration Rule
description: A 23yearold clerical worker who was found guilty of rape charges last Monday may be the first person convicted under the new state law that permits convictions without corroboration, the Bronx District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Music: Russian Evening
description: A program of Russian music that opens with Mussorgsky and closes with Prokofiev's strenuous cantata Alexander Nevsky seems in prospect to guarantee an evening of bonerattling sound and great splashes of orchestral color. For some reason, a lot of Russian music from Glinka to Shostakovich has little on its mind beyond that, but at its best it has attractive vigor and dash.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SMALL ENCHANTED EVENING The incoming Off Off Broadway season will have to look sharp to match one early bird, a trio of new short plays by Michael Shurtleff. The production has just opened a comfortable, snug showcase called the Corner Loft Theater (CH 35689, 4779799) at 121 University Place (and 13th Street). For $2.50, you get three pieces of imaginative theater  well written, performed and stagedand a lingering taste of skill and fun.

title: Music: French Chanson
description: Hunter College Playhouse audiences are being treated this season to an exploration of French, American and German songs in three recitals by Paul Sperry, tenor, and Martin Katz, his pianist. The first recital, on Monday night, took a fresh look at French chansons by including examples from composers who are usually neglected where this form is concerned.

title: Dance: Joffrey Gives Local Premiere of Evening Dialogues
description: There is nothing very much Wrong with Evening Dialogues, a new ballet by Jonathan Watts given its New York premiere by the City Center Joffrey Ballet at the City Center 55th Street Theater last night. Unfortunately there is nothing very much right about it either.

title: ELIE LESCOT DIES; LEADER IN HAITI
description: PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 22 (AP)  Elie Lescot, President of Haiti from May 15, 1941, to Jan. 11, 1946, died today at La Boule, Haiti. He was 90 years old.

title: Rail Worker Is Guilty In Ransom Cash Case
description: NEWARK, Oct. 22A former Penn Central brakeman was found guilty today of lying to a grand jury and possession of $50,000 in ransom money intended for the kidnappers of 8yearold John Calzadilla of Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Spot Gold Market Set By Chicago Exchange
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange plans to open the nation's first spot gold market and provide a cash price three times each day, when gold trading becomes legal. At present it is expected the Government will permit Americans to own and trade in gold on Jan. 1.

title: Profits at Minnesota Mining Rise 8.5%
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, producers of a wide variety of products ranging from Scotch brand tape to graphic systems and abrasives, reported yesterday that thirdquarter earnings were up 8.5 per cent and sales, up 16.8 per cent. Ninemonth earnings rose 8.8 per cent on a sales gain of 17.3 per cent.

title: Congress Races Studied
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 22In a reversal of the usual situation, Democratic Congressional candidates are raising more money this year than are Republicans, according to a study released today by Common Cause.

title: TWO BODIES FOUND IN EAST NEW YORK
description: The bodies of two 17yearold Brooklyn youths were found in an empty lot in East New York yesterday morning, and hours later detectives arrested two 16yearolds and a 15yearold and charged them with killing the youths.

title: DEAN TELLS COURT HE WITHHELD DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 John W. Dean 3d admitted under crossexamination today that he had continued to withhold damaging information about Watergate for many months after he had said that he had broken from the Watergate conspiracy and had told the authorities everything he knew.

title: Thieu Is Facing Strongest Opposition Yet
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 22Nguyen Van Thieu, who has led South Vietnam for nine years, has suddenly found himself embattled on the political front as never before.

title: Colborn Has Surgery
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 22 (UPI)  The Milwaukee Brewers said today Jim Colborn, who was plagued by injuries in 1974 after winning 20 games in 1973, underwent successful surgery yesterday on his left knee. The Brewers said Colborn, a righthander, was expected to be hospitalized about a week.

title: Islanders Win, 21, On Bourne's Goal
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 22 The rallying cry seemed unnatural in Nassau Coliseum. We are No. 1. We are No. 1, cheered the crowd of 11,254 as the New York Islanders pulled out a 21 victory over the Atlanta Flames tonight on a goal by a rookie, Bob Bourne, in the last 43 seconds.

title: About New York Clothes Are in Fashion Again
description: One thing about New York is that there is no boredom in it, and that whatever the problems of living here, ennui is not among them. New York is really a collection of big stage sets, and while the sets stay more or less the same, the people who pass in and out among them do not. The people shift, changing their worries and joys, and changing, of course, their clothes.

title: Turcotte Replaced By Piggott on Dahlia
OneThird of Taxis Tested So Far by City Fail Mandatory Inspection at Queens Center
description: Since late July, when the city started calling taxicabs into a new inspection center for mandatory annual inspections, more than onethird of the 1,728 vehicles tested have failed.

title: Flea Collar Warning Issued
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency issued a warning today against the human use of flea collars. Such collars, intended for use on pets, may be poisonous when worn by humans, the agency said.. Pet store owners have been quoted in newspapers as saying that people are buying Fleacollars for their own personal use.

title: MatraSimca Team Loses Subsidy
description: PARIS, Oct. 21 (AP)  ChryslerFrance confirmed today it was ending its $2million annual support to the French MatraSimca auto racing team, which has won the world championship of makes for sports cars the last two years. Chrysler, which owns the French Simca company, also is dropping its twoliter sports car competition program in the economy move. But Chrysler spokesmen emphasized that cooperation with Matra to build and distribute the Matra Bagheera sports car with a Simca engine would cintinue. Ending the racing subsidy to Matra put that company's racing future in considerable doubt. The subsidy accounted for about half its racing budget.

title: Programs for the Many, Airwaves for the Few
description: BERKELEY, Calif.Congress is nearing final approval of a bill designed by broadcasters and newspaper owners to make their existing television and radio licenses all but permanent. Such action is deserving of public disdain.

title: Gulf and 2 Other Oil Companies Also Improve
description: No letup in the oil industry's soaring earnings appeared in bight yesterday as major oil companies reported sharply higher profits for the third quarter of 1974.

title: Queens and Westchester Show Population Declines
description: New Census Bureau estimates yesterday reported population declines in Queens and Westchester Countythe first ever for Queens, and Westchester's first since 1880along with continuing declines for New York City as a whole, Nassau County and the entire state.

title: BEAME DEFENDS CREDIT POSITION
description: Amid all the recent talk of the city's budget deficit and fiscal difficulties, Mayor Beame struck an optimistic note yesterday by asserting that the city's credit position had improved considerably during the last 15 years and was solid and strong.

title: ABC Television Names Pierce New President
description: The appointments of Walter S. Schwartz as president of the newly created ABC Leisure Group II and of Frederick S. Pierce as. president of ABC Television were announced yesterday.

title: Quintuplets Doing Well
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 22 (UPI)  The Rohrer quintuplets turned two weeks old today, and doctors reported that all five were doing fine. Belinda and Jennifer joined Russell and Sandra today on a larger feeding schedule, receiving food every three hours. Only Michelle, the first born of the sixweeks premature babies, was still being fed every two hours.

title: U.N. DELAYS VOTE ON PEACE FORCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22The United Nations Security Council postponed until tomorrow its debate on renewal of the mandate for the United Nations peacekeeping force in the Sinai and instead continued a debate on South Africa.

title: QUARTER NETS UP IN METALS FIELD
description: Largely as a result of higher prices and heavy sales volume a number of the nation's lead ing metals and steel companies yesterday reported sharply higher earnings for the third quarter.

title: KENT STATE JURY TENTATIVELY SET
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 22 (AP)  Twelve jurors were tentatively seated today for the trial of eight former Ohio National Guardsmen indicted in the 1970 Kent State University shootings.

title: People of Japanese Castle Town Glad It Was Bypassed in Industrial Surge
description: KANAZAWA, JapanThe mighty surge of Japanese industry in recent years has left this old castle town be and the people here are glad of it.

title: SCHOOL IS BOMBED IN TEXTBOOK RIFT
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 22 (AP)An elementary school was bombed today as new violence erupted in Kanawha County's sevenweekold textbook protest.

title: ARAB MINISTERS MEETING IN RABAT
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 22Foreign Ministers from the Arab League countries opened three days of preparatory talks here today and immediately made it clear that a conference of Arab leaders starting here Saturday would be dominated by the question of Palestine.

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN LISTS QUARTER LOSS
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc., the parent of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, the brokerage firm, reported here yesterday that it lost $1.33million for the third quarter ended Sept. 30, down from a gain of $1.44million, or 18 cents share, a year ago.

title: A $70Million Hospital Planned on Staten Island
description: The board of trustees of Staten Island Hospital announced yesterday that it would build a new hospital on the island in order to accommodate the large number of persons waiting daily for admission. This number has been put at between 100 and 150.

title: A BOMB INJURES 3 IN A LONDON CLUB
description: LONDON, Oct. 22Three persons were injured by a bomb thrown tonight at the Brooks Club, an exclusive club on St. James's Street less than half a mile from Buckingham Palace.

title: Two Subway Employes Killed By IRT Work Train in Brooklyn
description: Two subway workers picking up equipment along an express track at 2 A.M. yesterday, were killed by an IRT work train near the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn.

title: Homebuilding Prognosis
description: LAKE GENEVA, Wis., Oct., 22Leaders of the American somebuilding industry have been deep in a seminar here with economists, Government officials and environmental critics of their industry in an effort to find answers to the question of how they can get back on a growth track  in an economy in which growth appears to have gone out of style.

title: Prison Reform Chief Named
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 (UPI)A former assistant district attorney was appointed by a threejudge panel yesterday to manage courtordered reforms of the city's prisons. The Common Pleas Court panel named Walter W. Cohen, 33 years old, to serve as master, or court agent.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Lavanoux ChurchArt Expert Is Dead
description: Maurice alvanoux, a specialist in church art, died Monday at his home. He was 80 years old and lived at 3435 79th Street, Jackson Heights, QuQeens.

title: Swiss Bank Puts Loss at $48.9Million
description: ZURICH, Oct. 22The Union Bank of Switzerland said today that what it described last April as a sizable loss from foreignexchange operations actually totaled $48.9million.

title: ExEnvoy to Chile Denounces Leaks Discrediting Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22The director general of the Foreign Service has expressed concern in the State Department's newsletter about malicious or calculated leaks aimed at discrediting high officials.

title: Snake Handler Dies of Bite, As His FatherinLaw Did
description: EAST LYNN, W. Va., Oct. 22 (UPI)A 28yearold religious cult snake handler died in this Wayne County community yesterday of an untreated snakebitethe same way his fatherinlaw died two months ago.

title: Congress Races Studied
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 22In reversal of the usual situation Democratic Congressional can didates are raising more money this year than are Republicans according to a study release( today by Common Cause.

title: STUDENTS IN BOSTON SEARCHED FOR ARMS
description: BOSTON, Oct. 22 (AP)Students were searched with metal detectors today as officials tried to prevent them from taking weapons into two racially troubled high schools.

title: Rockefeller Won't Reply To Press Queries for Now
description: WASHINGTON, act. 22 Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller issued tonight a statement declaring that he would answer no urther questions by news organizations until he next appeared before the two Congressional committees considering his nommation.

title: Special Clinton Zoning Voted by Commission
description: Special zoning protection for the Clinton neighborhood was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission after revisions were made to satisfy objections by residents of the West Side area.

title: Racial Clashes in Mozambique Leave 49 Dead, Many Injured
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Oct. 22 (Reuters)Portuguese' and black nationalist troops toured the wreckagestrewn Streets of Mozambique's capital today appealing for calm after a night of racial violence in which at least 49 people were killed.

title: U.S. DROPS CHARGES IN PONTIAC BOMBING
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22 (AP)The Federal Government dismissed charges today against five men arrested in the 1971 bombing of school buses in Pontiac.

title: Warrants Are Issued by Police Arson Investigators in Burning of Kentucky Newspaper
description: When someone poured kerosene through a broken tvindow infp the offices of The Mountain Eagle, a little weekly newspaper in Whitesburg, Ky., and put the torch to it almost three months ago there was no shortage of people with a possible motive.

title: NEW STUDY LINKS MUMPS, DIABETES
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 22Researchers from the State University of Buffalo reported today finding new evidence linking diabetes mellitus to mumps virus.

title: Taxi Panel Votes 17.5% Increase Nov. 1; Says Average Ride Will Go Up 35 Cents
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission announced yesterday that it had approved an increase in the fare rate averaging 17.5 per cent for the city's 11,787 medallion taxicabs.

title: LISBON PREPARES ELECTION RULES
description: LISBON, Oct. 22The militarydominated Government of Portugal is preparing an elaborate set of rules for the country's first free election since the first republic fell in 1926.

title: U.N. Group Votes 839 to Urge Chile To Restore Rights
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22The General Assembly's Social Committee voted today to urge the 13monthold military Government in Chile to restore human rights and free political prisoners detained after the overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: CANADA TIGHTENS RULES COVERING IMMIGRANT FLOW
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 22The Canadian Government, concerned over the steeply rising numbers and changing racial patterns in the steady flow of immigrants here, announced tighter regulations on new entries today.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Prompted by new disclosures of covert operations of the United States Central Intelligence Agency in Chile, a growing number of Congressmen are demanding that such agency actions be curtailed or stopped altogether.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: Excerpts From the Debate by 3 Candidates Seeking the United States Senate Seat
description: Following are excerpts from the debate among Senator Jacob K. Javits, Ramsey Clark and Barbara Keating, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Market Place
description: A number of major corporations have been shifting gears from an accounting point of view to conserve cash through a reduction in socalled inventory profits. They have thus sparked a debate in Wall Street.

title: A $500,000 Stock Fraud Is Charged to 7 by U.S.
description: A Federal grand jury in Manhattan has indicted seven men in a stock swindle that allegedly netted them nearly $500,000. City.

title: Turcotte Replaced By Piggott on Dahlia
description: Did Ron Turcotte give Dahlia the kind of tide she deserved in the recent Man o' War Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: Red Smith
description: If George Foreman and Muhammad Ali can stay upright one more week, their chance will come at last fight their way out of the African bush and into the ranks of economic royalty. When plans for a heavyweight championship in Kinshasa, Zaire, were announced last March, Hank Schwartz of Video Techniques, Inc., said letters of credit covering the fighters' purses had been deposited in Chicago and California banks by Risnelia Investment, Inc., the Swiss firm bankrolling the promotion.

title: Elizabeth H. Cook, Director Of Gazette in Little Rock
description: Elizabeth Heiskell Cook, a director of The Gazette in Little Rock, Ark., and a former member of that newspaper's staff, died yesterday in New Haven. She was 62 years old and lived in Old Lyme, Conn., and Jefferson, N.H.

title: Policemen Are Ordered To Kill Felony Suspects
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 (AP) Darby Township Police Chief William Johnson has issued orders for his patrolmen to try to kill suspects caught in the act of a felony.

title: Books of The Times
description: ANGELA DAVIS. An Autobiography. By Angela Yvonne Davis. 400 pages. A Bernard Geis Associates Book. Random Rouse. $8.95.

title: Judge Eases Rule On Papers of Nixon Involving ExAides
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP)  Federal. District Judge Charles R. Richey issued today an amended order slightly relaxing the seal that he had put on former President Richard M. Nixon's tape recordings and papers.

title: Minnesota Hall Acoustically Sound
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 22Orchestra Hall, the first permanent home of the 73yearold Minnesota Orchestra, was opened offically last night in downtown Minneapolis. Rushed to completion in 16 months, at a cost of about $.10million, it has proved to be a hall with unusual acoustic properties, as demonstrated by the orchestra and its conductor, Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, in a program of BachSkrowaczewski, Ives, Stravinsky and Beethoven.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE CUP

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 22The administrator of the Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration sided today with Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, in his dispute with Governor Byrne and New Jersey transportation officials over a proposed $300million PATH rapid transit extension from Newark to Plainfield.

title: Consumer Group Offers Guide to Queens Doctors
description: Charging that it is easier to buy a good toaster than to select a good doctor, the New York Public Interest Research Group yesterday released a ocnsumer's Guide to Queens Doctors that lists the office hours, billing practices and hospital affiliations for 335 of the 900 general practitioners and general internists presumed to be practicing in the county.

title: JOHN B. WRIGHT
description: John B. Wright, who retired in 1963 as vice president and assistant manager of United States borrowings for the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, died yesterday of a massive internal hemorrhage. He was 76 years old and lived at 233 Sands Lane, Hewlett, Li., and in Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: TV: ABC Afterschool Shows Sturdy Adam Rush
description: While ABCTV's Afterschool Specials series deserves high marks for today's production, at 4:30, of The Bridge of Adam Rush, it has to get a sharp rap on the knuckles for Sara's Summer of the Swans, which was shown a few weeks ago. More about that later.

title: EASTERN AIR LINES SHOWS RECOVERY
description: Earnings of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., continued to recover in the thirdquarter. Profits amounted to $6.3million, in contrast to a loss of $15.4million in the similar three months last year.

title: Center of Carmel Destroyed in Fire
description: CARMEL, N. Y., Oct. 22A string of six stores that had formed the heart of this Putnam County hamlet's business district for more than a century was destroyed last night in a swiftmoving fire that drew volunteer fire departments from half a dozen surrounding communities and caused damage estimated at $1million.

title: Girl, 5 Months in Plastic Room, Leaves Hospital Today
description: ALBANY, Oct. 22Nineyearold Bobbie Archer of Englishtown, N. J., is scheduled to leave the Albany Medical Center tomorrow cured, it is hoped, of aplastic anemia, a rare bonemarrow disease that has kept her in an isolation room since May 19.

title: Art Dealers Court Middle East Marke
description: Has the time arrived for a wellrounded art person to learn Arabic? David Nash, a senior vice president of Sotheby Parke Bernet, seems to think so. On the theory that it might prove useful the auction house executive, whose antenna for the art market is said to be acute, is taking a crash course in the language at Berlitz.

title: U.S. Aide Says Gas Rationing Or Tax Rises May Be Needed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) John R. Quarles Jr., deputy administrator of the EnvironMental Protection Agency, said today that additional gasoline. taxes or some form of rationing might still be necessary to cope with energy problems.

title: Change of Format For Minor League
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 22 (AP)The directors of the International League voted today to eliminate the baseball league's twodivision plan and revert to the eightclub program next season, according to George Sisler, the league president.

title: Consumer Price Index Here Shows the Largest Yearly Increase Since 1947
description: Catapulted by sharp rises in the cost of food and housing ownership and maintenance, the Consumer Price Index for the metropolitan New YorkNorthern New Jersey region shot up 11.7 per cent during the oneyear period ended in September, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Ravenel to Back Successor But Only With WriteIn Vote
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 22 Charles D. Ravenel, who was denied the Democratic nomination for Governor of South Carolina by the courts because he failed to meet a state residence requirement, said today that he would cast a writein vote for Representative William Jennings Bryan Dorn, who replaced him as the party's nominee.

title: WILSON ADDRESSES FORUM IN HARLEM
description: Governor Wilson told a predominantly black and Democratic audience in Harlem last night that black voters should for God's sake stop being taken for granted by the Democratic party.

title: Slaying Suspect Held
description: The police charged Mrs. JoAnne Brown with the murder of a law secretary who was found slain in State Supreme Court chambers in Mineola, L. I., last Sept. 30. Details on Page 28.

title: 3Way Senatorial Debate Erupts Intoan Angry JavitsClark Clash
description: A debate among the New York candidates for United States Senator that focused on campaign financing and the nation's troubled economy suddenly flared into an angry facetoface argument yesterday.

title: Poorer Israelis Said to Eat More Nutritiously Than Rich
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 22 (Reuters)  Lowerincome Israeli families are eating more nutritious foods than people in upperincome categories, according to a threeyear study by the National Institute released today.

title: Move to Coast Club Shocks Outfielder
description: Bobby Murcer, once heralded as the Yankees' next Mickey Mantle, traded teams yesterday with Bobby Bonds, once touted as the Giants' next Willie Mays.

title: 11 Are Indicted on Bribes For Queens Gambling Ring
description: Ten reputed members of organized crime and one police officer were indicted yesterday on charges that they had bribed undercover agentswho were posing as rogue copsto fix cases and obtain secret police information to protect a multimilliondollar gambling operation in Queens.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NEWPORT BEACH,.Calif., Oct 22 (AP)Eight of the 10 operating World Football League teams, drafted 16 of the defunct Detroit Wheels' 37 players today Philadelphia claimed Bubba Wyche, the quarterback who signed with the Chicago Fire after the Wheels went bankrupt recently. Philadelphia and Chicago later agreed that Wyche would remain with the Fire and that the Bell would receive compensation. The Hawaiians and the Florida Blazers the latter having been taken over by the league, were the only teams that didn't pick up a player in the telephone conference draft. Gary Davidson, W.F.L. president, said the league would pay the salaries of player who were not selected. Detroit had signed no National Football League players for the future. Shreveport, draftingg first in the reverse order of the standings, selected Mike Walker, a defensive end from Tulane. Portland seleeted a former New Mexico State running back, Jesse Mims, and the Hawaiians passed before Philadelphia named Wyche.

title: Judge Assails the Public For Avoiding Jury Duty
description: NEWARK, Oct. 22The presiding judge of Essex County Superior Court today bitterly denounced what he termed the miserable failure of the average citizen who refuses to serve on county juries, and said he would now rule on all excuse requests from potential jurors.

title: Prices Up ...
description: The one area of steady growth in the national economy is the inflation rate. The official announcement yesterday of another big jump in consumer prices last month brings the total increase for the year to more than 12 per cent, with no letup in sight.

title: Business Briefs
description: Foreign companies have invested in 72 manufacturing ventures in the United States during the third quarter of 1974, the Conference Board said yesterday.

title: Stocks Close Mixed As Trading Picks Up
description: The threesession advance on the New York Stock Exchange ended yesterday as profit taking and unfavorable economic news caused prices to finish mixed in accelerated trading.

title: Metropolitar Briefs
description: The New York Public Interest Research Group has released a Consumer's Guide to Queens Doctors, which reports the fees, office hours, billing practices and hospital affiliations, of about onethird of the 900 general practitioners and general internaists in the county.

title: PRICE INDEX ROSE 12% IN SEPTEMBER; 129 OVER YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22The Consumer Price Index rose substantially again in September, as the retail prices of foods took another jump, the Labor Department announced today.

title: Wards I. Escapee Sought in Slaying, Of a Psychologist
description: A 26yearold man who was sent to a state hospital for the criminal insane after he allegedly stabbed a girlfried to death three years ago is being sought in the murder of Judith Becker, a 26yearold staff psychologist at the Fishkill Correctional Facility in Beacon, N.Y.

title: Venezuela to Nationalize Oil and Iron by Yearend
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 22 (Reuters)President Carlos Andres Perez said here today that Venezuela's oil and iron industries would be nationalized by the end of the year.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Delaware River Port Authority is studying recommendations by a Federal hearing examiner to slash tolls on three bridges between New Jersey and Pennsylvania by 10 cents. A spokesman said that we are surprised at the recommendations and added that the authority soon would file a request for exceptions with the Federal Highway Administration.

title: Connecticut Utilities See Themselves As Victims of State Election Campaign
description: In Africa there is a proverb: When elephants fight, it is'the grass that suffers.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

description: A debate among the New York candidates for United States Senator that focused on campaign financing and the nation's troubled economy suddenly flared into an angry facetoface argument yesterday.

description: News Summary and Index, Page 47

title: Businesses Contribute
description: Scores of companies, ranging from Wall Street brokerage houses to neighborhood restaurants, have taken advantage of a controversial New York state law that allows them to contribute legally for the first time in statewide political contests.

title: Grant Hits 41 Points As Q's Win
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 22 (UPI)Travis Grant scored 41 points, 15 in the final period as the San Diego Conquistadors spoiled, the Memphis Sounds A.B.A. home opener with a 109106 victory tonight.

title: M'KENDREE SPRING PAYS LIVELY VISIT
description: McKendree Spring paid what was basically the band's annual visit to Manhattan when it appeared Monday at the Bottom Line. The addition of a drummer to the lineup has loosened the band's sound somewhat but it is still very much a bluesbased, countryoriented group.

title: College, School Results
description: CROSSCOUNTRY Colleges

title: China Oil to Japan Set
description: TOKYO, Oct. 22 (Reuters) China will supply a minimum 8 million metric tons of crude oil to Japan next year, compared with 4.5 million metric tons this year, the SinoJapan Oil Import Council announced today. The council said an agreement was recently reached between a Visiting Chinese oil mission and two Japanese oil importers.

title: Draft Choices in Cowboy, 49er Dealings
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 22The New York Giants did something about their quarterback situation today.

title: SAIGON OPPONENTS REPORT ARRESTS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 22Two opponents of the Saigon Government said today that the police had recently arrested 14 students involved in an antiGovernment organizationthe first indication that the police had suspended their handsoff policy since protests began to gather momentum in September.

title: Mayors See a Fiscal Disaster Without TaxReform Measure
description: PLAINFIELD, Oct. 22  The Legislative Action Committee of the New Jersey Conference of Mayors warned the State Legislature today that fiscal disaster confronted virtually all the state's more than 500 municipalities next year unless it acted swiftly and decisively on tax reform.

title: Dialogue With Mexico
description: President Ford's visit with President Echeverria of Mexico was obviously an enjoyable exercise in personal diplomacy for both men. Despite Mr. Ford's enthusiasm for personal dialogue and straight talk, however, the most that such brief meetings usually achieve is fenerate some momentum for negotiations at lower revels to head off or contain problems.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Advertising
description: Yes, says Charles Goldschmidt, there is another way for the principals of an agency to get their money out and still run the show without going public and without getting acquired by another agency.

title: Son of Israeli U.N. Delegate Is Robbed in Central Park
description: The 16yearold son of Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations was robbed of $28 yesterday by five youths who pushed him off his bicycle in Central Park, the police said.

title: TIMES CO. NET UP 6.8% IN QUARTER
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday increased consolidated neb incode for the third fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 of $4.48million, or 41 cents a share, up 6.8 per cent from last year's quarter. Net income in the 1973 quarter was $4.19million, or 37 cents a share.

title: U.S. Companies in Vietnan Dismissing 1,000 Americans
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Oct. 22 (AP)American conterns working on contract for the South Vietnamese Air Force are dismissing more than 1,000 American technicians and 900 Vietnamese civilians because of cuts in United States military aid to Vietnam, the Unite( States Embassy reported today.

title: Augustus Wolfman Dead at 66; Was Authority on Photography
description: Augustus Wolfman, editor and publisher of The Wolfman Report on the Photographic Industry in the United States, died Monday evening at his home, 20926 30th Avenue, Bayside, Queens. He was 66 years old.

title: KISSINGER TAKES OFF ON THREEWEEK TOUR
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 23 (UPI) Secretary of State Kissinger left early this morning on a threeweek mission to promote peace and the fight against world hunger in Moscow, South Asia and possibly the Middle East.

title: Businesses Contribute
description: Scores of companies, ranging from Wall Street brokerage houses to neighborhood restaurants, have taken advantage of a controversial New York state law that allows them to contribute legally for the first time in statewide political contests.

title: MARVIN N. GREENSTEIN
description: Marvin N. Greenstein, a psychologist, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 45 years old and lived at 1 Gracie Terrace,

title: Teacher Sues to Strike Censure From His File
description: A Suffolk County teacher, censured by his principal last year for discussing his vasectomy with his seventhgrade science students, filed suit in Brooklyn yesterday to have the censure removed from his record.

title: Monday's Fights
description: New York (At Felt Forum)Omar Piton, 139 pounds, Argentina, outpointed Art Kettles, 148, Asbury Park, N. J., 10 rounds.

title: Knicks Defeat Rockets
Cousteau to Study Red Tide
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 22 (AP)Jacques Yves Cousteau will begin extensive airandsea studies of the marine fungus that contaminates sea life that is known as the red tide and of pollution in the Gulf of Mexico early next month, an associate of the explorer says.

title: Sheriff's Aide Says James Earl Ray Was Kept 8 Months in jail With No View of Sunlight
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 22A Federal District Court was told here today that while James Earl Ray was awaiting trial for the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. he was held in a brightly lighted cell with the windows blocked off and that he was kept under constant surveillance by deputy sheriffs, television cameras and microphones.

title: MUSKIE DISPUTES FORD ON ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct., 22 (UPI) Speaking Congressional Democrats, Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine said tonight that President Ford's economic program would invite recession, weaken the nation and promote uneven sacrifice, but would prove ineffective against inflation.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Group Halts ABC News To Protest Over Ireland
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP)  An ABCTV news broadcast by Howard K. Smith was interrupted briefly tonight by two men and two women who walked into the Washington studio where Mr. Smith was.

title: OBSCENITY CASES TO BE TRIED AGAIN
description: TRENTON, Oct. 22State and county law enforcement authorities concluded at a meeting here today that what might be prosecuted as pornography in one New Jersey county might be legally acceptable in another.

title: Sesame Street Sues Over Use of Puppets
description: NEWARK, Oct. 22 (UPI)The creators of Sesame Street charged today that a New Jersey concern planned to put on the market 200,000 allegedly defective hand puppets of Bert, Ernie and Oscar the Grouch.

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market continued to rise yesterday as traders on both markets demonstrated confidence in the economy.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 3 P.M. on extension of United Nations Emergency Force.

title: A Changing America
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 22The America that will go to the polls in a couple of weeks is significantly different from the country that gave Richard Nixon a spectacular victory In the Presidential campaign of 1972.

title: Big Board Seat Price Up
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported a seat sale yesterday at $100,000the highest since Jan. 22 when a seat brought $105,000. The price was up $6,000 since the last sale on Oct., The market was $80,000 bid, $100,000 asked.

title: DEAN TELLS COURT HE WITHHELD DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 John W. Dean 3d admitted under crossexamination today that he had continued to withhold damaging information about Watergate for many months after he had said that he had broken from the Watergate conspiracy and had told the authorities everything he knew.

title: Arab Investing Seen
description: A leading Arab investment manager said yesterday that substantial sums of Arab money would be invested in real estate, banking and high technology industries in the United States, Europe and Japan. Detatils on Page 73.

title: Publishers Fund Articles
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) Francis G. Walett, a historian, has been commissioned by the American Newspaper Publishers Association Foundation to write a series of articles on the American Revolution.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: TIPS POURING IN ON MASS MURDER
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 22 Hundreds of residents deluged the police today with tips and possible clues in the massmurder Saturday night of six people in a bakery here.

title: Burroughs to Buy Graphic Sciences In 30Million Deal
description: The Burroughs Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Graphic Sciences, Inc., of Danbury Conn., for stock worth $30million. Graphic Sciences manufactures equipment for transmitting and receiving documents by telephone. Under terms of the agreement, Burroughs, a producer of computers and business machines, will exchange oneeighth of one share of its common stock for each of the 3 million common shares of Graphic Sciences outstanding.

title: FORD SEES THREAT TO FOREIGN POLICY
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 22President Ford contended today that if the Democrats gained a wide margin of Congressional seats in the election next month the chances for a bipartisan foreign policy would be threatened and peace could be in jeopardy.

title: Olympics Vote Today On '80 Site
description: VIENNA, Oct. 22Los Angeles or Moscow? The decision for the 1980 Summer Olympic Games will be made here tomorrow at the International Olympic Committee meeting. And if the 1980 Winter Games are to be held, the choice of Lake Placid, N.Y., as well.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Rail Worker Found Guilty Of Keeping Ransom Cash
description: NEWARK, Oct. 22A former railroad worker accused of lying to a grand jury and possession of $50,000 in ransom money intended for the kidnappers of young John Calzadilla was found guilty today on both charges.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: PRICE INDEX ROSE1.2% IN SEPTEMBER; 12.1% OVER YEAR
Jailed Guinea Pigs
description: Nine inmates of the Maryland House of Correction Jessup have sued Maryland prison authorities and the Departments of Defense and Health, Education and Welfare, among others, to challenge the practice of using prison inmates as volunteer guinea pigs in studies epidemic diseases. The suit is an important one because at least seven other states sanction such programs.

title: Woman He Lived With Held in Slaying Of a Law Secretary in Nassau County
description: Mrs. L. I. Anne Brown of Uniondale, L. I., was charged last night with the murder three weeks ago of Burr C. Hollister, a State Supreme Court law secretary with whom she had lived for the two years.

title: Homosexuals Picket Paper
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22, (Reuters)Fifty members of the Gay Liberation Front, a homosexual activist organization, picketed the entrance to the plant of The Los Angeles Times today to complain that the newspaper gave inadequate coverage to their activities. The pickets disbanded after six of them met with Robert D. Nelson, executive vice president and general manager of the Times Mirror Company, to discuss their grievances.

title: Rockefeller Won't Reply To Press Queries for Now
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller issued tonight a statement declaring that he would answer no further questions by news organizations until he next appeared before the two Congressional committees considering his nomination.

title: TOP E.P.A. OFFICIAL SCORES UTILITY'S AD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) A top official of the Environmental Protection Agency criticized today as irresponsible and misleading a newspaper advertisement by a Major utility group attacking the agency.

title: Intelligent Intelligence
description: JERUSALEMTo any state, intelligence with a capital I is important, in both the diplomatic and military fields, but for two reasons this is especially true in Israel. First of all, because of its habit of graduating generals to high political positions (for example the present Premier and Foreign Minister), the Government brings to civilian power men accustomed to basing their decisions on technically acquired information.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: The Off Broadway Circle Repertory Theater Company, a chief provider of new American plays, has taken a 10year lease on the Sheridan Square Playhouse, 99 Seventh Avenue South.

title: Orchestra Hall's Design: A Rebuke to Red Velvet
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 22Minneapolis seems rapidly on the way to becoming one of the most architecturally sophisticated cities in the United States. It is not merely a case of a community's having commissioned a lot of work from architects of note; experience has shown that getting big names is never in itself a guarantee of quality. Rather, what makes Minneapolis remarkable is the generally advanced level of taste so many of its new public buildings display.

title: SIGHTINGS BACK JUPITER THEORY
description: From observations obtained by two observatories on six recent nights, it now appears virtually certain that the planed Jupiter has a 13th moon.

title: Maxim Schur, Pianist, 67; Accompanied Actress Wife
description: Maxim Schur, a concert pianist and teacher, died yesterday of cancer at Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 345 West 88th Street.

title: Stoph Visits Finland
description: HELSINKI, Finland Oct. 22, (Reuters)The East German head of state, Will Stoph, arrived in Helsinki today on his first state visit to a nonCommunistcountry. He is the third Soviet bloc leader to come to Finland in the last month, following President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union and Gustav Husak of Czechoslovakia.

title: Arabs Expect to Invest Widely Abroad
description: Substantial sums of Arab money will go toward investments in real estate, banking and high technology industries in the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France and Spain, a leading Arab investment manager said yesterday.

title: Bridge: Novice Games Best Choice As the Route for a Beginner
description: For the beginner who hopes to make the long trek to expert, there are three possible roadsleaving out of account the necessary theoretical study:

title: Final Federal Standards Issued Setting Noise Levels for Trucks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 The Environmental Protection Agency released today final noise control standards for highways. The standards will trucks traveling on interstate require the replacement of mufflers or tires on an estimated 70,000 vehicles.

title: People and Business
description: Warren W. Lebeck, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation't largest commodities exchange, is leaving today for China. Mr. Lebeck declined to say in a telephone interview whether he had been invited by the Chinese Government.

title: Slaying Suspect Held
description: The police charged Mrs. JoAnne Brown with the murder of a law secretary who was found slain in State Supreme Court chambers in Mineola, L. I., last Sept. 30. Details on Page 28.

title: U.S. Study Urges Strong Energy Conservation Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  A strong conservation effort, including mandatory Federal standards for energy requirements of automobiles, appliances and buildings, is suggested in the Project Independence study on ways of achieving energy selfsufficiency for the United States.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: U.S. Transit Aide Sides With Ronan In PATH Dispute
description: TRENTON, Oct. 22The administrator of the Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administrator sided today with Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, in his dispute with Governor Byrne and New Jersey transportation officials over a proposed $300,million PATH rapid transit extension from Newark to Plainfield.

title: Deficit Despite Quarter's 21% Sales Rise
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22  The Chrysler Corporation reported today a loss of $8million in the third quarter despite a $493million increase in sales from the yearearlier period.

title: Bhutto Announces Extensive Changes In Pakistan Cabinet
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 22 (Reuters)Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto today announced extensive Cabinet changes, dropping his Finance Minister and bringing in four new men.

title: Bishops View Superstar
description: ROME, Oct. 22 (UPI)Participants in the Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops took time off for their deliberations today to witch the controversial film Jesus Christ Superstar. Their comments, if any, were not known.

title: Rangers' LineUp
description: AT GARDEN, 7:35 P.M.

title: Bishops Reject Synod Report As Largely Lacking Substance
description: ROME, Oct. 22The Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops met today to approve a report to Pope Paul VI on their monthlong discussion on evangelization in the modern world and decided to reject most of it.

title: SOVIET SEES GAINS FOR REDS IN WEST
description: MOSCOW, Oct 22The Soviet Union's leading ideologist today declared that the economic crisis in the West had strengthened the positions of Communists and other leftists in several countries.

title: V. H. Kazanjian, Who Taught Plastic Surgery at Harvard, Dies
description: Dr. Varaztad H. Kazanjian, professor emeritus of plastic surgery at the Harvard Medical School, died Saturday at the age of 95. He lived in Belmont, Mass.

title: NEW ORDERS DROP IN DURABLE GOODS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) New orders for durable goods in September suffered their sharpest monthly declines in nearly seven years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: TEACHERS STRIKE IN LONG BRANCH
description: LONG BRANCH, Oct. 22 (UPI)More than 300 public school teachers, secretaries and maintenance staff members in Long Branch went on strike today over a demand for higher wages, forcing the closing of six of the city's 10 schools.

title: Underground TestBan
description: The value of last July's SovietAmerican treaty barring underground tests of large nuclear weapons lies primarily in a projected breakthrough on verification, including onsite inspection, which now is being negotiated in Moscow.

title: Mob Breaks Car Windows Outside Struck Factory
description: BERLIN, Conn., Oct. 22 (AP) An angry crowd of 300 people broke windows in workers' cars at the Rowland, Inc., plastics plant today on the first anniversary of a strike there.

title: Consumer Group Offers Guide to Queens Doctors
description: Charging that it is easier to buy a good toaster than to select a good doctor, the New York Public Interest Research Group yesterday released a Consumer's guide to Queens Doctors that lists the office hours, billing practices and hospital affiliations for 335 of the 900 general practitioners and general internists presumed to be practicing in the county.

title: Enthusiasm in Paris Over State of Fashion
description: PARIS, Oct. 22Americans here for the spring readytowear showings are tremendously buoyed by the fact that fashion is alive and thriving. Teetering on the brink of economic disaster, the French are at least facing the precipice beautifully dressed.

title: People in Sports
description: Fred Carter, a holdout with the Philadelphia 76ers, signed a contract yesterday. The 76ers had suspended Carter at the start of the season for failing to come to terms with the club. He was the 76ers' leading scorer last season with a 21.4point average. Gene Shue, the Philadelphia coach, said the 6foot3inch backcourt man would remain suspended until he was in shape to play and until a spot on the roster was created for him.

title: CANADA TIGHTENS RULES COVERING IMMIGRANT FLOW
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 22The Canadian Government, concerned ever the steeply rising numbers and changing racial patterns in the steady flow of immigrants here, announced tighter regulations on new entries today.

title: Upstate Prosecutor Given Jail Term for Bondage
description: BELMONT, N. Y., Oct. 22 (UPI)  Edward M. Horey, acting Allegany County judge, today sentenced former District Attorney John T. D'Arcy to three oneyear jail terms, to be served concurrently, in connection with several incidents of bondage involving women. Judge Horey also fined him $2,000.

title: Two Festivals, and TextToImage Fun for Youngsters
MRS. BOTSFORD
description: Katherine C. Botsford, wife of Gardner Botsford, an editor for The New Yorker magazine, died Monday at the Hospital for Special Surgery. She was 58 years old and lived at 177 East 75th Street.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Abandoned Barges Burn in Hudson

title: CORPORATE PLANS FOR DEBT EXPAND
description: The Xerox Corporation arid the Caterpillar Tractor Company announced plans yesterday to borrow a total of $500million in the bond market soon. These two major financing announce ments raised to $1.5billion the volume of new corporate debt securities disclosed in little more than a week, and they pushed bond prices down. sharply yesterday.

title: 275YearOld Tree Is Named a Landmark
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 22State Conservation Commissioner James L. Biggane designated the 275yearold Balmville Tree a state landmark today and placed it under the protection of a new law to save rare or endangered trees.

title: Mild Quake Jolts Coast
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22 (UPI)A mild earthquake jolted a small part of Southern California today, awakening many residents but apparently causing no damage. The quake appeared to be centered in the Inglewood area 10 miles southwest of downtown Los Angeles.

title: Love, Bulls' Holdout, Granted Arbitration
description: Bob Love, who walked out of the Chicago Bulls' training camp last month in a contract dispute, will be granted an arbitration hearing Saturday in the office of Commissioner Walter Kennedy, the National Basketball Association announced yesterday.

title: Wards I. Escapee Sought in Slaying Of a Psychologist
description: A 26yearold man who was sent to a state hospital for the criminal insane after he allegedly stabbed a girlfriend to death three years ago is being sought in the murder of Judith Becker, a 26yearold staff psychologist at the Fishkill Correctional Facility in Beacon, N.Y.

title: U.S.Icelandic Base Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (Reuters)The United States and Iceland signed an agreement today to permit the continued operation of an American base at Keflavik. It is pert of the North Atlantic Treaty OrganizaLion system.

title: Loeb Claims Fraud In Big Sugar Loss
description: Loeb, Rhoades & Co., the big New York investment banking and brokerage house, disclosed yesterday that it had lost an estimate $3.25million as a result of what it termed fraudulently placed sugar futures contracts.

title: Britain Will Get E.E.C. Aid on Sugar
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 22 The agricultural ministers of the members of the European Economic Community agreed today to subsidize imports of sugar to Britain from world suppliers to cover that country's sugar deficit. The deficit is estimated to be 600,000 tons this season.

title: Notes on People
description: The British newspapers are making a big thing out of the reported plans of Rachel Fitler, the 61yearold aunt of Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller, to marry Michael Wilson, a 29yearold Welsh bartender who has worked as her chauffeur and companion, and all the attention has Mr. Wilson worried. This publicity could blow the whole thing up, he said yesterday at his parent's home in Wales, Papers have made me look like a gold digger. She might call it off now.

title: For Men, Books on Achieving Blissful Equality
description: It had to happen. Any she/he (or he/she) acquainted with Sir Isaac Newton knew it would, for the 18thcentury physicist's Third Law of Motion is as applicable to social movements as it is to mechanics: that the force of the women's movement was bound to generate a male response. Some measure of that response is found in five books published this fall, each aiming to advise men on how to cope with what John Knox once called the Regiment of Women.
