title: Delaware River Port Chairman Found to Profit From Contracts
description: TRENTON, Oct. 22  The State Commission of investigation reported today that Ralph Cornell, chairman and longtime member of the Delaware River Port Authority, benefited as an owner or a principal in compatiles that received about $3million in contracts awarded by the authority between 1954 and 1973.

title: Con Edison's Indicated Net Rises 12%
description: Indicated earnings of the Consolidated Edison Company rose 12 per cent, in the third quarter on a 46.6 per cent increase in indicated revenues, a company report showed yesterday.

title: Return to Help Us, Ghetto Asks Stars
description: Not all the basketball stars who leave the city streets come home again.

title: Regional Bank Profit Off But a Recovery Is Seen
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 22Profits of the nation's smaller and regional banks have slacked off but officials of those banks, who are attending the industry's annual meeting here, believe a quick recovery is in sight.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Olympics Vote Today On '80 Site
description: VIENNA, Oct. 22Los Angeles or Moscow? The decision for the 1980 Summer Olympic Games will be made here tomorrow at the International Olympic Committee meeting. And if the 1980 Winter Games are to be held, the choice of Lake Placid, N.Y., as well.

title: Baltimore and Orioles to Talk Today
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 22 (AP)The Mayor's Commission to Save the Baltimore Orioles will make another pitch tomorrow to buy the American League baseball team and assure its continuance in the city. An offer Of $10million for the team, one of the best in baseball over the last decade, was rejected yesterday by Jrold C. Hoffberger, the club's board chairman. Hoffberger declined comment today on the negotiations, but a commission source said the chairman had found the $10million unacceptable and was unwilling to allow 90 days for working out a deal. Last week, Hoffberger had said he wouldn't sell the team for less than $12million.

title: New Gallery, New Phase For Carnegie Institute
description: PITTSBURGH  Andrew Carnegie is everywhere in Pittsburgh. He is there in the dark satanic mills from which he made his fortune. He is there in the monumental institute that has borne his name since it was opened in 1895. And he is there even when he isn't there: at the foot of the antique funicular, for instance, which hoists the pleasurecrazed locals to the Tin Angel bar. Have you done a full day's work? he seems to snarl, over the ticket collector's shoulder, as if he had the power to send us all back to the mill.

title: JUDGE G. N. BEAMER SR.
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 22 (AP)  United States District Court Judge George N. Beamer Sr. died yesterday in South Bend Memorial Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Golf Ball Hit 362 Yards
description: SYDNEY, Australia Oct. 22 (Reuters)Bob Panasiuk, a Canadian golfer, hit a ball 362 yards today to win a longest drive competition during a proamateur event preceding the $35,000 Will Masters tournament.

title: Mets Get Clines in Dyer Trade
description: The Mets, who leave today for Japan from the Interna AD;tional Arrivals Building, and who will pick up Jerry Koosman in Alaska, made a deal yesterday designed to bolster their outfield.

title: Rams in Best Spot Among Contenders
description: The National Football League schedule is coming up to the halfway mark, the seventh of 14 games, for the 26 teams. Eleven of them may be regarded as serious contenders for the eight postseason playoff berths. There are always inequities in the N.F.L. schedules, although this year the differences are not so great. Only one of the 11 teams, the Los Angeles Rams, has an easy road ahead. They are the Jets' opponent here on Sunday, and have little opposition within their division, the Western of the National Conference.

title: White Sox Add Affiliate
description: DENVER, Oct. 22 (AP)The Denver Bears of the American Association signed a working agreement today with the Chicago White Sox for the 1975 baseball season, replacing last year's agreement with the Houston Astros. The White Sox were under a working agreement with the Iowa Oaks of the American Association last season.

title: Tanaka Acknowledges Private Interests
description: TOKYO, Oct. 22  Premier Kakuei Tanaka acknowledged today that he had continued his private business activities throughout his 27year political career and did not deny charges of financial irregularities that were made against him in a recent magazine article.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 47

title: PRICES BE MIXED ON GRAIN FUTURES
Javits Gets C.I.A. Tapes on Clark's Visit to Hanoi
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he had requested and received tape recordings from the Central Intelligence Agency of interviews given by Ramsey Clark and broadcast by the Hanoi radio during Mr. Clark's trip to North Vietnam in 1972.

title: U.S. Study Urges Strong Energy Conservation Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  A strong conservation effort, including mandatory Federal standards for energy requirements of automobiles, appliances and buildings, is suggested in the Project Independence study on ways of achieving energy selfsufficiency for the United States.

title: Watergate Clouds the FishAngell Contest
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y.The Watergate scandal ha's added flavor and an element of uncertainty to the campaign for a Representative in the 25th Congressional District.

title: Tensions in Integration
description: The incident that ostensibly triggered the racial clashes that led to the twoday closing of Brooklyn's James Madison High School last December was a fight that erupted when two youthsone black, one white  bumped while passing in the doorway of a lavatory.

title: Contract Awards
description: A $45million order for 74 diesel electric locomotives and spare parts has been received by the General Motors Corporation from the Iranian State Railways. The locomotives are to be manufactured at G.M.'s electromotive plants at La Grange, Ill. Shipments will begin in the last quarter of 1975.

title: Oil Fire in Kuwait Kills American and 8 Others
description: KUWAIT, Oct. 22 (AP)A fire broke out in a major pipeline link at the Kuwait Oil Company's installations near the Iraqi border today, killing nine persons and injuring several others, the police reported.

title: DEAN TELLS PLAN TO SAVE HIMSELF
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 John W. Dean 3d admitted today after repeated questioning that to save himself he had joined in a plan to have John N. Mitchell take the blame for the Watergate breakin.

title: Meredith Files Election Suit
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 23 (AP)James H. Meredith filed a suit in Federal District Court today in his battle for a place on the November ballot as an independent candidate for Representative from Mississippi's Fourth Congressional District. Mr. Meredith contended that the State Election Commission gave an unconstitutional interPretation to a 1956 election law amendment.

title: Quake in the Solomons
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (Reuters)A major earthquake occurred last night in the Solomon Islands area of the Pacific, the Geological Survey said today. A spokesman said the quake had a magnitude of 7.3 on the openended Richter scale.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS RAIL ACT IS LEGAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The Department of Justice argued today that the Railroad Reorganization Act that became law earlier this year is constitutional because the Federal Government stands ready to pay valid claims in the case of losses resulting from its operation.

title: LOCKHEED IS SEEN WINNER OF CONTRACT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (Reuters)The Navy has selected the Lockheed Aircraft Company over the Grumman Corporation to provide more than $350million of aircraft carrier supply planes, informed sources said today.

title: Security Council Extends the Life of U.N. Buffer Force in Sinai
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23The Security Council, after feverish lasthour negotiations behind the scenes, tonight extended for six months the mandate of the United Nations buffer force between Egyptian and Israeli troops in the Sinai peninsula.

title: JACOB SCHWALBE
description: Jacob Schwalbe, whose firm, Kornblum & Co., founded by his grandfather, was one of the oldest produce commission merchants here, died in his sleep Tuesday morning. He was 82 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street.

title: 150,000 Get Reading Test To Overcome Student Lag
description: Diagnostic reading tests are being given this week to 150,000 City high school students as the first step in a new programthe largest and most systematic ever attempted here to overcome widespread reading retardation in the secondary schools.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 23 (AP)  A skin rash turned up today in George Foreman's camp. For the time being, the rash has brought only a minor disruption to the heavyweight champion's training routine: He now has to make his own breakfast in preparation for his title bout with Muhammad Ali on Oct. 29, New York time.

title: Lifetime Jobs of Japanese In Peril as Economy Lags
description: MATSUOKA, Japan, Oct. 17Since it was built three years ago, the Toshiba Electronics Factory here in this small farming village has been the pride of the community.

title: Plan on Revamping Of Equity Funding. To Be Given Court
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (AP)  A reorganization plan that would convert the scandalshattered, bankrupt Equity Funding Corporation of America into a new company was announced today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: The last time St. Joseph's of West New York won a championship, Mike Tanner was a freshman. That was four years ago.

title: Soviet Bars Newsman Flying With Kissinger
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23Correspondents traveling with Secretary of State Kissinger today protested the Soviet Union's refusal to admit one of their colleagues with the official party.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: CABBIES ARE SPLIT ON FARE INCREASE
description: Nicholas Rosales paid $4,200 for his new 1974 Dodge Polara taxi. His previous taxi, also a Dodge Polara, cost him $3,200 in 1972.

title: Synod at Vatican Calls for Human Rights
description: ROME, Oct. 23The Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops, still without agreement on the principal topic of its meeting, adopted a message to the world today that urges the right to life, to food, to social, economic, political and cultural Advancement and to religious liberty.

title: KISSINGER ARRIVES FOR SOVIET TALKS ON ARMS CONTROL
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23  Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here today hoping to accelerate the talks on the limitation of strategic arms and prepare the way for progress by the time President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev meet, possibly next month.

title: Falconbridge Lifts Nickel Price by 20c; Gillette Also Acts
description: Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., of Canada announced yesterday it would lift its price in this country on Dec. 1 by 20 cents a pound. This amounts to about 10 per cent, and is the same increase as was announced last Friday by Socite le Nickel.

title: Suburbs Join City In On
description: Offtrack betting, a neighborhood game in the city that had been largely ignored by commuters, will also operate in the suburbs.

title: Crippled Plane Lands Safely
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Oct. 23 (UPI)A Skystream Airlines, plane carrying 15 passengers and a crew of two landed safely here today after one of its two engines exploded, damaging the cockpit and knocking out the copilot. An airlines spokesman said the pilot, Spencer Sullivan of Mount Clemens, Mich.; the copilot, Dennis Beaulieur of Detroit, and an unidentified passenger were slightly in jured.

title: MORRIS ROSEN
description: Morris Rosen, a men's clothing industry executive, died yesterday at his home, 52 Gramercy Park North. He was 90 years old.

title: Papadopoulos Sent Into Island Exile With 4 From Junta
description: ATHENS, Oct. 23George Papadopoulos and four other leaders of the military coup of 1967 were arrested today and exiled to the small Aegean Island of Kea.

title: Toron to Displays Its Moore Sculptures
description: TORONTO, Oct. 22With the reopening of the Mt Gallery of Ontario this week, the city of Toronto has acquired both a distinguished new museum facility and, what nowadays is even more unusual, a huge collection of primary works by a major living artist. The artist is Henry Moore, the British sculptor, who has already donated more than 300 of his works to the Canadian museum, and is still lavishing additional gifts on the gallery's Henry Moore Sculpture Center, which was recently established to house this extraordinary collection.

title: '68 Transit Pact Disclosed
description: Court papers filed six years ago and made available yesterday disclosed in detail how the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority was enabled to use part of its revenues in support of mass transit in the New York area.

title: TEACHERS' RETURN ORDERED BY COURT
description: LONG BRANCH, Oct. 23 (AP) Superior Court Judge Merritt Lane Jr. today ordered striking Long Branch public school teachers to return to work tomorrow.

title: Ray Will Give His Version of the 1968 Slaying of Dr. King as Court Hearing Continues Today in Memphis
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 23James Barl Ray will take the witness stand in Federal District Court here tomorrow to tell in public for the first time his version of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Ford Refuses to Sign Environmental Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) President Ford has told Congress that he has, in effect, vetoed an environmental protection bill, but Congressional sources say that by refusing to send Congress a formal veto message, Mr. Ford may have ensured the bill's enactment.

title: Soaring Budgetary Cost Of Police Is Indian Issue
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 23  The Indian Government has quietly increased its police and internal security budgets. A Parliamentary report points out that government allocations for the police have doubled in the last five years, and risen by 52 times in the last 24 years.

title: Italian Tanker Refloated
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 23 (AP) An Italian tanker that leaked some 2,200 barrels of crude oil into the Mississippi River after running aground was refloated and under way again today. The 807footlong Ercole went aground early yesterday near Donaldsonville, about 80 miles from New Orleans. The leakage was not completely stopped until yesterday afternoon.

title: Riggins Hurt, Doubtful as Jet Starter
description: John Riggins, the New York Jets' leading rusher, who suffered an injury to his right shoulder last Sunday, was listed yesterday as a questionable starter against the Los Angeles Rams in Shea Stadium this Sunday.

title: Pakistan and India to Meet On Trade and Overflights
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 23 Pakistan and India will meet next month to discuss the resumption of trade and commercial flights across each other's territory.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Treasure Trove From New York's Museum Basements on Show
description: Rummage in the basement of a New York museum and you're bound to flush a treasurea lefthanded whelk, forgeries of ancient Greek coins, a Yakut horse saddle or a commemorative chair commissioned by the man who first distinguished the crocodile from the alligator in Florida.

title: 4 From Boston View Southern Busing
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 23 (AP)Four Boston teenagers got a look today at integration and how it works in Charlotte's public high schools.

title: Meredith Files Election Suit
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 23 (AP)James H. Meredith filed a suit in Federal District Court today in his battle for a place on the November ballot as an independent candidate for Representative from Mississippi's Fourth Congressional District. Mr. Meredith contended that the State Election Commission gave an unconstitutional interpretation to a 1956 election law amendment.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW PRICE DROP
description: Soybean oil futures led a downturn in soybean prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat and corn prices followed.

title: Option for Morton: Giants' Legal Aid
description: A crucial clause in Craig Morton's contract with the defunct Houston Texans, May allow him to sever his World Football League connections and find a permanent home as the New York Giants' No. 1 quarterback.

title: Growing Anxiety Over Breast Cancer Strains the City's Detection Facilities
description: It is virtually impossible right now to get anything but a busy signal in telephoning the clinics and doctors' offices where breast cancer testing is being done. And some places, where women are advised to write to make appointments, are reporting that they can accept no new patients for several months.

title: Gallup Says Poll Shows Ford Popularity on Rise
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 23 (AP) George Gallup says a poll to be released this week will show that President Ford's popularity is again on the rise, but not enough to prevent a Democratic victory of landslide proportions in November.

title: Byrne Says Delay on PATH Line Could Peril Kennedy Rail Link
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23Ranking Byrne administration officials said today that New Jersey's dispute with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, over the construction of a PATH rapidtransit extension from Newark to Plainfield seriously jeopardized the chances of a companion proposal for a rapid transit link from Manhattan to Kennedy International Airport in New York.

title: PROFIT RISES 124% AT OHIO STANDARD
description: Five large oil companies reported yesterday gains in thirdquarter earnings ranging from 75 per cent to 124 per cent.

title: U.S. ACTION SOUGHT ON CAPITAL RAISING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The National Investor Relations Institute called today for action by the President and Congress recognizing the critical importance of the American system of raising capital for industry from millions of direct and indirect shareowners.

title: $500 Offered for Kangaroo
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (Reuters) A $500 reward was offered today to anyone catching Chicago's roaming kangaroo alive. The kangaroo, first reported on the loose in Chicago, last Friday, has not been sighted in the city since Sunday.

title: WIDOW, 73, IS FOUND MURDERED IN BRONX
description: A 73yearold widow, her face badly bruised, was found dead in the bedroom of her ransacked apartment at 1970 Walton Avenue in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, the police reported yesterday.

title: Moscow Gets Olympics
description: Moscow was awarded the 1980 Summer Olympics yesterday. It was the first time a city in a Communist country had been selected. Lake Placid, N. Y., was awarded the Winter Olympics. Page 53.

title: CHILE IS ACCUSED BY JURISTS GROUP
description: GENEVA, Oct. 23The International Commission of Jurists charged today that political repression in Chile was now more ubiquitous and more systematic than at any other time since President Salvadore Allende Gossens was overthrown by the military 13 months ago.

title: Abrams Assails State Milk Inspection
description: Robert Abrams, the Democratic candidate for State Attorney General, asserted yesterday that a scandalridden and industrydominated State Department of Agriculture and Markets had sabotaged the New York City milkdating law to benefit milk interests.

title: Moscow, Lake Placid Awarded '80 Olympics
description: VIENNA, Oct. 23Moscow was picked over Los Angeles today to hold the Summer Olympics in 1980, and Lake Placid, N. Y., the only candidate, will stage the Winter Games on virtually the same terrain as in 1932.

title: Chess: Korchnoi, Overextended, Puts Victory Out of Reach Again
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23Victor Korchnoi tried again to nail Anatoly Karpov in their final candidates match for the world championship, but after 46 moves in five hours in their 15th game, the Leningrad grandmaster had overextended himself and could hope only for a draw.

title: The Politics of Hunger
description: On the current trends of population and food production, according to international experts, by 1985 the poor countries of the world would need 85 million tons of grain a year from outside. In a year of bad harvests, the need could be 100 million tons, or even more.

title: Citizens Union Endorses $250Million Rail Bond Issue
description: The Citizens Union, the nonproposed partisan organization that produces an annual Voters Directory, announced its support yesterday for the $250million rail preservation bond issue that will be on the Nov. 5 ballot.

title: Clean Coal
description: Technology is now available to use this country's billions of tons of highsulphur coal without harm to the environment. This announcement by the Environmental Protection Agency refutes the almost hysterical advertising campaign of the American Electric Power System, which would have the public believe that the only hope for adequate energy lies in stripmining the lowsulphur coal of the West.

title: Lehigh Gets $125,000 Gift
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 23 (UPI)  Lehigh University received a gift of $125,000 from the Ford Motor Company Fund yesterday for scientific and engineering purposes. Lee A. Iacocca, Ford Motor Company president who is a trustee of the fund, delivered the first $25,000 installment of the contribution to Lehigh's president, Dr. Deming Lewis. Lehigh will use the money to build an auditoriumclassroom and polymer research center in Lehigh's new $7million chemistry complex.

title: For a Limited Jubilee
description: BOSTONIn pardoning Richard M. Nixon and initiating an earnedclemency program for thousands of men in exile or hiding, Gerald R. Ford acted in the spirit of charity.

title: Escaped Patient Sought
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 (UPI)  A north Philadelphia youth convicted of threatening the life of Mayor Frank L. Rizzo has escaped from the Philadelphia State Hospital at Byberry. David A. Herd, 18 years old, who had been confined at Byberry since September, is being sought by the police.

title: Candidate Told to Turn In All Campaign Literature
description: The State Board of Elections yesterday directed that a Republican candidate for the State Assembly from the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn surrender all his campaign literature to its New York City office.

title: 7 Die, 73 Hurt as Train Hits School Bus in Georgia
description: ARAGON, Ga. Oct. 23 (UPI)Seven children were killed and 73 other persons were injured today when a maintenance train backed into a school bus crammed with pupils who could see the train coming but could not escape.

title: Cavaliers Win First, Beat Celtics
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) The Cleveland Cavaliers, led by Austin Carr's 28 points, dominated the BostonCeltics in the first half tonight then held off a furious lastminute Celtic surge fora 108107 National Basketball Association victory.

title: Policeman's Killer Sought
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 23 (AP) About 1,000 Indianapolis policemen, sheriff's deputies and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation joined in the search today for a man wanted in the slaying of a 29yearold patrolman. Robert E. Schachte was woundedfatally yesterday as he started to search a man whose auto he had stopped. The authorities issued a firstdegree murder warrant for Rickey Lee Vaughn, who escaped from Central State Hospital Sept. 11.

title: 3 Black Militants Are Guilty In New Haven Bank Case
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 23 (AP) A Federal District Court jury today found three. Black Liberation Army members guilty on charges stemming from a $10,000 bank robbery here last spring.

title: Rangers Win, 51; Fairbairn Gets 3
description: Thanks, we needed that! The New York Rangers may well have expressed such sentiment last night after a threegoal performance by Billy Fairbairn, only one puck getting, by Ed Giacomin, the goalie, and a hardworking victory over the St. Louis Blues by the score of 51.

title: Moscow Gets Olympics
description: Moscow was awarded the 1980 Summer Olympics yesterday. It was the first time a city in a Communist country had been selected. Lake Placid, N. Y., was awarded the Winter Olympics. Page 53.

title: Good News Sets Previews
description: Good News, the musical revival cstarring Alice Faye, John Payne and Stubby Kaye, will begin previews Nov. 11 at the St. James Theater. It was to have given its first performance here on Saturday but a fire destroyed the show's scenery while it was being transported by truck in Los Angeles. A new opening date is to be announced soon. Those holding tickets for performances through Nov. 9 can get either exchanges or refunds at the St. James's box office.

title: Arkansas Law Challenged As Bar to Illiterate Voters
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 23 (UP)  Three Federal judges have taken under advisement a constitutional attack on Arkanas election laws from an attorney who contends the statutes discriminate against illiterate voters.

title: FORD AIDE HINTS AT A COMPROMISE ON TAX PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23.7One of the Ford Administration's top economic policymakers pledged today that the Administration would not hold stubbornly to its present economic program if the state of the economy changed.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 (UPI)Jerold C. Hoffberger, chairman of the Baltimore Orioles, gave a special commission seeking to keep the team in the city a 30day deadline today for raising half its proposed $10million purchase price. F. Barton Harvey Jr., cochairman of the Mayor's Commission to Continue the Baltimore Orioles, said Hoffberger agreed to give the panel that much time to raise $5million in private capital.

title: Noble Rogue Wins Rich Futurity Trot
description: WESTBURY, L. I Oct. 23 Noble Rogue, a belated arrival at the races this season, turned in a speedy performance tonight to beat the highly rated Skipper Walt by half a length bin the nonwagering $85,116 Westbury Futurity Trot at Roosevelt Raceway. The 2yearold son of Noble Victory, making only the ninth start of his career, against 27 for Skipper Walt, was first or in contention the entire mile race. Going into the top of the stretch he led by a length and came home in 2:05 3/5, only a second above the track record for juvenile trotters.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Judge W. Thomas McGann of Superior Court in Mount Holly swore in a jury of 11 men and five women for the trial of eight members' of the Campisi family and an associate. The defendants are accused of murder and racketeering. Jury selection took a month and Judge McGann said that in his two decades on the bench no other case had taken so long to get a jury.

title: OPEC DISCUSSING OIL PRICE REFORM
description: VIENNA, Oct. 23 (Reuters)Senior officials of oilexporting nations today began framing a new cost structure designed to give the producers greater maneuverability in fixing prices.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Greece: A Bell Tolls
description: Col. George Papadopoulos, who imprisoned and exiled thousands of his fellow citizens during more than six years as head of Greece's military dictatorship, has now experienced for himself the predawn knock on the door and the peremptory banishment to an Aegean island. Among those keeping him company on Kea, off Greece's south coast, are the other members of the triumvirate that overthrew the constitutional Government in 1967.

title: The Judge Rules for Elkhounds
description: Judge William H. Timbers and the late United States Supreme Court Justice John M. Harlan had two things in commona supreme respect for the law and a love for Norwegian elkhounds. When the Justice, who was a great constitutional jurist, agreed to swear me in as a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, said Timbers, I told him I was planning a simple ceremony, with on] ythe immediate family attending. Whereupon he said, If you don't bring the dogs, I'll declare the entire proceedings to be unconstitutional.

title: State Betting Commissioner Urges Veto of a Lottery Bill
description: Ronald Maiorana, Commissioner of Wagering Systems of the State Racing and Wagering Board, urged President Ford yesterday to veto a bill that he said would adversely affect the operation of state lotteries.

title: City to Require Exterminators at All Food Places
Monday or Nov. 11 (It Depends Where) Is Veterans Day
description: Federal agencies will be closed on Monday in honor of Veterans Day, but the holiday will be observed in New York and Connecticut on Nov. 11 when city and state offices and public schools will be closed.

title: CIGARETTE RULES URGED BY A PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) The National Cancer Advisory Board has called for Federal regulation of tar and nicotine content in cigarettes in the agency's annual report, which was sent to Congress today by President Ford.

title: Coast Bomber Called Insane
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (Reuters)  A courtappointed physician today said that Muharem Kurbegovic, the 31yearold Yugoslav immigrant accused of being the alphabet bomber who terrorized Los Angeles for two Weeks last August, was not sane enough to stand trial. Judge Raymond Choate of Superior Court set a hearing for Nov. 20 at which he planned to formally rule whether Mr. Kurbegovic should be sent to a mental hospital or stand trial for three bombing deaths at Los Angeles International Airport on Aug. 9.

title: People and Business
description: Two new senior executives have been named by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company. Gordon C. Griswold, who joined the utility as a cadet engineer in 1933, was elected chairman and chief executive officer yesterday. Mr. Griswold, who is 63, has been president since 1968. He succeeds John Heyke Jr., who died on Oct. 11.

title: TV Unions Threaten to Boycott British Version of Vidal's Burr
description: The National Conference of Motion Picture and Television Unions has warned ABCTV that it will attempt to mount a public campaign against the television adaptation of Gore Vidal's Burr if the network goes forward with its proposal to produce the series abroad. ABC planned to produce the multipart series, based on events in the life of Aaron Burr, in England as part of the bicentennial celebration.

title: Man Returned to Puerto Rico
description: Antonio Iglesias, a tattooed man described as Puerto Rico's Public Enemy No. 1, was turned over to Puerto Rican authorities at an extradition hearing in the Bronx Tuesday. Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Hughes ordered Mr. Iglesias sent back to Puerto Rico, where he allegedly escaped May 9, 1971, from the state prison in Rio Piedras, just outside San Juan. He was serving 20 years for murder, grand larceny, assault, narcotics and weapons charges.

title: Chicago to Honor '24 Football Team
description: This week it is the University of Chicago's turn to have a 50th anniversary celebration, just a week after Illinois had one for Red Grange and Notre Dame put on a show for the Four Horsemen backfield. Chicago's affair honors the 1924 Maroon football team that won the Big Ten championship after playing a 2121 tie with Red Grange's Illinois team.

title: STATE ACTS TO BAR BUS SERVICE HALT
description: NEWARK, Oct. 23The fate of 12 financially pressed New Jersey bus companies remained in doubt today despite a lengthy meeting between state officials and representatives of the bus lines, which State Transportation Commissioner Alan Sagner characterized as a healthy exchange of views on the situation.

title: The West Virginia Textbooks
description: COLUMBIA, Md.I'm an oldfashioned liberal. Prick me with a wordpoverty, prejudice, pollution  and I bleed. On reading accounts of the school violence in West Virginia, all my reflexes began twitching to the issues of censorship and bookburning and academic freedom.

title: Koreans Get a Pay Raise
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 23 (Reuters)The South Korean Government today announced a 30 per cent pay raise and a month's salary as a yearend, bonus, for all public officials to keep pace with soaring Hying cots.

title: Fossil Beds on Public Land Are Pillaged by Collectors
description: DENVER, Oct. 23A national heritage of fossilized animals and plants is being dug out of the earth and sold at an alarming fate by businessmen who are developing new and highly profitable markets for prehistoric remains as art objects, jewelry and materials for decorators.

title: U.S. AID TO SPUR CITY CRIME FIGHT
description: Under a new federally financed program, services will be provided victims and wit neses of crimes in Brooklyn to make it easier for them to appear in court.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two Hartford youths were arrested yesterday in what the police termed a break in a rash of stolen weathervane gases plaguing New England this year. The youthsJohn Wade, 18 years old, and Bert Davis, 19were seized after an allnight stakeout by 30 detectives in Hartford and the Farmington Valley.

title: Reward Is Raised in New Britain Massacre of 6
description: Residents of New Britain, Conn., have offered to put up $5,000 more in reward money for information leading to the arrest of the murderers of six persons in a bakery there Saturday night, John D. LaBelle, the Hartford County State's At. torney, said yesterday.

title: Ford Attack on Democrats Softened by White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  A White House spokesman sought today to tone down President Ford's charge yesterday that Democratic gains in Congress could jeopardize world peace. Ron Nessen, the President's press secretary, said that Mr. Ford had been surprised by the criticism of angry Democrats over his campaign remarks yesterday in Oklahoma and Ohio. world peace. Ron Nessen, the President's press secretary, said that Mr. Ford had been surprised by the criticism of angry Democrats over his campaign remarks yesterday in Oklahoma and Ohio.

title: Ford's Unchanged Style: Long Days and Endless Meetings, Rather Than Time Alone for Planning
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 22  When President Ford assumed office, former Gov. William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania and other experienced executives who helped with the transition recommended that he find some time to be alone, to think and plan.

title: Soviet Test Satellite Lofted
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union has launched an earth satellite with laboratory animals and other biological objects abroad, Tass reported today. The Soviet press agency gave no details of what the animals were. It said the satellite, called Cosmos 690, was launched yesterday and would investigate the effects of space flight on living organisms.

title: New Watergate Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23That's the best news I've hear in a year! a member of the Watergate Special Prosecution Force exclaimed earlier this week on hearing a report that Leon Jaworski, the departing special prosecutor, would probably be replaced by his deputy, Henry S. Rutha report that became official today.

title: Business Briefs
description: BONN, Oct. 23 (UPI)The Cabinet passed today a comprehensive energy program reducing planned fuel consumption by 9 per cent from previously planned levels.

title: U. of Connecticut Fee Raise
description: STORRS, Conn., Oct. 23 (AP) A proposal toraise University of Connecticut fees $160 to $175 a year next fall will be presented to the school's trustees at their November meeting, a school spokesman said. State residents now pay $2,600 to $2,800 a year in tuition and fees.

title: Nets Victors Over Sounds By 10496
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 23 What I've been trying to sell is that we're going to be competitive, said Mike Storen, former commissioner of the American Basketball Association and now general manager of the Memphis Sounds.

title: Lithuania Inducing Farmers to Quit Tiny Homesteads
description: VILNA, U.S.S.R., Oct. 18 The Communist leadership has been engaged for nearly three decades in trying to shift the individualistminded peasantry here in Lithuania from their traditional farmsteads into the villages that are part of collectives. Now broader financial inducements are being offered to speed the process.

title: Byrne Weighs Suit To Recover Profits Of Bridge Chairman
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23Governor Byrne said today he had directed the State Attorney General to determine whether a civil suit for damages should be filed against Ralph Cornell, chairman of the Delaware River Port Authority, whose construction company has profited from work done for the authority, according to an investigation.

title: Insurance Agent Accused Here Of Seeking a Deal on Candidate
description: A 31yearold insurance agent was indicted yesterday on a charge of an electionlaw violation for allegedly offering to arrange for James Eagan to withdraw from la?? month's Republican primary race in Queens against Representative James J. Delaney.

title: Jersey Governor Acts
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23  Governor Byrne announced today that he would require all New Jersey members of public authorities to make financial disclosures.

title: 1,000 Kurdish Refugees Return to Iraqi Authorities
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 23 (Reuters)About 1,000 Kurdish refugees, who had crossed into Turkey from wartorn northern Iraq, were transferred to Iraqi authorities today at their own request.

title: Stans Is Said to Be Negotiating With the Watergate Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Negotiations are being held between former Commerce Secreteary Maurice H. Stans and the Watergate Special Prosecution Force, a source with knowledge of those negotiations confirmed today.

title: Tenacity in Inflation Helps Manila Live
description: MANILAIts a relatively benign environment, a Western economist observed, leaning back in his armchair. It's not that difficult to survive without an income.

title: MARGARET MANNERS
description: Margaret Manners Lippmann, who as Margaret Manners was a wellknown writer of mystery stories, died Oct. 8 at the Princeton (N. J.) Medical Center. She was 60 years old and lived at 55 Harrison Street, Princeton.

title: Wilson Urges Stiff Penalties for Juveniles
description: Governor Wilson announced yesterday a get tough anticrime program that could make juveniles found guilty of serious crimes of violence subject to the same penalties as adults, including life imprisonment.

title: Bill Is Signed by Ford On Commodity Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI)President Ford signed into law today a bill creating a powerful, independent commission to strengthen federal regulation of commodity futures trading, which involves $500billion worth of transactions a year.

title: The Public Eye
description: It is an ironic twist that the Federal Communications Commission has lifted the licenses of eight educational TV stations in Alabama. Public broadcasters are supposed to offer an alternative to the usual commercial network programs that are built upon popularity ratings; yet the performance of this particular group of public stations was so blatantly racist that the F.C.C. was almost forced to take the extreme step under its Congressionally mandated regulatory powers.

title: Family Winery: The Mathiesens' Vineyard Is on Martha's
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass.There really is vineyard on Martha's Vineyard. And not a little backyard operation, either. It is a full  scale, no  nonsense, professional operation, and one of these days you are going to see the wine in your local store. Well, maybe not in your local store, but in some stores along the Eastern seaboard.

title: Police Free 4 in $4Million Chicago Vault Theft
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23The police arrested four men today  and later released themin connection with the theft of nearly $4million, the largest theft of cash in the nation's history and the, second largest recorded anywhere.

title: Fossil Beds on Public Land Are Pillaged by Collectors
description: DENVER, Oct. 23A national heritage of fossilized animals and plants is being dug out of the earth and sold at an alarming rate, by businessmen who are developing new and highly profitable markets for prehistoric remains as art objects, jewelry and materials for decorators.

title: Byrne Weighs Civil Suit On Bridge Aide 's Profits
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23Governor Byrne said today he had directed the State Attorney General to determine whether a civil suit for damages should be filed against Ralph Cornell, chairman of the Delaware River Port Authority, whose construction company has profited from work done for the authority, according to a state investigation.

title: In Praise of Sprawl
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23An agglomeration of Federal bureaucrats, foundation officials, social planners and nobly motivated landuse freaks have taken advantage of the energy faddism and the depression in the homebuilding industry to launch an attack on the singlefamily house.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: FRED J. MAHLSTEDT
description: Fred J. Mahlstedt, former director of licensing and merchandising for Viacom International, Inc., a television organization, died of cancer Tuesday at his home, 250 East 73d Street. He was 65 years old.

title: JOHN H. P. GOULD
description: John H. P. Gould, retired lawyer and real estate executive, died Tuesday at his home in Lenox, Mass. He was 71 years old.

title: KISSINGER ARRIVES FOR SOVIET TALKS ON ARMS CONTROL
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23  Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here today hoping to accelerate the talks on the limitation of strategic arms and prepare the way for progress by the time President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev meet, possibly next month.

title: Rail Service Is Resumed
description: ALBANY, Oct. 23 (UPI) Railroad passenger service linking New York City with Detroit through Buffalo and Niagara Falls will begin next Wednesday, Governor Wilson's office announced today. Mr. Wilson and Gov. William G. Millikin of Michigan had been pressing to restore the service, which was terminated in 1971. The new service will be jointly financed by the two states and the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (Amtrak).

title: Museum's Army Ants Succumb to the Cold
description: Too much cold weather, according to the American Museum of Natural History, has diminished the colony of army ants it had flown up earlier this month from Panama for exhibition.

title: Dow Plunges 17.83, Its Biggest Loss in Two Months
description: Weighed down by gloomy, economic developments  including sagging automobile salesthe stock market reeled yesterday under persistent pressure, and the Dow Jones industrial average incurred its largest loss in two months.

title: Shaffer Details a Mind's Journey in Equus
description: In 1972, Peter Shaffer heard from a friend the bare outline of a true incident about a stable boy in England who blinded a number of horses. Mr. Shaffer was never able to discover the actual details, but in his mind conducted his own private investigation of the crime and wrote a play about it.

title: A BOMB EXPLODES AT BRITISH SCHOOL
description: HARROW, England, Oct. 23 (AP)A bomb exploded at Harrow School, one of Britain's most exclusive schools tonight but no injuries were reported, the police said. It was the second explosion in the London area in 24 hours.

title: Prices of Modern Paintings Fall At Sotheby's Barometer Sale
description: A huge painting by the French artist Jean Dubuffet brought a record price of $340,000 at an auction of impressionist and modern paintings and sculpture at Sotheby Parke Bernet last evening. The sale of the painting to Peter Matthews, a London dealer, was the high spot of a disappointing evening, in which about onethird of the works offered a high percentagewere bought back by their owners, and prices, particularly of the impressionist school, were generally well below estimates.

title: Van Arsdale Challenged In Taxi Reelection Bid
description: Harry Van Arsdale Jr., president of the Taxi Drivers Union, which he has headed for eight years, is being challenged in his reelection bid by two opponents who contend he has been an absentee leader and has suppressed democracy in the 30,000member union.

title: Troisgros, Renowned Restaurateur, 77
description: JeanBaptiste Troisgros, founder and guiding Spirit of a restaurant that has often been acclaimed as the greatest in the world, died yesterday while vacationing on the French Riviera. He. was 77 years old.

title: Council Committee Backs Full Disclosure for High City Aides
description: City officials making $25,000 a year or more and all candidates for city office would have to disclose the sources of, most of their income under a measure adopted with some reluctance yesterday by a City Council committee.

title: 3 Are Killed in Argentina; Industrialist Is Kidnapped
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 23 (AP) Three persons died today in two separate shooting incidents and an industrialist was kidnapped as violence continued to sweep Argentina.

title: '68 Transit Pack Disclosed
description: Court papers filed six years ago and made available yesterday disclosed in detail how the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority was enabled to use part of its revenues in support of mass transit in the New York area.

title: Advertising
description: H. Sherman Howes Jr. is an evangelist of sorts, not so much interested in saving souls as selling soles. Its the family business.

title: Jersey Governor Acts
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23  Governor Byrne announced today that he would require all New Jersey members of public authorities to make financial disclosures.

title: Mormon Chief Subpoenaed To Tell of Policy on Blacks
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 23 (AP)The president of the Mormon church has been subpoenaed to disclose all church policies and practices concerning blacks, who are denied full participation in the 3.3millionmember religion.

title: Notes on People
description: Betty Ford resumed her role as White House hostess last night when she and President Ford gave a farewell dinner party for Brig. Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., who, after serving two Presidents as chief of staff, has returned to active Army duty to become commander of allied forces in Europe on Nov. 1.

title: South Vietnam Newsmen Ask Information Chief's Removal
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 23 (Reuters)Leaders of three associations representing the bulk of South Vietnam's journalists called today for the dismissal of Information Minister Hoang Duc Nha. It was the latest move in a campaign for press freedom.

title: Woman Is Charged in Death Of Her 8YearOld Son Here
description: A 27yearold woman was arrested last night at St. Luke's Hospital and charged with killing her 8yearold son, who died at the hospital five hours after he was allegedly beaten and scalded with hot water at home, the police reported.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The whining New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: LILCO Hearings Put Off
description: ALBANY, Oct. 23 (UPI)The Public Service Commission today announced a threeweek delay in hearings on a $19.9million gasrate increase sought by the Long Island Lighting Company. The hearings were rescheduled for Nov. 19 in the Riverhead Town Hall, Nov. 20 in the Nassau County Executive Building and Nov. 21 in the Suffolk County Center.

title: Strategy Institute Accuses CBSTV Of Slanted News
description: BOSTON, Va., Oct. 23 (AP)CBSTV news has been accused of using partial and slanted reporting that has resulted in narrowing the parameters of public debate on critical national defense issues.

title: James Tuite
description: Put him in the traje de luces, suit of sequins, and he is Dominguin answering the trumpet call to the Hour of Truth in the bullring. Put him in a dude outfit with a shoestring tie and he's a riverboat gambler. Put him in pinstripes and he is Joseph Paul Torre, a baseball player with long sideburns and deepset dark eyes who looks more like a matador or a Mississippi gambler than a baseball player.

title: Clark Exploited by Hanoi, Javits Says, Citing P.O.W.
description: Senator Jacob K. Jalits, citing a letter he said he had received from a former prisoner of war, charged yesteray that Ramsey Clark had allowed himself to be exploited by the North Vietnamese during Mr. Clark's visit with prisoners in Hanoi in 1972.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger arrived in Moscow with fairly concrete ideas on strategic arms limitation to explore in three days of talks with Soviet leaders. Accelerated progress would prepare the way for a meeting between President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev, possibly next month. Other subjects on the agenda include dtente and Middle East issues. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: LOYD WRIGHT DIES; COAST LAWYER, 81
description: Loyd Wright, former president of the American Bar Association, died Tuesday at his home in Hemet, Calif. He was 81 years old.

title: Stage: Flaccid Hothouse
description: Do you remember that raunchy, old longdistance theatrical runner, Tobacco Road? Have you ever wondered what it would be if Tobacco Road were to be rewritten today? Well, perhaps, but you get some idea of the effect from Megan Terry's Hothouse, which had its official critics' opening yesterday afternoon at the Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn.

title: Bonds Arrives With Reputation
description: He was so thrilled with the trade he flew all night from San Francisco to talk about it. He wasn't thrilled about the drug rumors that have plagued him this year, but he talked about them, too.

title: G.S.A SAYS BUILDING IS NOT NIXON LIBRARY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) The head of the General Services ices Administration denied, in a letter made public yesterday that the Government had acquired a huge office building, in a $27million trade, to house the papers of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Auto Industry Pessimistic; Action by President Urged
description: DETROIT, Oct. 23Declines In automobile sales, profits and stock prices have spread gloom throughout the auto industry.

title: Market Place
description: MidOctober sales figures for the nation's four auto makers were released yesterday, bringing added gloom for holders of the companies' shares.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Laborite Position Shifts, Favors Common Market
description: LONDON, Oct. 23Despite all the threatening talk about pulling Britain out of the Common Market, the Labor Government of Prime Minister Harold Wilson is drawing closer to the ninenation community as well as toward a formal decision to insure continued membership.

title: Byrne Says PATH Delay Perils Kennedy Rail Link
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23Ranking Byrne administration officials said today that New Jersey's dispute with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey over the construction of a PATH rapidtransit extension from Newark to Plainfield seriously jeopardized the chances of a companion proposal for a rapid transit link from Manhattan to Kennedy International Airport in New York.

title: DEAN TELLS PLAN TO SAVE HIMSELF
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 John W. Dean 3d admitted today after repeated questioning that to save himself he had joined in a plan to have John N. Mitchell take the blame for the Watergate breakin.

title: Five Civil Servants in Nassau Expected to Testify on Kickbacks
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 23At least five Civil Service employes in Nassau County who said they had been coerced into making kickbacks to the local Republican party have been subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury, an informant close to the situation said today.

title: OIL CONCERN FINED FOR ELECTION GIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 The Time Oil Company of Seattle and its president, Raymind Abendroth, both pleaded guilty today to allegations that they made illegal corporate contributions to the 1972 Presiden tial campaigns of Richard M. Nixon and Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Wash ington.

title: Alvin L. Weil, a Chief Developer Of Roosevelt Raceway, Is Slain
description: Alvin L. Weil, a former director and president of Roosevelt Raceway, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, Sarasota, Fla., as a result of a gunshot wound received some hours earlier. He was 66 years old.

title: No Battle As Fingers Visits Plaza
description: That great clubhouse philosopher, Roland Glen Fingers, twirled his Salvador Dali mustache yesterday and explained that life on the Oakland A's was like being married.

title: Angry Keeper Stages Monkey House LockIn
description: A 23yearold zookeeper at the Prospect Park Zoo, brandishing a pitchfork, locked himself inside the Monkey House yesterday and smashed several windows before he was calmed by the police and Parks Department officials and removed to a hospital.

title: A's Get Williams Of Cubs
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP)The Chicago Cubs traded Billy Williams, their slugging outfielderfirst baseman, to the Oakland A's today in exchange for Darold Knowles and Bob Locker, both relief pitchers, and Manny Trillo, a second baseman.

title: U.S. Court Tells Jaycees They Can't Shift Convention
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 23 (UPI)The National Jaycees organization can take action against its Kansas City chapter for admitting women into membership, but a Federal judge prevented the national group yesterday from moving its 10 outstanding young men convention to another city.

title: DRIVERS IN BRONX REJECT BUS PACT
description: Striking drivers and mechanics yesterday rejected a contract settlement aimed at ending their threeandahalf month walkout against New York Bus Service, which runs express buses from several Bronx apartment complexes.

title: '68 Transit Pact Disclosed
description: Court papers filed six years ago and made available yesterday disclosed in detail how the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority was enabled to use part of its revenues in support of mass transit in the New York area.

title: Syria, at Arab Talks, Urges Palestinian Role in Military Command
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 23Syria proposed today to the Arab countries the creation of a joint military command comprising the Palestine Liberation Organization as well as Jordan, Egypt and Syria.

title: Personal Finance
Papadopoulos Sent Into Island Exile With 4 From Junta
description: ATHENS, Oct. 23George, Papadopoulos and four other leaders of the military coup of 1967 were arrested today and exiled to the small Aegean Island of Kea.

title: Books of The Times
description: OR ELSE. By Robert Penn Warren. 102 pages. Random House. $6.95. I was surprised and pleased by the intimacy of Robert Penn Warren's new book of poems, Or Else. It is reassuring to see a prizewinning poet, a monument of a man now nearly 70, still looking around him Innocent with wonder, startled by the unsleeping principle of delight, intoxicated by the way that Glory, like gasoline spilled/on the cement in a garage, may flare of a sudden, up/in a blinding blaze.... The movement of some of these poems mocks his age. They dance, as in Kenneth Burke's beautiful remark: The symbolic act is the dancing of an attitude. In poems such as The Nature of a Mirror, Composition in Gold and RedGold and especially Birth of Love, Mr. Penn Warren's rhythms and perceptions fuse in a kind of unity that nonpoets find, if they are lucky, only in love itself.

title: Contract Awards
description: A group of four Japanese companies has received contract valued at about $200million from P. T. Pertamina, the Indonesian Governmentowned concern, to build a natural gas pipeline on Java Island, it was announced in Tokyo yesterday by Mitsui & Co. The other companies are Toyo Menka Kaisha, Ltd., Marubeni & Co. and the Far East Oil Trading Company. The Nippon Steel Corporation will do the construction work for the group.

title: Carey Terms TaxCredit Plan A Desperate Effort by Wilson
description: WANTAGH, L.I., Oct. 23Representative Hugh L. Carey said today that Governor Wilson's plan to double the investment tax credit for small business was a desperate attempt to provide a lastminute windfall for business and to deflect attention from the steady loss of jobs in the state.

title: Republican in Perth Amboy Area Wages Uphill Fight
description: PERTH AMBOY, Oct. 21 Dominated by bluecollar workers and upwardmobile suburbanites of Italian, Polish and Hungarian ancestry, among others, New Jersey's traditionally Democratic 15th Congressional District gave President Nixon a robust majority of 61 to 39 per cent over Senator George S. McGovern in the 1972 presidential election.

title: Auto Industry Pessimistic; Action by President Urged
description: DETROIT, Oct. 23Declines in automobile sales, profits and stock prices have spread gloom throughout, the auto industry.

title: India's Commodity Prices Fall; Some Economists Are Alarmed
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 23After rising steadily for two years, prices of commodities in India have begun to decline. But Indian economists are debating whether to applaud the phenomenon as a sign of economic recovery or to sound the alarm for the beginning of a recession that could have disastrous consequences.

title: MARKET BASKET RESUMES CLIMB
description: The cost of feeding a family of four resumed its climb last week after a one week pause when prices remained about the same.

title: POLES ARE VEXED BY UNPAID LABOR
description: WARSAW, Oct. 19  Polish parents are complaining that their children are being compelled to perform increasingly longer periods of voluntary unpaid labor for the state.

title: People in Sports
description: Walton Alston of the Los Angeles Dodgers, was named the National League manager of the year yesterday by The Associated Press and United Press International. Alston, who piloted the Dodgers to the pennant for the seventh time in his 21 seasons, did better in the voting than his team did against the Oakland A's in the recent World Series. Alston outscored Danny Murtaugh of Pittsburgh, 290 to 87 in the AP poll. He beat Danny Ozark of Philadelphia, 113, in the UPI poll.

title: Panel Questions Nadjari on His Methods in Rao Case
description: A fivemember Appellate Division panel sharply questioned the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, yesterday on the methods he used in obtaining an indictment last spring against Judge Paul P. Rao Sr. of the United States. Customs Court.

title: National Airlines Planning Partial Service by Nov. 2
description: MIAMI, Oct. 23 (UPI)National Airlines, which has been struck by machinists for 101 days, said today it would begin taking reservations immediately for a partial resumption of service on Nov. 2.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP)Charlie Chaplin announced today that he had changed his mind about retiring and planned to produce a movie of one of his stories, The Freak.

title: Jury Expected to Be Set Today in Kent State Trial
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 (UPI) The judge in the Kent State shootings trial moved jury selection along swiftly today, leaving the defense and prosecution with only three peremptory challenges each before the opening statements can begin.

title: ROCKEFELLER TAXES SUBJECT OF REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) Representative Peter W. Rodino, Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, received today a report on Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller's income taxes for the last six years, but refused to talk about its contents.

title: 4 Children Die in Blaze
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP)Four children were killed early today in a fire that struck a wood frame house in Boston's Dorchester, section. Fire officials said the blaze had started at the rear of the house and spread quickly through a back stairway to attic bedrooms where the children were sleeping. The victims were identified as Vicki White, 12 years old; her sisters, Junifer, 10, and Melvalisa, 7, and their brother, Napoleon, 6.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Byrne Asking Fiscal Data Of Authority Appointees

title: Bridge: Games for Pairs or Teams Require Different Strategy
description: The Metropolitan Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association do not swing into full gear here at the New York Hilton Hotel until tomorrow, but players at both ends of the skill scale have opportunities tonight.

title: GOODYEAR NET UP 81% FOR QUARTER
Russians Are Firm On Bar to Newsmen At Soyuz Launching
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) James C. Fletcher, the head of the national space program, said today that the Soviet Union steadfastly refused to permit American newsmen to view the launching next July 15 of. Russian astronauts in the joint United StatesSoviet space mission.

title: SALES BY MERRILL OF C.D.'S REVIEWED
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 23 (Reuters)The chairman of the Federal Deposit, Insurance Corporation, Frank Wille, said here the F.D.I.C. would be reviewing very carefully whether recent sales by Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith, Inc., of participations in bank certificates of deposit was a violation of Regulation Q interest rate ceilings.

title: L.I. Swindle Suspect Is Extradited
description: HAUPPAGUE, L. I., Oct. 23Eight months after he fled the United States for Sweden, Robert A. Luongo Jr. was brought home this evening to face charges of swindling more than 2,000 people here and abroad of at least $15million in a getrichquick investment scheme.

title: Laver Battles Connors In Las Vegas On Feb.
description: Rod Laver and Jimmy Connors set the date and place yesterday for the first match ever between the two star lefthanded tennis players. The $100,000 winnertakeall challenge match (the loser gets an unspecified consolation prize) is slated indoors for Feb. 2 at the Caesars Palace Hotel in Las Vegas.

title: Autumn of Discontent for Main Street Voters
description: SAUK CENTRE, Minn., Oct: 23Original Main Street, they call it now. That's its official name, lettered large in white on green at the corners along its broad expanse.

title: Turkey Charges 14 Editors With Publishing Secrets
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 23 (UPI)The editors of 10 Turkish newspapers and two major news agencies were indicted today on charges bf having published state secrets during Turkey's invasion of Cyprus.

title: Nixon Hospitalized For Complications In Phlebitis Case
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon was readmitted unexpectedly last night to Memorial Hospital Medical Center of Long Beach, Calif., because of complications in his phlebitis treatment.

title: High Bail Set for Canadian Held Here on Drug Charges
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn today ordered Frank Cotroni, a Montreal businessman, held in lieu of $1.5million bail on narcotics conspiracy charge after he was returned to the United States from Canada when the Supreme Court there refused to block his extradition.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: People in Sports
description: Walton Alston of the Los Angeles Dodgers, was named the National League manager of the year yesterday by The Associated Press and United Press International. Alston, who piloted the Dodgers to the pennant for the seventh time in his 21 seasons, did better in the voting than his team did against the Oakland A's in the recent World Series. Alston outscored Danny Murtaugh of Pittsburgh, 290 to 87 in the AP poll. He beat Danny Ozark of Philadelphia, 113, in the UPI poll.

title: Ozawa Conducts a Precentennial Tribute to Ravel
description: The Program

title: Corporate Profile
description: The Singer Company, proprietor of a brand name that is as much a part of Americana as Kodak, Levi's and CocaCola, is faced with omitting or drastically reducing the 65cent quarterly dividend that it pays its 54,000 stockholders, many of whom are present and former employes.

title: Agency Sells Notes Yielding 7.89%Buying Is Off
description: The Treasury borrowed $1billion yesterday by selling notes yielding 7.89 per cent in a financing that attracted fewer individuals that the Government's note sales late last summer. In the latest note sale, prospective buyers placed orders totaling $2.3billion for the $1billion issue with bids ranging in yield from a low of 7.78 per cent to a high of 7.93 per cent. The came to 7.89 percent.

title: Government Is Mailing New Medicare Booklet
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP)  At a cost of up to $4.2million, the Social Security Administration is mailing new Medicare booklets to 23.5 million aged and disabled beneficiaries.

title: Biaggi Willing to Concede Conservative Line to Foe
description: Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx announced yesterday that he had petitioned the city's Corporation Counsel not to hold a special election for the Conservative party candidate in the 10th Congressional District.

title: Trifecta Pays $21,402
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y. Oct. 23 (AP)  An 1181 trifecta paid $21,402 at Finger Lakes race track today. It was the third largest trifecta paid at the thoroughbred track this year, track officials said. Teedon, a $23 winner, beat 501 Glenora and Golden Frost showed.

title: WOMAN SAYS SHE KILLED MAN ON L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 23JoAnne Brown tearfully admitted today that she had killed Burr C. Hollister, a State Supreme Court law secretary with whom she had lived for several years.

title: BODIES OF 2 WOMEN EXHUMED FOR TESTS
description: The bodies of two of the women in whose deaths Calvin Jackson is said to have implicated himself have been exhumed, the Acting Chief Medical Examiner said yesterday.

title: Turandot Feb. 21 Heads New City Opera Stagings
description: Rachel Mathes, an American soprano who recently made her debut with the Metropolitan Opera as Donna Anna in Mozart's Don Giovanni, will shift to the New York City Opera next spring will have multimedia staging devised by Frank Corsaro and Ronald Chase, with costumes by Miss Aldredge. The leading roles will be sung by Carol Neblett and John Alexander, with Imr Palo conducting.

title: Council Committee Backs Full Disclosure for High City Aides
description: City officials making $25,000 a year or more and all candidates for city office would have to disclose the sources of most of their income under a measure adopted with some reluctance yesterday by a City Council committee.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FRIENDLY BITER Prof. Irwin Corey is a funny man with a glare that could wilt a cactus, a twinkling edge, and a running patter of gobbledygook that shifts to slashing Swiftian satire, essentially political. Then comes a bellylaugh wisecrack. The effect is acidly nourishing.

title: FORD AIDE HINTS AT A COMPROMISE ON TAX PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23One of the Ford Administration's top economic policymakers pledged today that the Administration would not hold stubbornly to its present economic program if the state of the economy changed.

title: A BELGIAN ACCORD IS WON BY TRUDEAU
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 23 (Reuters) Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada today won Belgium's backing for his demand that the European Common Market sign a formal trade agreement with Canada.

title: Soviet Ends Missile Tests
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (AP) The Soviet Union announced today that a new series of rocket tests in the Pacific Ocean had been successfully completed. The test area was closed Oct. 17. The United States Defense Department said the tests included the firing on Sunday of an intercontinental ballistic missile.

title: Overkill
description: If we get the wrong kind of Congress, peace could be in jeopardy, President Ford told a Republican rally Oklahoma City this week.

title: Ford Attack on Democrats Softened by White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23A White House spokesman sought today to tone down President Ford's charge yesterday that Democratic gains in Congress could jeopardize world peace. Ron Nessen, the President's press secretary, said that Mr. Ford had been surprised by the criticism of angry Democrats over his campaign remarks yesterday in Oklahoma and Ohio.

title: YUGOSLAVIA JAILS 74YEAROLD FOE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 23A 74yearoid wartime opponent of Yugoslavia's President Tito and the Communist Partisans was sentenced by a Belgrade court today to five years in prison on charges that he wrote antiTito articles for foreign publications five years ago.

title: CANNED VEGETABLES SEEN RISING IN PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) Consumers will see higher prices and shortages of some of their favorite canned vegetables again this fall and winter, a report by the Agriculture Department indicated today.

title: Defeated Candidate in Primary To Appeal for Vote on Monday
description: Sheldon Silver, who was narrowly defeated in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary for City Council in lower Manhattan's Second District, said yesterday that he would appeal a court decision against a new primary election that had been set for Monday.

title: CLERK CONVICTED IN POLICE KILLING
description: A 32yearold hospital clerk was convicted last night by a Bronx Supreme Court jury on charges of reckless manslaughter in the death of a Transit Authority police officer in a shootout in a Bronx subway station two years ago.

title: KENNETH JOLLY, 56, OF CAMPBELL SOUP
description: Kenneth N. Jolly, vice president and assistant to the president of the Campbell Soup Company, Camden, N.J., died yesterday in the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Villanova, Pa.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Two aspects of Mr. Ford's pardon of Mr. Nixon appear to have escaped notice.

title: Bonds Arrives With Reputation
description: He was so thrilled with the trade he flew all night from San Francisco to talk about it. He wasn't thrilled about the drug rumors that have plagued him this year, but he talked about them, too.

title: BUCK IS BEATEN IN SOUTH BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23A black man was pulled from a truck anctbeaten in South Boston this afternoon as parts of this city remained tense under a courtordered plan of busing for school desegregation. This was the first serious incident in a week.

title: Lifetime Jobs of Japanese In Peril as Economy Lags
description: MATSUOKA, Japan, Oct. 17Since it was built three years ago, the Toshiba Electronics Factory here in this small farming village has been the pride of the community.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Wet, Page 43

title: Morton Happy to Join Giants
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 23What Craig Morton didn't know when he helped maneuver his trade from Dallas by refusing to report to a Cowboy practice session early in the week was where he might land if a deal was made.

title: State Issues: Albany's Interrelationship With the City
description: The first year that Robert F. Wagner was Mayor of New York, he helped to nominate and elect Averell Harriman as Governora post that, as it turned out, the Democrats were able to hold only briefly in between the Albany reigns of Thomas E. Dewey and Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1974

title: Wyandanch Eleven Is Waiting Its Turn
description: Saturday it may be Wyandanch's turn. Two weeks ago, Dickinson of Jersey City broke a 42  game losing streak. Last Saturday, Dobbs Ferry snapped a 47game span without a victory (45 losses, two ties). Now Wyandanch, which four years ago today suffered its last victory, will try to end its streak at 31 against Greenport.

title: Laxalt Hopes for Comeback in Nevada In Attempt to Succeed Bible in Senate
description: SPARKS, Nev., Oct. 23Paul Laxalt, a 52yearold former Governor, is trying a political comeback here in a Republican effort to pick up a normally Democratic Senate seat.

title: Big Spending Seen By Steel Industry To Raise Capacity
description: The steel industry worldwide will have to spend over $165billion during the decade of 1970's to add 300 million metric tons of capacity, Dr. Arnold E. Safer, an energy and minerals specialist with the Irving Trust Company, said yesterday.

title: $8.4Million Loss Is Seen For a Bank in Germany
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 23 (Reuters)About 21 million marks ($8.4million) may have been lost by the Commerzbank as a result of alleged embezzlement by the former chief clerk at its Frankfurt bookkeeping department, the Hesse state prosecutor, Dietrich Rahn, said today. The mark is equivalent to about 40 cents.

title: Police Removed From P.S. 46 As Effects of the Boycott Ease
description: Attendance at Public School 46 in Harlem, where It parents' protest against four teachers kept 99 per cent of the students out of school last Friday, was flack up to 70 percent yesterday and the police contingent there had been reduced from a peak of 100 officers to the normal detail of two.

title: OFFICIAL CLEARED IN OBSCENITY CASE
description: NORTH HAVERHILL, N. H., Oct. 23A young County. At. torrsey, or prosecutor, in rural New Hampshire, charged with violating the state's obscenity statute by showing the movies Deep Throat and The Devil hi. Miss Jones, has been cleared on two of four obscenity charges by an allmale jury.

title: Steele Says Bailey Netted $2Million In Illegal Deal With Hartford Utility
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 23United States Representative Robert H. Steele, the Republican nominee for Governor of Connecticut, today accused John M. Bailey, the state Democratic chairman, of illegally buying an office building from the Hartford Electric Light Company and then renting it back to the company in a deal that brought him a profit of more than $2million.

title: SAMUEL G. CAW, ARTIST, 88, IS DEAD
description: Samuel G. Cahan, an oldtime quicksketch newspaper artist, who had been on the staff of The New York World for 32 years, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital at the age of 88.

title: Army Discharges Pilot In White House Buzzing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (Reuters)  The Army said today that it had discharged Pvt. Robert Preston, the helicopter pilot who buzzed the White House last winter.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SNOW A DECLINE
description: Prices tumbled on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market yesterday in decreased trading.

title: expansion Studied Of O.E.C.D. Oil Plan By 6 New Countries
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 23  There is a chance that more oilconsuming nations will join the original 12 countries in creating an emergency oilsharing system next month, an informed source said today in Brussels.

title: Rate Increase of $500,000 For Railroad Is Set Aside
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23 (UPI)The State Supreme Court unanimously set aside today a $500,000 rate increase on sand shipments on the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey.

title: Ford vs. Ford
description: The White House currently appears as a stage on which two plays are being acted side by side, with President Ford the leading character in both. In one scenario, he earns applause for having replaced a devious, solitary, autocratic Richard Nixon with his own gregarious frankness and simplicity. In the other, he disturbs the audience with inexplicable deviations and decisions that shock and confound political friends and opponents alike.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Metropolitan Briefs
description: The prosecution rested its case yesterday in State Supreme Court, Manhattan, in the murder trial of Police Officer William R. Phillips. He is being retried for the alleged 1968 slaying of a pimpJames Smith, alias James Goldbergand an 18yearold prostitute, Sharon Stango.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Planners Propose Giving City Island SpecialDistrict Status to Retain Aura
description: At a meeting alongside a quiet boatyard, city planners proposed last night to safeguard the fishingvillage flavor of City Island by declaring it a special district.

title: 6 WESTERN LANDS IN CREDIT ACCORD
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 24Six major Western countries including the United States have reached an agreement on credit terms for exports to each other and six wealthy oilproducing countries.

title: Benson Leader In Club Pro Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 24 (AP)Bobby Benstm, the 34yearold former Connecticut open champion from. Easton, Conn posted a fiveunderpar 67 today on the Pinehurst No. 2 course to take the firstround lead in the Professional Golfers Association club professional championship.

title: Kite Shares Lead In Australian Golf
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 24 (UPI)  Tom Kite of Austin, Tex., and Ian Stanley of Australia each posted a fiveunderpar 67 today in the first round of the $45,500 Wills Masters golf tournament.

title: MISSOURI DIOCESE TO ORDAIN WOMEN
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24 (UPI)The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Eastern Missouri has voted to ordain and license women priests.

title: SCHOOL STRIKERS DEFY LONG BRANCH
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 24  More than 340 striking teachers and school employes at 10 Long Branch schools defied a court order today and continued their walkout.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Oct. 24  Air Force visits New Jersey for the first time and Rutgers will provide the opposition Saturday in a football game that could be decided by the kicking and linebacking ability of Dave Lawson, one the most versatile athletes in Falcon sports history.

title: Banco di Roma Selling Interest in Real Estate
description: ROME, Oct. 24 (UPI)  The statecontrolled Banco di Roma said today it was selling a controlling interest in Rome's biggest real estate company which it received as collateral for a $200million loan to Michele Sindona, the controversial Sicilian financier.

title: The Little French Restaurant You've Always Dreamed Of
description: The little French restaurant that was the glory of New York dining in the nineteentwenties, to hear some people tell it, and on through the nineteenfifties, as they think they remember, has taken an awful beating in the last 15 years.

title: 212 Million Americans
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Census Bureau estimated today that the nation's population as of Sept. 1 totaled 212,216,000. This was an increase of 155,000 over the figure for the previous month and 1.5 million, or 0.07 per cent, over the same month a year earlier.

title: SYLVIA SYMS SINGS WITH BUOYANT LILT
description: It often takes so long for good singers of popular songs to bring everything into balance that they give up the effort before they reach a maturity of their potential. Despite more hard knocks than even a pop singer usually has to face, Sylvia Syms has hung on for more than a quartercentury and has finally come into full artistic bloom.

title: A Relaxed Giulini Leads Philharmonic
description: Carlo Maria Giulini's second week as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic, starting last night, brought a program with two works and a soloist. Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 2, the Little Russian, opened the evening, and the big D minor Piano Concerto by Brahms closed it. Rudolph Firkusny was the pianist.

title: College, School Results CROSS COUNTRY
