Integration on Trial
description: In its study of the causes of last year's racial clashes at Madison High School in Brooklyn, the city's Commission on Human Rights has explored some fundamental problems arising in urban schools throughout the country.

title: Australian Wheat Sale
description: SYDNEY, Oct. 24 (Reuters) The Australian Wheat Board announced today that it had sold one million metric tons of wheat worth $158million to the Soviet Union. The board said that the sale was on a cash basis and provided for shipment of wheat between November, 1974, and August, 1975.

title: FOOTBALL TONIGHT
description: Home teams listed first

title: KISSINGER MEETS BREZHNEV 6 HOURS ON MAJOR ISSUES
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24 Secretary of State Kissinger met with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today for six and a half hours of talks that were dominated by the Middle East situation and European security problems but that also included SovietAmertican trade.

title: Giants Get Pettigrew On Waivers
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 24By virtue of having the worst wonlost record of all 13 teams in the National Football Conference the New York Giants had first crack at the N.F.C. waiver list yesterday. They stuck in their thtimbs and pulled out what they think might be two plums.

title: Bruins Tie Blues, 44, On Late Score by Orr
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP)Bobby Orr scored on a 35foot backhander with 34 seconds left tonight to help the Boston Bruins tie the St. Louis Blues, 44, in a National Hockey League game.

title: PROFIT RISE SHOWN BY SHEARSON HAYDEN
description: Shearson Hayden Stone, Inc., the stockbrokers, reported yesterday that it had a prat of $103,000, or 3 cents a share for the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 3. This contrasted with a loss of $668,000 a year earlier. Revenues, meanwhile, rose to $21.8million from $15.5million the year before.

title: Yanks Give Virdon Pact For 2 Years
description: In an atmosphere of mutual admiration and hope, the Yankees signed Bill Virdon yesterday to a new twoyear contract as manager.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing Passenger and kill Ships

title: Madison High Split Into 2 Racial Worlds
description: After 10 years of integration and one small race riot, James Madison High School is still a?? institution in which black and white share little more than space.

title: Venezuela at a Glance
description: Venezuela, a South American country more than twice the size of California, lies in the northernmost part of the continent on the Caribbean Sea. On the east is. Guyana, on the south Brazil and on the west Colombia: The country has 1,748 miles of irregular coastline, and its southernmost point, about 650 miles from the Caribbean, is within one degree of the Equator.

title: OPEC EXPERTS ASK NEW PRICE SYSTEM
description: VIENNA, Oct. 24 (AP)Experts of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have reached agreement on a simplified system for setting crude oil prices, a delegate disclosed today.

title: India's First Lady Moves Into the Official Spotlight
description: NEW DELHIIn the past few weeks the first lady of India has eaten kebabs with the Shah of Iran; she has exchanged views with President Omar Bongo of Gabon; at the end of October she will spruce up the guest suite of her home for Secretary of State Kissinger and his wife, Nancy.

title: Clark Make Public His Hanoi Tapes; Sees Cloak and Dagger Act by Javits
description: Ramsey Clark made public yesterday tapes and transcripts of his 1972 comments over Radio Hanoi and denounced Senator Jacob K. Javits for a cloakanddagger stunt in ordering the material from the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Dow Drop Is Cut to 8.77 By Late BargainHunting
description: The growing possibility of a major recession dealt another sizable blow to stock prices yesterday in modest trading.

title: WEICKER CRITICIZES STEELE ON ATTACKS
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 24The gubernatorial campaign of United States Representative Robert H. Steele was set back today be criticism of his campaign tactics by a Republican colleague, Senator Lowell B. Weicker.

title: Supreme Court, in Rare Action, Rejects Brief as Being Lengthy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24For the first time in many years, and perhaps the first time ever, the Supreme Court has refused accept a brief filed by an attorney and has ordered him to rewrite it or lose his chance to argue his case before the Justices.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: For many years, I have admired your newspaper for advocating con. servation and a balanced ecology and for standing up against rapacious developers, wasteful business practices, etc. Logically, this would call for reining in our overblown economy of high consumption. The business section of your paper, however, continues to report on economic developments in the conventional way, i.e., you register with alarm an even slight decline in the G.N.P. as the beginning of a recession; the drop of sales and profits of manufacturing companies and others is a black mark.

title: Libraries Widen Activities, Sparking Debate on Goals
description: Time was when some people thought of libraries as gloomy repositories of dusty books, presided over by stiff little ladies who shushed noisy children and hid the dirty books. No more.

title: To Keep Pretoria In
description: Nothing would be gained either for the cause of world peace and security or for the effectiveness of the United Nations by expelling the white Government of South Africa from the U.N. On the contrary, the chances for peaceful evolution to selfdetermination and majority rule in both South Africa and Namibia (SouthWest Africa) will be greater if the Pretoria Government remains in the organization of which it is an original member.

title: Books of The Times
description: TATTOO. By Earl Thompson. 588 pages. Putnam. $8.95.

title: Jurors Are Seated In Kent State Case; For Strong Forces
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 (AP)A jury of four women and eight men, all of whom say they favor keeping America's military strong, was seated today to try eight former Ohio National Guard men indicted in the 1970 Kent State University shootings.

title: Opera: Esclarmonde a Hit on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 Are we in the midst of a Massenet revival? Until a few years ago Manon was the only one of the composer's two dozen operas to be performed with any regularity.

title: Javits for Senator
description: In his eighteen years in the Senate and eight in the House of Representatives, Jacob K. Javits has compiled an enviable record of enlightened legislationfrom gun control and school busing to daycare centers, health insurance and consumer protection  modified at times by the dictates of parliamentary compromise.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: GEORGE WELBES
description: George Weibes, a stage actor, died Oct. 17 at Trafalgar Hospital. He was 40 years old. Death was ascribed to a cerebral hemorrhage.

title: G.M. Will Lay Off 6,000 at 4 Plants
description: DETROIT, Oct. 24The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would lay off 6,000 workers indefinitely at four plants making small cars, including 2,000 at the Tarrytown, N.Y., plant.

title: Fears of Unemployment Bring Easing in War Against Inflation
description: BONN, Oct. 24West Germany, in the face of rising unemployment that could leave as many as 1 million out of work this winter, took a major step today towdrd loosening its highly successful antiinflationary credit policies.

title: Northwest Sets Expansion
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP)Northwest Industries, Inc., said it planned to spend more than $60million to expand tubular steel production at Lone Star Steel, a Dallas subsidiary. Northwest Industries said the program, expected to end by 1976, would increase Lone Star's production of tubular steel for the oil industry by about 40 per cent.

title: KISSINGER MEETS BREZHNEV 6 HOURS ON MAJOR ISSUES
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24 Secretary of State Kissinger met with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today for six and a half hours of talks that were dominated by the Middle East situation and European security problems but that also included SovietAmerican trade.

title: Libraries Widen Activities, Sparking Debate on Goals
description: Time was when some people thought of libraries as gloomy repositories of dusty books, presided over by stiff little ladies who shushed noisy children and hid the dirty books. No more.

title: Head of Petroleum Council Out; Washington Fraud Inquiry Is Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Vincent M. Brown has resigned as executive director of the National Petroleum Council and is under investigation by the fraud division of the District Attorney's office here.

title: WOMEN TO REVIEW ROLES IN RELIGION
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct, 24Three national organizations are starting a series of seminars aimed at giving women an equal policymaking role in organized religious groups.

title: Continuing Crime at Hotel Brings Contempt Finding
description: The operators of the West Side Towers, which the police say is one of the more crimeridden single  room  occupancy hotels in the city, have been found guilty of contempt of court for allowing the premises to be used for crime, for failing to provide a proper security force and for letting refuse accumulate.

title: Dance
description: Gerald Arpino's The Clowns, which has not been given for several years, returned to the City Center Joffrey Ballet on Wednesday night at the City Center. Dim memories of this ballet suggested that once you'd seen it, you'd seen it. The revival confirmed that it should be seen at least once.

title: HardPressed Cafe Theater In Passaic to Close Today
description: PASSAIC, Oct. 24 (AP)The Cafe Theater, which opened here nine months ago and presented nine plays, will close tomorrow because of financial problems, according to its producer. Bob Bartola, the producer, inflation, lack of a subsidy and apprehension about traveling to the city for theater. Aonther New Jersey theater, The Meadowbrook in Cedar Grove, closed two weeks ago because of high costs and labor problems.

title: TV: Bowie, British Rock Performer, All aGlitter
description: According to latest reports, David Bowie, the British rock performer, has given up his glitter wardrobe for a simpler, more tailored look, apparently along the lines of those broadshouldered suits that Once used to transform Rosalind Russell into a movie newspaperperson. But, for the questionable record, his glitter phase has been recorded by D. A. Pennebaker, the film maker, in Bowie '73 With the Spiders From Mars, which can be seen tonight at 11:30 on ABC's In Concert series.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: There wil be 42 scheduled rounds of boxing tonight in Madison Square Garden. In the main bout, Rodrigo Valdes, the World Boxing Council middleweight champion for Cartagena, Columbia, will meet unbeaten Vinnie Curto of Minnie Beach in a nontitle 10rounder. Valdes has won 22 straight fights since the spring of 1970, 18 of them by knockouts, to run his lifetime wonlostdrawn mark to 5242. Curio, 20 years old, has won all 17 of his professional bouts.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The City Center Jaffrey Ballet will leave here Nov. 16 for a fourweek State Department tour of the Soviet Union. The company will open in Leningrad on Nov. 20 and also perform in Riga, Latvia, Vilnius, Lithuania, and Moscow. The Jaffrey Ballet, predecessor to the present Joffrey company, toured the Soviet Union for three months in 1963.

title: RAY'S TESTIMONY IS OFF UNTIL TODAY
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 24Testimony by James Earl Ray on the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was postponed this afternoon until tomorrow as his attorneys decided to call his relatives before putting Mr. Ray on the stand.

title: FUNDS FOR JAVITS CALLED LAGGING
description: Afflicted by a sagging economy and Republican apathy in the wake of Watergate, the reelection drive for Senator Jacob K. Javits has talsed a disappointing sum of $680,000 pnd is unlikely to reach its goal of $1million, Mr. Javits's campaign manager said yesterday.

title: Curb on U. S. Waste Urged To Help World's Hungry
description: As the daily ration of rice becomes steadily smaller in several poor countries, some Aniericans are beginning to look at their dinner plates of steak and potatoes not with pleasure but with a trace of guilt.

title: British Lead U.S., 20, in Cup Tennis
description: DESIDE, Wales, Oct. 24 (AP)Britain took a 20 lead today in the Wightmen Cup tennis competition as Virginia Wade and Glynis Coles beat American rivals in long matches on the opening day.

title: Weil Killing Recalls '50 Trot Scandals
description: Florida police were digging into a tangled web of romantic and business involvement yesterday in connection with the murder of Alvin L. Weil, former president of Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.6 From. WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 230.9 from 231.5 last week.

title: 4 LEAVE CABINET IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 24Information Minister, Hoang Due Nha, a cousin of president Nguyen Van Thieu and one of his closest advisers, resigned today along with three other Cabinet members.

title: About Real Estate
description: CENTEREACH, L. I.Ronald Roth used to smoke 12 cigars a day. He is down to four now, and he is slimmer, too. All the better tb wrestle with his problems.

title: Northwest Up Sharply
description: UAL, Inc., the holding company that owns United Air Lines, the world's largest air carrier; Delta Air Lines, the most profitable of the nation's trunk systems in the last two years, and Northwest Airlines all reported sharp profit gains in the three months to Sept. 30.

title: City Bar Unit, in Rare Act, Urges Fuchsberg's Defeat
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York departed yesterday from its usual style of rating judicial candidates in a word or twopreferred, highly qualified, not approvedto issue a strongly worded statement criticizing Jacob Fuchsberg and urging the voters to choose from among his three opponents in the Court of Appeals race.

title: RICHFIELD PROFIT SHOWS 140% RISE
description: More record profits for the third quarter were chalked up by the oil industry yesterday as Texaco, Inc., the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Marathon Oil Company announced sharp earnings advances.

title: Seattle Coach ReSigned
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 24 (AP)Seattle University has signed its basketball Coach, Bill O'Connor, to a threeyear contract.

title: The Pop Life
description: Shows like Richard Nader's rock'n'roll revivals remind usif we needed reminding, given the prevalent historicism about presentday rock that rock has a past. And even though many of us still like to think of the form as a defiantly contemporary phenomenon, rock has its historians.

title: Rift With Palestinians Emerges at Rabat
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 24Arab foreign ministers failed today for the third day to reach agreement on how to end a longstanding quarrel between the Palestinian leaders and King Hussein of Jordan.

title: Autograph Collector Gets Big 3 at Watergate Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Dozens of people have been coming to the Watergate coverup trial each day in hopes of hearing the White House tape recordings or of seeing John W. Dean 3d, the chief prosecution witness. There are only 30 or so seats for the public, so the people stand or sit in a long line in the hallway outside Judge John J. Sirica's courtroom, waiting, reading, talking.

title: EUROPEANS URGE TRADE CONTROLS
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 24The executive commission of the European Common Market has proposed that the world's chief trading partners agree on a system of controls aimed at preventing brutal ruptures in the flow of trade, especially raw materials.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Atlantic City (Steel Pier), deduct 26 min, from Sandy Hook time.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: BUSINESS LOANS OFF AT CITY BANKS
description: Business loans at major New York City banks declined $390million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. It was the largest weekly decline of the year.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Hustling on the Hustings
description: President Ford has the Democrats in a flap over his suggestion that if too many of them are elected to Congress next month, peace could be in jeopardy. But this is only a new version of the familiar Republican charge that the Democrats are the war party; it is, in fact, the least of Mr. Ford's transgressions inthe, fall campaignmost of which have been against himself.

title: Cavaliers Beat Hawks By 11697
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 24 (AP)Austin Carr scored 25 points and Bobby Smith 22 to lead the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 11697 triumph over the Atlanta Hawks tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: Harvest hedge selling put pressure on soybean and corn prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean prices for nearby delivery dropped the 20centabushel daily limit, and corn prices moved down about 4 to 7 cents a bushel.

title: Ruling Bonn Party Faces Regional Vote Loss Sunday
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 23Fears about unemployment, banking troubles and civil disorder are expected to co Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's vote in the election in the state of Hesse this Sunday.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: OAKDALE, L. I.Entering the sylvan oasis of Connetquot River State Park from overburdened Sunrise Highway shortly after 7 A.M., we slowed the car to watch seven deer, one of them a magnificent buck, grazing under the trees.

title: Forgetting You Are President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Every man who, by the accidents of life, has suddenly had to take over the terrible responsibilities of the American Presidency, has gone through a temporary period of staggering and blundering, and President Ford is no exception.

title: Miller Accused of Lying On Mental Health Plans
description: Members of a mental health task force appointed by Dr. Alan D. Miller, head of the State Department of Mental Hygiene, have accused him of lying and obfuscation in replying to five recommendations they made to him more than a month ago.

title: McAdoo, Braves Top Knicks
description: TORONTO, Oct. 24  Bob McAdoo faked left and right, drove the middle, soared overwhelmed the four Knicks who tried to guard him tonight. But the National Basketball Association's leading scorer last season was only part of the show the Buffalo Braves staged in battering the Knicks, 11191, at Maple Leaf Gardens for their third victory in four games.

title: David Oistrakh, Violinist, Dies
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 24David Oistrakh, the premier Soviet violinist, died today in a hotel here. He was 65 years old.

title: Ingersoll Going to Ecuador
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (Reuters)Robert S. Ingersoll, Deputy Secretary of State will head the United States delegation to a meeting of the Organization of American States in Quito, Ecuador, on Nov. 8, the State Department announced today. The meeting will consider ending the organization's economic sanctions against Cuba, imposed in 1964.

title: Distressed European Airlines Are Cutting Down on Services
description: PARIS, Oct. 24  Most of Europe's airlines are having dismal year, and, like the America,n carriers are scaling down services and studying other ways to economize to meet higher fuel and other costs.

title: NIXON'S SURGERY STILL UNCERTAIN
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 24Doctors have deferred surgery for former President Rich. ard M. Nixon and decided to try to prevent potentially dangerous developments from his phlebitis with another round of anticoagulation, or bloodthinning, therapy, according to a medical source connected with the case.

title: NICHOLAS ANNESE
description: Nicholas Charles Annese, chairman of the board of Yorke Shirtmakers, in Belton, S. C., died Sunday at his home there. His age was 75, and he formerly lived in Brooklyn.

title: Dominick Waging Uphill Fight in Colorado
description: DENVER, Oct. 24Seeking to overcome his poor health, his connections with the Nixon Administration and his opponent's organization, Peter H. Dominick is waging an uphill battle to retain his place in Washington as the senior Senator from Colorado.

title: MOB FIGURE SAYS HE TRACED S.L.A.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24Mickey Cohen, a onetime underworld figure who now lives in Los Angeles, said in an interview tonight that two and a half months ago he established contact with persons knowing the whereabouts of Patricia Hearst.

title: MOTOROLA READY TO ACQUIRE HUNT
description: Motorola, Inc., and the Philip A. Hunt Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that an agreement in principle had been reached for Motorola to acquire Hunt for stock valued at about $130million. Hunt Chemical, with headquarters in Palisades Park, N. J., is a leading, independent manufacturer of platemaking and photographic chemicals.

title: Ofticials Plan to Remove Hazard at Niagara Falls
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Oct. 24 (AP)State park officials have disclosed plans to destroy as a hazard part of an observation point on Goat Island, befween the American and Horseshoe Falls, at this worldfamous attraction.

title: MORE RENT AID FOR AGED BACKED
description: The Beame administration said yesterday that it supported legislation to expand significantly a program of rentrise exemptions for the elderly poor, even though the expansion could cost the already deficitridden city up to $40million a year in lost revenue in a very short time.

title: Northwest Sets Expansion
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP)Northwest Industries, Inc., said it planned to spend more than $60million to expand tubular steel production at Lone Star Steel, a Dallas subsidiary. Northwest Industries said the program, expected to end by 1976, would increase Lone Star's production of tubular steel for the oil industry by about 40 per cent.

title: Heart Study Finds No Coronary Risk In Coffee Drinking
description: The Framingham Study of coronary risk has concluded that coffee drinking does not cause heart disease.

title: Warm Tokyo Welcome Starts Met Orientation
description: TOKYO, Oct. 24It seemed a long distance to go to test Tom Seaver's hip and Joe Torre's shoulder, but the New York Mets flew into Tokyo tonight after a 21hour trip that will introduce Japan for the next four weeks to what has already become a legendary team of American baseball.

title: J. & L. Offsets Wilson
Riggins Has Shoulder Sprain
description: In these days of frustration and anguish for the Jets, good news is relative, so the Jets received good news yesterday: John Riggins does not have a separated shoulder and he should not be out for four weeks as some people previously thought.

title: BERTHOLD J. REESE
description: Berthold J. Reese, a retired commercial artist, died Wednesday at his home, 230 Central Park South.

title: Advertising
description: Some 500 PepsiCola bottlers gathered in solemn congress in San Francisco will learn today that there's a zipper in their future.

title: Palestine Debate Protest At U.N. Is Set by Jews
description: Plans to fill Dag Hammarskjold Plaza with a massive demonstration against Arab terror at noon on Nov. 4, preceding the United Nations debate on the Palestine question, were announced jointly yesterday by 33 American Jewish organizations.

title: TURKS ARE ACCUSED OF VIOLATING TRUCE
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 24The Cyprus Government charged that Turkish forces had again violated the ceasefire with a onemile advance today just south of Famagusta on the east coast.

title: Letter to City Contains Damage Report, $50
description: City officials, unlike Diogenes, have found an honest man, and the city is $50 richer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Strike at Rider College Ends

title: Notes on People
description: A passion that has long consumed Paul H. Douglas, the former Democratic Senator from Illinois, is chamber music. But the 82yearold Mr. Douglas is, in failing health, and he has been unable to get to the Library of Congress, where the Juilliard String Quartet is in residence. So Wednesday morning the Juilliard carne to Mr. Douglas in his Washington home, and he and his wife and about 25 friends listened happily as the musicians played the Beethoven Quartet No. 16 in F (Op. 135), the composer's last. The Senator particularly enjoyed the slow movement of the quartet, which is his favorite. The Juilliard visit was arranged by frends, with the help of Ann Schein, a concert pianist from New. York and the wife of Earl Carlyss, a Juilliard violinist.

title: Goldwater Now Undecided On Rockefeller Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Senator Barry Goldwater, the symbolic leader of the Republican party's conservative wing, has backed away from his unequivocal support of Nelson A. Rockefeller's VicePresidential nomination and is said by an aide now to be undecided.

title: Film: A Rueful 'Sindbad':Hungarian Import Is at Screening Room
description: Although a certain radiant obscurity permeates parts of Zoltan Huszark's "Sindbad," this Hungarian movie, made in 1970, is well worth the attention of film makers (and others) who are concerned with the use of imagery on film. "Sindbad" is playing today and tomorrow at noon and midnight at the First Avenue Screening Room.The movie explores an aging rou's memories and reveries about the women he was involved with, circa 1900. In some cases, he revisits them in personin others, in his fantasies. His old flames are grateful or reproachful or nostalgic or indignant, according to characterizations that are left deliberately vague. Two themes concur: the rueful man alternates between admiring and loathing himself, until his lack of self-respect overrides the impulse of self-congratulation; also, he confesses that "women were always good" to him just because he never pretended that he loved themalthough he occasionally scatters that message around. Throughout, there's the consciousness of death: he clings to the past because he senses the brevity of the present.The atmosphere of this movie may sound banalbut it isn't, because of the extraordinary (and very beautiful) images that pour over the screen, intensified by rapid cuts. Sap leaking from bark gives way to the faces of those remembered; a piece of raw cauliflower evokes a split lip; a red shawl stiff with ice, dragged from a river, is then seen on the shoulders of the person who drowned herself. There's a marvelous scene in a restaurant where the privileged Sindbad luxuriates in a fine meal while he both stimulates and discourages the waiter in describing his private life  a conversation that results in the discovery that both were once married to the same young woman.Actually, this movie treats food more seductively than most I've seen; perhaps intentionally, eating comes through more pungently than sex. All in all, the visual enchantments of the film outweigh the very old-fashioned romanticismwhich isn't exactly what one expects from Hungary.

title: Filly Sets Pace Mark In Earnings
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 24 Tarport Hap became the richest 2yearold pacing filly in harness racing history tonight when she won the $??4,205 Belle Acton pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: U.N. CASE ARGUED BY SOUTH AFRICAN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24South Africa, facing a drive led by black Africans to expel her from the United Nations, today declared that her race relations were changing. She appealed to the world or ganization to keep open the channels of communication to encourage further change.

title: Paper Backs Shapp
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 (AP)The Pittsburgh PostGazette endorsed Gov. Milton J. Shapp today for reelection, crediting him with leading the state out of a fiscal wilderness.

title: School Boards Grappling With Budget Uncertainty
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 24Representatives of the state's 607 school boards, facing a confused and gloomy fiscal outlook for next year, met here today to consider what Commissioner of Education Fred G. Burke described as a crisis of confidence in the state's educational system.

title: Eleanor H. Wolkind Dies; Economist for U.S. Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Eleanor Heyman Wolkind, economist, author, and builder, died Tuesday of cancer at her home in McLean, Va. She was 62 years old.

title: Austin to Visit Bahamas
description: LONDON, Oct. 24 (Reuters)Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip will visit the Bahamas next Februuary before their state visit to Mexico, Buckingham Palace announced today.

title: U.S. PANEL SHIFTS ON REARING AIDS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24A Government study group that had concluded that prescrip tions should be required to buy hearing aides eliminated that requirement in final recommendations made public todty.

title: $54Million Due for Copper Interest
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation said yesterday it had agreed to a $54million settlement for its share of the El Teniente copper mine in Chile, nationalized in 1971 by the Government of the late Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Garden State Parkway Rejects Byrne Plan for Motorcycle Trial
description: WOODBRIDGE, Oct. 24 (AP) Garden State Parkway officials said no today to a suggestion by Governor Byrne that motorcycles be allowed on the parkway for a trial period.

title: David Oistrakh, Violinist, Dies
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 24David Oistrakh, the premier Soviet violinist, died today in a hotel here. He was 65 years old.

title: Cornell Hit by Key Loss Before Facing Unbeaten Yale
description: Cornell, which faces undefeated Yale in Ithaca, N. Y., tomorrow afternoon, got some bad news yesterday. Don Fanelli, the tailback who leads the team in rushing, will sit the game out, because of a knee injury suffered in the loss to Harvard a week ago. Jack Musick, who had to be unhappy with his team's porous defense against the Crimson, now has to fret about revamping his attack for the burly Elis.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: OAKDALE, L. I.Entering the sylvan oasis of Connetquot River State Park from overburdened Sunrise Highway shortly after 7 A.M., we slowed the car to watch, seven deer, one of them a magnificent buck, grazing under the trees.

title: LEBANON TRIES AGAIN ON FORMING CABINET
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 24President Suleiman Franjieh, seeking to solve a Government crisis, today chose Rashid Solh, a political independent, as Premierdesignate to form a new Cabinet.

title: Store Sales Advance
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.08billion, up 6 per cent from last year's $1.02billion. Total retail store sales were about $10.53billion, up 7 per cent from last year's $9.81billion.

title: ATTILIO R. GRANITO
description: Attilio R. Granito, Mayor of Hackensack, N. J., from 1949 to 1953, died Wednesday in Englewood (N. J.) Hospital. He lived at 60 Edgewood Street in Tenafly, N. J.

title: Stewards Withold Drugging Penalties
description: It became official at Aqueduct yesterday. No disciplinary action is to be taken against the three trainers and four veterinarians questioned about drugging cases at the Big A last month. The track's three stewards, Francis P. Dunne, Nathaniel J. Hyland and Warren C. Mehrtens, revealed this decision after explaining no facts had developed in a thorough investigation pointing to negligence in the protection of the four horses involved.

title: F.C.C. Approves Policy on Children's TV
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Federal Communications Commission gave final approval today to a policy statement that all television stations must provide a reasonable amount of programing for children and that a significant part of it should be educational.

title: CBS Bars Ford Interview Calls Proposed Date Too Near Election
description: CBS News has turned down an opportunity to televise an exclusive interview with President Ford because the date proposed by the White Housetomorrowis too close to the November elections.

title: Calvin Jackson Indicted in 9 Murders, But Mental Status May Prevent Trial
description: Calvin Jackson was indicted yesterday in the murders of nine women who lived alone on the West Side, but it is doubtful if the 26yearold suspect will be tried on any of the charges.

title: GISCARD ASSERTS WORLD IS IN GRIP OF FISCAL CRISIS
description: PARIS, Oct. 24President Valery Giscard d'Estaing warned today that the world was in the grip of a general economic crisis and that all the curves are leading us to catastrophe.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
Equus a New Success on Broadway
description: EGUUS, a play by Peter Shaffer. Directed by John Dexter; setting and costumes by John Napier; lighting by Andy Phillips; sound by Marc Wilkinson; Mime by Claude Chagrin; American supervision of scenery and lighting by Howard Bay; costumes by Patricia Adshead; production stage manager, Robert L. Borod. Presented by Kermit Bloomgarden and Doris Cole Abrahams, in association with Frank Milton. At the Plymouth Theater, 236 West 45th Street.

title: Floods in Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 24 (Reuters)Rainswollen rivers have flooded 150 villages and left 430,000 acres of farmland under water in northern and central Yugoslavia, according to reports reaching here today.

title: Byrne Reports Agreement On Financial Disclosures
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23Governor Byrne announced today that he had the full agreement of New Jersey's six commissioners on the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to meet his request for public financial disclosures.

title: State Trooper Slain Upstate on Thruway At Roadblock Site
description: A New York State trooper was shot and killed yesterday, apparently while trying to arrest three robbery suspects on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway near the community of Canastota, east of Syracuse.

title: Gentle Musical Master
description: There had been rumors about the state of David Oistrakh's health. He was known to have had an ailing heart. Thus the news of his death was not altogether surprising. Yet it is with a pang that one realizes his noble art will no longer be heard. And musicians around the world are losing a dear friend and devoted colleague.

title: Ford Prodded on Electricity
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I, Oct. 24 (AP)Gov. Philip W. Noel said today that he would request President Ford's personal intervention in attempts to lower New England's electric ratesMr. Noel made the comment at a news conference.

title: Army Molds Elite Ranger Unit for Deployment to Trouble Spots
description: FORT STEWART, Ga. The First Ranger Battalion, a deep penetration force, is being welded into an elite unit here among the pine woods, swamps and sandy hills of the vast fort.

title: GEN. JAMES DOZIER
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 24 (UPI)Lieut. General James C. Dozier, Adjutant General of South Carolina for 33 years and former head of the United States National Guard Association, died today. He was 89 years old.

title: Francis Warren Dies at 72; Turner Construction Aide
description: Francis B. Warren, retired vice chairman and director of the Turner Construction Company, which he had served for 47 years, died Wednesday at his home in Chappaqua, N. Y. He was 72 years old.

title: Moscow's Sole UsedCar Lot Is Thriving Gray Market Tolerated by the State
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24  A cluster of prospective buyers crowded around a used blue Zhigult sedan and not one of them batted an eye when the owner announced that he was asking 10,6100 rubles ($13,300), a markup of onethird over the list price.

title: Bach Aria Group Performs Cantatas Splendidly
description: If one wonders why the Bach Aria Group after 28 years can still draw nearcapacity audiences to its annual series of three concerts, the answer is easy: the music. The care that William H. Scheide, founderdirector of the organization, lavishes on the performances has something to do with it, of course, but it remains the extraordinary riches and variety of the Bach cantata repertory that brings people back again and again.

title: Commission on Oil TakeOvers Releases Bill Data in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 24A Presidential commission charged with drawing up plans for the state takeover of Foreignowned oil companies operating in Venezuela has released an advance version of its oil nationalization bill.

title: Horse Show Event To Miss McEvoy
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP)Michele McEvoy of Summit, N.J., riding High Hopes Farm's Sundancer, won the Pennsylvania High 8 Jump competition tonight at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

title: Early Music Quartet Heard at Hunter
description: There is a healthy audience in New York for medieval and Renaissance music, and on Wednesday night a devoted segment, of it gathered at Hunter College Playhouse for a concert by the Early Music Quartet. The ensemble has performed here before, and its approach to music of the 13th to the 15th century Is familiar to people who know and care for this literature.

title: Mrs. Rockefeller Leaves Hospital, Feeling Great
description: A smiling Margaretta (Happy) Rockefeller left Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases yesterday morning on the arm of her husband, Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller, seven days after having surgery for breast cancer, and with an excellent chance that there would be no recurrence of cancer.

title: An Orchestra Was Wedged Between the Coats and the Hats
description: What an introduction to New York! said Peter Sanborn, a resident of Maui, Hawaii, as he twirled and glided on the dance floor, resplendent in a rented dinner suit and blue shirt.

title: Alleged BlackGang Chief Held in Defector's Death
description: The reputed leader of a 10member black gang that allegedly kidnapped and shook down black underworld figures was arrested yesterday on a murder charge, the police said.

title: New York Telephone Co. Reports Rise in Profits
description: The New York Telephone Company, all of whose stock is owned by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday net income of $88.9million for the quarter to Sept. 30. This compared with $69.4miillion in the same quarter a year ago.

title: NIXON'S SURGERY STILL UNCERTAIN
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 24Doctors have deferred surgery for former President Richard M. Nixon and decided to try to prevent potentially dangerous developments from his phlebitis with another round of anticoagulation, cir bloodthinning, therapy, according to a medical source connected with the case.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Curb on U.S. Waste Urged To Help World's Hungry
description: As the daily ration of rice becomes steadily smaller in several poor countries, some Americans are beginning to look at their dinner plates of steak and potatoes not with pleasure but with a trace of guilt.

title: Chess: Resumed 15th Game Drawn After One More Move Apiece
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24Anatoly Karpov and Viktor Korchnoi came into the Moscow Central Chess Club this afternoon at 4 o'clock, made one move each and called the 15th game of their final candidates match for the world championship a draw.

title: People and Business
description: Rogers C. B. Morton, Secretary of the Interior and head of the new Energy Resources Council, declared yesterday in Washington that price controls on oil would continue and endorsed a program to eqaulize the price of crude oil.

title: FACULTY AT RIDER ENDS 8DAY STRIKE
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP, Oct. 24An eightday faculty strike at Rider College, ended early today with a wage settlement that college officials say will require a tuition increase at the 110yearold institution.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: Nineyearold Barbara Bobbie Archer of Englishtown, N.J., isolated in a special hospital clean room for four months, was released from the hospital after her family and hospital employes gave a party for her. The girl lived in an 8by12 foot room at the Albany Medical Center Hospital while recovering from an operation to correct a blood disorder.

title: ALICE BLUMQART
description: Alice Jane Loomis Blumgart, who had been a social worker here for many years, died Wednesday in St. Petersburg, Fla., at the age of 80.

title: GISCARD ASSERTS WORLD IS IN GRIP OF FISCAL CRISIS
description: PARIS, Oct. 24President Valry Giscard d'Estaing warned today that the world was in the grip of a general economic crisis and that all the curves are leading us to catastrophe.

title: MURDER SUSPECT IS INDICTED ON L.I.
description: MINEOLA, Oct. 24Shortly after two of her children testified before a Nassau County grand jury, the panel indicted Joanne Brown today in the murder of a State Supreme Court law secretary.

title: Nixon White House Pay Subject to State Taxes
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP)All of Richard M. Nixon's 1974 Presidential salary will be subject to California state income tax under a law signed by Gov. Ronald Reagan last month.

title: HENRY SELL DIES; MAGAZINE EDITOR
description: Henry Blackman Sell, editor at large of Harper's Bazaar and something of a legendary figure in the worlds of publishing, society and food, died Wednesday evening at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 320 East 57th Street.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: The F.B.I. Computers
description: Wherever law enforcement is discussed seriously in this country, there are usually grave incantations about the right of. privacy and about how unthinkable the development of a national police force would be. Such views are given regular and ritualistic expression in the Department of Justice and in the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: SEIZURE OF 44 ENDS 4DAY COLLEGE SITIN
description: Fortyone students and three teachers  all Hispanicwere arrested at 4 A.M. yesterday in the registrar's office at Brooklyn College as Sheriff's deputies moved in to break up a fourday sitin.

title: Davis Cup Group May Renew Bid to Expel South Africa
description: Renewed attempts to expel South Africa from the 1975 Davis Cup tennis competition are likely to be made next month.

title: Manhattan Crawl
description: When the bus creeps laboriously through snarled traffic and past the routine obstructions of the city's continuous excavations, nothing can be done about it. But traffic is not the only cause of the Manhattan crawl; absence of traffic can slow a bus to an even more snaillike pace.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC SLUMP
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market, dropped sharp ly again yesterday for the second straight consecutive session. Traders reacted to such bearish news as declining auto sales and the characterization of the economy as being in a recession by Paul W. McCracken, a University of Michigan economist, who is a close but unofficial adviser to President Ford.

title: Music. Akiyama Group
description: Kazuyoshi Akiyama, who became music director of the American Symphony Orchestra last season, is a conductor whose talent is not unknown herd. But he was heard in a fresh context at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, when he led the recently organized New Japan Philharmonic in its New York debut. Most of its members had played under him in the Japan Philharmonic, which also continues to function following a schism that disrupted the parent organization.

title: China Lifting Secrecy on Large Industrial Projects
description: A provincial radio in northwest China announced the other day that under the guidance of Chairman Mao's proletarian revolutionary line, the first giant power plant on the Yellow River had been completed.

title: SEOUL REPORTERS DENOUNCE REGIME
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Oct. 25Reporters for South Korea's largest newspaper called off an unusual 11hour strike last night when their publisher acceded to a demand for publication of their statement denouncing Government press restrictions.

title: George Foreman and the Pol Parrot
description: N'SELE, Zaire, Oct. 24Outside, the sudden shower had stopped. Blue sky appeared between the clouds above low mountains across the Congo River that is so wide it appears to be a vast lake. Hyacinth pads moved swiftly in the current. In the dusty brownishgreen valley here where the Zaire diplomatic retreat of low cement buildings and villas is located, a warm breeze fluttered dozens of flagspale green with a yellow circle on whidh a black forearm holds a flaming torch. Music blared from outdoor loudspeakers. Inside, above the stage in the pale green and white Congressional Hall, Mobutu Sese Seko, the President of Zaire, stared down from a huge oil painting. But the Congress hasn't met lately. Its hall is where George Foreman and Muhammad Ali are training for their super combat du siecle in nearby Kinshasa that will be seen Tuesday night in United States closedcircuit TV locations.

title: Wilson Extends Sharp Attacks on Carey to TV Ads
description: Governor Wilson has extended his newly pugnacious campaign style to television and radio, where he is vigorously attacking Representative Hugh L. Carey, his Democratic opponent, in a series of commercials.

title: State Issues: Environment Poses Thorny Problems
description: Many of the environmental problems that face the next Governor of the State of New York have been made more difficult by the energy crisis and the slowdown in the economy.

title: Steelworkers to Get Raise
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 (UPI) The United Stelworkers of America announced today that about 400,000 of its members in the basic stel industry would receive a costofliving wage increase of 16 cents an hour Nov. 1. The union said that 36,300 other members employed in the can industry would receive a similar increase Nov. 15. The adjustment will be the third under threeyear contracts signed earlier this year.

title: R.A.F. Man's Book Describes Breaking Of the Nazis' Codes
description: LONDON, Oct. 23 (UPI)A book published here today by a high Royal Air Force intelligence officer describes the cracking of the Nazis' most secret codes by Allied intelligence.

title: Rockefeller Support Fell In September, Poll Finds
description: Public support for the confirmation of Nelson A. Rockefeller as Vice President dwindled during the month of September in a poll released yesterday by Louis Harris, according to United Press International. But the poll indicated that a plurality of Americans want Mr. Rockefeller confirmed.

title: About New York
description: I happen to feel that the Lesbianism issue is relatively unimportant, Betty Friedan was saying. She was picking up an old battle flag and waving it with her usual style and energy. It is possiWe to challenge Mrs. Friedan when she does this, but not many people ever do. Mrs. Friecian is Messianic.

title: CHARGES BY JURISTS DENIED BY CHILEANS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24Chile's delegation here has denounced a report on conditions in Chile made by the International Commission of Jurists and has said that the commission was repeating Soviet propaganda and grotesque lies.

title: Rites for Licata, Mafia Figure, Attended by 150 in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 Nick Licata, identified as the longtime Mafia chieftain of Los Angeles, has been entombed in Holy Cross: Mausoleum here following a funeral attended by 150 family members, friends and associates.

title: GIBSON OPPOSES CASINO GAMBLING
description: NEWARK, Oct. 24Calling the casinogambling proposal that will be on the November ballot very dangerous legislation, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson today denounced the measure and warned that lawenforcement problems would skyrocket if it was approved.

title: Henrietta Wakefield Dies; Former Contralto With Met
description: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 24Henrietta Wakefield Evans, a former contralto with the Metropolitan Opera Company, died Wednesday at a nursing home here. She was 96 years old.

title: Rally Planned On Funds For Ethnic Minority Groups
description: An organization concerned with the Jewish poor will sponsor a rally and walkathon from City Hall to Gracie Mansion at 10 A.M. next Sunday, in part to protest the uncertain future of financing of antipoverty programs for thnic groups by the Beame administration.

title: German Typhoid Spreads
description: MAINZ, West Germany, Oct. 24 (AP)Typhoid spread to the RhinelandPalatinate today and the authorities reported up to 50 cases in neighboring BadenWurttemberg.

title: Car Makers and Top Government Aides Will Meet Tuesday on Gasoline Mileage
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Administration has called a meeting next week of the Big Four automobile makers and Government officials to discuss ways of achieving President Ford's fouryear goal of a 40 per cent increase in gasoline mileage. Consumer, environmental and labor organizations have not been invited and are making their displeasure known.

title: 3 Keepers Deplore Death Rate at Zoo
description: Three young zookeepers walked past the empty sea lion pool in Prospect Park's zoo yesterday and talked about animal deaths, sickly animals and veterinarians.

title: Jets, Giants Again In Underdog Roles
description: As with last Sunday, the Jets will be bypassed by a local television station, the CBS Channel 2 outlet, which had the option of televising the soldout JetsRams game at Shea Stadium on Sunday. Channel 2 instead will go for the Cardinals  Redskins confrontation in St. Louis, starting at 2 P.M. Then Channel 4 will follow with the 49ersRaiders from tan Francisco, 4 P.M. Both the Jets and the Giants, who play Dallas at New Haven, are two touchdown underdogs. Here is a preview of all games with wonlosttied records in parentheses.

title: Army Molds Elite Ranger Unit for Deployment to Trouble Spots
description: FORT STEWART, Ga. The First Ranger Battalion, a deep penetration force, is being welded into an elite unit here among the pine woods, swamps and sandy hills of the vast fort.

title: JOSEPH WAGNER, 74, CONDUCTOR, TEACHER
description: Joseph Frederick Wagner, composer, conductor and leacher, died Oct. 12 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 74 years old.

title: BUILDERS UNITE ON LABOR POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Two national construction industry groups announced today a cooperative agreement on labor relations policymaking and invited the rest of the disunited industry to join them.

title: MITCHELL FAULTED BY SIRICA IN COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Judge John J. Sirica told the defendants, lawyers and spectators, but not the jury, at the Watergate coverup trial today that the case would never have occurred if John N. Mitchell, one of the five defendants, had said, Get them out fast, when campaign employes first presented him with plans for illegal political intelligence operations.

title: Trustee of Walston Seeking $5Million From 2 Big Banks
description: The courtappointed trustee for a bankrupt brokerage firm sued two major banks yesterday to recover more than $5million the firm paid out prior to going into bankruptcy.

title: 3 Key Corrections On Commodity Bill Are Sought by Ford
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 24 (UPI)President Ford said today he would submit legislation to a postelection session of Congress to correct his strong objections to a bill he signed yesterday strengthening regulations on the commodity futures market.

title: Ballot Sought for Mentally Retarded
description: The New Jersey Advocate has filed suit to allow 33 residents of the New Lisbon State School for the Mentally Retarded in Woodland Township, Burlington County, to vote in the Nov. 5 election.

title: Dr. Edmond Uhry Jr. Dead; Orthopedic Surgeon Was 61
description: Dr. Edmond Uhry Jr., attending orthopedic surgeon at Montefiore Hospital, died there last night of a heart attack. He was 61 years old and lived at 201 East 77th Street.

title: FULL STUDY ASKED ON PORT AGENCY
description: Moves toward a bistate inquiry into the operations and finances of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey were begun yesterday by officials and political candidates in both states.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
New YorkDetroit Rail Run To Begin Next Wednesday
description: ALBANY, Oct. 23 (UPI)Railroad passenger service linking New York City with Detroit thorn Buffalo Buffalo and Niagara Falls Will begin next Wednesday.

title: FULL STUDY ASKED ON PORT AGENCY
description: Moves toward a bistate inquiry into the operations and finances of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey were begun yesterday by officials and political candidates in both states.

title: 3 AMERICAN NAZIS CHARGED IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) Three members of the American Nazi party were arrested today on charges of attempting to incite a riot in racially troubled South Boston.

title: Speculation on a Cut in Bank Loan Level Follows Drop
description: Interest rates kept moving downward yesterday, causing speculation that the First National City Bank would lower its base rate on corporate loans today to 11 per cent.

title: Reducing the Demand for Energy
description: WASHINGTONIn October, 1973, we were hit with the Arab oil embargo and saw the first peacetime gasoline lines in America's history. Last March, Richard M. Nixon told us that the energy crisis was over. Something called Project Independence several times redefined  became the password, and our first tentative efforts towards serious energy conservation were abandoned.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct 24Two national Construction industry groups, announced today a cooperative agreement on la bor relations policymaking and invited the rest of the disunited industry to join them.

description: BASKETBALL

title: W.F.L.: Some Bright Spots
description: Things may not be as bad as they seem for the World Football League, after all, and not just because the club owners came out of a consolidation meeting Monday feeling more optimistic about the league's future than they had during the preceding month.

title: Venezuela Views Oil Wealth as Last Chance for Her Democracy
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 21There is a feeling of urgency here in the halls of Congress, the plush skyscraper offices, the noisy factories and even the tropical parks where the unemployed wait for day's work.

title: LittleNoticed Law Curbs City's NursingHome Role
description: In the closing minutes of the 1973 Legislature last June, Assembly Bill 7242A slipped to final passage without a hearing or public notice.

title: SPINAL CORD HARM ASSAYED IN STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety said today that decreasing either the number or the severity of auto accidents was the key to reducing paralyzing spinal cord injuries.

title: Religious Party to join Israeli Coalition
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 24The National Religious party voted tonight to join the Government of Premier Yitzhak Rabin.

title: Bridge: Declarer Sometimes Merits The Terrible Break He Meets
description: Enthuslasts here have their first, and perhaps last, opportunity this weekend to win regional titles in New York City in the month of October. Thelinnual Metropolitan Sectional Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association has been promoted to a regional because the usual regional in July was displaced by the national championships here.

title: Trevino Shares Japan Golf Lead
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Oct. 24 (UPI)Lee Trevino shot a threeunderpar 69 today and shared a onestroke lead with Hsieh YungYo of Taiwan and Toshiaki Sekimizu of Japan in the first round of the $133,000 Tokai international open golf tournament.

title: Gold Price Soars To FiveMonth High In Trading Abroad
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 24 (UPI) Gold soared to a fivemonth high on bullion exchanges toslay, gaining $6.50 in London and Zurich to close at $164.25 an ounce.

title: Costa Rica Denies Gans Got to Vesco
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 24 (AP)  The Costa Rican Govenment says it has found that Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, did mit smuggle guns into the country and it will therefore not deport him.

title: Libel Action Against a French Priest Turns on Issue of Who Killed Jesus
description: TROYES, France, Oct. 21Who killed Jesus, the Romans or the Jews? Two thousand years after the Crucifixion the question is being debated in civil court here.

title: CARREPAIR PLANT REJECTED BY CITY
description: Heeding the pleas of more than 100 residents of the Corona section of Queens, the Board of Estimate yesterday unanimously rejected a plan to install the city's first doityourself automobile repair facility.

title: 1,300 Democrats Dine in Heady Hopes
description: More than 1,300 Manhattan Democrats welcomed each other to Careytown last night as they savored the prospect of the first statewide Democratic victory in 20 years.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI)  The nation's reserve stock of corn on Oct. 1 was 53 million bushels greater than predicted earlier by Government experts but was still down to the lowest level in 26 years, the Agriculture Department reported today. The report estimated reserves on hand Oct. 1 from 1973 and previous crops at 481 million bushels. Oct. 1 was the official starting date for the 197475 marketing year in which the dissapointing 1974 crop will be used.

title: City Bar Unit, in Rare Act, Urges Fuchsberg's Defeat By MARY BREASTED
description: The Assodation of the Bar of the City of New York departed yesterday from its usual style of rating judicial candidates in a word or twopreferred, highly qualified, not approvedto issue a strongly worded statement criticizing Jacob Fuchsberg and urging the voters to choose from among his three opponents in the Court of Appeals race.

title: CELE H. RUBIN
description: Cele H. Rubin, secretary and board member of Tootsie Roll Industries of Chicago and the widow of William B. Rubin, former president of the company, died Wednesday, in University Hospital. She lived in the Hampshire House.

title: Panel Checks Kuh Office On '59 Loan to Morhouse
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Senate Rules Committee has consulted the New York County District Attorney's office in connection with a $49,000 loan in 1959 from Laurance S. Rockefeller to L. Judson Morhouse, then the Republican State Chairman in New York. The loan was made the year after Nelson A. Rockefeller was elected Governor.

title: G.M. Will Lay Off 6,000 at 4 Plants
description: DETROIT, Oct. 24The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would lay off 6,000 workers indefinitely at four plants making small cars, including 2,000 at the Tarrytown, N.Y., plant.

title: People in Sports
description: After transforming the Texas Rangers in one year from a lastplace team to one that finished only five games behind the Oakland A's, Billy Martin was named yesterday as the American League's manager of the year in the Associated Press poll of writers and broadcasters.

title: Wallace's Race for Governor Has Tone of a Presidential Quest
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 24  The Democratic party doesn't know what to do with me, George C. Wallace says with a smug chuckle.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HARRIET AND NORA Two of the bestknown heroines in modern drama are being provocatively reframed in a pair of Off Off Broadway revivals worth anybody's time and money. Uptown, Fridays through Sundays at 8 P. M., the West Side Community Repertory Theater (8749400; 6663521), 252 West 81st Street, has a most interesting version of Ibsen's A Doll's House at $2.50.

title: Oil Council Aide Out
description: The executive director of the National Petroleum Council, Vincent M. Brown, resigned on Oct. 7 and is under investigation by the fraud division of the District Attorney's office in Washington. Details on Page 65.

title: City and Firemen at Odds on Productivity Clauses
description: The city and the Uniformed Firefighters Association disagreed angrily yesterday over the productivity provisions of the new contract that they had agreed upon last July.

title: U.S. in Field Hockey Tie
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 (AP)  Beth Anders took pass and scored early in the first period to give the United States women's national field hockey team a 11 tie today with the Wales national touring team at Agnes Irwin School near here.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: Harvest hedge selling put pressure on soybean and corn prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean prices for nearby delivery dropped the 20centabushel daily limit, and corn prices moved down about 4 to 7 cents a bushel.

title: F.C.C. Approves Policy on Children's TV
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Federal Communications Commission gave final approval today to a policy statement that all television stations must provide a reasonable amount of programing for children and that a significant part of it should be educational.

title: Payments Are Cited for Expropriation
description: A crosssection of top metals companies showed yesterday mixed results for their September quarterly operations.

title: J. Elaine Marzullo, Teacher, Is Married
description: J. Elaine Marzullo, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Marzullo of Brooklyn Heights and Huntington, L.I. was married yesterday at noon to Patrick McCoy of New York. The civil ceremony was performed at the Municipal Building.

title: Ford Attacks Democrats For Economic Ills of U.S.
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 24President Ford, continuing his hectic schedule of campaign appearances for Republican candidates, tonight blamed the Democrat controlled Congress for the nation's economic ills.

title: CANADA TIGHTENS TIES WITH EUROPE
description: PARIS, Oct. 24Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada has been visiting Paris and Brussels this week to promote what Canadians like to call their third optiondiversification of economic and political relations to reduce Canada's dependence on the United States.

title: MITCHELL FAULTED BY SIRICA IN COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Judge John J. Sirica told the defendants, lawyers and spectators, but not the jury, at the Watergate coverup trial today that the case would never have occurred if John N. Mitchell, one of the five defendants, had said, Get them out fast, when campaign employes first presented him with plans for illegal political intelligence operations.

title: Peru Daily's Office Bombed
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 24 (Reuters) A bomb exploded in an office here owned by the daily newspaper La Prensa causing substantial damage but no injuries, the newspaper reported today. The blast last night was the second this month at the newspaper, which was expropriated recently by the Peruvian Military Government with five other dailies.

title: 2 Mills Called Polluters
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency has accused the Erving Paper Mills and Baldwinville Products of violating Federal water pollution control regulations. The companies have 30 days to correct the violations.

title: SILLS UNDERGOES PEZVIC OPERATION
description: Beverly Sills underwent surgery here yesterday for a possible malignancy in the pelvic area. She was reported in satisfactory condition last night.

title: Goldwater Now Undecided On Rockefeller Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Senator Barry Goldwater, the symbolic leader of the Republican party's conservative wing, has backed away from his unequivocal support of Nelson A. Rockefeller's VicePresidential nomination and is said by an aide now to be undecided.

title: Stockade Barbarism
description: WRIGHTSTOWN, N. J.Now that a Federal amnesty review board is in existence, its members would do well to look into related injustices in American military life.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS A FORMER EDITOR
description: A Federal grand jury indicted yesterday a former editor of Value Line Selection and Opinion, William Eric Aiken, on charges of failing to disclose he received a $15,000 bribe for writing an article recommending the purchase of Power Conversion, a stock traded on the overthecounter market.

title: Court Lets Di Salvio Keep Conservative Endorsement
description: A Federal District Court judge yesterday rejected a motion to bar the name of Louis Di Salvio from appearing on the Conservative party line in the contest for Manhattan's 62d Assembly District seat in next month's election.

title: Fords at Camp David For Weekend of Rest
description: THURMONT, Md., Oct. 25 (UPI)President Ford, accompanied by his wife, Betty, flew to the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., today, for a weekend of rest after a busy week of campaigning for Republican Congressional candidates in the Midwest.

title: G.M. Workers Take Layoff News Calmly
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 25I don't think the shock of what's happened has gotten to them yet, said Ray Calore, president of the auto workers' union local at the General Motors assembly plant here, where half the work force is scheduled to be laid off in two weeks.

title: LAWYERS CLASH OVER CARTER USE
description: Defense and prosecution lawyers in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case blamed each other yesterday for failing to comply with a court order to exchange confidential evidence before a hearing on a new trial begins.

title: ChainStore Sales Rose 11.6% In September, Best Since May
Poland Raises Wages in Coal Fields to Lure Workers to Mines
description: JASTRZEBIE, Poland  The growing interest of a petroleumfamished world in Poland's coal fields has convinced the Polish miner that he can demand and get the best, even in a somewhat threadbare Communist society.

title: MARSHALS IN BOSTON ARREST NAZI LEADER
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)The national commander of the American Nazi party was arrested today when he tried to] force his way into a Federal] courthouse. A second member of the party was arrested by the Boston police, on a traffic violation.

title: Clocks to Go Back 1 Hour Tomorrow, To Standard Time
description: Most of the country will turn clocks back one hour tomorrow at 2 A.M., returning to standard time and ending the emergency yearround daylight saving time that had been instituted as a result of the energy shortage.

title: People in Sports
description: I'm happy to be here, was a Green Bay fan even before I started football, said John Hadl yesterday on his arrival in Wisconsin as the newest member of the Packers of the National Football League.

title: British Take Tennis Cup From U. S.
description: DEESIDE, Wales, Oct. 25 (AP)Britain gained an unbeatable 40 lead in the Wightman Cup tennis competition tonight by winning a singles and a doubles match from the United States.

title: Citizens Union Rates Kuh Able, But First Choice Is Morgenthau
description: The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it had found both District Attorney Richard H. Kuh and former United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau highly qualified for Manhattan District Attorney, but preferred Mr. Morgenthau.

title: Stevens and Cooke
description: As voters go to the polls to select two associate judges for the Court of Appeals, it is useful to recall that the opinions delivered from this bench by such legal luminaries of the past as Cardozo, Pound and Lehman are still cited as the law here and in jurisdictions all over the country. Elections come and go, but the decisions of New York State's highest court affect the rights of citizens in civil and criminal cases into the long future.

title: G.M. Workers Take Layoff News Calmly
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 25I don't think the shock of what's happened has gotten to them yet, said Ray Calore, president of the auto workers' union local at the General Motors assembly plant here, where half the work force is scheduled to be laid off in two weeks.

title: Residency Law Upheld
description: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 25 (AP) A threejudge Federal panel has ruled that the state has a compelling interest to require State Senate candidates to rove seven years' residency in New Hampshire. The decision, released yesterday, rejected arguments that the residency requirement was unconstitutional. was in control. He won in his hand, ruffed a low club and

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, Oct. 25 (AP)The United States men's national volleyball team defeated China in three straight games tonight in the consolation tourney of the world volleyball championships. The scores, were 158, 157, 1511.

title: OTTAWA SEEKING TO SET OIL PRICES
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 25The Federal Government introduced legislation today giving Ottawa the power to set domestic prices for oil and natural gas.

title: West Warned in U.N. on South Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25A leader of South Africa's oldest black political movement, addressing the Security Council, warned Western powers that any nation that vetoed the resolution introduced today to expel South Africa from the, United Nations would be guilty of complicity with international criminals.

title: Sex Discrimination Linked To Communications Union
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) The Washington Human Rights Commission has tentatively decided that the Communications Workers of America must develop a plan for equal opportunity for women and minorities.

title: ESTIMATES RAISED FOR GRAIN EXPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)Agriculture Department analysts raised today their estimates orgrain exports over the coming year because they said dampened harvest prospects abroad have increased export demand.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: JACOB KURTZ DEAD; A METALLURGIST, 80
description: Jacob Kurtz, founder and chairman of the board of the Kulite Tungsten Corporation and Kulite SemiConductor Products of Ridgefield, N.J., died Thursday in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 592 North Forest Drive, Teaneck, N.J.

title: Kuh Points to Morgenthau and a Bugging
description: Richard H. Kuh, the Mullettan District Attorney, said yesterday that he had received information late in August suggesting strongly that Rober M. Morgenthau had hired a wiretapper on behalf of a client while working as a private at torney 20 years ago.

title: Business Briefs
description: AMSTERDAM, Oct. 25 (Reuters)The Netherlands cut her bank rate today by 1 percentage point from 8 per cent to 7 per cent, effective Monday. The rate has been at 8 per cent since Dec. 6, 1973.

title: Knicks Losing Knack
description: The Boston Celtics and the Knicks are teams in trouble. For Boston the problems are temporary until the return of Dave Cowens and Don Nelson, but for the Knicks they may be permanent.

title: Chess: Karpov, a Pawn to the Good, Is on Verge of 3d Triumph
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25  Anatoly Karpov stands on the verge of winning the 16th game of his final candidates match for the world championship with Viktor Korchnoi. When play broke off after 40 moves in five hours tonight, the 29yearold grandmaster held a onepawn lead that could give him his third victory in the series. Korchnoi has not won a game.

title: Houston Sets Back Cincinnati, 27 to 6
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) The University of Houston, relying on three running backs, Marshall Johnson, John Housman and Reggie Cherry, who all gained more than 100 yards, rolled to a 276 victory tonight over the University of Cincinnati.

title: JURY HEARS SIRICA SAY DEFENSE DID GOOD JOB ON DEAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 Judge John J. Sirica caused something of a furor today on the 19th day of the Watergate coverup trial with a remark about John W. Dean 3d, the prosecution's chief witness.

title: Miss Furtseva Dies
description: Yekaterina A. Furtseva, the only woman in Soviet history to become a member of the ruling inner circle of the Communist party, died in Moscow yesterday of a heart attack. Miss Furtseva was Minister of Culture from 1960 to her death. Page 34.

title: FANFANI GIVES UP ON NEW COALITION
description: ROME, Oct. 25After eleven, days of arduous negotiation, Premier  designate Amintore Fanfani tonight abandoned his attempt to reconstitute the Tian centerleft coalition.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Testimony ended yesterday in the battle over the estate of the late artist Mark Rothko in Surrogate's Court. Seven sets of lawyers had argued over the value of 800 paintings left by Rothko, one of the leading abstractexpressionists of the 20th century.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1974

title: Aide of Jewish Unit Sees Risk Of Intergroup Inflation Conflict
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25The executive head of the American Jewish Committee warned today that inflation, brought on by quadrupled Arab oil prices, could result in intensified intergroup conflict in the United States.

title: Lithuania, a Bit Subtly, Keeps Past Alive
description: VILNA, U.S.S.R., Oct. 18 In a glade near the traditional birthplace of this city stands an enigmatic modern statue of three large headsa symbol of the uneasy compromise between the Lithuanian national spirit and Soviet control over this small Baltic republic.

title: Air Force Fires ICBM Successfully From Plane
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The Air Force, in a step toward development of a strategic missile with mobility in the air and on land, has successfully testfired for the first time an Intercontinental ballistic missile dropped from an airplane, the Defense Department announced today.

title: FRANCES K. WOOD
description: Frances Kelley Wood, the widow of John C. Wood, who was chairman of Brooks Brothers at his death in 1970, died Wednesday evening, apparently of a heart attack. She was 67 years old and lived at 770 Park Avenue.

title: 2 Top Security National Aides Resign Because of Basic Policy Differences
description: Two top officers of the Security National Bank, a $1.8billion Long Island bank that published one of the poorest thirdquarter earnings reports among major banks, have resigned as officers and directors, Patrick J. Clifford, chairman, announced yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: State Issues: SchoolAid Revisions
description: A fourinchthick report on the cost and quality of education in the statea report that cost taxpayers $2millionwill be vital reading for the person who is Governor during the next four years.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Soybeans continued their sharp decline that began Tuesday, with prices once again dropping the 20centsabushel limit on the Chicago Board of Trade. With the harvest nearing completion and a large amount of soybeans heading to markets, commercial buyers generally sell futures to hedge their increasing supplies.

title: Kent State Jurors to Hear Opening Remarks Tuesda.
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 (UPI)The United States District Cous trial of eight former Ohio N??tional Guard men charged It the 1970 Kent State Univeesits killings has been adjourned uttil Tuesday when ape?? statements will be presented.

title: The Game Lasts All Week for Coach
description: A thumb flips the projector's backup switch, and the football players on the the screen hurtle silently into reverse.

title: State Starts a Plan to Augment U.S. SupplementalIncome Aid
description: Governor Wilson initiated a temporary program yesterday to meet the emergency needs of the aged, blind and disabled poor in response to their protests about the Federal Supplemental Security Income program.

title: JURYHEARSSIRICA SAY DEFENSE DID GOOD JOB ON DEAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 Judge John J. Sirica caused something of a furor today on the 19th day of the Watergate coverup trial with a remark about John W. Dean 3d, the prosecution's chief witness.

title: 2 TAKE CAMPAIGNS TO HOSTILE AREAS
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 25The principal gubernatorial candidates in Connecticut crossed in opposite directions into traditionally hostile territories today, each hoping to undermine some of the other's strength.

title: NixonComfortable Despite Side Effects of Therapy
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Opt. 25 Former President Richard M. Nixon experienced a small amount of bleeding from the gums and spent a comfortable night with a minimum of pain at Memorial Hospital Medical Center here, Mr. Nixon's doctors said today.

title: Shell Oil Seeks Buyer For Alberta Tar Sands
description: The Shell Oil Company, the American affiliate of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group announced yesterday that its wholly owned subsidiary, Shell Explorer, Ltd., was seeking a buyer for its interest in the Athabasca Tar Sands, which it shares with Shell Canada, Ltd. The tar sands are in Alberta.

title: Visit to Nixon Off
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) David Eisenhower said today that he and his wife, Julie, had decided against flying to California this weekend to visit former President Richard M. Nixon in the hospital because we're not needed urgently.

title: American Press Institute Dedicates New Headquarters in Virginia
description: RESTON, Va., Oct. 25The American Press Institute, which for 28 years has been devoted to improving the nation's daily newspapers; dedicated a new building here today in the suburbs of Washington.

title: KUH ACTS TO CURB HOLDUPS OF CABS
description: In a move to aeter crimes against taxicab drivers, District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan announced yesterday that his office would place most such crimes under its majorfelony bureau so that they could be stringently prosecuted.

title: PRICES ARE DOWN AT MORE AUCTIONS
description: Prices for contemporary art Thursday night were in dramatic retreat in a series of sales at Sotheby Parke Bernet, 980 Madison Avenue, though they were not so badly buffeted as modern and impressionist works were the night before.

title: BLACKS TELL FORD HE WEAKENS LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  A group of black civil rights leaders told President Ford in blunt language today that his recent public statement on the Boston school violence had the effect of encouraging whites to violate the law.

title: Cornell's Scoring Machine To Test Yale's Top Defense
description: For many years Dartmouth was among the nation's major leaders in defensive statistics, Now it is another Ivy League team's turn to display statistical excellence on defense. Yale leads the nation this week in, the most important defensive statistic of alldefense against scoring.

title: Nets Triumph; Erving Gets 37
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 25 The New York Nets put together their best game of the young American Basketball Association season tonight and defeated the San Antonio Spurs, 11393, before 7,167 fans at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Israel And the River Plate
