description: The cobwebs that stretch from newel post to chandelier, or from firescreen to stuffed buzzard, in the tasteful junkheap of a set that Julia. Trevelyan Oman has provided for Roy Dotrice's Brief Lives, are not the only cobwebs on stage. The flimsiest by far is Mr. Dotrice himself, who, as he crawls from behind the moldy curtains of a canopied bed, looks as though he were composed of wisps of cloud that have slipped in beneath the windowsill during the night. You could turn him endup, with his beard where his hair should be and vice versa, and not even he would know the difference. Father Time after time has expired altogether.

title: A Monument to William Sidney Mount
description: STONY BROOKAs a local boy who made good, William Sidney Mount will receive the ultimate tribute from his hometown today when the Museums at Stony Brook open a Fine Arts building devoted to the 19thcentury painter's work.

title: Redistricting Plan in Dispute
description: MINEOLA  Francis T. Purcell, Presiding Supervisor of Hempstead and vice chairman of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors, said last week that Democrats could possibly lose their representation on the board if a proposal to retain the present county government system was not approved.

title: Edwin Newman to the defense of English
description: As a TV critic, I've always looked up to Edwin Newman. Not only because at 6 feet 2 itches he is one of the tallest newsmen on the, ir. He's as tall as Howard Cosell, the other man who speaks real English on TV. But he can outspell Howard. By TV English I mean words that you can actually see as well as hear. Everybody in television news is trying to write English that you hardly notice. Real words, they fear, will take one's attention off the charismatic speaker.

title: 2 Americans Die in Crash Of Drivers Bus in the Sinai
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 26 (AP)A bus carrying a group of American scuba divers through the Sinai veered off the road and crashed today, killing two women and injuring more than 20 other persons, United States Embassy officials reported.

title: Mrs. Bona Has Son
description: A son was born Oct. 19 to Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Emil Bona of Boonton Towriship, NI:, at St. Claire's Hospital in Denville, N.J. Mrs. Bona is the former Doris Hurlbert. Mr. Bona is manager of press relations with W.R. Grace & Co. The child has been named Frederick Arthur. of the Sacred Heart here and attended Southampton College,. She was presented in 1972 at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball and at the International Debutante Ball. Her father is director of sales for the Puritan Beef Company, Inc., a wholesalemeat concern. Her mother, the former Dorothy Palmer Hines, is an author.

title: Some Tricks, Some Treats for Halloween
description: Trickortreat bags get stolen, mail boxes explode and toilet paper clings to trees till well into November. But Halloween has its advantages over other holidays: No gatherings of relatives, no gifts, no guilt, no rigmarole. It's for kids and their fun. In keeping with this spirit, I have saved the best for first: Lonzo Anderson's THE HALLOWEEN PARTY, (Scribner's, $6.95). This takes place deep in a velvetdark forest under a myriad of firegrinning jacko'lanterns. Only witches, gremlins and ogres are invited. But a human boy comes tooand he nearly lands in the stew pot, almost becoming the meal instead of a guest. But then good parties aren't necessarily safe ones. Adrienne Adams's pictures throb with movement, blaze with moonlit colors. They make one laugh and marvel and not want to look away. Yet they never overwhelm the fresh, unbelabored story.

title: Sewage Project Boon to Building Trade
description: SAYREVILLE  David J. Bardin, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, reported last week that New Jersey's $300million sewage  plant construction program not only was the largest publicworks project currently under way in the state, but also was proving a boon to the stagnating building industry. Unemployment in that trade is running at 30 to 35 per cent because of the national housing slump.

title: White People's Party Head Is Held at Boston City Hall
description: BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP)Matt Koehl, the commander of the National Socialist White People's party, was arrested today in front of City Hill on a charge of disorderly conduct.

title: Mrs. Rose Has Son
description: A son was born Oct. 6 to Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Rose at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Rose is the former Suzan P. Frank of Oceanside, L. I. Mr. Rose is an account executive with the J. Walter inomspon Company.

title: Cashing In on an Old Haunt
description: ALL HALLOW'S EVE. Windwhipped clouds scuttle across the face of the moon. A marble figure, larger than lifesize, glows eerily beside the Grecian masoleum. Across the road, candlelight flickers in the windows of the looming Victorian mansion, and strange shapes move along its empty hallways.

title: Occupational Hazards of Track Owners: Security Guards, Old Trailer Park Law
description: Owning ??ace tracks is not an easy job these days. Joe Mattioli, president of Pocono International Raceway, was looking for the key to his track's V.I.P. Lounge last weekend when a hireling of the World Series of Auto Racing Corporation, which had leased the plant, rather impolitely asked him to leave. Mattioli politely told the overzealout security guard no. Security personnel were supplied by the World Series Corporation and they did such a good job that few customers (less than 5,000) showed up for the races, which were not the kind to attract big crowds in the first place. A $15 ticket gave the spectator less than 48 minutes of racing, and that in midget and sprint cars. Mattioli, perhaps, should have known better and left.

title: Mary Goodyear, H. B. Sawyer 3d Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Goodyear of Aiken, S. C., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Coon Goodyear, to Henry B. Sawyer 3d, son of Mr. Sawyer Jr. of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Mrs. Sawyer.

title: Decision Is Expected Tuesday On Prosecution of Milk Lobbyist
description: DALLAS, Oct. 26 (UPI)A Federal appeals judge will decide Tuesday if special prosecutors can take over the case of a milk lobbyist indicted for defrauding a savings and loan company, according to United States Attorney Frank McCown.

title: Profits: True and False
description: The job of analyzing profits these days is a little like playing in the billiards game described by the Mikado on a cloth untrue, with a crooked cue and elliptical billiard balls.

title: Lost Power Being Recycled
description: JERSEY CITYA prototype power plant, tucked away in a residentialcommercial complex that is nearing completion in the heart of this city, is demonstrating that the vast amounts of energy traditionally lost in generating electricity can be almost completely recovered and put to use.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: Enough of the sophisticated nitpicking about the Hirshhorn! As a tourist who Was fortunate to be in Washington, D. C. the day of the opening, I must say that I was thrilled beyond words with the museum and most of the paintings and sculpture.

title: Klein Critics More Vocal
description: RIVERHEADThree years after he was elected with a record majority as Suffolk's first Republican Country Executive, John Van Nostrand Klein finds himself at the center of a growing controversy over the power of the County Executive's office and his own style of leadership.

title: Summit Book Sale Has Happy Ending
description: SUMMITEarly one morning last weekend, while most Summit residents slept unawares, the annual 10day invasion of book buffs began on a quiet street in the north side of town.

title: Mindy Naider Engaged
description: The engagement of Mindy Naider, to David Wertheimer, son of Mrs. Howard Werthcimer of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Mr. Wertheimer, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Naider of Rego Park, Queens. The future bride is a student at Queensboro Community College. Her fianc is a senior at the School of Engineering of the City University.

title: Hawks Trounce Leafs, 93
description: TORONTO, Oct. 26 (UPI) Dennis Hull and Stan Mikita scored two goals apiece to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 93 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

title: Nessen Strives to Banish Ziegler's Ghost
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26President Ford's new press secretary, Ron Nessen, is haunted by the ghost of Ronald. L. Ziegler.

title: Looking Toward Radical Solutions
description: This week's disclosure that new orders for durable goods plunged last month at the steepest rate in nearly seven years while at the same time consumer prices soared at a 14.4 per cent clip should jar us into taking a closer look at the President's antiinflation proposals.

title: Bridget F. McDonough Is Married
description: Bridget Friel McDonough, daughter of William Friel McDonough of Danbury, Conn., and the late Mrs. McDonough, was married yesterday afternoon in St Anne's Episcopal Church in Lincoln, Mass., to Theodore Vail Marsters. He is a son of Mrs. Katherine Stillman Marsters of New York and Theodore Newton Vail Marsters of New Haven. The Rev. Stephen Apthorp performed the ceremony.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART.

title: Jewish Wedding Pact Revived as Art Form
description: GREAT NECKA marriage contract outlining the responsibilities of the bride and groom may seem peculiarly modern. But for more than 2,000 years, observant Jewish couples the world over have been signing a k'tuba, or writ, that specified their marital roles.

title: Dave Anderson
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 26Shortly after Muhammad Ali arrived here several weeks ago, a visitor to the ivory market in this tropical city of 1.2million obtained a carved statue worth about $250 in exchange for one Ali button and two Ali shirts. But the Zairian traders have learned. No buttons, they say now. No shirts. And so Zaire continues to emerge as an African nation. At 4 o'clock here Wednesday morning, in order to display George Foreman and All at 10 o'clock Tuesday evening (New York Time), Zaire will emerge even more, or it will slightly submerge. Under an aluminum canopy in an 80,000seat soccer_ stadium, the gladiators will serve is the most expensive public relations men in the history of world government. Not far from the stadiuin, women wash clothes in a shallow stream. But each gladiator has been guaranteed $5million, by Zaire for his presence in Africa's first world heavyweight title fight. For better or worse, the nation once known as the Belgian Congo will have experieneed the boxing business. If it's an unblemishid spectacle, Zaire will profit in stature. If it's a mess, Zaire will be remembered as another victim of boxing plunderers, right up there with Shelby, Mont., and Lewiston,

title: Stacey Brown Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elbert R. Brown have made known the engagement of their daughter, Stacey Ellen Brown, to Michael D. Mathias, son of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Mathias of Jupiter, Fla.

title: HEALTH PARLEY SEEKS TO AID POOR
description: Despite attempts over the years to improve the health of the countrys poor, the gap between the haves and the have note appears to grow wider, caused by and creating a situation that may be intractable, according to evidence presented to a health conference last week.

title: Keeneland Stakes To Summer Guest
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 26 (AP)Summer Guest put a crimp in Desert Vixen's bid for handicap mare honors today when the daughter of Native Charger posted a narrow victory in the $56,850 Spinster Stakes at Keeneland.

description: Tishman Realty & Construction Co., Inc., has completed two transactions involving major midtown sites.

Tens of thousands of manufacturers, distributors, dealers, importers, exporters, and photographers gather at Photokinathe World's Fair of Photographyin 11 huge halls filled, with booth after both full of every imaginable sort of photographic apparatus and paraphernalia.

description: Strong evidence has been found that an explosive device caused the crash of a World Airlines plane off Greece on Sept. 8 in which all 88 persons on board were killed.

description: For tennis players at any level, there is probably no more intoxicating feeling than blasting a serve past an opponent for an outright ace.

title: Europe's Communists Adjust, for Power's Sake
description: PARISLenin in his day denounted the treason of the Social Democrats and broke with them because they rejected what he saw as inescapable recourse to violence and instead accepted class collaboration. What would he say today seeing the Communist parties of the Latin part of Europe set out, one after the other, on the very road he condemned?

title: 5 Cheetahs Born in Zoo
description: IRVINE, Calif., Oct. 26 (AP) Mildred the cheetah gave birth to five cubs today at Lion Country Safari. Steve Craig of the park's zoological staff said workers did not know the cubs' weights or sexes. We're afraid to go in there, he explained. Mildred's still quite nervous. Cheetah births in captivity are quite rare, another park spokesman said.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Amid growing Congressional concern, the Defense Department will spend $253million this year supporting commissary stores that sell food to military families at a substantial discount.

description: Trick or treaters might not be happy with the Halloween loot this year, but they properly should aim their brickbats at inflation.

description: THE HAGUE, Oct. 26Four armed men, including a Palestinian terrorist, took 22 persons hostage today during, an evening church service side a prison at Scheveningen, near The Hague.

title: WOMAN APPEALS IN COAST KILLING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26The prison sentence of five years to life imposed this week on Inez Garcia for killing a man she said had helped to rape her will be appealed in a move that will seek to reexamine attitude about women, rape and the Iaw.

title: Headliners
description: James Earl Ray's version of the killing of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was expected to be heard last week, but it was not. Ray, who originally pleaded guilty to the murder and is serving a 99year sentence, now wants to go on trial for the crime. He says that he was coerced into pleading guilty by his lawyers, Percy Foreman and Arthur Hanes Sr. because both of them wanted royalties from a book about the case.

description: Basketball

title: R. J. Nichols Weds Miss Merriman
description: Katharine Flint Merriman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Merriman of Woodbury, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon in Watertown, Conn., to Robert John Nichols, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Nichols of Middlebury, Conn.

title: ROSE WILDES EXCELS WITH HERMIT SONGS
description: Rose Wildes, a soprano who gave a Town Hall recital in 1969 sponsored by the New York Singing Teachers Association, has since been a valued member of the New York City Opera. Thursday night she turned recitalist again, singing in Alice Tully Hall as a result of winning the Joy in Singing award. Joy in Singing is a series of public master classes in interpretation founded and conducted by Winifred Cecil, the soprano.

title: Stanford Victor, 2018
description: PULLMAN, Wash., Oct. 26 (AP)  Stanford put its only sustained touchdown drive together, early in th efourthquarter and survive da twotouchdown Washington State rally to score a 2018 victory over the Cougars in a Pacific8 Conference game played today.

title: ART VIEW
description: THIS year marks the 100th anniversary of the first exhibition specially organized by the Impressionist painters in Paris to show their work as a group. The exhibition, mounted in the studio of the photographer Nader, was at Once a gesture of protesta protest against the conservative taste of the official Salon, which had rejected so many of their paintingsand a practical means of winning attention and possible patronage for a mode of painting then considered, if considered at all, an affront to established standards. Among the painters included in this fateful exhibitionone of the stellar events in, the history of the avantgardewere Degas, Renoir Pissarro, Cdzanne, Monet, Sisley and Morisot, and I think it can safely be said that none was a rebel either In temperament or in principle. Their historic gesture of protest was forced upon them, by the benighted practices of entrenched artistbureaucrats. It was not intrinsic to the Impressionist esthetic.

description: SAILING TOMORROW South America, West Indies, Efc. AMERICAN LIBERTY (U.S. Lines), Yokohama Dec. 9; sails from Elizabeth, N.J.

description: HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 26Harvard defeated a fumbling Dartmouth team, 1715, today before 21,350 chilled fans, the most to view a game at Memorial Field.

title: Clarkstown South Stops Nyack, 1610
description: Clarkstoivn South stopped a lastperiod scoring threat by the Nyack Indians yesterday and won, 1619. The winners (50) thus retained first place in Rockland County Public School Athletic League football.

description: GENEVA, Oct. 26 Scheduled North Atlantic airlines, disappointed that an increase in charter fares was less than they had hoped for, today abandoned a lowpriced advancepurchase plan scheduled to begin Nov. 1.

description: AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 26 (AP)  Connecticut rallied after a fumble recovery and a pass interception and then made a goalline stand in the final seconds today for a 109 Yankee Conference victory over Massachusetts.

title: DR. RODNEY YOUNG, ARCHEOLOGIST, 67
description: Dr. Rodney Stuart Young, the renowned archeologist who directed the excavations of the University of Pennsylvania Museum at Gordium, Turkey, died Friday at Chester Springs, Pa., where he lived. His age was 67.

title: Wallace Orders Crackdown on Bonds
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 26 Gov. George C. Wallace, responding to a Federal court lawsuit and investigations into alleged fraud in connection with the issuance of state industrial development bonds, issued an executive order yesterday aimed at creating greater state supervision of industries financed by public bond issues.

title: Assembly Democrats To Sift State Fiscal Woes
description: TRENTON  Facing what has been described by state officials as the worst fiscal crisis in New Jersey's history, the 66 Democrats in the State Assembly will meet here Tuesday to begin examining its dimensions.

title: Air Force Upset, 203, By Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 26Rutgers took advantage of two firsthalf fumbles by Air Force and 147 yards rushing by Curt Edward to defeat the Falcons, 203, before 18,000 spectators today.

description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 26 (Agence FrancePresse) The Ethiopian armed forces' designation, of former Emperor Haile Selassie's son, Crown Prince Asfa Wossen, as constitutional monarch was only temporary, Lieut. Gen. Aman Michael Andom, head of the provisional military government, said today.

title: Ridgewood Turns Back Paramus, 126
description: Paramus, which had upset Hackensack and Passaic Valley on consecutive weekends, failed to produce a third surprise yesterday and dropped a 126 decision to undefeated Ridgewood at Ridgewood. The victory was the fourth for Ridgewood.

title: WILFRED HENSCHEL
description: Wilfred Henschel, a consulting engineer who headed his own company at 101 Park Avenue, died Thursday at his home, 61 Broadway, Pleasantville, N. Y. He was 66 years old.

title: Book Ends
description: Hurricane. The timing of a book often determines its ultimate success or obscurity. Timing, however, is often just another word for luck. Consider Rubin (Hurricane) Carter's new book, The Sixteenth Round, which was published Oct. 16. As it happened, on Sept. 27 a story by Selwyn Raab appeared in The Times revealing that two key witnesses against Mr. Carter in a New Jersey murder trial had recanted their testimony. The conjunction of the two events  The Times story and the publication of Mr. Carter's autobiographywas the sheerest coincidence but perhaps a happy one for the book and surely for Mr. Carter, who has spent the last seven years in New Jersey penitentiaries, serving a life sentence for murders he denies he committed. We asked Mr. Carter's editor at Viking, Linda Yablonsky, what started him writing the book, and she informed us that it was that corny remark, uttered by friends, that Your life would make a good movie. Miss Yablonsky heard about the partially completed MS. from a friend of Mr. Carter's She read the 250 or so pages of typescript at a sitting and a contract for the book quickly followedthis was in January, 1972. Typing in his cell, Mr. Carter rewrote the book six times, with Miss Yablonsky working closely with himvisiting him every two weeks and spending all day. She found Mr. Carter an easy author to work with, almost too deferential in accepting criticisms. The only previous writing he had done was short story in an anthology of prisoners' writings. Asked if Rubin Carter seemed bitter man, Miss Yablonsky said no; despairing would be more like it. Once the former prizefighter, noted for his roughness in the ring, told her that after she left he often went back to his cell and cried; he also had thoughts of killing himself but thoughts of his wife and children stopped him.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Ample measures of recognition, approval and prestige were bestowed recently on the Grow More FoodFood for All coinage program sponsored internationally by the Food and Agriculture Organization (F.A.O.) of the United Nations. In a ceremony in Washington, three framed panels holding 54 of the F.A.O. coins were accepted for permanent display in the offices of the Senate Committee on Agriculture and Forestry and the House Committee on Agriculture. The presentations were made to the chairmen of the committees, Senator Herman E. Talmadge and Congressman W.R. Poage, by Mrs. Virginia Culver, president of the American Numismatic Association.

title: Thanks to WTVJ's Crusading Cameramen Floridians Are Dining in Cleaner Restaurants

I.What was to have been the second phase of a triumphant onslaught on the trout, the fresh water bass and the striped bass of Long Island, failed miserably on two successive cold and blustery days at Fresh Pond in Hither Hills State Park and nearby Big Reed Pond, but the unwitting participants in the third phase, Montauk's famed striped bass, proved highly cooperative.

Y.

title: Opera: Cav and Pag
description: John Nelson, who made his debut with the Metropolitan Opera conducting nothing less than Berlioz's monumental Les Troyens and who later conducted Carmen there, took on that popular pair of verismo works, Cavalleria Rusticana and Pagliacci, for the company Friday night. He treated the Mascagni and Leoncavallo scores with respect, giving performances that were fullblooded, sonorous and dramatic. This is not the best music in the operatic world, but Mr. Nelson found a happy middle interpretive course by neither souping it up nor overdignifying it.was Richard Tucker, acting as if his life depended on it and doing surprisingly well and singing his heart out. Even if the tenor's voice lacks the ring it once had, he sang excitingly. It was certainly one of the best performances this listener has ever heard him give.

title: Is West Point an expensive factory turning out big tin soldiers?
description: Fragging, the grudge technique perfected in the Vietnam war whereby unhappy soldiers dispose of unpopular officers by rolling hand grenades into their tents at night, seems to have surfaced in the book world. Either that, or Joseph Ellis and Robert Moore are such clumsy fellows that they pulled the pin by mistake. In any event, the men who run the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., will be picking this shrapnel out of their hide for some time.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT Multifaceted Trade Reform
description: WASHINGTONThe Trade Reform Act now before Congress is not simply a bilateral SovietAmerican treaty  it only seems that way.

description: Pamela Pardee Eldridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Munson H. Pardee of Clinton, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to James Warner Paisley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Warner Paisley of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Wickham, pastor of St. James' Episcopal Church in Clinton, at the home of the bride's parents.

Mixon during the impeachment inquiry, is banking heavily on a wellspring or personal friendships in his tailormade conservative Republican district to help him weather the strongest challenge of his 17 years in public office.

description: There is a charming and edifying small exhibition in the Mall of the Graduate Center of the City University of New York at 33 West 42d Street that affordsin New York's own throwaway fashionseveral casually related pleasures. Calls The Crystal Palace on 42d Street, 185354: A Graphic Presentation, the showi celebrates an early and shortlived landmark of the 42d Street area; the Crystal Palace burned in 1858 after a rapid slide from high hopes to economic disaster.

title: ...And How They Are Getting By Now
description: Of the seven major nonCommunist industrial nations, only two, the United States and Canada, now have significant oil production, although Britain is placing great hopes on finds off its North Sea coast. This is the crux of the energy crisis; the countries which use oil have to buy it from some one else.

When he faces the hapless Jets at Shea Stadium today, he will be making the fifth start of his career and the second for the Los Angeles Rams, who hope to be next season's defending Super Bowl champions.

title: OLIVE MIDDLETON
description: Olive Townend Middleton, an English soprano who had sung at Covent Garden under Sir Thomas Beecham principally in Mozart operas and with the Halle Orchestra in Manchester, died yesterday at the Brandywine Nursing Home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. She was 83 years old and lived at 171 West 57th Street.

title: Sculpture Tamed For Outdoors
description: There is a perplexing difference between sculpture that is made for enjoyment in a gallery or museum setting and sculpture which goes public, so to speak, intended for architectural sites or public thoroughfares. It is a difference involving something more than scale, although there are sculptors who simply scale up studio pieces for outdoor sites. Aside from the obvious demands of satisfying a business client or meeting the challenges of an architectural setting, artists who decide upon making public sculptureeven those working in an abstract mode seem obliged to adopt a different, more public stance in their works.

title: U.S. to Send Finns Vaccine
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) The United States will provide an experimental vaccine and financial support for an inoculation program to help fight an epidemic of meningitis among children in Finlan it was announced yesterday.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Those magic words in a title: connection, transfer, exchange. We know immediately where we stand before opening the book, and so it is in THE RHINEMANN EXCHANGE by Robert Ludlum (Dial, $8.95). Not the details of the plot, of course, but there has to be espionage, counterespionage, action, supermen types (even if supermen in reverse), complication of plot, doubledealing.

title: Christine DeLuca to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald De Luca of Ardsley, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Christine Ann De Luca, to Peter Lotto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lotto of Mountain Lakes, N. J.

title: A Family Captures Nature in Wood
description: VINCENTOWNThis tiny town on the edge of the Pine Barrens is home to an extraordinary family, one whose efforts and artistic talents are devoted to creating bird and flower sculptures in wood.

title: Peter De Vries: What is the thinking man's cereal? Joyce Carol Oates
description: A recent month of listening to afternoon phonein programs, a form of entertainment that could be recorded and sold under the title, L'apres midi d'un Phone, continually reminded me of how colloquial speech can give to the most ordinary rejoinder a texture that seems both comic and wise. There is something irresistible in the honk of common speech, as Eliot no doubt guessed when he planned to title his aristophanic melodrama Wanna Go Home, Baby? That he later called it Sweeney Agonistes is more an example of caution than pedantry, for after all, it's easy to be misunderstood, or suspected of triviality, if you use slang. One of De Vries's earliest pieces was an excursion into Eliot, an essay called Thurber: The Comic Prufrock (the compliment of a thoughtful essay has been extended to De Vries himself, but only in England, where his mastery of slang has been justly recognized as a mature effort to rephrase our anxieties). And from Spofford and Joe Sandwich and Al Banghart, to Jim Tickler of the present novelits title from Eliotthe shadow cast across the De Vries hero is that of an even more extroverted Sweeney.

title: Death in Burundi, and U.S. Power
description: PHILADELPHIAThe Burundi tragedy is a good example of the limitations of United States power.

title: Sedmara Rutshtein Excels at Piano
description: Everybody likes a happy ending, so there was an extra edge of pleasure at Sedmara Rutshtein's radiant success at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night. The Russian pianist, believed to be the first Jewish performing artist to be allowed to emigrate directly to the United States, rather than by way of Israel, arrived here only last April, but already she has been appointed artist in residence at Grinnell College in Iowa. If talent is any guideline, this New York debut will also mark the start of a major American career: Mrs. Rutshtein is a pianist of long experience, including 12 years on the faculty of the Leningrad Conservatory, and it was clear from the very first notes (of Bach's Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue), that she has forceful interpretive ideas and the technique to them out.

title: Garden Has Innovation For College Basketball
description: Madison Square Garden again will stage a full schedule of collegiate basketball competition this winter, but there will be innovations in the Garden's 197475 schedule.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The growing possibility that the recession and inflationary spiral would intensify weakened stock prices last week in modest trading.

title: U.S. Grand Jury Investigating Possible Theft of Union Funds
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn has begun investigat ing the finances of a 2,000 member union local of factory workers for possible embezzle ment of union funds.

title: Among Them: Transportation, Discrimination, Gambling
description: TRENTONReferendums have become the all but forgotten issues of American elections. They were originally conceived as the quintessential expression of participatory democracy, but because they are generally written in a legalese few voters can understand and usually lack the interest of the rest of the ballot, where there is much campaign hoopla, they are invariably consigned to remote corners of the voting machine and often go unnoticed and unanswered.

title: EXHOSPITAL HEAD IS GUILTY IN THEFT
description: MIAMI, Oct. 26Sanford K. Bronstein, former president of the federally financed and now bankrupt Cedars of Lebanon Hospital of Miami, has been convicted of stealing $525,000 of the hospital's funds.

title: SAIGON NEWSPAPER SAYS IT IS CLOSING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26Dai Dan Toc, one of Saigon's leading opposition newspapers, announced in its issue today that it would suspend publication indefinitely because Government confiscation of the paper had driven it into bankruptcy.

title: 2 Waterfowl Trips Slated for Nov. 23
description: FRANKLIN LAKES  The Field Committee of the New Jersey Audubon Society has scheduled two waterfowl trips on Nov. 23. They are to the Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge, near Atlantic City, and the coastal area of northern Monmouth County.

title: Morristown and Bridgewater Triumph
description: Morristown and Bridgewater East, the top teams in Morris and Somerset Counties, respectively, remained undefeated yesterday. Morristown powered to its 15th consecutive success, 34.6, at the expense of Hanover Park in East. Hanover. Bridgewater East beat South Plainfield, 28.15. Morristown scored the first time it gained possession of the ball on a 30yard run by Mickey Rayder. Sonny Holt then raced 53 yards to another touchdown on the way to a 164yard game on 21 carries. Rick Sofield made it 21.0 before halftime with a 54yard run.

title: Letter from Turkey
description: ANKARA, I wonder what most people in the Western world think about when they hear the name of Turkey? The question washed about lazily in my mind not long ago as I sunned myself on a balcony on the European shore of the Bosphorus and watched the traffic of that lovely waterway sliding to and fro between me and the hills of Asia.

title: Rockefellers Rest at Home
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 26 (AP)Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller spent a quiet weekend at his Pocantico Hills estate with his wife, Margaretta, who was released from a hopsital Thursday after breast surgery.

title: The LineUp: 1 Institution, 1 Maverick1 Spoiler?
description: The Ramsey Clark juggernaut was ready to roll. With a pained smile, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate in New York alighted from his battered Dodge van and ambled diffidently down Jamaica Avenue in Queens. He was in his usual uniforma shapeless blue suit coat, skinny tie, levi pants, argyll socks and hush puppies. A couple of eager aides handed out leaflets; they were dropping to the ground. At the rear was Mr. Clark's wife, Georgia, wearing a turquoise Mexican peasant dress. She was unselfconsciously bending down and picking up the leaflets from the sidewalk.

title: Penguins Lose, 54, to Vickers's Goal
description: Pittsburgh, Oct. 26Steve Vickers, the young opportunist wing who was named rookie of the year two seasons ago, tallied the first and last goals tonight in leading the New York Rangers to a 54 victory over the Penguins.

title: No. American Union Looks to FarOff Races
description: Leaving the remainder of 1974 to the frostbiters, the North American Yacht Racing Union is looking ahead far ahead. The schedule for the 1975 Southern Ocean Racing Circuit is set; the racing union already has received an unofficial challenge for the next America's Cup series and sailors are speculating on what the conditions will he like in the Soviet Union for the 1980 Olympic Games.

title: Feasts of a Militant Gastronome
description: Just think, writes Robert Courtine alias La Reynire, restaurant critic for Le Monde, Two meals a day for nearly forty yearstwo meals a day, never at homer!

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Columbia University is offering halfprice tickets to students from any senior, junior or community college the metropolitan area for the 62d ColumbiaCornell football game next Saturday at Baker Field. For such guests the normal $6 ticket will be reduced to $3, the same price charged to Columbia Students.

title: Springfield's Schmid Trained At Least 110 Soccer Coaches
State Rent Law Pleases No One In Yonkers
description: A tenant protection act signed into law in Albany last May authorized New York City, and Westchester, Rockland and Nassau Counties to institute new controls on rents. If city, town or village legislative bodies in those counties find a hoksing emergencya vacancy rate of 5 per cent or lessthey can, ask the state to set up county rent guidelines boards that would control rent increases under state supervision.

title: Fittipaldi Wins WreckFilled Auto Race
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 26 Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, the 27yearold world drivers' champion, beat 11 other motor racing superstars today in the accidentmarred second race of the International Race of Champions Seies at Riverside International Raceway.

title: REFORMS In U.M.W. STIR STRIKE FEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The rising likelihood of a national coal miners' strike in two weeks now appears to hinge less on the chance of a negotiation deadlock than on democratic reforms that the United Mine Workers union has adopted.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Carroll Rosenbloom, owner of the Los Angeles Rams, talking to reporters 24 hours before his quarterback, John Hadl, was traded to the Green Bay Packers: We expect John to be with us a long time.

title: The $39Million Refund
description: SAN FRANCISCOWhen a visitor first walks into the huge thirdfloor office at 45 Second Street here, he has the feeling he has come upon a mass mailing at the headquarters of a hardrunning political candidate.

title: A.T.&T. ACCORD SET WITH JEWISH UNIT
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26A cooperative effort by a major Jewish intergroup agency and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to recruit qualified Jewish personnel for management posts with the company is underway.

title: News of the Screen
description: Jane Fonda is as active in films as she is politically, with at least four projects that should keep her busy and on the move for many months. Included are a largely unheralded documentary made in Vietnam and a contemplated drama about the American Revolution, in which she would costar for the first time with her father and broper, Henry and Peter Fonda.

title: New Prosecutor Pledges Independence
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Henry S. Ruth Jr. was sworn in today as the third Watergate special prosecutor and gave assurances of continued independent work by his office.

title: Outasight, outamind
description: It is extraordinary how many things we don't talk about any more. There is Watergate, which everybody is tired of hearing about, and there is Vietnam, which everybody wants to pretend doesn't exist.

title: ?? in Canada Depict U.S. as Domineering
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 26The Americans look on our resources as being their own, the commanding general of Canada's armed forces tells his men just before a crucial battle in Exxoneration, a popular new Canadian novel. They look on us as being weakkneed, grayfaced people, and they see our country as a colony of the States.

title: Dr. J. G. Perpich Fiance Of Cathy J. Sulzberger
description: The engagement of Cathy Jean Sulzberger to Dr. Joseph George Perpich has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ochs Sulzberger of New York. Dr. Perpich is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anton R. Perpich of Hibbing, Minn.

title: Lawrence Streak Ended at 22
description: New Jersey's longest schoolboy football unbeaten streak was brought to a halt yesterday when Central Ocean, which had not won all season, defeated Lawrence, ;2420, at Lawrence. Lawrence's unbeaten skein had reached 22 games.

title: A trio of fictions
description: The Drunks

title: ENTRY COST EASED BY EAST GERMANY
description: BERLIN, Oct. 26The East German Government announced tonight that it would lower currency requirements for Western visitors crossing the Berlin wall.

title: Citizens' Croup in Connecticut Analyzes Legislators' Records
description: HARTFORDThe Connecticut Citizen Action Group made public here last week a 1,500page analysis of the voting records, legislative performance and personal finances of all 147 State Senators and Representatives running for reelection to the General Assembly.

title: Ham Radio: A World Party Line
description: There must be something very special about a hobby which has as active supporters such diverse personalities as Senator Barry Goldwater, Arthur Godfrey, King Hussein of Jordan, Gen. Curtis Le May, Astronaut Owen Garriot, and Pitcairn Island's Torn Christian, a direct descendant of Fletcher Christian of Mutiny on the Bounty fame.

title: Drug Convictions Eated
description: LANSING, Mich., Oct. 26 (UPI)xProsecutors need not submit physical evidence of marijuana for juries to convict persons of drug possession, the Michigan Court of Appeals ruled this week. The ruling was on the appeal of Victor Belleville and Edward C. Dale, two Michigan youths convicted in 1972 of marijuana possession on the testimony of two undercover informants.

title: BRITAIN'S FAIRPORT A FOLKROCK FUSION
description: Fairport Convention concerts are not for thte casual listener. For a start, there was John Faheny's solo, acousticguitar recital, almost an hour long, to open the group's Carnegie Hall concert Friday. Mr. Fahey built almost everything around British folk themesalthough he also threw in a nifty uptempo country bluesand an hour's working within this forth was a little taxing. Mr. Fahey is, however, an excellent player, with high nuance value in the folk field.

title: Learning to Love the Bus On acrossCountry Odyssey
description: LEAVING New York City on the spur of the moment, craving large expanses of sky, I embarked on a busriding binge, courtesy of Greyhound's AMERIPASS  a onemonth, $165 strip of blank tickets good for all parts of the States and Canada. Strains of California Here I Come ran through my head. They were to be gradually replaced by the score of Midnight Cowboy as blearyeyed fellow travelers and I, huddled in Greyhound depots, wondered if we'd gently die on a southbound bus while speeding through the night at a fuelconscious 55 miles per hour.

title: Ward Engravings on View
description: TENAFLYAlthough Lynd Ward is known today as an illustrator of children's books, he also has proved himself to be a more versatile artist, one capable of mature and symbolic themes.

title: Lengyel Dies at 95 in Budapest; Czarina Among His Hit Plays
description: PARIS, Oct. 26  Melchior Lengyel, the Hungarian playright, died yesterday in Budapest at the age of 95. The Hungarian Government will honor him with a state funeral next week.

title: A HEALTH PARLEY SEEKS TO AID POOR
description: Despite attempts over the years to improve the health of the country's poor, the gap between the haves and the have note appears to grow wider, caused by and creating a situation that may be intractable, according to evidence presented to a health conference last week.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Miss Cambere Sets Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ara A. Cambre of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Yvonne Susan Cambre, to Mr. Dale Lyon of Phoenix, Ariz., where he is senior vice president of the Great Western Bank and Trust Company.

title: Rockefeller, an Aggressive Taxpayer
description: WASHINGTONThe case of Nelson Rockefeller's taxes is now before the House Judiciary Committee, the Senate Rules Committee and the nation.

title: Barbara M. Simmons Engaged To James R. Eustis Jr., Lawyer
description: Barbara Michelle Simmons, an inteinal investigator with Loeb, Rhoades & Co., and James Ross Eustis Jr., a lawyer with Hawkins, Delafield & Wood, New York lawyers, will be married Dec. 8 in Lookout Mountain, Tenn.

title: A havenot world
description: Tattoo is a great big brawling book that picks up where Earl Thompson's first novel, A Garden of Sand, left off. Once again John Jack Andersenspawned out of wedlock, hungry for love and lifeis the protagonist.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Uphill

title: Three Russians Enid a Fast; Plan Another in November
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP) Two Soviet film makers and a journalist who have been denied permission to emigrate said today that they were ending a 12day hunger strike but would stage another in November.

title: Poll in News Gives Carey 59% in Race With Wilson
description: The Sunday News reported today that Representative Hugh L. Carey, the DemocraticLiberal candidate. for Governor, was ahead of Governor Wilson in its straw poll.

title: The Silver Dove
description: A few years ago in a televised interview, portions of which were reprinted in The New York Times, Vladimir Nabokov called Andrei Bely's novel Petersburg one of the four greatest masterpieces of 20thcentury prose, the others being Joyce's Ulysses, Kafka's Metamorphosis and, as he put it, the first half of Proust's fairy tale In Search of Lost Time. Those unfamiliar with Bely's name and achievement must have dismissed such a selection as either a legpull or a deliberate paradox. But Nabokov was simply stating the facts: the novel he named is indeed the most important, most influential and most perfectly realized Russian novel written in the 20th century, and its author is the man who affected the development of modern Russian prose more than any other 20thcentury figure.

title: College Program Aids Guardsmen
description: SEA GIRTMilitary education won a vote of confidence from the civilian educational community last weekend, when 105 National Guardsmen were awarded a total of more than 2,000 college credits for their military schooling and civilian work experience.

title: Alabama Routs T.C.U. for 7th in Row; Florida State Is Trounced by Auburn
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 26 (AP)Robert Fraley and Jack O'Rear, substituting at quarterback in fine style, directed fourthranked Alabama to a 413 football victory over Texas Christian today.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
New Rochelle Ends Roosevelt's Streak.
description: Roosevelt ran out of both luck and time yesterday.

title: Nebraska 73 Victor; S.M.U. Beaten, 2017
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 26 (AP)  Nebraska's cornerbacks, Ardell Johnson and Jim Burrow, made key defensive plays in the final three minutes to halt drive by Oklahoma. State and preserve a 73 victory for the ninthranked Cornhuskers in a Big Eight Conference football game today.

title: Montclair State Triumphs, 3720
description: HAMDEN, Conn., Oct. 26 Craig Hugger threw three touchdown passes to Don Mattucci today as Montclair State defeated Southern Connecticut, 3720

title: What's Doing in PUERTO RICO
description: GAMBLINGSomething new has been added to the casinosslot machines. The onearmed bandits became, legal here on Oct. 1 and now all of Puerto Rico's 16 or so casinos have them. The machines give a payoff of 80 per cent. Sixty per cent of the profit goes to the Government, which uses most of the income for scholarships for university students. Other diversions are blackjack, roulette and dice. A jacket and a tie are required of men in casinos, and women also need appropriate attire. The casinos, which can be found in the major hotels, are Govermnentsupervised and honest. The ponies run three times a week at El Comandante Racetrack, where exotic bets occasionally pay as much as $80,000. On Sundays you can bet on your favorite bird at Coliseo Gallistico, the cockfighting arena in the Isla Verde area of the town of Carolina near El San Juan and the Americana Hotel. The lottery is drawn on Wednesdays. During special drawings winnings go up to $400,000 on an $80 ticket, which is usually sold in pieces of $5 each, with winners sharing prize money. Regular lottery tickets are $40, with $2.50 pieces.

title: St. Louis Soccer Victor
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26 (UPI)Goals by Kevin Handian and John Roselin gave St. Louis University a 20 soccer victory over Clemson last night. The Bills, ranked No. 1 in the nation, scored one goal during each half to increase their wonlosttied record to 1211. Clemson is 8.2.

title: Curtis Shaw, Lawyer, Marries Barbara Lee Tiffany
description: Barbara Lee Tiffany and Curtis, Stoughton Shaw were married yesterday afternoon in the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev, Robert Edwards of Hartford. He was assisted by the Rev. Kenneth Wildrick, pastor of the church.

title: REP. MARAZITI HAD EDITOR ON PAYROLL
description: Llyod Millegan, general manager of the State Publishing Company, said yesterday that he discharged the managing editor of The Hackettstown, N. J., StarGazette on Friday, one day after he learned that the editor had also been on the payroll of Representative Joseph Maraziti, a Republican.

title: COLLEGE AID RISES FOR MIDDLE CLASS
description: College students from middleincome families have won the promise of increased scholarship help because of new governmental and collegiate policies that widen the definition of financial need.

title: HOLDUP MAN GETS $40,000 IN JEWELS
description: An armed man robbed an Indian maharani and a French viscountess of about $40,000 in jewelry as they were returning by limousine at 3 A.M. yesterday from a dance at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel and a stop at the El Morocco nightclub.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Courses for Alumni Get 100 in 1st Year At Columbia College
description: Columbia College, which has been in the business of educating undergraduates since 1754, has begun220 years laterits first serious attempt at teaching alumni.

title: LEWIS P. DOLAN
description: Lewis P. Dolan, a member of the law firm of Dolan & Dolan in Newton, N.J., former counsel for the United Milk Producers of New Jersey, who also represented insurance companies and banks, died Friday in Newton, where he lived. He was 76 years old.

title: Design Awards: Skill, But No Innovation
description: If the 18 buildings cited by the New York State Association of Architects as their 1974 award winners prove anything, they prove that there is still a place for thoughtful, skillful design, and that there are plenty of architects around who can produce it.

title: People/Business
description: The state's multimilliondollar healthcare industryand the aged residents it servesare afflicted by inflation.

title: Parrot Killed by Secrecy
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 26 (AP)Three boys who admitted breaking into a house said they had killed the owner's parrot because they feared the bird would disclose their identities, the police said. The boys, two of whom are 15 and the other, 12, said one of them had called another's name during the burglary. They said they feared that the parrot would repeat it later, so they killed it.

title: Forced Pregnancy Leave In Eighth Month Is Upheld
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 26 (UPI)A regulation requiring teachers to take unpaid maternity leave when they reach the eighth month of pregnancy does not violate their constitutional rights, a Federal District Court ruled yesterday.

title: Discovery of love
description: Love Story. Remember it? The cynicism of that title, tacked onto such a calculated little tear jerker! The real message, I think was that there are no more love stories. None of us sophisticated 20thcentury folk believe in that stuff any more (though with a regretful sigh when nobody's listening, because love stories, like fairy tales, carry powerful magic, and the human constitution craves magic as porcupines crave salt). So, the more unreal the merrier. Set it at Harvard/ Radcliffe, that prince's palace for the modern masses. And by all means knock the heroine off at the end, lest she even approach the pumpkin age of 30. So much for love, midcentury. Between the sordid reality and the saccharine fantasy lies a void where our most earnest dreams used to root.

title: Most Amtrak Rides To Cost 10% More Beginning Nov. 15
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Fares on most routes of Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, will increase an average of 10 per cent effective Nov. 15.

title: Steel Workers Get Bonus
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 (UPI) About 400,000 members of the United Steelworkers of America are receiving cash bonuses of $150 each this month from the 10 major basic steel companies, the union said Thursday. The bonuses were paid under an experimental negotiating agreement that spared the companies the expense of stockpiling steel during contract negotiations with the union earlier this year. Such stockpiling prior to a possible strike had been routine.

title: Prototype of B1 Bomber, Plagued by Inflation and Facing 2 Years of Tests, Is Rolled Out for Display
description: PALMDALE, Calif., Oct. 26The prototype of the controversial manned B1 bomberlike the taxpayers who financed it, a victim of inflationwas rolled out of its assembly hangar here today in traditional pomp and circumstance.

title: Jenkins Triumphs At National Show
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 26 (AP)Rodney Jenkins won the class blue ribbon, jumping championship and leading rider title tonight at the 29th annual Pennyslvania National horse show.

title: Nigeria Releases 21 Officers Who Fought the Government
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)Twentyone army officers who took part in the first of two Nigerian coups in 1966 or who fought with Ibo forces in the civil war were released from detention here yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Ford has agreed to meet with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, on Nov. 23 and 24 in the Vladivostock area of the Soviet Far East. The announcement came at the end of three days of talks between Mr. Brezhnev and Secretary of State Kissinger in Moscow on the limitation of strategic offensive weapons. (1:8)

title: INFANT DRUG RECALL ANNOUNCED BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday the recall of all lots of a contaminated infant drug from United States and Puerto Rican hospitals.

title: St. Louis Bridge Is Star of Princeton Art Show
description: PRINCETON  Marcel Duchamp is supposed fa have called the bridges of New York the greatest art works in America. Had the witty French artist seen the Eads Bridge in St. Louis, the subject of a current exhibition at the Princeton University Art Museum), he would have glorified it as a supreme example of its kind.

title: Jeffs Scoreless Until Fourth, Win, 146
description: Jefferson rallied for all of its 14 points in the fourth period yesterday to move one step closer to the Public Schools Athletic League Brobklyn East Division II title with a 146 victory over South Shore.

title: Pittsburgh's Scaife Gallery Opens With Ooh's, Aah's and Champagne
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26John Sweeney was wandering around the wide, whitewalled galleries sipping champagne and looking awed.

title: Mia Kiernan, an Equestrienne, Mary Conkling Married to Thomas Laughlin Plans Nuptials
description: Maria Rlanagan Kiernan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Kiernan Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas M. Laughlin of Nahant, Mass. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Laughlin of Windham, N.H.

title: Crafts Unit May Quit Trocks Site
description: PETERS VALLEY  Peters Valley Craftsmen, Inc., a nonprofit educational organization that runs an arts and crafts village here on land owned by the Federal Government, may vacate the premises on Jan. 1 if certain demands made to the National Park Service remain unmet.

title: Another Oil and Gas Discovery Is Reported Off South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26A Shell Oil Company subsidiary in South Vietnam announced today that it had struck oil and gas in its second wildcat well in the South China Sea.

title: Moonlight Sonata Of Waring Danced By Toby Armour
description: Toby Armour sustains a solo program as well as anyone and decidedly better, than most. She has her own company, but from time to time she does selections from her repertory, as well as pieces of other choreographers for which she has an affection. It is an affection sufficiently broad to include the amusing James Waring and the athletic Yvonne Rainer. She gave the first performance of Mr. Waring's Moonlight Sonata Friday evening at the Cubiculo.

title: Opera: Poetic Pelleas et Melisande
description: The New York City Opera gave the first of the season's two perfromances of Debussy's Pellas et Mlisande yesterday afternoon at the New York State Theater. It was go successful that one wishes there could be at least half a dozen more.

title: Pierce Sparks West Essex's 210 Victory
description: Eric Pierce staged a running show for unbeaten West Essex yesterday in a 21.0 victory over Boonton in North Caldwell.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: There is something fundamentally wrong in our political and economic system. This something is a tendency to promote excessive rates of money and credit growth and the inflation it produces over long stretches of time. If uncorrected, economic distortions, inefficiencies and inequities will grow worse, and a drastic lowering of living standards could set off social disturbance on a scale unparalleled for a half century.

title: Sweepstakes Lottery
description: The winning number in the special $100,000 New Jersey sweepstakes lottery, determined by the winning horse in the eighth race at Monmouth Park yesterday, was 343937. Tickets with the first five numbers matching win $10,000, those with the first four numbers matching win $1,000. Details about the race and additional winning numbers appear on Page 1 of the Sports Section.

title: Atlantic City Sculpture Stirs a Storm
description: ATLANTIC CITYBrooke Larsen views himtelf as just one more artist beleaguered by an unappreciative public.

title: I Give You My Word
description: While this informal autobiography about the career of one of the most influential women in France was still on the bestseller list, Frangoise Giroud turned around and, at age 57, launched a new career. She became France's first State Secretary on the Condition of Women, a newly created post and, to the best of my knowledge, the first of its kind in the world.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Walton
description: Priscilla Ann Walton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Walton 3d of Short Hills, N. J., and Rehoboth Beach, Del., was married yesterday afternoon to John Anthony Rizzo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ralph Rizzo of Wayland, Mass.

title: Labor's New Managers
description: WASHINGTON  When George Meany was business agent for Plumbers Local 463 in the Bronx more than 50 years ago, he said that the only thing the plumbers union leadership had to do was fight the pipefitters.

title: STAMPS
description: Little heralded and largely unknown, the American Commemorative Stamp panels are handsome and informative adjuncts of philately, especially for the collector of U.S. stamps.

title: Beame Will Seek Laws to Curb Plea Bargaining
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he would seek legislation next year to prevent plea bargaining in robberies and assaults involving guns in order to compel courts to give convicted defendants mandatory jail terms.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX rose 1.2 per cent in September to 151.9 per cent of the 1987 bake period. The index was up 12.1 per cent in 12 months. . . . General Motors will lay off 6,000 workers in four plants in the wake of lagging sales. . . . Industrywide car sales in the second 10 days of October were down 21 per cent from the yearearlier level. . . . Lynn A. Townsend, Chrysler's chairman, urged President Ford to take steps to restore consumer confidence to stimulate housing and car sales.

title: James M. Costello, 58, Dies; Member of Fencing Family
description: James M. Castelo, former assistant fencing coach at New York University, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Nassau County Medical Center, East Meadow, L.I. He was 58 years old and lived in Levittown, L.I.

title: Chamber Gives 18 Senators Zero Rating
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) The national Chamber of Commerce gave 18 Senators17 Democrats and one Republicana zero rating today, concluding that they had sided against business interests in 10 key votes.

title: Residents Are Victors In Fights On Zoning
description: Residents of two Queens neighborhoods learned last week that persistence pays off in seeking to prevent construction projects that they perceive as threats to their environment.

title: Soups With the Texture of Stews Provide OneDish Meals
description: Start with a titanic casserole. Fill it with the colorful harvest of field and vine, portions of meat and fragrant herbs. Simmer them in rich broth until the components are tender, their flavors complementing and enhancing each other.

title: SOVIET SEES REDS AIDED BY DETENTE
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25There are increasing indications that a conservative faction, of the Soviet leadership views the current political and economic, disarray in the West as a chance for Western Communists to make gains in their strength and position.

title: Clare Lewis Sets Bridal in January
description: The engagement of Clare deforest Lewis to Edgar Burgess Gardner has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Blakeslee Hall of Woodbridge, Conn., stepfather and mother of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mr. Walter Herbert Gardner of Butler, Pa.

title: Apathy and Money Impair Campaigns
description: TRENTONVoter apathy and serious moneyraising problems are plaguing most of the New Jersey Congressional campaigns, which end a week from Tuesday.

title: Even the families of some workers are endangered by occupational diseases.
description: Imagine this in your history books: In October, 1974, amid much fanfare, a evolutionary process burst upon the typewriter irndustry when a research engineer for the Teletouch Corporation finally invented the ribbonless typewriter. He found that type blocks made of the metal pantalonium could burn an imprint into specially treated paper, obviating the need for ribbons and cutting manufacturing costs by 8 per cent. The following spring, a mysterious epidemic arose throughout the country, characterized by shortness of breath, chest pains, insomnia, dizziness, and, in seven to 10 days, pulmonary failure and death. Amid the chaos, epidemiologistsmedical sleuths who trace the origin of disease outbreaksquickly found that the victims were all typists, secretaries, journalists and others who had used the new typewriters. Investigating the chemistry of the typing process, they discovered that each time a letter was seared onto paper, traces of a volatile petrochemical were released into air. Tests demonstrated that this chemical caused irreversible lung changes in laboratory animals after a lag time of several weeks, and in humans after several months. A national furor ensued, during which the officers of the typewriter company went to jail and the inventor himself was kept in protective seclusion. After a trial that dragged on for two years, the officers were all acquitted: No laws could be found regilating nonconsumable chemicals.

title: Anguish of the Hungry Is Spreading Across India
description: BANKURA, India, Oct. 22A woman feeds her emaciated child in an eerily quiet outdoor Government food kitchen. An old man, sitting on the ground, bites his knuckles and stares vacantly at the line of hungry families. A young man who holds a small boy in his arms begins to cry.

title: News of the Stage
description: Terrence McNally's 10th play, The Rit, which was presented as The Tubs for 35 performances by the Yale Repertory Theater last spring, is now Broadwaybound. It will be placed in rehearsal Nov. 11 and open here in January at a theater to be announced shortly: Roiiert Drivas will direct, and Adela Holzer is the producer. The same playwright, director and producer gave us last season's Bad Habits Off Broadway a program of two long oneacters.

title: Ford Discusses the Economy, the Presidency, Congress and Nixon
description: Over the back of his chair hung a blue Air Force One lounge jacket. The name tag said Gerald Ford. The name tag on the jacket that his predecessor wore said The President.

title: I Thought It Would Be Easy!
description: More and more women are running away from their homes to sell other people's through rain, sleet, snow and mortgage and gas crunches. Television's Maude Is doing it. So am I.L At a recent meeting of the Long Island Board of Realtors, I noticed that threequarters of the members were women.

title: Study Finds New York Drug Law Fails in Aim
description: TRENTON  A legislative study commission has coneluded that a narcotics law adopted by New York State last year has failed to significantly deter drug  related crime or force addicts to seek help.

title: Joseph Durso
description: TOKYO, Oct. 26Tom Seaver walked across the grass of Korakuen Stadium, held out his right hand to the Japanese capitalist and said: Good morning, Mr. Oh. Then the most celebrated pitcher in America and the most famous baseball player in the Orient Stood with the New York Mets, the Tokyo Giants and 50,000 fans while the Central Military Band of the Japan SelfDefense Force played The. Star Spangled Banner, and the 10th JapaneseTournament began.

title: Seton Hall's GoalLine Stand Preserves Victory Over Hofstra
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 26 Seton Hall's quarterback, Jerry Castaldo, completed two touchdown passes and Lou Racioppe ran for 160yards today as the Pirates downed Hofstra University, 1422.

title: Queens Disputes New Census
description: Federal census estimates notwithstanding, Queens has not, only kept growing hut We're on the upswing again, according to Harold L. Strauss, president of the Queens Chamber of Commerce.

title: Michael Kramer Makes Piano Debut
description: Michael Lewis Kramer's first New York recital, at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, established his credentials as a fleetfingered manipulator of the piano keyboard. The aplomb with which the young graduate of Northeastern University handled the technical challenges of such a proving ground as Schumann's Symphonic Etudes put him in the virtuoso class.

title: Coal Miners And Wage Explosion
description: In 1949, when a dizzying succession of unionenforced threeday weeks and even noday weeks in the soft coal mines had brought the national economy close to paralysis, John L. Lewis, imperious leader of the United Mine Workers, told the coal industry's top negotiators: You need men and I have all the men and they are here in the palm of my hand; and now I ask, What am I bid?

title: Our brave hunters under fire
description: The big game under fire in Cleveland Amory's new book, Man Kind?, are the hunters, trappers, furriers and private and governmental agencies that are responsible for the suffering and slaughter of hundreds of thousands of wild animals annually. The hardhitting text is an effective followup to Mr. Amory's frequent appearances on television and radio and to his newspaper and magaz.ine columns where he has become an outspoken critic of man's inhumanity to animals. As president of Fund for Animals, an organization that has brought worldwide attention to many of the controversialissues that he discusses in the book, Mr. Amory has managed to accumulate a great deal of documentation which he presents here in an admittedly biased and highly readable form, liberally salted with sarcastic humor and vivid extracts from firsthand accounts of animal destruction intended to shock and anger the reader.

title: ALEXANDER ZELIG
description: Alexander Zelig, a watch importer who was exclusive representative in this country for Sovietmade timepieces, died Thursday apparently of a cerebral hemorrhage in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 175 East 74th Street.

title: NEW. PREPARING A WELFARE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger of the Health, Education and Welfare Department is preparing to offer President Ford proposal to replace the nation's major welfare programs with a $21.6billion cash transfer plan.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Ludman of Cranston, R. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dianne Marie Ludman, to Brian Michael Asserson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Asserson of Bayside, Queens.

title: Tales of Power
description: By Carlos Castaneda. 287 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $7.95.

title: By Almost Any Standard, the Amnesty Plan Isn't Working
description: CAMP ATTERBURY, Ind.Until two months ago, this old military base, with its rows on rows of twostory frame barracks, white paint peeling from their sides like sooty tissue, belonged to a simpler time. It was built in a hurry after Pearl Harbor, served as a training center and, shortly after VJDay, was abandoned.

title: SOVIET HOLDS MAN IN SLAYING OF II
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP)Moscow police officials say they have arrested a man they accuse of being responsible for a recent series of stabbings that have taken the lives of at least 11 women.

title: DEFICIT IS SHOWN BY MET MUSEUM
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art wound up with an operating deficit of $94,000 for the fiscal year 197374, according to the museum's president, Douglas Dillon. But although the deficit exceeded the $69,000 recorded in the fiscal yaar 1973, it remained far below the levels of the three preceding fiscal years.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Mfanwy Piper's libretto to Benjamin Britten's Death in Venice, which had its Metropolitan Opera premiere on Oct. 18, is itself a tour de force. It is, incidently, conspicuously more successful than the queer script that Visconti worked up for his film on the same subject. Mrs. ??per has synthesized every element in the famous Thomas Mann novella of 1911. And she (presumably working with the composer, as she has done so may times in the pass) has gotten around the fact that the hero of the story, Gustav von Aschenbach, never speaks to his beloved. She has cast the roles of Tadzio, his friends and his family, for dancers. This is one opera where ballet is an integral part of the action.

title: Rockhounds Dig the Scene
description: FRANKLINIt costs only $1 to unearth and carry home 25 pounds of minerals from The Fluorescent Mineral Capital of the World.

title: Ominous Veto
description: In terms of substance and of constitutional practice, President Ford's veto of a littlenoticed bill concerning wildlife refuges sets an ominous precedent for his young Administration.

description: Linn Keese Ahlers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Nicholai Ahlers of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday afternoon to Lieut. Paul Robert Manley, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Manley of Fair Haven, N.J.

description: President Ford, in his first interview since moving into the Oval Office 10 weeks ago, discusses the economy, the Presidency, his last days as Vice President and his final meeting with President Nixon. Details, Page 56.

description: Thousands of gallons of Rheingold beer were poured into Brooklyn sewers last February as Pepsico, Inc., owners of the brewery, prepared to close it. But then, at the last minute, William J. Black, chairman of Chock Full O'Nuts, reached agreement with Pepsico and the unions, took over the business, reopened the brewery and saved 1,200 jobs.

description: BOSTON, Qct. 26 (UPI)Senator Edward M. Kennedy said in an copyrighted interview in The Boston Globe's Sunday issue that his conduct immediately after the 1969 incident at Cliappaquidick Island hi which a woman companion drowned was irrational and indefensible and inexcusable and inexplicable.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: BucknerMeiskle/Automatic Out
description: To the Editor: When Billy Buckner of the Dodgers, in the eighth inning of the final World Series game, with his team behind one run and nobody out, attempted to go from second to third and was thrown out, he pulled a monumental boner just as stupid as Fred Merkle's famous bonehead play when he failed to touch second base.

title: Consortium of WellOff Countries, Including Oil Producers, Increases Its Aid to Stricken Bangladesh
description: PARIS, Oct. 26Oilproducing nations have begn to show an awareness that they have responsibility to the developing countries hardest hit by the fourfold increase in oil prices.

title: Subcontinent's Leaders Face The Enemies Within
description: RAWALPINDI  Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan rarely goes to bed before 2 or 3 in the morning, and sometimes he hardly sleeps at all. He prowls his official residence, reading documents, leafing through American news magazines, writing statements, abruptly phoning foreign diplomats about food imports or arms supplies or aid.

title: Dorothy H. Jones Is Married To George Alexander Wrigley

The Rev. Harry L. Babbit performed the ceremony.
