title: The Finger in The Dike
description: President Gerald R. Ford, cast unprepared as both the leader of his country and his party when both are on hard times, played his Political role last week as an increasingly strident partisan, but it did not seem to help.

title: A personal view of Capitol Hill
description: A Personal View of America From Kennedy to Nixon to Kennedy. By Richard J. Whalen. 320 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $8.95.

title: KARPOV, KORCHNOI PLAY TO 14TH DRAW
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP)Anatoly Karpov and Viktor Korchnoi agreed to a draw in the 16th game of their worldchess challengers today after 67 moves.

title: JOHN SCHULMAN
description: John Schulman who retired recently as a lawyer specializing in copyright here, died Friday in Albuquerque, N.M., where he had moved last March. He was 79 years old.

title: No.7 for Ohio State, Michigan Elevens
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 26 (AP)Archie Griffin ran for 173 yards on 19 carries to match a National Collegiate record as topranked Ohio State crushed Northwestern, 557, in Big 10 football today.

title: Down to Earth
description: A brilliant autumn color season, such as we had this year, usually makes the woodlands glow for days as the maples, birches and poplars shed their leaves a few at a time. But when hard frosts bring down the leaves almost overnight, as happened last weekend, and when this occurs while the color is still at its peak, the whole spectacle is spread out underfoot. The trees are stripped to winter bareness, but the leaves beneath them are dancing with sunlight, the brilliance of early October brought down to earth.

title: Princeton Defeated by Quakers, 2018
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26In a struggle between unbeaten but tired teams, Penn warded off late passing thrusts by Ron Beible of Princeton for a 2018 Ivy League triumph. It was the 66th meeting between the teams since 1876 and was played before 23,317 fans at Franklin Field.

title: GALLUP PREDICTS HOUSE LANDSLIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Continued indications of what was described as an impending Democratic landslide in the Nov. 5 elections for the House of Representatives emerge front the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Newcombe Bows at Net; Ramirez Defeats Borg
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 26 (AP)Geoff Masters scored an upset in the South Pacific tennis championships today when he defeated John Newcombe, 63, 36, 62, in an allAustralian semifinal.

title: DECISION AW AITED ON NIXON SURGERY
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 26 (UPI)Richard M. Nixon's doctor should know early next week whether surgery is needed to check the flow of potentially fatal blood clots in the former President's phlebitisdamaged leg, a hospital source said today.

title: R. C. Rolfing Is Dead at 83; ExChairman of Wurlitzer
description: EVANSTON, III., Oct. 26 (AP) R. C. Rolfing, retired board chairman of the Wurlitzer Company, manufacturer of pianos, organs and jukeboxes, died Thursday. He was 83 years old.

title: At One Legion Post, a Crack In Front Against Amnesty
description: VENTURA, Calif.It is the season of the Santa Ana winds that blow hot across the inland deserts of California and spill down the coastal valleys to cities like Ventura and drive men into the cool retreats of barrooms like the dark lounge inside American Legion Post 339.

title: Mary Conklin Sets December Nuptials
description: Theron Ludlow Marsh, hoard chairman of the Midlantic Banks, Inc., and Mrs. Marsh of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Marsh's daughter, Mary Kemna Conklin, to Neil A. Upmeyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst A. Upmeyer of Clearwater, Fla.

title: BAVARIAN VOTE HELD ATEST FOR SCHMIDT
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Oct. 24More than seven million Bavarians are due to vote Sunday in a state election that is widely looked upon as a test of the public appeal of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's national leadership in a time of economic uncertainty.,

title: Bertram Tower Jr. Weds Robin Lasley
description: Robin Rose Lesley, daughter of Maj. John A. Lesley Jr., U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Lasley of Scott Air Force Base, Ill., was married yesterday to Capt. Bertram Bailey Tower Jr., U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tower of Short Hills, K. J. Captain Bailey's father is chairman of the board of ITT World Communications, Inc., a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Grambling 2613 Victor
description: GRAMBLING, La., Oct. 26 (AP)Doug Williams threw two touchdown passes and ran for one score as Grambling defeated Jackson State, 2613, today.

title: Herbs On the Windowsill
description: Let's face it, most herbs are not good house plants. They grow too rapidly. Herbs need cool temperatures and sunny windows for best results. However, with today's conserration of energy resulting in reduced temperatures, indoor herbs. may have a chance.

title: CITY OPERA VIOLETTA BY JOAN PATENAUDE
description: Joan Patenaude made her City Opera debut as Micaela in Carmen a couple of seasons ago, but only on Friday night did the Canadian soprano return to the New York State Theater, this time as Violetta in La Traviata.

title: BRIDGE
description: One of the characters in the novels of P. G. Wodehouse was in the habit of pointing out, quite correctly, that one should not confuse the impossible with the improbable. The experienced bridgeplayer should be ready to make the best of improbable situations. These can arise in various forms when the opponents commit some technical misdemeador.

title: Child Abusers Seeking Help
description: MONTCLAIR  Mrs. Jolly K., founder of Parents Anonymous, a selfhelp group of child abusers, told a meeting here last week that one to two American children were killed by their parents daily.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery cumber yesterday was:

title: K. L. Rilander to Marry Miss Weberman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ben Weberman of Kings Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Beth Weberman, to Kenneth Lawrence Rilander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Rilander of Rockville Centre, LI. A March weddmk is planned.

title: Crooke Is First in Title Run
description: Albertus Magnus High School of Rockland County captured the team title yesterday and Peter Crooke of St. Anthony's won individual honors in the Fordham University Eastern interscholastic crosscountry championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: CHESS
description: MOSCOW  It is the unglamorous lines of play that quite often are neglected, especially in those openings which branch off into early fireworks requring hairsplitting precision tactics differentiating a victory from a defeat. The theoretical analysis may cover as many as 30 moves intensively: An alternative continuation, if tranquil and positional, may, however, go all but uninvestigated.

title: Lord Rebeau Captures Monmouth Sweepstakes
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Oct. 26Favored Lord Rebeau won the $40,000 Jersey Sweepstakes Handicap today as New Jersey gambling's first mixed marriage got off to a promising start by drawing the largest crowd, of the season to Monmouth Park. The turnout, was 29,693, a solidly affirmative response to the merger of horse racing and the lottery.

title: The Sandstone Bluff That Is the Birthplace Of Graffiti in America
description: LOOMING up out, of the endless sand and sagebrush of western New Mexico some 60 miles southeast of Gallup is an abrupt bluff 200 feet high that holds some of the most fascinating old messages in America. Its ancient sandstone face displays a written record of almost every explorer, conqueror, missionary, surveyor, sourdough, pioneer and tourist who has passed this way since the first Spaniards wandered out here, under immaculate and silent blue skies cut by the sharp outline of the Zuni Mountains. Fifteen years, before the Pilgrims touched shore at Provincetown, the early colonist Don Juan de Onate in 1605 carved the first inscription of the hundreds of historic graffiti that make this great rock the birthplace of wallwriting in America.

title: Eugene Ionesco: In the light of mortality every motive looks mad
description: Ionesco has always been such a master of the banal that he has run the risk of seeming either trivial or merely satirical. In his early absurdist plays The Bald Sopranb, The Lesson or The Chairs, he pushed the polite conventionalities of middleclass life to the point of madnessmad refusals to deal with failure, danger, old age, suffering or anything else that good manners are compelled to ignore. The object of his contempt appeared to be the smug bourgeoisie, and since ridiculing the bourgeoisie is a venerable national sport, as insipid and familiar a French pastime as one _could hope to find, after a while lonesco came off as a bit of a bore himself.

title: The Nation
description: In Summary

title: Confederal Europe?
description: For the last sixteen years the wagontrain of European unity has had to move with the speed, of its slowest mule, France. Gen. Charles de Gaulle's stubborn insistence on preserving French sovereignty and independ, ence in decisionmaking was little challenged by his first successor, President Pompidou, although he did lift de Gaulle's veto on British entry into the Common Market. Now a new nonGaullist President, Valry Giscard d'Estaing, is lifting de Gaulle's veto of merged sovereignty and political union.

title: FLORINE C. CLEARY
description: Florine Christesen Cleary, a teacher of speech and remedial reading in the city schools until her retirement in the midnineteensixties, died Thursday in Great Neck, L. I., where she lived. She was 64 years old.

title: Cortland Defeated By Alfred Eleven
description: ALFRED, N. Y., Oct. 26 Running 91 plays while limiting Cortland to 56, the Alfred Saxons defeated Cortland State 190 here today to balance their season record at three victories and three defeats.

title: Other N.J. Scores
description: MERCER

title: New &Novel
description: We were bankers, muses the narrator of Morris West's latest. We washed money clean as cheesecloth; but we ourselves could never quite escape the taint that attached it. So much for morality and conscience, of which the characters have occasional, but not crippling attacks. And on with the murder, mayhem and chicanery, which Mr. West views with alarm and appreciation.

title: Angela Davis
description: When Angela Davis finally obtained access to the library in the Women's House of Detention during the long incarceration that preceded her trial, she found among the cockroaches and the literary trash a handful of books that had some meaning for herthe autobiography of W. E. B. DuBois, a book on China by Edgar Snow, a work on communism. These, she eventually realized, were the remnants of the imprisonment of Elizabeth Gurley Flynn and Claudia Jones, Communists like herself, imprisoned in the same jail under the Smith Act and also made to leave behind the books they received as inmates. Her own book is destined for the same shelves. It is meant to strengthen the next generation of prisoners, as the books left by her predecessors strengthened her.

title: TERRORISTS HERE SET OFF 5 BOMBS AT BUSINESS SITES
description: Five bombs exploded at about 3 A.M. yesterdayone in the financial district, two in Rockefeller Center and two in the corporation row on Park Avenue north of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: The Senate Races
description: Several outstanding incumbents are seeking reelection to the Senate in various parts of the country polls and other political indicators are correct, the Democrats in this category are running ahead of their opponents. Most of the tension and uncertainty involves incumbent Republicans.

title: V.A. Seeks More Medical Funds; Says Lack of Stall Limits Care
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26, (UPI) The Veterans Administration said today that a former serviceman was taking a chance by seeking emergency treatment of a Veterans Administration hospital because critical staff and shortages had adversely affected the agency's ability to offer medical care.

title: Odds on Foreman to Retain Title Rise to 31
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 26 In the most expensive and most political scenario in boxing history, George Foreman will defend the world heavyweight championship against Muhammad All here Wednesday morning at 4 o'clock. The bout will be shown live Tuesday night at 10 o'clock (New York time) at more than 200 closedcircuit. TV locations in the United States and Canada.

title: New Brunswick Seeks Racial Peace in High School
description: NEW BRUNSWICK School officials and student leaders, upset over an interracial clash in the senior high school that resulted In several injuries, are seeking to forestall any further conflicts.

title: Secrecy Veils British Intelligence Service
description: LONDON, Oct. 26The British spy, as etched in fiction, is that handsome chap who wears the right clothes, appears in the right places at the right time, carries the right weapons, drinks martinis of the right mix and never does anything wrong.

title: Elizabeth F. Anton, Plans a June Bridal
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Mark J. Anton of Short Hills, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Flower Anton, to Robert Bardwell Adelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Adelman of Westport, Conn.

title: LESLIE B. YOUNG
description: Leslie B. Young, who retired in 1967. as a member of the New York law firm of Penney & Edmonds, died Friday at his home on Sunset Hill Road, New Canaan, Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: 3 House Republicans Put on Defensive
description: Three of the most influential Republicans in the House of Representatives, men accustomed to winning reelection on a smile and a newsletter, suddenly find themselves seriously threatened by Democratic women.

title: Plainfield Upset by Linden, 29 to 15
description: Glenn Gutowski and Al McCall, taking turns at fullback, scored two touchdowns each yesterday as Linden upset previously unbeaten Plainfield, 2915, in Linden.

title: ROCKEFELLERS PAY STATE G. O. P. AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26George L. Hinman, New York States Republican national committeeman, went on the Rockefeller family payroll in 1960, less than a year after he assumed the party post, Mr. Hinman and the Rockefellers have confirmed.

title: Larry O'Brien from Mattoon Street No Final Victories By Lawrence F. O'Brien. 394 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $12.50.
description: In 1952, Joseph P. Kennedy, former ambassador, multimillionaire and legendarily formidable figure, sat across from Lawrence F. O'Brien and gave the young politician andformer saloon keeper from Springfield, Mass., some advice. Whenever you're sitting across from some important person, he said, always picture him sitting there in a suit of long red underwear. That's the way I always operated in business. I thanked him for his advice, O'Brien recalls in his book. Whenever I've had to deal with the important and the selfimportant, I've often followed it.

title: Greenwich Wins, 526, For No. 7
description: The Greenwich High School Cardinals buried Rippowam of Stamford, 526, for their seventh victory of an undefeated season.

title: $40,000 Jewel Robbery
description: An armed robber took $40,000 in jewels from an Indian maharani and a French viscountess after he forced his way into their limousine in front of 17 Sutton Place. Details, Page 38.

title: Mary Conkling Plans Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank Wheeler Conkling of Upper Nyack, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Melissa Conkling, to Peter F. Winstanley Jr. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Winstanley of Boston. The wedding is planned for Dec. 28 in Grace Episcopal Church in Nyack, N. Y.

title: Pro Transactions
description: ST. LOUIS (NL)  Called up Doug Capilla, pitcher, from Arkansas of the Texas League; Mark Covert, pitcher from Modesto of the California League, and Rudy Kinard, Infielder, Joe Lindsay, outfielder, from Tulsa of the American Association. Assigned Barry Lersch, pitcher, Jerry Devanon, infielder, and Richle Scheinbium, outfielder, to Tulsa.

title: New for the Home
description: Two new products have recently been introduced which should be of interest to readersone for doityourself handymen and handy women, and the other for doityourself home decorators.

title: Miss Quintano, Ronald Mattson Married Here
description: Franesca Alice Quintano, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene S. Quintano of New York and Tuxedo, N. Y., was married in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church here yesterday afternoon, the anniversary of her parents' wedding in the same church, to Ronald Mattson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Mattson of Rocky Point, L. I. The couple will use the surname QuintanoMattson.

title: Carey vs. Wilson And in each cornerNelson Rockefeller
description: Jimmy's is a restaurant on West 52d Street that specializes in lousy food, good drinks and better conversation, if you like better political conversation. People do say the damnedest things there. One nightit was March 18, 1973a bunch of overaged adolescents who practice or observe the political arts were there laughing about Nelson Rockefeller's latest, his attempt to resurrect Robert F. Wagner as Mayor of New York City. One guy even cracked up everyone by saying, He's already planned the next election for GovernorMalcolm Wilson against Hugh Carey.

title: I.R.S. LIMITS FEES IN LAWFIRM CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26The Internal Revenue Service has issued private rulings to two Californiabased public interest law firms that could have a significant impact on the longterm viability of such firms.

title: MEETING OF FORD AND BEND SET FOR VLADIVOSTOK
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26  President Ford will meet with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, on Nov. 23 and 24 In the Vladivostok area of the Soviet Far East, the two governments announced today.

title: Elis Triumph, 273, for Fifth in Row
description: ITHACA, N.Y. Oct. 26Rudy Green, Yale's senior halfback from Fort Worth, scored two touchdowns today while running for 101 yards as the Elis defeated Cornell, 273, before a disappointed Homecoming Day crowd of 17,000 at Schoellkopf Field.

title: Two Suspects, 18 and 14, Held In Slaying of Bronx Woman, 65
description: Two teenagers, one 18 and the other 14, were arrested in connection with the knife slaying of a 65yearold Bronx woman in her apartment last Friday, the police said yesterday.

title: Shady doings
description: ACROSS

title: Oas Area Named For Nixon
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 26 (AP)A new South Louisiana natural gas area has been named after Richard Milhous Nixon, according to an independent oil operator. T. J. McIntyre of Houston said Thursday that he had named the area after Mr. Nixon in recognition of his Vietnam peace negotiations, ending the draft, avoiding a confrontation in the Middle East, negotiating a ??peace settlement in the Middle East, and negotiating trade agreements with the Soviet Union and China.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Pain is the feature
description: Among the many branches of literature is one that gives information and excitement, but never pain. No matter who dies or leaves, no matter how cruel an event may dominate it, such a work involves the reader in ingenuity more than humanity, in relief more than suffering. We read about people we believe in when we read A. Conan Doyle or O. Henry or John Collier or Roald Dahl, but what happens is more important than to whom. External atmosphere is more important than internal. Revelation is intellectual or mechanical, the surprises are not human mysteries. Extreme limits are imposed on our knowledge of the characters. The literature is for fun, its discomforts comforting.

title: Film/My admiration for Joe Levine as a picker of movies may not be great, but I do admire the boldness of his frontal assault on the critics. (Vincent Canby)
description: Whenever the itchyfingered ad men perform some particularly questionable act of lifting a quote out of the context of the original review, a colleague of mine and I are given to playing a game that is, for a few minutes, anyway, most revivifying. We compete to come up with the kind of quote that would be so hyperbolical that no distributor would be able to resist using it in his ads, no matter how inappropriate it might be to the film. For some years now my colleague has been hoping for a truly dreadful film version of Coriolanus, which he could then describe as an avalanche of hilarity!

title: North Babylon gowns Lindenhurst, 86
description: Rich Fryer returned the secondhalf kickoff 85 yards for a touchdown yesterday and John McShane passed to Wes Louis for the conversion as North Babylon, the AAA Conference champion, beat. Lindenhurst, 86, for its 13th straight victory.

title: Ford, Moscow and Peking
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The relations between the United States and both the Soviet Union and China have changed in subtle ways since President Ford moved into the White House.

title: How Rail Bond Plan Woald Affect Long Island
description: Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island have been allocated a quarter of the funds from the proposed $250million rail preservation bond issue to be decided on by the voters Nov. 5.

title: Dining Out in Jersey.
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishmerits. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: 3 Men in an Aegean Boat
description: PARISThe most urgent task Henry Kissinger has set himself on his current diplomatic foray is moving the Cyprus crisis along the path to peaceful settlement, thereby healing serious breach in NATO. The undertaking's magnitude may not compare with the ultimate goals sought in continued talks with Russia; but the immediate dangers of failure are great.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A great blue heron that apparently became disoriented at the onset of its migration from the Bronx River alighted yesterday on a sidewalk in the Fordham section of the Bronx and was captured after a brief chase by the police, who then took it to the Bronx Zoo.

title: Linda Benson Married To William. Adamek
description: Linda Joy Benson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Benson of Fair Haven, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to William Alan Adamek. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Adamek of San Antonio, Tex.

title: Missing Tracks Block Amtrak Upstate
description: RENSSELAER, N. Y.  More than a year ago, railroad workers tore up a 12mile stretch of tracks just south of here that both the Penn Central Railroad and Amtrak (the national passenger corporation) said was no longer needed.

title: Giants Face Cowboys At a Bad Time of Year
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 26Each year about this time, the Dallas Cowboys are pictured as heading or their last roundup. Somehow, they always seem to drift back to the ranch and the National Football League playoffs.

title: City Council Schedules 2 Committee,Hearings
description: City Council committees have scheduled two meetings this week, both open to the public.

title: The President May Try Something Else if WIN Doesn't
description: WASHINGTONIf President Ford abandons his minimal, slowspeedahead economic policy and instead adopts a tougher, and perhaps mandatory, program for combating inflation and recession, what steps is he likely to take?

title: Army Sets Back Holy Cross On Late Field Goal, 13 to 10
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 26Until the final seconds today, Homecoming Day at this fortress on the Hudson was simply and excuse to do some tailgatedrinking.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Plays with so much as half an idea hidden in their backstage pockets can prove treacherously elusive, even to the actors playing them, even to the writers writing them.

title: SPAIN PRESCRIBES A MILD AUSTERITY
description: MADRID, Oct 26A worried Spanish public learned today that it would have to face only mild austerity and only a slight economic slowdown despite the world fiscal crisis.

title: Men whose fortunes glittered
description: There is a sort of poetry in lists. We can scan a simple list of Spanish kings or Met third basemen, making our ccmparative value judgments as we go, and emerge, perhaps, with a better understanding of the monarchy or the game. Robert Sobel's latest book is such a compilation; a series of biographical essays about businessmen whose fortunes glittered almost as brightly as those of Carnegie, Rockefeller or Morgan but who only rarely caught the eye of serious biographers.

title: Columbia's Lions Finally Roar
description: Tired of having their tails twisted unmercifully over the last two seasons, the Columbia Lions clawed androared their way to a 3833 victory over Bucknell yesterday at Baker Field, endingan 11game losing streak that was the equal of the longest in Columbia history.

title: Ideas &Trends Education, Security, Health
description: The Poor Get Poorer Health Care

title: David Collins Plays Ives Violin Sonatas
description: There were doubtlessly many concerts in tribute to Charles Ives on his 100th birthday last Sunday. Among the best possibly was the one devoted to the composers four violin sonatas played in Carnegie Recital Hall that night by David Edward Collins. Mr. Collins is a formidable technician, as one must be to tackle these works, and he had two excellent accompanists to shire the equally demanding piano assignments, Russell Riepe in Nos. 1 and 2 and John Gates in Nos. 3 and 4.

title: Rockefeller Assists Art Benefit on L.I.
description: MANHASSETTwo pieces from Vice  President designate Nelson A. Rockefeller's private art collection are to be among the highlights of an elaborate fundraising event in Brookville in midDecember.

title: MARJORIE B. WALZ
description: Marjorie Blackman Walz, who in the nineteentwenties and early thirties was one of the earliest buyers of high fashion at the Paris couture showings, died Friday in Englewood (N. J.) Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived in Englewood.

title: 3 Dairy Coops Step Up Political Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)The three big dairy cooperatives, which had trouble giving political money away earlier this year, have donated $90,105 to candidates and political committees since Sept. 1.

title: Lawyers Appeal Limit on Fees
description: TRENTON  Two years ago, Joseph Weintraub, then Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court, was hooted and jeered by several hundred lawyers when he told them that they would have to accept limits on the fees they receive in contingency cases.

title: Home Clinic
description: In order to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, most of the Home Improvement column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of these letters pose questions that are similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not be published here. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, N. Y. 10036.

title: TV VIEW
description: Should there be a tribute to American dance series on television? And if so, how? These questions were explored with some curious twists at a daylong seminar a week ago last Friday. The explorations were being made, of course, for public TV. With the possible exception of a guest slot for Rudolf Nureyev or some other superstar, commercial prime time wouldn't touch dance with a 10foot barre. Dance may be booming in this country, but as far as commercial television executives are concerned, it's stilt a minority bauble.

title: Kansas State Victim of Ground Assault
description: NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 26 (AP)Joe Washington's swift running and Steve Davis's poised performance at quarterback led secondranked Oklahoma to a smashing, 630 victory over Kansas State today in a Big Eight game.

title: BLACKS' CENTER IS HISTORIC SIT??
description: FROGMORE, S.C., Oct. 26I 1862, two Philadelphia women arrived in the midst of Union occupied Saint Helena Island 30 miles northeast of Savannah Ga., to establish a school for newly freed slaves.

title: C. P. Snow: Like Chinese water torture, the persistent drip of platitudes
description: C. P. Snow is one of the best contemporary practitioners of Late Victorian Humdrum, that style in which an allknowing but coy narrator (larding his omniscience with perhaps and maybe) sluggishly unfolds a story patched together from conventional plot elements and occurring to conventional charactersa narrative repeatedly interrupted, as if by commercials, while the author informs us of facts he has not troubled to work into the action, meanings he does not trust us to perceive, details we could do without, and literature's equivalent of the Chinese water torture, a persistent drip of ponderous platitudes:

title: Acrostic puzzle

description: Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Nelson Page Johns of Richmond, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeanne Cordier Johns, to Vernon Anthony Andrew Cassin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cassin of Athens, where his father is president of Icon Consultants, Inc.

description: The winning number in the special $100,000 New Jersey sweepstakes lottery, determined by the winning horse in the eighth race at Monmouth Park yesterday, was 343937. Tickets with the first five numbers matching win $10,000, those with the first four numbers matching win $1,000. Details about the race and additional winning numbers appear on Page 1 of the Sports Section.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Nahm of Suffern, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Nahm, to Karl F. Schneider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Caspar C. Schneider Jr. of Emerson Hill, S. I.

title: A Leading Scientist Lauds Fossil Find In Ethiopian Valley
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 26 (AP)  A prominent Kenyan anthropologist said today that the discovery in Ethiopia of what are thought to be the world's oldest human fossils adds weight to theories that man existed in Africa as long as five million years ago.

title: Christine Barth to Marry Nov. 16
description: Christine. Anne Barth and David Arthur Sylvester, psychiatric aides at the Institute of Living, a psychiatric hospital in Hartford, will be married Nov. 16 in the Grace United Methodist Church i,n Baltimore.

title: Redskins Hoping to End Cards' Streak Today
description: The city of St. Louis is bracing itself for an air raid today.

title: Strike at Borax Plant Ended
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Oct. 26 (Reuters)A 132day strike at the United States borax and chemical plant, which was marked by rioting, arson and bombings, ended yesterday as members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union voted to accept a 25 per cent raise spread over three years.

title: Editors' Choice
description: LOOK AT THE HARLEQUINS! by Vladimir Nabokov. (McGrawHill, $7.95.) Anagrams, obscure literary allusions, brilliant word play bejewel the story of a novelist named Vadim, Nabokovian alter ego.

title: Notes. A Threat to A.A.A.'s Driver Alert
description: Since the early ninteensixties, the American Automobile Association has been alerting its members and the motoring public to sites across the country where they are likely to encounter stricter than usual trafficlaw enforcement.

title: Youth Gains 608 Yards
description: ELKINS, Ark., Oct. 26. (UPI)John Bunch of Elkins High School set a national schoolboy record when he rushed for 608 yards last night. Bunch, a halfback, carried the ball 38 times and scored five touchdowns in a 740 victory over Winslow.

title: Arturo H. PeraltaRamos 3d Is the Fianc of Lee Gamble
description: The engagement of Claire Lee Gamble to Arturo H. PeraltaRamos 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. J. Carr Gamble Jr. of St. Louis, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. PeraltaRamos Jr. of New York and Mrs. William E. Weiss of Mill Neck, L. I.

title: Golden Retriever Takes Top Queensboro Award
description: Coming to New York has proved rather profitable for a golden retriever, Ch. Cummings Gold Rush Charlie, owned by Mrs. Robert V. Clark Jr. and L. C. Johnson of Middleburg, Va.

description: George Fraley stepped out of relative obscurity among Nassau County running backs by scoring five touchdowns while leading Calhoun over Herricks yesterday, 426, in a Conference III game.

title: State Opens Hearings On APlant In Suffolk
description: RIVERHEAD  Speakers from as far away as long Beach came here last Wednesday to oppose the Long Island Lighting Company's two proposed 1,150megawatt, $1.55billion nuclear power plants at Jamesport. They spoke at the opening of the first state Public Service Commission siting and environmental hearing on a nuclear power installation.

title: Miami Falls, 38 to 7, to Irish, Clements
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind, Oct. 26 (AP)Tom Clements engineered five firsthalf scoring drives and Notre Dame routed highly regarded Mi aini of Florida, 387, today for its sixth victory in seven games.

description: Morris (Moe) Lewis, entertainment director of the Stardust Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., died yesterday in Las Vegas, where he lived. He was 65 years old.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: In the record industry there is an unwritten rule of thumb, a tenet or forecast, stating that the average career of a straight (nonrock) pop star lasts seven years. Seven years with gold peaks and greenback valleys, and then, when the hit seasons subside and the returns outnumber the sales, the contract options expire, the studio doors close and eventually the catalogue cutout lists are issued.

title: Nevada Madam Seeks Place. In a Different Type of House
description: LIDA JUNCTION, Nev., Oct. 26  Some of Beverly Harrell's friends are concerned that she is going to ruin her reputation.

title: MEN'S WEAR
description: The most talkedabout, writtenabout, sketched, photographed and analyzed category of men's clothing these days is the leisure suit. Essentially this is a casual suit for wearing almost anywhere but in the office or on formal occasionsand, for the very casual man, perhaps in the office and on formal occasions, too.

title: Parkway Steps Up Policing
description: WOODBRIDGEThe special task force of state troopers that operates in unmarked cars on the Garden State Parkway issued 3,126 summonses in the year ended May 31, and 3,042 of those were for hazardous violations.

description: This Week:

title: 2 Seized as Ringleaders Of L.I. Gambling Operations
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 26 (AP) The alleged ringleaders of two bookmaking operations said to have taken a total of $30million a year in sports bets were arrested today.

title: Democrat Leads in Kentucky Senate Race
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 25Kentucky's bitterly fought campaign for the United States Senate went into its final days this week with most political observers predicting that Wendell H. Ford, the popular Democratic Governor, would unseat Marlow W. Cook, the incumbent Republican.

title: Japanese Reveal Oral P act On U.S. AtomArms Entry
description: TOKYO, Oct. 26Authoritative Japanese sources have revealed that a secret agreement permitting the United States to move nuclear arms through Japan was concluded without a Japanese text so that it could be denied in this nuclearsensitive nation.

title: Elizabeth Tysen Bride of F. S. Abbott Jr.
description: The chapel of St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Elizabeth Lorenza Tysen and Frank Shepard Abbott Jr. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Paul McKenna, after which there was a reception at the home of Mrs. John C. Tysen, the bride's mother.

title: Letters: Playboy of The Western World
description: To the Editor: While Daniel Rolfs is replaced by Ricardo in The Man I Travel With Is Not at All Like My Husband (Travel Section, Oct. 13), my husband becomes a multilingual, extravagant insomniac. Like Mary Jane Rolfs's spouse, he undergoes a complete transformation as soon as we embark on vacation.

title: Nonsmokers Seek Rights
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP)Some 300 persons have petitioned the Illinois Pollution Control Board to adopt a nonsmoker's bill of rights. They contend the board has the power to regulate indoor as well as outdoor environment and want elimination of smoking in stores, restaurants, theaters. libraries, museums, hospitals, government buildings, public. elevators and public transportation.

title: Food
description: In the days when quenelles de brochet were a rarity outside of grande luxe restaurants, Claude Terrail, patron of Paris's celebrated Tour d'Argent, paid a visit to Manhattan. On two successive evenings he was served quenelles in fine homes on Fifth Avenue. On the third he was taken to the late Henri Soul's famous Pavillon Restaurant. Extending a menu, Martin Decre, the maitre d'hotel, whispered, M. Terrail, I recommend quenelles. Terrail looked up. Tell me, Martin, he said, are quenelles beginning to replace hamburgers in America? Terrail's previous dinners, it seems, had been catered by Le Pavilion's kitchen. Quenelles (kuhnell) are made with a forcemeat of fish or seafood and make elegant first courses.

title: Democrats Again Promise To Reform the Legislature
description: The Democratic party reaffirmed yesterday its pledges of past campaigns to make sweeping reforms in the State Legislature, including opening up its workings to greater public scrutiny and giving legislators greater powers to challenge actions by the Governor.

title: Bankers Girding Up for Gold
description: HONOLULUBankers are eagerly preparing to play a role in what one of them describes as the 1975 gold rush.

title: Miss Metzner Wed To Henry Faulkner
description: Elisabeth Lillian Metzner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Metzner of Wilmington, Del., was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday morning to Henry Belin Faulkner, son of Dr. and Mrs. James Morison Faulkner of Brookline, Mass. The ceremony was performed in the University Lutheran Church by the Rev. Constance Parvey.

title: Manhasset Wins at 3Inch Line Greenwich
description: If there is such a thing as a 3inch line, Roosevelt was on it when time ran out yesterday in an 1812 loss to Manhasset. The victory gave Manhasset sole possession of first place in Nassau Conference VIII.

title: Disk Jockey Killed in Florida; 2 Arrested, $10,000 Recovered
description: DELAND, Fla., Oct 26 (AP) The body of a disk jockey, Fred C. West, was found today in a wooded area, a day and a half after he was apparently kidnapped for $10,000 ransom, the police said.

title: JetsRams Scoring
Halloween Observed Early
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Oct. 27 (AP)  Children in at least two New Hampshire communties had their Halloween fun this afternoon, as a safety measure. Manchester and Candia declared that today would be the time for trickortreating. Manchester officials said they felt that this afternoon was a safer time than next Thursday night, which is Halloween, for children to be on the streets.

title: Kivitt and Miss Gregory To Dance in Cuban Fete
description: Ted Kivitt, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will partner Cynthia Gregory, a ballerina also with the company, next month at Cuba's annual Ballet Festival in Havana. Miss Gregory, whois the first major American performing artist to be invited to Cuba since diplomatic relations were broken in 1961, was originally scheduled to appear with Michael Denard. A spokesman for Miss Gregory said Mr. Denard was unable to be released from his commitments with the Paris Opera Ballet.

title: Two Indomitables
description: Rounding out the top of the Nov. 5 ballot are two offices that have been occupied by the same two menone a Republican, the other a Democratfor as long as many voters can remember. These two menby their integrity, intelligence and industrious service to the state have earned the respect and support of New Yorkers of all political persuasions and have made of their offices models for the nation. They are Louis J. Lefkowitz, Republican Attorney General for the last eighteen years, and Arthur Levitt, a Democrat who is completing his twentieth year as Controller.

title: Man, 73, Found in Home 2 Weeks After His Death
description: The body of a 73yearold man who had apparently been dead for more than two weeks was found in his Brooklyn home last night after his wife reportedly called the police and told them her husband had died Oct. 13.

title: A CODE FOR POLICE IS SOUGHT AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27On the basis of reports about increased use of torture against political prisoners, United Nations members have called for adoption of an international code of police ethics.

title: The Front Porch Restaurants Close: In the End, Inflation Brought Failure
description: Dear Customers: We don't seem to have any other choice. We have tried to rearrange menus and recipes, and there is no way out. We must raise prices. Because of constantly increasing food costs, labor costs, utilities, paper products, linens, on and on . . . We are forced into the spiraling price situation with thousands of others who are bewildered and disheartened. No one seems to know where it will all end . . . Liz & Cleves

title: PARENTS APPEALING INTEGRATION ORDER
description: LAKEWOOD, Oct, 27  The longstanding controversy over school desegregation here apparently has not been resolved by last week's state ruling that directed the local Board of Education to continue an integration program.

title: U.S. AID TO NIXON CALLED LIMITED
description: LONG BEACH, Calif. Oct. 27 (AP)Richard M. Nixon's press aide said today that the extent of Federal aid given to the former President was exaggerated, and said Mr. Nixon did not have insurance to pay for his hospitalization.

title: Two ExClassmates in Heated Ninth District Race
description: EAST RUTHERFORD  As fellow graduates, of the old East Rutherford High School, Class of 1940, Representative Henry Helstoski, a Democrat, and Harold A. Pareti, his Republican opponent in the Ninth Congressional District, have a certain wry respect for each other's talents.

title: 3 Disputed Women Priests Lead Communion Here
description: Three of the 11 women deacons who were ordained to the Episcopal priesthood last July celebrated the Eucharist last night at Riverside Church, defying their bishops and risking ecclesiastical trials that could defrock them.

title: Kuh Asks Morgenthau to Open 20YearOld Wiretapping File
description: Richard H. Kuh, the Manhattan District Attorney, yesterday challenged Robert M. Morgenthau, his principal opponent in next week's election, to make public all files relevant to a wiretapping that, Mr. Kuh suggested, had been illegally carried out 20 years ago by a private detective hired by Mr. Morgenthau.

title: Miss Schulder Bride of Jerry Gruenhut
description: Lynnette Schulder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Schulder of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Jerry Gruenhut, son of Ad Gruenhut of New York and the late Mrs. Gruenhut.

title: SovietU.S. Scientists Talk
description: MOSCOW, Oct 27 (ReutersSoviet and American space scientists have begun to discuss space biology and medicine in their fifth working session in the Central Asian capital of Tashkent, the newspaper Pravda reported today. The scientists are to exchange information on the Soviet manned orbital missions and the results of experiments by American astronauts on the Skylab mission.

title: Defendants in Watergate CoverUp Case Are Turning Against One Another as Trial Enters Fifth Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27The Watergate coverup trial goes into its fifth week tomorrow in an atmosphere in which each of the five defendants are turning more and more against one another.

title: Phantom of Liberte Opens at the Paris
description: Luis Buels The Phantom of Libert (formerly titled Le Fantme de la Libert) opened commercially yesterday at the Paris Theater. It was shown Oct. 13 at this years New York Film Festival, and was previewed then.

title: Laker Spurt Downs Suns By 123116
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 (AP)Jim Price sparked a 130 spurt at the start of the second half tonight and the Los Angeles Lakers went on to defeat the Phoenix Suns, 123116, in the National Basketball Association.

title: Demonstration: in Japan
description: TOKYO, Oct. 27 (Reuters)Japan's defense forces celebrated their 20th anniversary today with a parade at an army base near Tokyo as 1,500 people staged an antimilitary demonstration nearby.

title: Personal Finance: On Leasing Cars
description: Lease or buy a car? More individuals are asking that question these days as longterm leasing of single automobiles becomes more widely available.

title: Books of The Times
description: FOREVER PICASSO, Text and photographs by Roberto Otero. Translated from the Spanish by Elaine Kerrigan. illustrated. 197 pages. Abrams. $20. GOODBYE PICASSO. Text and photographs by David Douglas Duncan. Illustrated. 300 pages. Grosset & Dunlap $35.

title: The State Indicates A Vote on Casinos Is Still Scheduled
description: TRENTON, Oct. 27 (UPI)New Jersey's Attorney General says the state's failure to publish notices on next week's casinogambling referendum in two counties does not mean the referendum is automatical illegal.

title: Alioto Favors Veterans Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 27 (UPI)  San Francisco Mayor Joseph Alioto, president of the United States Conference of Mayors,1 said today that President Ford should observe Veterans Day by announcing tomorrow he would sign a bill increasing G.I. benefits by 23 per cent. Mr. Ford has threatened to veto the bill as inflationary. It would. increase monthly benefits for a veteran in college fulltime from $220 to $270.

title: Okla, State Star Out
description: STILLWATER, Okla., Oct. 27 (UPI)Oklahoma State's fullback, George Palmer, will undergo surgery for torn knee ligaments tomorrow and will be out the rest of the year, Coach Jim Stanley said.

title: 247 Held in Portugal In a Show of Vigilance
description: LISBON, Oct. 27 (Reuters)A total of 247 people were detained for questioning in northern Portugal over the weekend in a military security operation affecting about three million people, a military spokesman said today.

title: CHICAGO GUARD HELD IN 4.3MILLION THEFT
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (UPI)A security guard who was on duty when burglars took more than $4million from an Armored Express Company vault was arrested today and charged with participation in the theft.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: 20,000 Rally Here for Puerto Rican Independence
description: Nearly 20,000 people crowded into Madison Square Garden yesterday for a cheering, chanting, festive rally for Puerto Rican independence, in which the portraits of five Puerto Ricans jailed for a 1950 attempted assassination of President Harry S. Truman and 1954 shooting in the House of Representatives were draped from the arena ceiling.

title: WALTER BRUNING
description: COVINGTON, Ky., Oct. 27 (AP)  Walter Bruning, a retired vice president of the Gristede's food store chain, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Greater Cincinnati Airport. He lived in Stirling Court, Lakewood, N. J.

title: Kissinger Received Coolly in New Delhi; Mrs. Gandhi to Leave While He's There
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 27Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here tonight to a surprisingly cool reception.

title: Boston Busing Foes Drive To Education Chief's Home
description: NEEDHAM, Mass., Oct. 27 (UPI)A motorcade of about 700 antibusing demonstrators drove to the home of Gregory Anrig, State Education Commissioner, today to protest Boston's school desegregation program, but others were turned back by the police when they attempted to reach the home of the Federal judge who ordered the program.

title: Bout Lifts Barriers To Zaire
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 27  Sixteen nonwhite South Africans made history here this evening by stepping down from a commercial jet liner, Walking into the Ndjili Airport and picking up entry visas to Zaire. Legal travel between South Africa and black African countries is normally all but impossible.

title: 500 WAR PRISONERS RELEASED IN CYPRUS
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 27 (UPI)  More than 500 Greek and Turkish Cypriote prisoners of war traded buses in a hotel courtyard here today, leaving only a few hundred more captives of the summer war on Cyprus to be exchanged, United Nations spokesman said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Because Tom Wicker has given us much sensible and constructive comment on many controversial issues, I felt disappointed, in reading his Oct. 13 column on No Policy for School Integration, to note a rather glaring omission. This lies in his failure to distinguish between the Boston (1974) and Little Rock (1954) situations with respect to the closely related fundamental questions, relative to the role of ethnic differences in the publicly controlled aspects of our lives, of (1) what our Federal Constitution calls for and (2) what our longrange objectives are.

title: A Skeptical Jersey vs. Port Authority
description: When the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced 10 days ago that it was temporarily shelving a proposed $300million extension of PATH, New Jersey officials denounced the decision. Their reaction, however, was motivated not just by concern for the future of the railroad but also by their longstanding fear that the Port Authority was trying to get out of its pledge to help the state with all its transit problems.

title: Allison Wins, Driving With a Broken Back
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 27 (UPI)Bobby Allison, driving with a broken vertebrae in his back and a cracked rib, won the third leg of the International Race of Champions series today at Riverside Raceway.

title: EXP.O.W.'S IN ISRAEL SENTENCED TO PRISON
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 27  Two Israeli Army sergeants were sentenced by a military court today to seven years in prison for having refused orders during the war last year. They were among prisoners of war repatriated from Egypt.

title: Veterans Day
description: Today is the Federal observance of Veterans Day. Post offices and all Federal offices will be closed.

title: Cowboys Win, 217; Morton Impressive
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 27Craig Morton pumped life into the New York Giants'; offense today, but Drew Pearson, a wide receiver, threw the surprising pass that produced the crucial points in the Dallas Cowboys'; 217 victory at Yale Bowl.

title: Israeli and Syrian Forces Are Active on Golan Heights
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 27Israel lookouts on the Golan Heights reported that Syrian forces across the ceasefire line had moved forward today after the Israelis began largescale maneuvers on the heights.

title: Veterans Day
description: Today is the Federal observance of Veterans Day. Post offices and all Federal offices will be closed.

title: Meanwhile, the Mad Scientist Created an Airborne Division...
description: SEATTLEYou can't pick up newspaper these days without getting scared to death over what the mad geneticists have in store for us. We read that if we fail to stop them, the human race will rapidly become band of organisms ruled by a few unspeakable tyrants.

title: And Now, the High Cost of TrickorTreat
description: Climbing sugar prices have Sent candy prices spiraling to as much as twice as high as they were last year, and to Thursday night's marauding Halloween hobgoblins and witches, this may mean skimpy pickings of trickortreat sweets.

title: MANSFIELD, SIMON SPLIT ON ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon predicted today that the postelection Congress would pass legislation taxing away some of the windfall profits of the oil industry but Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, predicted it would not.

title: Nuptials Held Here For Olivia Shamoon
description: The marriage of Olivia Shamoon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Niazi Shamoon of London, to Edward Alan Greenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Greenberg of Great Neck, Li., took place here yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed at the Pierre by Rabbi Jacob Philip Rudin of. Temple BethEl in Great Neck.

title: Happy Birthday To Ivory Coast
description: KINSHASA, Faire, Oct. 27 (Agence FrancePress)President Felix HouphouetBoigny of the Ivory Coast as directed his country's television service to arrange for Wednesday's Mahammad AliGeorge Foreman world heavyweight boxing title fight to be seen liv by satellite linkup, it was disclosed here today.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: The State Public Advocate hopes to have ready for presentation to the Board of Public Utility Commissioners in the next two weeks a series of proposals that will sharply limit utility deposit charges and perhaps call for still another increase in the rate of interest that utilities are required to pay on deposits.

title: CONFLICTS ROCK FRENCH POLITICS
description: PARIS, Oct. 27Six months after presidential elections, the political knives have again come unsheathed in France. Feuds are threatening the common program of the Communists and Socialists, there is disgruntlement among the waning Gaullists and a deteriorating economic situation is taxing the powers of the new leader, Valery Giscard d'Estaing.

title: 3 Journalists Will Get Maria Moors Cabot Awards
description: Three journalists and two newspapers will receive the 36th annual Maria Moors Cabot prizes tomorrow at Columbia University.

title: SAFETY PROBLEM RISES AT COLUMBIA
description: The rape of a Barnard College sophomore in Morningside Park and the mugging of Columbia College varsity football player on the main campus thoroughfare have touched off new concerns about security in and around Columbia University's Morningside Heights campus.

title: Poll Finds Economy and Taxes Are the Voters' Main Worries
description: The low state of the economy and the high state of taxes are strongly preoccupying New Yorkers who next week will be choosing a Governor, a United States Senator, the state's 39 Congressmen and all 210 members of both houses of the Legislature.

title: Wilson and Carey Raise Few New Issues in Debate
description: The candidates for Governor, their tempers sharpened by weeks of intensive campaigning, traded barbs but raised few new issues yesterday at their second facetoface debate.

title: Ford's Day: Swimming, Tennis and Football
description: THURMONT, Md., Oct. 27 (UPI)President Ford swam and played tennis today at Camp David and watched a televised football game before he returned to the White House for supper.

title: Dahlia, Ridden by Piggott, $152,750 Stakes Winner
description: ETOBICOKE, Ontario, Oct. 27Dahlia, the thoroughbred queen from France, continued to perform majestically today. The plucky daughter of Vaguely Noble, with a late rush, captured the $152,750 Canadian International Chainpionship Stakes, in the record time of 2:40 for the 15/8mile race at the Woodbine Track.

title: A Municipal Report
description: GREENVILLE, S. C.There is a special place for James Mann in our memory of that extraordinary week last summer when the House Judiciary Committee debated the impeachment of Richard Nixon. In his soft intense voice, reflecting on the role of the people and their representatives in this democracy, Mr. Mann seemed to speak for the old American values, reemerging after bad times. No one who listened is likely to forget his warning that, if the system failed now, the next time there may be no watchman in the night.

title: BONN'S OPPOSITION GAINS IN ELECTIONS
description: BONN, Oct. 27A climate of economic uncertainty and the threat of growing unemployment today cost Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic party seats in the state legislatures of Hesse and Bavaria, in the first test of voters Moods since last spring.

title: Experts Back Pest Control To Multiply World's Food
description: Each year an estimated half of the world's critically short food Supply is consumed or destroyed by insects, molds, rodents, birds and other pests that attack, foodstuffs in fields, during shipment and in storage.

title: Nets, Sparked by Erving, Trounce Spirits, 10991
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27 (AP)Julius Erving scored 20 points and the New York Nets took advantage of numerous early mistakes to down the Spirits of St. Louis, 10991, tonight in an American Basketball Association game.

title: France's Outcast Moslems Stage Protest
description: PARIS, Oct. 27Huddled in the twilight of the crypt of the Madeleine, the parish church of French presidents near Maxim's threestar restaurant and the fabled food shop Fauchon, a tiny band of Moslems is staging a hunger strike.

title: TRANSIT SYSTEMS GAIN CUSTOMERS
description: Six months after the easing of the severe gasoline shortages of last winter and spring, many mass transit systems around the nation are still gaining new riders.

title: Call of the Wild
description: There are studies and plans and infinite good intentions about the Central Pirk and Prospect Park and other city zoos, but in the meantime the animals sicken and die without proper veterinarian facilities under archaic conditions of imprisonment that bear no resemblance their natural habitats.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FLESH AND FANTASY An estimable roundup of vintage movies titled The Fantastic in Cinema begins a new series with four Monday programs starting at 1 P.M. today and continuing through Dec. 2 at the Carnegie Hall Cinema (PL 72131) at 883 Seventh Avenue (between 56th and 57th Streets). The sponsoring organization, known as The Thousand Eyes of Carnegie Hall Cinema, is a subscription group still offering memberships at the box office, priced at $25, $12.50 for students and $7.50 for afternoon attendance only.

title: CampaignAct Flaws
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y.  The new Federal Elections Campaign Act, widely hailed as a cleansing response to Watergate, may be remembered as an even graver infringement of American liberty.

title: Voluntary Mental Groups Ask More Planning Power
description: Many of the city's outstanding voluntary agencies, in sharp criticism of the State Department of Mental Hygiene, have opened a drive to force the department to give them more power in planning services for the mentally handicapped.

title: Big Oil Deposits Indicated Beneath Norwegian Sea
description: The discovery of highquality oil at two widely separated sites in the Norwegian Sea has raised the possibility that extensive petroleum deposits lie beneath those deepsea areas, between Norway and Iceland, far from what are generally considered territorial waters.

title: Sonia Rykiel First It Was the Connoisseurs, Now the Masses
description: PARISIt isn't that Sonia Rykiel just burst upon the scene. Like most of the pacesetting readytowear houses here, she has been designing since the early nineteensixties.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: KISSINGER LEAVES MOSCOW HOPEFUL ON ARMS ACCORD
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 27Secretary of State Kissinger left Moscow today believing that his three days of talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev had moved the United States and the Soviet Union substantially closer to a longsought formula for limiting still further their arsenals of strategic missiles and bombers.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Second Hearing Set Nov. 12 On Gurney's Dismissal Plea
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 27 (AP)A second hearing has been set for Nov. 12 on a petition by Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, asking for dismissal of a Federal indictment charging him with bribery, conspiracy and perjury.

title: James M. Cox Jr. Is Dead at 71; Led News, Broadcasting Chain
description: MIAMI, Oct. 27 (AP)James M. Cox Jr., chairman of the Cox Enterprises newspaperpublishing company and the Cox Broadcasting Corporation, died today at a hospital here. He was 71 years old and lived here and in Dayton, Ohio, and Atlanta.

title: Attorney General Rivals Focus on Financing Issue
description: The rival candidates for state Attorney General made campaign financing the major item in their electioneering yesterday.

title: Optimism Is Seen Setting Tone in Credit Markets
description: The credit markets these days are optimistic. Interest rates are headed down, and bond prices are bound to rise.

title: Jamaica Center Gets $75,000 Grant
description: The Jamaica Arts Center, in the old Register Building at 16104 Jamaica Avenue, will receive a grant of $75,000 from the New York State Council on the Arts. The grant will be used for maintenance of the center, which opened last June, and for various programs including exhibitions, artist demonstrations, lunchtime exercises and stage performances. The project is sponsored by the Queens Council on the Arts and the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, nonprofit organizations.

title: Thomas J. Herbert Dies at 79; ExG.O.P. Governor of Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 27 (AP)Former Gov, Thomas J. Herbert died last night in a Grove City nursing home. He was 79 years old.

title: Recital
description: Subscribers to the Distinguished Artist Series at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and 92d Street, received a worthy dividend Saturday night: a bonus concert with Michele Campanella in his American recital debut. The 27yearold Italian pianist, a multiple prize winner in Europe, teaches at the Verdi Conservatory in Milan. He has appeared here with the Cleveland, Cincinnati and Detroit Symphony Orchestras. He is, in other words, a highly experienced artist.

title: 1100 Scholars Gather to Debate Two Economists New Book on Slavery in U.S.
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 26Many of the country's leading experts on slavery met here this week to confront a pair of economists who have brazenly invaded their territory with computers and formulas to suggest that blacks thrived under slavery in the South.

title: 2 ReunionsFor SoloistIn Concert
description: The reorganized American Symphony Orchestra began its second season in rearing good form at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. Energetically conducted by Kazuyoshi Akiyama, its music director, the orchestra gave a program of three 20thcentury pieces now in the mainstream of our concert lifeWilliam Schuman's American Festival Overture, the Sibelius Violin Concerto and Stravinsky's The Rite of Springplaying cohesively and with infectiously buoyant spirit.

title: Paper Endorses Schweiker
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 (UPI) The Philadelphia Inquirer, this city's second largest news. paper, today endorsed Senator Richard S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, for reelection. His opponent is Pittsburgh Mayor Peter Flaherty, Democrat.

title: BONN'S OPPOSITION GAINS IN ELECTIONS
description: BONN, Oct. 27A climate of economic uncertainty and the threat of growing unemployment today cost Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic party seats in the state legislatures of Hesse and Bavaria, in the first test of voters moods since last spring.

title: Music: Mahler's Sixth
description: Mahler's Sixth Symphony had to wait 42 years for its first performance in this country (the New York Philharmonic under Dimitri Mitropoulos introduced it in 1947), and it remains to this hour one of the less frequently played of the nine symphonies. In spite of its direct connections with Mahlee's own gloomy view of his lifein good Romantic tradition it used to be subtitled the Tragic Symphonythe Sixth somehow does not move the listener as surely as do many other Mahler works.

title: Plunkett Takes Patriots 86 Yards in 85 Seconds for 1714 Victory Over Vikings
Jane W. Fischer Bride Of Arthur Salzfass
description: Jane W. Fischer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Fischer of Middlebury, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Arthur Salzfass of New York. The ceremony was performed in Temple Israel in Waterbury, Conn., by Rabbi Arnold Miller.

title: Extra Cold Winter Is Seen For States East of Rockies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) The Commerce Department and a professor of meteorology predicted today that this winter could be an extra cold one, particularly for states east of the Rocky Mountains.

title: 5 of 22 Hostages Freed by Convicts In a Dutch Prison
description: THE HAGUE, Oct. 27Four armed convicts, one of them a Palestinian guerrilla, today released five of the 22 hostages they had been holding in the chapel of a prison in Scheveningen, near the Hague, since last night.

title: COURT TO TAKE UP RIGHTS OF YOUTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27The Supreme Court is beginning to explore a controversial new area with few legal guideposts, trying to determine whether young people have the same constitutional rights as their elders.

title: Bout Lifts Barriers To Zaire
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 27  Sixteen nonwhite South Africans made history here this evening by stepping down from a commercial jet liner, walking into the Ndjili Airport and picking up entry visas to Zaire. Legal travel between South Africa, and black African countries is normally all but impossible.

title: Dahlia, Ridden by Piggott, $152,750 Stakes Winner
description: ETOBICOKE, Ontario, Oct. 27Dahlia, the thoroughbred queen from France, continued to perform majestically today. The plucky daughter of Vaguely Noble, with a late rush, captured the $152,750 Canadian International Championship Stakes, in the record time of 2:40 for the 1 5/8mile race at the Woodbine Track.

title: Chaim Grade's Heart Is Still in Vilna
description: I was born in Vilna. can't leave Vilna. I lived five years in Russia, two in Paris, now 25 years here, but I am still in Vilna.

title: ABBOTT COTTEN MARTIN
description: Abbott Cotten Martin, a specialist in Victorian literature and Wordsworth's poetry who retired in 1969 as professor of English at the University of the South, Sewanee, Tenn., died Tuesday at a nursing home in Atlanta. He was 75 years old.

title: Texas Instruments Shows 4% Decline In Quarter Profits
description: The Texas Instruments Corporation reported yesterday that its net income declined 4 per cent in the third quarter ended Sept. 30 from the level in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Watson Defeats Snead in Playoff
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 27 (AP)Roger Watson of Cary, N.C., rolled in an 85foot birdie putt on the last hole of regulation play today and then parred the first hole of sudden death to win the Professional Golfers' Association club pro championship.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: JetsRams Scoring
Landmark Group Sets New Concerts
description: A new series of free concerts will be offered by the American Landmark Festivals In cooperation with the National Park Service of the Department of the Interior. They will be given Sundays at 3 P.M. at the Hamilton Grange National Memorial, 286 Convent Avenues (at 141st Street), beginning Nov. 3. Previously established series that continue are being given Tuesdays at 5:30 P.M. at the Federal Hall National Memorial, Wall and Broad Streets, and Thursdays at 7 P.M. at the Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace, 28 East 20th Street. American Landmark Festivals is a nonprofit corLoration founded by Francis Heilbut.

title: Sona Robbins Wed To Robert Cohen
description: The marriage of Sona Robbins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Robbins of New York, to Robert D. Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Millard Cohen of Lawrence, L. I., took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

title: Zack Clayton Is Candidate For Referee
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 27 Zack Clayton, the chairman of the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission and a longtime referee, loomed today as the foremost candidate to be the referee for the George ForemanMuhammad All world heavyweight championship fight here Wednesday morning (Tuesday night in New York).

title: Buerkle, N.Y.A.C. Win A.A.U. Race
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 27 Dick Buerkle led the New York Athletic Club to a repeat victory in the Amateur Athletic Union's 3kilometer national team race today at the Freehold Raceway.

title: Ford the Campaigner
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 I President Ford was relaxed and happy. He was in Melvin, Ill. flat, blacksoiled corn andbean country 100 miles south of Chicago  surrounded by friendly faces. The occasion was a cerNews emony last week Analysis honoring Leslie C. Arends, the House Republican whip, who is retiring after 40 years in Congress. The several thousand people who had gathered outdoors at the Melvin fairground on an unusually warm October day weresave for a few dozen protestersbedrock Republicans, plain country folk welldisposed toward Mr. Ford, the main of the day.

title: Miss Franklin's Earthy Soul Fills Revue
description: Aretha Franklin's arrival onstage at Radio City Music Hall, dressed in a circusclown out fit and singing That's Entertainment, might offend soulmusic purists who have long regarded Miss Franklin as one of the pinnacles of the art. But others who consider soul as a state of mind rather than rigid form and appearance would have no complaints about either singer or surroundings at her midnight concert Saturday. Miss Franklin's That's Entertainment was soul singinganyway, dressing up an act is no worse, no better than dressing one down. All those rock n roll millionaires in their plantation denim coveralls  that's still entertainment and show biz.

title: Film Institute Prize For Orson Welles
description: Orson Welles has been named to receive the American Film Institute's Award for Life Achievement. The award, given so far only to the late John Ford and, last year, to James Cagney, honors an individual who has contributed to the filmmaking arts and has been recognized by his peers and the public and whose work has withstood the test of time. The 59yearold actor, writer, director and producer, who has worked on stage, screen, radio and television for more than 40 years, will be honored at the award dinner in Los Angeles in February.

title: R. J. Zimmer Weds Miss Schwartzman
description: Terese Anne Schwartzman and Robert J. Zimmer were married yesterday afternoon at the Green Valley Country Chib in Lafayette Hill, Pa., by Rabbi Dennis Math of the Village Temple here.

title: Rangers Defeat Flames, 47
description: Held scoreless in the first period last night and trailing 10 in the second period, the New York Rangers righted their ship and went sailing into a tie for first place with a 41 victory over the Atlanta Flames at Madi son Square Garden.

title: DATING OF PAPERS BY I. T. T. STUDIED
description: Federal investigators are looking into charges that some key documents produced in a $12million civil fraud case involving the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation were chemically altered after they had been received ?? the giant conglomerate, wellin. formed sources said yesterday.

title: Retired Americans Find Economic Haven in Poland
description: WARSAW, Despite signs that the haven offered by Communist Poland to retired economic refugees from the United States is filling up, American immigrants continue to stream in.

title: ROCKERS OF CARMEN SERVE UP ZESTY MIX
description: Carmen, the Spanish rock group at the Academy of Music on 14th Street on Saturday, provided on offbeat view of European rock. The group appeared to be making the flamenco dance routine, beloved of nightclub cabaret, palatable to rock audiences as two members of the group broke into heel stamping, hand clapping and castanet clicking at intervals.

title: Key Legislators Get Funds Even With Election Certain
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 27In the last weeks of the election campaign, special interest groups are donating thousands of dollars to influential members of Congress whose reelection is not seriously challenged.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Union leaders representing members at eight state colleges in New Jersey say they are ready to strike if contract negotiations remain stalemated. The union leaders unanimously agreed in New Brunswick yesterday to ask teachers to authorize a strike saying that the state was not negotiating in good faith.

title: Butz Denies U.S. Diet Cuts Will Ease World Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27It is wrong, Secretary of Agriculture Carl L. Butz said today, to talk about eating one less hamburger per week as a contribution too solving the world food shortztge.

title: Suspect's Friend Led to Arrest in '72 Slaying of Jersey Student
description: A confession to a friend was instrumental in linking a yearold Syracuse man with the murder nearly two years ago of Karen Levy, an 18yearold Syracuse University freshman from Cherry Hill, N. J., the police said yesterday.

title: Experts Back Pest Control To Multiply World's Food
description: Each year an estimated half of the world's critically short food Supply is consumed or destroyed by insects, molds, rodents, birds and other pests that attack, foodstuffs in fields, during shipment and in storage.

title: Penalties Hurt in 2013 Defeat
description: The Jets, who from time to time have paid a few pennies for their outspoken thoughts on officiating, have not played well enough this season to cry about the officials in their laughable losses.

title: TV: Rhoda Gets Married Tonight (Finally)
description: Event television, supposedly the best kind, is generally associated with the transmission of live happenings, anything from football games to Congressional hearings. The lowly situation comedy, however, is not entirely excluded from the game. Way back near the beginning there was the birth of Lucy's TV baby, cleverly timed to coincide with the birth of Lucille Ball's offcamera baby. And tonight at 9, in a special CBS hourlong production, there is a wedding on Rhoda.

title: Issue and Debate
description: A major West Coast bank went to Federal regulators early last year to find out whether there was an objection to a new customer service it had in mind.

title: Dave Anderson
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 27Muhammad All is hearing voices. The voices are chanting, Ali, bomaye. Pronounce it, Ali, boomahyea, meaning Ali, kill him, meaning George Foreman. The voices provided a thunderous accompaniment when about 10,000 Zairians discovered something different to do Saturday nightattend boxing's ritual the scale. Most weighins are held shortly before 12 o'clock noon, in an empty arena or a dusty commission office with boxing's not always beautiful people nodding sleepily when the weights are announced. This one was held shortly before 12 o'clock too, 12 o'clock midnight, in the steaming humidity of the Stade du 20 Mai with 10,000 chanting Zairians and a mixed blessing of afro, bongo and hard rocx music. All weighed 216, Foreman 220 but the numbers weren't even announced the cast of thousands. Not that the Zairians cared. They were there to enjoy a spectacle, probably not realizing that they, not the gladiators, had created the spectacle. They cheered for the champion but they changed for the challenger. Judging by the decibel count of Ali, bomaye thb weighin, the Zairians should be at peak voice by o'clock Wednesday morning when the world heavyweight title bout will begin in order to display it on closedcircuit TV at 10 o'clock Tuesday evening, New York time. Ali, bomate will be the shout heard around the world.

title: Choice for Governor ...
description: The critical issue for New Yorkers in the gubernatorial election on Nov. 5 is the relative capacity of the two candidatesGovernor Malcolm Wilson and Represenative Hugh L. Careyto demonstrate leadership and imagination in responding effectively to the massive problems confronting the state. In our view, Mr. Carey is clearly the better choice.

title: Unhappy Americans in Paris
description: PARIS, Oct. 23They sat around glumly in their booths, which cost them at least $1,300, waiting for the eager hordes of European customers to descend. The hordes never materialized, but the Americans, taking part for the first time in the International Trade Fair of Fashion at the Porte de Versailles, eventually decided the loss wasn't total. They were learning about foreign markets; they were making contact with potential customers; some were picking up sales representatives in Europe, and some even sold some goods.

title: ExPrisoners Now Teach School at Adolescent Jail
description: Eight young men slouch at their desks, absorbed in working out the problem that is on the chalkboard at the front of their cramped classroom.

title: Monzon Is Arrested
description: SANTA FE, Argentina, Oct. 27 (AP)The world middleweight boxing champion, Carlos Monzon, was arrested early today for beating his wife, the official news agency Telam reported.

title: Hussein and Arafat Seek Showdown at Arab Talks
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 27King Hussein of Jordan and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, taking equally adamant positions, told Arab leaders today that they had to choose between them and could not hope for a compromise in their conflict.

title: Six Minor Parties Offer Candidates in State Races
Sports News Briefs
description: St. Francis Prep and Cardinal Hayes won Catholic Schools Football League games yesterday and remain tied for first in the City Division with 41 wonlost marks. St. Francis converted two blocked puntsone by Tom Nevitt, the other by Brian Sullivaninto touchdowns and scored four times on short runs to defeat Cardinal Spellman, 4120. Hayes intercepted five passes in a 4114 rout of Holy Cross. Rich Witherspoon had two interceptions and returned one 91 yards for a score. Tony Alguero carried 32 times for the winners, gaining 173 yards and scoring twice. His season's totals are 835 yards and 74 points.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger is in New Delhi after three days of talks in Moscow with the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, in which he believes the United States and the Soviet Union moved substantially closer to finding a formula for new limits on strategic weapons. But Mr. Kissinger's reception in India was cool, with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi planning to fly to Kashmir tomorrow, in the midst of his visit. [Page One Col. 8.]

title: Switzerland Discounter Is a Successful Don Quixote
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 18Karl Schweri, a slight man whose 57 years are betrayed only by his graying hair, sees the chain of discount stores he owns as a means to right the injustices suffered by the humble.

title: SUSPECTS FRIEND BROKE COED CASE
description: A confession to a friend was instrumental in linking a 23yearold Syracuse man with the murder nearly two years ago of Karen Levy, an 18year old Syracuse University freshman from Cherry Hill, N.J., the police said today.

title: Populist Given Edge in Tennessee Governor's Race
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 26  A former segregationist is trying, to recapture the Tennessee Governor's office for the Democrats with a 19thcentury populist appeal to the economically hardhit of both races.
