description: The CNA Financial Corporation of Chicago, a holding coznpany for insurance and real estate operations, said yesterday that its directors had decided to recommend that shareholders accept the offer from the Loews Corporation to buy 20 million shares at $6 a share for the common stock and $8 a share for the preferred.

title: 2 NEW U.S. RULES COULD FORCE CUT IN GASOLINE PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The Federal Energy Administration published today two regulations that could force some international oil companies to reduce gasoline and oil prices temporarily by a penny or two gallon.

title: 2 From Cahn Office on L.I. Accused of aid to Embarrass Rival
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Oct. 28Two men with a camera walked into a topless bar here this afternoon, and in the style of campaign dirty tricks, began taking pictures of a topless dancer seated next to a campaign poster of Denis Dillon, the Democratic candidate for prosecutor.

title: 2 Hurt in Propane Blast and Fire at Oil Depot
description: A series of propane explosions ripped through an oilcompany distribution center in Enfield, Conn., yesterday afternoon, touching off a fire that critically burned two employes and melted cars in a nearby parking lot.

title: Dolphin in the Swim at Northport
description: NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 28 a dolphin was sighted in the harbor here at 9 A.M. today, and by late this afternoon, grownups and children on Main Street and nearly everywhere else in this small village on Long Island's North Shore were asking, How is he?

title: Garment Workers Settle
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 (AP)Levi Strauss & Co. announced today it had reached agreement with the United Garment Workers Union, settling a 13day strike against its plant in Knoxville, Tenn. Details of the pact were not disclosed.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: United Parcel Talks to Resume

title: SAUDICUT IN PRICE OF OIL IS A'NAITED
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 28Saudi Arabia plans to announce shortly a modest reduction in the price of her oil and the freezing of the price at the new level for a year, an informed Arab source said here today.

title: Soviet Press Silence Fans Rumors About Crime
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 28  The Moscow press is suffering from a credibility gap that points up the problems of a closed society where unfavorable news is normally suppressed and people are inclined therefore to believe the worst.

title: A Week at a Health Manor an the Last Resort Die Fasting
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y.SUNDAY: Check into the Pawling Health Manor for week to try to lose the eight pounds mysteriously gained over the summer. Nothing else has worked, so it is time for The Last Resort. Robert R. Gross, who calls himself a physiochemist and runs the place, promises that a fast will produce a weight loss of from 10 to 20 pounds a week as well as flushing the poisons and toxins out of the system.

title: Italian Banks Lift Rates
description: MILAN, Oct. 28 (Reuters)Most major Italian banks are raising their prime lending rates by one percentage point to around 18.5 per cent because of the liquidity squeeze, banking sources said. The rates were last increased in early September after a onepoint rise to 15.5 per cent on June 7.

title: Militants' Areas Are Cordoned Off
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 28In a display of force, uniformed and plainclothes policemen cordoned off three blocks of downtown Tu Do Street today with barbed wire and jeeps in anticipation of demonstrations that never materialized.

title: Market Place
description: In the current rush to go privatebuy back shares offered the public years ago the individual shareholder often feels he is at the mercy of those who own the controlling interest in the company.

title: New jersey Sports
Chez Mao:
description: NEW HAVENFrom the first day of a monthlong trip to China this summer, ten student leaders and were aware of a tremendous presence: Chairman Mao. One cannot walk a block without seeing his words or face painted on colossal billboard displays.

title: Ray Returns to Stand Today in Move to Obtain New Trial in Assassination oaf Dr. King
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 28James Earl Rays returns to the stand tomorrow in his bid for a new trial in the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Helen Estelle, 86, Is Dead; ExHead of State W.C.T.U.
description: Helen G. H. Estelle, former New York State president and world vice president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, died Sunday in Elmhurst (Queens) General Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Israeli Soldier Is Wounded In Clash at Lebanon Border
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 28 (Reuters)  An Israeli soldier was wounded today by smallarms fire from southeast Lebanon, an army spokesman said. Israeli forces returned the fire, he added.

title: DEPORTATION PLAN ROUSES CANADIANS
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 28  A move to deport 800 Haitian immigrants who are in Canada illegally has touched off an angry controversy from the back streets of Montreal to the floor of the House of Commons.

title: Bonn Officials in Accord With Paris on Market Ties
description: BONN, Oct. 28  After months of pessimism about the future of the European Common Market, high West German officials have welcomed recent French proposals for closer political ties within the community as potentially a historic turning point.

title: Ford Motor Co. Defends Loan From Bank in Spain
description: MADRID, Oct. 28A few days ago some Spanish commentators on business affairs discovered to their shock that the giant Ford Motor Company had actually borrowed money from a Spanish bank.

title: STOCKS ON HEX SHOW MIXED TONE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday as the index and the price of an average share rose but declines outnumbered advances.

title: Giant Defense Has Scoring Key
description: As Roy Hilton rumbled toward the Dallas goal after recovering a fumble last Sunday at Yale Bowl, a wall of blueshined bodyguards formed on each side of him.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: To Congress, He's Still Jerry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Just three days after taking office, President Ford told his former colleagues in the Congress, I do not want a honeymoon with you. I want a good marriage.

title: Textbook Protesters Hold March in Charleston, W. Va.
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 28 (UPI)Hundreds of parents, waving flags and signs reading teach English, not revolution, marched through this city today in a protest against series of textbooks introduced into schools this fall.

title: Coming Up for Air
description: After forty years, there is a strong chance that Congress will change but not necessarily raise the stondards for granting Federal franchises to privately owned radio and television stations. The Broadcast License Renewal Act would amend the 1934 law by extending the present threeyear license term to five years and establishing other criteria for serving the public interest. House and Senate versions of the amended act now go into conference to define the standards that influence programs for tens of millions of viewers.

title: Edward McCabe, 75, Dies; Surgeon Here 40 Years
description: Dr. Edward James McCabe, a New York surgeon for 40 years, died yesterday of heart attack in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE PATTON PAPERS, 19401945. By Martin Blumenson. 889 pages. Illustrated With Photographs and With Maps by Samuel H. Bryant. Houghton Mifflin. $17.50 until Dec. 31; $20 thereafter.

title: Dr. Sheldon Weiss, 52, Dies; Dentist and Fluoride Expert
description: Dr. Sheldon Weiss, a past president of the Nassau County Dental Society, and presidentelect of the Tenth District Dental Society made up of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 22303 56th Road, Bayside, Queens. He was 52 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 28 (UPI)Doctors said today that a paralyzed Texas Christian University running back, Kent Waldrep, had more sensation to touch, but that he had no more motor power than before his surgery Saturday night. Waldrep, 20 years old, was injured in T.C.U.'s 413 loss to Alabama. He landed on his head after being tackled in the second quarter, and was instantly paralyzed from the neck down.

title: Dow Stock Index Off 2.35 In Session of Light Volume
description: Although a mild afternoon recovery enabled the stock market to erase some of its earlier losses yesterday, prices closed lower in the slowest trading in more than four weeks.

title: LEFKOWITZ VISITS TEACHER IN BRONX
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was In the Bronx yesterday renewing an old acquaintance, while his Democratic opponent, Robert Abrams, the Borough President, was in Mineola, L. I., wooing commuters.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Court IsAsked to Close Steel Plant on Pollution
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 29 (UPI)  Health officials have voted to ask a court to close down three open hearth furnaces at the Fairfield works of United States Steel Corporation, although the company says such a shutdown would cut plant production in half.

title: U.S. Boxers vs. Hungary
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 29 (AP) The Hungarian Olympic team and the United States National Amateur Athletic Union team will have their first boxing match in the United States on Nov. 30 in the new Coliseum here. The American team is returning from a trip to Poland, where it won three consecutive matches.

title: Freehold, Strike Over, to Open Today
description: New Jersey's struggling Sports Authority will finally start generating some parimutuel revenue for its Hackensack Meadowlands Complex today when Freehold Raceway begins a strike  delayed special meeting. The 60day meeting had been scheduled to open last Thursday, with the Authority getting most of the state's regular 7 per cent cut of the betting handle. But demands by the horsemen for a contract with the Authority had kept the harnessracing track closed.

title: Arabs Agree on Vast Aid To Main Foes of Israel
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 39A multibilliondollar program of financial aid to three Arab countries bordering on Israel and to the Palestine Liberation Organization was agreed upon today in the final moments of the Arab summit meeting here, conference sources said tonight.

title: Student Heads Ticket Line for Title Bout
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 29 A little before noon, as the heat of the day climbed to its peak, Citizen Binkangalo Boguele claimed first place at the main gate to the Stade du 20 Mai for the world heavyweight boxing championship match between the champion, George Foreman, and Muhammad Ali.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: All Regains Title, Flooring Foreman
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Wednesday, Oct. 30Muhummad Ali became today the second man in boxing history to regain the world heavyweight championship, with an eighth  round knockout of George Foreman.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 47

title: Saudi Denies Reports On Cut in Price of Oil
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 29 (UPI)A high Saudi Arabian diplomat denied today that his country planned a moderate reduction in the price of oil and the freezing of the price at the lower level for a year.

title: State Poll Shows Conservatism Ebbing
description: The strong conservative trend of recent years in New York State has receded noticeably since the political departure of Richard M. Nixon, with the slack being taken up by new liberal support.

title: Ship Burris Waste in Gulf In First U.S. Disposal Test
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Shell Oil Company said today that the incinerator ship Vulcanus had successfully disposed of 4,200 metric tons of industrial waste at a burning site in the Gulf of Mexico 130 miles south of Galveston, Tex.

title: SILVERIUS C. M'CAFFREY
description: Silverius C. McCaffrey, retired general superintendent of station construction and shops department of Consolidated Edison, died Monday at St. Johns Hospital in Yonkers. He was 76 years old and lived at 65 Lefferts Road in Yonkers.

title: Gold Price Drops To $167.75 an Ounce On London Market
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 29 (UPI)The price of gold soared to over $170 an ounce on the London market today for the first time in six months, but later fell back because of profit taking, and closed at $167.75 in both London and Zurich.

title: MRS. E. J. AMOURY
description: Mrs. Hannah Balish Amoury, wife of Dr. E. J. Amoury, wellknown Staten Island physician, died Monday at her home. She was 74 years old and lived at 57 Palmer Avenue, Port Richmond, S.I.

title: 2 Ministers Out in Spain; Liberals Facing Pressure
description: MADRID, Oct. 29Pio Cabanillas Gallas, the Minister of Information and Tourism, who had given the Spanish press its greatest freedom in 35 years, was dismissed today in a major concession to rightist forces.

title: Big International Banks, Under Strain, Reject Petrodollar Deposits
description: LONDON, Oct. 28With the commercial banking system's capacity to cope with the massive flow of money from the oilproducing nations under intense strain, possibly approaching the saturation point, major international banks operating in the London financial center are turning down petrodollar deposits.

title: U.N. SHIFT SOUGHT ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29Members of the Security Council and other delegates were negotiating privately all day today in a search for transitional solution to the problem of South Africa that would avoid both expulsion of that country from the United Nations, and a bigpower veto to block an ouster.

title: U.S.STEEL'S PROFIT CLIMBS BY 144.7%
description: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported net income for the September quarter soared by 144.7 per cent on a gain of 38.9 per cent in sales.

title: Two Recant in Court 1967 Testimony That Helped Convict Carter and Artis
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 29Two witnesses whose testimony in 1967 helped to convict Ruben (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis of a triple murder recanted their testimony here today at a court hearing for a new trial.

title: Guard Enjoys Security of a Personal '75 Pact With W.F.L.'s Chicago Fire
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 29 For a while today, the Jets thought they might not lose Garry Puetz to the World Football League after all.

title: ALBERT KEEP
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Oct. 29Albert Keep, headmaster from 1959 until his retirement in 1967 of the Antilles School in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, died today of cancer in the North Adams Regional Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Williamstown.

title: Exits and Entrances
description: There is an unwritten law that New Yorkers should suffer a lot. The ultimate torture is transportation. It takes a citizenry proud of its stoicism to survive the world's worst subways, taxis and buses, with nerves and character put to the test on every trip. There is even a rumor that some New Yorkers never leave home.

title: Canal Break Floods A Rochester Suburb
description: Fifteen square miles of a wealthy Rochester suburb were flooded to a depth of four feetand in some places morewhen the State Barge Canal burst in the Monroe County hamlet of Bushnells Basin yesterday afternoon,

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: Danger of City Fiscal Crisis Seems Real, but Will Budget Retrenchment or New Taxes Resolve It?
description: New York businessmen are constantly telling New York politicians that the proper way tot run the city is the way they run their businesses, The businessmen argueand the argument seems plausiblethat when a company is suffering drastically falling revenues and sharply rising expenses, as the city is, the only way to hold off disaster is to retrench, to cut costs hard until they are once again in balance with income.

title: Advertising
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 29If it was up to Edward N. Ney, the president of Young & Rubicam, political candidates would be stripped of a powerful weaponthe television commercial.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Oct. 25 editorial endorsing Senator Jacob K. Javits for election is an affront to those Americans who can still nourish optimism about the future of this country.

title: Stage: A Trivial Satire
description: One hardly knows whether it is worth mentioning, but over the last few years triviality has crept up on us as an art form. Bullshot Crummond, which opened last night at Theater Four, is termed a satiric reminder. It is intended, I presume, to be a reminder of those British thrillers of before World War II concerning Bulldog Drummond, written by a writer with the engaging pseudonym of Sapper. A reminder it may bein the early films the hero was played by none other than Ronald Colmansatiric it is not. It is jokey, whimsical and, above all, trivial.

title: Paradox for Economists
description: The economics profession is caught in a curious and complicated paradox: The worse economic policy is, the worse the state of the economy; but the worse the economy, the more people turn to economists for solutions; and the more society turns to the economists to solve unsolved problems, the greater the sense of dissatisfaction and inadequacy within the economics profession.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Seattle Drops N.F.L. Franchise Bid

title: Chinese Art Show Coming to Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The State Department announced today that an exhibition of Chinese art and archeological artifacts, ranging from a jadeandgold shroud to a bronze flying horse, will go on display at the National Gallery of Art here Dec. 13.

title: Armco Steel Expansion
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 29 (Reuters) The Armco Steel Corporation said today it planned an expansion in the manufacture of oil and gas well control equipment by the machinery and equipment division, which will increase the Houston plant's capacity by about 150 per cent. The company said the expansion would be completed over a threeyear period.

title: Jersey Acts to Restrict Sex Conduct Testimony
description: TRENTON, Oct: 29A measure that would spare rape victims the humiliation of ??estifying about their sexual conduct before he alleged assault received overwhelming approval in the Assembly today.

title: Senator Percy Visits City To Lend Backing to Javits
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, the Illinois Republican, came to New ork yesterday to help Senator acob avits in his campaign for reelection.

title: Arabs Agree on Vast Aid To Main Foes of Israel
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 29A multibilliondollar program of financial aid to three Arab countries bordering on Israel and to the Palestine Liberation Organization was agreed upon today in the final moments of the Arab summit meeting here, conference sources said tonight.

title: Typhoon Kills 15 in Luzon
description: MANILA, Oct. 29 (AP)Typhoon Elaine killed 15 persons and left a wide swath of destruction in Luzon Province, weathermen and rescue officials said today.

title: TV: Family at War Is a Lesson in Quality for U.S.
description: In their new quest for more adult or more mature programing, the kind that might appeal to younger viewers, some network executives have developed a new ploy for dealing, with any possible objections, reasonable or unreasonable. The alternative to material that may be somewhat controversial, they insist, is returning to the genre of Make, Room for Daddy. Rarely is heard a more discouraging word.

title: CHICAGO'S CONCERT PACKS THE GARDEN
description: The synthesis of rock and jazz, loudly hailed some years ago, has been dormant of late, mainly because of the breaking up of some groups and the emergence of the jazzrock group itselfthat is jazz musicians exploring the rock milieu and electrification rather than the other way around.

title: FRANKING ABUSE IS LAID TO JAVITS
description: Waving at the cameras a blueandwhite Senator Javits Reports newsletter, Ramsey Clark accused Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday of abusing an incumbent's freemailing privilege.

title: $1.5Billion of Bills Auctioned by Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Treasury auctioned today $1.5billion of 227day bills representing new cash at an average rate of 7.93 per cent.

title: Auto Men Hear U.S. Plea On 40% Gas Mileage Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Secretary of Commerce Claude S. Brinegar said today that President Ford was dead serious about achieving a 40 per cent average increase is gasoline mileage by 1980 and that auto company representatives were so informed at a White House meeting with Government officials this afternoon.

title: FIXED FEES NEED NO BROKER HELP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Participants in a conference of institutional money managers and securities firms with the Securities and Exchange Commission appeared agreed today that fixed minimum commission rates on brokerage transactions had little or nothing to do with profits or losses of brokerage firms in the last few years.

title: Ray Contends He Was Miles From Murder
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 29James Earl Ray testified today that he did not assassinate the Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., that he was more than a mile away at the time of the murder and that he had witnesses to prove it.

title: MILEDEEP HOLE IN OCEAN PLANNED
description: Plans are shaping up for an international effort to drill more than a mile into the bedrock of the ocean floorprobably in the western Atlanticto determine the structure of the earth's oceanic crust.

title: Hobgoblins Right & Left
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The hobgoblin of this year's elections is that the Democrats want a massive victory in the House and Senate races so that they can dominate President Ford and override his vetoes, but this is Halloween talk rather than practical politics.

title: HERBERT C. CHILDS JR.
description: Herbert C. Childs Jr., a premedical student at Dartmouth College, died at Herat, Afghanistan, on Oct. 2 of food poisoning.

title: U.S. Grain Pledge To India Reported In Kissinger Visit
description: NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Oct. 30  Secretary of State Kissinger met senior Indian officials yesterday and diplomats said afterward that the United States would supply India at least 500,000 tons of grain at reduced prices.

title: 3d Man Charged in Burglary
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP)A third man was charged today with burglary and larceny in the theft of $4.3million from the Purlator Corporation here. He: was James Maniatis, 53 years old, of Worth Ill., who was already being sought by the police on charges not related to the Purlator case.

title: Hofstra Football Future Is in Doubt Over Funds
description: Hofstra University probably won't have a football team in 1975. But then maybe it will. It was not easy to figure the future of the sport at the Hempstead, L. I., institution after listening yesterday to Dick Thiebert, Hofstra's director of athletics. I think there will be an official statement of no team in 1975 coming shortly. Yet I feel personally Hofstra will field a team in 1975, Thiebert said.

title: Quake in Central Yugoslavia Leaves 500 Without Homes
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 29 (UPI)An earthquake rocked the area around Tuzla in central Yugoslavia today, damaging buildings and leaving some 500 inhabitants homeless. About 15 persons were slightly injured, the police said.

title: People in Sports
description: Wasting no time since he took over as general manager of the. Mets on Oct. 1, Joe McDonald made his third player deal yesterday, acquiring 26yearold Bob Gallagher of the Houston Astros in exchange for Ken Boswell, an infielder. Boswell had been with the Mets since late in the 1967 season. He hit .216 in 96. games last season. Gallagher, an outfielder in his second major league season, batted .172 in only 87 times at bat this year. The lefthanded Gallagher hit .264 rookie in 1972.

title: Ford Signs a Measure Barring Denial of Credit on Basis of Sex
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) President Ford signed today legislation designed to force companies to correct billing errors when their customers demand it and to prohibit corporations from denying credit to women on the basis of sex.

title: Defensive Stalwart Puts Luster on Dim Season With Many Sacks and Tackles
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 29It's not true that John. Mendenhall is Clark Kent or that he says Shazzam! when he wants to change into his New York Giant uniform. It only seems that way.

title: Capitals Beat Bulls By 96 to 80
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP)Phil Chenier and Elvin Hayes combined for 47 points tonight to lead unbeaten Washington to its sixth consecutive National Basketball Association triumph as the Capitals crushed the sagging Chicago Bulls, 9680.

title: Nixon in Critical condition After Surgery
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 29Sudden intensive internal bleeding sent former President Richard M. Nixon into shock today about six hours after surgeons completed an operation, to combat a potentially lethal blood clot.

title: INMATE FROM ATTICA SLAIN AT DANNEMORA
description: Richard Bilello, the first inmate to be sentenced for crimes arising from the 1971 Attica prison rebellion, died early yesterday after being stabbed by another inmate at the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora.

title: Nuggets Top Nets Again In Denver
description: DENVER, Oct. 29The Denver Nuggets, off to good start in reviving an ailing franchise, defeated the New York Nets, 126115, tonight, for their second home victory in 10 days over the American Basketball Association champions.

title: U.S. to Give Jordan Loan
description: AMMAN, Jordan (AP)The United States has decided to loan Jordan $17.5million to finance irrigation projects in the Jordan Valley, the Amman Government announced. The projects are part of a rehabilitation plan involving nearly 300,000 refugees.

title: Notes on People
description: Mstislav Rostropovich, the Soviet cellist, who left his homeland this year with his wife Galina on a twoyear visa, said in an interview in Paris yesterday that they did not intend to return to the Soviet Union until there was full artistic freedom there. Mr. Rostropovich, speaking for himself and for his wife, who is an opera singer, told the newspaper L'Aurore: I will go back when I have a firm assurance that I can give all my art and talent to my people as I see fit. As artists, we must be able to play what we want, where and when we want, with whom want.

title: 2 Crabiel CoDefendants Admit Conspiracy Guilt
description: ELIZABETH, Oct. 29Two companies indicted with J. Edward Crabiel, the New Jersey Secretary of. State, pleaded guilty today to charges of conspiring to rig highway bids and control the, price of paving materials in the Passaic County area between 1957 and 1970.

title: Racing Bill Goes To Byrne
description: TRENTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Assembly passed a bill today calling for yearround horse racing in New Jersey, but shelved another bill aimed at determining how much local communities could benefit from betting.

title: CITY SCHOOLS ACT ON FISCAL ABUSES
description: The Board of Education moved yesterday to strengthen its depleted audit staff as part of what it called a new gettough policy to curb financial abuses and irregularities by some community school districts.

title: City Is Withholding Rents To Pay Delinquent Taxes
description: The city's Finance Administration began a crackdown yesterday on landlords who lease property to the city and fail to pay their taxes on time. The delinquent taxes will be withheld by the city from rents owed.

title: 60 IN CHINATOWN ROBBED BY YOUTHS
description: Four armed youths with turtleneck sweaters pulled up over their faces entered a social club in Chinatown yesterday afternoon and robbed 60 men playing mahjongg and cards of about $2,000 the police said.

title: MUNICIPAL BONDS IN PRICE SETBACK
description: Municipal bond prices suffered a setback yesterday after two syndicates for recent offerings were broken up to allow the bonds to trade in a free market. Dealers, describing the general municipal bond market as heavy, noted that the retreat followed six weeks of improving prices. It was an adjustment after a good rise, commented dealer.

title: Stock Prices Soar
description: Buoyed by a continued decline in interest rates, the stock market yesterday made its best gain in almost three weeks, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 25.50 points. Traders apparently ignored the news that the Government's index of leading business indicators fell 2.5 per cent in September. Details on Page 63.

title: Dining Well in Tokyo: The Joys of Yakitori
description: TOKYOIf misery loves company, we have garnered some measure of consolation in that food and lodging in the major cities of Japan are only occasionally a shade more costly than in New York.

title: Hialeah Deal Hits Obstacle
description: MIAMI, Oct. 29The proposed sale of Hialeah's racing dates to Gulfstream Park took a complex and confused turn today. State Attorney General Robert Shevin has issued an opinion in. Tallahassee that the sale is illegal, but the written opinion will not be available until tomorrow.

title: Ford Gets Report Urging End to Cuban Embargo
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Major changes in United States policies toward Latin America were recommended today by group of prominent American businessmen, scholars and former Government officials in a repor that was welcomed by President Ford.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Birgit Nilsson will make her debut with the New York City Opera Company Nov. 13, when she will fill in for Beverly Sills. She will sing the title role in Puccini's Tosca in the openingnight benefit performance of the company's 1974 season at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles.

title: People and Business
description: Willard M. Bright, who joined the Curtiss  Wright Corporation Feb. 1 as president and chief operating officer, has resigned as an officer and director of the New Jerseybased company, which holds exclusive rights to the Wankel engine in North America.

title: Yugoslavia Devalues Dinar
description: BELGRADE, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Yugoslavia effectively devalued the dinar against foreign currencies today by about 7 per cent in what was seen as a move to counter inflation and growing trade and payments deficits. The United States dollar was fixed at 17.285 dinars, according to a list published after today's biweekly interbank trading session. Yugoslavia floated the dinar against other currencies in July, 1973.

title: Profit Records Set by WarnerLambert
Rivals Showing Awe Over Unbeaten Yale
description: Astonishment would be the best way to describe Jack Musick's feelings about Yale after the undefeated Elis trounced Cornell last Saturday. Yale was the best team we've played in the last couple of years. They're just overpowering. Unless somebody gets them on a down day, they're going to be tough to beat the rest of the way, Musick said.

title: Arabs Hail Leaders' Declaration of Support for the Creation of a Palestinian State
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 29Arabs here said today that new realities had been created in the Middle East by the declaration yesterday of Arab leaders calling for the creation of a Palestinian state and giving the Palestine Liberation Organization responsibility for any Palestinianclaimed territory relinquished by Israel in a peace settlement.

title: KOREAN WORRIED ABOUT FORD VISIT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 29  The leader of South Korea's largest opposition party has expressed concern over what he sees as a possibility that President Ford's visit to Seoul next month may have some unfavorable results.

title: ARAB CLERIC DEFIES JERUSALEM COURT
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 29  The hearing of evidence in the trial of the Most Rev. Hilarion Capucci, the Greek Orthodox Archbishop of East Jerusalem, ended abruptly today when the Archbishop declined to take the stand, contending that the Israeli court was not competent to try him.

title: Socialists Seek Injunction To Bar F.B.I. Surveillance
description: The Socialist Workers party and the Young Socialist. Alliance moved in Federal Court yesterday for a preliminary injunction to prevent the Federal Bureau of Investigation from carrying out surveillance of the upcoming national convention of the Alliance.

title: FORD GETS A REPORT ON COAL MINE TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) President Ford met today with the United Mine Workers' President, Arnold Miller, and said later that he had received very encouraging reports from Mr. Miller about efforts to reach a contract for coal miners.

title: ISRAEL IS SILENT ON ARAB DECISION
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 29The Israeli Government remained silent today on the dedaration by Arab leaders naming the Palestine Liberation Organization as sole representative for the Palestinian people, but two Israeli newspapers termed it a serious blow to the chances for peace in the Middle East.

title: BRITISH ANNOUNCE PLAN TO LEGISLATE MORE SOCIALISM
description: LONDON, Oct. 29The Labor Government announced legislative plans today to extend nationalization of private industry and inject more socialism into British society.

title: U.S. Studying Food Prices For Possible Illegal Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Attorney General William B. Saxbe disclosed today that the Justice Department is investigating the possibility that recent food price increases may have resulted from pricefixing or other illegal behavior. He said the inquiry involved sugar, beef, eggs, tuna and other basic costofliving items.

title: Jazz: A Basie Reunion
description: Count Basie flew in from Europe on Monday evening and went directly to the Riverboat, where he found an unusual version of the Basie band waiting for him, along with an audience so large and enthusiastic that the Riverboat management immediately began making plans to bring in big name bands every Monday night.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Oct. 29 (Reuters)Recycling of oil dollars helped Japan to produce in September its first balanceofpayments surplus in 19 months, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: COUSIN OF KENNEDY SUBJECT OF REPORT
description: BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP)Sen. ator Edward M. Kennedy's cousin, Joseph Gargan, almost accepted responsibility for the Chappaquiddick auto accident that killed Mary Jo Kopechne in 1969, The Boston Globe quotes a highly knowledgeable source as saying.

title: 4 IN DUTCH JAIL DEMAND A PLANE
description: THE HAGUE, Oct. 29The four convicts holding 16 hostages in Scheveningen Prison demanded a plane today to fly them out of The Netherlands.

title: U.S. Set to Enter Energy Consortium, But France Resists
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 29 (AP)The United States has notified the secretariat of the Energy Coordination Group here that it would join an oilsharing pact with Canada, Japan and most European Economic Community members, an E.C.G. spokesman said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Arab summit meeting in Rabat agreed on a program of aid to countries and forces confronting Israel$1billion a year each to Egypt and Syria, $300,000 a year to Jordan and $50million a year to the Palestine Liberation Organization, conference sources said. The Arab League will also make a single $150million payment to Southern Yemen for the lease of the strategic Perim Island at the southern entrance to the Red Sea. The final communiqu marked the yielding of King Hussein of Jordan to the insistence of the others on recognition of the P.L.O. as sole representative of the Palestinian Arabs. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Few Sign Campaign Code
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 29 (AP)Less than half the candidates running for the state and Federal offices in Connecticut this year have signed the state's Fair Campaign Practices Code, the State Elections Commission said today. Signing voluntary. The latest tabulation shows that 283 candidates signed the code, including Ella T. Grasso, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, and Thomas Pallone, gubernatorial nominee of the George Wallace party.

title: Ribicoff Is Heavy Favorite Despite Spirited Challenge
description: HARTFORD  Unless sheer drive and determination can overtake a huge lead at the last moment, United States Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff is expected to beat his Republican challenger overwhelmingly at the polls next week.

title: Justices to Decide if Lawyers' Minimum Fees Are PriceFixing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the minimum fees that many bar associations have for years required lawyers to charge their clients are a form of illegal pricefixing.

title: Priest, 79, Beaten to Death In Jersey Rectory Robbery
description: PATERSON, Oct. 29  A 79yearold Catholic priest who worked for the last 23 years in St. Boniface Church in the city's downtown section was beaten to death this morning during daylight robbery of the rectory.

title: Racing Bill Goes To Byrne
description: TRENTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Assembly passed a bill today calling for yearround horse racing in New Jersey, but shelved another bill aimed at determining how much local communities could benefit from betting.

title: Jersey Hearing on the $550,000 Rockefeller Gift to Ronan Delayed
description: TRENTON, Oct. 29  The chairman of the New Jersey joint legislative committee that will investigate Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller's gift of $550,000 to Dr. William J. Bonen, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said today that the inquiry's public ing would be delayed for a month.

title: G.O.P. BID FOR FUNDS TERMED SUCCESSFUL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The National Republican Congressional Committee said today that a lastminute appeal for big campaign contributions had brought good results.

title: Launching Delayed Again
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 29 (UPI)The launching of the weather satellite ITOSG, scheduled for Thursday, has been rescheduled for Nov. 13 because of problems with the electrical system, an Air Fore official said today. The nation's newest weather satellite was originally scheduled to be launched today. An earlier electrical problem caused rescheduling of the launching for Thursday.

title: Goodell Asserts Deserters Lack Faith in Review Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) Charles Goodell, chairman of the Clemency Review Board, said today that lack of trust by deserters and draft evaders was the reason so few had applied for clemency.

title: Virginia Bank Calls Off Unusual Stock Offering
description: The Hirschfeld Bank of Commerce, a bank being organized in tidewater Virginia with ambitious plans to raise as much as $76million in initial capital, has run into a storm of opposition from oorporate executives and regulators.

title: PHASE TWO OPENS IN SUIT BY MAHEU
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29The second phase of Robert A. Maheu's defamation suit against Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive industrialist, opened today.

title: Water Main Break Halts Lower East Side Trains
description: A 20inch water main burst on the Lower East Side early yesterday morning, tearing a jagged 30by10foot hole in the intersection of the Bowery and Delancey Street.

title: Democrats Now Lead Connecticut District Rolls
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 29 The last of Connecticut's six Congressional districts to remain a Republican bastion the Fourth, which takes in Fairfield County  fell to the Democrats today in a new count of registered voters.

title: Bernard Castro Jr. Slain, Wife Arrested, in Florida
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Oct. 29Bernard Castro Jr., 26yearold heir to the Castro Convertible furniture business was shot to death early this morning at his home here.

title: Ford Says a Runaway Congress Would Harm Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 President Ford, before leaving for a final week of preelection campaigning, said today during a news conference that a runaway Congress would make it much harder for him to conduct an international policy of peace.

title: Rutgers Captures Title In Jersey Harrier Meet
description: HOLMDEL, N. J., Oct. 29Princeton runners took the first two places, but Rutgers won the team title today at the seventh annual New Jersey college crosscountry championships at Holmdel County Park.

title: STATE GETS ROLE IN SCHOOL STRIKE
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 29Judge Merrit Lane Jr. today lifted his earlier order that striking Long Branch school employes and the Board of Education hold nonstop negotiations until a settlement is reached.

title: Assembly Votes to Restrict Testimony on Sex Conduct
description: TRENTON, Oct. 29A measure that would spare rape victims the humiliation of testifying about their sexual conduct before the alleged assault received overwhelming approval in the Assembly today.

title: ISRAELI TROOPS KILL 3 ARAB GUERRILLAS
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 29, (Reuters) Israeli soldiers today intercepted and killed three Arab guerrillas who infiltrated from Lebanon last night while Israeli forces were continuing a wide search for other infiltrators.

title: Rangers Are Wary Of Rugged Islanders
description: They used to laugh when the Rangers played the Islanders. Probably for good reason, with the Rangers running up 11 victories in their last 12 meetings. No more, however. The smiles will turn to sweat at 7:35 tonight when the teams meet at Madison Square Garden in a sudden battle of equality.

title: Hialeah Deal Hits Obstacle
description: MIAMI, Oct. 29The proposed sale of Hialeah's racing dates to Gulfstream Park took a complex and confused turn today. State Attorney General Robert Shevin has issued an opinion in Tallahassee that the sale is illegal, but the written opinion will not be available until tomorrow.

title: Makers of Labels and Officers Fined $272,500 on Price Fixing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 (AP),Seven major paper label makers and eight officers were fined $272,500 for price fixing, and five officers were ordered to make public speeches about their crime, a judge said today.

title: Congress: The Region
description: The Times recommendations in Congressional elections in the metropolitan region, including Suffolk, Nassau and Westchester Counties, the lower Hudson Valley and parts of New Jersey and Connecticut follow:

title: Rivals Showing Awe Over Unbeaten Yale
description: Astonishment would be the best way to describe Jack Musick's feelings about Yale after the Undefeated Elis trounced Cornell last Saturday, Yale was the best team we've played in the last couple of years. They're just overpowering. Unless somebody gets them on a down day, they're ping to be tough to beat the rest of the way, Musick said.

title: Magruder Says Mitchell Did Not Object to Plan to Bug McGovern Hotel Room in '72
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The jury in the Watergate coverup trial was told today that form er Attorney General John N Mitchell heard aboutand die net object toa plan to but the hotel room that Senator George McGovern, then the leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, was to occupy at the 1972 Democratic National Convention at Miami Beach.

title: Stale Poll Shows Conservatism Ebbing
description: The strong conservative trend of recent years in New York State has receded noticeably since the political departure of Richard M. Nixon, with the slack being taken up by new liberal support.

title: WAYNE O. REED DIES; U.S. EDUCATION AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Dr. Wayne O. Reed, retired associate United States Commissioner of Education for FederalState Relations, and an early advocate of aviation education, died Sunday of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

title: The Profit Machine
description: KENSINGTON, Calif.The price of oil all over the world is unjustifiably high now, if only for one reason: The people who use it are starting to say it is. Hints are beginning to appear that officials in some big oilexporting countries feel the same way and would like the price to come down.

title: Ford Goes to Home Town To Help G.O.P. Candidate
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. Oct. 29President Ford received a wet but rousing welcome today as he flew into his old Congressional district to campaign for a Republican challenger in a close House race.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Oct. 29Camille Henry isn't ashamed to remember he has either been watching, playing, coaching, admit that his life has been onedimensional. Since he can scouting, reading or talking hockey. But it has been a full, rewarding life, nevertheless. He has played professionally for 20 years, coached a team in the World Hockey Association and handled matters in the front office. Now he's starting another career. Somethnig besides hockey? No way.

title: Machinists Vote on Pact
description: MIAMI, Oct, 29 (UPI)About 1,200 members of the International Association of Machinists voted last night on a proposal that may end the 106day walkout against National Airlines. Results were not expected until later in the week. The proposed settlement was reached in a long bargaining session in Washngton last week, but no details were disclosed.

title: Columbia Pictures' Shift In Par Value Is Approved
description: Stockholders of Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., approved yesterday a previously announced proposal to reduce the par value of the company's common stock to 10 cents a share from $2.50 and the preferred stock to 10 cents a share from $1.

title: Champion Vague on Retiring
description: KINSHASA, Zaire. Wednesday, Oct. 30 (AP)  They took my title away from me unjustly and I want to hang on to it for a few months, said Muhammad Ali today after his eighthround knockout of George Foreman last night.

title: Preelection Recess At Princeton Finds Students Apolitical
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 29Four years ago, Princeton University declared a preelection recess, and young campus activists spread out to work on political campaigns.

title: Detectives Investigating Bombings
description: City detectives from the bomb section are continuing their investigation of the five bombings of banking and corporate centers in Manhattan early last Saturday, for which a Puerto Rican nationalist group said it was responsible.

title: PRESIDENT NAMES AN ENERGY TEAM; SAWHILL RESIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29President Ford announced today the forced resignation of Federal Energy Administrator John C. Sawhill and the selection of Andrew E. Gibson, a supporter of the merchant marine, to succeed him.

title: Continuity in Bonn
description: At a time of considerable instability in the democratic countries of Europe, even state and local elections take on heightened interest. There was unusual curiosity European Community and NATO capitals about the effect of last weekend's state elections in Bavaria and Hesse on Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's fivemonthold West German coalition.

title: Ignoring Bad News, Market Advances on Broad Front
description: Spurred by a continuing decline in shortterm interest rates, the stock market ignored some bearish news yesterday and registered its bigggest gain in almost three weeks.cent from 11 per cent or to 11 per cent from 11 per cent. Many banks recently have lowered this key interest rate, which they charge their most creditworthy corporate customers.

title: Text of Arab Resolution at Rabat
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 29 (Reuters)Following is the text in an unofficial translation from French of the resolution adopted last night by the Arab summit conference here and published today by the official Moroccan News Agency.

title: New Chief of Energy Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Andrew Edward Gibson seems on the surface to be an unlikely choice to head the Federal energy agency. His life has been ships and shipbuilding. But former associates of his, like Peter G. Peterson, were rooting for him today after President Ford announced that Mr. Gibson would succeed John C. Sawhill in the post.

title: Citizens Panel in West Virginia Backs Controversial Textbooks
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 29 (UPI)A special citizens committee issued a favorable report tonight on a series of school textbooks that has caused controversy and protest for two months.

title: West Germans Get Fight on Home TV
description: MAINZ, West Germany, Oct. 29 (AP)  Only a few hours before the Muhammad AliGeorge Foreman heavyweight title fight in Kinshasa, Zaire, early tomorrow, the West German television system purchased the rights for live coverage of the bout.

title: PROFIT GAINS 23% AT UNION PACIFIC
description: Freight rate increases totaling more than 20 per cent in the last year helped the Union Pacific Corporation, parent of the railroad of the same name, to report record revenues and earnings for the third quarter and first nine months this year.

title: A Key Precinct Shows Bout Was Loser
description: The Garden did over $400,000 and the Los Angeles Forum collected $174,000 for screening the latest Fight of the Century last night, and 50million poeple saw it over home television.

title: Urban Blight
description: I walked through the edges of the city And saw the late afternoon light Impeach The squalid district of Quandary Near the waterfront of Desolation. The place there mainlined blight.

title: Main Break Rips a 30by10Foot Hole in Bowery Intersection
description: A 20inch water main burst on the Lower East Side early yesterday morning, tearing a jagged 30by10foot hole in the intersection of the Bowery and Delancey Street.

title: Preelection Recess At Princeton Finds Students Apolitical
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 29Four Years ago, Princeton University declared a preelection recess, and young, campus activista spread out to work on political campaigns.

title: 3 PROTEST IN SOVIET BUT ARE NOT SEIZED
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29 (AP) Three young Soviet Jews demonstrated here today in support of the rightto go to Israel, and, in a rare move, policemen let them go free instead of taking them into custody.

title: California Republicans Expect to Take a Beating on Election Day
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29Unless they find a miraculous formula in the next week, California Republicans are expected to take a beating on Election Day.

title: KuttnerLed Group Is Sued by Texfi
description: Texfi, Inc., one of the world's largest manufacturers of doubleknit fabrics, filed suit yesterday in the United States District Court in Greensboro, N.C., charging that group headed by Ludwig Kuttner, West German industrialist, was seeking to take control of Texfi.

title: About New York Hugh Carey Looks Ahead
description: The election is not yet here, but Robert M. Morgenthau, acting as if he had it in the bag, kept his campaign headquarters closed last weekend. Then, on Sunday night, Governor Wilson spoke at a fundraiser on East End Avenue, and after he spoke he stood about and ate little sandwiches and nibbled on nuts and acted as if he had nothing else to do, either.

title: Pan Am Reports It Lost $459,000 in Third Quarter
description: Pan American World Airways, Inc., reported yesterday a net loss of $459,000 for the third quartertraditionally, its most profitable period. The loss compared with a thirdquarter profit last year of $22.6 million, equal to 56 cents a share.

title: WILSON STRESSES ANTICRIME STAND
description: Governor Wilson put his greatest emphasis at street rallies here yesterday on his anticrime stance, and drew his loudest cheers on that issue.

title: Expo '74 in Last Week
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 29 (UPI)The Expo '74 World's Fair has begun its final week of operation with fair officials confident that the exposition will break even or possibly turn a profit. Total attendance through Sunday was 4.976.424.

title: SCHMIDT'S TALKS IN MOSCOW SLOW
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29Disagreement over Bonn's relationship to West Berlin hampered progress in the second day of talks here between the Soviet leadership and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany.

title: U.S. Studying Food Prices For Possible Illegal Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29At torney General William B. Saxbe disclosed today that the Justice Department is investigating the possibility that recent food price increases may have resulted from pricefixing or other illegal behavior. He said the inquiry involved sugar, beef, eggs, tuna and other basic costofliving items.

title: Books of The Times
description: WINTER IN THE BLOOD. By James Welch. 176 pages. Harper & Row. $6.95. James Welch, author of Winter in the Blood, is an American Indian, Blackfoot on his father's side and Gros Ventre on his mother's. He grew up on a reservation in Montana and attended his first schools there. Of his writing, he says: I have seen works written about Indians by whites... but only an Indian knows who he is. If he has grown up on a reservation he will naturally write about what he knows. And hopefully he will have the toughness and fairness to present his material in a way that is not manufactured by conventional stance. Whites have to adopt a stance; Indians already have one.

title: A Halloween Party and Other Fun for
description: A haunted greenhouse? Yes, a haunted greenhouse with Deadly Nightshade, Devil's Backbone, Witch's, Broom, the Devil's Shoestring and even Bloodroot, at the New York Botanical Garden's Halloween Party to be held in the greenhouse tonight and tomorrow night from 5 to 9 P.M.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The chairman of the bankrupt Investors Funding Corporation of New York and eight other defendants charged with conspiring to bribe the Mayor of Fort Lee moved to have their cases separated from that of the Valentine Electric Company, another defendant. Norman Danker, the chairman of the corporation, and the eight defendants joined with him in seeking the separation argued through attorneys in Federal Court in Newark that the reputation of Valentine as an allegedly mobconnected business would hurt their cases.

title: City Going Ahead With Cutback of Emergency Repair Program
description: The Beame administration said yesterday that, effective Friday, it was going ahead with plans to curtail sharply the city's program of emergency repairs in slum housing.

title: P.S.C. Examiner Opposes Western Union Rate Rise
description: ALBANY, Oct. 29 (UPI)A Public Service Commission examiner has recommened that the P.S.C. reject a rate increase request by Western Union Telegraph, saying the company had failed to prove the increase was justified.

title: Stags Triumph In W.H.A., 43
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP)Danny Gruen scored at 4:22 of sudden death overtime to night to give the Michigan Stags a 4.3 World Hockey Association victory over the Minnesota Fighting Saints.

title: U.S. Grain Pledge To India Reported In Kissinger Visit
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 29Secretary of State Kissinger met senior Indian officials today and diplomats said afterward that the United States would supply India at least 500,000 tons of grain at reduced prices.

title: GORDON B. AMBLER
description: Gorden B. Ambler, a lawyer, died Saturday at Nbrthern Westchester Hospital Center, Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 48 years old and lived in Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Jaworski Denies Charge He Has Discussed Case
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)Leon Jaworski, the former special Watergate prosecutor, said today that charges that he had discussed the Watergate coverup case on television panel shows were without foundation.

title: Dukes Held For Acting As Lawyer
description: Walter L. Dukes Jr., a former allAmerican at Seton Hall University who once played for the New York Knicks, was arrested yesterday, accused of practicing law in New York State without a license and of accepting legal fees from one of his clients.

title: Dairymen Sue for Price Aid
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 29 (AP) The Minnesota Farmers Union filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court today seeking to force Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz to raise milk support prices.

title: TIMES IS PERMITTED TO RUN AFRICA ADS
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday voided an order by the city's Commission on Human Rights barring The New York Times from running classified advertisements for employment in racially segregated South Africa.

title: BERTA C. M'DONALD
description: CHAR LOTTESVIILLE, Va., Oct. 29 (AP)Berta Coburn MacDonald, former promotion director of Harper's Bazaar magazine, died Saturday in the University of Virginia Hospital. She was 83 years old.

title: HighVoltage Line Kills Two Firemen After Bronx Blaze
description: Two firemen were electrocuted last night when an aluminum ladder they were maneuvering brushed an 11,000volt power line at a Bronx freight yard where they had helped extinguish a threealarm warehouse blaze.

title: COUNCILMEN WEIGH CITY RESIDENCY LAW
description: The City Council's Civil Service and Labor Committee moved yesterday to delete possible unconstitutional features from a proposed bill to mandate three years' city residency for municipal Civil Service employes.

title: Signposts to Disaster
description: PARIS  Fortyfive years ago the Great Depression began with a crash on Wall Street and by the time it staggered to its halt the whole world had been shaken out of fatdripping illusions. Now we appear to be on or over the brink of a similar collapse althoughas in 1929few leaders are willing to admit it and even the prissy word recession is disliked.

title: U.S. Aides Still See Role for Hussein in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON; Oct. 29 Government analysts feel that despite the Arab leaders declaration yesterday naming the Palestine Liberation Organization as the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people, King Hussein of Jordan cannot be ruled out of future Middle East negtotiations.

title: Lake Placid Already Aglow With 1980 Olympics Fever
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y.List weekend, a group of hearty men in blue blazers returned from Vienna to a hero's welcome in this tiny upstate resort. The townspeople gathered to escort their automobiles, press their hands and murmur Great job.

title: PRICES INCREASE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose sharply yesterday in stepped up trading.

title: Arson Suspect Is Suicide
description: ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Oct. 29 (UPI)A 22yearold woman accused of setting a Sept. 9 fire that killed seven persons in the Shildknecht Nursing Home was found hanged early today in her jail cell. Jack Fleck, Buchanan County Sheriff, said Debbie Withrow had hanged herself with a headband borrowed from another woman inmate.

title: ITALY ASKS MORO TO FORM CABINET
description: ROME, Oct. 29President Giovanni Leone tonight asked Foreign Minister Aldo Moro to attempt to form a new cabinet to solve the country's government crisis.

title: Opera: Ballo Restaged
description: This is the season for restagings at the New York City Opera. It was only a few weeks ago, that Don Giovanni had a facelift, after its disastrous entry two seasons ago. Last night it was the turn of Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera, which received its premiere in 1971. Nobody was very happy about the sets and direction. The sets have been retained, but there is a new staging by David Hicks, and two new singers in principal roles.

title: CITY SCHOOLS ACT ON FISCAL ABUSES
description: The Board of Education moved yesterday to strengthen its depleted audit staff as part of what it called a new gettough policy to curb financial abuses and irregularities by some community school districts.

title: Fan Killed in Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 29 (AP)One man was killed and two were wounded in a shooting that erupted tonight in a convention center just before the start of the showing of the Muhammad AliGeorge Foreman fight, the police said. The police identified the victim as John Robert Franklin, 27 years old, of Louisville. They said that Frank Hamblen, 51, also of Louisville, was charged with murder. The shooting apparently took place over a $100 bet, but the police did not know whether Franklin was involved in the wager.

title: AVIS DIVESTITURE PRESSED BY U.S.
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it had requested the Federal District Court in Hartford to appoint a trustee to sell the 52 per cent interest in Avis, Inc., the No. 2 car rental agency, held by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Ruling on Gurney Delayed
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 29 (UPI)A Federal judge delayed yesterday ruling on the legality of the 10count indictment against Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, but would not dismiss bribery and perjury charges against the Senator. Judge Ben Krentzman, in refusing to dismiss the charges, turned down 11 defense motions attacking each of the counts in the indictment against Senator Gurney and six codefendants.

title: Gambler Sitting in Car In Brooklyn Is Shot Dead
description: A man the police tentatively identified as a gambler was killed by three bullets in the head as he sat in a parked car near Prospect Park in Brooklyn last night.

title: Latin America's Role of food Exporter Threatened
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 24Under the crush of a rapidly increasing urban population and a strong government bias in favor of industrial growth, Latin America is threatened with losing its status as a net exporter of food in coming years.

title: Paris: Impressionism Celebration Drawing Throngs
description: PARIS  Some 10,000 people a day are flocking to the Grand Palais to visit the exhibition organized jointly by the Muse du Louvre and the Metropolitan Museum to celebrate the centenary of impressionism. If this pace keeps up, the records established by Picasso and Tutankhamen will be broken. In other words, we are dealing here with a phenomenon that relates less to art than to idolatry.

title: Calley Asks Court to Order Release From Army Prison
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) William L. Calley Jr. asked the Supreme Court today to order his release from a military prison.

title: NIGH COURT DECLINES STOCKHOLDERS' SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)  The Supreme Court declined today, to referee a fight over the future of a Beverly Hills, Calif. savings and loan association that has been ordered merged with subsidiaries of the Equity Funding Corporation of America.

title: DAVID JONES DIES; POET AND PAINTER
description: LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP)David Jones, the Welsh poe?? and painter, died yesterday a?? his home here. He was 78 years old.

title: Transcript of President's News conference on Domestic and Foreign Matters
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Following is the White House transcript of news conference held by President Ford today in the briefing room of the White House.

title: Davidson Out as W.F.L. Commissioner
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP)Gary Davidson resigned today as commissioner of the World Football League after an apparent showdown with Tom Origer, owner of the Chicago Fire, who had threatened to withdraw his team from the league.

title: BRITISH ANNOUNCE PLAN TO LEGISLATE MORE SOCIALISM
description: LONDON, Oct. 29The Labor Government announced legislative plans today to extend nationalization of private industry and inject more socialism into British society.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BACK WHEN This is the day when browsers and buyers begin to converge on Greenwich House (CH 24140), at 27 Barrow Street, for the 31st annual antiques show and sale. Starting at 7 P.M., the oldest continuing antiques spread in town will be previewed with a festive reception stressing the show's country harvest format this year, as longtime Village residents and hostesses dispense countrystyle refreshments and hospitality. The traditionally informal event opens at 1 P.M. and ends on Sunday.

title: Bank Cancels Offering
description: The Hirschfeld Bank of Commerce, being organized in Virginia, has withdrawn an unusual stock offering after it ran into a storm of opposition from corporate executives and state securities regulators. The bank says it will come up with a new financing plan to raise as much as $76million in original capital. Page 74.

title: NADER AND OLD FOE DEBATE ON ENERGY
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29Edward N. Cole, the recently retired President of the General Motors Corporation, debated for two hours with Ralph Nader today, then shook hands with the consumer advocate and said: At least you've got to give me credit for getting the lead out.

title: New SovietGerman Deal
description: ESSEN, West Germany, Oct. 29 (Reuters) A West German consortium said today it had agreed in Moscow with Soviet agencies on a third natural gas for pipes deal under which the Soviet Union would deliver at least 2.5billion cubic meters of gas annualy in return for 950,000 metric tons of heavy pipe to be financed by a German bank consortium credit of about $58.5 million. The consortium is led by Deutsche bank, A.G., with Commerzbank A.G., Dresdner Bank. A.G., and Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale as joint managers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Police Officer Stephen Lucadamo, accused of defaming his commanding officer, two sergeants and a woman officer with obscene and scurrilous graffiti on the lavatory walls of a Brooklyn station house, pleaded no defense at a brief departmental trial yesterday at police headquarters, 1 Police Plaza.

title: THIEU CRITICIZED BY LABOR LEADER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 29The head of South Vietnam's largest labor union today shifted away from his usual proGovernment position and issued an appeal for the eradication of corruption, the implementation of the Paris truce agreements and the establishment of democratic liberties.

title: Canal Break Floods A Rochester Suburb
description: Fifteen square miles of a wealthy Rochester suburb were flooded to a depth of four feetand in some places morewhen the State Barge Canal burst in the Monroe County hamlet of Bushnells Basin yesterday afternoon.

title: NIXON IS DISPUTED ON BID FOR TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Lawyers for the special prosecutor's office said today that former President Richard M. Nixon's assertion that he needs his original tapes and documents to prepare for his possible testimony at the Watergate coverup trial was baseless.

title: Freehold, Strike Over, to Open Today
description: New Jersey's struggling Sports Authority will finally start generating some parimutuel revenue for its Hackensack Meadowlands Complex today when Freehold Raceway begins a strike  delayed special meeting. The 60day meeting had been scheduled to open last Thursday, with the Authority getting most of the state's regular 7 per cent cut of the betting handle. But demands by the horsemen for a contract with the Authority had kept the harnessractrack closed.

title: LABOR TROUBLES SPREAD IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Oct. 29France today went into the 11th day of her most severe postal strike in two decades, and labor unrest was spreading to other sectors, from coal mines flagging economy and creating a potential social crisis for the sixmonth old Government.

title: Steel Production Declines by 0.6% In the Latest Week
description: For the first time in eight weeks, domestic steel production turned downward, dipping by 0.6 per cent to 2,850,000 tons in the week ended Oct. 26.

title: Mobutu on Ticket
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 30 (Wednesday)  On the back of the ticket for tonight's ForemanAli world heavyweight title fight, a photo of Mobutu Sese Seko, the President of Zaire, had been glued over the original printing. The spelling of Mobutu's name had been incorrect on the original ticket printed. The printing was done in the United States.

title: Seekers of Puerto Rico Independence Expect Hearing Before U.N. Unit Today
description: Puerto Rican advocates of independence fur the island expect to get another hearing today before the United Nations' special 24nation Committee on Colonialism, amid widely differing views of their following at home and on the mainland.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1974

title: KENT CASE LACKS BALLISTICS DATA
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 29Government lawyers conceded today in their opening statement in the Kent State trial that they had no ballistic evidence to connect any single Ohio National Guard weapon with the killing and wounding of students on the Kent State University campus on May 4, 1970.

title: FOREIGN DOCTORS CRITICIZED HERE
description: New York State is becoming overdependent on foreignborn and foreign  educated physicians, many with inadequate medical ability, the State Board of Regents declared in a report yesterday that recommended steps to reverse the trend.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 47

title: Mental Hospital Upstate Is Equipped but Empty
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y.More than a year after it was supposed to have opened, an elaborate state institution here for the mentally retarded has a director, a staff of about 180and no patients.

title: Two in Court Recant 1967 Testimony That Helped Convict Carter and Artis
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 29Two witnesses whose testimony it 1967 helped to convict Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis of a triple murder recant. ed their testimony here today at a court hearing for a new trial.

title: SHAKEDOWNS LAID TO 5 IN RACIAL UNIT
description: Five men who visited construction sites, allegedly under the pretext of seeking jobs for minority workers, were charged yesterday with using bombs, arscn and personal threats to extort money from Bronx contractors.

title: Women's Movement Is Scored By Mrs. Keating on Abortions
description: Barbara Keating, the Conservative party candidate for United States Senator from New York, deplored yesterday some of the causes that she said the women's rights movement has identified so exclusively with.

title: Ali Regains Title, Flooring Foreman
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Wednesday, Oct. 30Under an African moon in the darkness before awn today, a bee battered a lion as Muhammad Ali registered an eighthround knockout of George Foreman and regained the world heavyweight title at the age of 32 after a lapse of more than seven years.

title: Kraber's Program Lives Up to Billing As Flute Marathon
description: Karl Kraber's flute recital on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall lived up to its billing as a marathon, lasting nearly three hours with Mr. Kraber playing almost continuously. And he played very well, too, with a clean, sweetly focused tone, minimal breathiness and longlined, seamless phrasing.

title: Supreme Court Agrees to Reexamine The Legality of Capital Punishment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Supreme Court decided today to reexamine the legality of capital punishment for the first time since a 5to4 majority ruled in 1972 that the death penalty, as then applied, was unconstitutional.

title: MRS. FLEISCHMAN
description: Sylvia Burd Fleischman, widow of Arthur Fleischman, who, was president of Fleischman Burd Metals, Inc., dealer in precious metals, died Sunday at her home, 5400 Fieldstan Road, Riverdale, the Bronx. She was 70 years old.

title: Priest, 79, on Phone With a Parishioner, Is Beaten to Death in Paterson Robbery
description: PATERSON, Oct. 29A 79yearold Roman Catholic priest who worked for the last 23 years in St. Boniface Church in the city's downtown section was beaten to death this morning during a daylight robbery of the rectory.

title: A Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Priest Is Slain
description: A 79yearold Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Francis Man English, was beaten to death during a robbery in the rectory of the St. Bdniface Church in Paterson, N.J. A parishioner, who had been talking to him on the phone, heard the priest cry, Oh, my Gud, they're killing me. Page 49.

title: Cypriotes, at U.N., Exchange Charges On Island's Strife
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29Seated side by side, representatives of the Turkish and Greek Communities on Cyprus blamed each other today for the years of fighting on the island.

title: Lake Placid Already Aglow With 1980 Olympics Fever
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y.Last weekend, a group of hearty men in blue blazers returned from Vienna to a hero's welcome in this tiny upstate resort. The townspeople gathered to escort their automobiles, press their hands and murmur Great job.

title: Muskie Criticizes Ford
description: PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 29 (UPI)  Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, criticized the Ford Administration today for not following through on its pledges of openness in government. Specifically, he criticized President Ford's veto of a package of amendments aimed at closing loopholes in the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Lopez Ring Victor
description: PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 29 (AP)  Jimmy Lopez, New England lightweight champion, scored a unanimous 10round decision tonight over Jose Resto of New York in a nontitle bout. Lopez weighed 129 pounds, Resto 134.

title: In Paris, Women Are Captivated By the Voluminous, Booted Look
description: PARISIt is not absolutely obligatory to wear highheel boots with the long skirts almost everybody has adopted here this fall. Some women have found they could get, by perfectly adequately with the colored stockings that are far more readily available here than they are, say, in New York. When someone buys a new skirt, dress or coat, she simply heads for the nearest hosiery counter and picks up some pantie stockings to Match. Attention to details counts.

title: WILLIAM J. SHEEHAN
description: William J. Sheehan, a retired vice president and regional manager in Boston for Doremus & Co., advertising and public relations agency, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Newton Centre, Mass. He was 72 years old.

title: All U.N. Sessions Closed to Public Following Threats
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29The United Nations today barred visitors indefinitely from public meetings as a result of anonymous bomb threats over the last two days.

title: Prison Escape Foiled
description: CUMMINS PRISON FARM, Ark., Oct. 29 (UPI)  Two prison inmates trying to escape through a minimum security unit under construction were shot and wounded by guards late yesterday, a spokesman said. Both men are reported in good condition at the prison infirmary.

title: Bridge: Swiss Team Championship Is Captured by 6 Top Stars
description: Six topranked stars scored a convincing victory in the Swiss team championship, which concluded the Metropolitan Regionals at the New York Hilton Hotel here Monday.

title: Carey Gets a Tepid Wall St. Reception
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey brought his message that a change is overdue to a noontime rally yesterday in the Wall Street area.

title: PRICES OF SUGAR MOVE UP SHARPLY
description: Sugar prices rose yesterday bath in the spot and wholesale markets as the commodity continued its spiraling climb at both raw and retail levels.

title: Bodies of Couple Found In a Clearing in Alabama
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Oct. 29 (AP)The bound and gagged bodies of the daughter of a Huntsville publisher and her husband have been found in a clearing near the Big Cove community.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Action, Not Words, on Inflation Is the Main Demand in Savannah
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 29 There is no mistaking the people of this old city for anything but Southerners.

title: MRS. VAGUIDE S. GUIREY
description: Mrs. Vaguide Sheretlock Guirey, widow of Prince Kadir Guirey, a descendant of the Tatar khans who ruled Crimea before the Czars, died Saturday in her home at 50 East 96th Street. She was 81 years old.

title: JAMAICA BUYING COMPANY SHARES
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Jamaican government, involved in a bauxite royalty dispute with the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation and Reynolds Metals, Ltd., has been buying shares of the two companies on the New York Stock Exchange, the governor of the Bank of Jamaica said today.

title: Stock Prices Soar
description: Buoyed by a continued decline in interest rates, the stock market yesterday made its best gain in almost three weeks, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 25.50 points. Traders apparently ignored the news that the Government's index of leading business indicators fell 2.5 per cent in September. Details on Page 63.

title: Lefkowitz, Abrams Debate Prosecution of Oil Concern
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and his Democratic opponent, Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx, heatedly debated yesterday Mr. Lefkowitz's legal action against an oil company accused of hoarding oil during last winter's energy crisis.

title: PRESIDENT NAMES AN ENERGY TEAM; SAWHILL RESIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29President Ford announced today, the forced resignation of Federal Energy Administrator John C. Sawhill and the selection of Andrew E. Gibson, a supporter of the merchant marine, to succeed him.

title: Harry Kalven Jr. Is Dead at 60; Jury Expert Taught at Chicago
description: Harry Kalven Jr., a professor of law at the University of Chicago and an authority on the First Amendment and the American jury system, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Chicago. He was 60 years old.

title: Tenants at Rochdale Village Win Suit on Carrying Charges
description: Tenants of the Rochdale Village Cooperative in Queens won a battle against the state yesterday when a State Supreme Court justice nullified a 32 per cent increase in carrying charges that had been approved by the State Housing Commissioner.

title: SAMUEL JACOBSON
description: Samuel Jacobson, a founder and former president of F. Jacobson & Sons, manufacturer of Jason and Excello men's shirts, died Monday in New York Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nixon in Critical Condition After Surgery
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 29Sudden intensive internal bleeding sent former President Richard M. Nixon into shock today about six hours after surgeons completed an operation to combat a potentially lethal blood clot.

title: Palestinians View State As a Tactical Objective
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 29Leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization visualize a state that is meant above all to provide an independent home for a people who have been stateless for a quarter of a century.

title: Priest Is Slain
description: A 79yearold Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Francis Aidan English, was beaten to death during a robbery in the rectory of the St. Boniface Church in Paterson, N.J. A parishioner, who had been talking to him on the phone, heard the priest cry, Oh, my God, they're killing me. Page 49.

title: U.N. UNIT URGES AID ON MISSING IN WARS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 (UPI)The Social Committee gave unanimous support today to a move backed by the United States urging the United Nations to lake action in helping account for missing and dead in wars. About a thousand Americans are still missing in Indochina.
