title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Bridge Authority Says It Will Fight Toll Cuts in Court
description: CAMDEN, Oct. 29John R. Bunting, vice chairman of the Delaware River Port Authority, said today that if the authority was required to roll back tolls on its three bridges between New Jersey and Pennsylvania it would block the order in court.

title: WILLOWBROOK CARE ASSAILED BY EXPERT
description: An expert in the field of early child development yesterday strangely critized the educational program at the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded, on Staten Island, and said the institution's barren physical and psychological environment led to regressive development among residents.

title: Red Smith
description: There was no understanding George Foreman but the crowd in Madison Square Garden didn't care. The crowd in the Gardenin the darkness it looked pretty close to a full househad paid up to $30 a seat to watch Muhammad Ali for the last time, and when he wound up on his feet with the heavyweight championship of the world once more in his possession, his idolators didn't ask how he got there. For them it was fulfillment of a wish they had scarcely dared to believe could come true, and they didn't care at all how it looked to anybody else. They knew what they had seenForeman counted out in the eighth round. On the closedcircuit telecast from Africa last night the sound was so distorted that no description or commentary came through. When the customers left the Garden, none of them knew the time of the knockout, or cared. When they saw Ali fire a 1, 2 combination and Foreman drop like an ox, that was enough.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Tornado Strikes Gulf Town
description: CROWLEY, La., Oct. 29 (AP) A tornado, one of several severe storms to strike southern Louisiana today, chewed a twomile strip of this city to rubble and killed a man. Only a week before, residents had carried out the last rubbish from Hurricane Carmen. Total damage throughout the state was estimated at $10million, with about $7.5million of the total here.

title: Aide Beaten at Palestinian Office Here
description: Three men forced their way into the Park Avenue office of the Palestine Liberation Organization yesterday, beat an official with a piece of lead pipe and fired at least two shots before fleeing, the police said.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: BOSTON YOUTH FACES RIGHTS INDICTMENT
description: BOSTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)A white teenager was charged today in Boston with Federal civil rights violations, including possession of a molotov cocktail, stemming from his arrest near a newly desegregated high school earlier this month.

title: Cancer Center Is Formed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (UPI) Dr. Frank Rauscher, head of the National Cancer Institute, announced today the formation by Hahnemann, Thomas Jefferson University and Temple University Hospitals of a Comprehensive Cancer Center. He said it would improve and expand health care in southeastern Pennsylvania, Delaware and southern New Jersey.

title: Senator Brooks Hails Dole
description: LAWRENCE, Kan. Oct. 29 (AP)  Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, said today that Senator Robert Dole ably represented his constituents in Kansas. The Senator expressed his friendship for and support of his Kansas colleague

title: MRS. RUSSELL L. GILBERT
description: Mrs. Geraldine Payne Gilbert, the wife of Russell L. Gilbert, a retired stockbroker, died yesterday at her home. She was 78 years old and lived at 640 Park Avenue.

title: Music: A Modern Flute
description: Most flute recitals zero in on the rococo era of the 18th century, when an enormous quantity of music for the instrument was written. Often the result, even when performances are on a supervirtuosic level, is boredom with too much of a good thing. Doriot Anthony Dwyer's series of three concerts, which began Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, will run no risk in any such direction as that, at least.

title: Chinese Airline Opening Direct Service to Paris
description: PEKING, Oct. 29 (Reuters)A Chinese jet airliner took off for Karachi and Paris today, inaugurating China's first commercial air service to Western Europe.

title: Seiling Sold by Rangers
description: The Rangers solved one of their excess riches problems last night by selling Rod Selling to the Washington Capitals for the $30,000 waiver price.

title: Dutch Raid Prison Chapel And Rescue All Hostages
description: THE HAGUE, Thursday, Oct. 31In a surprise move this morning, Dutch marines and police units stormed a prison chapel and rescued 15 hostages who had been held since Saturday at the jail in Schveningen, just outside the Netherlands capital. The four captors were arrested.

title: People and Business
description: H. Virgil Sherrill, president and chief executive of the brokerage house of Shields Model Roland, Inc., was named here yesterday to serve as board chairman of the Securities Industry Association, the investment community's trade group. He will 14 installed at the S.I.A. national convention in December.

title: Labor Candidate Arrested
description: WOODHAVEN, Mich., Oct. 30 (AP)The police here said that Peter Signorelli, the United States Labor party candidate for governor, was arrested today and charged with breach of peace. Officers said that Mr. Signorelli had been released on his own recognizance. The authorities declined to disclose details of the incident.

title: Report Due on Alleged Illegal L.I. Police Search
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 30  A report on what has been described as an illegal search of a Roosevelt pharmacist's home last week will be made to Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso tomorrow, a spokesman for Mr. Caso said today.

title: The Ghosts of Halloween Past and Present Evanesce Over the City Streets
description: Wideranging adult misconceptions about the true nature and significance of Halloween were deplored and debunked in an informal survey conducted by The New York Times with a sample group picked at random from Leslie Silverman's thirdgrade class at Public School 145.

title: Parts Foreign Minister In Israel for 4Day Visit
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 30 France's Foreign Minister, Jean Sauvagnargues, arrived in Israel tonight for a fourday official visit, the first by a French minister in this country's 26 years.

title: New Summary and Index
description: International

title: Business Briefs
description: Underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation marketed yesterday 4 million new common shares of the Southern California Edison Company common stock at $17.75 per share. The utility plans to use the proceeds of the sale to repay part of its shortterm debt.

title: Planning Agency Votes Sports Center for 57th Street
description: A $10million sports center proposed for the site of the defunct Great Northern Hotel on West 57th Street was approved by the City Planning Commission yesterday over the objection of a Commissioner who argued that the project would be an unwarranted intrusion in prime shopping area.

title: 3 VETO U.N. OUSTER OF SOUTH AFRICANS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 30  The United States, Britain and France tonight vetoed a resolution in the Security Council to expel South Africa from the United Nations.

title: Tampa Gets N.F.L. Franchise; Seattle Next on Expansion List
description: The National Football League yesterday went for more. The 26 owners sold an expansion franchise to Tampa, Fla., and to Torn McCloskey, a Philadelphia builder, for $16million and the league indicated that it would do more. Another franchise for Seattle would be granted to an unknown owner, to be cited soon. Furthermore there would be two more franchises, bringing the total to 30.

title: Tape Cited as Evidence Police Coerced Carter Witness
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 30Hear me, now I assure you I will go to the top people in the State of New Jersey. I promise you this.

title: NIXON'S CONDITION CALLED IMPROVED; BLEEDING HALTED
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 30 Former President Richard M. Nixon's internal bleeding has apparently stopped and his condition showed some improvement after three blood transfusions, but he remains on the critical list as he receives intensive care, Mr. Nixon's doctor said today.

title: Tuna Concern Fined
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (UPI)StarKist Foods Inc. and its Samoan subsidiary were fined $4,000 each after they pleaded guilty today to violating Federal law by shipping tuna fish containing harmful material.

title: Ray Says He Has Addresses and Phone Numbers of Others Involved in Events Leading to King Killing
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 30James Earl Ray testified today that he had addresses and telephone numbers of others involved in events leading to the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968, but that he had never given most of this information to his lawyers.

title: N.F.L. in Drug Inquiry
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 30 (AP)  A National Football League spokesman said today that a routine league investigation had begun on the arrest of Mike Ernst, Cincinnati Bengals' reserve quarterback, on drug charges.

title: Thieu Ousts 3 Army Aides In Seeming Bow to Protests
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 31Apparently bowing to opposition pressure, President Nguyen Van Thieu last night announced the transfer of three powerful military commanders from their posts.

title: Salvation Army Fills Post
description: Lieut. Col. Orval A. Taylor, greater New York unified commander of the Salvation Army since 1971, has been named chief secretary of the Army's Southern Territory, with headquarters in Atlanta. He will be succeeded here by Brig. Walter C. French, commander of the Northeastern Ohio Division, whose offices are in Cleveland.

title: Carey Joined by Kennedy In Homecoming Campaign
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey took his campaign for Governor home to Brooklyn yesterday, but it was a homecoming with a difference. He brought Senator Edward M. Kennedy with him.

title: Schmeling Is Surprised
description: HAMBURG, Germany, Oct. 30 (UPI)The former world boxing champion, Max Schmeling, said today that Muhammed All's knockout over George Foreman came as a giant surprise. Schmeling who won the title in 1930, added: The fight was not nice, but it proved once again technique defeats strength.

title: LAWYER FOR NIXON DROPS TAPES BID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Because of former President Richard M. Nixon's critical illness, his lawyer dropped today what had been an urgent request for original White House tape recordings and documents.

title: Americans Feel Ill Will In Laos City
description: LUANG PRABANG, Laos, Oct. 29In this tiny royal capital, where the Communistled Pathet Lao has made its most pronounced impact since the coalition Government was formed last April, there is a slight air of antiAmericanism.

title: KENT STATE JURORS VISIT SITE OF CLASH
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (AP)Jurors and defendants walked across the Kent State University campus today, retracing the steps of the National Guardsmen and student antiwar protesters who clashed there early 4 years ago.

title: Events Today
description: TUBSTRIP, a comedy by A. J, Kronengoid, directed by Jerry Douglas, starring Calvin Culver, at the Mayfair Theeter, 235 West 46th Street, 7.

title: A Borzois' Breeder Owes All to a Letter;
description: It was a letter that started Mrs. Lorraine Groshans in borzojs. I couldn't decide whether I wanted samoyeds, salukis or borzois, she said, so l wrote letter tobreeders of all three. The most interesting answer came from a borzoi owner end I wound up, buying a puppy bitch.

title: Senator Asks Energy Steps
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) Senator James Abourezk, Democrat of South Dakota, asked today that the Senate Interior Committee schedule hearings on a national energy policy before Ford Administration plans are set in concrete. Mr. Abourezk said there were obvious deficiencies in a draft of a proposal to make the nation independent in energy resources that has been prepared by the Federal Energy Administration.

title: Police Persuaded Brooklyn Slaying Is Not MobLinked
description: Police officials said yesterday that they did not feel that the murder Monday night of a Brooklyn man with mob connections was a gangland execution.

title: 32 KILLED AS PLANE CRASHES IN ARCTIC
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Oct. 30 (Reuters)A fourengine plane crashed through the Arctic icecap last night, killing 32 of the 34 oil technicians and crewmen aboard, a spokesman for the aircraft's owners said today.

title: U.S. Leads by Stroke In World Amateur Golf
description: LA ROMANA, Dominican Republic, Oct. 30 (UPI)The United States Amateur champion, Jerry Pate, shot a oneoverpar 73 today to help the United States take a oneshot lead in the first round of the world amateur golf championship.

title: Steele Favors End to Election Of Hartford's State Secretary
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 30Representative Robert H. Steele, the Republican nominee for Governor of Connecticut, said today that he favored making the post of Secretary of the State appointive.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Arab Council of War
description: WASHINGTONThe Arab leaders who gathered in Rabat this week decided that a peace settlement was not a worthy objective, and that ultimate victory over Israel was within their grasp.

title: Nixon's Attacks of Phlebitis Believed Linked to Stress of Watergate Events
description: Doctors who have studied the effects of psychological stress on susceptibility to physical illness and, in particular, on the body's clotting mechanism, believe that pressures related to the Watergate scandal may have had a great deal to do with Richard M. Nixon's recent repeated attacks of phlebitis.

title: 4 Guerrilla Groups Denounce Arafat
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 30 Four militant Palestinian guerrilla groups have denounced Yasir Arafat, the bead of the Palestine Liberation Organization, for joining in what they regard as a declaration of reconciliation with King Hussein of Jordan.

title: 4 PRODUCERS SET A COPPER ACCORD
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 30 (UPI)Representatives of four major copper producing countries, meeting in the Peruvian capital this week, have agreed on common action to increase falling copper prices.

title: Papadopoulos Is Described as Melancholy in Aegean Exile
description: KEA. Greece, Oct. 30From the approaching ferry, Kea looks like most other Aegean islands: bare and rocky, a sparking white village built like an amphitheater near the top of abrupt mountains, a steeple standing out among the low houses along the harbor.

title: Clark Tells Labor Group Javits Forgets Workers
description: Ramsey Clark, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, told a luncheon meeting of labor leaders yesterday that the NixonFord Aministration, and Senator Jacob K. Javits, the RepublicanLiberal whose seat he seeks, have forgotten the working people who built this country and all countries.

title: Javits Talks on Economy To a Wall Street Crowd
description: A few hundred people attracted by the amplified din of a fourpiece musical combo stood in Wall Street yesterday and heard a short lunchtime lecture on economics, along with some predictions of political success, from Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: Some Public Smoking Becoming a Crime Here
description: Smoking in supermarkets, elevators and a wide variety of public halls and, classrooms becomes a misdemeanor tomorrow in New York City, punishable by fines up to $1,000 and up to a year in jail.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Louise Larabee plays the role of ceramist nowadays, working in her bright airy studio on Union Square West turning out the stoneware fountains, planters and animals for which she has become known. What started out as a hobby back in 1965 has become a fulltime occupation.

title: Las Vegas Hotel Man Found Guilty of Tax Fraud
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 30Irving Resnick, a Tropicana Hotel Hotel executive, was found guilty yesterday on three counts of tax fraud by Judge Roger Foley in Federal District court.

title: BLACK STAGE UNITS TO HOLD FESTIVAL
description: The Black Theater Alliance, an association of 30 independent black theatrical groups, will hold its fourth annual festival of plays at the Harlem Cultural Council, Seventh Avenue and 137th Street, from next Wednesday through Dec. 8.

title: 3 Arrested as 75 Protest West Side Traffic Pattern
description: A onehour demonstration by 75 to 100 people protesting traffic conditions on West Side streets in the area from 72d to 79th Street caused by detours on the Henry Hudson Parkway led to the arrest of three men yesterday.

title: MILTON GOLDSTEIN
description: Milton Goldstein, a fundraiser, died Sunday at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 56 years old and lived at 333 Bronx River Road, Yonkers.

title: Lack of Funds Ending Drive on Illegal Guns
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 (AP) The Baltimore Police Department's gun bounty program, will be ended because of a lack of funds, department officials said today.

title: Carey and Wilson Campaigns Running Short of Funds
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey's campaign is running $700,000 in the red despite polls that show him the frontrunner and despite an acceleration of major contributions in anticipation of victory, according to the last preelection fi nancial reports compiled by the candidates.

title: SOVIET THAW SEEN ON WEST BERLIN
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany wound up three days of negotiations with Soviet leaders today amid indications that Moscow might be making some adjustments in its intransigence over West Berlin.

title: ClayCourts Plan Approved for Open
description: The way has been cleared for the West Side Tennis Club to convert half its grass courts to clay for the next United States Open championships.

title: He's 11, in Foster Care, and a Long Way From Horne
description: The day his fifth grade class said goodby to David there was a party in the classroom and the children wrote letters for David to remember them by.

title: Manhasset Bay Skipper Gets Achievement Honor
description: James B. Moore Jr., a past commodore of Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, received the Ned Anderson Achievement Award last night at the annual meeting, of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

title: Halt Urged in Buying Sprays That Might Hurt Ozone
description: An immediate halt to the purchase of spray cans using a propellant that some scientists fear may threaten the earth's protective ozone layer was recommended yesterday by the chairman of a committee appointed to assess the alleged threat.

title: CALLS REPORTED ON EVADERS LIST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The American Civil Liberties Union says overwhelming numbers of draft evaders have called to ask if they are named in a Justice Department computer list of men under indictment or investigation.

title: The District Attorneys
description: The Times recommendations in elections for District Attorney of New York, Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland counties follow:

title: TAPE IS PLAYED IN CARTER CASE
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 30Hear me, now I assure you I will go to the top people in the State of New Jersey., I promise you this.

title: 270,000 Cadillacs Recalled Because of Steering Defect
description: DETROIT, Oct. 30 (UPI)The Cadillac division of General Motors said today that it had begun recalling all of its 1973 models, with the exception of Eldorados, and some 1974 cars because of a defect in the steering system that could impair control.

title: Settlement of Pollution Case Is Accepted by High Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The United States Supreme Court has accepted the second outofcourt settlement of Vero mont's suit against the International Paper Company and New York over pollution of Lake Champlain.

title: Kissinger Assures India That C.I.A.Won't Interfere
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 30  Secretary of State Kissinger bluntly assured India today that the Central Intelligence Agency would not interfere in the political situation here.

title: Fraud Is Charged to 5 in Deal Involving Mexican Investments
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 30Indictments by a Nassau County grand jury of five persons and two companies in what was described as a major securities fraud involving $4million and 300 investors was announced here today by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: Irish Rovers' Songs And Audience Turn Concert Into Party
description: All the Irish Rovers had to do to get an enthusiastic response from their audience after they bounced out on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening to mention anything pertaining to Ireland. The audience clapped for Ireland. It clapped to the be of the Rovers' songs. It shaded out comments that kept even garrulous Will Millar, the leader of the group, on the alert for the potshots that fell into his running fire of commentary.

title: Testimony Is Heard Here On Kennedy Boy's Mugging
description: A young man accused of mugging John F. Kennedy Jr. told the police he had sold the boy's bike to buy two bags of cocaine, a policeman testified at a pretrial hearing yesterday.

title: FORD IS EXPECTED TO SHIFT CABINET
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30In the weeks between next Tuesday's election and the first of the year, President Ford will make over his Cabinet, replacing some but not all of theNixon appointees, according to White House officials and others close to the President.

title: Bulls To Celtics, 105104
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30 (UPI)The Chicago Bulls, helped by Chet Walker's 8 secondquarter points, built a 19poin halftime lead tonight and held on to beat the Boston Celtics, 105104.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 30 (AP) A 28yearold former airline stewardess testified today that the Boston Red Sox infielder, Rico Petrocelli, kicked and punched her in 1970 on a flight from Boston to Detroit.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: JACK  O  LANTERN JAMBOREES New York inclined to step out tonight, rather than stay at home for a Halloween cocktail and perhaps a fright movie on TV, have some diverse invitations for seasonal fun and games.

title: Dave Anderson
description: N'SELE, Zaire, Oct. 30Beyond his stucco villa, the Congo River flowed swiftly. On the lawn, several dozen Africans, men in their slacks and bright shirts and women in their long dresses, had come for a glimpse of the famous man, now that he was the world heavyweight champion again. They stood there quietly, thinking that Muhammad Ali probably was asleep. Five hours earlier he had dethroned George Foreman with an eighthround knockout. But suddenly he appeared. He carried a carved mahogany cane with inlaid ivory. He wore a pale blue shortsleeved shirt, black pants and scuffed work shoes. When he saw Budd Schulberg, he shook hands with the author of The Harder They Fall and hugged him.

title: Tricks' n' Treats Today At Central Park Zoo
description: The Parks Department will scare up some free Halloween tricks and treats for children today at a party in the Central Park Zoo from noon until 2 P.M.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: A PUERTO RICAN SEES GENOCIDE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30The United Nations heard charges today that North American imperialists were embarked on a plan of genocide in Puerto Rico that has led to sterilization of 200,000 women, or 35 per cent of those of childbearing, age.

title: Rivers of Sand, a Documentary
description: Robert Gardner's stunning documentary, Rivers of Sand, operates on two levels at once: It educates us about the daily life of the Hamar people of southwestern Ethiopia, and, while exploring an utterly alien culture, the narrative also dwells on a phenomenon that everyone knows wellthat is, male supremacy. The film opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art and will run through Tuesday.

title: Nassikas Backs Project Independence
description: John N. Nassikas, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, called on the Congress to take legislative action as soon as possible to implement Project Independence and Project Interdependence.

title: Gulf Western Industries Sets Sales and Earnings Records
17 Sales in 195971 Found For a Nursing Home Here
description: A search of city realestate registries by a community agency has turned up 17 changes of ownership for one typical private nursing home from December, 1959, to June, 1971.

title: ... and Old Boys Recall a Time of Tricks and No Treats
description: A long black stocking, packed with coal ashes from heel to toe, was all the Halloween equipment a New York boy needed before the candy manufacturers discovered that the sweet tooth paid better than an aching back.

title: A RIGBTIST PARTY FORMED IN BERLIN
description: BERLIN, Oct. 30The formation of a new political party designed to attract conservative and nationalist elements was announced here today by a group of rightwing political figures.

title: NIXON'S CONDITION CALLED IMPROVED; BLEEDING HALTED
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 30 Former President Richard M. Nixon's internal bleeding has apparently stopped and his condition showed some improvement after three blood transfusions, but he remains on the critical list as he receives intensive care, Mr. Nixon's doctor said today.

title: Woman Held, Man Sought On the Theft of a Sailboat
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 30 (AP)A New York City woman has been arrested and a man was sought here in connection with the alleged theft of a sailboat belonging to a couple who befriended. them at an uninhabited island in the Pacific.

title: Chile to Pay $58 Million
description: LONDON, Oct. 30 (Reuters) Chile and Britain signed an agreement under which British creditors will receive payment from Chile for debts totaling about $58million, the Foreign Office announced today. The payment will be made over nine years, a Foreign Office spokesman said. The totalChilean debt to Britain is about $289million, including the $58million.

title: Hunter Outvotes Jenkins for Young Award in American League
description: Jim (Catfish) Hunter, a leading contributor to the string of three straight world championships rung up by the Oakland A's, edged Ferguson Jenkins of the Texas Rangers yesterday in voting for the American League's Cy Young Award.

title: Thoreau's Old News
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind.  I am faced with the unpleasant task of teaching. Henry David Thoreau's Civil Disobedience to cynical, civically apathetic Midwestern college freshmen, most of Whom completed their last year in high school while Richard M. Nixon was finishing his last official year in the White House.

title: Newspaper Endorses Shapp
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (UPI)The Philadelphia Daily News endorsed Gov. Milton J. Shapp today for reelection. In an, editorial, the newspaper said that Governor Shapp, a Democrat, was not without blemishes but when they are compared to his accomplishments we will take him over Republican Drew Lewis. The Philadelphia Bulletin has also endorsed Mr. Shapp, while the Philadelphia Inquirer has backed Mr. Lewis.

title: Palestinian Coup
description: Leaders of the Arab world have dealt a major psychological blow to prospects for new ArabIsraeli agreements in the near future. Recognition of the Palestine Liberation Organization by the Rabat summit conference seems sharply to reduce the possibility of negotiations between Israel and Jordan leading ultimately to Israeli withdrawal from the Jordan West Bank. In effect, the Arab leaders have opted for an aggressive ideological stance rather than for a pragmatic position offering hope of early diplomatic movement.

title: Farmer's Befriending of Youth, Leads to Bistate Custody Battle
description: DOVER, Del., Oct. 30spontaneous act of kindness by a Delaware farmer who befriended, fed and gave a home to a New Jersey boy he found hungry and neglected on a Newark street corner last month has set the stage for a court fight between New Jersey and Delaware over custody of the boy.

title: All Has an Offer of $10Million For His Next Fight, He Says
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 30 Muhammad Ali, again the world heavyweight champion, spoke today of a mysterious $10million offer from an unidentified promoter for his next title fight, probably with Joe Frazier next year.

title: DAVID OPOCHINSKI
description: David Opochinski, president of Titra Film Labs, Inc., a company specializing in film processing and dubbing of sound, died yesterday at his home. He was 74 years old and lived at 277 West End Avenue.

title: 3% DROP SHOWN IN PRODUCTIVITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) Productivity dropped sharply in the third quarter while labor costs continued to soar, further adding to inflationary pressures, the Government reported today.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson Leaving Gallery
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University is planning to phase out its relationship with the New York Cultural Center, the opulent marble art gallery in Columbus Circle that it took over in 1969 from Huntington Hartford. The decision, according to Allen Russell, the center's president, has been made in the light of rising costs and an inadequate base of public support.

title: Polls Find Dole Now Even in Kansas
description: COLUMBUS, Kam, Oct. 29Six weeks ago Senator Robert Dole was trailing his Democratic opponent, Representative William R. Roy, in his reelection race by eight to led points in the opinion polls.

title: Held Anticompetitive
description: An administrative law judge of the Federal Trade Commission ruled yesterday that an $80million acquisition of stock in Airco, Inc., by the British Oxygen Company, Ltd., of London, was anticompetitive. Both companies produce oxygen.

title: 3% DROP SHOWN IN PRODUCTIVITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) Productivity dropped sharply in the third quarter while labor costs continued to soar, further adding to inflationary pressures, the Government reported today.

title: Alertness Is Half of Successful Street Vending
description: Inmates of the Branch Queens House of Detention, where rioting broke out four years ago over conditions therean outbreak that spread to four other city jails  are now pleading with the City Correction Department to spare the doomed institution.

title: Foy Asserts a Long Coal Strike Would Damage Future Performance
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corpora. tion reported yesterday thirdquarter net income had risen by 92.3 per cent on a sales gain of 50 per cent over the comparable 1973 figures.

title: Jack o'Lantern Riot Is a Yearly Display At an Upstate farm
description: CAMDEN, N. Y.At first it looks like another roadside stand, but then the hundreds of glowing jack o' lanterns come into view and visitors know they have arrived at Robert and Verda Will's CackleBerry Farm, a pumpkin lover's paradise. Thousands of the orangeyellow fruit, representing Halloween to many people, cover the hillside behind the fruit stand.

title: INFLATION HITS POOR HARDEST, U.S. SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) Inflation and unemployment are hitting the poor harder than any other income group, a Government study said today.

title: Zaire's Loss on Bout Is Around $4Million
description: Although there were some spectacular successes in the closedcircuit telecast of the Muhammad AliGeorge Foreman bout, it appeared yesterday the bout would cost the Zairian Government more than $4million because it fell far short of the breakeven point.

title: Bonn and Warsaw Initial 10Year Economic Accord
description: BONN, Oct. 30 (Reuters)West Germany and Poland today initialed a 10year agreement of economic cooperation, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

title: Inquest Under Way in Death of Fetus After Abortion
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30An unusual coroner's inquest began here today to determine whether a prominent obstetrician deliberately allowed a fetus to die when it might have been alive after an abortion.

title: Bout Lifts Morale of Zairians
description: Kinshasa, Zaire, Oct. 30It seems there are two kinds of Zaire citizens in Kinshasa today. One group is the more than 50,000 blearyeyed but happy Africans who watched the world heavyweight boxing championship fight during the early hours of this morning and who are talking about it today. The other group is listening.

title: PRIEST IS INDICTED IN WEST ST. ESCAPE
description: A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted a Roman Catholic priest and a correction officer on charges that they had played key roles in paving the way for seven major narcotics violators to escape on Sept. 22 from the Federal House of Detention on West Street. Six are still at large.

title: People in Sports
description: Henry Aaron the Atlanta slugger who broke Babe Ruth's career home run record, left for Japan yesterday with the assurance that the Braves would not stand in his way if he decided to sign with Milwaukee for the 1975 campaign. The Brewers would like to use Aaron as a designated hitter. They also regard Aaron as a gate attraction. Aaron finished the 1974 season with 733 career homers.

title: Screen.'Monster From Hell' and 'Vampire Hunter':Both Are Foolish but Respectable Fun
description: "Frankenstein and the Monster From Hell" and "Captain Kronos: Vampire Hunter," the new double bill from the Hammer horror-film factory in England, presents something of a problem. Anyone with a grain of sense shouldn't care less about them, but anyone who has a grain of sense as well as a fondness for horror films, especially the expensive-looking, mostly deadpan Hammer kind, can't afford to miss them.The two movies, which opened yesterday at the Liberty Theater and other houses around town, are foolish but fun in quite respectable ways.Of the two, "Captain Kronos" is easily the more foolish, and the more elaborately produced. The film introduces into movie vampire lore a superman of fine Nordic good looks, a slight German accent and a vow to go wherever evil is to be fought. To those of us of the World War II generation, a superman like Kronos (Horst Janson) is possibly a scarier concept than plain old blood-sucking, which may be beside the point to people who have doted on the comic-strip exploits of Captain Marvel and Clark Kent.I have a personal preference for conventional vampire movies in which every vampire shrinks before the sign of the cross, goes invisible in mirrors and can be efficiently dispatched with a stake through the heart. In this film, written and directed by Brian Clemens, there are, to quote the screenplay, as many varieties of vampire as beasts of prey. It takes all of Kronos's energies before he finally traps the fiends who have been ravaging a magnificent English country-side, stripping pretty little girls of their youth and leaving them in heaps of wrinkled flesh, washed up, at 15 or 16. The acting is terrible.Good old Peter Cushing, his hair blonder and more spit-curled than ever, shows up once again as the visionary doctor, the 19th-century father of body-part transplants, in "Frankenstein and the Monster From Hell." The setting is a hospital for the criminally insane run by Baron Frankenstein, who persists in trying to put people together in eccentric combinations God never intended.The Baron has learned a few things since the last time I saw him in the fastidious dress and manner of Mr. Cushing. There's now a good deal of dialogue about a patient whose head is rejecting the brain newly placed in it.Late in the story the Baron suggests, with a marvelously woeful sigh, that perhaps his career's ups and downs are the result of his always having relied too much on surgery and not enough on biochemistry.The film, written by John Elder and directed by Terence Fisher, is not without its intentional giggles. Compared with "Andy Warhol's Frankenstein," however, it is very straight and solemn, chock full of the old horror film values we don't see much of any more.

title: Japanese Bank Set for City
description: The Industrial Bank of Japan said yesterday it had received Federal Reserve Board approval to form a bank holding company and establish a full service commercial bank in New York City. The bank is to be called the Industrial Bank of Japan Trust Company. The company will primarily be a wholesale bank specializing in financing of trade between Japan and the United States, a company spokesman said.

title: AMEX PRICES UP FOR SECOND DAY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose again yesterday for the second straight session.

title: ... and Old Boys Recall a Time of Tricks and No Treats
description: A long black stocking, packed with coal ashes from heel to toe, was all the Halloween equipment a New York boy needed before the candy manufacturers discovered that the sweet tooth paid better than an aching back.

title: TV: Newsmen Examine Fordand Presson WNET
description: Behind the Lines, WNET/ 13's journalism review, returns to Channel 13 tonight at 8:30 (it will be carried nationally by the Public Broadcasting Service on Sunday) with a new weekly 30minute format and a new host, Harrison E. Salisbury. With Jeff Wheelwright as reporterproducer, the first installment offers The Honeymoon Is Over, an examination of the press and its handling of President Ford.

title: BOSTON JUDGE BIDS BUSING BE MINIMAL
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30 (UPDFedleral Judge W. Arthur Garrity issued his order in final form today to desegregate Boston public schools by next fall and told the School Committee that integration should be achieved with minimal busing.

title: ABC Delays Ford Film, Cites Election
description: A tour with President Ford of the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md.,which was filmed last weekend as an epicode of ABC TV's The Reasoner Report, has been withheld from broadcast this Saturday on the ground that its political overtones might be considered an influence on Tuesday's elections.

title: Magruder Says His Role In CoverUp Drew Praise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Jeb Stuart Magruder testified at the Watergate coverup trial today that he was informed in the summer of 1972 that President Richard M. Nixon was pleased with his efforts to keep the truth about Watergate from coming out.

title: Meredith Loses Election Bid
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 30A threejudge Federal court accused James Meredith today of trying to abuse state election procedures and denied a petition to place his name on the ballot in the fourth Congressional District race. The panel ruled that Mr. Meredith, a civil rights figure, had tried to confuse voters by first running in the June Democratic primary and then pulling out of a runoff to run as an independent.

title: Personal Finance
description: Residents of urban areas who may have difficulty in getting property insurance or who may be unable to get it at all have an option of which few are awareFederal crime insurance.

title: More Sectors of Economy Are Pinched by Recession
description: The recession, which many economists, businessmen and labor leaders expect to be the longest and harshest in 30 years, is biting into more and more sectors of the economy.

title: Alioto Sets Example on Public Transit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30Mayor Joseph L. Alioto rode a bus today. In fact, he rode two buses, two trolleys, one subway and one cable car, all in an effort to publicize the merits of public transportation and save energy.

title: Chess: Karpov Drives a Third Nail Into Korchnoi's Catafalque
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30Viktor Korchnoi, driving his position beyond its capacity to deliver, blundered in time pressure and collapsed in defeat in the 17th game of his final Candidates Match for the world championship with Anatoly Karpov here in Tchaikowsky Hall tonight.

title: EnergyPolicy Search: Sawhill vs. Morton
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The departure yesterday of John C. Sawhill as Federal Energy Administrator was another episode in the Government's search for a coherent energy policy and a workable mechanism for resolving energy issues. Mr. Sawhill, an economist and businessman who joined the Government 18 months ago, was forced by President Ford to resign, and the consensus here is that Mr. Sawhill is out because Rogers C. B. Morton, the Secretary of the Interior, is in. As chairman of the new Energy Resources Council, Mr. Morton is the overall boss of our national energy program, as Mr. Ford said to Congress Oct. 8.

title: Jack o'Lantern Riot Is a Yearly Display At an Upstate Farm
description: CAMDEN, N. Y.At first it looks like another roadside stand but then the hundreds of glowing jack o' lanterns come into view and visitors know they have arrived at Robert and Verda Will's CackleBerry Farm, a pumpkin lover's paradise. Thousands of the orangeyellow fruit, representing Halloween to many people, cover the hillside behind the fruit stand.

title: PHILADELPHIA BLAZE ENGULFS WAREHOUSE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (AP) A sevenalarm fire engulfed a warehouse along the Delaware River tonight and threatened for a time to spread to nearby railroad terminal, the authorities said.

title: The Politics Of Hunger: II
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30Secretary of State Kissinger was explaining recently why the United States Government had been so slow to understand the world food problem. Until 1972, he said, we thought we had inexhaustible food surpluses and the fact that we have to shape our policy deliberately to relate ourselves to the rest of the world did not really arise until 1973.

title: Postel Served With a Writ As Publisher Seeks Damages
description: Robert I. Postel, a former City Councilman who lost a Democratic primary election on Monday for nomination to the Assembly in the 68th Assembly District on the Upper East Side, was served with legal papers in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday in a case arising from his alleged interference with the distribution of a weekly newspaper that backed his rival, Alexander B. Grannis.

title: New YorkDetroit Train Will Roll Again Today
description: Greeted by bands, politicians and sizable crowds at each stop, a special sevencar train crossed the state yesterday to herald the resumption of New YorkDetroit passenger service, starting today, and to plug the $250million railimprovement bond issue on Tuesday's ballot.

title: Contract Awards
description: Northwest Airlines, Inc., has purchased three 747F all freight jets from the Boeing Company. According to Northwest, the order is worth more than $90million. It brings to nine the number of 747F's sold by Boeing.

title: Palestinian Chief to Meet With Leaders Of Egypt, Syria and Jordan on Tactics
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 30Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that he would meet with the heads of state of Egypt, Syria and Jordan to coordinate Arab strategy on the military economic and political level. Two hours earlier, King Hassan of Morocco said that a meeting betwen Mr. Arafat and King Hussein would be held within 10 days.

title: State Poll Finds Voters Favor More Urban Aid
description: New York City's perennial complaint that it deserves more state aid than it receives has been found to elicit a surprising amount of sympathy among suburbanites competing for the same aid.

title: HUGH G. BERGEN
description: Hugh G. Bergen, a lawyer who had been president of the Nassau and Queens Counties Bar Associations, died yesterday at his home, 5 Robbins Drive, East Williston, L. I. He was 75 years old.

title: California Standard Net Gained 32.3% in Quarter
description: The Standard Oil Company of California, the last of the major oil companies to report the thirdquarter, announced yesterday a 32.3 per cent advance in profits in the period, giving the industry an almost perfect srecord of strongand often harply higherearnings.

title: Wilson Will Visit the U.S. For Talks With Ford Soon
description: LONDON, Oct. 30 (Reuters)Prime Minister Harold Wilson will soon visit the United States for talks with President Ford, Foreign Secretary James Callaghan announced today in Parliament.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Scoring touchdowns and piling up lots of yardage are two things Bill Martin does better than the average high school running back.

title: Islanders Tie Rangers, 11
description: Equality finally wended its way into the RangerIslander hockey rivalry last night as the intercounty rivals skated to a 11 tie at Madison Square Garden. When Bob Nystrom of the Islanders scored with a littie more than 2 minutes left, the goal ended more than two years of Islander futility at the Garden during Which they had not won or tied in six games.

title: SUCREST TO LIFT PRICES ON SUGAR
description: The Sucrest Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase prices by $3.85 per 100 pounds on industrial sugar, effective at the close of business tomorrow.

title: COYERUP CHARGED TO SCHOOL BOARD
description: The chairman of the City Council's. Education Committee charged yesterday that the central Board of Education had known about and had Covered up mismanagement and outandout stealing of money in some community school districts in the city.

title: TOP BANK ADOPTS RESTRAINT POLICY
description: The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, has adopted a formal policy of restraint that will make borrowing from it more difficult and that may slow its growth. The move came at a time of astonishingly rapid growth for the bank.

title: KISSINGER PLANS A SALVAGE VISIT TO MIDDLE EAST
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Oct. 30 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he did not believe the decisions of the Rabat summit meeting of Arab leaders had foreclosed further ArabIsraeli negotiations, but he said he would have to hold urgent consultations with both sides to see how best to proceed.

title: Wrigley Sets Extra Payout
description: The William Wrigley Jr. Company announced in Chicago yesterday that it would pay an extra dividend of 60 cents per share on common stock payable Dec. 2 to shareholders of record Nov. 15. Last year the company paid an extra dividend of 75 cents. At the same time, Wrigley announced that it would pay regular monthly dividends of 20 cents per common share on Dec. 2, Jan. 2 and Feb. 1, to shareholders of record Nov. 15, Dec. 16 and Jan. 15, respectively.

title: New White House Role On Release of Photos
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)A new White House policy on the release of Presidential photographs taken by White House photographers was announced today after numerous complaints from the news media.

title: Fraud Is Charged to 5 in Deal Involving Mexican Investments
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 30Indictments by a Nassau County grand jury of five persons and two companies in what was described as a major securities fraud involving $4million and 300 investors was announced here today by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: KISSINGER PLANS A SALVAGE VISIT TO MIDDLE EAST
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Oct. 30 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he did not believe the decisions of the Rabat summit meeting of Arab leaders had foreclosed further ArabIsraeli negotiations, but he said he would have to hold urgent consultations with both sides to see how best to proceed.

title: Korff Says Nixon Fund Is $99,428 in the Red
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. (AP)  Rabbi Baruch Korff says his fund to pay former President Richard M. Nixon's legal fees is $99,428 in the red, with more bills expected.

title: Israeli Craft Shell Camp in Lebanon Used by Refugees
description: A squadron of Israeli gunboats bombarded a Palestinian refugee camp of Rashidiyeh in southern Lebanon today, just hours after the Lebanese Army said it had repulsed an Israeli ground patrol in the same area.

title: Thieu Ousts 3 Army Aides in Seeming Bow to Protests
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 31,Apparently bowing to opposition pressure, President Nguyen Van Thieu last night announced the transfer of three powerful military commanders from their posts.

title: Boyden Hanover Feared in Messenger
Utility Rate Bid Expected
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP)Robert Meade, chairman of the state Department of Public Utilities, said today that Massachusetts utility companies were expected to request rate increases totaling $200million to $300million next month. Mr. Meade also said in an interview that Massachusetts consumers would be paying considerably more for utilities by 1976 than they are now, primarily because of inflation.

title: Hondurans' Plight Grim But the Aid Gets Through
description: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras, Oct. 25Five weeks a hurricane devastated large areas of this country, rivers along the northern coast are still swollen, the land saturated and 30,000 people are reported to be isolated floodwaters and mud.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Kuh Says Judges Imperil Public Through Leniency
description: Richard H. Kuh, the Manhattan District Attorney, yesterday charged that all 35 State Supreme Court justices, who hear his office's cases, were so lenient in sentencing convicted felons that city residents had been endangered unnecessarily.

title: HAN JORDAN
description: Henrich (Han) Jordan, retired executive vice president of the Slavenburg Corporation, a commercial financing house, died Sunday at United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. He was 72 and lived at the Orienta Point Apartments, Mamaroneck.

title: Greyhound Is Fined $5,000 for '72 Gifts In Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI)  The Greyhound Corporation was fined $5,000 today for making illegal corporate campaign contributions to the 1972 Premdential campaigns of President Nixon and Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota.

title: Expectations of Further Drops in Interest Rate Are Held a Factor
description: The stock market scored its second sizable consecutive advance yesterday, in much heavier trading, although some late profit taking reduced its earlier gains.

title: JOHN E. BENNETT
description: John E. Bennett, executive vice president of Volk & Huxley, Inc., advertising typographers, died Tuesday at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 58 years old and lived at Huntington Station, L.I.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Dozens of detectives and policemen in Paterson pressed the search for three men seen running out of the St. Boniface Church rectory Tuesday just after the Rev. Francis Aiden English, 79 years old, was beaten to death during an 8 A.M. robbery there. The investigation focused on the search for a 1968 or 1969 yellow Lincoln Continental Mark III with a black vinyl top and a trunkmounted wheel cover, the apparent getaway car, which was reportedly driven away by a fourth man. In addition, detectives circulated throughout the church neighborhood and worked match prints lifted from the rectory with those of convicted criminals.

title: GAMBLER INDICTED IN A GRAFT INQUIRY
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 30A special grand jury investigating alleged corruption in the Mount Vernon Police Department dicted a reputed gambler today on a perjury charge after he had denied knowledge of conversations recorded by underagents.

title: Study Denounces NursingHome Deals As Costing State and Medicaid Millions
description: A gigantic Monopoly game in which nursing homes are sold back and forth to inflate their costs at the expense of Medicaid has been denounced in an official report to the New York State Public Health Council.

title: Use of Surgical Clip Is Defended by Inventor
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 30 (AP)Ninetyfive per cent of the clips surgically implanted to trap blood clots are not followed by the bleeding and shock that has afflicted former President Richard M. Nixon, says the clip's inventor.

title: FORD IS EXPECTED TO SHIFT CABINET
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30In the weeks between next Tuesday's election and the first of the year, President Ford will make over his Cabinet, replacing some but not all of the Nixon appointees, according to White House officials and others close to the President.

title: SUGAR FUTURES RISE 1C A POUND
description: World sugar futures contracts rose the 1centapound limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchangeas they have each day this week. Each day a record high has been set for the March delivery. Yesterday is was 44.97 cents a pound.

title: Service of the France Formally Terminated
description: PARTS, Get: 30 (AP)The crew of the 66,347ton France was paid off today and the liner was formally taken out of service.

title: RABIN PESSIMISTIC ON ARABS' STANCE
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 30Premier Yitzhak Rabin said today that the actions taken by Arab leaders at their conference in Rabat bode no good and may possibly call for significant conclusions regarding our policy.

title: Textile Workers End a 25Day Strike
description: The majority of textile and dye workers in the metropolitan area will return to work today, ending a 25day strike that has virtually shut down the industry in the area.

title: COVERUP CHARGED TO SCHOOL BOAR
description: The chairman of the City Council's Education Committee charged yesterday that the central Board of Education had known about and had coverec up mismanagement and outandout stealing of money in some community school districts in the city.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1974

title: $140,923 Insurance Said to Be the Total Paid to Kopechnes
description: BOSTON, Oct 30 (AP)Auto insurance held by Senator Edward M. Kennedy paid $140,923 to Mary Jo. Kopechne's parents After she died in a 1969 crash in the Senator's car at Chappaquiddick.

title: Earnings Loss Expected
description: Loew's, Inc., said yesterday that it was deferring action in completing a tender offer for 20 million shares of the CNA Financial Corporation because of CNA's losses.

title: Applauding Crowds Greet Wilson on Tour of Nassau
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 30With a retinue of Republican officeholders at his side, error Wilson stormed through Nassau County today imploring large and friendly crowds of supporters not to let Watergate and the pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon deter them from backing the G.O.P. ticket.

title: Rockefeller Link to Book Described to House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Members of the House Judiciary Committee, meeting in closed session, heard details today of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's inquiry into the financing of a biography of Arthur J. Goldberg by Laurance S. Rockefeller, the brother of Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: City Market Basket Increases 52 Cents to $63.89 in a Week
description: The cost of feeding a family of four went up eighttenths of a per cent last week in New York City, compared with the week before. The City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday that its 39item Market Basket cost $63.89, up 52 cents.

title: Bank Lifts Passbook Rate
description: The interest rate on passbook savings accounts at the EuropeanAmerican Bank and Trust Company will be increased to 5 per cent from 4 per cent, effective tomorrow, the bank nnounced yesterday. EuropeanAmerican on Oct. 8 took over the branch network of the Franklin National Bank, which was then declared insolvent.

title: MRS. DOUGLAS FREEMAN
description: Inez Goddin Freeman, widow of Douglas Southall Freeman, the historian and Pulitzer Prizewinning biographer, died yesterday at her home in Richmond. She was 83 years old.

title: A Public Offering of New Notes and Bonds Is Set for Next Week
description: The Treasury, disclosing plans for its quarterly refunding cycle, said yesterday it would publicly offer $4.85billion of new notes and bonds next week. The nation's debt manager also stated it expects to raise approximately $4.5billion in additional cash prior to the Dec. 15 tax date, when it will receive large tax payments.

title: Polls Show Democrats Hold a Big Lead In Florida Governor and Senate Contests
description: TALLAHASSE, Fla, Oct. 30 Several Florida political reporters wrote last weekend that they could feel a small shift of voter sentiment toward underdog Republican candidates for both Governor and Senator in Florida.

title: SAKHAROV REPORTS SOVIET PRISON FAST
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, asserted today that an unknown number of inmates in two prison camps had staged a hunger strike to mark today as the day ofthe political prisoner.

title: Witness Again Says Phillips Was Home During Slayings
description: A witness repeated testimony yesterday that he had given at the first trial in State Supreme Court of William R. Phillips, a suspended police officer, that the defendant was at home decorating a Christmas tree with dollar bills on Christmas Eve, 1968.

title: TEACHER TESTIFIES ON WILLOWBROOK
description: A former teacher at the Willowbrook State School for the land Retarded on Staten Island testified in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday that it was virtually impossible to teach at the institution because of an environment that led to the mental and physical deterioration of the residents.

title: Six Division Titles On the Line in City
description: With six football games this weekend deciding division titles, the Public Schools Athletic League's new division setup is proving its merits. The following weekend's quarterfinal playoffs, however, may prove this systems' demerits. In Brooklyn, for instance, Boys High and Erasmus play for first place in their division tomorrow night at Boys. Each of these schools has strong athletic, traditions, but has fallen on hard times in football in the last several years. Now, playing in a division with John Jay, Wingate and Tilden, each has become moderately successful.

title: Two Are Killed in Ulster In Sniping and Car Blast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 30 (AP)Two men died today in another outbreak of the sectarian violence that has been plaguing Northern Ireland.

title: Early Mexican Frost Wipes Out Two Years of Grain Research
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30 (AP)An early frost appears to have wiped out two years of experiments at the grain research center of Dr. Norman E. Borlaug, the Iowaborn agronomist who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1970 for his development of highyield wheat and rice.

title: Battle Narrows on Casino Plan
description: TRENTON, Oct. 30  The casino gambling proposition in next Tuesday's referendum in New Jersey, initially regarded as an oddson favorite for approval, was reported in trouble here today.

title: 16 SEIZED IN SALE OF DRUGS BY RING
description: City and Federal officials said yesterday that undercover drug agents had smashed a major drug distribution network they say supplied about 30 per cent of the illegal heroin and cocaine sold in Brooklyn after shipment from Mexico and North Carolina.

title: Mondale in Jersey, Acts Like a Candidate
description: CRANFORD, N. J., Oct. 30With Congressional elections just one week away, Senator Walter F. Mondale is campaigning as if he were one of the candidates up for election.

title: Opera: Ballo Restaged
description: This is the season for restagings at the New York City Opera. It was only a few weeks ago that Don Giovanni had a facelift, after its disastrous entry two seasons ago. Tuesday night it was the turn of Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera, which received its premiere in 1971. Nobody was very happy about the sets and directions. The sets have been retained, but there is a new staging by David Hicks, and two new ?? in principal roles.

title: Terrorism or Liberation Struggle? Violence Begets Many New Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 30A few ageold nations, like China, seem to have existed since the dawn of history; others were born in the collapse of oncemighty empires and through civil war or revolution; and yet others have emerged through a painful process of violence by relatively small groups.

title: SPANISH RIGHTISTS TIGHTENING GRIP
description: MADRID, Oct. 30The dismissal yesterday of Pfo Cabanillas Gallas as Spain's Minister of Information and the resignation of Antonio Barrera de Iritno, the Minister of Finance, are expected to be followed by extensive toplevel changes that would leave the Government in predominantly rightist hands.

title: Lawyers Delay Own Cases To Attend CoverUp Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Lawyers of all specialties and ages have been coming to the coverup trial each day, taking time off from their own cases because, as Steven Wolf, a young lawyer from Philadelphia, put it, I don't feel like waiting 200 years for the next case like this.

title: Metropolian Briefs
description: Inmates of the branch Queens House of Detention, where four years ago rioting broke out over conditions there  an Outbreak that spread to fout other city jails are now pleading with the Department of Correction to spare the doomed prison.

title: Albanian Minister Ousted; Attitude on Moscow Cited
description: VIENNA, Oct. 30 (AP) Premier Mehmet Shehu of Albania said today that he has dismissed his Deputy Premier and Defense Minister, Beyir Balluku.

title: Discharge Permit
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agen cy has proposed to issue a temporary discharge permit to Microfab, Inc., of Haverhill, to dump waste water into the Merrimack River. The decision to issue the permit is tentative, pending public comment on the proposal.

title: State Poll Finds Voters Favor More Urban Aid
description: New York City's perennial complaint that it deserves more state aid than it receives has been found to elicit a surprising amount of sympathy among suburbanites competing for the same aid.

title: Driver Sentenced to Pray
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (Reuters)A woman driver was sentenced here to pray for the soul of a man who died when her car jumped a curb and struck him. Alice Siman, 32 years old, was told by Judge James DeVinne to pray two hours a week in a church of her choice for one year. She had originally been sentenced to six months imprisonment and fined $1,000 on a charge of vehicular homicide in the death of Stephen Zawada, of Cleveland.

title: Peter Paul to Cut Dividend
description: Peter Paul, Inc., announced yesterday in Naugatuck, Conn., that it would pay a reduced quarterly dividend of 20 cents per share of common stock. The quarterly dividend rate was previously 30 cents per share. The dividend is payable Dec. 1 to shareholders of record Nov. 15.

title: Politicians See Little Effect on Election
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Republican and Democratic politicans agreed today that former President Richard M. Nixon's grave illness was unlikely to change radically the outcome of Tuesday's elections.

title: WEST BERLINER WON'T SEE POPE
description: BERLIN, Oct. 30 Mayor Klaus Schtz of West Berlin said today that he had canceled a visit to Rome last weekend because Pope Paul VI had refused to receive him in the company of West Germany's Ambassador to the Holy See.

title: Teacher Seeks to Unseat A Confident Thompson
description: TRENTON, Oct. 30Representative Frank Thompson Jr. of New Jersey's Fourth Congressional District has described his Republican opponent, Henry J. Keller, as a very attractive, really decent chap.

title: Design Negligence Alleged In Jet Crash Fatal to 346
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30A Federal District Court here was told yesterday that there was new evidence of negligence in aircraft design and development, and possibly of fraud, in connection with the crash of a DC10 airliner near Paris in March.

title: Mert & Phil, a Play About Mastectomy, at Beaumont
description: Anne Burr's play Mert & Phil, which last night opened the New York Shakespeare Festival's season at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, is a monstrously difficult play to be fair to. It is both repulsive and honest. The writing seems at times cheaply written caricature, but appears elsewhere to have been written in the author's Hood. It's a onedimensional play  it describes a woman and her situation. I have rarely disliked a play more or could, in general terms, recommend a play less.

title: Dutch Raid Prison Chapel And Rescue All Hostages
description: THE HAGUE, Thursday, Oct. 31In a surprise move this morning, Dutch marines and police units stormed a prison chapel and rescued 15 hostages who had been held since Saturday at the jail in Schveningen, just outside the Netherlands capital. The foul captors were arrested.

title: Girl Loses Little League Plea
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 30 (AP)A Federal appeals court turned down today a girl's request for ap injunction against Little League Baseball, Inc., because of alleged sex discrimination. The ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit came in the case of Carolyn Ann King, 13 years old, of Ypsilanti, Mich. The judges did not rule on whether Little League baseball's rule against girl players was constitutional, but said only that a lower court had been correct in dismissing the case for lack of jurisdiction.

title: Recital
description: Whenever a young pianist arrives to make his New York debut pulling a wagon full of awards won in international competitions, the reviewer braces himself for a special kind of recital. To win contests a pianist must first of all be an expert contestant, which generally Means playing the piano with the precision of a machine and being able to do it coolly, if not coldly, under terrible pressure.

title: Nets Overcome Stars, 95 to 91
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 30 Surviving their own premature slowdown and the prevailing prejudice of referees in favor of trailing teams, the New York Nets emerged with a 9591 victory over the Utah Stars tonight and completed a fourgame trip with a 31 wonlost record.

title: Bullard and Wilson Cleared Of Violating Election Law
description: ALBANY, Oct, 30 (UPI)The State Board of Elections said today there was no basis to support allegations that either Governor Wilson or T. David Bullard had violated the Election Law in connection with the latter's withdrawl from the Conservative party gubernatorial contest.

title: MACHINISTS RATIFY PACT WITH NATIONAL
description: MIAMI, Oct. 30 (AP)A machinists' strike that shut National Airlines for the last 108 days ended today, in time to put the nation's eighth largest carrier back in the air for a share of the winter season's lucrative New YorktoMiami trade.

title: PAN AM ARRANGES $125MILLION LOAN
description: Pan American World Airways, one of the country's most financially pressed corporalions, announced yesterday the arrangement of a new credit line with a group of 36 banks. the airline immediately borrowed $30million under the new credit line, which enables it to draw up to a total of $125million over the next year for working capital.

title: Palisades Park Aide Asks Vote for Rail Bond Issue
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Oct 30Peter Dudan, vice president of the Palisades Interstate Palk Commission, asked today for support for the rail transportation bond issue proposition because the parks should have rail service in making parks more available to city residents.

title: WEST VIRGINIA BLAST RIPS BOARD OFFICES
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 30 (AP)A blast was set off outside the Kanawha County Board of Education offices late tonight, just hours after a board, meeting on the county's emotionridden text book protest.

title: Text of Bulletin Issued by Nixon Doctors
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 30Following is the text of a bulletin issued at 9:30 A.M. today by Dr. John C. Lungren, cardiologist and personal physician to former President Richard M. Nixon, and Dr. Eldon Hickman, cardiovascular surgeon who headed Mr. Nixon's surgery team, at the Long Beach Memorial Hospital Medical Center:

title: NEWS INDEX
Market Place Stockholders Find Reports Wanting
description: Are annual reports effective? Perhaps. One man who has prepared many in the last 10 years comments: Never have so many worked so hard and spent so much to impress so few.

title: NAVY CONFIDENT ON CONTROL OF SEA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Adm. James L. Holloway 3d the new Chief of Naval Operations, expressed confidence to day that the United States Navy could maintain control of the seas in its rivalry with the Soviet navy.

title: 3 VETO U.N. OUSTER OF SOUTH AFRICANS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 30  The United States, Britain and France tonight vetoed a resolution in the Security Council to expel South Africa from the United Nations.

title: Hussein Says Arab Pact on Palestinians Won't Halt Jordan's Aid to West Bank
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 30 (Reuters)King Hussein told Palestinians on the occupied West Bank of Jordan tonight that the Arab leaders' declaration recognizing the Palestine Liberation Organization as the sole representative of of Palestinians would not change his feelings toward them

title: Paper Industry Expects Demand to Hold Steady
description: The demand for pulp and paper products is expected to remain at present levels for the next 15 months as a result of the downturn in the nation's economy, the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

title: Baptist Minister Indicted
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 30 (UPI) A Bpaist minister has been indicted by Federal grand jury on income tax evasion charges. The Rev. Amos Terrell, pastor of Lakeside Baptist church in Shreveport, surrendered to United States marshals yesterday and was released on recognizance bond of $1,000.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Most of the 8,000 textile and dye workers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut who have been on strike for 20 days will return to work today. Agreements on threeyear contracts have been reached with more than 120 the 150 companies involved by representatives of 5,000 6,000 employes. The new agreements call for a 31 per cent wage increase over a threeyear period, with a costofliving increase included.

title: Canadiens, Hawks in Tie, 44
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 30 (UPI) Cliff Koroll scored his second goal of the game early in the third period tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 44 tie with the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Mrs. Keating Says Her 2 Rivals Have Heads in Sand on Crime
description: Barbara Keating, the Conservative party candidate for United States Senator from New York, called yesterday for a new commitment to crime prevention and said that her two opponents have their heads in the sand on this issue.

title: PRIEST IS INDICTED IN WEST ST. ESCAPE
description: A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted a Roman Catholic priest and a correction officer on charges that they had played key roles in paving the way for seven major narcotics violators to escape on Sept. 22 from the Federal House of Detention on West Street. Six are still at large.

title: Gunman Gets $3,000
description: An armed man held up the First National City Bank branch at 753 Madison Avenue, at 65th Street, shortly before 3 P.M., and escaped in a waiting taxicab with $3,000, according to the police.

title: Exxon Sets Dividend Of $1.55 for Quarter
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, declared yesterday a quarterly cash dividend of $1.55 per share of common stock, payable Dec. 10 to shareholders of record Nov. 12.

title: U.S. to Hunt Violent Criminals Through Violations of Gun Law
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 (UPI)  The Federal Agency that regulates guns announced today a nationwide crackdown on violent crime in the streets, including terrorist groups.

title: Design Negligence Alleged In Jet Crash Fatal to 346
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30A Federal District Court here was told yesterday that there was new evidence of negligence in aircraft design and development, and possibly of fraud, in connection with the crash of a DC10 airliner near Paris in March.

title: Advertising
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 30  The sloppy sixties, when everyone could put up with halfbaked presentations or strategies in the advertising business are gone forever, David B. McCall, president of McCaffrey & McCall, told the final session of the Association of National Advertisers meeting here this morning.

title: Long Branch Gets Help of Mediator To Reopen Schools
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, Oct. 30The longdrawnout and fruitless contract negotiations between the Long Branch Board of Education and the unions representing its employes, who are now on strike, got off to a fresh and hopeful new start here at 3:30 P.M. today under mediation by the state's Public Employment Relations Committee.

title: Bridge: For Some Tournament Victors, Good News Travels Slowly
Notes on People.
description: After five years as Ambassador to Britain, Walter H. Annenberg left London yesterday by private jet, bound for his Philadelphia home. A spokesman said that the 66yearold publisher and businessman had planned to resign his post as early as last July, but delayed doing so until recently because of the events around that time in Washington.

title: Books of The Times
description: DOG SOLDIERS. By Robert Stone. 342 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $8.95.

title: G.O.P. in New Hampshire Given Edge In Races for Governor and Congress
description: CONCORD, N. H., Oct, 30He Kept His PromiseNo New Taxes, say the billboards promoting the reelection of Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. Smaller posters echo the New Hampshire Republicans' main theme: Fight Taxes! Keep Thomson.

title: Giants' Johnson Strives To Recapture His Stature
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 30It has been a year of agony and very little ecstasy for Ron Johnson, the Giants' running back who has been trying to make a comeback after suffering an ankle and knee injury in the third game of the season against Dallas. He is also trying to fight off suspicions that' maybe the New York Giants don't want him anymore.

title: DORIS K. PADLEY
description: Doris Kaene Padley, a retired member of the staff of Mount Holyoke College, died Monday at the Northern Westchester Hospital in mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 75 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Legislative Choices
description: It is a regrettable fact of political life in this predomimantly Democatic city, with its pockets of entrenched Republican control, that the disposition of most state legislative seats is decided in the primaries or in party caucuses. Nevertheless, next Tuesday's general election offers a number of lively contests whose outcome could have some significant bearing on the quality of the next Legislature, particularly on crucial legislative reform.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Accepting your own premise that the Critical issue of this gubernatorial campaign, is the capacity of the candidates to demonstrate leadership and imagination, it is incredible to me that The New York Times could have gone so far wrong as to endorse Mr. Carey. The Times editorial [Oct. 28] is governed neither by logic nor by reason.

title: Bullets Defeat Knicks
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 30 The undefeated Washington Bullets ran their winning streak to seven games tonight in a contest with the Knicks that began as a comedy of errors and wound up in a close, physical defensive struggle.

title: Oil Nations Invested $8Billion in the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (Reuters)The Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, Jack F. Bennett, said today that during the first nine months of this year oilexporting countries invested about $8billion in the United States.

title: Rep. Holtzman, One of Six Likely Winners in Brooklyn, Is a TV Personality in Her Second Race
description: Following Representative Elizabeth Holtzman around these days is a bit like trailing after Mary Tyler Moore. Every where she goes, people exclaim, I saw you on television!

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Japanese Tempura: Always Shrimp, Then Whatever You Like
description: OSAKA, JapanSomeone here observed recently that all the world's cuisines can be categorized according to their most characteristic cooking medium: Chinese cooking is based on oil, French on butterand Japanese on water.

title: Smith Toppled by Borg, Briton Defeats Mrs. King
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Oct. 30 (AP)Bjorn Borg, scoring with a spectacular forehand, defeated Stan Smith, 26, 6.4, 6.0, in the men's semifinal of the $40,000 World Invitation tennis tournament today.

title: Schmeling Is Surprised
description: HAMBURG, Germany, Oct. 30 (UPI)The former world boxing champion, Max Schmeling, said today that Muhammed Ali's knockout over George Foreman came as a giant surprise. Schmeling who won the title in 1930, added: The fight was not nice, but it proved once again technique defeats strength.

title: G. M. Will Reduce CostsSays It Has No Plans for More Price Rises
description: DETROIT, Oct. 30The Ford Motor Company announced today that its earnings for the third quarter of this year were off 50.1 per cent from the same quarter last year despite a massive effort by the company to capitalize on the smallcar market.

title: Bank Lifts Passbook Rate
description: The interest rate on passbook savings accounts at the EuropeanAmerican Bank and Trust Company will be increased to 5 per cent from 4 per cent, effective tomorrow, the bank nnounced yesterday. EuropeanAmerican on Oct. 8 took over the branch network of the Franklin National Bank, which was then declared insolvent.

title: 8 Food Outlets Are Listed As Health Code Violators
description: The Health Department has listed eight more foodhandling establishments as having violated the Health Code on a second inspection. The department warned that failure to pass a final inspection could result in closing orders.

title: Beef Producers Urge Ford To Restrict Meat Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) Spokesmen for livestock producers caught, in a costprice squeeze urged President Ford today to cut meat imports and give them a bigger share of the meat sold in American supermarkets.

title: F.B.I. Seeks Three In 4.3Million Theft, Two in West Indies
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP)Three more men were charged with burglary today in the theft of $4.3million from the Armored Express Corporation, believed to be the largest cash haul ever in the United States.

title: Music: Twin Pianists
description: The Contiguglia twins, Richard and John, have searched the twopiano repertory with some diligence, if not profit. Last night in Carnegie Hall they presented a program of twopiano music by Franz Liszt, building it around Liszt's transcription of the Beethoven Ninth Symphony. In some respects it turned out to be the strangest thing since Glenn Gould's recording of the Beethoven Fifth Symphony for solo piano, also in Liszt's transcription.

title: ROBERT J. KERR 2D, PRESERVATIONIST, 45
description: Robert Johnson Kerr 2d, a city planner and historic preservationist, died yesterday at his home in Salem, Mass:, where he had been recovering from a heart attack, He was 45 years old.

title: GALLUP POLL FINDS FORD APPROVAL UP
description: The latest Gallup poll shows an increase in public approval of the way President Ford is handling his job.

title: Nixon Is Facing a Large Medical Bill for Treatment
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 30 Former President Richard M. Nixonhis finances deteriorating, according to aidesfaces a large personal medical bill for his phlebitis treatment.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Classified pages distributed in metropolitan New York and adjacent territory.

title: More Sectors of Economy Are Pinched by Recession
description: The recession, which many economists, businessmen and labor leaders expect to be the longest and harshest in 30 years, is biting into more and more sectors of the economy.
